dialogue: Therapist: Hi, Jackie. ; Therapist: How are you doing today? ; Patient: I'm all right. ; Therapist: You're all right? ; Patient: Yeah, I've been having a rough time. ; Therapist: Having a rough time? ; Therapist: I understand there have been some difficulties lately that brought you into the agency. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Tell me what's going on. ; Patient: About a week ago, I went out with some friends to a boxing match. ; Patient: I didn't really want to go. ; Patient: I've never really been to one. ; Patient: It's not really something I'm interested in. ; Patient: But I went just to hang out with my friends and stuff. ; Patient: I watched a few fights, and this one fight, this guy, nothing was really happening. ; Patient: I wasn't really into it, but this guy got knocked out right in front of me. ; Patient: It was really close to the ring. ; Patient: He got knocked out right in front of me, fell right on his face, and I just saw him lifeless in front of me. ; Patient: And I just ever since then, it's happened the same. ; Patient: I had to leave right away. ; Patient: I just couldn't be there anymore. ; Therapist: What did you notice right away? ; Patient: One of the boxers was knocked out. ; Therapist: You saw that. ; Therapist: What did you notice right away that was happening? ; Patient: I just felt really, really scared. ; Patient: My heart started racing. ; Patient: I couldn't focus on what was going on around me. ; Patient: I just had to get out of there. ; Patient: So I don't even really know what happened to him, if he was okay or not. ; Patient: So I just couldn't handle how I was feeling, so I had to leave. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So you left, and the symptoms, they continued? ; Patient: Yeah, pretty much daily for the past week. ; Patient: I got home that night. ; Patient: I couldn't sleep. ; Patient: It took me almost all night to fall asleep. ; Patient: And then at work on Monday, I was having a lot of problems there. ; Therapist: What kind of problems? ; Patient: I couldn't focus when anyone was talking to me. ; Patient: I had a meeting on Tuesday, and my boss was talking for a while. ; Patient: I felt like I couldn't concentrate at all. ; Patient: Everything was just a blur around me. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Do you find that you're having memories of the incident at the boxing match that are intrusive? ; Patient: Yeah, I think about it a lot, pretty much all the time. ; Therapist: And it's bothersome for you? ; Patient: Yeah, if I'm at work trying to get some paperwork done or something, it just pops in my mind, and I can't make it go away. ; Therapist: And you try, but the memories stay there. ; Therapist: Any dreams related to the... ; Patient: No, I haven't really been dreaming about it. ; Patient: I'm barely sleeping, so... ; Therapist: Any times when you feel like you're reliving what you saw, like you're seeing it again? ; Patient: No, not really. ; Patient: I just think about it a lot. ; Therapist: You think about it? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Is anything reminding you of the boxing match, and then that's causing you to have symptoms? ; Patient: At the end of my meeting, people started clapping, you know, this big cheering, and that kind of made me feel really bad. ; Patient: Again, my heart was racing. ; Patient: I started sweating. ; Patient: It just kind of reminded me of being there, and I started thinking about it again. ; Patient: So things like that, you know, I pump up music when it comes on the radio, same kind of music they played there. ; Patient: That kind of makes me feel the same way. ; Patient: My heart starts to race. ; Patient: I just kind of feel like I need to get away from it. ; Therapist: Do you find yourself working to avoid, like, music that was similar? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I've been trying to really avoid the radio, because you never know what's going to come on on the radio. ; Patient: So I've been avoiding listening to music in case something like that happens and avoiding crowds. ; Therapist: Do you find that you've had any trouble remembering what happened? ; Patient: No, I can pretty vividly remember it. ; Therapist: It's pretty clear to you? ; Patient: Yeah, when I think about it. ; Therapist: Have you been irritable at all since the... ; Patient: Yeah, you know, just out of nowhere. ; Patient: If something doesn't go the way I want it to, I just kind of snap on people. ; Patient: And that's not like me at all. ; Patient: I usually am pretty easygoing. ; Patient: And, you know, people, my boyfriend, for instance, I yelled at him the other day for not putting the toilet paper on the roll. ; Patient: And that's not something I'd usually care about. ; Patient: It's just, it's not me. ; Therapist: How about your awareness level of what's around you? ; Therapist: Do you find that your awareness level has increased, that you're more aware? ; Patient: Um, it kind of depends. ; Patient: Sometimes I kind of feel like I'm in a daze and don't really know what's going on around me. ; Patient: But, um, I've been, um, one of the students that I work with, he popped out from behind the door, which he would do all the time. ; Patient: And, you know, typically I would laugh and think it was funny before, but he did it the other day and I just could not control myself afterwards. ; Patient: Like, I couldn't calm myself down. ; Patient: You know, I didn't think it was funny at all. ; Patient: It really, really scared me. ; Patient: And that went on for about 10, 15 minutes and I just, my heart was racing. ; Patient: I had to go take a walk. ; Patient: And it was just really hard to relax again after that. ; Therapist: So you feel like your reaction to that was stronger than it normally would have been? ; Patient: Definitely. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Have you used drugs or alcohol recently? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No. ; Therapist: Any medical problems? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No. ; Therapist: So Jackie, I'm going to get you in to see a counselor here at the agency if that's something that you're okay with. ; Patient: Yeah, I think that would be really helpful. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: Just take a couple days to get you on the, to get you in to see somebody, to get you on the schedule and get you in to see somebody. ; Therapist: And I'll get that arranged. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Thank you. ; Patient: Thanks.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name jackie ; Clinical Identifiers: Agency ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms ptsd chief complaints sleep disturbances intrusive thoughts irritable mood difficulty concentrating ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior; speech, mood  affect, thought, perception, cognitive functions, judgement and insight. ; Issues discussed in Current Session: 1 problem patient had traumatic event at a boxing match where a boxer was knocked out and appeared lifeless, leading to ongoing distress and symptoms consistent with post-traumatic stress disorder ptsd. He experiences physical symptoms such as a racing heart, sweating, and difficulty focusing. Intrusive thoughts, sleep disturbances, concentration and avoidance behaviors are also there. 2 willingness patient acknowledges the need for professional help and is open to seeing a counselor to address these issues. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Ptsd ; Action Plan : Referred to a counselor

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Jasmine, how you doing today? ; Patient: Hi, I'm okay. ; Therapist: You're okay? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: What's been going on? ; Patient: I just been dealing with so much anger that I'm having difficulty controlling it in my everyday life. ; Therapist: A lot of anger, huh? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Can you give me some examples? ; Patient: Like for instance, I go to the dry cleaner to pick up my fiance's uniforms and the lady had them like all bagged together and I mean I could have easily just asked her because she separate them but I began to yell causing a big commotion because I was so frustrated and angry. ; Patient: She actually was about to call the police to escort me out and I don't think I'm even allowed to go back to the dry cleaner anymore. ; Therapist: So quite a bit of anger. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: My neighbor's dog was barking late at night and I know my neighbors really can't control that but I get into a huge fight with my neighbor's argument. ; Patient: We're not speaking at the moment and it's just real uncomfortable but I mean I feel bad now that it's over with now that I thought about it and I just don't know why I was so upset that the dog was barking. ; Therapist: Alright, so from your perspective it doesn't seem to make sense why you got so angry. ; Patient: No, I just, it's been going on for some time now and I just get little things just, I just explode. ; Patient: So, I don't know why. ; Therapist: Did anything change around the time that the anger started? ; Patient: Nothing that I can really think of. ; Patient: Just when I'm overwhelmed and I have so much to do, I kind of just break down and just become extremely upset with everything around me. ; Therapist: Alright, so you're getting upset, you have some anger. ; Therapist: Any other time that you're feeling angry? ; Patient: When I go to the, I go work out at the kickboxing class, I'm like, I go all out. ; Patient: Like I use that as like a release. ; Patient: I'm punching the bags extremely hard. ; Patient: I actually had hurt my wrist last week. ; Patient: I just go all out in there and my trainer kind of notices like, are you okay? ; Patient: And I'm like, yeah, it's just relief kind of getting all the anger I had out. ; Therapist: Alright, so that experience for you, you feel like you're releasing more energy than maybe the other people in the kickboxing class. ; Patient: Yeah, way more. ; Therapist: Way more. ; Patient: I'm like loud, I'm sweating bullets, I'm just going all out, like extreme anger. ; Therapist: Alright, so the, in recent memory, your anger has increased, but it's still not really clear what's going on that's causing the anger. ; Patient: Not really, I just feel like frustrated, just have too much going on at the moment. ; Patient: So it's just kind of like, I just feel overwhelmed I guess and I take it out. ; Therapist: You feel busy, like in your daily life, like a lot of responsibilities? ; Patient: Yes, a whole lot. ; Therapist: What kind of things are you doing? ; Patient: Mainly, mainly take care of home, I don't work or anything. ; Patient: So I kind of just take care of home and you know with the kids and everything, it's just a lot. ; Therapist: Do you see a lot of responsibilities in the home? ; Patient: Yes, all of the responsibilities. ; Therapist: All of them? ; Patient: It feels like all of them. ; Therapist: What type of things are you doing? ; Patient: I'm cooking, I'm cleaning, now I have to iron all of my husband's uniforms and get everything ready for him. ; Patient: I have to make sure I cook breakfast, I have to make sure I pack lunch, I have to make sure I have dinner ready when come, I have to help the kids with their homework. ; Patient: I just have so much going on, like it's constant catering, catering, catering, catering. ; Patient: It feels like I just really don't get a break or any other help, it's just me doing everything. ; Therapist: You're doing everything? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: And has it always been this way? ; Patient: Not always, but it seems, it's been like this for some time. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Were you really just doing everything in the home? ; Patient: Everything. ; Therapist: I want to ask you, I want to ask you or mention a few words, right? ; Therapist: And I would like you to, if you're okay with this exercise, tell me the first thing that comes to mind. ; Therapist: And you can, when I say a word, you can offer several responses. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: But try not to invest a lot of thought into the response, but more just what occurs to you. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Does that make sense? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So the first word is home. ; Patient: Structure, responsibility, repetition. ; Therapist: Repetition. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Let me give you another word, relationship. ; Patient: Conflict, power struggle, disagreements. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Let me offer you another word. ; Therapist: Work. ; Patient: Independence. ; Patient: Freedom. ; Patient: Able to express creativity. ; Therapist: Good. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: And how about another word here? ; Therapist: Power. ; Patient: A constant struggle. ; Patient: Extremely controlling. ; Therapist: So do you see any themes in the words that you provided back? ; Patient: It just seems like everything is like really controlled and structured. ; Therapist: Controlled and structured. ; Therapist: What's the source of that control and structure? ; Therapist: Or is there a source of it? ; Patient: A lot of it may come from my fiancé, now that I'm thinking about it. ; Therapist: Tell me what you're thinking. ; Patient: Because I feel like he doesn't give me the freedom or the ability to do a lot of the things that I would like to do, like work. ; Patient: And I think he should help more with the kids around the house and do things. ; Patient: And I shouldn't have to do everything. ; Patient: And I feel like that's probably a lot of the... ; Patient: Why I'm so frustrated, because I feel that I don't have any help. ; Patient: It's like I'm single and I'm doing everything on my own. ; Patient: So that's probably where the bulk of my frustrations come from. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So as you're telling me this and you're explaining kind of that relationship with your fiancé, what are you feeling? ; Patient: I'm feeling angry and disappointed. ; Patient: Like I don't really know if I want to further anything because will it be like this forever? ; Patient: So I'm kind of just like angry and frustrated. ; Therapist: Is this similar to the anger that you've been experiencing recently, like at the dry cleaner and other places? ; Patient: It's far worse than that, but it's like... ; Patient: I think that's why I'm always so upset and angry. ; Therapist: So you're thinking that maybe that relationship or some part of that relationship is what's really causing the anger? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Because I feel alone at the same time completely. ; Patient: Like I'm not in a fair relationship. ; Patient: It's like I'm in a controlling one and I don't have freedom to do anything. ; Patient: I don't have help and it's just... it's weighing a lot of stress on me. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So is this... as you talk about this, do you feel like this is new information that you're kind of realizing something that you didn't realize before? ; Patient: Yeah, because honestly I kind of... I never really focused on that aspect of it. ; Patient: I kind of just thought that's the way it should go and I just thought I was angry because I just had bad days. ; Patient: I never really looked deep into it because I try so hard to make everything in my family right. ; Patient: So I kind of really don't pay attention. ; Patient: I kind of ignore it. ; Patient: But now that I'm thinking and putting out different things, it's going to spin into how I really feel. ; Therapist: So you feel this is kind of a big moment in terms of awareness? ; Patient: Definitely because I don't think I would have... like I said, I think I'm kind of... ; Patient: I try to hide it and really don't focus much on it because I want things to be perfect. ; Patient: So I think I kind of ignore it. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So maybe through this session you've developed more insight about what's contributing to the anger. ; Patient: Yeah, definitely because I would just go off for no reason at all and just later just think about like, why did I even do that? ; Therapist: But this source of anger, this relationship, you recognize this as maybe more causal or more contributing. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Whereas the other objects of your anger you weren't really sure. ; Patient: I wasn't sure at all why, but with that I definitely could see the reasons why I'm angry in my relationship. ; Therapist: Alright Jasmine, I feel like we've made some progress here and I'd like you to, between now and the next session, if you're comfortable with it, kind of reflect on what themes have maybe come to the surface, what information has maybe been revealed to you a little bit and we can pick up there and explore this further with the anger issue. ; Therapist: Does that sound like a good plan? ; Patient: Yeah, definitely. ; Patient: Definitely is a good plan. ; Therapist: Well I appreciate you coming in today and I'll see you in a week. ; Therapist: Okay, thank you.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name- jasmine; sex- female; marital status married ; Clinical Identifiers: Outpatient ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Increased anger 2. Irritability associated disturbances ; History: Patient finds it difficult to control her anger. There have been incidents like once she got into a huge argument with her neighbours because of their dog barking. She realised that it wasnt in their control but couldnt resist it. She also yelled at the lady on her regular dry cleaning shop which led to the involvement of police as well. She had the realisation that she could have handled it in a very polite way. Patient was having a difficulty controlling her anger and had sudden outbursts of it. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Thought- content frustration due to household chores; affect- irritable; insight- grade 4 ; Psychotherapy Type: Psychoadynamic therapy ; Psychotherapy Technique : Free association ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patient has been experiencing increased anger than usual and finds it difficult to control. She has ended up facing social conflicts as well. She also gets irritated frequently which leads to her anger outbursts. ; Reflections by the therapist: Patient had been feelings restricted and controlled by her husband. She feels that her husband doesnt participate in her household chores and help with kids which makes her do all the work. She has been holding on to pent up frustration on husband which was being displaced on others. ; Action Plan : Client has been asked to reflect on more incidents to identify the themes and patterns leading to her anger. ; Next session details: After 1 week

dialogue: Therapist: Hi, Sherry ; Therapist: How are you doing today? ; Patient: I've been better. ; Therapist: You've been better? ; Therapist: I understand you haven't been feeling so well lately. ; Patient: I haven't. ; Therapist: Can you tell me about that? ; Patient: Yeah, I think I've been depressed. ; Therapist: Been depressed? ; Patient: For about two months. ; Patient: It's been getting worse and that's why I'm here. ; Patient: I haven't been sleeping very well. ; Patient: I haven't had very much of an appetite. ; Patient: I haven't been eating very well. ; Patient: Last couple of months, ; Patient: I've lost a bit of weight from it. ; Patient: I'm tired all the time. ; Therapist: Tired all the time? ; Therapist: Do you find you have low energy? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And you say this has been going on for a couple months? ; Patient: Yeah, for about two months. ; Therapist: Did anything major happen that you think might have brought this on? ; Patient: Well, I mean, a big thing that happened between five and six months ago was my cat died. ; Therapist: Sorry to hear that. ; Patient: I miss him a lot, but I was sad for a little bit. ; Patient: I'll have days where I miss him, but the last two months have been nothing like what I felt when he died. ; Therapist: The last two months, the symptoms have been more severe or less severe? ; Patient: More severe. ; Therapist: More severe. ; Therapist: So your cat passed away six months ago? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And these symptoms you've had for the last two months? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So you're not sure if they're really related? ; Patient: Yeah, I don't know. ; Patient: Like, I do miss my cat, but... ; Therapist: Do you think about your cat most days? ; Therapist: How often? ; Patient: No, just, I would say, you know, a couple times a week it will hit me that, like, he's gone because he's not there. ; Patient: I'll think about him, but, you know, I'll have bad days without thinking about missing him. ; Patient: So I don't know if it's that. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: I'm going to ask you some other questions related to depression, if that's okay. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Have you noticed any change in your interest in seeking fun or pleasure, like in how you approach pleasurable activities? ; Patient: I mean, I feel like I'm still trying to have fun, you know, like I'll still, like I know what I like to do and I'll try to do those things. ; Therapist: What types of things do you still try to do? ; Patient: I like going out to dinner with my sister and I like reading books and watching movies, so I'll try to do that and enjoy it. ; Patient: Sometimes it's hard for me to concentrate when I'm reading or watching a movie, like I'll get distracted, but I still try. ; Therapist: You still try? ; Patient: Uh-huh. ; Therapist: Do you ever feel restless or kind of the opposite of that, like slowed down, like you can't move as fast as you want to? ; Patient: Yeah, I mean, I have noticed that like as, you know, the last couple months, like at work, it will be hard for me. ; Patient: It just feels like time is going so slowly and I just like, I want it, like almost like I'm in a dream and like I can't move. ; Patient: It's weird. ; Therapist: So you feel slowed down? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Any feelings of worthlessness? ; Patient: I mean, yeah. ; Therapist: Can you tell me about that? ; Patient: Um, you know, I just don't think that anyone really cares about what happens to me. ; Therapist: How about your ability to concentrate? ; Therapist: Any changes there over the last two months? ; Patient: Yeah, like it's harder for me to like pay attention to movies and stuff and at work it's, I don't know if it's because I'm tired or what, but it's hard for me to pay attention to the projects I'm supposed to be working on and I have noticed, yes. ; Therapist: Do you have any thoughts related to death or dying? ; Patient: Not really. ; Therapist: No? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Any drug or alcohol use? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Medical conditions? ; Patient: None. ; Therapist: Do you ever see or hear things other people can't see or hear? ; Patient: Not recently, no. ; Therapist: Not recently? ; Therapist: How about before that? ; Patient: Well, years ago I was hospitalized, but it was because my neighbors said that I was like throwing things and saying things that I didn't say like about the government, but I haven't had anything like that happen for years. ; Therapist: So this is years ago you were hospitalized. ; Therapist: Did they tell you anything about that hospitalization? ; Therapist: Like exactly why? ; Patient: I don't remember. ; Therapist: You don't remember it? ; Therapist: Did you feel depressed back then like you do now? ; Patient: Uh, I think maybe. ; Patient: I think probably some of the same things. ; Patient: I don't know. ; Therapist: It sounds like it's not clear in your memory what happened. ; Patient: No. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Have you ever had a period of time where you're too happy, where you had like a lot of energy and just couldn't stop moving? ; Therapist: Nothing like that? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: Alright, Sherry. ; Therapist: I'm going to get you in to see a counselor. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: It'll just take you a couple days for us to get you in to see somebody and it's my hope that they can help you. ; Therapist: I want to thank you for answering these questions. ; Therapist: This has been helpful. ; Patient: Thank you.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name sherry ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Patient is seen by a psychiatrist. ; Past Session Information: Follow-up session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symtoms depression chief complaints 1 loss of appetite 2 weight loss 3 fatigue 4 difficulty in sleeping. 5 worthlessness 6 dizzy  slowing down ; History: Medical history patient has a past hospitalisation related to the behavior described by neighbours. Past history death of his cat around six months ago. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Appearance and behaviour low in energy; speech patients is giving short answers which indicates his tiredness and sadness; mood  affect depressed mood; thought, perception thoughts are foggy and a perception of worthlessness. Cognitive functions his memory seems affected as it was difficult for him to recall past details of hospitalisation and feels that nobody cares for him; judgement and insight his insight is intact and judgement is poor. ; Psychotherapy Type: Nil ; Psychotherapy Technique : Nil ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: There are few issues discussed in the session 1. Depressed mood patient has symptoms of depression for the past two months, including loss of appetite, weight loss, fatigue, and difficulty sleeping. They also express feelings of worthlessness and a sense of time passing slowly. A recent death of his cat is one of the reasons of his depressed mood. 2. Lack of concentration and interest  difficulty concentrating on activities which he used to enjoy, such as reading and watching movies. Noticed slowed down at work and struggling to focus on tasks. 3. Feeling of worthlessness feels worthlessness and a sense of belief that people do not care about him. 4. Hospitalisation patient has a history of hospitalisation in past once related to his behavior described by neighbours, pertaining to mental health concerns. 5. Action plan psychiatrist recommends counseling to address his depressive symptoms and provide support and intervention. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Depression ; Action Plan : Referred to a counselor for support and further interventions. ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Hi George. How you doing today? ; Patient: I'm okay. ; Therapist: You're okay? ; Patient: I'm okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: I'd like to give you a test that measures your thinking and memory. ; Therapist: Is that okay with you? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: I'm going to ask you a few questions and if you could answer as best as you can, I would appreciate it. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: What's today's date? ; Patient: It's today. ; Patient: Today is the 15th. ; Therapist: The 15th? ; Therapist: What is today's year? ; Patient: Uh, 15. ; Therapist: What is the month? ; Patient: June. ; Therapist: And what day is today? ; Patient: It's Thursday. ; Therapist: Can you also tell me what season it is? ; Patient: It's hot. ; Patient: It's summer. ; Therapist: Can you tell me the name of the building that we're in right now? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: What floor are we on? ; Patient: The floor's hard. ; Therapist: What city are we in? ; Patient: New York. ; Therapist: What county are we in? ; Patient: Blue Castle. ; Therapist: And what state are we in? ; Patient: Pennsylvania. ; Therapist: George, I'm going to ask you to say some objects back to me. ; Therapist: Repeat some objects back to me. ; Therapist: They are ball, flag, and tree. ; Therapist: Can you repeat those back to me? ; Patient: Ball, flower, plant. ; Therapist: I would like you to begin with the number 100 and count backward by 7. ; Therapist: I'll let you know when to stop. ; Therapist: Go ahead. ; Patient: 93 ; Patient: 7 ; Patient: 14 ; Patient: 21 ; Patient: 28 ; Patient: 34 ; Therapist: That's good, George. ; Therapist: Thank you. ; Therapist: I would like you to spell the word 'world' backwards. ; Patient: The world. ; Patient: Spell the world. ; Patient: W-O-R-L-D. ; Therapist: Can you recall the three items that I mentioned to you a minute ago? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: George, can you tell me what this is? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: What is it? ; Patient: It's a watch. ; Therapist: Can you tell me what this is? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: What's that? ; Patient: It's a pencil. ; Therapist: I'm going to say a phrase to you and I'd like you to repeat it back to me. ; Therapist: The phrase is, no ifs, ands, or buts. ; Patient: No ifs, ands, or buts. ; Therapist: George, are you right-handed or left-handed? ; Patient: Right-handed. ; Therapist: I'd like you to take this paper and your right hand, fold the paper in half, and put the paper on the floor. ; Therapist: Thank you. ; Therapist: I'm going to hold this sheet of paper that has some instructions written on it that I'm going to point to. ; Therapist: I'd like you to follow the instructions that I'm pointing to. ; Therapist: Thank you. ; Therapist: George, on the left side of your chair you'll find a clipboard. ; Therapist: Could you put that up? ; Therapist: Should be a pen on there. ; Therapist: On the bottom section of that piece of paper, can you write a sentence for me? ; Therapist: Thank you, George. ; Therapist: Now on the same piece of paper you'll see an image up the top. ; Therapist: Can you see that? ; Therapist: Could you copy that for me on the bottom section? ; Therapist: Thank you. ; Therapist: Thank you. ; Therapist: George, this has been helpful. ; Therapist: I appreciate you participating. ; Patient: Okay.

Therapist: Okay, so I noticed on your diary card that you have, that you did cut. ; Patient: Yep. ; Therapist: Okay, so let's talk about that a little bit. ; Therapist: What day did that happen on? ; Patient: Tuesday. ; Therapist: Tuesday? ; Therapist: Okay, so where were you on Tuesday when you first had the thought that you wanted to cut? ; Patient: Where I usually always am at school. ; Patient: I was at my locker. ; Patient: And that stupid girl. ; Therapist: What was going on at your locker? ; Patient: Melanie was talking about Tim. ; Patient: My Tim. ; Patient: My boyfriend. ; Patient: And I know it was my Tim she was talking about. ; Patient: I just wanted to punch her so bad. ; Therapist: Okay, so you were standing at your locker and you heard somebody say something about Tim that you didn't want to hear. ; Patient: Yeah, she was talking about him and he didn't text me the night before. ; Patient: So who knows what's going on. ; Therapist: What were you feeling right then? ; Patient: So angry. ; Patient: So angry. ; Therapist: On a scale of one to ten, how angry would you say you were? ; Patient: Like a nine. ; Therapist: Pretty angry then. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: What did you do right then? ; Therapist: You were at your locker. ; Therapist: What's the next thing you did after you heard it? ; Patient: Next thing I did, I slammed my locker. ; Patient: Then I walked down to the gym. ; Patient: But what I wanted to do was push her or punch her. ; Therapist: So I know that the gym is usually the place where you cut. ; Therapist: Because you said you can go behind the bleachers. ; Therapist: People don't usually see you there. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay, so where between hearing the person talking about Tim and going to the gym, where did you decide to cut? ; Therapist: Because you said you were also feeling like punching somebody. ; Therapist: There must have been a point where you decided, I'm going to cut. ; Patient: I think it was right after I slammed my locker and thought, I can't punch her. ; Patient: I'm going to get in trouble. ; Patient: I'm going to go cut. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So that was when you decided to cut. ; Therapist: You went down to the gym. ; Therapist: What happened when you got there? ; Patient: Well, nobody was there because gym class isn't in the morning. ; Patient: So I knew that nobody was going to come in the gym. ; Patient: So I went behind the bleachers. ; Therapist: What did you use to cut? ; Patient: The pencil that I have always used. ; Therapist: It's the same pencil as usual? ; Therapist: The one with the metal tip? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay, that was a pencil that you were saying that you were going to get rid of. ; Patient: Yeah, I know. ; Patient: It's just, it's my favorite pencil. ; Patient: I use it for school. ; Patient: And it's my favorite pencil. ; Therapist: Okay, so you still had the pencil. ; Therapist: You got under the bleachers. ; Therapist: You said you were feeling angry still. ; Therapist: Were you still on the scale of one to ten? ; Therapist: Where were you, when you got under the bleachers? ; Patient: I was still at like, I was still pretty high, maybe like an eight and a half though because I knew I was going to cut. ; Patient: So it like came down a little bit. ; Therapist: What were you thinking at that point? ; Patient: Well, I thought a couple things. ; Patient: I thought I'm glad I kept this pencil. ; Patient: And that I'm just so pissed that I just want to cut so badly. ; Therapist: So you have your pencil. ; Therapist: Where did you cut? ; Patient: On my leg. ; Therapist: How many times? ; Patient: Three. ; Therapist: How deep did you cut? ; Therapist: Was it deep enough that you needed a band-aid? ; Therapist: Did you need more than a band-aid? ; Patient: No, I mean, I guess I could have used a band-aid, but I mean, whatever. ; Therapist: But it wasn't so deep that you needed something more? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Right after you cut, where were you on the scale of one to ten with your anger? ; Patient: Like a three. ; Therapist: Three? ; Therapist: What were you thinking right afterwards? ; Patient: That felt good. ; Patient: I feel better. ; Patient: And I'm going to have to talk to Michelle about this. ; Therapist: Did that feeling last you for the rest of the day? ; Patient: The feeling better? ; Patient: Um, yeah, for the most part. ; Patient: Yeah, it did. ; Therapist: Okay, so that's what happened right afterwards. ; Therapist: Later in the day, what were you thinking about the cutting? ; Patient: Well, I kind of forgot about it. ; Patient: But then I just started thinking about it again right before bed. ; Patient: And just feeling really guilty that I cut. ; Patient: Because I knew I was going to have to talk about it with you. ; Patient: And I just, I mean, in the night time I just constantly think about what happened that day and then what the next day is going to be like. ; Patient: I mean, you know, it's usually a pretty hard time. ; Therapist: I know night is a really difficult time for you. ; Patient: It is, yeah. ; Therapist: Everything seems worse at night. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So you were thinking back on it then and you were feeling guilty. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Sounds like you weren't feeling so good about it then as you were in the afternoon. ; Patient: No. ; Patient: That always seems to happen. ; Therapist: Sounds like for you cutting works for a little while, but it doesn't last. ; Patient: Yeah, I guess so. ; Therapist: I know you've also been working on doing less cutting. ; Patient: I've been doing pretty good. ; Therapist: You have. ; Therapist: You've been working really hard. ; Therapist: I'm just wondering if we can find something that might last, that you can feel good about later that you won't have those guilty feelings. ; Patient: Yeah, maybe. ; Patient: I mean, those guilty feelings really suck. ; Therapist: Okay, so with the cutting, it sounds like the point where you decided to cut at your locker. ; Therapist: What triggered it was hearing that girl talking about Tim. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Because she's stupid. ; Therapist: Okay, it sounds like you're also already having a pretty bad day. ; Therapist: You said you hadn't called, you hadn't been texting as much, and that was on your mind. ; Patient: Yeah, that's right. ; Therapist: So I'm wondering if at that point, if we can think of two things that you can try differently next time instead of the cutting. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: I'll bring that anger from a nine down a little bit. ; Patient: It's not going to bring it down all the way to a three though. ; Patient: I'll tell you that much. ; Therapist: It might not, but it'll bring it down a little bit. ; Therapist: Maybe each thing you try brings it down a little bit more. ; Patient: All right. ; Therapist: Maybe there'll be things you'll feel good about later. ; Therapist: You won't have to worry about that guilty feeling coming back. ; Patient: All right. ; Therapist: So the first thing is that pencil. ; Therapist: It sounds like it's comforting to have it. ; Patient: Yeah, it is. ; Therapist: But it also sounds like it's tempting. ; Therapist: What do you think about that? ; Patient: I mean, only if I am in the mood to cut, it's tempting. ; Therapist: Sounds like having that pencil is gonna make it harder to try other things. ; Therapist: And you've been talking about how you're really committed to not cutting anymore or cutting less. ; Patient: Yeah, I am. ; Therapist: Sounds like that pencil is standing in your way. ; Patient: Yeah, maybe. ; Therapist: What do you think about getting rid of the pencil this time? ; Therapist: Choosing a different favorite pencil that maybe you can't cut with. ; Patient: I mean, maybe, only if it can be like a really cool pencil. ; Therapist: That way you can still have something that can be your favorite, but which won't tempt you. ; Therapist: That'll make it easier to try the two things. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay, what do you think our first thing should be? ; Therapist: What do you think you can try? ; Therapist: You just heard somebody say something you don't wanna hear, you're feeling pretty angry. ; Therapist: What can you do in that moment? ; Patient: Well, what I do a lot at home when my mom's bothering me and saying stuff I don't wanna hear, I put my headphones on. ; Therapist: Do you have your headphones with you at school? ; Patient: Yeah, they actually, they let me keep them on in school. ; Therapist: Is that something you'd be willing to try next time? ; Patient: I think so, there's a few songs that usually help me, so I think so. ; Therapist: Okay, that sounds like a good one to try. ; Therapist: So we have headphones, we need to come up with one more. ; Therapist: What do you think you'd like to try? ; Patient: Well, I really like my teacher, Mrs. Eaton, so she seems to always kinda be there when I need to talk, and her room's kinda right down the hallway from my locker, in the same hallway, so I guess I could talk to her. ; Therapist: That sounds like a good option. ; Therapist: So that's our goal, is to keep pushing cutting further down the list, and to keep adding things that you're gonna try first, and you're right, that the first thing you try might not bring you all the way down to a two or a three, but it might bring you down a little bit, and each thing you try might bring you down just a little bit more, so you have to be willing to try a few things. ; Therapist: Can you do that? ; Patient: I can, but I really want a cooler pencil, though, like a cooler pencil, so I don't know, maybe we could go look for a pencil together? ; Therapist: I think that's a good idea. ; Patient: Okay, I'd like that. ; Therapist: Okay, thank you for answering all of my questions on this. ; Therapist: You did a great job with this chain, and I know it wasn't easy. ; Patient: Yeah, you're welcome. ; Therapist: Let's go look for that pencil.
summary: Patient Particulars : Sex female ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Follow -up ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms anger chief complaints 1 self - harm behaviors 2 inability to control anger ; History: Nil ; Crisis Markers: Self-harm tendencies ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior normal; speech aroused, mood  affect angry, thought negative; cognitive functions distorted, judgement poor ; Psychotherapy Type: Type cbt; mode individual. ; Psychotherapy Technique : Supportive, thought challenging, problem solving. ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: 1 problems therapist talked about her uncontrollable anger issue and self -harm behavior. 2 coping mechanisms explored ways to cope with intense emotions, such as anger, instead of resorting to self-harm, identified triggers and recognizing them, such as hearing upsetting comments, and understanding their role in escalating emotional distress. 3 seek help outside find supportive figures, like teachers or counsellors, in providing healthy options for expression and emotional support. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Anger issues and self-harm behavior. . ; Action Plan : Encouraged to proactive steps towards recovery, such as making decisions about removing triggers and seeking support. ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Hello, Alison. ; Therapist: How are you doing today? ; Patient: I'm good. ; Patient: How are you? ; Therapist: I'm doing well. ; Therapist: Thanks for asking. ; Therapist: I was hoping we could start today by beginning your treatment plan. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: I don't know if you remember from the first session that I had told you about, but I was hoping we could start today by beginning your treatment plan. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: I don't know if you remember from the first session that I had told you around session four that we would start your treatment plan and try to finish it around session five. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: So the treatment plan, I usually like the treatment plan to have two or three goals and each goal has some objectives. ; Therapist: So today I thought we'd just work on one goal. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: And I'll kind of get that down and then give you some time to think about it until next week and then kind of work on the other goals from there. ; Therapist: We'll finish off the treatment plan next week. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: That sounds good. ; Therapist: That sound okay to you? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: So the goal is kind of like your overarching goal for therapy in general. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Which I'm going to note too are specific tasks you can do that will help you achieve that goal. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So they're specific, they're measurable, and we hope they're achievable. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Does that make sense? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: So you have like an overall goal in mind for our counseling sessions? ; Patient: Yes. ; Patient: I would like to be able to kind of, I've been feeling a little depressed and I would really like to be able to reduce those, you know, the depression. ; Therapist: So reduce feelings of depression? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: That would be your goal. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Sounds like a good goal. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So what objectives, what tasks do you think that you could do that would help you to feel less depressed? ; Patient: I guess maybe some sort of physical activity, maybe like walking. ; Patient: I like to be outside, so maybe walking could be one. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Have you had a plan before where you've walked regularly? ; Patient: You know, I used to. ; Patient: I did. ; Patient: And it would give me some relief because I was able to clear my mind whenever I was walking. ; Patient: So yes, yes. ; Patient: I've had success with walking before. ; Therapist: So walking has worked before? ; Therapist: Yes. ; Therapist: And you've noticed that you're walking less since you've had a feelings of depression? ; Patient: I have been. ; Patient: I really haven't been doing too much of anything. ; Patient: I've just been kind of at home doing homework, stressing out over getting homework done because I'm back in school and it's been so stressful and overwhelming. ; Patient: Like I said, it's just kind of got me in this little funk, this depressed mood. ; Therapist: Well, since you're on the topic of homework, is there something you think you can do there? ; Therapist: You mentioned that it's stressful and overwhelming and that sounds like the type of feelings that are related to depression sometimes. ; Therapist: Do you find that kind of being stressed about the homework is? ; Patient: Yeah, because you know, it's so much work to be done and sometimes I get several assignments due and at the same time I find myself rushing to get assignments in and you know, it can just be a little daunting. ; Patient: It's just overwhelming sometimes. ; Patient: So yeah, and I don't know, maybe if I spaced it out and you know, took, you know, did some time management or something like that, I don't know, to kind of help me with that. ; Therapist: So you feel like maybe you're starting the homework late compared to when it's due? ; Patient: Yeah, yeah. ; Therapist: So that's where the feeling, maybe overwhelmed? ; Patient: Yes, I would say that. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So yeah, you're right, it sounds like this is just an organizational thing, right? ; Therapist: So if you can space it out where you kind of start your homework earlier and do it in small bits instead of waiting more or less the last minute, that would reduce, I mean likely I would think, reduce some of the stress and feelings of being overwhelmed. ; Patient: Yeah, I'm sure it would. ; Therapist: You sure would. ; Therapist: So you want to make that your second objective then? ; Therapist: So you have the walking. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And then you'll have trying to space out the homework. ; Patient: Yeah, okay. ; Patient: That sounds doable. ; Therapist: That sound good? ; Therapist: All right. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: So we have, so we have the walking and then spacing out the homework a little more. ; Therapist: So that's two objectives and both of those seem tied to the feelings, to the oppressive feelings that you're trying to eliminate. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: What other objectives might work? ; Patient: Let's see. ; Patient: You know, since I've been back in school, I just kind of, you know, I used to love to sing and I haven't done that in a while. ; Patient: And so maybe getting out and singing again and, you know, socializing with my friends that I used to sing with, maybe that could help because it would get me out of the house, you know. ; Therapist: Has that worked in the past for you? ; Patient: You know, it was something that I enjoyed doing. ; Patient: And right now I feel like I'm not doing any of the things that I've enjoyed doing because I've been so busy doing work, doing homework. ; Patient: So I think that would probably help. ; Therapist: So it's a good break from thinking about, stressing about, as you put it, the homework. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: For you. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: It has kind of a, I mean the singing part's fun for you it sounds like, but also there's a social component it seems like. ; Patient: Yes, it is. ; Patient: It is. ; Patient: So I enjoy, like I said, I enjoy singing and, you know, I enjoy the people that I would sing with and we would go and hang out together, go to different, you know, like jazz clubs or events, you know, different bands that we're playing at, you know, it would just be nice. ; Patient: It's fun. ; Patient: So I love music. ; Patient: So I love listening to it and I love, you know, singing. ; Patient: So making music. ; Patient: So that would be, I think that would be a good goal. ; Therapist: You seem to kind of light up a little when you talk about singing. ; Patient: Yes, I just love it. ; Patient: I enjoy doing it and I just haven't had a chance to do it lately. ; Therapist: So part of this is just making the time. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Good. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So we'll make that a third objective. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So we have walking and kind of organizing your homework differently. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: And singing and that socializing that accompanies that singing. ; Therapist: That's great. ; Therapist: So, three objectives is good. ; Therapist: I try to get to four if you have one. ; Therapist: Is there a fourth objective that you can think of, something else that you associated with not feeling depressed? ; Patient: Well, I used to absolutely love going to the beach and visiting with my aunt. ; Patient: And so that's two things. ; Patient: The beach. ; Patient: I love the beach because it's soothing. ; Patient: It's comforting. ; Patient: And my aunt, she's just such an awesome person. ; Patient: She's always pouring into me and I just love spending time with her. ; Therapist: And she lives down at the beach. ; Patient: Yes, she does. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So that's, it seems like a good objective too. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: So, you're suggesting maybe visiting her more often? ; Patient: Yes, again, just at home doing homework and I haven't gone to visit her. ; Patient: And the thing is she only lives like an hour away. ; Therapist: So it's not a huge ride. ; Patient: No, it's not. ; Patient: So that's like a little trip I can do on a Saturday. ; Patient: So I can take a break and go down there and spend some time with her. ; Patient: I think that would be helpful. ; Therapist: So again, kind of getting away from the school stressors and kind of just taking a break from it for a day. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: And then also spending time with somebody that you enjoy spending time with. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Good. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So I want to go through each one of these. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And make sure that we're kind of meeting all the criteria for an objective, which I think we can do. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: These are all specific, which is good. ; Therapist: Do you feel these are all achievable? ; Therapist: These are things you can do? ; Patient: I think so. ; Patient: Yes, I do. ; Therapist: Well, some of them you've done in the past, right? ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: So now we have the specific and the achievable. ; Therapist: Now I want to get to parts a little more tricky, which is making it measurable. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: What I'd like to do here, and I don't want to be overly prescriptive in terms of objectives. ; Therapist: I want you to decide. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: But I want to see if we can quantify in some manner how often you'll be able to do these different things, or how, you know, like in the homework, we'll have to think about the spacing would be the quantity. ; Therapist: But first with the walking. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: So in a given week, say, what's realistic for you in terms of getting out and walking? ; Therapist: How many times? ; Patient: Maybe I can start out with twice a week. ; Therapist: Twice a week. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Do you have two particular days in mind? ; Therapist: Days where your responsibilities aren't too great and you have that opportunity? ; Patient: Maybe we need to start with one day a week. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Let's go with one day a week. ; Therapist: Let's go one time. ; Therapist: One time a week. ; Patient: Let's start with one and then we'll see what happens. ; Therapist: That's a good start. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So what day of the week are you thinking of for walking? ; Therapist: How about Monday? ; Therapist: Is there a window of opportunity there you see on Monday? ; Patient: It is. ; Therapist: Yeah? ; Patient: Plus, it just kind of, I think, well, no, no. ; Therapist: How about Wednesday? ; Patient: Wednesday. ; Patient: Yes. ; Patient: Wednesday, middle of the week, stress from work and school and, yes, Wednesday sounds good. ; Therapist: Wednesday. ; Therapist: Do you have a particular time range you like to walk, what would be the time of the day? ; Patient: Like 6.30. ; Therapist: That's a good time for you? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: That's a time you can get out of the house? ; Patient: Yes. ; Patient: Off work and give me a little bit of time to get home and change and out the door because if I make it too late, I'm not going to go. ; Patient: So 6.30 is kind of a good, that's the good time to get out there. ; Therapist: Yes, 6.30. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Good. ; Therapist: So we'll start with that objective, the walking. ; Therapist: Every Wednesday at 6.30. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: And for every amount of time you're comfortable with. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: So the homework. ; Therapist: This is a little trickier. ; Patient: All right. ; Therapist: So this is about spacing it out. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So the homework assignments, they're stressing it out. ; Therapist: How much time do they take? ; Therapist: Well, I'll ask you a few questions. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: How much time do they take to complete generally? ; Therapist: Like in hours, so. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: It depends on the assignment. ; Therapist: Have you had the average? ; Patient: The average, maybe about two hours, two and a half hours, I guess. ; Therapist: Well, let's go with the worst case. ; Therapist: Let's go two and a half hours just to cover the worst case. ; Therapist: Would that generally be the worst case? ; Patient: I think so, maybe. ; Patient: It depends because of, yeah. ; Therapist: Want me to get three? ; Patient: Yeah, let's make it three. ; Therapist: And then how much time do you have from when it's assigned to when it's due, usually? ; Patient: Maybe a couple of weeks. ; Therapist: A couple of weeks? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: And what have you been doing now in terms of managing those three hours relative to that two-week period? ; Therapist: Like it doesn't sound like you're doing it early in the two-week period. ; Patient: No, I'm not. ; Therapist: Yeah, so a little bit later? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I get distracted, so I get a little distracted. ; Patient: So it's, you know, I start reading and I'll fall asleep or I get distracted by something or, and then before you know it, the time is gone and I'm rushing at the end to try and get it all done. ; Patient: Two hours with the work. ; Patient: Three hours. ; Therapist: Three hours with the work. ; Therapist: Squeezed into the last, okay. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: I could see how that would be stressful. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: What day of the week is it usually assigned? ; Patient: On Tuesdays. ; Therapist: On Tuesdays. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So you have Tuesday and then you have another Tuesday and then the week after that is due. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: You have three hours of work in those two weeks. ; Therapist: So let's look at it this way maybe. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: What time could you set aside, say near that first Tuesday, that you could put maybe the first hour in? ; Therapist: Maybe divide it in three parts? ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Is that enough parts? ; Patient: Yeah, it should be. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Can you say what time? ; Therapist: Yeah, what would be the first day and time? ; Therapist: Like kind of like when you specify Wednesday at 6-30, that's going to be your walk-in time. ; Therapist: Right, right. ; Therapist: How about the time when you could start the homework? ; Therapist: If it's the first hour. ; Patient: Maybe after I've come back from my walk on Wednesdays. ; Therapist: How long do you foresee a walk? ; Patient: Normally I only walk for an hour. ; Therapist: So give you some time to decompress maybe around 8, 8 o'clock. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So from 8 to 9 on Tuesday, on Wednesday, I'm sorry. ; Patient: Wednesday. ; Therapist: On Wednesday, you'll get that first third of your homework. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And then you'll stop. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: That'll be that for the night. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Does that sound like a plan? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: What's the second hour? ; Therapist: Maybe a few days, give yourself a few days. ; Patient: No, I guess I could start it Thursday. ; Therapist: Thursday? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: So that's just one day apart. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: You want to make yourself more time? ; Therapist: It seems like you're not sure. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Let's do Thursday. ; Therapist: You want to go Thursday? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: In an hour? ; Therapist: Yes. ; Therapist: And what hour do you have in mind? ; Patient: Thursdays, about 7 o'clock. ; Therapist: So about 7 to 8? ; Patient: 7 to 8. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So one night, Wednesday, it'll be 8 to 9, it's your walk. ; Therapist: And then on Thursday, 7 to 9. ; Patient: Well, that's two hours. ; Therapist: 7 to 8, sorry. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So now just the last hour remains. ; Therapist: Sunday. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Sunday. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So you want to get everything done from Tuesday to Sunday night. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: And have the rest of that time off. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Are you sure that's achievable? ; Therapist: That seems like you're getting a lot in there. ; Therapist: Do you think you can do it? ; Patient: I'll get dry. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: That sounds good. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: What time Sunday? ; Patient: Sunday around 5. ; Therapist: So 5 to 6? ; Patient: 5 to 6, yes. ; Therapist: And I'm assuming it won't run over because we kind of asked me on the high side, but if it did, would you be able to go 5 to 7? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: So that's kind of like flexible time there. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: So what would that feel like to get your homework done by Sunday? ; Patient: It would be a relief. ; Patient: And then I could do some other stuff like, you know, maybe my next goal. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So, and there's a potential backup plan I see in here is that if something happens on Sunday, where you need more time and you don't want to stress, you still have that Wednesday after you walk, bacon. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So that could be like your backup. ; Therapist: Yes. ; Therapist: Does that make sense? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Because you still have another six days to have done after that. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: Does that seem realistic and achievable? ; Patient: It does. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So how about the singing? ; Patient: I have no idea how long the singing thing takes, so. ; Patient: Well, if I get back in the group that I was in, we would normally get together on a Friday after work. ; Therapist: Every Friday, every so many Fridays? ; Patient: Every Friday. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: So on Fridays, it would just be rehearsal. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: And then another Friday, it would be a shorter rehearsal, and then we would go someplace if we knew of a group of some friends of ours that were performing. ; Therapist: So this is an every Friday commitment, right, the singing? ; Patient: Yes. ; Patient: But one Friday is generally, it's like the end, about two hours. ; Therapist: About two hours. ; Therapist: So two hours every Friday. ; Therapist: This is something you really enjoy, though. ; Patient: It is. ; Therapist: So it sounds like you look forward to it. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So Friday, two hours, I guess, would be the afternoon or evening? ; Patient: Evening. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So that's one that you would kind of look forward to. ; Patient: Yes. ; Patient: The singing. ; Therapist: That's good. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So that's one you feel you could achieve a couple hours on Friday. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: So I think it was something that came up that I really had to get done. ; Patient: It's not like I can't not go. ; Therapist: So... ; Therapist: It won't be managed or anything? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: They know I'm in school. ; Patient: In school, they understand. ; Therapist: Good. ; Therapist: So then there's the last objective. ; Therapist: This is, I guess, about a whole day commitment, right, because you go to the beach. ; Patient: That would be more like a Saturday. ; Therapist: But of course it wouldn't be every Saturday. ; Therapist: So how many times in, say, a month? ; Therapist: Like once? ; Patient: Once a month. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So you would go down on Saturday morning and come back that same day? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Is that something you look forward to? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Is that something that would be okay in terms of like, because on Friday night potentially you'd be out, right? ; Therapist: And then Saturday. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: But if I, if on those Saturdays that I know that I'm going, I could not be out too late on that. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: That's a good idea. ; Therapist: So you kind of make sure you restrict how long you stay out. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: When you know that Saturday's coming. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Or not go at all that Friday. ; Therapist: Either way. ; Therapist: Just take a break that time. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Re-store. ; Patient: All right. ; Therapist: So that's four separate objectives. ; Therapist: And what I want to do since I've kind of made a lot of specific notations here, I want to take a moment, just take a break and print this up for you. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: We'll work on the rest of your goals next time, but I want you to have this so you can get started on it right away. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So before I print these up, is there any changes you want to make? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: I would like to try that and if it doesn't work, can we tweak it? ; Therapist: Oh yeah. ; Therapist: Just make changes. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Maybe certain things will work really well. ; Therapist: Maybe certain things will have to take off the list altogether and maybe substitute something else. ; Therapist: But yeah, we can make edits to it the whole time you're here. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: We can just make a document that changes as needed. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: But if you think it's a good starting place, I'll go ahead and print this up as it is and give you a copy and we can resume with today's session and then next time I see you in a week, we'll work on the rest of the treatment plan. ; Patient: Sounds good. ; Therapist: Does that sound like a good plan? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Thanks Alison. ; Patient: Thank you.

dialogue: Therapist: I see you made your bed. ; Therapist: It's great. ; Therapist: It really makes a difference. ; Therapist: How did waking up early go? ; Patient: Well, it worked for like a day or two, but then the power went out, so then my alarm clock stopped working. ; Patient: And then I kind of started sleeping in again. ; Therapist: I thought that might happen, so I made this sign for you. ; Therapist: It'll help you remember to set the alarm. ; Patient: Oh, I did get out to the park. ; Therapist: How did that go? ; Patient: It didn't go so well. ; Patient: I don't have enough clean clothes, and I felt really uncomfortable. ; Patient: This thing is really hard, man. ; Patient: Like, why bother? ; Therapist: Well, that's why I bought you these. ; Therapist: You can put your dirty clothes into the hamper, and your clean clothes, you can fold them up and put them into this bin. ; Patient: Well, that's cool. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Well, last time we talked about how you forget to take a shower. ; Therapist: So I brought you this hygiene basket, because I remembered you become overwhelmed. ; Therapist: If you keep it here by the bed, it'll remind you to take a shower, and you can carry it with you. ; Patient: I think I could use a shower. ; Patient: Well, why don't you go have one? ; Therapist: I'll put the calendar up for you, and I'll also put this picture I love up here by the bed. ; Patient: You blew it up. ; Therapist: Well, guess what? ; Therapist: I got you a container so you can put all your meds in. ; Therapist: If you fill it up for each day and keep it by your bed with a glass of water, it'll remind you to take your pills. ; Patient: I'm going to go take that shower now. ; Therapist: Sounds good. ; Therapist: I'll put up your calendar.
summary: Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms 1 forgetting things 2 not able to maintain basic hygiene ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior nad; speech incoherent, mood  affect agitated, thought disorganized, perception distorted, cognitive functions poor, judgement and insight poor ; Psychotherapy Type: Dynamic supportive ; Psychotherapy Technique : Supportive ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Themes discussed in the session 1 supportive work therapist tries to use supportive techniques to help patient relationship with daily living skills and self-care routines by providing practical solutions to overcome challenges. 2 structuring therapist provides tools to create a structured environment, which can make daily routines more manageable such as an alarm clock sign, a hamper for dirty clothes, and a medication container. Also, offers a hygiene basket to keep necessary items organized and accessible. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Psychosis tentative

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Lisa, how you doing today? ; Patient: Well, I guess I'm doing okay. ; Therapist: You're doing okay? ; Patient: I'm having some problems. ; Therapist: Having some problems? ; Therapist: What's going on? ; Patient: I find myself getting really distracted, kind of fidgety and stuff. ; Patient: I think I might have that one disorder that I hear about all the time on TV. ; Therapist: Like ADHD? ; Patient: That's the one. ; Therapist: You think you might have ADHD? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right, so let me ask you some other questions, and then we'll get into some questions specifically about that and see what's going on there. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Do you ever find yourself depressed? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Anxious? ; Therapist: No. ; Therapist: Any trouble with drugs or alcohol? ; Patient: Oh, no. ; Therapist: Nothing like that. ; Therapist: When did you first notice you had the symptoms? ; Patient: Early teens, maybe before. ; Therapist: Do you know what age? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No? ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: But you're thinking early teens, maybe before? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Do the symptoms, are they really bothersome to you? ; Therapist: They cause any problems? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Yeah? ; Therapist: What kind of areas do they cause you problems? ; Patient: I mean, really everywhere, I guess. ; Therapist: Yeah? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Do you work? ; Patient: Yes, I do. ; Therapist: Does it cause problems at work? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: How about college? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: It does? ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: How about at home? ; Patient: Oh, yeah. ; Therapist: It does? ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So, tell me a little bit about the symptoms that you think might indicate ADHD. ; Therapist: What's going on? ; Patient: Well, I mean, when I go to class and I find myself, you know, kind of going off into my little world where the teacher's talking, it's kind of like I just, I can't stand sitting down and then I'll stand up and the teacher's looking at me like, do you need something? ; Patient: And I'm like, no, I just really needed to stand up. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So, you feel compelled to stand up in class? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Even though you know, you know it might draw some attention? ; Patient: Yeah, unfortunately. ; Patient: I mean, I know it, but I still, I need to do it. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So, I'm going to ask you a few questions and I'm going to ask you kind of two categories of questions. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So, I'm going to start with the first category. ; Therapist: Do you feel like you have trouble establishing attention? ; Therapist: Let's look at this in terms of school. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: You do? ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: How about when you have established attention, do you find yourself struggling to hold on to it? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Yes? ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And again, I'll just stick with the school environment, right? ; Therapist: That's the place where these symptoms bother you? ; Patient: Well, yeah, again, they bother me a lot. ; Therapist: As well as other places, but they're definitely school. ; Patient: Yeah, school's a big issue. ; Therapist: That's a big one. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Do you have trouble listening in class? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: You do? ; Therapist: How about following through on instructions that are provided by, say, the professor? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: Class projects are the hardest. ; Therapist: Do you find yourself organized? ; Patient: Yeah, I am pretty organized. ; Therapist: You are pretty organized? ; Therapist: Do you find yourself in school or other settings avoiding activities that require a lot of mental effort and energy? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Yeah? ; Patient: They give me a headache and I just don't want to deal with it. ; Therapist: What are some things you avoid? ; Patient: Oh, board games. ; Patient: I can't stand chess. ; Patient: I just don't understand it and then people explain to me the rules and I just zone out. ; Therapist: Do you ever find yourself losing things that you need to function at work or school? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No? ; Therapist: Distracted? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Do you find yourself distracted? ; Patient: I do get distracted. ; Therapist: Fairly easily? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: How about forgetfulness? ; Patient: Yeah, I am pretty forgetful. ; Therapist: Okay, so I'm going to move and ask you another category of questions. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Do you find yourself fidgeting? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: How do you do with ... I think you touched on this before, but how do you do with quiet activities, like for example, reading? ; Patient: Oh, I really struggle with that. ; Therapist: You struggle with that? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I can play a video game for an hour, but I can't read or play a game or draw. ; Therapist: So when you are engaged in quiet activities, do you find yourself kind of wandering off? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: You do? ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Do you ever feel like you have an internal motor that won't shut off? ; Patient: No, I wouldn't say that. ; Therapist: No? ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Do you feel like you talk excessively? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Yeah? ; Patient: Yeah, almost to the point that I ... Well, not even almost. ; Patient: I interrupt people a lot. ; Therapist: What settings do you find that's a problem? ; Patient: At school is a big one. ; Therapist: That's a big one? ; Patient: Yeah, because I'll talk and I'll talk. ; Patient: I mean, I'll get off track when called on by the teacher, and then somebody else will say something and it'll be like, oh yeah, no, I forgot. ; Patient: Yeah, that too. ; Patient: I mean, I feel horrible, but I just, I can't stop it. ; Therapist: Do you ever find that, say in class, you blurt things out? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Yeah? ; Therapist: And interrupt people? ; Patient: Yes, I do interrupt people. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Have a situation where, like say at work or school or at home, where you have to wait your turn for something. ; Therapist: Do you find that's a problem? ; Patient: What, like at a drive-thru? ; Therapist: It could be a drive-thru. ; Therapist: Do you ... If you're a drive-thru, do you find ... ; Patient: I mean, doesn't really ... I don't get it. ; Therapist: You don't have any trouble with waiting in lines or waiting for your turn? ; Patient: I guess not. ; Therapist: I guess not. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So, I'm going to get you in to see one of our counselors. ; Therapist: You mentioned that these symptoms are bothersome to you. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: And I want to make sure you get treated. ; Therapist: It'll take a couple days to get you in to see somebody. ; Therapist: Is that okay? ; Patient: Yes, that's fine. ; Therapist: Well, Lisa, I want to thank you for spending this time with me and answering these questions. ; Therapist: This has been really helpful. ; Patient: Thank you. ; Therapist: Thanks.
summary: Patient Particulars : Nil ; Clinical Identifiers: Setting opd ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: The doctor is going to send the patient to a therapist ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Interrupting conversations and blurting out since teenage ; History: Present history pt has been noticing symptoms like inattention, concentration difficulty, talkativeness and inability to sit at one place since his teenage years. For the same reason he consulted the doctor. Substance use history theres no history of psychoactive substance use ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Nil ; Psychotherapy Type: Nil ; Psychotherapy Technique : Nil ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: This was an introductory session where the doctor was trying to arrive at a diagnosis ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Adhd ; Action Plan : To send the patient to a psychiatrist counsellor ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Barbara Roberts. ; Therapist: Yes. ; Therapist: Hello there. ; Patient: My name is Dr. Betty. ; Patient: I'm one of the new GPs in the practice. ; Patient: First of all, what would you like me to call you? ; Patient: Well, you can call me Barbara. ; Patient: That'll be fine. ; Patient: Okay, that's fine. ; Patient: Okay, so Barbara, I'm seeing you today. ; Patient: But I think it's usually Dr. Brown that sees you, is that right? ; Patient: Yes, Dr. Brown's my doctor. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: What is it that's brought you to see me today? ; Patient: Well, I've come about my tummy problem. ; Patient: I've got terrible trouble with my stomach and Dr. Brown just doesn't seem to be able to get to the bottom of it. ; Patient: I thought perhaps I'd come and see you to see if you could help. ; Patient: Right, okay. ; Patient: Can you tell me a bit more about your tummy problems? ; Patient: Well, I have this terrible discomfort nearly all the time. ; Patient: It very often feels bloated. ; Patient: I swing between being constipated and having diarrhoea. ; Patient: I have sort of cramping feelings sometimes and other times it stabs. ; Patient: It's a real stabbing feeling. ; Patient: I often have the urge to go to the toilet and I pass very smelly wind. ; Patient: So quite a few symptoms there and some of them sound quite troublesome to you. ; Patient: Yes. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: And how long has this been going on? ; Patient: Well, I've traced it back to a holiday I had in Egypt about four years ago. ; Patient: I had a horrible bout of sickness and diarrhoea and I don't think my stomach's ever been really right since then. ; Patient: Okay, okay. ; Patient: So you think it began about four years ago after this holiday? ; Patient: Yes. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: And what sort of treatments have you tried for this before? ; Patient: Well, Dr. Brown gave me some muscle relaxants at the beginning. ; Patient: But I've been to the health shop and they've been really helpful. ; Patient: They've given me lots of different tablets and medicines for different things. ; Patient: Oh, and Imodium. ; Patient: I have Imodium in my handbag all the time just in case. ; Patient: So these different tablets that you've got from the herbal shop, how are you taking them? ; Patient: Well, different tablets. ; Patient: You know, I don't have the same problem every day so I'll take some tablets for certain symptoms and other tablets for other things. ; Patient: So am I right in thinking you perhaps decide on a day-to-day basis what you're going to take depending on what your stomach's doing? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Okay, okay. ; Patient: And what about tests? ; Patient: Have you had any tests for these problems? ; Patient: Yes, I had in the early days I had a gastroscopy. ; Patient: Was that the tube down from the top? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: And at the same time I had a barium enema. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: That was very uncomfortable. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: But no, I've tried, well, I don't think he's tried enough tests because he said after that that they didn't find anything and he's just not sent me for any more. ; Patient: That's it now as far as he's concerned. ; Patient: Sent me back to the doctor. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: It sounds as though you're not happy with that. ; Patient: Well, you know, I think that actually the NHS are running out of money, aren't they? ; Patient: And he's decided that I've had enough tests and, you know, if you go on the internet there's loads of tests that he could have sent me for. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: If I had a bit more money I'd go private. ; Patient: I just don't think he's got to the bottom of it. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: So you feel as though actually enough hasn't been done in the way of tests? ; Patient: No, he's not. ; Patient: There's loads more he could do, I'm sure. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: It sounds like you've had these problems now for about four years. ; Patient: You've got a lot of various symptoms in your stomach. ; Patient: You've tried a lot of tablets, some prescribed, some herbal remedies and you've had some investigations but you're not entirely happy that you've even been investigated thoroughly enough. ; Patient: Is that about...
