I'd say so, yes. ; Therapist: Have I got the story right? ; Therapist: Yes. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: And can I ask you, Barbara, how is all of this affecting you day to day? ; Patient: How's it affecting your life? ; Patient: Well, it's had quite a big impact. ; Patient: I mean, the first thing, the biggest thing I suppose is that I went from being full-time to part-time at work. ; Patient: I just couldn't sit all day comfortably. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: And so I went part-time. ; Patient: But in the end, about a year ago, I stopped work altogether. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: I miss that. ; Patient: I miss the girls. ; Patient: We used to go out at least once a week to the pictures or for a drink. ; Patient: That's one thing. ; Patient: Sounds as though that's something you quite enjoyed. ; Patient: Yes. ; Patient: Yes. ; Patient: We used to have a laugh. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: I used to go to swing into shape. ; Patient: I used to go to an exercise class. ; Patient: That was... I missed the exercise actually. ; Patient: That was once a week. ; Patient: But the thing was I wasn't comfortable... ; Patient: I never felt quite right doing all this exercise. ; Patient: I was always worried I was going to be taken short or... So I stopped that. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: Then... Well, my husband and I used to go out for meals. ; Patient: That's another thing we don't do anymore now. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: Yes, quite a few things really. ; Patient: Yes, it does sound as though over the last few years your life has really changed quite a lot because of these symptoms. ; Patient: Yes. ; Patient: It sounds like you're doing... there are a few of the things that you used to do. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: Yes. ; Patient: What is it you spend your average day doing now? ; Patient: Well, I potter around the house. ; Patient: I spend perhaps a little bit too much time watching... I've got a bit hooked on daytime television, I have to say. ; Patient: They draw you in, don't they? ; Patient: They certainly do. ; Patient: I read a bit. ; Patient: There are magazines. ; Patient: But generally I'm at home. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: And have there been any times over the last four years that you've noticed any significant changes in your symptoms? ; Patient: For example, have there been any times when things have been better for you? ; Patient: Well, last year my son got married and I have to say I was worried that I wouldn't be able to cope with it, that I wouldn't be feeling well enough. ; Patient: Surprisingly enough, I was in good form. ; Patient: I think it was about three weeks in the summer, getting ready for it and the whole hoo-ha of the wedding. ; Patient: But I was in really good form for that. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: That was a good time. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: And how were your tummy symptoms then? ; Patient: I hardly noticed them. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: It seemed to clear up. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Which was good. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: That's interesting. ; Patient: And are there any times when your tummy symptoms bother you more, seem particularly bad? ; Patient: Well, I'm having a bit of a bad patch at the moment. ; Patient: It's particularly uncomfortable. ; Patient: I have to say I do notice it when my husband's away. ; Patient: He travels with his job and he can be away a couple of times a month. ; Patient: And that's not, it's not a bad thing but it's very often not good then, I have to say. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: So you notice it's, they're worse when your husband's not around. ; Patient: Maybe I'm thinking about it a bit more. ; Patient: I don't know when he's not there. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: I know you've been seeing Dr. Brown about this for the last few years. ; Patient: What is it that he's said that he thinks might be wrong with you? ; Patient: Well, he's, he thinks it's all in my head. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: He's, yeah, he says it's stress. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: And what do you think? ; Patient: Well, I mean, it can't all be in my head. ; Patient: I get too much physical pain for it to be in my head. ; Patient: I mean, it's real. ; Patient: It's, it's a real pain. ; Therapist: And have you ; Patient: had any thoughts yourself about what you think might be causing it? ; Patient: Well, I mean, I did think that perhaps it was an infection that hadn't cleared up in the early stages. ; Patient: But I think, I mean, sometimes I think it's IBS. ; Patient: A friend of mine's got that and it sounds similar. ; Patient: And then other times I'll think, I wonder if it's an ulcer. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: On a really bad day, I start to think it might be cancer. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: My mother-in-law, my mother-in-law died of cancer last year and she had a growth that the doctor didn't investigate. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: By the time they'd found it, it was the size of a football. ; Patient: And of course it was too late to operate then. ; Patient: So, you know, when I go to bed at night now, I just feel and make sure there's nothing different going on. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: And yeah, I worry about that. ; Patient: So you're kind of prodding, having a feel at night. ; Therapist: Oh yes. ; Patient: To see if you can feel anything. ; Patient: Yes. ; Patient: I just want to make sure there's nothing changing down there, you know. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: So just to make sure that I've got the story straight, you've, you've seen Dr. Brown for a couple of years. ; Patient: You've tried a variety of medications, some prescribed, some from the herbal shop and none of them really made a great deal of difference. ; Patient: You've had some investigations, but you perhaps feel you've not had enough investigations. ; Patient: And at times you worry that this could be something quite serious like a cancer. ; Patient: Is that, have I got the story right? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Yes. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: Barbara, what was it that you were hoping that I'd do for you today? ; Patient: Well, I thought, you know, you're a new doctor here and you've just finished your medical training. ; Patient: I wondered whether, you know, with new eyes and a new way of looking at, at the problem. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: You probably know about different tests, new tests that my doctor doesn't know about, you know, new developments. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: So perhaps you could send me for some different tests. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: So you were hoping that I'd send you for more tests. ; Patient: Hmm. ; Patient: Well, I think there's, there's got to be something that a test might, might reveal. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: Well, I think Barbara, having, having heard your story and heard about the symptoms, I'm not sure that actually sending you for more tests at this point would be the most useful thing that we could do for you. ; Patient: And the reason for that is because you've, you've had some of the main investigations in the last couple of years and they've not shown anything. ; Patient: And your symptoms haven't really changed that much. ; Patient: So it's very unlikely that if we were to send you for more tests now that, that they'd show anything different than what we already know. ; Patient: So it would be, I think it would be a waste of time for you to go for more tests. ; Patient: So it's like, do you think it's all in my head then? ; Patient: You're going to be like Dr. ; Patient: Brown. ; Patient: You think I'm imagining all of this? ; Patient: No, I think that you clearly have pain and it clearly, you have lots of physical symptoms and they clearly getting in the way of your life and causing you a lot of disability. ; Patient: I guess, I guess the way I think about these things is that they're not necessarily either all in the mind or all in the body. ; Patient: Sometimes these things can go together. ; Patient: I guess I'm thinking about how you told me that last year when your son got married and you were very busy and quite happy that somehow your symptoms seemed less and that when your husband's away, which is something you don't like very much, somehow your symptoms then will seem greater. ; Patient: So I guess what I'm wondering Barbara is if there might be some kind of a link with you between how you're feeling in your mind and what's going on in your life and how much your symptoms trouble you. ; Patient: Do you think that's a possibility? ; Patient: Well, I can't see that my mind can be causing this amount of pain. ; Patient: I'm not saying that the pain's in your mind. ; Patient: I guess what I'm saying is that sometimes the way that we feel and the way that our lives are going can impact how we notice our symptoms. ; Patient: Given that we've tried medication for you and we've tried investigations and we've drawn a blank really with those, none of those have really helped you. ; Patient: I guess I'm wondering whether now it would be a good idea to try a different approach to your problems. ; Patient: I think that's a good approach to your problems. ; Patient: What sort of approach? ; Patient: Well, I guess thinking a little bit about those other areas of your life, I'm thinking about the fact that over the last four years your life's really changed. ; Patient: It seems to have really shrunk down and it sounds as though you're not doing lots of the things that you used to do that you used to get pleasure out of. ; Patient: Is that right? ; Patient: Well, I just can't do them. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I can't do them anymore. ; Patient: And I guess I wonder, it sounds as though you've dropped doing those things because you felt you couldn't do them, but I wonder if in a funny way what's happened is the fact that you're not doing those pleasurable things now has kind of fed into your feeling unhappy with the way that your life is at the moment. ; Patient: And I guess I wonder whether that can then make your symptoms worse for you. ; Patient: Oh, I don't know. ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: And I guess what I'd be wondering is whether one of the approaches we need to be using now is thinking about what you do with your life and what you do with your day and maybe trying to bring back some of those pleasurable things, even if it's just meeting up with your female friends once a week, and whether actually doing those sorts of things might generally improve your quality of life. ; Patient: I'm also thinking about the tablets that you're taking and the fact that you seem to be taking quite a lot of them and wondering whether it's worth us sitting and looking at them and maybe trying to rationalize them a little bit and really decide which are helping you, which are doing nothing, and which may actually be making some of your symptoms worse, I guess. ; Patient: What would you think about trying that slightly different approach for, say, two or three months just to see whether or not it makes any difference? ; Patient: Well, two or three months is a long time if there is something going on. ; Patient: I mean, that's what happened to my mother-in-law. ; Patient: You know, they left her and didn't spot it. ; Patient: Well, I guess if we did decide to work together like this, this new approach, I'd be seeing you regularly. ; Patient: We can keep an eye on your symptoms, and if they change, then we can investigate as appropriate. ; Patient: But if they stay the same, then we could be pretty clear that there's nothing new happening that we're missing. ; Patient: How would that sound? ; Patient: So, what are you saying then, that I should come back and see you? ; Patient: I think that would be a good idea. ; Patient: I think we've only just begun to talk about it, and I think perhaps you need to have a bit of time to think about it and then perhaps come back, perhaps if you booked him for a double slot next week, and that would give us a good chunk of time to think about this new approach. ; Patient: And perhaps if you could also bring your tablets in or make a list of them, we can look at what you're taking and perhaps go from there. ; Patient: How would that sound, Barbara? ; Patient: Okay, well, to make an appointment for next week, I'll come back and see you again and talk about it a bit more. ; Patient: Yes, I think so. ; Patient: I think that would be a good start. ; Patient: And I'll make a list of the tablets that I'm taking. ; Patient: I won't bring all the bottles down. ; Patient: Okay, all right. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: All right. ; Patient: So, shall I see you again next week? ; Patient: I'll make an appointment for next week. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: All right. ; Therapist: Thank you, Barbara. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Bye bye.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name barbara; sex female; occupation currently unemployed since past 1 year ; Clinical Identifiers: Setting opd ; Referral Information : Referrer name dr brown; reason for referral no response to medications and the referring doctor feels that the illness is psychiatric ; Therapist Information : Name dr betty ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Bloating4yrs 2. Alternating diarrhoea and constipation 4yrs 3. Abdominal cramps on and off since 4 yrs ; History: Patient was apparently maintaining well 4 yrs back when she went for a trip to egypt. She reports that she suffered from fever and diarrhea back there and has been facing the above mentioned symptoms since then. According to the patient the symptoms get exaggerated during times of stress and get somewhat relieved when her mood is better. The symptoms have remained the same in the past 4 yrs but have affected the patients quality of life. She gets troubling thoughts that these might be symptoms of a grave illness that nobody is able to detect and diagnose and that she might die of cancer as her mother in law did an year ago. She went from full time to working part time and stopped working altogether 1 year ago. Despite taking multiple medications her symptoms are not getting relieved for which she was sent by her doctor to the therapist. Treatment history multiple meds since past 4 yrs including imodium past history underwent gastroscopy and barium enema which came out to be normal ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Nil ; Psychotherapy Type: Type supportive; mode individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Reflective listening, psychoeducation, behavioral activation ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: History of the presenting complaints was discussed alongwith how they have affected the patients life. Patient was psychoeducated about mind playing a role in the altered perception of symptoms ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Somatoform disorder irritable bowel syndrome ; Action Plan : 1. Pt was told to make a list of the medicines she has been taking and bring those with her in the next session 2. To try and go out with her female friends every week as she used to do earlier ; Next session details: Pt asked to book a double slot next week

dialogue: Therapist: Hi, this is Dr. Grande. ; Therapist: I hope you find this video useful. ; Therapist: If that's the case, please like it and subscribe to my channel. ; Therapist: As always, thanks for watching. ; Therapist: Hello, Peggy. ; Therapist: How are you doing today? ; Therapist: Hi, Dr. Grande. ; Patient: I'm okay. ; Therapist: You're okay? ; Patient: I am. ; Therapist: Yesterday, when you were here at the agency, you took a few different tests. ; Therapist: Do you remember that? ; Patient: I did. ; Therapist: One of the tests that you took is called the SCL-90, the symptom checklist 90. ; Therapist: Do you remember taking that test? ; Patient: I think so. ; Therapist: It's 90 items and they're ranked. ; Patient: Ask me like true and false questions. ; Therapist: They're not true and false. ; Therapist: They're numbers that you select. ; Patient: Oh, okay. ; Patient: I do remember that. ; Therapist: Remember that? ; Therapist: So, I have the results from that test and I want to review some of those findings with you. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Is that all right? ; Patient: Sure. ; Therapist: So, this particular instrument has a number of what we refer to as subscales. ; Therapist: So, these are areas that are measured by the instrument. ; Therapist: For example, depression or anxiety. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So, I'm going to review a few of these subscales, ones where you scored a little higher than we might expect. ; Therapist: I'll just review those with you and see what you think and we can talk about it. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: Are you recording this? ; Therapist: I'm not. ; Therapist: Are you worried about that? ; Patient: Well, I think you probably are, but okay. ; Therapist: What makes you think I'm recording it? ; Patient: Because that happens to me a lot. ; Therapist: It happens to you a lot that you get recorded? ; Patient: I think so, yes. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Do you remember the last time that happened to you? ; Patient: Probably yesterday. ; Therapist: And do you think you were recorded while you were taking this? ; Patient: Probably, yes. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: That sounds worrisome. ; Therapist: That's a feeling you get a lot that you're being recorded? ; Patient: I worry about it a lot. ; Therapist: You worry about it a lot. ; Patient: But I know it's happening. ; Patient: That's why I worry about it. ; Therapist: You're certain that's happening? ; Patient: Yeah, I am. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Well, you're not being recorded now. ; Patient: I know it probably feels like you are, but you're not. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: But I appreciate you bringing up that concern with me. ; Therapist: So a few of the scales where you were a bit elevated on, I want to discuss, as I mentioned. ; Therapist: I need to explain the concept of percentile rank to you. ; Therapist: Okay? ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Is that a term you've ever heard, percentile rank? ; Patient: I think so in school. ; Therapist: Maybe in school, right. ; Therapist: That would make sense. ; Therapist: So say, for instance, you had a percentile rank of 65%, right, percentile. ; Therapist: That would mean that your score is equal to or higher than 65% of the people that took that test. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Does that make sense? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: So if you took a test on math or English and you were at, say, 75 percentile, you'd be higher than three-quarters of the people that took the test, 75 percentile. ; Patient: I think I understand that. ; Therapist: Does that make sense? ; Patient: I think so. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: If you want me to come back to that later, just let me know as I go through if it doesn't make sense. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So areas here on the SCL results where you were a bit higher than we would normally see, one is the phobic anxiety scale. ; Therapist: On that one, you were about 64 percentile. ; Therapist: So your score was as high or higher than 64% of people that would take it. ; Patient: To more than half the people in the population. ; Therapist: More than half the people in the same situation as you in outpatient mental health treatment. ; Patient: So I have more phobic anxiety than most people. ; Therapist: It does seem that way. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: So this construct would measure things like being afraid of going out, being afraid of being in crowds. ; Therapist: Does that connect with you? ; Therapist: Does that seem like a fear that you have? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Can you tell me about that? ; Patient: I don't like being on public transportation. ; Patient: Crowds make me nervous. ; Patient: And if I ever have to public speak, I feel like I'm just going to pass out. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So it does appear that you have kind of phobic anxiety symptoms. ; Therapist: So that score, that 64 percentile, that kind of makes sense. ; Patient: I kind of get that. ; Patient: I get that. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: I want to move on to the next one, which is paranoia. ; Therapist: So in this one, you were at the 84th percentile. ; Therapist: So quite a bit higher. ; Patient: Is that where you were recording me? ; Therapist: This wasn't recorded. ; Therapist: Nothing was recorded here. ; Therapist: I understand that's a worry that you have. ; Patient: Are you going to share those results with anybody? ; Therapist: In your particular case, the only people that would be shared with is the rest of the treatment team and anybody that you sign a release for. ; Patient: But if the government asked you, you'd have to give them those results? ; Therapist: There's no reason right now why I did that. ; Therapist: There are certain limits to confidentiality, but in your situation here at this clinic, there's no reason I would share this information with the government or anybody else other than the people I indicated. ; Therapist: So the rest of the people here would treat you. ; Therapist: And if you wanted to release the results to somebody, you could sign a release, and I would let them have the results. ; Therapist: Are you worried about the results getting to other people? ; Patient: Well, I'm worried that I know people are recording me, and I think that that result shows that I know that's happening. ; Patient: And now you want to make it look like that means I have a problem when I'm just reporting what I know is true. ; Therapist: All right, so you're worried that we're trying to prove that you're paranoid. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: And kind of rigging the results of this test to make it ; Patient: But this test says that I'm wrong to think that it makes me paranoid. ; Therapist: Oh, I understand. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So, these things are really happening. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Right? ; Therapist: But the test is arranged so that it's making you look paranoid when you're not. ; Patient: Exactly. ; Therapist: Because it's not paranoia in your case. ; Therapist: It's really true. ; Patient: Exactly. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So that would explain why your score is elevated on this scale. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Is that what you're thinking? ; Patient: I do, yes. ; Therapist: And I wanted you to know that. ; Therapist: Well, I appreciate you telling me that. ; Therapist: Do you think it's possible that it's working the other way around, that the test is measuring something that is actually there? ; Patient: No, I don't think so. ; Therapist: You don't think so? ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So, you understand that result, that the 84 percentile, you understand what that means? ; Therapist: Higher than we'd expect? ; Patient: I understand that I'm higher than 84—I'm higher than 84 percent of the population. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: But those people just think that's happening. ; Patient: And I know what is. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: You believe their situation is different than yours? ; Therapist: I do. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: I understand. ; Therapist: So the last area, the last subscale I want to discuss—there's one global scale I want to discuss—the last subscale is one that's referred to as psychoticism. ; Therapist: And there you are at the 93rd percentile. ; Therapist: And that's when maybe you can—you hear things other people don't hear or see things other people don't see or have beliefs or thinking that are far outside the norm and can't be supported by evidence. ; Therapist: Do you ever feel like that's happening to you? ; Patient: Are you going to put me away? ; Therapist: There's nothing here that would indicate that I'm going to put you away or send you anywhere. ; Therapist: You know, I just really, the purpose of this is just to discuss the results, to make sure you understand kind of how these inform our treatment of you. ; Therapist: Like, so we're going to provide treatment to you in part based on these results. ; Patient: Sometimes I hear things other people don't hear. ; Patient: I know that. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So this is a score that makes sense to you, where you think the test might be right. ; Patient: Maybe that's true. ; Therapist: Maybe that's true. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: But I am being recorded. ; Therapist: But you believe you're being recorded. ; Therapist: You're certain of that. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So you understand those three scores, right, the phobic anxiety, the paranoid scale, subscale, and the psychoticism subscale. ; Therapist: I'd like to talk about one referred to as the global severity index. ; Therapist: So this kind of takes all the different scores, all different items that you responded to, and gives us a big picture of how you're doing. ; Therapist: You know, how bad your symptoms are, how bothersome they are overall. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Does that make sense? ; Patient: Uh-huh. ; Therapist: On this one, you were at the 68th percentile. ; Therapist: Close to normal. ; Therapist: Well, a little bit higher than we'd want to see. ; Therapist: Not extremely far out, but it's 18 percentile higher than we'd want. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Or than we'd normally see, rather. ; Therapist: So it's a bit of a concern. ; Therapist: Do you feel like overall you're dealing with symptoms okay? ; Patient: I mean, I don't like to go out much. ; Patient: And it really frustrates me when I see things or hear things other people don't. ; Patient: I promise you. ; Patient: But the other score is high, and it shouldn't be. ; Patient: So I might be closer to normal than you think. ; Therapist: So with the paranoid, if that scale was accurate, then your estimation, your global severity might be lower. ; Patient: I think so. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Closer to that 50 percentile. ; Patient: I think so. ; Therapist: So even if you were closer to the 50 percentile, you can understand how we're concerned that your symptoms are somewhat severe. ; Therapist: And we want to make sure we deliver treatment to address that. ; Patient: Sure. ; Therapist: Is that okay? ; Patient: It is. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So I will meet with the counselor that will be treating you here. ; Therapist: And I'm going to go over these scores, and I'll explain to her what you've explained to me. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: In terms of why you think you might have received each score. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: I'll go over that with her. ; Therapist: And of course, you could discuss that with her too. ; Therapist: And she'll have the results of this test in your chart. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: She's not going to record our session, is she? ; Therapist: She's not going to be recording. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Does that make sense, everything I've talked about here today? ; Patient: It does. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: I appreciate you allowing me to go over this set of results with you. ; Therapist: And I'll get you assigned to that counselor, and we'll move forward with treatment. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: Thank you. ; Therapist: Thank you.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name peggy, sex  female ; Clinical Identifiers: Hospital, opd ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Follow up session. Scl 90 test was administered in the pervious session and being discussed in the current session. ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms phobia and paranoia chief complaints 1 anxiety, 2 paranoia, 3 fear of public speaking, 4 hallucinations 5 fear of being in crowd and travel in public transportation. ; History: Nil ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior; anxious; speech understandable, mood  affect anxious and depressed; thought and perception persecutory and paranoid, cognitive functionsincoherent; judgement and insight poor ; Psychotherapy Type: Nil ; Psychotherapy Technique : Nil ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: There are few issues discussed in the session 1 discussion about the test psychiatrist administered the scl 90 in the last meeting to assess various psychological symptoms. He explained the tests and what the scores meant and how he will go about the treatment. He made her understand that the assessment is a part of treatment which will provide her support, rather than to judge or penalise her. 2. Sub-scales there are high scores on specific sub-scales such as phobic anxiety, paranoia, and psychoticism. 3. Difficulty patient is concerned about being recorded, which could be indicative of paranoid ideation. She also questioned the validity of the test results, which she might not accurately resonate with her experience. She also has discomfort in crowds, fear of public speaking, and occasionally hearing things which others dont hear. 4. Action plan psychiatrist convinced her to meet a counselor for ongoing treatment based on the assessment results and assured her confidentiality to reduce her anxiety ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Paranoid schizophrenia ; Action Plan : Referred to a counselor for support and further therapeutic treatment. ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Carly, how are you doing today? ; Patient: I'm good. ; Patient: How about you? ; Therapist: I'm doing well, thanks for asking. ; Therapist: How did you do this week? ; Patient: Better. ; Therapist: Better? ; Patient: Well, last time we talked about the... ; Therapist: The postpone graphication? ; Patient: Yeah, that. ; Patient: And I think you wanted 10 minutes for me to put it off? ; Therapist: 10 minutes, yeah. ; Patient: So I did better. ; Patient: I think I ended up only doing like a joint and a half instead of two. ; Patient: I was able to put it off for I think the 10 minutes a couple times and then there was I think one or two days where I went out for a walk because I was tired of staring at the clock waiting for the 10 minutes to pass. ; Patient: So I got up, went for a walk and then I passed one of my friends so I ended up walking with her and I actually didn't get back to my house for like an hour. ; Patient: So I kind of put it off for like an hour because then I came home and took a couple hits. ; Therapist: So it sounds like you were able to maintain waiting 10 minutes to smoke marijuana at least. ; Patient: It was rough. ; Therapist: It was rough? ; Patient: It was rough. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So it was difficult for you but in most cases you're able to hold off the 10 minutes. ; Therapist: And it sounds like there was a few instances where you're able to hold it off longer because something else kind of came up. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I actually talked to a couple people on the phone and before I knew it like a half hour had gone by. ; Therapist: So another activity presented itself and you forgot about the marijuana? ; Patient: Kind of. ; Therapist: Yeah? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I guess I just wasn't thinking about it. ; Therapist: So has your feelings about marijuana changed since we last talked? ; Patient: No, not really. ; Therapist: Tell me about that. ; Patient: I mean I don't see it as a problem. ; Patient: It's legal in a lot of states now and I mean it's not that bad for you. ; Patient: It doesn't really endanger me much. ; Therapist: So you still believe you should have the right to smoke marijuana? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I mean I'm not hurting anybody else. ; Therapist: But at the same time you want to go back to work and if I remember right, you're the person that you could go work for. ; Therapist: I guess you know them, right? ; Patient: Yeah, it's my uncle. ; Therapist: Your uncle. ; Therapist: And you need to be clean for, what is it, about two months? ; Patient: Yeah, I think two to three months. ; Therapist: So you have kind of opposing forces here, right? ; Therapist: You have your enjoyment of the marijuana and then you, you know, that's something you like, you don't want to give up and you believe you should have a right to do that. ; Therapist: But then there's that job. ; Patient: Yeah, I mean my parents are pretty cool with it. ; Patient: They know but I mean I'm at the point now where they kind of want me to move on and move out. ; Patient: But I don't know. ; Patient: I mean it'd be nice to have that job. ; Patient: I think it's a really good job but at the same time like I don't see why I have to sacrifice something that I like. ; Therapist: So it doesn't seem fair to you but you recognize it's the reality of your situation. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So it really does come down in your instance to marijuana use or employment. ; Patient: Yeah, it's pretty accurate. ; Therapist: So you're not happy about that choice. ; Patient: Not at all. ; Therapist: And kind of what we did with the postponed gratification was just, I mean I really just asked you to wait 10 minutes and you were able to do that and more, although it was difficult. ; Patient: It was difficult. ; Therapist: It was difficult for you. ; Therapist: So I asked you to track the number of times you smoked marijuana. ; Therapist: Were you able to track that over the last week? ; Patient: Yeah, for the most part. ; Therapist: Do you remember how many times that was? ; Patient: I think I did like 15, 15, 15, and 20. ; Therapist: Between 15 and 20. ; Therapist: And how many times did something kind of get in the way? ; Therapist: Did something else come up in that 10 minute span that distracted you or that you enjoyed? ; Patient: I would say 10. ; Patient: Like almost closer to 20 times I guess. ; Patient: Otherwise I probably would have kept going and smoked more. ; Patient: I mean there were a couple times where somebody would call me or somebody would text me and that kind of distracted me. ; Patient: So I would have put it off for a little bit. ; Therapist: So you can see in that 10 minutes things can happen. ; Therapist: Things can happen that can help you to avoid the marijuana. ; Therapist: Sometimes nothing does and after the 10 minutes you use it and sometimes something does kind of get in the way with the marijuana, like distract you or you have another activity that you enjoy and then you didn't use. ; Therapist: So with that in mind, you found the experience rough but was it tolerable? ; Patient: Yeah, it wasn't bad. ; Therapist: Was it bad? ; Therapist: Do you think for this next week we could try postponing that gratification from 10 minutes to 20 minutes? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: That seems kind of, that seems like a longer time. ; Therapist: That is definitely, that is a longer time. ; Patient: I don't know about that. ; Patient: Maybe like 15 minutes. ; Therapist: You want to compromise at 15? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: You think you could maintain 15 minutes, weigh 15? ; Patient: I think I could try a little bit more than 20. ; Patient: It would be a little easier than 20. ; Therapist: Alright, so let's go with 15 minutes. ; Therapist: So 15 minutes as compared to 10, that will give you 5 extra minutes that something could happen that could distract you and you wouldn't use in that instance, right? ; Therapist: There's also, you know, to constructively use that time, you could consider alternatives like you mentioned walking, right? ; Therapist: You could use that time and start walking. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: Anything else that you, like maybe in the past on occasion when you wanted to use marijuana but you didn't have anything available, what would you do instead, if anything? ; Patient: Binge watch TV. ; Therapist: Watch TV? ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Well, so perhaps in that 15 minute time period, that time you're delaying using marijuana, you could start watching a show that you like? ; Patient: Yeah, I could do that. ; Therapist: At the end of 15 minutes, you might end up using marijuana or you might want to continue watching the show. ; Therapist: So do you see kind of how it works? ; Therapist: Like is it making sense to you, the postponing? ; Patient: Yeah, it doesn't make it any easier but... ; Therapist: It's tough for you, yeah. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: No, I definitely see how it helps. ; Therapist: And maybe if we're successful with the 15, who knows, we could move it up from there. ; Patient: Maybe. ; Patient: We'll see how the 15 goes. ; Therapist: We'll see how it goes with the 15, yeah. ; Therapist: We'll see how that goes. ; Therapist: You know, I'm hoping, and I hope this kind of makes sense, that there'll be a point where you'll be really interfering with the vast majority of the times that you use marijuana. ; Therapist: Because you're giving yourself that many more opportunities the longer you wait. ; Therapist: The more minutes you wait, the more opportunities for something else to get in the way, so to speak. ; Therapist: And probably what you'll see, just like you saw this last week, is you used marijuana less frequently just by waiting the 10 minutes. ; Therapist: Even though you describe it as difficult, and I'm sure it was, but there were a few times where it kind of worked out. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So I think that planning something for that time would be helpful. ; Therapist: Try to plan something for 15 minutes. ; Therapist: Even if you fully intend at the end of the 15 to go right and use, I think it's still useful to plan something in there. ; Therapist: And you never know what all that might take you. ; Therapist: You might end up walking or watching TV or doing something else that would distract you or pull you away from the marijuana use. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So does that sound like a plan? ; Patient: Yeah, I think I can give that a try. ; Therapist: Good. ; Therapist: I think it would be the same thing if you could kind of write down the number of times that you used, like mark each time you used, and kind of what happened in terms of the 15 minute wait. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: Actually, I guess more accurately, every time that you initiate a 15 minute wait period would be a good time to note it. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Right, because the idea is that something's going to come up and that you're going to have an opportunity to distance yourself from the use and you won't use as much. ; Therapist: So I want to kind of get an idea of the thought process that's occurring as you start that 15 minute, right, and if you end up using, what happened then, if you end up not using, kind of like the outcome for each possible scenario. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: And then we can kind of analyze that and we can see if moving the minutes up would be ; Therapist: something we could do. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Does that sound like a plan? ; Patient: Yeah, I think I can manage that. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: We'll go with that and I'll see you in a week. ; Patient: Okay.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name corleto; ; Clinical Identifiers: Outpatient ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Behavioral technique was introduced in the last session where she it was decided to postpone her urge to smoke for 10 minutes every time she felt like it. ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Smoking marijuana ; History: Present history patient has been smoking marijuana and finds it difficult as well as unnecessary to quit smoking. She would smoke for more than 20 marijuanas. She started working and was suggested by her uncle to quit smoking and come out clean for 2 months. According to the patient, her parents have no objection with this habit and she herself wishes to continue it but is only trying to quit as she wishes to hold a job. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: General behavior rapport was established and patient was cooperative. She was receptive of therapy and took an active participation; judgement personal judgement impaired. ; Psychotherapy Type: Behavioral therapy ; Psychotherapy Technique : Delayed gratification ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patient was able to resist her urge of smoking by postponing it to 10 minutes and was also able extend it for an hour by indulging in different social activities that came her way. ; Reflections by the therapist: Patient has been adhering to the treatment but she was less motivated for it. She has been doing it for her job. It was suggested to increase the delay for 20 minutes from 10 minutes. She was reluctant to it and the mutually decided time was 15minutes during which she can use distraction like going for a walk or binge watch tv. ; Action Plan : Extend delayed gratification 15 minutes ; Next session details: After 1 week

dialogue: Therapist: Watch what happens this time when the youth minister allows the team to tell his story and guides him to consider how his drinking could interfere with his goals and to think about how he might benefit from making a change. ; Therapist: So Tommy I wanted to talk to you because I was on Facebook the other day and saw some pictures from a party you were at and made me a little bit concerned because I saw you were drinking and I wonder if you can tell me a little bit about how alcohol fits in your life. ; Patient: I mainly just drink whenever I'm at parties or whenever somebody hands me a beer I'll take sips every now and then but it's not something that I feel hovers around my life. ; Therapist: It's kind of a social thing for you not like a major priority. ; Therapist: How much do you think you're drinking? ; Patient: I guess I would say like every other weekend maybe every two weeks on occasion maybe if there's a basketball game going on or a football game I'll have a beer just to drink with my boys but other than that I don't really see it as much of a problem. ; Therapist: So you're drinking maybe half the time depending on what's going on that weekend? ; Patient: Yeah I guess you can say that. ; Therapist: How would you describe the difference between weekends when you drink versus ones when you don't? ; Patient: When I'm not drinking I'm usually more involved in doing more productive things like I try and do more school work whenever I have the time or whenever I can go work out or something just to like whenever I'm drinking I devote my time to just letting loose and having fun and just relaxing with friends. ; Therapist: So you feel like you get more stuff done on weekends when you don't drink but maybe you don't feel like you can relax as well. ; Patient: Yeah I mean whenever I'm drinking I know that I'm devoting time to not doing other things so I try and make it so that I don't allow myself to pile on so much work so I try and like get work done before but I know that drinking gets in the way of productivity so I try and minimize that as much as possible. ; Therapist: You're trying to be responsible and get your stuff done knowing that the drinking is going to make it harder. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay and but it sounds like are you getting everything done or is some stuff sort of slipping when you drink? ; Patient: Yeah I guess when I drink some things do slip a little bit but just because like when I'm drinking I'm not really focused on what I have to do I'm focused on the moment and just enjoying the time that I have at that time and it's really something that I just it's something of a pleasure giver it's like an enjoyment type of thing. ; Therapist: What are the things you enjoy about the drinking? ; Patient: Just the way that it it sort of like liberates you it makes you it makes you feel like a more confident more energetic person that you don't feel like yourself you feel like a different version of yourself and it's something that you it it's just empowering to a degree. ; Therapist: Okay so you feel liberated or kind of more confident in some ways? ; Patient: Yeah yeah. ; Therapist: Are there any not so good things about drinking? ; Patient: Whenever I drink too much I sort of lose control of myself and I I just like the aftermath of whenever I drink too much or whenever I my friends mix drinks and it just has a harmful effect on my body and that's probably one of the major drawbacks that I have from drinking. ; Therapist: What kinds of things happen? ; Patient: I mainly when when I puke or it's just the the feeling that I get in my stomach if I drink too much is just very overwhelming. ; Therapist: So like you notice it in your body? ; Patient: Oh yeah definitely. ; Therapist: How much do you think is the most you've ever drank in one time? ; Patient: Wow I would say probably at a friend one of my friends had a birthday party recently and he wanted to let loose it was it was just a all the guys were together and they had a couple of friends over and it just turned into one big party and I just I lost it I drank way too much I would say like probably a bottle or two and just some beers along the way like it got to a point where I lost count. ; Therapist: That was out of the ordinary for you to lose count. ; Therapist: What's a more typical amount that you drink? ; Patient: I don't let myself drink more than three or four beers on a given night just because I know I've gotten to the point where I sort of know my limit but I kind of flirt with my limit just to see how far I can go and I think that that sort of is very dangerous to play with fire but I want to see how far I can go just so I know not to go that far. ; Therapist: Got it. ; Therapist: So you're sort of testing and pushing it and sometimes crossing that limit and having some of the consequences that you mentioned before. ; Patient: Yeah just so I know how it feels now so that later on when this situation is more drastic and more out of control I know what I can do or where my limit is at. ; Therapist: Okay well kind of along those lines looking ahead you know five years from now what do you see as a goal for yourself? ; Patient: In terms of career wise? ; Therapist: Yeah in terms of what do you think you'll be doing in five years? ; Patient: I would love to be I would love to travel I would love to see the world for what it is and I've always seen pictures and videos of how the world is but I've never really experienced that like I've always wanted to travel to Europe or China or someplace like that so I can really experience the world that we live in. ; Therapist: So getting a full experience is really important to you it sounds like throughout your life you know you talked about wanting to make the most of your high school experience and now you're looking ahead to think of how you can enrich your life in other ways. ; Therapist: How do you think drinking too much would fit into you know being able to experience life to its fullest? ; Patient: I guess it could interfere with allowing myself to feel the effects of living life to the fullest but I wouldn't want to tamper with drinking too much like often just because I know I've seen the consequences that drinking has on people and I know that I would never want to get to a degree where I need to drink constantly every single day. ; Patient: I don't want to ever get to that point. ; Therapist: So just to kind of summarize what you've told me so far you're drinking pretty regularly but you are trying to limit yourself you feel like three drinks maybe is probably the maximum that you can drink before you're having some of these negative consequences and you feel better if you limit yourself to three or less. ; Patient: Yeah I feel more in control. ; Therapist: And then kind of looking ahead you don't want to find yourself being someone who's drinking all the time or someone who feels out of control with their drinking that you've seen that maybe in other people's lives and it's not appealing to you at all. ; Therapist: And you do have some big goals for your life that you want to achieve that drinking too much could also interfere with. ; Therapist: So where do you think you want to go from here with regard to your drinking? ; Patient: Maybe now that I know my limits to an extent I kind of don't want to push it so much. ; Patient: Now that I know what I can do and where I can go I would like to mitigate that as much as possible. ; Patient: I just want to have fun being me but I don't want me to be influenced by alcohol so much. ; Patient: Like I want to live the sober life to an extent but I know that alcohol is just going to tamper with that. ; Therapist: So for right now it feels like a reasonable goal for you would be to sort of limit your drinking and make sure you're stopping at three for example or maybe even limiting the number of times that you're drinking. ; Patient: Yeah and like not drinking in the mornings or just strictly for social purposes. ; Patient: Just to not have it around like I don't want to have it in my fridge if my parents have it. ; Patient: I don't want to have to deal with that. ; Therapist: What do you see as some benefits to that? ; Patient: Benefits in terms of? ; Therapist: To sticking to those limits. ; Patient: I guess I could definitely be, I could live a more fulfilled life to an extent. ; Patient: Like I could possibly be more productive, more efficient in my work and where I can possibly be in the next few years of my life. ; Patient: I think that by not drinking it will definitely have a better effect on my life. ; Therapist: Yeah well I think taking steps to limit and cut back on your drinking is a really good idea. ; Therapist: I really appreciate you taking the time to talk with me about it and being open and honest. ; Patient: My pleasure. ; Therapist: You know if you don't mind I would like to talk to you probably about this in a couple weeks or a couple months and just kind of check in how things are going. ; Patient: Alright sounds good. ; Therapist: Thank you very much. ; Patient: Sure. ; Therapist: This time the youth ministry began by expressing concern but relied on open questions and reflective listening to build rapport and encourage Tommy to share his experiences. ; Therapist: Tommy provided a great deal of useful information regarding his drinking very quickly which set the stage for a more productive conversation. ; Therapist: By exploring both sides of the issue, Tommy was given the opportunity to open up without fear of condemnation and was also able to admit to some of the consequences of his drinking. ; Therapist: This gave him the chance to consider the reasons he might benefit from making a change. ; Therapist: The youth minister also encouraged Tommy to look ahead to consider how his drinking could affect his future plans. ; Therapist: By exploring his values and relating them to his drinking, she developed a discrepancy between his future goals and his current behaviors, highlighting the need to make some adjustments to his drinking. ; Therapist: Using a summary, the youth minister was able to transition smoothly to a discussion of options and Tommy identified a realistic goal for himself that matched his values. ; Therapist: As a result, he is much more likely to follow through on his plans and actually make a change in his drinking. ; Therapist: .
summary: Patient Particulars : Name tommy ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms substance use alcohol chief complaints dependence on alcohol ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behavior cooperative; ; Psychotherapy Type: Dynamic supportive analytical ; Psychotherapy Technique : Reflective listening supportive problem solving ; Issues discussed in Current Session: 1 problem patient has dependence on alcohol which he intends to avoid as it gives negative effects of heavy drinking in others. Patient has experienced negative physical effects, such as nausea and loss of control, when drinking too much, which serves as a deterrent against heavy drinking. 2 willingness to change patient takes a responsible approach to drinking by planning to complete tasks before social events and recognizing the need to maintain control over their alcohol consumption. Patient is open to making changes in their drinking habits to achieve a more balanced and fulfilling life. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Substance use alcohol ; Next session details: Couple of weeks or months

dialogue: Therapist: Hi, this is Dr. Grande. ; Therapist: I hope you find this video useful. ; Therapist: If that's the case, please like it and subscribe to my channel. ; Therapist: As always, thanks for watching. ; Therapist: So when you have... ; Therapist: So let's talk about this. ; Therapist: So those type of thoughts, like I can't make a mistake or something like that, we call those automatic thoughts. ; Therapist: And we'll have plenty of time to talk about the different structures in CBT. ; Therapist: I do want to explain it to you, but over the course of several sessions. ; Therapist: Let's just take pieces of it for now. ; Therapist: So what we believe is that your beliefs combine with the situation and create these thoughts. ; Therapist: So you have this belief, so you're laying in bed before work, and you have this belief that you're maybe not competent. ; Therapist: And then the situation that combines with that is, it's time to go to work. ; Therapist: So the stress of it being time to actually get up and get ready and go to work. ; Therapist: And then you have an automatic thought in that moment. ; Therapist: And right now it's one tied to dread and fear. ; Therapist: Let's try to identify an exact one for this example. ; Therapist: So let's use that scenario. ; Therapist: You believe that you might not be competent. ; Therapist: You're laying in bed and the alarm clock goes off. ; Therapist: So you're kind of pressured to make a decision about, do I get ready for work or not? ; Therapist: What's the thought right then? ; Patient: If I go to work, I'm going to make a mistake. ; Therapist: Going to make a mistake. ; Therapist: So if I go, I'm going to make a mistake. ; Therapist: And then we talked about your reactions, being late, worry, anxiety. ; Therapist: So what we like to do when we identify an automatic thought like that is what's called self-talk. ; Therapist: And at first this may seem a little odd. ; Therapist: So you have this thought that comes through. ; Therapist: It can be an image too, a thought, image, but it's cognitive in nature. ; Therapist: I can't make a mistake. ; Therapist: I'm going to make a mistake. ; Therapist: I'm going to make a mistake. ; Therapist: That's your thought. ; Therapist: And the self-talk, this is like a rehearsed statement that you literally say to yourself, which again, I get that seems a little odd the first time I do it. ; Therapist: So really you're talking to yourself. ; Therapist: But over time, we believe if you can keep applying the self-talk strategy, that you will eventually change the outcome, the reaction, and change the underlying belief. ; Therapist: At first though, it's going to seem quite foreign to you. ; Therapist: Tell me how you're processing this now in terms of... ; Patient: So, I mean, what am I supposed to say to myself, I guess? ; Therapist: That's a good question. ; Therapist: We'll work on that, and that's what we can do now. ; Therapist: Let's take a look at some self-talk, some adaptive responses that we can build. ; Therapist: So I'm going to make a mistake. ; Therapist: That's the automatic thought. ; Therapist: What's directly leading, seems to be, to feelings of worry, dread, and physically not getting to work on time? ; Therapist: Have there ever been times when you've had that thought, and you went to work on time still? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: What was different about those times? ; Patient: I guess I told myself I have to get to work on time, because if I don't, it's going to be even worse. ; Patient: If I make a mistake and I'm late, then it just compounds, and I guess I would tell myself it's going to be okay. ; Patient: You just have to get through this day. ; Therapist: Alright, so when you do that, in essence, you are applying self-talk. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Alright? ; Therapist: So that's really the same thing, except you probably didn't have a label for it. ; Therapist: And when you apply that, it seems to work. ; Therapist: So the message you're kind of sending yourself now, you're telling yourself is, I'm going to make a mistake still, but if I'm late for work, it'll be worse. ; Therapist: So there's a little bit of positive and negative in the... ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: That's okay. ; Therapist: Right? ; Therapist: Self-talk doesn't have to be all positive. ; Therapist: Self-talk needs to be, I think more than anything, realistic. ; Therapist: And sometimes realistic includes a little negativity. ; Therapist: I'd rather focus on the more positive elements as we build this as possible, though. ; Therapist: So that's pretty good self-talk you have now. ; Therapist: Let's work on refining it a little bit to maximize its benefit.
summary: Therapist Information : Name grande ; Past Session Information: Follow up ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms fear of making mistake ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior cooperative ; Psychotherapy Type: Cbt; mode individual. ; Psychotherapy Technique : Psychoeducation ; Issues discussed in Current Session: 1 understanding cbt 2 self talk 3 automatic thought 4 adaptive thoughts ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Not clear

dialogue: Therapist: How you doing today? ; Patient: I'm alright. ; Therapist: You alright? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: There's been some changes in my life, but, um, yeah. ; Therapist: Good changes? ; Patient: Eh, not really. ; Therapist: Not really? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: What kind of changes? ; Patient: You know, just, you know, you know I lost my job, so things are kinda, you know, domino effects from that, so. ; Therapist: So there's been consequences from those in your job? ; Patient: Yeah, I mean obviously, that's, you know, you have a job, so you can take care of certain things, so. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Like what things? ; Patient: Like, you know, like paying your bills, and that's pretty much it, I guess that's really why most people have a job. ; Therapist: So you've been unable to pay your bills? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah, definitely. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: How's your mood overall? ; Patient: I mean, what can I say? ; Patient: I lost my job. ; Patient: I'm seeing you because I have a drinking problem, so things are not that great. ; Therapist: Things are not great? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Tell me about the drinking now. ; Therapist: How's it been going? ; Patient: I drink a lot. ; Patient: Um, I always say to myself that I'll try to drink less, but at this point it's kind of like, what have I got to lose, you know? ; Therapist: Are you drinking more? ; Patient: Yeah, yeah, yeah. ; Therapist: A lot more? ; Patient: Yeah, I mean, not a lot more, I mean I guess I have more free time now, so. ; Patient: Because of not having a job. ; Therapist: What effects do you think that you're experiencing because of the increased drinking? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: I don't know. ; Therapist: Are you feeling good about the drinking? ; Patient: At this point it's kind of like, who cares, like what difference does it really make, you know? ; Therapist: So you're indifferent towards the drinking? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: When you're drinking does it still feel good? ; Patient: Nothing really feels good. ; Therapist: No? ; Therapist: Does it just get you back to normal? ; Patient: Yeah, pretty much. ; Therapist: When's the last time you drank? ; Patient: This morning. ; Therapist: And how much? ; Patient: A lot, I don't know. ; Therapist: You don't recall? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Is that typical? ; Patient: I mean, I don't recall you drinking on the same day that we've had sessions before. ; Patient: I mean, at a certain point it's like, you know, difficult to wake up and not have a drink. ; Patient: Like to get through the day. ; Patient: So, yeah, I mean I just drink as much as it takes for me to function and I don't really know how much that is. ; Patient: Like I don't sit there and count it like, these are my three shots for the morning. ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: Like I get up, I drink some to make me feel better. ; Patient: I keep some alcohol by my bed because it's hard when I wake up in the morning, like, it's just really difficult to like get out of bed without having a drink. ; Patient: So I'll drink some then, you know, and just to function. ; Patient: So I don't know how much. ; Patient: I don't know. ; Therapist: But you feel as though it's worsened, like you're drinking more. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: What would you say your attitude toward increased drinking is right now? ; Patient: I'm pretty indifferent, like I said. ; Patient: I mean, I just don't, I don't, at this point it's like, what does it matter? ; Patient: Like everything else has, I don't know. ; Therapist: So a couple of times you indicated that you're indifferent toward it, right? ; Therapist: And why I'm curious about that is because that's not been the way that you've appeared before. ; Therapist: You appeared before to be unhappy that you were drinking. ; Therapist: And now it's more or less something that you don't have strong feelings about one way or the other. ; Patient: I guess I just don't know why I should keep suffering and like making myself suffer. ; Therapist: So the drinking takes away the suffering. ; Patient: No, the feeling bad about the drinking makes me suffer. ; Therapist: The feeling bad about the drinking. ; Patient: And yeah, I mean, yes, the drinking takes away the suffering, but that's not what I meant. ; Therapist: So feeling guilty about drinking, that's what's causing you problems. ; Patient: That, I mean, I don't know if that's what's causing me problems, but at this point it just seems pointless to keep making myself feel guilty about it is what I'm saying. ; Therapist: How would you like to feel about it? ; Patient: I would like to not, I would like to be happy. ; Patient: I would like to not drink. ; Patient: I would like to have a good life. ; Patient: But at this point I'd rather just, I don't know, like why should I keep feeling guilty about it? ; Patient: What is the point? ; Patient: Like what is the point of this life where I have no job and I'm going to lose my house and, you know, I just don't get it. ; Patient: Like why do you want me to keep feeling guilty about my drinking when everything else is not working? ; Patient: It's not working. ; Patient: And so I'm just supposed to like keep trying. ; Patient: I don't get that anymore. ; Patient: I don't get it. ; Therapist: So you no longer understand the point of life? ; Patient: Yeah, I mean, yeah. ; Patient: As it is, like this just doesn't make any sense to me. ; Patient: Like why should I keep fighting to be sober if I can't, you know, I lost my job. ; Patient: It's too late for that. ; Patient: Like the whole point of coming to you is to, you know, have a better life. ; Patient: Things are getting worse. ; Patient: I'm not saying it's your fault. ; Patient: I'm just saying like what's the point of this if it's not getting better? ; Patient: And things are getting so bad that even if I was sober I wouldn't be able to handle it. ; Therapist: So what do you see as your options right now? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Therapist: Can you tell me about some of the things you've been doing recently, like in the last three or four days? ; Patient: Sitting at home drinking? ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: That's about it. ; Patient: A lot of drinking. ; Therapist: Anything else? ; Patient: Yeah, going to the liquor store. ; Patient: That's about it. ; Patient: I mean, seriously, it's just funny. ; Patient: Like I don't even... ; Patient: There is nothing. ; Therapist: Now I know you were working on a few things, like you were working on finding another job. ; Therapist: Have you been doing that? ; Patient: No, not really. ; Patient: I mean, I'm going to lose my house, so I'm just biding my time until that happens. ; Patient: I don't really know. ; Patient: Like, yeah, no. ; Patient: I'm not looking for a job, no. ; Therapist: So you stopped looking for a job. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: And when are you losing your house? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: It's hard to tell, you know, with the banks and everything, but it seems like it will be soon. ; Therapist: And what's your plan for when that happens? ; Patient: I don't have one. ; Therapist: You don't have one? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Now, before we've talked, and I haven't seen you in a while, you're always pretty careful about planning things out. ; Patient: I've just decided that I'm not going to worry about it anymore. ; Patient: I can't. ; Patient: I just can't do it anymore. ; Therapist: You can't worry anymore? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: My whole life is just full of worrying. ; Patient: I mean, there's nothing to do except to worry about all of it, you know, my job, my drinking, my house. ; Therapist: So what do you see as your alternative to all this worrying? ; Patient: There is no alternative. ; Therapist: So what do you do? ; Therapist: You don't know? ; Therapist: I sense at this time you're much more negativistic as compared to what I've seen you before. ; Therapist: Do you recognize that as being the case? ; Patient: Yes. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Like, markedly so. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Like, I feel like things have taken a turn. ; Therapist: Can you tell me about that turn? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: I just feel like, you know, I'm losing my house, I lost my job, I don't really have anything that needs to be gotten in order. ; Therapist: Got in order for what? ; Patient: Just, you know, in general, like, I don't know, in my own life, like, if something were to happen to me, there wouldn't be anything that needed to be taken care of. ; Therapist: What's going to happen to you? ; Patient: Like if I died. ; Therapist: If you died. ; Therapist: If you died, nothing would have to be taken care of? ; Patient: I mean, like... ; Patient: I mean, they probably have a funeral, but, you know, my house is gone, my job is gone, my drinking will be gone. ; Therapist: Would your family miss you? ; Patient: I don't really care. ; Therapist: Even still, do you think they would miss you? ; Patient: Maybe. ; Patient: I mean, in their own way. ; Patient: They probably would have wished that they would have done different things differently, yeah, but that's not my responsibility. ; Therapist: What's your responsibility right now? ; Patient: Nothing. ; Therapist: Nothing? ; Patient: Nothing. ; Patient: Nothing. ; Patient: I mean... ; Therapist: So, no one would, correct me if I'm wrong, no one would care if you died? ; Patient: I mean, they probably care a little bit. ; Patient: Do I care if they cared? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: So you care a little, but you're not concerned with that. ; Therapist: And you have this sense that you have nothing left to lose because you lost the job, and now, soon, your house. ; Therapist: Do you have anything else that you care about? ; Therapist: Any goals? ; Patient: I used to. ; Therapist: How about now? ; Therapist: No? ; Therapist: What happened to your goals? ; Patient: I drank them away. ; Patient: I lost my job. ; Patient: I lost my house. ; Patient: You know, I was thinking maybe I could find myself a new job, but at this point, I'm just so far gone, like my life is so ruined. ; Patient: I don't know how you could expect me to come back from this. ; Patient: I don't know how you can expect me to live a life, how to pick this up and make something of it, like... ; Patient: How to redeem yourself. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: You can't see a way to do that now. ; Patient: No. ; Patient: I mean, come on. ; Therapist: Because all the things that happened to you overwhelmed you. ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: I mean, happened to me, did to myself. ; Patient: It's just, at this point, it's like I've lost so much of what I worked for, and I don't have one scrap of dignity or anything at all. ; Patient: I don't have anything. ; Therapist: You don't have anything. ; Therapist: You don't have any worth. ; Therapist: Worthless. ; Therapist: That's how you're feeling? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Alone. ; Patient: Worthless. ; Patient: Yeah, like nothing... There's nothing redeemable. ; Patient: There's nothing I can build upon. ; Therapist: So you've lost everything. ; Therapist: You're worthless, and you can't be redeemed. ; Therapist: So of all the time I've been treating you, this is the most severe I've seen in your hopelessness. ; Therapist: Would that be accurate? ; Patient: This situation is more dire than I ever thought that I would have to experience. ; Patient: You know, when I started seeing you, I thought, this is as bad as it can get, and I have to fix things now, or, you know, I can't go on like this. ; Patient: Like, I can't... This is as bad as my life can get, and I cannot let it continue to get any worse. ; Patient: But things have gotten worse, and... Yeah. ; Therapist: Aaron, have you been thinking about ending your life? ; Therapist: Are you hesitant to tell me that? ; Therapist: Why is that? ; Patient: I guess... a lot of reasons. ; Patient: Um... I know that we have worked together, and I don't want you to feel like you've failed. ; Patient: I really don't want you to try to do anything, because I feel like nothing that you have tried has worked. ; Patient: You know, I'm a hopeless case, and I feel like at this point it shouldn't even be your responsibility to try, because it's not fair to you anymore. ; Patient: And... I don't know, I just... ; Therapist: Are you planning on ending your life? ; Therapist: Like, do you have a plan in place? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Can you tell me about the plan? ; Patient: I don't really want to talk about it. ; Therapist: But you have a plan. ; Therapist: You don't want me to interfere in your plan. ; Patient: No. ; Patient: No, obviously not. ; Therapist: But you're aware that I'm going to try to interfere with your plan. ; Patient: I guess so. ; Therapist: You mentioned earlier that you just... I mean, it sounds like what you're saying is you've hit rock bottom. ; Therapist: And rock bottom can't be tolerated. ; Therapist: And... your family would care if they lost you, but you're indifferent to that. ; Therapist: Right? ; Therapist: I would care if you died. ; Therapist: Alright? ; Therapist: I'm going to do everything I can to prevent that. ; Therapist: It's hard to see when you have thoughts of worthlessness. ; Therapist: It's hard to see strengths. ; Therapist: But I see something with strengths. ; Therapist: I see a young lady that over the last few months has told me about all kinds of strengths. ; Therapist: All kinds of situations where you've been resilient. ; Therapist: Do you recall those conversations? ; Patient: I guess. ; Therapist: But that's not in the forefront of your mind right now, your strengths. ; Therapist: But they're still there. ; Therapist: Do you have an intent to commit suicide? ; Therapist: And you don't want me to stop you? ; Therapist: I'm going to stop you. ; Therapist: Alright? ; Therapist: I want to, I'm obligated to, and it's really the best thing to be done. ; Therapist: Is to prevent it. ; Therapist: I know you feel this way now, and I know I can't fully understand that. ; Therapist: But I'm fairly sure that you won't feel this way a week or two from now. ; Therapist: Feelings of worthlessness, feelings of hitting rock bottom, they cycle just like all feelings. ; Therapist: You've had ups and downs before. ; Therapist: Remember? ; Therapist: I see somebody with a long and productive life ahead of them. ; Therapist: Suicide's not the answer. ; Therapist: I know it seems like the only option right now. ; Therapist: I get that. ; Therapist: But there's still some other options. ; Therapist: Does that make sense? ; Therapist: I know you probably don't want to hear about other options. ; Therapist: I think what we should do today is get you over as an impatient. ; Therapist: Alright? ; Therapist: And they'll probably keep you for five, ten days. ; Therapist: And kind of work on getting your mood stable. ; Therapist: My guess is when you come out, you'll feel differently on this subject. ; Therapist: You'll feel a little better. ; Therapist: Maybe a little better place where you can continue. ; Therapist: And we will. ; Therapist: I'll see you, we'll schedule this, I'll see you on the day, or the day after you come out. ; Therapist: Preferably on the same day. ; Therapist: Does that make sense to you? ; Patient: I mean, I guess. ; Therapist: Are you disappointed that I'm trying to save your life? ; Therapist: Do you understand why I'm doing it? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: So I'm going to walk you over to one of the other counselors. ; Therapist: I'm going to make some phone calls. ; Therapist: And we'll get you over there, okay? ; Patient: Alright. ; Therapist: Thanks, Aaron.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name angela; sex female; marital status unmarried ; Clinical Identifiers: Setting outpatient ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Follow up session patient was unhappy with her drinking issues and was maintaining better earlier. ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Sense of compulsion to take alcohol 2. Increased quantity of alcohol intake 3. Progressive neglect of alternate pleasures 4. Ideas of suicide 5. Ideas of unworthiness ; History: Course fluctuating; progress deteriorating; perpetuating factor losing job; present history patient was maintaining well until last session. She was resilient and had some goals to achieve. She used to consume alcohol and was seeking therapy meanwhile and was maintaining well until this week, when she reported losing her job and feeling worthless. She lives away from her family; substance use history she used to consume alcohol. ; Crisis Markers: Active suicidal ideations; duration 1 week ; Current Mental Status Examination: Thought content- it reflected worry regarding losing her job and losing her house in near future  hopelessness; mood dysphoric; affect restricted; judgement personal judgement impaired. ; Psychotherapy Type: Type person centered therapy; mode of therapy individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Reflective listening, empathy, crisis intervention ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patient recently lost her job and had been feeling difficulty to cope with her current phase. She finds it difficult to manage her expenses and has been relying on alcohol for even basic functioning. She also mentioned about her suicidal ideations ; Reflections by the therapist: Patient was careful of her actions before and had certain goals on life she wanted to achieve. Until this session, she had taken a negativistic turn towards her life where she seemed careless and totally hopeless for her future due to which she had made an active plan to commit suicide. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Dependence syndrome comorbid with depressive episode ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: Crisis intervention, patient will be admitted.

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Jackie, how are you doing today? ; Patient: I'm doing alright. ; Therapist: How about you? ; Therapist: I'm doing well. ; Therapist: Thanks for asking. ; Therapist: I understand you've had some recent difficulties and that brought you into our agency. ; Patient: Yeah, I'm having some problems with friends and family, relationships I guess in general. ; Therapist: Relationships? ; Patient: Yeah, I have a lot of stuff. ; Therapist: You have a lot of stuff? ; Patient: Yeah, a lot of stuff. ; Therapist: Like where you live? ; Patient: Yeah, my house is full of things and it's kind of embarrassing. ; Patient: I don't like to get rid of things. ; Patient: I worry that I'm going to need them or something. ; Patient: So yeah, it's overflowing my house with stuff. ; Therapist: So there's a lot of stuff in your house and this is affecting your relationships? ; Patient: Yeah, you know, all the stuff is taking over my house. ; Patient: There's no room for anyone to really come over and visit me which has really become your problem. ; Patient: You meet people and it's normal to go over to their house and have lunch or whatever. ; Patient: And I get really embarrassed. ; Patient: I don't want people to do that. ; Patient: I don't want my family even coming over. ; Patient: My sister was over last week and she threw something away. ; Patient: She threw this newspaper away from two years ago and I freaked out. ; Patient: What if I need that? ; Patient: Those things are important to me. ; Patient: So that's kind of putting a strain on my relationship with my family in that way. ; Patient: I think they're the only ones probably that would feel brave enough to actually do something like my sister did. ; Therapist: To throw something away? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah, so it's embarrassing that I can't have my friends over. ; Patient: What it's like to have my family over and I just can't. ; Patient: I don't know what to do. ; Therapist: So you mentioned your house is overflowing. ; Therapist: How cluttered can you describe it? ; Patient: There's room for me to live in there. ; Patient: There's a path from my front door to the kitchen, to the bedroom and the bathroom. ; Patient: Sometimes it's blocked by stuff but when things fall or whatever, pretty much my whole house is full of things. ; Therapist: What type of things? ; Therapist: You mentioned a newspaper. ; Patient: I don't like to get rid of cards or newspapers or magazines, mail, things like that. ; Patient: But I've also collected things over the years. ; Patient: I inherited the house from my grandmother so all her stuff was in there. ; Patient: I really can't get rid of that. ; Patient: It has a lot of sentimental value to me. ; Patient: My things have just been piled up on her things. ; Therapist: So you have a lot of stuff in the house and it's congested but you're able to move around and live there. ; Patient: Yeah, I'm not freely able to move around but it works for me. ; Therapist: But it'd be difficult or it is difficult when other people come by. ; Patient: Yes, they wouldn't really be able to be in there. ; Therapist: Some of these items you said you received when you received the house, do you ever go out and buy things and bring them in? ; Patient: Yeah, I like to go shopping. ; Patient: I like to get the yard sales on the weekends. ; Patient: I'm kind of a deal hunter so if I see something on sale I don't want to pass it up. ; Patient: If it's a good deal I might not be able to come back to it. ; Patient: I do like to buy things. ; Therapist: How often do you buy things?
