; Patient: I probably like, on the weekends I go to yard sales. ; Patient: I usually buy a few things every weekend from yard sales. ; Patient: They're such good deals. ; Patient: I make a trip to the mall or DJ Maxx once a week at least. ; Patient: So I usually buy something then too. ; Therapist: Does your vehicle have stuff in it now that you bought? ; Patient: Yes, I actually picked something up that I saw that was for sale on the side of the road on the way here. ; Patient: It was a little bedside table. ; Patient: So it was only a few bucks so it was fun. ; Therapist: Alright, so you have some things you buy, you have some things that you otherwise obtain that are in the house. ; Therapist: They're already there. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And you have trouble parting with them. ; Therapist: Have you ever tried to throw anything out or give anything away? ; Patient: People have suggested that I do that but I just can't bring myself to do that. ; Patient: My sister came over, she tried to give her something for me. ; Patient: I couldn't do it. ; Patient: It's too hard. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: I just think I might need it. ; Patient: What if I need it? ; Patient: What if I want to look back and reference that newspaper that she tried to throw away? ; Patient: I won't have it. ; Therapist: So what would you like to gain from counseling? ; Patient: I would like to be able to get rid of things. ; Patient: I would like not to worry so much when I do or when someone wants me to. ; Patient: So I can kind of gain relationships with people. ; Patient: People don't really like to come over. ; Patient: I mean they don't like to come over. ; Patient: I don't like them to come over. ; Patient: It kind of puts a strain on relationships, especially dating relationships. ; Patient: I don't want to tell people about it. ; Patient: I don't want people to see that. ; Patient: That's embarrassing to me. ; Patient: So significant others kind of think that's weird and that kind of, I think I'm shady because I don't want them to come over. ; Patient: I have something to hide or something. ; Patient: I mean I do but they don't know that's what it is. ; Therapist: So you'd like to be able to throw things out? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Clear out your... Yeah, a little bit at a time. ; Patient: I don't think it's going to happen right away but I'd like to get there eventually. ; Therapist: Just start working on it? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Alright, I have a couple other questions. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Do you have any medical problems? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Any history of mental health disorders? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Drug and alcohol use? ; Patient: I mean I drink socially with friends. ; Therapist: Drink socially? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Nothing else? ; Patient: No, that's it. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: And you're doing okay at work? ; Patient: Mm-hmm, yeah. ; Patient: I love my job. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Is there any problems there? ; Patient: No, I work as a call receiver, the call center. ; Patient: I get along with everyone. ; Patient: The boss thinks I do a great job. ; Therapist: Okay, great. ; Therapist: Alright, Jackie, if you're okay with it, I'll get you in to see a counselor. ; Therapist: We'll get that scheduled? ; Patient: Yeah, I look forward to that. ; Therapist: Okay, great. ; Therapist: Thanks.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name jackie ; Clinical Identifiers: Agency ; Therapist Information : Psychiatrist ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms 1 difficulty in maintaining relationships, 2 feels sad chief complaints 1 not able to declutter the house 2 difficulty in hanging out with people and inviting them at her house. ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior; speech coherent, mood  affect low, congruent, thought negative, perception distorted, cognitive functions disturbed, judgement and insight poor and intact ; Issues discussed in Current Session: There are following themes in the session 1 hard to declutter patient has hoarding tendencies coming from her emotional attachments, which are impacting her relationships and quality of life. 2social isolation patient made herself isolated as she feels embarrassed to have friends and family over. This creates barriers to intimacy and connection. 3willingness to change patient has a desire for change and acknowledges the need to address her hoarding tendencies. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Mild depression ; Action Plan : Asked to schedule a meeting with counselor ; Next session details: No

dialogue: Therapist: Hi, this is Dr. Grande. ; Therapist: I hope you find this video useful. ; Therapist: If that's the case, please like it and subscribe to my channel. ; Therapist: As always, thanks for watching. ; Therapist: Well, I could see these types of decisions where you're talking about potentially breaking families up and having real consequences to families. ; Therapist: I could see how these decisions could be... ; Therapist: I mean, I'm sure there's guidelines you are supposed to follow that you really don't have a whole lot of choice in. ; Therapist: But you could also really agonize and overanalyze a decision like that because the consequences are so great. ; Therapist: You feel like that could be happening? ; Patient: Yeah, I think so. ; Patient: I mean, you're right to a certain extent, we have guidelines and everything like that, but I also feel like certain things that just isn't black and white and I have to make a judgment call. ; Patient: And I used to trust my judgment, but now I feel like, how do I know that I'm making the right decisions? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Well, and this is really one of the key parts of what may be causing this distress is, we talked about this insecurity, you're unsure. ; Therapist: So one question may be, did you make an efficient or less efficient decision with this particular family? ; Therapist: But the larger question is, you as a person, can you do this job? ; Therapist: And if you do it and make a mistake, what do you do then? ; Therapist: Could you go through this again? ; Patient: Yeah, I think that's where the fear is, is that if 99 times out of 100 I do it right, there's still going to be that one that I messed up. ; Patient: And I'm starting to feel like that one mistake could be life-changing for somebody. ; Therapist: And it could be. ; Therapist: Yeah, you're certainly in a job where, like most jobs where mistakes have consequences, you also do a lot of good for a lot of people. ; Therapist: So by you not being in the field, they're not getting the benefit of the skills you have. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I guess that's true. ; Patient: Like, yeah, maybe somebody else could come and replace me, but do I think that they would be better at it? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: I feel like I was pretty good at it before I started to have all these doubts. ; Therapist: So mostly this was good until this incident. ; Therapist: Well, all right, let's look at this from another point of view. ; Therapist: You really seem like you can empathize with these families. ; Therapist: To me, it seems like you really know what they're feeling. ; Patient: Yeah, I care about them. ; Therapist: And appreciating their perspective, take a moment and try to walk in their shoes. ; Therapist: If a professional like yourself came to you in your family situation, and maybe you're engaged in the activities where it was warranted that your family be broken up temporarily, what would you want, how would you want them to process that? ; Therapist: Like you're thinking about the caseworker from the point of view of the family. ; Therapist: How would you want them to feel that? ; Therapist: How would you want them to process that decision? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: That's a hard question. ; Patient: I mean, if they took my kids away, even if it was the right thing, I would want them to be at least a little bit, you know, feel a little bit bad about having to make such a hard decision. ; Patient: But I guess if they fell apart every time that they made that kind of decision, they wouldn't be able to help other people. ; Therapist: So from the family's point of view, if you're in that situation, you can appreciate what the caseworker has to do, but you'd like them to have some compassion for you. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: That seems reasonable. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So now flip back into the role you're in. ; Therapist: You made a decision you had to make, although you're second-guessing it. ; Therapist: That's separate. ; Therapist: Do you have compassion for them? ; Patient: For the families that I took, yeah. ; Patient: I mean, I think that might be the problem is I have too much of it, you know? ; Patient: I worry about how they feel, even if maybe taking the kids away was the right thing. ; Patient: It's just like so devastating to lose your kids, whether you're doing the right things or not, you know? ; Patient: You want your kids with you. ; Patient: You want to be able to take care of them, even if you're not doing a really good job at it.
summary: Patient Particulars : Nil ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Name dr grande ; Past Session Information: Follow up session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Feeling distressed ; History: Present history patient had been working on a case where they had to temporarily break the family and take the children away. Patient was disturbed by their own decision and has been having second thoughts about this decision ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behavior patient was cooperative and rapport could be established; mood dysphoric; affect restricted ; Psychotherapy Type: Type cbt; mode individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Cognitive restructuring ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patient had recently handled a case of a family where they were disturbed about her own decision of not being fair to them. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Nil ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Andy, do you want to come on in and have a seat? ; Therapist: I'm Dr Taylor, I'm the on-call psychiatrist for this afternoon. ; Therapist: I got a call this morning from your family doctor, because I think you went to see him this morning along with your mum, and I gather that things have been a little bit difficult for you, you've had some other distressing experiences, so I think your doctor thought it might be helpful for us to have a bit of a discussion about that, to see if I could help. ; Therapist: Would that be alright with you? ; Patient: No, it's fine. ; Therapist: Would it be alright Andy for you to tell me a little bit about what's been going on? ; Patient: Well, you're going to think it sounds stupid, but my housemates are working for MI5, and they're doing stuff to my brain, and they're out to get me. ; Therapist: OK, that must be very difficult for you. ; Therapist: How long has this been going on for Andy? ; Patient: About two months. ; Therapist: And how did you first work out that this was happening? ; Patient: I came home one time and moved the TV to the other side of the room, and I knew then. ; Therapist: What was it that you knew at that moment? ; Patient: That they were for MI5. ; Therapist: Right, OK. ; Therapist: So it's been going on a couple of months? ; Patient: Yeah, this new lecturer started at uni, and he worked for MI5, and he basically drafted me housemates in, turned them against me. ; Therapist: OK, OK. ; Therapist: Now I've noticed a couple of times while we've been talking that you've sort of looked round you into the room as if you're checking for something. ; Therapist: Could I ask you what's happening at those times? ; Patient: Well, I can hear them talking about me. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: Who is it you can hear? ; Patient: My housemates. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: So that you recognise it as their voices? ; Patient: Yeah, I can hear them all the time. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: How many voices can you hear, Andy? ; Patient: Three, there's three of them. ; Therapist: OK, and do they sound real, like my voice sounds, talking to you now? ; Patient: Yeah, it's odd. ; Patient: It's like I can hear them when they're not here. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: So when they're not in the house with you? ; Patient: Yeah, it's like they're in the other room or something. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: And can you hear what they're actually saying? ; Patient: Yeah, they're talking about me. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: They're always talking about me. ; Patient: They're always commenting on everything that I'm doing. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: Can you give me an example of what they would say? ; Patient: Well, like if I'm packing me back to go to uni or something, they'll comment on that, like you've left the house now. ; Therapist: OK. ; Patient: OK. ; Therapist: Anything else? ; Therapist: Do they ever talk to each other, perhaps, about you? ; Patient: Yeah, that's what they do. ; Patient: I mean, and now they know the sort of twig that I know about them now. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: They're saying like I'm making trouble. ; Therapist: OK. ; Patient: And that they're going to sort me out. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: What about actually talking directly to you in the way that I'm talking to you now? ; Therapist: Does that ever happen, Andy? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: So you've been hearing the voices of your housemates. ; Therapist: Have there been any other changes? ; Therapist: Have there been any changes, perhaps, to the way you're thinking? ; Therapist: Sometimes people tell us that they're thinking changes in some way. ; Therapist: So, for example, they might feel that they're getting thoughts put into their head that aren't their own. ; Therapist: Have you had any experiences like that? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I do think things that aren't me. ; Therapist: OK. ; Patient: Like they're putting stuff in my brain. ; Patient: It's not me. ; Patient: I'm not thinking. ; Therapist: So different thoughts in your brain. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: It's stupid stuff as well. ; Patient: It's like the other day I suddenly just started thinking about some woman in Carnation Street. ; Patient: I don't watch any of that crap. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: It's not your kind of thing normally. ; Patient: They're not my thoughts. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: And do you have any idea how that's happening? ; Therapist: Or who's responsible? ; Patient: It's MI5. ; Patient: It's this chip they're putting in my head. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: OK. ; Patient: And I can feel it all the time. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: So you're getting thoughts put into your brain that aren't your own. ; Therapist: What about a different sort of experience? ; Therapist: What about the experience that somehow other people are able to know what you're thinking even though you haven't actually told them? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Nothing like that? ; Patient: They're just putting stuff in my head. ; Therapist: Just putting stuff. ; Therapist: And can I just check Andy as well that you're not getting the experience when your thoughts just stop altogether like you have no thoughts left? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: If anything, there's too much in there. ; Patient: I wish I could unplug it. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: OK. ; Patient: Just get this thing out of my head. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: And you mentioned this chip or this device in your brain. ; Therapist: Do you want to tell me a bit more about that? ; Patient: Well, it's a tracking device so they know where I am at all times and I can feel it moving around, like rotating around. ; Therapist: So you can feel the physical sensation in your brain? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: That must be very difficult for you. ; Patient: I don't know why they're doing this to me. ; Patient: I've done nothing wrong. ; Patient: OK. ; Therapist: Can I just check? ; Therapist: Are there any problems, Andy, with the rest of your body? ; Therapist: Any changes in sensation or any bits that feel different in any way? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: I feel fine. ; Patient: I'm not ill or anything. ; Patient: I just want this thing out of my head. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: It sounds like a very difficult time for you. ; Therapist: Can I ask you, Andy, how are you coping with all this? ; Therapist: How is it affecting you? ; Patient: Well, I know we're leaving my room much and I sort of have to wait until they go out to go down and get some food. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: But they've been doing stuff to my food now. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: What do you think is happening to your food? ; Patient: The poison in it. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: Are you actually eating much at the moment? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: Now, with all this happening, and this sounds like you don't feel very safe, have I got that right? ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: Have you felt the need, I don't know, to take steps to protect yourself in any way? ; Patient: Well, I've got a knife. ; Therapist: OK. ; Patient: And I've got like a baseball bat. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: It's just in case they get in my room. ; Patient: I just don't want to hurt anyone. ; Patient: I just feel like I've got to protect myself. ; Patient: It's like cornering me to do this. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: Have you felt the need to use either the knife or the baseball bat so far? ; Therapist: I'll take it out with you for protection. ; Patient: No. ; Patient: No, I don't want to get caught. ; Therapist: OK. ; Patient: No. ; Patient: It's just in my room. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: Has it ever got so bad, Andy, that you've felt the need to hurt yourself or even kill yourself as the only way out, the only way of coping with this? ; Patient: Well, I thought about getting some pills, but I couldn't leave the house, so I didn't get anything. ; Therapist: And when you say getting some pills, would that be to take an overdose of tablets? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: But you've not actually done anything about that so far. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: In the past, have you ever had any problems either with your temper or getting into fights, being aggressive, either with your housemates or anybody else? ; Patient: No, I'm not that kind of person. ; Patient: I don't want to hurt anybody. ; Patient: They're just driving me to this. ; Therapist: And can I just check again? ; Therapist: You've not been in trouble with the police or anything like that? ; Therapist: No, never. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: With all this that's going on, is there anywhere at the moment, Andy, that you feel safe? ; Patient: My parents' house. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: And have you seen much of your parents recently? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I thought about going back there, but I don't want to drag them into this. ; Patient: I don't want them or if I've known about them. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: And throughout this last couple of months, when you've had all these worries, have you ever worried that your parents might in some way be involved in this? ; Therapist: I thought about it, but no. ; Patient: OK. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: Can I just check out a couple of background things with you, Andy? ; Therapist: You're general health. ; Therapist: Is that OK? ; Therapist: You generally fit and well? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: I'm not ill. ; Patient: There's nothing wrong with me. ; Patient: It's just this thing in my head. ; Therapist: And you're not on any regular medication from your own doctor at this stage? ; Patient: No, I don't take any pills. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: What about other drugs? ; Therapist: And by that I'm meaning alcohol, cannabis, pills, anything else? ; Patient: I don't drink much alcohol. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: And what about drugs like cannabis? ; Patient: Is my mum going to know about this? ; Therapist: No, I think it's something that's important that I hear about, but this wouldn't be something we'd be discussing with your mum. ; Therapist: I smoke a bit of weed. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: Would that be regularly for most days? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And how much would you be spending on weed? ; Patient: I get like a ten bag, it lasts me a day or so. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: So you have a ten bag lasting you a day of weed. ; Therapist: Any other drugs? ; Therapist: I'm thinking in particular things like speed or pills. ; Patient: I've done a bit of speed. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: Is that on a regular basis, Andy? ; Patient: I was grabbing my mates for the weekend, we'd do a bit, but... ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: When was the last time, Andy, that you would have had any speed? ; Patient: About a week or so ago. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: Any other drugs at all? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: No. ; Patient: No. ; Patient: But I know what you're getting at, though. ; Patient: It's not the drugs. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: This is... It doesn't matter how out my face I get, this is constantly there, it's always there. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: I guess the reason I was checking, I think is what you've picked up on, is that sometimes when people are having the kinds of experiences that you are, they find if they take certain drugs it can make things feel a lot worse. ; Therapist: I just wanted to check if that hadn't been your experience. ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: I appreciate from what you're saying that you're really very worried about this MI5 conspiracy and that that's the cause of the difficulties that you're having at the moment. ; Therapist: I just wanted to check with you. ; Therapist: Do you think it could be due to anything else? ; Therapist: I mean, I've obviously met other people who've had similar experiences and sometimes they're extremely stressed, some people might be actually mentally unwell. ; Therapist: And just whether any of these things might be relevant to you at the moment? ; Patient: No, because I'm not ill. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: It's them. ; Patient: And I've read books on this as well. ; Patient: I don't... The government know about them. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: They know that they do this to loads of people. ; Patient: I don't know how they can get away with it. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: OK. ; Patient: I've done nothing wrong. ; Patient: I don't know why they're doing this to me. ; Patient: OK. ; Therapist: I just want it... I just want it to stop. ; Patient: OK. ; Therapist: Sure. ; Therapist: And I think I can appreciate that. ; Therapist: I guess what I'm wondering is whether you think there's anything that someone like me might be able to do to help you as a doctor, that sometimes meeting with someone like a psychiatrist or having medication or for some people even coming into hospital for a short time might be helpful. ; Therapist: Do you think any of those things would help you at the moment? ; Therapist: I don't know. ; Patient: I mean, I'm only here really because I'm a warm-up. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: I've tried to... I don't want to worry her. ; Patient: I've tried to talk to her about it. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: And she doesn't understand. ; Patient: She doesn't really believe me. ; Patient: I mean, do you believe me? ; Therapist: Well, I certainly believe that you're having a really difficult time at the moment. ; Therapist: I guess what I'm not as sure about is what's causing this. ; Therapist: And I'm less sure this is due to MI5. ; Therapist: I guess what I'm wondering is that perhaps you're not as well as you might be at the moment. ; Therapist: I mean, we've been through a lot of questions and what I'm thinking is we need to try and come up with a way of supporting you through this. ; Therapist: So I'm wondering, because I know your mum is... I think she's waiting in the waiting room. ; Therapist: It might be a good chance now to get your mum in and then perhaps the three of us can put our heads together, have a bit of a discussion about where to go from here and try and think of getting you some proper support. ; Therapist: Would that be alright if I got your mum in? ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: If you want to sit there then, Andy, I'll just get your mum. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Okay.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name smith; sex female ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Follow-up session. Discussed about dysfunctional thinking, irrational thinking, the usefulness of these thoughts, and how does it reflect. ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptom anxiety chief complaint 1 guilt 2 catastrophic thoughts ; History: Nil ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior anxious; speech low, mood  affect sad, thought negative, perception normal, cognitive functions distorted, judgement poor. ; Psychotherapy Type: Cbt; mode individual. ; Psychotherapy Technique : Thought challenging and cognitive restructuring. ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Issues discussed in the session 1 problems patient feels guilt and anxiety to able to balance work responsibilities with caring for their sick child. 2 internal conflict she struggled between striving a good parent and a good employee and fell short in both areas, despite objectively fulfilling all the responsibilities. 3 strategies therapist highlighted dysfunctional thought patterns, such as catastrophizing and all-or-nothing thinking which leads to anxiety and guilt. Therapist asked he to engage in self-talk and adaptive responses to counteract negative thoughts and reduce emotional distress. 4 action plan therapist suggested to explore support systems and clarifying expectations with others. dialogue: Therapist: Hi, this is Dr. Grande. ; Therapist: I hope you find this video useful. ; Therapist: If that's the case, please like it and subscribe to my channel. ; Therapist: As always, thanks for watching. ; Therapist: If we could, let's talk about the moment in the presentation again. ; Therapist: I want to try to help you develop some strategies to bring those anxiety symptoms down. ; Therapist: Let's actually go right before the moment. ; Therapist: You're still sitting down and you're getting ready to present. ; Therapist: Let's just say you're second to present, like we've talked about. ; Therapist: They're thinking they're going to see me as anxious. ; Therapist: They're going to think I don't belong here. ; Therapist: These thoughts occur because you have an expectation, a rule, an attitude that you brought into that class. ; Therapist: When you walked into that class, you have these expectations already. ; Therapist: It's perfectly natural. ; Therapist: It's not right or wrong. ; Therapist: Everyone has these beliefs. ; Therapist: Whatever these beliefs are, and we'll talk about that at another point, they combine with the stressor of having this presentation in front of you and the classmates watching you. ; Therapist: They result in these thoughts. ; Therapist: We call them automatic thoughts. ; Therapist: Just like the beliefs, they're not good or bad. ; Therapist: They don't say anything about the person having them. ; Therapist: They're just thoughts. ; Therapist: Actually, they're fairly understandable and natural thoughts. ; Therapist: The problem is that they lead to symptoms. ; Therapist: You're sitting there at your desk and you're thinking, they're going to see that I'm anxious. ; Therapist: They're going to realize I'm not good enough or think I'm not good enough. ; Therapist: What reaction do you have when you have that thought? ; Patient: I guess I'm very observant. ; Patient: I start looking around. ; Patient: I'm sweating. ; Patient: I'm having physical responses. ; Patient: I'm looking around to see if anyone's already looking at me, like hypervigilance. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Distressing symptoms. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: What's something that you could say to yourself in that moment that would maybe get in between that thought and that reaction? ; Therapist: That thought of, they're going to know I'm not good enough or think I'm not good enough and that reaction. ; Patient: I think in that moment, most people are looking at the person who's presenting and not at me. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: So that I could maybe take some deep breaths or try to calm myself down. ; Patient: Maybe look over my notes one more time because they're all watching the person who is presenting, not me. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So some deep breathing, looking over your notes, preparing yourself more, focusing on that and realizing they're not really looking at you anyway at that moment. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Good. ; Therapist: Good. ; Therapist: You bring your notes with you to class? ; Patient: I mean, usually have index cards or maybe some stats on something that I want to look over, like some numbers or something. ; Patient: I don't want to forget. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So you always have those with you? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: It's a matter of can you focus your attention on them? ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: Exactly. ; Therapist: Enough to not forget them. ; Therapist: If you're focusing on that and you're thinking about that, you're not thinking about whatever they might be thinking about. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: Exactly. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: How about the deep breathing? ; Therapist: Is that a strategy you've tried before? ; Patient: A little bit, but with not much success because usually when I think to remember it, I'm in panic mode and then it's really hard. ; Therapist: So you've been able to do it sometimes, just not often? ; Patient: Not consistently. ; Therapist: All right.

dialogue: Therapist: Okay, I want to switch gears again. ; Therapist: I want to talk about risk, like suicide or harming others. ; Therapist: I know all these things don't apply to everybody, but I want to make sure I go through and ask certain questions. ; Therapist: Is that okay? ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Have you ever had a suicide attempt? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: It's a sin to kill yourself. ; Patient: Only God can take your soul away, so that's... ; Patient: No, you can't do that. ; Therapist: So no attempts. ; Therapist: Have you ever had thoughts of suicide? ; Patient: I mean, sometimes when I get really sad, I think that the world would be better without me, but I bring myself out of that. ; Patient: I don't think it's anything I'd ever do, but... ; Therapist: Not something you ever do, but sometimes a thought crosses your mind like that. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Do you remember the last time a thought like that crossed your mind? ; Patient: We were getting evicted from our last place because I just felt like a complete failure. ; Therapist: How long ago was that? ; Patient: That was about a month and a half ago. ; Patient: Yeah, all my friends in the house turned against me because I couldn't pay rent. ; Patient: And it had been like the third month, but not consecutively, so I didn't see the big issue. ; Patient: And so they told me that if I didn't get out, they would call the police. ; Patient: And I had to stay with my sister, and then I just... ; Patient: I felt like a failure. ; Patient: I felt like a failure to myself, to my kids. ; Therapist: So it's a tough time for you. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So you had some... ; Therapist: It sounds like maybe passing thoughts. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: But like I said, it's nothing I could ever do. ; Patient: Ever. ; Therapist: If that ever changes, would you tell me? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I'll tell you. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: So how about harm to others? ; Therapist: Meaning... ; Therapist: Do you ever feel like you have thoughts or do you ever develop a plan to hurt someone else? ; Patient: When I was younger, not anymore. ; Therapist: When was the last time? ; Patient: Probably when I was in high school. ; Therapist: So a while back. ; Patient: Yeah, when I was still in that violent stage in my life, where I would fight. ; Patient: But I never went to anything like, I'll kill this person. ; Patient: It was always just, I'll knock you out, but I won't kill you. ; Therapist: That was a while ago. ; Therapist: Presently, no thoughts of harming anybody else. ; Patient: No. ; Patient: If I ever feel really, really angry, I just gonna punch a wall. ; Patient: I have special plates that I'll throw on the ground and break them. ; Therapist: Like the suicidal thoughts. ; Therapist: If thoughts of harming others do come up, would you tell me about those? ; Patient: Oh yeah. ; Patient: I don't want to go to jail over hurting somebody, so I'd tell you. ; Therapist: Thank you. ; Therapist: Have you ever heard or seen anything that other people have not heard or seen? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Never? ; Therapist: How about under the influence of drugs? ; Patient: Well, when I used to do cocaine, sometimes I would like think that somebody's at the door and they're not at the door, like nobody's there. ; Patient: I think somebody's in the house when there's nobody in the house. ; Therapist: But not under the effect of drugs. ; Therapist: It never happened. ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So, I want to switch gears again. ; Therapist: I want to talk about, if you're okay with this, the goals for counseling. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So the goals that you want to meet by spending this time with me, you know, with treatment. ; Therapist: And your general goals, like your goals in life. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So, let's start with, if you're okay, your goals in life in general. ; Patient: Hmm. ; Patient: Because I haven't really thought much about it, but I would like to just have a real, I mean, I don't care what the job is, just a nice cushy job. ; Therapist: A better job? ; Patient: Yeah, where I can just relax, you know, my kids will have a good future. ; Patient: I'll have a good future. ; Therapist: A better future for your children? ; Patient: Oh, yeah. ; Therapist: Any other general life goals? ; Patient: I guess be drug free. ; Patient: Like I said, I'd really like to quit, but it's hard. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: How about goals specifically for counseling? ; Therapist: Like what you hope to get out of this counseling? ; Patient: I'd like to learn to be less angry. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: And bring my blood pressure down a little bit. ; Patient: Um, sleep more. ; Therapist: More sleep? ; Patient: Eat less. ; Patient: I don't know, I guess try to quit. ; Patient: Try to quit drugs. ; Therapist: Quitting drugs? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: How confident right now are you that you can meet these goals? ; Therapist: Specifically the counseling goals? ; Patient: Like, kind of, I guess, is that an answer? ; Therapist: It's an answer. ; Patient: Kind of. ; Therapist: Kind of confident. ; Patient: Yeah, I mean, like I said, I haven't really moved forward anywhere every time I go to a counseling place, so I mean, I'm willing to give it another shot, but because of my history with it, it didn't really go anywhere in the first place, but I'm willing to try again. ; Therapist: Alright, so you're kind of confident and willing to try again. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: So, throughout this intake, I've asked you a lot of questions. ; Therapist: I want to thank you for answering them. ; Therapist: Do you have any questions for me? ; Patient: No, not really. ; Therapist: So next time I see you, sorry, with you it would be about a week. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: I'm going to start with the actual counseling sessions. ; Therapist: So, I'll still have some questions, but not as many as I've asked today. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Does that make sense, how it's structured? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Alright, so we've completed intake. ; Therapist: I'll still have some more questions, but we'll get to the counseling sessions. ; Therapist: Next week we'll get started working on specific details of what's happened to you and what might be causing it and how you can treat it. ; Patient: Alright. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: So, I appreciate again you taking this time and answering these questions and I'll see you next week. ; Patient: Alright, thank you. ; Therapist: Thanks Rhonda.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name rhonda ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. dialogue: Therapist: Hi, this is Dr. Grande. ; Therapist: I hope you find this video useful. ; Therapist: If that's the case, please like it and subscribe to my channel. ; Therapist: As always, thanks for watching. ; Therapist: Has it made you rethink your entire job and the profession you're in? ; Patient: Yeah, I mean, it's making me think like, you know, if I just had some desk job, like if I just crunched numbers or something, I would never have to have this responsibility. ; Patient: Like, why would they trust me with a job like this? ; Patient: Like I'm just a human being who, you know, doesn't know any better than any other person and I just don't know if I can do this. ; Patient: It's just so much responsibility and I guess, I guess before I felt like I could handle it and now I just feel like it's so much responsibility for one person and I don't think that I can handle it anymore. ; Patient: But I don't want to change jobs because I've been here for so long and I liked it before and I don't know. ; Therapist: You're fearful of this happening again. ; Patient: Yes, yes. ; Therapist: And how you may handle it, what may happen. ; Patient: I feel like it's just around the corner and this isn't even resolved. ; Patient: I'm still afraid of the consequences of this, you know, like what if, you know, these kids are out of their parents' home and I just feel like what if something bad happens to them where they are now and then that's going to fall on me and, you know, people like other, my coworkers know that I'm the one that did this. ; Patient: So like if something happens to the kids, like I'm going to be the one that they're going to blame for it. ; Therapist: So just to make sure I understand, your report, so they were engaging these behaviors and your report is what precipitated them being broken up? ; Patient: Yeah, because, you know, before that, I guess, you know, probably nobody else would have known about it. ; Patient: So I made the report about what was going on and I think, yeah, as a direct result. ; Therapist: All right, let's take a look at the evidence, right? ; Therapist: So in CBT, we like to evaluate evidence and try to look at the facts as we understand them. ; Therapist: Really we want to scrutinize and carefully review the facts and evidence and hold a light to it and try to figure out what's going on. ; Therapist: What would have happened with this family if you hadn't or if no one intervened? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: I mean, it wasn't going great for the kids. ; Patient: It wasn't really a great environment, but I just feel like if I had left it alone, I don't know that the kids would be with their parents. ; Therapist: So they'd all be together. ; Therapist: And you feel like right now, you think with them being apart, that's not as good as if they were together. ; Patient: Yeah, I mean, I guess I feel like it probably wasn't great for them to be there. ; Patient: I mean, that's why I made the report. ; Patient: That's my job. ; Patient: But it just feels like, you know, I just feels like I'm playing God. ; Patient: You know what I mean? ; Patient: Like that I'm just coming in here and spend like five, 10 minutes with a family and then to turn their whole world upside down. ; Therapist: You have a tremendous amount of power. ; Therapist: And if you misuse that power, you could devastate families. ; Therapist: That's maybe what you think happened here. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So going back to what would have happened to them, let me just step back there for a moment. ; Therapist: They would still be together without your intervention. ; Therapist: And that could be a positive. ; Therapist: What about consequences that may be more negative? ; Patient: Well, I mean, like I said, I thought they were using drugs in the home. ; Patient: So that's like a really dangerous situation for kids to be in because you don't know what kind of people are coming in and out of the home, if the parents are going to be, you know, coherent enough to help them if there's an emergency or if the parents are even making them food and taking care of their needs and stuff like that. ; Patient: So I guess in that sense, that's really concerning. ; Patient: And that's a big part of the reason why I made the report. ; Therapist: So you made the report because it's your responsibility, but also you had concerns about their welfare. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: If you could go back and do it again, would you change anything? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: I guess that's just the hardest part for me is like, I feel like I can't make the right decision. ; Patient: I just feel like I don't know if I'm equipped to be the person to make that kind of decision. ; Therapist: So you don't know if you made a good decision or not, and further, you question your ability going forward to make decisions. ; Patient: Yeah, definitely. ; Therapist: And that's the uncertainty, the anxiety.
summary: Therapist Information : Name grande ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms fear and anxiety chief complaints fear of making mistakes, job-related anxiety, ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior cooperative; speech, mood  affect anxious, ; Psychotherapy Type: Cbt; mode individual. ; Psychotherapy Technique : Reflective listening ; Issues discussed in Current Session: 1 problem patient feels significant anxiety about their job responsibilities and doubts their ability to handle the pressure. Feels pervasive fear of making mistakes and the potential consequences of those mistakes, feels overwhelmed by the idea of having the power to make decisions that can significantly alter others lives like family 2 techniques cbt techniques is being used to help the individual process their thoughts and feelings and providing strategies to cope with the stress and anxiety associated with their role. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Anxiety

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Alex, my name is Tony, I'll be your nurse for today. ; Therapist: How are you doing? ; Patient: I'm okay I guess, just waiting for the stitches to come out, it would be nice. ; Therapist: Oh, what happened? ; Patient: Got into a bar fight. ; Therapist: Can you tell me a little bit more about this bar fight? ; Patient: Okay, story time, you ready for this? ; Patient: So, we're out with my girls, having a fantastic time, looking all on fleek and ish. ; Patient: And then this girl, like she has the nerve to stare at me from across the room, it gives me this kind of like this. ; Patient: And then she comes up to me, she bumps into me, she spills my drink, and she comes up and then she's like, I slept with your man. ; Patient: So I'm like, excuse me? ; Patient: So obviously I pushed her, she pushed me kind of thing, and yeah, one thing led to another. ; Patient: I'm here, it's a blur from that point on, but all I know is that cops showed up, I'm here, and I have this to deal with. ; Patient: Fantastic, right? ; Therapist: Well, from what I'm getting here, you were intoxicated at that point in time, and then you had a confrontation with this girl, which led to the bar fight. ; Therapist: Am I missing anything? ; Patient: Oh god, I was more than intoxicated, I was smashed! ; Patient: You should have seen it. ; Patient: But like, this type of thing doesn't happen often, so I don't want you to be sitting here and referring me to some AA, because yo, I'm not an alcoholic. ; Therapist: Okay, so it seems like you get offended, you feel offended being referred to an AA. ; Patient: Yeah, I'm not an alcoholic, no. ; Therapist: Okay, because it labels you as an alcoholic. ; Patient: Yeah, exactly. ; Therapist: Alright, well we do have some time right now, if it's okay with you, I was wondering if we could talk a little bit about your drinking habits? ; Patient: Yeah, sure, what do you want to know? ; Therapist: Well, to you, what is drinking different for you? ; Patient: Well, you know, being 25, that's what we do. ; Patient: We get together, we hang out, we get a couple of drinks, it's me and my girls, we do this all the time, and I love this. ; Patient: It breaks the ice when we go socializing, so meet new people kind of thing, you know, grow a friend circle, it's fantastic. ; Patient: And it definitely relaxes me after a stressful week, and my weeks are so stressful, I need this, you know. ; Patient: So, I mean, yeah, but just so you know, I do drink responsibly and I never drink and drive and I don't intend on doing that. ; Therapist: Okay, so to me, it seems that drinking is your way of relaxing with your friends, it's your way to socialize, and it breaks that ice, right, it helps you socialize. ; Therapist: I also want to say that it's very responsible of you to be drinking and not driving. ; Patient: Thank you. ; Therapist: How has it affected your life? ; Patient: Oh, has it? ; Patient: Well, I mean, now that this happens, I do have it because of that bar fight, and oh, my kid's going to kill me, oh my God. ; Patient: He's going to be disappointed. ; Patient: So I guess you could say that my relationship with Henry, it's been great, fantastic, but he says that when I drink, it's like I'm not myself, it's like somebody he's never met before. ; Patient: And obviously you can imagine the arguments, the fights, and oh, my God, all that stress. ; Patient: It's just, I love him so much, but you know, but it's a stress, and it's like I don't know if we're going to make it. ; Therapist: I see. ; Patient: It's just, oh, my God. ; Therapist: So from my understanding, drinking, it helps you socialize with friends, it relaxes you, it's your way of just, you know, it breaks that ice for you. ; Therapist: But on the other hand, it's causing a lot of arguments with you and your significant other, Henry, and it's causing a lot that all those arguments are leading to a lot of stress in your relationship this point in time. ; Patient: Yeah, I mean, we're engaged, and look how pretty this is. ; Patient: I don't want to lose that. ; Patient: Like, you put it that way, I mean, I'm worried because what's he going to think of me later on in life? ; Patient: What's he going to tell our children? ; Patient: Oh, your mom's an alcoholic? ; Patient: She drank this and they got him to fight? ; Patient: I don't want anyone to ever think of me that way. ; Patient: But at the same time, I mean, I don't want to quit cold turkey. ; Patient: I mean, you must understand how hard this is for me to even be here and talk about it. ; Patient: But I love him so much. ; Patient: I mean, I would do anything for him. ; Patient: And he's going to be so disappointed in me. ; Patient: He hasn't even seen me, oh, my God. ; Patient: I don't know how can I face him. ; Patient: I don't know. ; Therapist: He seems like a very lucky guy to have someone love him that much. ; Patient: I mean, boy, seriously, he's not going to find anybody that loves him as much as I do. ; Patient: Trust me on that. ; Patient: Not going to happen. ; Therapist: So what I'm getting here right now is that you do want to quit. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And it's just partly because this alcohol is leading to the arguments with Henry and it's causing that stress to your relationship. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: I know we spoke about AA earlier and I know you don't really like the idea of it. ; Therapist: But what do you know about AA? ; Therapist: Like what's your, you want to shed some light on that? ; Patient: It's a place where alcoholics go to discuss their problems. ; Patient: And like I said, I'm not an alcoholic. ; Therapist: Well, you're right. ; Therapist: They're from multiple flocks of life and they share their drinking stories. ; Therapist: And everyone just kind of helps each other through this journey of being sober together. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: I know you don't want to join AA at this point in time perhaps. ; Therapist: But hypothetically speaking, would you ever consider joining AA maybe later on down the road? ; Patient: If this is what I have to do to get my guy back, then I'll do it. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Well, on a scale of one to ten, ten being like for sure and one being not really sure about it at all, what would you say where you are on the scale with joining AA? ; Patient: Well, you put it that way. ; Patient: Everything I told you, I would say a six. ; Therapist: A six? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Why would you say a six instead of say a three? ; Therapist: I mean, you're really adamant about not joining AA earlier. ; Patient: Well, it's all about Henry. ; Patient: At the end of the day, it matters to me if I want to keep this engagement. ; Patient: And I will do anything for that man. ; Patient: So of course, if this is what I have to do, then I have to do. ; Patient: This is him, let me tell you. ; Patient: His relationship with me and I with him is so much more important to me than drunken nights at a bar. ; Therapist: You're a lucky man, like I said. ; Patient: I'll tell him that. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: So right now we're sitting at a six. ; Therapist: What needs to happen to say maybe we can jump that to an eight or a nine? ; Patient: You know, like flexible hours maybe, if that is even an option. ; Patient: Also, maybe if there's a place nearby somewhere, like nearby my house, that would be great. ; Patient: So I don't have to waste gas because it's expensive. ; Patient: I already go to work and it's far anyway. ; Patient: And I guess it has to do with attitude as well. ; Patient: I don't want to sit there in a circle like this and somebody judging me because the way I look and my drinking habits and all of that. ; Patient: So I guess I'm just looking for a good vibe. ; Patient: I don't want to be judged or labeled. ; Therapist: All of these are very understandable. ; Therapist: I mean, it's just, of course you want some meeting to be close to you so you don't have to commute so far. ; Therapist: We all have very busy schedules. ; Therapist: That's something that fits within our busy schedule. ; Therapist: It definitely makes sense. ; Therapist: And of course the environment. ; Therapist: I mean, if you're not happy, they're just an even and learning environment. ; Therapist: If you're not comfortable there, then it's very hard for you to be in that environment. ; Patient: Yeah, exactly. ; Therapist: Well, actually today, I was wondering if it's okay with you. ; Therapist: I can give you this for sure. ; Therapist: It's just for an AA meeting, you're really close to your location where you live. ; Therapist: And my number is also on there. ; Therapist: You can always give me a call if you have any concerns. ; Therapist: And also, I just want to thank you today for sharing with me your experience with drinking. ; Therapist: And I know it's not easy to just... ; Patient: No, it's not. ; Therapist: This is a very sensitive subject. ; Therapist: So I want to thank you. ; Patient: Thank you for listening to me. ; Patient: No one has actually sat down and talked to me about anything. ; Patient: I feel like you shed some light on an issue. ; Patient: So thank you. ; Therapist: You're very welcome. ; Therapist: It really means a lot. ; Therapist: You're very welcome. ; Therapist: And if it's okay with you, perhaps maybe we can schedule another follow-up meeting. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Say about two weeks or so. ; Patient: Yeah, that sounds fine. ; Patient: Yeah, that's okay. ; Patient: I think two weeks work. ; Patient: We'll go on from there. ; Patient: Two weeks. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay, I'll see you then. ; Patient: I'll see you then.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name alex; age 25 years; sex female; marital status unmarried ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Name tony; occupation nurse ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Alcohol consumption ; History: Present history patient went to a bar and was intoxicated where another woman initiated an argument with her by confronting her about patients romantic partners infidelity which led to a physical fight; substance use history alcohol consumption; family history patient is engaged. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behavior patient is cordial and rapport could be established; mood calm; affect broad ; Psychotherapy Type: Type solution focussed therapy; mode individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Scaling technique ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patients alcohol consumption habits were discussed. She expressed that she acts different after consuming alcohol that others see her with a different personality. Her reluctance from joining alcohol anonymous group was discussed. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Nil ; Action Plan : To join alcohol anonymous group ; Next session details: After 2 weeks

dialogue: Therapist: Jessica, how are you doing today? ; Patient: I'm well. ; Therapist: You're doing well? ; Patient: That's right, that's good, yes. ; Therapist: I understand you've been having some difficulties recently that have brought you into the agency. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Can you tell me about that? ; Patient: Well, I was in a car accident about a month and a half ago. ; Patient: And I've just been having these issues that are preventing me from doing the things I'm used to doing. ; Therapist: Can you tell me about the accident? ; Patient: Well, I was on my way home from work and I was sitting at a stop sign and waiting for my term to go. ; Patient: And as I proceeded through the stop sign, a car just came and blew through and hit me on the side and pushed me straight through the stop sign. ; Therapist: Were you hurt? ; Patient: Not too bad, no. ; Therapist: Not too bad? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Scary though, huh? ; Patient: It was very scary. ; Therapist: And when was this? ; Patient: This was about a month and I guess maybe two months ago. ; Therapist: About two months ago? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: And when did the symptoms start? ; Patient: Shortly after. ; Patient: I've been feeling pretty bad for about a month or so. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Can you tell me about those feelings? ; Patient: I've had a lot of anxiety, especially when it comes to getting in my car and going places. ; Patient: I just get really overwhelmed with fear. ; Patient: Just scared that I'm going to get into another car accident. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: You are still driving? ; Patient: Not a lot. ; Therapist: Not a lot? ; Patient: Not a lot, no. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: You're not driving a lot, but you are able to drive. ; Therapist: But when you do drive, there's a lot of anxiety. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: There's a lot of fear. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Are you more aware of what's going on around you? ; Patient: Definitely. ; Patient: I think I'm, I would say, over aware. ; Patient: I can't, sometimes I can't even focus on where I'm going because I'm just paying attention to all the drivers on the road. ; Patient: Just, you know, making sure that I don't get hit again. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So you're driving with more awareness of what's going on around you? ; Therapist: Anxious? ; Therapist: Any irritability? ; Patient: Yes. ; Patient: Yes. ; Patient: A lot more than usual. ; Therapist: Can you tell me about that? ; Patient: Well, I have two dogs and I love my dogs. ; Patient: And just lately, everything they do just gets on my nerves. ; Patient: You know, just barking, walking. ; Patient: I mean, everything just, and I don't know where that's coming from. ; Patient: I've never been like that with them before, but they just, they bother me so much that I don't even want them around sometimes. ; Therapist: Have you, since the accent, or since the symptoms started, have you had positive feelings like happiness, joy? ; Patient: No, everything just depresses me anymore. ; Therapist: Everything. ; Patient: Nothing seems to be going right at all. ; Therapist: No? ; Therapist: Not since the symptoms started. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Do you know how when something surprises you and you're startled, right, that's natural for everybody, have you noticed that that startle response is different now after the accent? ; Patient: It is. ; Patient: Everything startles me. ; Patient: Just, you know, a knock at the door or the phone ringing or anything just, yeah, just kind of scares me out of my skin. ; Therapist: So that's more so than it would have in the past? ; Patient: Yeah, I've never been like that before. ; Therapist: Any changes in your concentration? ; Patient: I can't seem to focus on anything. ; Patient: I'm in school and when I have readings to do for school, I just, I get so distracted. ; Patient: I have to close the book and do something else. ; Patient: I can't, yeah, I definitely can't focus when it comes to my schoolwork. ; Therapist: So when you're having trouble concentrating, what kind of thoughts are you being distracted toward? ; Patient: If I have somewhere to go, I'm thinking about, you know, getting in the car and driving and, you know, the possibility of being in another accident. ; Patient: I just, a lot of my thoughts seem to focus on being in my car and just the accident. ; Patient: I can't seem to shake that. ; Therapist: So you've tried to kind of push the thoughts aside and then they're still there? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Any trouble sleeping? ; Patient: Somewhat. ; Patient: I don't have any trouble getting to sleep, but I have trouble staying to sleep. ; Therapist: So you wake up several times? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: At night? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: How about your relationship with other people? ; Therapist: Do you feel there's the same distance or do you feel closer or more detached? ; Patient: Well, my mom is probably the person I'm closest to and I haven't really wanted to spend a lot of time with her anymore. ; Patient: I'm really just staying in the house and just staying to myself. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: How about dreams? ; Therapist: Any change in dreams, like the events of the accident come up? ; Patient: Well, one night there was this dream that stuck out to me. ; Patient: I was driving home from work and I was just about to get on the highway and I heard sirens coming. ; Patient: And I stopped to see where the sirens were going and they got closer and closer to me and they seemed to surround me. ; Patient: And I was like, wait, what's going on? ; Patient: And I woke up and I was like, oh my gosh, I felt like I was right back there in that moment where I was in a car accident and the police responded to the accident. ; Patient: But it was so much more intensified. ; Patient: I've never had a dream like that before. ; Patient: And when you woke up, it sounds like you were alarmed and distressed. ; Patient: I was. ; Patient: I was. ; Therapist: Has that ever happened when you weren't asleep instead of like a dream? ; Therapist: Have you ever had a moment where you're kind of back in the car accident? ; Therapist: You know, in the car as the accident is happening, like it feels like you're really back there? ; Patient: Maybe once or twice, but not really, no. ; Therapist: Not sure? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Do you have any medical problems? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Nothing coming on? ; Therapist: Any use of drugs or alcohol? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Nothing like that? ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: Do you remember all the details of the accident or do you feel like there's pieces of that memory that are missing? ; Patient: I really can't remember the details. ; Patient: I just know I got hit. ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: I can't remember back to what happened and people keep asking me and I just, I can't remember at all really what happened. ; Therapist: Alright, so there's some memory loss surrounding that? ; Patient: Yeah, definitely. ; Therapist: Do you ever have, or since the symptoms have come on, do you ever feel like you're not really yourself, you're separated from yourself, kind of an unreal experience, or you're separated from the world? ; Therapist: Either one of those? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Nothing like that? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Alright, Jessica, based on our conversation here, I'm going to set you up to see a counselor if that's something you're open to. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And I want to thank you for taking the time to tell me what happened and answer my questions. ; Therapist: It's been very helpful. ; Patient: Thank you. ; Therapist: Thanks.

There are vivid and distressing dreams related to the car accident, indicating the impact of the trauma. 6 feelings of dissociation patient experiences symptoms of dissociation, feeling detached from themselves or their surroundings at times ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Fear and anxiety ; Action Plan : Referred to a counselor for support and other interventions. ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Patient: Come in. ; Therapist: Hi, Ms. ; Therapist: Alexander. ; Patient: Hi. ; Therapist: Hi, my name is Brittany and I'm a medical student working with Dr. Parrott today. ; Therapist: I'll try to get this all rubbed in. ; Therapist: It's nice to meet you. ; Patient: Nice to meet you. ; Therapist: So she has sent me in just to ask you some questions and do a brief physical exam, and then I will step back out and talk to her, and then she'll be in behind me. ; Therapist: Is that okay? ; Patient: Yeah, that's fine. ; Therapist: Great. ; Therapist: So what brings you in today? ; Patient: I've been having pretty bad neck pain. ; Therapist: Oh, goodness. ; Therapist: Well, I'm glad you came in so we can take a look and make sure there's nothing going on. ; Therapist: So how long has this been going on? ; Patient: Probably about two days. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Did anything happen a couple days ago out of the ordinary? ; Patient: Well, I was in a small car accident. ; Therapist: Oh, okay. ; Therapist: Must have been scary. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: What happened? ; Patient: I was at a stoplight and the person behind me rear-ended me. ; Patient: We weren't going very fast, though. ; Patient: I think he was maybe going five or ten miles an hour. ; Therapist: And were you wearing your seat belt at the time? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So you said you didn't go to the hospital or anything because you didn't feel any pain initially. ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: So when exactly did the pain start? ; Therapist: About how many hours after the accident? ; Patient: I would probably say maybe four to six hours after. ; Patient: I think maybe I was just in shock at first and so I didn't really feel any pain or anything. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: And where is it bothering you specifically? ; Therapist: Can you pinpoint a specific area on your neck? ; Patient: It's mostly just the back of my neck and on the sides of my neck. ; Therapist: Both sides? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: And did you hear any pops or have any numbness or tingling that occurred during the accident? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Mm-mm. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: And is there anything that's making the pain worse? ; Patient: Mostly when I bend my head forward and try to turn it to the left, it kind of- ; Therapist: I notice it's a little uncomfortable. ; Patient: It's really tight. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Anything you've ever felt before? ; Patient: I took some ibuprofen and I put ice on the back of my neck and that helped a little bit, but it still hurts. ; Therapist: It still hurts. ; Therapist: Mm-mm. ; Therapist: And how much ibuprofen are you taking? ; Patient: I took two tablets every six hours or so since then. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: I'm just taking some notes so that way we can get the pain back. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So it's worse whenever you're bending forward and to the side, to the left. ; Therapist: Is that correct? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: And can you describe the pain to me? ; Patient: It just feels like a tight kind of dull pain. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So tight and dull. ; Therapist: And is this pain radiating or moving anywhere? ; Patient: Not really. ; Patient: It just goes up and down the back of my neck. ; Therapist: So nothing coming down into the arms? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And on a scale of one to ten, with ten being the worst pain, where would you say you're at? ; Patient: Probably around a six or a seven out of ten, especially when I try and bend forward and turn my head. ; Therapist: And is it a constant pain? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: And so, but it'll get worse whenever you bend forward and turn to the left. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And would you say since the accident, since that evening, has it been constant or is it getting worse, better? ; Therapist: What would you say? ; Patient: It feels like it's getting worse, but I don't know if that's because the ibuprofen's not working. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Well, I'm glad you came in. ; Therapist: You know, the over-the-counter stuff's not working, and we can do an exam and make sure there's nothing we're missing. ; Therapist: You know, if we need to possibly do some osteopathic treatments, and we'll get on to that later, okay? ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And as far as your past medical history, have you ever had a neck injury before? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No? ; Therapist: So you've never had problems with your neck? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Well, that's good to know. ; Therapist: And any medical conditions that you're currently being treated for or that you've ever been treated for? ; Patient: I have asthma, and I take medicine for that. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: So that's about it. ; Therapist: Ever been hospitalized? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Mm-mm. ; Therapist: Ever had any surgeries? ; Patient: I had my tonsils taken out when I was a kid. ; Patient: I think I was probably nine. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And as far as medications, you said you take the over-the-counter ibuprofen, and then you take something for asthma. ; Therapist: What do you take for your asthma? ; Patient: I take albuterol. ; Therapist: Do you just take that as needed? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: And do you take any other medications? ; Patient: I take a loratadine or a Claritin for allergies. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: What about any herbal supplements, vitamins? ; Patient: I take a multivitamin. ; Therapist: And I always like to ask all my patients, any recreational drug use? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: None. ; Therapist: And are you allergic to any medications? ; Patient: I am. ; Patient: I'm allergic to penicillin. ; Therapist: And what happens when you take penicillin? ; Patient: I break out in a rash. ; Therapist: In a rash. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Well, we'd be sure never to give you penicillin for anything. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Thank you. ; Therapist: And as far as family history, any medical conditions in the family with your mom and dad? ; Patient: My mom, she's pretty healthy. ; Patient: She has diabetes, though. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: And it's pretty under control. ; Therapist: Good. ; Patient: My dad has high cholesterol, but he takes medicine for that. ; Therapist: Any brothers or sisters? ; Patient: I have a brother, and he's healthy. ; Therapist: He's healthy? ; Patient: He doesn't have any conditions or anything. ; Therapist: And no one's ever had problems with joints or arthritis? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Great. ; Therapist: And I always like to just get an overview of my patients, kind of get to know them a little better. ; Therapist: What do you do for a living? ; Patient: I'm an administrative assistant. ; Therapist: Oh, where do you work? ; Patient: I work for the Fish and Wildlife Services. ; Therapist: Oh, wow. ; Therapist: That must be fun. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: You've been doing it for a while? ; Patient: Yeah, for a few years. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Stressful or pretty? ; Patient: It's not very stressful at all. ; Therapist: That's good. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: And are you married? ; Patient: I am. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Congratulations. ; Patient: Thanks. ; Therapist: Do you have any children? ; Patient: No, not yet. ; Therapist: No children? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: And so do you have hobbies that you like to do? ; Patient: I do. ; Patient: I like to cook, and I like to garden. ; Patient: It's been kind of difficult to garden because I can't lean forward as much for the past ; Patient: two days. ; Therapist: Yeah, it can be frustrating when you can't do the things you enjoy. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Any tobacco use? ; Patient: I smoke probably maybe half a pack a day, if that. ; Therapist: And how long have you been smoking? ; Patient: Oh, I want to say maybe seven years or so. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Any alcohol use? ; Patient: Occasional. ; Patient: I'll have a glass of wine with dinner maybe once a week. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Well, I believe I got all the information I needed from you, so we're going to go ahead and move on to the physical exam portion. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So what I'm going to do is I'm just going to have you take a seat up here. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: For the physical exam, I'm going to go ahead and listen to your heart and lungs and make sure those sound nice and clear. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So I'm just going to slide this down and just breathe normal. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And go and take a big deep breath. ; Therapist: And again. ; Therapist: Again. ; Therapist: And last one. ; Therapist: Good. ; Therapist: And so I'm just going to do a structural exam here and palpate down your spine. ; Therapist: Let me know if there's anything that's tender. ; Patient: It's tender everywhere. ; Therapist: Everywhere. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: I'm going to work my way down. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And I'm going to check the range of motion in your neck. ; Therapist: So what I want you to do is try to put your chin down to your chest. ; Patient: It's about as far as I can go. ; Therapist: And then looking up to the ceiling, pretty stiff. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And what about looking, turning and looking over to this shoulder? ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: And turn and look to that shoulder for me. ; Therapist: Right there. ; Patient: Right there. ; Therapist: And then ear to your shoulder. ; Therapist: Trying to touch your ear over to your shoulder. ; Therapist: And then ear to the other shoulder. ; Patient: That's as far as I can go on this side. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: And I'm going to go ahead and check just some reflexes. ; Therapist: This will kind of tell me if there's any nerves that are involved. ; Therapist: So just relax your arm. ; Therapist: And we're going to rest your arm right here on your lap. ; Therapist: And just relax. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And I'm going to do the same thing on this arm. ; Therapist: So just relax your arm. ; Therapist: And just relax. ; Therapist: And then the last one, just let your arm hang. ; Therapist: And now I'm going to test and see how strong you are. ; Therapist: So place your arms like this for me and don't let me move your arms. ; Therapist: Good. ; Therapist: And arms up. ; Therapist: And don't let me push them. ; Therapist: Good. ; Therapist: And fingers out for me. ; Therapist: Don't let me squeeze them. ; Therapist: And fingers together and try to push them out. ; Therapist: Good. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: If it's okay with you, as an osteopathic student we've learned some treatments. ; Therapist: So I'm going to do some soft tissue to try and break up some of this tension that you're having. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: If that sounds okay. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: I'm going to hurt yourself. ; Patient: It doesn't want to hurt too bad. ; Therapist: No, it's not going to hurt. ; Therapist: And if there's any pain, I want you to let me know. ; Therapist: And so I'm just going to do just very gentle, it's called myofascial. ; Therapist: I'm just going to slowly up. ; Therapist: And if this is something that you do get some relief from after this evening, then you can come back and we can be a little more aggressive. ; Therapist: But since the car accident was just two days ago, I want to be very gentle. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: I'm just going to hold this right here. ; Therapist: All those muscles that are tight and spasming right now attach right up where my fingers are at. ; Therapist: So I'm just trying to get them to relax and loosen. ; Patient: So this is supposed to relax all the muscles in here? ; Therapist: Uh-huh. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: I think that will be enough for today. ; Therapist: I don't want to do too much since it was such an acute injury. ; Therapist: So I'm going to go ahead and help you up. ; Therapist: And then I'm going to go ahead and summarize everything that you told me from earlier, if that's okay. ; Therapist: Would you prefer sitting back down in the chair? ; Patient: Sure. ; Therapist: I'll help you here. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So you started having some neck pain two days ago after a motor vehicle accident. ; Therapist: You were rear-ended, but you were wearing your seat belt. ; Therapist: You didn't hear any pop or have any numbness or tingling that occurred. ; Therapist: And it's just been real tight for the past two days, real constant, but it's worse whenever you flex your head down or turn to the left. ; Therapist: Is that correct? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: And as far as your past medical history, you just have asthma and you're taking some medication for that. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And you're not allergic to anything? ; Patient: Penicillin. ; Therapist: Oh, excuse me. ; Therapist: Yes, that's right. ; Therapist: You are allergic to penicillin. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: What I will do is I will go talk to Dr. Parrott, and then we will be back in to put together a treatment option plan for you. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Any other questions or concerns you have for me today? ; Patient: No, I don't think so. ; Patient: I just want to feel better. ; Therapist: All right. ; Patient: Well, that is our main goal, so I'm glad you came in today. ; Therapist: Great. ; Therapist: Thank you. ; Patient: Thank you.
summary: Patient Particulars : Marital status married ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Psychiatrist ; Past Session Information: Nil ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting complaint snoring and weight gain chief complaints 1 weight gain 2 sleep apnea 3 allergic reaction 4 fatigue ; History: Present history snoring issues from past two years. Medical history currently taking xanax. Substance use history used to consume tobacoo. Stared smoking at the age of 16. Currently consuming alcohol but gets a reaction after having it. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior agitated; speech normal; mood  affect irritable, thought organized; cognitive functions normal; judgement and insight intact ; Psychotherapy Type: Nil ; Psychotherapy Technique : Nil ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: There are few themes discussed in the session 1. Presenting symptoms patient is experiencing snoring since he has gained weight which also caused increased fatigue and tiredness during the day. 2. Medical history he had a history of allergic reactions to nickel, penicillin, and alcohol. It caused gastrointestinal issues when he consumes alcohol. He has been on medication xanax. He also has been smoking since the age of 16 but quit at the age of 36. 3. Other details he is a truck driver, spends about a week away from home at a time. Also, he has an active sexual life with his wife and have children. 4.
