Few tests he recommended include a sleep study to assess sleep quality and potential sleep apnea, as well as an ecg to check for any heart conditions. He also suggested lifestyle changes such as weight loss through diet and exercises. 5. Safety concerns educated him about the importance of addressing sleep issues like snoring and sleep apnea, especially for someone who works as a truck driver, as it can affect alertness and increase the risk of accidents on the road. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Nil ; Action Plan : Advised to take a test ecg test, sleep study to assess sleep quality and potential sleep apnea and few changes in lifestyle. ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Emma, how are you doing today? ; Patient: I'm doing good, thanks. ; Patient: How are you? ; Therapist: I'm doing well. ; Therapist: Thank you for asking. ; Therapist: I understand that you've come here today because you've had some symptoms that have been bothering you. ; Patient: Yeah, I have anxiety sometimes and I've lost about three jobs within the past year. ; Therapist: You've lost three jobs in the past year? ; Therapist: Is it because of the anxiety? ; Patient: Yeah, well I'm scared that something's going to happen at my apartment so I need to unplug things. ; Patient: But it has to be in order. ; Patient: So when I unplug things it has to start with the TV and then my computer and then my phone and the lamps and then I've been late to work. ; Therapist: Alright, so you have a system you go through of unplugging different objects in your apartment and you're worried that they're going to cause a problem if they're left plugged in? ; Patient: Yeah, like if they overheat it could like burn it down. ; Therapist: So you're afraid that if you leave them plugged in they'll overheat? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And your apartment will catch on fire? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: And you have a particular order you go in as you unplug? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: What happens if you're unplugging the items and you get distracted or something interrupts that? ; Patient: Well, I mean sometimes I'll get like a text message and I'll hear my phone go off. ; Patient: I'll have to just start all over again. ; Therapist: Will you plug the objects back in or will you, how will you do it for the items that are already unplugged? ; Patient: I would just have to unplug them and then I would have to plug them back in or vice versa. ; Therapist: So you go back and plug them in? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And unplug them. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: What's your anxiety level like as you start that process? ; Patient: It's really bad. ; Therapist: Is it? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: How about toward the end of the process? ; Patient: It goes away but it's just kind of temporary just for a little bit of time and then it comes back and I have to go check it again. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So when it comes back, everything's unplugged. ; Therapist: So you have to plug everything back in and unplug it? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And go through the whole process again? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: So it's pretty distressing. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: And you think that this is what led to the problems of employment? ; Patient: Yeah, because I also, I have to lock my door but I like to lock it 12 times. ; Patient: So I'll put the key in and I'll hear it click but then I just like doing it 12 times just to make sure it's locked and that made me late for work. ; Patient: And then when I was at work, I have a drawer on my cashier so I would just make sure it was locked but I would have to do it 12 times just to make sure it was locked and I didn't get back in time to help the customers. ; Therapist: Alright, so your employer wasn't happy with that? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And that led to you losing your job? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Are you working now? ; Patient: No, I had a job for a little bit of time. ; Patient: It was again a cashier position but I was on break and I was like in the room and I had the lights and I just wanted to make sure they would go off all the way because I didn't want to leave the light on. ; Patient: And by the time I got done turning them on and just making sure they were off, I didn't get back in time on the floor and my employer just said I wasn't a good fit. ; Therapist: Wasn't a good fit. ; Therapist: Alright, so these symptoms have caused you some real problems with employment and how about with your anxiety level? ; Patient: My anxiety is really bad. ; Therapist: If we were to put on a scale where one was very little anxiety and ten was the worst anxiety you've ever experienced, what kind of anxiety are you having on a daily basis now? ; Patient: Probably like a ten. ; Therapist: A ten, so the worst ever. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And checking doors, checking light switches, unplugging everything, this reduces your anxiety for a while? ; Patient: Just for a little bit. ; Therapist: But then it comes back. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Is there anything else that you do that helps to reduce the anxiety? ; Patient: It's just I guess when I'm in the act of doing it, it will relieve it and then I'll be okay for a little bit of time. ; Patient: Like even coming in, you know, I have like, I have somebody had chairs and some pitchers and I just like I had to touch them, like I had to touch the chairs, but I wanted to touch the chairs first and then the pitchers and that's normally what I do in a room. ; Patient: Like I have to touch the chairs first and I feel okay when I'm doing it and then when I'm finished I feel a little better but then it comes back. ; Patient: The anxiety. ; Therapist: Do you know how long you've had these symptoms? ; Patient: Probably since I guess like third grade maybe. ; Therapist: So sometime. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Did they start off like they are now or were they different? ; Patient: It started off with a little bit of things, like I would just get a little bit of anxiety and I just would want to play with the doorknob and then as I got, it went away for like a year maybe and then I would start to play with the lights and just make sure that they were off. ; Therapist: It was the same thing that helped reduce anxiety? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Did it cause you any trouble? ; Patient: My parents didn't really like it. ; Patient: They kind of were like, you know, something's wrong with you. ; Patient: You know, stop playing with that. ; Therapist: Were you ever taken somewhere and diagnosed or treated? ; Patient: No, no. ; Patient: My parents just thought it was like nerves. ; Therapist: And now it's the worst it's ever been? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Do you feel like you're able to go back to work with the symptoms the way they are now? ; Patient: Probably not. ; Therapist: Because they're so disruptive? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Have you ever had any medical conditions? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Nothing? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: And have you ever used or do you use any type of drug or alcohol? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: None? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: Emma, I want to thank you for coming in. ; Therapist: I'm going to get you scheduled to see one of our counselors. ; Therapist: I appreciate you spending this time with me. ; Therapist: It's helped me to understand what you're going through. ; Patient: Thank you. ; Therapist: Thanks.

dialogue: Therapist: What was your relationship with your teachers and maybe those that some of the peers that you had at the school? ; Therapist: I mean was there any? ; Patient: You know what? ; Patient: Usually I didn't get along with the teachers honestly. ; Patient: I was always a class clown so I'm usually getting kicked out. ; Patient: I was always getting detention so I didn't really get along with the teachers. ; Patient: I would try and ditch class and stuff. ; Therapist: So overall today are you pursuing or do you want to further your education? ; Patient: Yeah I'm trying to get into college actually. ; Therapist: So you're looking into maybe like a four year old junior college. ; Therapist: Yeah a junior college for right now actually. ; Therapist: What would be like, give me a little bit, during the time that you were in school did you have a job? ; Therapist: Have you worked? ; Patient: I did. ; Patient: I was working at Paul's Place. ; Patient: It's a restaurant through the school. ; Patient: And it was like a job program. ; Patient: Packaging knives and forks and napkins, salt and pepper and would send them over to the restaurant. ; Therapist: You would send them over to the restaurant? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: So you would prep everything, all the utensils, get ready. ; Therapist: Now when you were working, how did that make you feel when you were working? ; Patient: I liked it. ; Patient: It got boring at times honestly. ; Patient: And because the paychecks were also really small. ; Therapist: But it was a start. ; Patient: Yeah it was a start. ; Therapist: And so how did it make you feel good? ; Therapist: Because you worked for something and then the finished product was your paycheck. ; Therapist: Yeah that's what you get. ; Therapist: So if you want something in life you pretty much have to work for it. ; Therapist: Work for it. ; Therapist: Work hard. ; Therapist: It's going to teach you how to work at a young age. ; Therapist: How old were you when you started working? ; Therapist: I was 15. ; Therapist: You were 15 years old and then you started working and it was a program for the school. ; Therapist: So you know at a young age that it's going to take hard work. ; Therapist: Yeah to achieve something. ; Therapist: To achieve something. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Great. ; Therapist: Now what about your dream job? ; Therapist: What would be if tomorrow you could say I'm this person tomorrow or this is my profession tomorrow. ; Therapist: What would be your dream job? ; Therapist: A pilot. ; Therapist: A pilot. ; Therapist: Oh a pilot wow. ; Therapist: And what was your reasoning behind that? ; Therapist: I love airplanes. ; Therapist: I used to make model airplanes. ; Therapist: That's right you mentioned that you made model planes. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: Tell me more about that. ; Therapist: What would you do in your dream job? ; Therapist: I just want to fly. ; Therapist: Fly. ; Therapist: I like being in the air. ; Patient: I like going fast. ; Patient: Going fast. ; Patient: Going to the air. ; Patient: Going fast. ; Patient: Going fast. ; Patient: Going fast. ; Patient: Going fast. ; Therapist: Going fast. ; Therapist: Going fast. ; Therapist: Being in the air. ; Therapist: Being above. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Above things. ; Therapist: Being able to see from a different view. ; Therapist: And so a pilot. ; Therapist: Have you looked into what it would take to become a pilot? ; Patient: You know what the only star goal with that is math. ; Patient: So I don't think it's going to work out. ; Patient: What would be your next dream job? ; Therapist: A cop. ; Therapist: A cop. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: A police officer. ; Patient: Have you looked into that? ; Patient: Yeah I'm trying to get back into this cadet program I was doing for about around three weeks ago. ; Patient: I was doing it but it was too far so I had to kind of let it go. ; Patient: And I'm trying to look for one in my area. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: And maybe that's something we can discuss to help you find a cadet program close by. ; Therapist: And then we're able to give you some goals to set and get you in a program like that. ; Therapist: But let's look at, let's back up a little bit to the marijuana. ; Therapist: Because you and I know being in law enforcement, you know, marijuana and being a cop, pretty much you would have to. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: And you would have to, what would you have to do? ; Therapist: Let it go. ; Therapist: You would have to let it go. ; Therapist: So what we want to do while you're here, we want to help you here develop a treatment plan, a treatment model where you can pursue some realistic goals. ; Therapist: We want to set some goals for you. ; Therapist: Also what about your medical history? ; Therapist: Tell me a little bit about your medical history. ; Therapist: Have you ever been in the hospital? ; Therapist: Has anything ever happened to you? ; Therapist: You've broken a bone? ; Patient: I've had surgery on my arm because I was in a motorcycle racing. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: I fell. ; Patient: And I had to get it all stitched up. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: And then you cut your shelf on what? ; Therapist: It was a piece of metal that was scripted. ; Therapist: Scripted on. ; Therapist: So you got stitches. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: And you're doing better. ; Therapist: What about in your family is there any diseases that might in your family anyone suffer from any illnesses, ailments? ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And as far as medical attention, is there anyone that needed medical attention in the past? ; Therapist: Maybe someone on meds, in your family, psychological, health. ; Patient: Can you explain a little bit? ; Therapist: Is there anyone maybe that has gone to therapy, that has been in therapy in your family, a ; Patient: family member? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And what we want to do, what I want to do to help you with this Curtis is one, we want to develop a treatment plan to help you with the marijuana use. ; Therapist: We want to be able to look at your support system. ; Therapist: You know, who's in your life right now? ; Therapist: What are your, the friends that you smoke marijuana with? ; Therapist: What type of people are they? ; Therapist: Would this be, is this a good fit for you? ; Therapist: But our whole goal is to start you off with small steps. ; Therapist: So today you're using marijuana how many times a day? ; Therapist: So you pretty much said you're using it every day. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: I believe you said every day. ; Patient: But how many times a day? ; Therapist: Yeah, how many times a day for a month. ; Therapist: Yeah, so. ; Therapist: Do you wake up and you do it? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: It's not like my morning routine, you go ahead and do it. ; Patient: And then usually around noon time I do it again and then towards five o'clock I do it again, then at nighttime, five other days I'll do it again. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: So one of, maybe one of the realistic goals is you're okay, you know, we can narrow down maybe the relationship. ; Therapist: Which of your friends right now today, how many of them smoke marijuana? ; Patient: About six, seven. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Maybe a realistic short term goal is to begin to see which friends. ; Therapist: To hang out with? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: That's what my mom told me. ; Therapist: And then also your mom makes it. ; Therapist: What did she tell you? ; Patient: She told me before you fall into the wrong crowd and you fall into something, just she pretty much said that if I keep this up it's going to get me into something I don't want to get into. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: You know, jail time. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: You know, because we make you do things that you shouldn't be doing. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: And other things legal. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: So definitely we want to look at your whole peer relationships, who your friends are. ; Therapist: We also want to look at your time right now. ; Therapist: So you mentioned earlier that you were working. ; Therapist: Are you working today? ; Patient: No, I'm not. ; Therapist: Okay, so maybe that's another thing, a realistic goal that we need to look at and maybe help you pursue is a job. ; Therapist: Maybe because the idle time sometimes can trigger events, you know, where you begin to want to use marijuana. ; Therapist: And then we can identify some of the emotions that you're feeling. ; Therapist: Let's go over that maybe briefly. ; Therapist: Before you get, before you smoke marijuana, is there a feeling that you have that says, hey, I'm a little depressed. ; Therapist: Depressed. ; Therapist: So we can look at the depression and see how we can treat that. ; Therapist: What else, what are some of the other feelings that you see? ; Therapist: Sad, angry, you know. ; Therapist: What were you angry about? ; Therapist: There might be asking for this. ; Patient: I would actually like to be up in the morning with my girlfriend. ; Patient: So it's kind of a stress still. ; Patient: It still bothers me as much as I'm trying to ignore it. ; Patient: It still bothers me. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: Are there certain days that maybe perhaps you remember? ; Therapist: Is there events? ; Patient: Like Thanksgiving and Christmas and holidays and things like that. ; Patient: That's when you become angry towards how you were brought up. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: I mean it's not that I don't appreciate my foster parents because I do. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: But I just really have been born with my biological family. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: But I've been a lot better. ; Therapist: So we want to maybe equip you with some coping skills. ; Therapist: How to cope with those things. ; Therapist: How to prepare you maybe for the holidays. ; Therapist: Maybe there's a way we can begin to look at that during the holidays. ; Therapist: These are the emotions I feel. ; Therapist: So we identify those emotions and we'll be able to take care of that. ; Therapist: We'll be able to prepare you prior to you falling back into the trap and going out and using marijuana. ; Therapist: Maybe during Christmas. ; Therapist: Do you feel the same way during Christmas? ; Therapist: I do. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Maybe even your birthday, father's day, mother's day. ; Therapist: These are all the things that we can kind of get you ready for. ; Therapist: Because once again it's going to take small steps. ; Therapist: Realistic goals. ; Therapist: And then what we want to do after that, the realistic goals is just get you ready for long term goals. ; Therapist: But Curtis, I'm glad you came into my office. ; Therapist: It was great meeting you. ; Therapist: I look forward to working with you. ; Therapist: Is there any other questions that you may have for me? ; Therapist: Is there anything that I can do at all? ; Patient: I do. ; Patient: I just kind of run a whole lot of times a week and I'm going to be allowed to come in ; Therapist: to therapy. ; Therapist: Well what we can do, we'll set you up with a treatment plan and then I'd like to at least have two contacts with you a week. ; Therapist: And we can go over that. ; Therapist: And then maybe during one of the contacts we can help you with a job. ; Therapist: And then identifying some of the emotions. ; Therapist: And then maybe we can get the whole marijuana use, we can begin to kind of taper it down. ; Therapist: Instead of every day, we'll begin to see how we can taper that down. ; Therapist: But again, I'm glad that you came. ; Therapist: It was a pleasure meeting you and we'll be in touch and we'll be able to do this again. ; Therapist: Alright Curtis, good seeing you.

Marijuana usena ; History: Present historypatient reports that he smokes marijuana daily with his friends 3-4 times in a day. He reports that the triggers for his marijuana use include feeling sad or feeling angry. Whenever hes idle like on festivities and holidays he remembers past traumatic events and his girlfriend and resorts to smoking marijuana medical history surgery on? cybereason family history no family history of medical or psychiatric illness ; Crisis Markers: Marijuana use leading to multiple changes in jobs ; Current Mental Status Examination: Nil ; Psychotherapy Type: Mode individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Reflective listening ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Triggers for marijuana use ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Mental and behavioral disorders due to use of cannabinoids ; Action Plan : To begin analysing which friends to hang out with and which friends to spend less time with ; Next session details: Pt was asked to come twice every week

dialogue: Therapist: Good afternoon Lily, I'm glad you could make it in today. ; Patient: I'm glad I came in. ; Therapist: How has your week been so far? ; Patient: I'm still a little bit anxious. ; Therapist: Yes, last week when you were in you were telling me that you were experiencing great anxiety and we had developed a plan, a plan for your anxiety. ; Therapist: And according to my notes, you were going to look into some yoga classes, you were going to attempt to drink less coffee, you were going to get out more with people because you were kind of isolating yourself in the home and you were going to spend more time in nature. ; Therapist: So I'm wondering how all that went. ; Patient: Well, I looked at the gym and there weren't really any yoga classes so I didn't really do that. ; Patient: I did cut back on my coffee a little bit but I just find that it wakes me up in the morning so you know I've cut back to one cup instead of two cups and I did take the dog for a walk but I haven't really gotten out other than that. ; Therapist: Okay, so it sounds like you've made some movement forward towards your goals. ; Therapist: You did at least look into yoga even though the gym didn't have yoga classes. ; Therapist: You did cut down from two cups of coffee to one and you did get out with your dog in nature for a walk but it sounds like you had a little bit of an issue getting out more with people. ; Patient: Yeah, I don't really like to go out with people. ; Patient: There's usually a lot of chatter and a lot of talking and it's hard for me to be in that. ; Therapist: So it's uncomfortable for you to be out around people with all the speaking and chatting and talking and how does that make you feel? ; Patient: It just makes me feel a little bit nervous and then when I get out there I don't really engage in conversation. ; Therapist: So actually getting out with people actually makes you even more anxious. ; Therapist: So I'm wondering what we could do about that. ; Patient: I'm not really sure. ; Patient: Maybe I could invite people over instead. ; Therapist: That would absolutely be one option. ; Therapist: You could invite people over to your house and then you could get to choose who you're around. ; Patient: Yeah, that's a good idea. ; Therapist: In terms of the yoga, let's get back to the yoga for a minute. ; Therapist: Tell me more about where you looked for yoga classes. ; Patient: I just looked at my gym. ; Patient: I didn't really look anywhere else because I'm already paying to go to a gym and I don't really want to pay extra to go somewhere else so that's why I didn't really look anywhere else. ; Therapist: If I were to ask you right now, how motivated are you to find a yoga class on a scale of 1 to 10? ; Patient: Maybe about a 5 or 6. ; Therapist: What made you say 5 or 6 rather than 2 or 3? ; Patient: I see all these pictures in my news feed about yoga and I see all these pictures and I just want to do it so I'm interested in doing it. ; Patient: It's just really hard. ; Therapist: When you see the pictures on your news feed, it makes you excited about doing it but when you actually go to do it, it makes it a little bit more challenging. ; Patient: I haven't done it before so it's a little bit hard to get out there because I don't think I'm as flexible as the other people. ; Therapist: You're thinking that you're not as flexible as the other people. ; Therapist: I'm wondering if that's what yoga is about, flexibility. ; Patient: I think that people go to become flexible but I think that maybe some people are already just flexible. ; Therapist: You are concerned that maybe you might not be as flexible as the rest and you'd be a beginner. ; Patient: I'm worried I wouldn't be able to do the poses in class. ; Therapist: What do you think would happen if you couldn't do the poses in class? ; Patient: I'd feel embarrassed, I think. ; Patient: If the teacher tried to get me to do it and everybody else would see that they're trying to get me into a pose, I think it would be embarrassing. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: You'd be embarrassed if you couldn't do the certain poses. ; Therapist: How would you feel if you could do all the poses in the class? ; Patient: I think I'd feel really good. ; Therapist: What do you think it is preventing you from not doing all the poses in the class? ; Patient: I guess it's just the embarrassment of maybe not being able to do it. ; Therapist: What would cause you to not be able to do it with the poses? ; Patient: I'm not sure. ; Therapist: I remember when you first came in last week, you told me that when you were younger, you used to be very, very flexible. ; Therapist: I'm wondering what would make that difference between then and now? ; Patient: When I was a kid, I used to just practice and stretch a lot. ; Patient: Now that I don't, I don't have the same flexibility. ; Patient: As long as I've gotten older, I've lost a lot of flexibility. ; Therapist: How would it be if you couldn't do all the poses in the class and you did get embarrassed and you just let it be? ; Therapist: Embarrassed? ; Patient: It would be okay, but I don't like that feeling. ; Therapist: What would be the payoff, do you think, if you put up with a little bit of embarrassment? ; Patient: I probably feel really good in the end. ; Therapist: You know, I can give you, I have lots of studies that I can give you and videos that I can show you of people that started yoga and started practicing yoga and their anxiety went way down. ; Therapist: As a matter of fact, some studies show that anxiety, doing yoga can be decreased the same as medications. ; Therapist: So I'm not sure if you knew that or not. ; Patient: I didn't really know that. ; Patient: I just thought that yoga was more about flexibility. ; Patient: I didn't realize there were so many other benefits. ; Therapist: So how motivated would that make you feel on a scale of 1 to 10? ; Patient: Well, I probably, if I thought that I'd be, it would make me less anxious. ; Patient: I think I'd probably be around an 8 or 9. ; Therapist: Good. ; Therapist: Good. That's a definite improvement! ; Therapist: And you could determine after that first class whether your anxiety levels had decreased or not. ; Therapist: Would that be validation for you or would that give you even more motivation if your anxiety levels were decreased instantly after the yoga class? ; Patient: I think that would be a lot of motivation to continue. ; Therapist: So one other thing that I wanted to mention to you was you said that you had walked your dog in nature. ; Therapist: And I'm curious as to how much time did you spend walking your dog in nature? ; Patient: Well, it was only about 30 minutes. ; Patient: It was really cold and windy so we didn't want to stay out. ; Patient: And by we, I mean the dog and I. ; Therapist: And so because it was cold and windy you decided to kind of cut the walk short. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And that's definitely understandable. ; Therapist: I'm wondering what you could do to possibly get an hour of walking the dog in a day. ; Patient: Well, it might help if I take a jacket next time. ; Therapist: Okay, so if you took a jacket in case it's cold. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And do you have a special place in nature that makes you feel peaceful that you could be in that would help you even more? ; Therapist: Enjoy it? ; Patient: Well, as long as I'm just away from road noise and traffic then it's a lot better. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: And there's lots of trails around my house like that. ; Therapist: Okay, excellent. ; Therapist: It's great that you have trails around your house where you're not exposed to all that noise. ; Therapist: And so do you think you could commit to an hour? ; Patient: Probably. ; Therapist: And on a scale of one to ten, tell me what that probably means. ; Patient: It's probably a ten. ; Patient: I can commit to that. ; Therapist: Okay, alright. ; Therapist: So it sounds like last week you had a few problems carrying out the assignments towards decreasing your anxiety. ; Therapist: You really couldn't find a yoga class because you're already signed up for a gym that doesn't have the yoga classes, but you already know about the yoga videos that I've sent you so you could actually do them at home. ; Therapist: How strongly do you feel about doing them at home? ; Patient: If I could do them at home, I would probably do them all the time. ; Patient: I think that would be a big difference. ; Therapist: And then there would be no embarrassment factor if you couldn't do the poses. ; Therapist: Less coffee, you've gone from two cups to one cup. ; Therapist: That's very good. ; Therapist: And get out more with people. ; Therapist: You've decided to invite people over to your house rather than going out with other people not knowing who's going to be in your space. ; Therapist: That's always an apprehensive moment when you don't know, you have no control over who's going to be in your space. ; Therapist: And on a scale of one to ten, you think that you could spend at least an hour a day walking with the dog. ; Therapist: Good job. ; Therapist: I think we have a plan. ; Therapist: So overall, on all four of these items, how motivated do you feel on a scale of one to ten? ; Patient: I think it's a ten. ; Patient: I think I can do them. ; Therapist: On all four? ; Patient: On all four. ; Therapist: Fabulous. ; Therapist: And how do you think you will feel? ; Therapist: If you were to envision how you would feel incorporating all of these items in your life next week, over the course of next week, how much of a difference do you think it would make you feel? ; Patient: I think it would maybe even make me look forward to doing these things if I were doing them ; Patient: on a regular basis. ; Therapist: And how would it make you feel? ; Patient: I think it would make me feel really good. ; Therapist: And so you'd feel relaxed and you would feel more positive and I think you would too. ; Therapist: Very good. ; Therapist: Thank you. ; Therapist: We'll check in next week. ; Therapist: We'll make an appointment for next week and catch up and see how you're doing with all this. ; Therapist: Good job. ; Patient: Thank you so much.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name lily, sex female ; Past Session Information: Follow up session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms anxiety ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behavior cooperative; speech, mood  affect anxious, ; Psychotherapy Type: Cbt; mode individual. ; Psychotherapy Technique : Reflective listening behavioral activationcognitive restructuring ; Issues discussed in Current Session: 1 anxiety management session was around the patients anxiety levels and related feelings. 2 strategies yoga, reducing coffee intake, social interactions, and spending time in nature. 3 goal setting reviewing progress on previously set goals and identifying areas needing improvement. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Anxiety ; Action Plan : Follow up on what they have discussed in session. ; Next session details: Next week

dialogue: Therapist: So, Eric, what's on the agenda for today? ; Patient: Definitely my dad. ; Patient: He's just been on my case like all week getting on me. ; Patient: He's being a real jerk in my room playing video games and talking to my friends. ; Patient: And he just barges into my room. ; Patient: He's getting on me at dinner. ; Patient: He just never lets up. ; Patient: He's on me about getting a job, getting my life together. ; Patient: All the time. ; Patient: As soon as I wake up in the morning, there's an email from him or something just telling me to do stuff I don't want to do. ; Patient: It doesn't get that I'm not feeling good and I'm not going to do that stuff. ; Therapist: Let me interrupt you for just a second here. ; Therapist: Make sure I understand you. ; Therapist: You're really upset about your father getting on you this past week, right? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: There's something that we could talk about today. ; Therapist: Is there something that you think we could do to help the situation out? ; Patient: Yeah, we've got to figure out some way to get him to back off. ; Patient: He's just on me. ; Patient: Maybe we can bring him in here or tell him something. ; Patient: Write him a letter. ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: But something to just get him to leave me alone. ; Therapist: Well one idea would be to get him to bring him in here and get him to back off. ; Therapist: But he's not here right now. ; Therapist: Maybe there's some things that you can do to help him calm down or back off the situation. ; Patient: He's the one being a jerk. ; Therapist: Well that may be, but maybe there's some things you could do to be a little more assertive with him, to let him know how you're feeling, or perhaps to calm the situation down. ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: I mean if you've got some ideas I'll listen I guess. ; Therapist: Okay well maybe we can put our heads together and come up with some strategies to deal with your dad a little bit better. ; Patient: All right. ; Therapist: Is that Sutter, right? ; Patient: Sure. ; Therapist: Is there anything we could put down on the agenda then? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: No I definitely want to talk about that. ; Therapist: So how do I describe that then? ; Patient: Dealing with my dad. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Dealing with dad. ; Therapist: Is there anything else you'd like to put on the agenda? ; Patient: I've been really tired lately. ; Patient: Just been sleeping a lot. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Last week or two. ; Therapist: So I put down tired and sleep. ; Therapist: So we have dealing with dad and tired and sleep. ; Therapist: Which thing do you want to talk about first? ; Patient: Definitely my dad. ; Patient: I mean I think. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So we don't want to forget about the homework, so we want to make sure we put that down on the agenda. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And so you want to talk about dealing with your dad or do the homework first? ; Patient: Definitely my dad. ; Therapist: Do it definitely with your dad. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So we want to make sure we allow enough time to talk about your homework because it's important. ; Therapist: So tell me what happened this past week with your dad.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name eric; sex male ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Nil ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Irritability 2 weeks 2. Decreased sleep 2 weeks ; History: Present history patient has been facing issues with his father where he feels that his father is indulging in his life a lot. He wants the patient to start working and make his life more stable but his ways of doing so make the patient irritable; family history his relationship with his father is strained. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behavior patient was cooperative and rapport could be established; mood irritable; affect restricted; thought content- preoccupation with frustration towards his father; insight grade 5 ; Psychotherapy Type: Nil ; Psychotherapy Technique : Nil ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patients frustration towards his father were discussed along with some ways through which patient could deal with this situation. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Nil ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Kyle, how are you doing today? ; Patient: I'm doing okay I guess. ; Patient: I guess something happened over this past week. ; Patient: I've been looking for a new job since I left my last one and I found this really good job on the internet. ; Patient: But the problem is that the job is working with kids and they have to do a drug test in order for me to get the job. ; Patient: And it kind of like made me think a little bit more about something that I've been considering for a while which is kind of just giving up weed for good. ; Patient: Like I've been thinking about it for a while but I also kind of think about the way weed really helps me. ; Patient: If I'm ever feeling really really anxious about something, I mean weed kind of helps me chill out and helps me relax and I just don't know if I'm ready to give that up yet. ; Therapist: So the marijuana has a real value for you that you don't want to see going. ; Patient: Yeah, yeah it does. ; Patient: It's like a way to self-medicate in a way. ; Therapist: And at the same time you would like this job. ; Therapist: So I could see how this would be in a pinch here. ; Patient: Right, yeah it's kind of like it's put me in a difficult spot. ; Patient: Like I definitely want to get that job but you know if I cut out smoking like I don't know what else I would do. ; Patient: Like if I started to have a panic attack or if I was really like anxious about like anything that I'm worrying about. ; Patient: Like I don't know what I'd do to cope. ; Therapist: Have you ever been treated for anxiety before? ; Patient: I did therapy for a little bit but it was like, I don't know. ; Patient: Back then it was kind of like when the anxiety was just starting so it wasn't too big of a problem. ; Patient: So I like I quit therapy because it wasn't really doing that much. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Do you take the marijuana for any other reason other than to help with the anxiety? ; Patient: I mean like if I'm bored or maybe if I'm like hanging out with buddies like I don't really have a reason not to do it like until now. ; Patient: But it wasn't like like I really use it whenever I'm like feeling really anxious about something. ; Therapist: So and you may not be able to answer this question but if you didn't have any anxiety would that change your motivation to use marijuana? ; Patient: If I didn't have like any kind of anxiety. ; Patient: Like it would still be kind of tough to give it up because like if I'm hanging out with my buddies and they offer it to me like that's always pretty chill. ; Patient: But I don't like I really I'm really looking forward to this job and like the benefits of having that job would outweigh the benefits of just like smoking my buddies. ; Therapist: So you're excited about the job? ; Patient: I am. ; Patient: Yeah it's almost kind of a dream job. ; Therapist: Well tell me about it. ; Patient: Well it's working with it's working with kids with autism in the school so like I would be kind of like a almost like a personal TA in a way. ; Patient: So like it's a part of an inclusion program so when the kids are going into the class like I would either sit with them or like maybe back behind the class and kind of like help them out in case something comes up. ; Patient: And it's like since my brother has autism that's like it's that's something that I've always really kind of wanted to work with. ; Therapist: So it sounds like you have real passion for this type of work. ; Therapist: And really the big obstacle here is this marijuana. ; Patient: It is it's like a catch-22 too because it's like I know the job will be great but it's like it's a it's a big step for me to take that job. ; Patient: And it's going to be super it's going to make me super anxious. ; Patient: You know it's going to be like it's going to be a lot of anxiety taking a new job so it's like if I have to give up the marijuana and then like not have another way to cope with anxiety like to get the job it's like a catch-22. ; Therapist: Yeah it's a predicament. ; Therapist: You're kind of weighing both sides of this right. ; Therapist: Now I'm wondering do you have do you think you have like a physical craving for the marijuana? ; Patient: No I mean not really. ; Therapist: So you're really using it recreationally and as an anti-anxiety agent. ; Patient: Yeah yeah pretty much. ; Therapist: So if you were I know you didn't have great success before in therapy to combat anxiety but if you were being treated for anxiety and working that job which it seems like you would really like. ; Therapist: You think you'd be able to stay away from marijuana? ; Patient: I think if the therapy really worked I would be able to. ; Patient: Like it's just so easy now just to kind of light up like that's an easy fix and like I don't think therapy is going to be that instant so like it would it would be tough. ; Patient: I think if I had real confidence that the therapy would work I could do it but I mean it would have to it would definitely have to work like just as well as smoking. ; Therapist: You would need to see results. ; Patient: Yeah yeah definitely. ; Therapist: Would having the job that you're passionate about reduce your anxiety? ; Patient: After a while like after I got used to the job but like just starting the new job would make me kind of anxious and then like it would be tough not to not to smoke while doing that. ; Patient: Like I don't I don't even get why they drug test anymore because like it's it's being decriminalized it's being legalized in so many places and there's so much research saying that it's not that bad that it's kind of like it's really upsetting that the place that I really want to work has that policy. ; Patient: I think it's really silly. ; Therapist: You're frustrated marijuana is illegal. ; Patient: Yeah it's yeah. ; Therapist: At the same time it's the reality you're living in. ; Patient: Right yeah it's I think it will be legalized in like in the state in a couple years but until then like I mean I can't wait that long to start start working so. ; Therapist: Until then you still need to address this dilemma. ; Patient: Right yeah it's still a problem. ; Therapist: So you have choices here right? ; Therapist: You can continue to use marijuana and not take the job. ; Therapist: And that seems like something that has some advantages for you but some some disadvantages. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: Because you would really like that job. ; Patient: Yeah and I would it's it sounds so pathetic to be like no I don't want to take my dream job because I need weed like sounds really stupid. ; Therapist: So where do you think you are in terms of making this change? ; Therapist: Do you feel motivated to take some steps toward it? ; Patient: I don't like I'm I'm still kind of on the fence because like if I if I have to give it up for the job I could do that but I would definitely need like some other way to get rid of all this anxiety. ; Patient: Like whether it's therapy or whether it's like something else I yeah I would I would definitely need like a substitute if I got rid of it for good. ; Therapist: So you definitely you're saying you definitely need it. ; Therapist: So you can't give up the marijuana unless you have some other available alternative that would help with that anxiety. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: That's the key to you to make this change. ; Patient: Yeah yeah definitely. ; Therapist: But at the same time that would be ideal because then you could take the job. ; Patient: Right yeah I mean I mean if I really thought that I could like get some kind of treatment that was as good as weed yeah I mean I could I could maybe quit especially if it helps ; Patient: to get this job especially. ; Therapist: So with anxiety reduction your chances of stopping marijuana increase and then you could take the job that you want. ; Patient: Yeah yeah I mean that would be the best best outcome. ; Therapist: Is that the outcome you would most want? ; Patient: Yeah I think so. ; Patient: I think I could give up record like dealing with my buddies recreationally. ; Patient: I could yeah I'm just light up a cigarette. ; Therapist: So here's what I'm thinking and let me know what you think about this. ; Therapist: When you come back next week right what if we start looking at this anxiety? ; Therapist: What if we start you know I start treating this anxiety? ; Therapist: All right and we see if we can get it reduced and kind of work from there because maybe when you start to feel if that works and that anxiety starts to abate it sounds like it would just be easier for you to stop the marijuana usage. ; Patient: Yeah yeah it would be. ; Therapist: What kind of time frame are you going to want in terms of taking this job? ; Patient: I mean the job it has a high turnover rate so like even if I like I need to apply this week but if I don't get in more than likely another position like it will open up like within a month or two. ; Therapist: And when would they drug test you? ; Patient: It would be like right after I apply. ; Patient: So if I applied and then did the interview that's when they would give him the paperwork and I'd have to go get drug tested. ; Therapist: When's the last time you used marijuana? ; Patient: Just a couple days ago. ; Therapist: So you see what I'm getting at? ; Patient: Yeah yeah it's a yeah so I like I wouldn't be able to do I wouldn't be able to make it this application but I mean I would like to be off it by the next one. ; Therapist: So you're fortunate in the sense that the turnover is high. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: So that's an opportunity to apply later on. ; Therapist: So do you feel like you could invest in that plan? ; Therapist: Let's work on the anxiety see what happens with the marijuana see if we can reduce your usage of it or have you stop that altogether and then kind of move toward this job? ; Patient: Yeah yeah I could deal with that. ; Therapist: Alright so how about next time you come in we'll start talking about the anxiety and let's see what we can do about that and we'll kind of move from there. ; Patient: Alright yeah sounds good. ; Therapist: Sounds good? ; Patient: Mm hmm. ; Therapist: Alright thanks Kyle. ; Patient: Thank you.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name kylie; sex female; marital status unmarried ; Clinical Identifiers: Setting outpatient ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Worries about future na 2. Feelings of nervousness na ; History: Present history patient got a new job which she likes but requires her to quit smoking. She isnt completely ready to do it which makes him feel anxious; past history she had started taking therapy for anxiety related issues but didnt continue; family history patients brother has been diagnosed with autism; substance use history she smokes marijuana on a regular basis. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: General behavior rapport could be established and patient was cooperative; mood anxious; affect restricted; thought content- concern regarding quitting smoking leading to anxiety; judgement personal judgement was impaired; insight grade 4 ; Psychotherapy Type: Type cognitive behavioral therapy; mode individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Socratic questioning ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patient has been smoking marijuana on a regular basis. She expressed her concern about losing this way of coping as well as for recreational purposes, to get her dream job. ; Reflections by the therapist: From next session, major focus will be on treating anxiety. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Nil ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: After 1 week.

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Laura, thanks for coming in. ; Therapist: So I'm not sure how much you know already about sort of what you're doing here. ; Therapist: If it's okay I'll give you a little rundown. ; Therapist: So basically we're here, I'm just gonna talk to you for a little bit about sort of what your goals are for your life, get to know you a little bit better, and talk about some different behaviors that you might be engaging in. ; Therapist: It's not my job at all to judge you or to try and change you, you know. ; Therapist: Basically I'm gonna talk to you about how things are going, any changes you might want to make in your life, how I could help you with that, and just what I can do that's gonna be most beneficial for you. ; Therapist: Does that sound okay? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Alright so I guess just to get started can you tell me a little bit about yourself? ; Patient: Well my name is Laura, I'm 17 years old, and I'm a senior in high school. ; Therapist: Okay and what kinds of things do you have planned for your life? ; Patient: Well hopefully go to college, get you know good enough grades to go to college. ; Therapist: That's great. ; Therapist: Do you have a plan as to where you might want to go? ; Patient: I'm not sure yet, maybe a few schools in the area. ; Patient: I'm looking maybe to apply out of state, so I can move away for college. ; Therapist: Cool. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So kind of keeping your options open. ; Patient: Yeah definitely. ; Therapist: Great and do you have an idea about what you might want to study or? ; Patient: Yeah maybe pre-law. ; Therapist: Oh wow ; Therapist: okay that's exciting. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Alright cool. ; Therapist: What do you like to do for fun? ; Patient: Well on the weekends I like to hang out with my friends, maybe go to like a party or go to the mall to shop or if there's like a school related event we'll go to like a football game or something like that. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I like to have a good time. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: And you have a lot of friends or a few close people? ; Patient: I would say like a modern amount. ; Patient: I'm not really really popular or like I have no friends. ; Patient: I'm like normal. ; Therapist: That's a good way to be right? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Alright so it sounds like in general your things are going pretty well for you. ; Therapist: How are your grades right now? ; Patient: They're pretty good A's and B's so I'm doing okay. ; Therapist: Okay great. ; Therapist: Well one thing I want to ask about is you know different people have sort of different values or things that are important to them. ; Therapist: They might you know be really close with family or really have you know their friends as being something particularly important. ; Therapist: I'm going to show you just a few things on this sheet and if you can look them over so there's things like belonging, community, cultural identity, family, friendship, modesty, religion, respect, self-determination, and spirituality. ; Therapist: Which of those do you think is sort of important to you? ; Therapist: Family definitely, friendship, and belonging. ; Therapist: Okay what's important to you about your family? ; Patient: Well I love them so I want them to think well of me and I want them to be accepting and love me. ; Therapist: Okay and you have brothers or sisters? ; Patient: Yeah I have one sister. ; Therapist: Okay great and how about friendship? ; Patient: Friendship I've grown close to many people that I care about so I would like them to be accepting of me as well. ; Therapist: Great so being a good friend and having people who are good friends too is important. ; Therapist: And then what about belonging? ; Therapist: You mentioned that one too. ; Patient: Yeah just a sense of like fitting in and not and like being accepted in general. ; Therapist: Yeah not wanting to be part of a group. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay great. ; Therapist: Alright well one of the things I want to talk about is you know you mentioned that you like to go out with friends and party and that sort of a thing and I'm curious when you're at the parties do you ever have any alcohol? ; Patient: Um not much maybe like one or two drinks at the most. ; Therapist: Okay can you tell me a little bit about how alcohol fits into your overall social scene? ; Patient: Um I pretty much just have a drink just just have it like so it looks like I'm drinking even though I'm not so maybe people won't bug me about drinking or something. ; Therapist: Okay you're kind of getting pressure from other people who are drinking and it feels easier for you to hold a drink. ; Patient: Yeah just have one there and pretend you have it. ; Therapist: Okay and do you think that this is most weekends or occasionally how often do you think that you are around alcohol? ; Patient: Maybe one or two weekends a month at the most. ; Therapist: So one or two weekends a month you're in a situation where there is alcohol. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay and what sort of situations are you in? ; Patient: Well just I guess at a party or something someone's house. ; Therapist: Uh-huh. ; Patient: Or even if it's not a party like a small social gathering maybe there'll be like a few beers around. ; Therapist: So mainly just kind of hanging out with friends? ; Patient: Pretty much yeah. ; Therapist: Are you ever places where there are parents around or mostly just just with the kids? ; Patient: Mostly just with us but sometimes I'll go to like a close friend's house and like I'm close to their family as well so we'll all just hang out. ; Therapist: And what about driving? ; Patient: Um like drunk driving? ; Therapist: Yeah do you ever go anywhere in a car after you've had any alcohol? ; Patient: Definitely not I've never drunk driven and I've never been in a car with a drunk driver. ; Therapist: So that's something that you've sort of made a decision about. ; Patient: Yeah because I know that's extremely dangerous. ; Therapist: Okay what do you know about how that's dangerous? ; Patient: Well alcohol definitely impairs your judgment so I mean driving under the influence of alcohol can lead to like crashes and accidents and things like that so I'd rather not be in that situation. ; Therapist: So you're really trying to be safe and make sure that you're not putting yourself in that situation. ; Therapist: That's great you know it's it's tough to do sometimes and I really commend you for being able to to stick with that. ; Patient: Thank you. ; Therapist: So you mentioned you pretty much will like hold a drink or maybe have a drink or two. ; Therapist: What do you think's the most alcohol you've ever had in in one day? ; Patient: No more than two drinks. ; Therapist: Okay so the the absolute most. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay and what kinds of things do you like about alcohol? ; Patient: I've never really been drunk so I can't really say that I like that feeling or not but it's just I mean you're just in a good mood. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm so it just kind of makes you feel relaxed? ; Patient: Yeah yeah relaxed. ; Therapist: Okay anything else? ; Patient: No not really like I said I don't drink that much so I wouldn't be able to tell you. ; Therapist: Okay and any not so good things about alcohol? ; Patient: Definitely yeah I mean when I'm at parties it's up and it's getting a little later some people that drink like drank too much they start throwing up or they get hurt or they're really loud and obnoxious and that's not fun for anybody. ; Therapist: So you've seen a lot of other kids who had some consequences and decided that's not for you. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Got it. ; Therapist: I can understand that. ; Therapist: Any other things that you can think of? ; Patient: No I mean I've never you know been friends with anybody that's got into like a serious accident and stuff it's just very like obnoxious thing. ; Therapist: Okay well so you know as someone who's not 21 yet it is underage drinking is something that's not illegal and it is something that is considered pretty risky so I wonder what you think about that just in terms of how it fits into your life? ; Patient: Um I know it's definitely risky but I mean I guess we still do it. ; Therapist: Uh-huh so it's kind of something that you're... It's just there. ; Therapist: It's just there okay and I'm curious you mentioned you know your friends are important to you and your family is important to you and sort of fitting in is important to you and how does alcohol play a role with that? ; Patient: Um well definitely not in my family life because my parents don't really condone alcohol use but friendships I mean when I'm hanging out with my friends or we're at a party or something there's usually alcohol involved. ; Therapist: Okay so from your family perspective the drinking is not something that fits very well. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And with friends you feel like it's easier to hang out with alcohol or maybe you wouldn't have as much fun or your friends wouldn't like you as much. ; Patient: I guess I mean this is just there. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Ties in with the whole belonging thing. ; Therapist: Okay well when you think about your drinking and sort of looking forward in five years or ten years how do you think the drinking might fit in with your life? ; Patient: It probably will have a very small role if any in my life considering I have big plans for my future. ; Therapist: Okay can you expand on that a little bit more what do you mean? ; Patient: I mean I don't think I would be you know drinking as much or going to parties as much if I'm studying for school or in college or trying to get it off school things like that. ; Therapist: Okay so the alcohol something that might make it harder to reach your goals. ; Patient: Yeah definitely. ; Therapist: So when you're sort of looking ahead how often do you think you might be drinking say when you get to college? ; Patient: Maybe less than I am now I mean I don't drink much anyway so maybe like one drink every once in a blue moon. ; Therapist: Okay so you sort of have a plan to cut back on your drinking eventually. ; Therapist: How might that go? ; Patient: Well I mean I guess right now I would try to stop in high school and once I get older maybe just like socially once in a while but not anything big or anything. ; Therapist: Yeah so you don't feel the need to make any major changes but you feel like you could make some adjustments that would make it easier. ; Patient: Definitely yeah that's a good word. ; Therapist: Okay how important is it to you to make some adjustments to your drinking on a scale of one to ten where one is not at all important not something you're thinking about and ten is the most important thing? ; Patient: Maybe a five or six. ; Therapist: And why'd you say five or six rather than like two or three? ; Patient: Because it's not something I do not care about at all but it's not something that's just constantly on my mind that I want to change about myself. ; Therapist: Okay so it is something you have thought about. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And how confident are you that you could make a change if you decide you wanted to on that same scale? ; Patient: I'm pretty confident that I can considering that I'm not really an alcohol user per se. ; Patient: I'm not really into that whole scene so it's not gonna be difficult for me. ; Therapist: So what number do you think you'd say? ; Patient: On a scale of one to ten if I can quit or not? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: Maybe like an eight or nine. ; Therapist: Okay and why'd you say eight or nine rather than even like five or six? ; Patient: Because like I said it's not a big part of my life so it's not really that difficult. ; Therapist: Okay all right well kind of keeping that in mind it sounds like you do have sort of a vague plan to make some adjustments in your drinking at some point and it's moderately important to you it's something you would like to do because you have these big goals for yourself and you actually feel very confident that you could be successful with it. ; Therapist: What sort of goal do you think might be good to set for today? ; Patient: Probably to stop maybe next party I go to not have a drink at all. ; Therapist: Okay do you feel pretty confident that you could just stop completely? ; Patient: Yeah I mean I can just tell my friends my friends aren't really that pressuring it's just like outside people that I don't really know that well so I could just tell them hey I don't feel like having a drink today. ; Therapist: What might be some benefits of following through with that goal? ; Patient: Definitely I'll have like all my senses there and I'll be aware of everything that's going on. ; Therapist: Uh-huh Anything else? ; Patient: Um health concerns I guess I know alcohol is bad for your health so that would be one. ; Therapist: Okay so it's it sounds like you're actually pretty comfortable with setting a goal of not drinking anymore at least at the next party and seeing how it goes? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay do you think it would be alright if we met again to kind of check in on how it goes and see if it's working out for you? ; Patient: Yeah that would be okay. ; Therapist: Alright great and then it sounds like some of the benefits you're expecting are health benefits and having an easier time with achieving your academic and career goals and just sort of not having to deal with some of the consequences that your peers deal with. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: Okay well very good. ; Therapist: Is there anything else that you think would be important for me to know? ; Patient: Um how would you advise me to like get maybe my friends to stop drinking? ; Therapist: Oh that's a great question so a lot of times kids who are trying to cut back it's harder if their friends are still drinking and one of the easiest things is trying to have more activities that don't involve alcohol but of course that's harder if you're not the one planning so some of the things that can be useful if you're at a party say and there's already alcohol there and there are other kids that maybe aren't your closest friends. ; Therapist: Some of the things that I would recommend since you're interested are you know carrying around a different drink that looks like it has alcohol in it so you know even carrying an empty beer bottle or beer can or you know if people are having a mixed drink just having the Coke say without any alcohol mixed into it. ; Therapist: Often having anything in your hand is a good barrier for people who are trying to offer you alcohol because you already have something in your hand and it kind of prevents them from trying to stuff something else in there. ; Therapist: Do you think any of those things might work for you? ; Patient: Yeah for sure. ; Therapist: Okay what about in terms of talking to your friends about it have you thought about how you might approach with them or is that something else you'd like some tips about about telling them about your plan to stop drinking? ; Patient: I was just planning on playing them that I never really want to drink anymore that wasn't me. ; Therapist: Uh-huh your friends would be pretty comfortable with that. ; Patient: Yeah I mean my closest friends for sure. ; Therapist: Okay great any other concerns or questions anything else I can help with? ; Patient: No I think I'm okay. ; Therapist: Okay so then like I said I'll try and see if we can meet up maybe in a few weeks and see how it's going and then if things are going great then fantastic and if you run into any stumbling blocks then we can maybe problem-solve together. ; Patient: Okay great. ; Therapist: That sound okay? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right thanks so much. ; Patient: No problem.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name laura; age 17 years; sex female; education high school ; Clinical Identifiers: Outpatient ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Therapist at school ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Nil ; History: Present history client is a senior in high school with ambitious plans for her future; family she family consists of her mother, father and a sister; personal history social relations- she is able to make and sustain relationships with friends and family; substance use history she consumes 1-2 drinks of alcohol occasionally. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: General behavior rapport formation initiated and was established, she was cooperative; mood calm; affect broad ; Psychotherapy Type: Counseling ; Psychotherapy Technique : Psychoeducation ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Session was around exploring substance use history and habits of the client. It was established that client doesnt misuse the substance. ; Reflections by the therapist: Client is ambitious and well aware of use and misuse of alcohol. She was quite comfortable with the idea of quitting alcohol completely in the near future. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Nil ; Action Plan : Client has to abstain from drinking in the next party she attends. Some ways avoiding drinking while being in a social setup were also discussed, like carrying empty an or own preferred drink to the party and sticking to it, or initiating activities or plans which do not involve alcohol. ; Next session details: In next few weeks

dialogue: Therapist: Hi, Kyle. ; Therapist: How are you doing today? ; Patient: Pretty good, Dr. Grande. ; Patient: How are you? ; Therapist: I'm doing well. ; Therapist: Thanks for asking. ; Therapist: What's been going on? ; Patient: I've been applying to doctorate programs for this upcoming fall, and I'm kind of stuck because I got into two of the schools that I was looking at. ; Patient: I got into both of them, and both of their programs are really good. ; Patient: Both of them have great research track records and kind of what I want to do. ; Patient: Yeah, but the problem is I don't know how to decide between the two now. ; Therapist: Okay, so you applied to two places, and you got in both. ; Therapist: It sounds like both have programs that are really well suited to what you want to do. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: And you're having difficulty deciding which one to go with. ; Patient: Yeah, I've always had trouble with indecisiveness, and it's like when I have two choices of something that's very similar, I always get stuck. ; Patient: It's very hard for me to actually make a decision. ; Therapist: Well, let's start at the beginning. ; Therapist: You definitely want to go on for a PhD. ; Therapist: So we've established that. ; Therapist: So it's going to be one of these programs either way. ; Therapist: So really the only question you're really left with is which one. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So oftentimes these situations we look at pros and cons. ; Therapist: Well, it sounds like there's a lot of pros to each one. ; Patient: Are there any cons to either one? ; Patient: I mean, really not any that I can think of. ; Patient: I've tried to write them down on a piece of paper, do the pros and cons, and the pros look very close, and it's like the same number. ; Patient: But I mean, both programs are good. ; Patient: I have connections with some of the teachers in both of them. ; Patient: They're both in the same city. ; Patient: They're really close to each other. ; Patient: They're both very similar, but for some reason I just don't know. ; Patient: It would be easier if there's some cons to one of them. ; Patient: It would make the decision easier if you had some negatives for one of the programs and weren't there for the other one. ; Therapist: So in a way, I guess this is what we call a quote unquote good problem. ; Therapist: It's a problem, but you're choosing between two alternatives that are both really positive for you. ; Therapist: But it's still a choice. ; Therapist: It's still tough. ; Therapist: And you mentioned before that you had some in your past, you're indecisive. ; Therapist: So maybe what we can do in this process is help you build decision-making skills or contribute to that ability because whichever program you get into or you choose, you're going to have to make decisions later on too. ; Therapist: And probably there, maybe some of those will be easier. ; Therapist: Maybe some of those choices won't be as easy. ; Therapist: So I think this would be a matter of looking at what's important to you. ; Therapist: You mentioned the research agenda or agendas at both universities. ; Therapist: That's important to you. ; Therapist: What are the aspects, and maybe not so much thinking about these two universities, but in general, if you had to rank one of them, what aspects are really the most important? ; Patient: Well, definitely the research is up there. ; Patient: I definitely want to get that out of whichever school I go to. ; Patient: I think something else that's important is for the university to have kind of like maybe a post-doctorate plan, whether they have connections with like businesses where I can get a job like right after I graduate, or like if I was going to move into a faculty position, like if they kind of had a pathway that would help set me up for that, like that, those are probably the biggest, like the biggest influencers. ; Patient: The research and not a guarantee necessarily, but some high probability of employment. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: So really what we could do here, if you want to look at these two universities, even though we don't really have any negatives to look at, we can rank these positives. ; Therapist: So it sounds like both have the research that you're looking for, that they're both there, but if you could rank, and maybe you don't have this information right now, but if you could rank them in terms of the next most important aspect, which is really how hard will you work to find me a job? ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: That's kind of what you're saying. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: I mean, it sounds like what you're saying. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: So do you have an information or is that something you can find? ; Patient: Actually, I never thought about that. ; Patient: Like I guess I could go online and kind of look at, a lot of times universities put up like job acceptance rates like afterwards, and they put up percentages, kind of like what people do afterwards. ; Patient: So maybe if I looked at the websites and kind of found the information to see like how many of them go on to be professors or like work in the industry, maybe I should check that out. ; Patient: That might help me. ; Therapist: That might allow you to have a different difference between them. ; Therapist: Because right now it's like they're just kind of melded together. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: You have really no way yet to separate them. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: So maybe this can build a bit of a discrepancy, a bit of a gap between them, so you can say, okay, this one, neither one is bad. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: But this one might be a little better for what I want to do. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Does that kind of- ; Patient: Yeah, that makes sense. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Similarly, as you think about it, I know whenever I leave, you know, speaking with somebody or in some situation, that's where I always think of all the questions I wanted to ask. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: So when you leave here, you can consider some of the other aspects and like think it over. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: It's really important to me. ; Therapist: And try to create that distance between them so you can look at them as really two separate entities. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: Another possibility would be to find out this information, maybe talking to representatives from each university. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And seeing if they may or may not have more information about potential pros and they might even have some cons. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: You know, I'm sure they'll present in a polite manner, but they can let you know maybe some of the negatives associated with the other university or maybe some of the positives that aren't quite as positive. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: Something that they do well with others, other university doesn't do as well. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So it sounds like this information gathering would really be your next step. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I never actually thought about ranking the pros and going from there. ; Patient: So I think that's a good idea. ; Patient: I like that. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: And one of the things that might be helpful to drive you is what importance you place on these different aspects. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: So kind of clarify and we can, we may again, we'll talk about this, but clarify your values and what's important to you. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And then that'll help you to kind of rank some of these attributes. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: Yeah, that makes sense. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Let's leave it there and we'll kind of pick up next time with looking at what we talked about unless you have any further questions. ; Patient: No, no. ; Patient: I think, yeah, I think I know what I can do afterwards to help me decide. ; Therapist: Great. ; Therapist: So I'll see you in about a week and we'll pick up there. ; Patient: All right. ; Patient: Sounds good. ; Patient: Thanks, Scott.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name kyle ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Name dr. Grande ; Past Session Information: Follow up session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Difficulty taking decision for college admission ; History: Nil ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behaviour client was cooperative and rapport was established; mood calm; affect broad ; Psychotherapy Type: Cognitive behavioural therapy ; Psychotherapy Technique : Active listening, problem solving ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Client was confused to pick a college out of two were equally desirable. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Nil ; Action Plan : To read more about strength areas of each university to better compare and decide ; Next session details: After 1 week

dialogue: Therapist: Hey Rhonda, how are you doing today? ; Patient: I'm fine. ; Therapist: You're fine? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: I'm glad you could come in today for this intake. ; Therapist: I want to explain a little about the process. ; Therapist: I understand you've already completed the informed consent. ; Patient: Yes. ; Patient: Yeah, I've done this before. ; Patient: You've done this before? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: So you understand my obligations to report certain things. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So you answered some other questions in that packet that you filled out with the informed consent. ; Therapist: It's actual type questions. ; Therapist: Information might be on your driver's license or insurance card, things like that. ; Therapist: I'm going to be asking you more emotionally oriented questions as part of this part of the intake. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Some of the topics we'll be covering are sensitive for many people and you may not want to talk about it and that's okay. ; Patient: All right. ; Therapist: So if I stumble upon one of those topics, you know, I discuss it, just let me know and we don't have to talk about it. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: If there's an area that you don't want to talk about right now but you want to talk about later, we can talk about it later. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Does that make sense? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So how are you referred here to our agency? ; Patient: Well, I have this friend that I've known her forever and she told me that she was really concerned about the way I was living my life and that, you know, I should be coming here. ; Patient: So as a favor to her, I'm here. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So you're here as a favor to your friend. ; Therapist: Do you feel committed to counseling? ; Patient: I mean, I guess there's some things I can work on, but I mean, they have problems that I really just don't have. ; Therapist: And when you say they, who are you referring to? ; Patient: Some of my other friends, the friend that referred me. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So there's some elements that they're observing and reporting to you, but you're not quite seeing them. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And you think they might not be there at all? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Fair enough. ; Therapist: So I want to talk about what we refer to as the presenting problem. ; Therapist: I know you indicated you're here because a friend referred you, but in terms of the, any symptoms or any problems, issues that might be going in your life, are any of those you can identify, you could talk about? ; Patient: Well, I mean, I will admit I do get angry a lot. ; Therapist: Anger? ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: And sometimes when I get mad, I break a few things. ; Patient: I'll punch a wall, I won't hit anybody. ; Patient: So I mean, that's not a problem, you know, but I'll take it out on something that doesn't feel pain. ; Patient: I thought that was a good thing. ; Therapist: So inanimate objects are the target of some physical and angry behavior. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: But not people. ; Patient: No, not people. ; Therapist: So do you view anger as a problem you want to work on? ; Patient: I guess I could work on being less angry. ; Patient: I don't think I have a anger problem, but I can be less angry. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So one of the symptoms would be anger. ; Therapist: You don't necessarily feel like it's a large problem, but you could be less angry. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: You'd be okay. ; Patient: I mean, I think everybody can work on being a little more peaceful. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: That makes sense. ; Therapist: Anything else? ; Patient: Now, this is something I have tried to stop before, but I'm having a problem. ; Patient: I do smoke marijuana a lot. ; Patient: I'm not even going to lie to you. ; Patient: A lot. ; Patient: Um, and recently I've been getting into like snorting some drugs. ; Therapist: Can you tell me what drugs? ; Patient: Like Xanax. ; Patient: And I've tried to stop before and it didn't work, but I mean, I like it. ; Patient: So it's kind of like that. ; Patient: Do I really want to give it up? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: Sure. ; Therapist: You seem a little more torn on that. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So you say a lot of marijuana. ; Therapist: And that can mean something different depending on the person. ; Therapist: What's it mean to you? ; Patient: Several times during the day. ; Patient: Even when I'm at work, I'll go to my car on break. ; Therapist: Does anybody notice that? ; Patient: I mean, the place I work at isn't very professional, I guess. ; Patient: I mean, there are managers that I hide it from, but everybody there pretty much knows. ; Therapist: They're okay with it. ; Therapist: And you mentioned specifically Xanax and Benzodiazepine. ; Therapist: Any other drugs?
