; Patient: Uh, no. ; Patient: It's just mainly the marijuana and then I've started the Xanax. ; Therapist: That seems like it's more recent. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I mean, within the past four months, a friend introduced it to me and started to like it. ; Therapist: How often do you use that? ; Patient: About once less often, I'd have to say about maybe twice every weekend. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And the marijuana sounds more like an everyday thing. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Any other drugs? ; Therapist: Pretty much it? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: No more drugs. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: How about in your past? ; Patient: In my past, I have experimented with cocaine, but I kind of got in trouble with the DUI for that. ; Patient: Had to stop that. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Anything else? ; Therapist: No. ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Any other problems you identify to work on? ; Patient: Um, I can sometimes let my pride get in my way. ; Therapist: Pride? ; Therapist: Tell me a little bit about that. ; Patient: I don't like being told I'm doing something wrong. ; Patient: Because most of the time I'm not or I'm doing it in a way, like just because I'm not doing it your way doesn't mean I'm doing it wrong. ; Patient: I know what I can do and I know what I'm capable of. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So is somebody telling you that you're acting in a way that's proud? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I've had several people. ; Patient: I've lost a few friends because over, you know, little things that I won't budge on. ; Patient: For example, things like, you know, like what the best TV show is. ; Patient: I know what the best TV show is and anybody who says any different is wrong. ; Patient: But I've lost friends. ; Patient: But you know what? ; Patient: Maybe they're not real friends. ; Therapist: So you're indicating pride, but it sounds like maybe inflexibility is a part of it too. ; Patient: I guess. ; Therapist: Has anybody ever said that to you? ; Patient: I mean, not in that word, but I mean, now that you say it, I guess, yeah. ; Therapist: You think that's kind of together with the pride? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: You feel like, okay. ; Therapist: Is that a fair adjective, inflexible? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So we have anger, mostly the objects though. ; Therapist: Not at people. ; Therapist: Marijuana, a lot. ; Therapist: Xanax, not as much. ; Patient: Occasionally. ; Therapist: Occasionally. ; Therapist: And then inflexibility and pride. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Does that sound like an accurate? ; Patient: I mean, yeah, that really would. ; Therapist: Accurate list. ; Patient: Not that I hate to admit it. ; Patient: It does. ; Therapist: So it's tough for you to talk about this part? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah.
summary: Patient Particulars : Nil ; Clinical Identifiers: Agency ; Referral Information : Referred by a friend ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms anger and substance use chief complaints 1. Difficulty in controlling anger 2. Substance abuse ; History: Nil ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Speech there is a sense of embarrassment and hesitation in the speech; mood  affect sad; thought, perception patient perceive himself as an angry person who doesnt not hurt anyone but object also he hopes and desires to change himself; cognitive functions cognition seems fine; judgement and insight insight is intact. He believes in himself and can judge what works for him. ; Psychotherapy Type: Cbt; mode individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Reflective listening ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: There are few themes which can be seen in the session 1 issues related to anger  patient discussed problems, including anger management issues, and also issues with pride and inflexibility. He acknowledges his anger which is primarily directed towards objects rather than people. They express some willingness to work on reducing their anger. 2 substance use he reports heavy marijuana use, including during work breaks, and occasional use of xanax. Session reflects his desire to quit, particularly with regards to cocaine, which they have previously struggled with use mainly marijuana and occasional xanax. 3 shame and discomfort patient finds it challenging to discuss his problems as it is discomforting and shameful for him. 4rigidity  patient has inflexibility in certain matters have caused conflicts in relationships. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Anger and substance use ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Heidi, I appreciate your participation in the intake so far. ; Therapist: I want to change to a new section, if that's okay with you. ; Therapist: And this section is on substance use. ; Therapist: Is that an area you feel comfortable discussing? ; Patient: Sure. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So are there any substances that you currently use? ; Patient: I drink a bit. ; Therapist: Can you tell me how often you drink? ; Patient: I guess it's more than a bit. ; Patient: I would say I have probably three drinks a day. ; Therapist: And what are you drinking? ; Patient: Beer. ; Therapist: Do you know what size? ; Patient: The bottles, I think they're 16 ounces. ; Therapist: Three bottles of beer a day? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: How long does it take you to consume those? ; Patient: Probably a couple of hours. ; Therapist: So every day, three beers in about two hours. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Does that do anything to you in terms of your mood or feeling? ; Patient: It just kind of helps me unwind after a long day of work, relaxes me. ; Therapist: So it's relaxing for you? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Has it ever gotten you into any type of trouble? ; Patient: There was one time that my friends and I kind of got into a fight after I had been drinking. ; Patient: And we almost stopped talking because of it, but we were able to work it out. ; Patient: But I've almost lost friends over it before. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Is there any other areas where it might disrupt functioning? ; Patient: Sometimes it's hard to get up and get to work the next morning after I've had... ; Patient: If I drink it later in the day, it's hard to get up and get to work on time the next morning. ; Patient: So I've been late a couple of times too. ; Therapist: So three bottles of beer pretty much every day? ; Patient: Pretty much every day. ; Therapist: Pretty much every day. ; Therapist: Has there ever been a time when you've consumed more or less in a particular day? ; Patient: Not typically during the week, but sometimes I'll drink more on the weekends. ; Patient: Maybe drink my normal three in a couple of hours and then maybe three or four hours later I'll have a couple more. ; Therapist: You have a few more? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And how long have you been drinking alcohol? ; Patient: I guess I started when I was around 17. ; Therapist: 17? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Now you mentioned beer. ; Therapist: Have you ever consumed any other type of alcohol? ; Patient: I've tried wine and shots before, but I always kind of just gravitate more towards the beer. ; Therapist: Back towards the beer? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Any other substances that you use currently? ; Patient: On the weekends as well I'll smoke some pot with my friends Saturday night. ; Therapist: That's pretty much just weekends? ; Patient: Sometimes during the week before I go to sleep I'll have a joint. ; Patient: It helps my anxiety and my worries before I go to bed. ; Therapist: When did you first start using marijuana? ; Patient: That was probably a couple years ago when I first started college. ; Therapist: About two years ago? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And on the weekends sometimes other times? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Actually I guess it's more on the weekends, but I would say maybe every other day during the week. ; Therapist: So mostly on the weekends, occasionally during the week. ; Therapist: Has it ever led to any trouble or change of functioning? ; Patient: Not, I mean on the weekends no because I don't really have anywhere to be, but sometimes during the week if I, again kind of like the alcohol, if I smoke it too late again it's hard to get up in the morning and get to work on time and my boss is really starting to get irritated with me with how often I've been late. ; Patient: Not that I'm like super late, but I'm late enough. ; Therapist: Have you ever tried to cut down on the substance use, alcohol, or marijuana? ; Patient: I've tried to cut back on the alcohol before, about a year ago I tried. ; Patient: When I started this job that I have now, I tried to cut back when I first started and I was able to get down to like two, one or two beers instead of three, but then the job got stressful and I got comfortable I guess and started drinking more again. ; Therapist: So you think perhaps the alcohol use is connected to the stress of your job? ; Patient: I would say it's definitely connected. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: Have you ever been annoyed by people that perhaps criticize your substance use? ; Patient: Yeah, my family can be critical of, they don't really know about the marijuana, but they can be critical of my alcohol use. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: And that bothers you? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Have you ever felt bad or guilty about your substance use? ; Patient: I've felt guilty with my mom because it upsets her so much sometimes, like I'll feel guilty about how my substance abuse upsets her. ; Patient: And sometimes I feel bad like if I have a fight with my friends, if I'm drunk I'll feel bad the next day about getting into an argument with them because it's usually over something silly. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: Have you ever had to drink or use drugs first thing in the morning to steady your nerves or to lessen the effects of a hangover? ; Patient: I would say not during the week, but on the weekends when I'll drink a little bit more, sometimes I'll have just a little bit. ; Patient: If I drink Saturday night I'll have a little bit Sunday morning to just get going. ; Therapist: So on occasion that happens? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I wouldn't say it's often, but on occasion. ; Therapist: So alcohol and marijuana, two substances you currently use. ; Therapist: Can you tell me about substances you've used in the past? ; Patient: I had a party one time, I tried Ecstasy, but I didn't like it and I ended up not really hanging out with those people anymore so it wasn't an issue. ; Therapist: So just the one time? ; Patient: Yeah, just the one time. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Patient: In high school my friends, a lot of my friends were smokers, so I smoked cigarettes but it just made me feel sick and I didn't really like it very much, it didn't really do anything for me. ; Patient: So that didn't last long. ; Therapist: She discontinued? ; Patient: Yeah, that didn't last long at all. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: Any other substances or just those two? ; Patient: Just those two that I'm currently using and then just the smoking and the Ecstasy previously. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: Do you have a family history of substance use? ; Patient: My grandfather, my mom claims that my grandfather was an alcoholic. ; Therapist: Any other history? ; Patient: No, not that I'm aware of at least. ; Therapist: Before I move to the next section of the intake, while we're still talking about substance use, is there anything else you want to add? ; Therapist: Any other comments you want to make about this section? ; Patient: I think so, I think that covers it. ; Therapist: Does that cover it pretty well? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: I appreciate you answering these questions and if you're okay I'm going to move from the section and move to the next section of the intake. ; Patient: Okay.
summary: Patient Particulars : Age 19years; marital status unmarried; education high school ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Strong desire to take alcohol and marijuana 2. Difficulties in controlling substance taking behaviour 3. Persisting with substance use despite harmful consequences 4. Progressive neglect of alternative pleasures associated disturbance- negative social consequences ; History: Present history dependence syndrome due to alcohol for 2 years; onset- insidious; course- continuous; precipitating factor work stress; past history patient first started consuming alcohol and marijuana when first joined work and found oneself under regular stress; family history patients grandfather consumed alcohol regularly; substance history consuming alcohol and marijuana from last 2 years. Patient used to smoke as well but didnt continue for long; tried mdma once but didnt continue; premorbid history- reaction pattern to stress indulge in drinking; social relations disrupted relations with friends, colleagues and family ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: General behaviour patient was conscious and in touch with the surroundings, cooperative towards the examiner, rapport could be established; content- ideas of guilt, affect restricted; judgement personal judgement impaired ; Psychotherapy Type: Person centered therapy ; Psychotherapy Technique : Active listening ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patient came with the complaints of regular substance intake, including alcohol and marijuana. It started 2 years back when patient started working oneself under stress. Different psychoactive substances were also tried in the past but werent continued. Patients social relations have got strained. Complaints and issues at workplace have also been rising. Theres also some guilt in the patient for upsetting mother due to substance taking habit. ; Reflections by the therapist: Patient was cooperative throughout. Rapport could be established. There was concern regarding social disruptions especially with mother which was accompanied by feelings of guilt. ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Hi, this is Dr. Grande. ; Therapist: I hope you find this video useful. ; Therapist: If that's the case, please like it and subscribe to my channel. ; Therapist: As always, thanks for watching. ; Therapist: So, alright, let's take a step back and talk about competency. ; Therapist: What education did you need for the job you have now? ; Patient: I have my bachelor's degree, and we got a little bit of training. ; Patient: You know, every so often we get some training at work and stuff like that. ; Therapist: Are you evaluated at work by anybody to see if you're doing the job you should be? ; Patient: Yeah, I have a supervisor, so they check up on stuff, and also if I feel like I have questions and stuff like that, I can go to them as well. ; Therapist: Have you been found in that system to be somebody who's satisfying the requirements of, in terms of competency, satisfying the requirements of an employee? ; Patient: Yeah, I mean, I haven't been fired, so that's a good sign, I guess. ; Therapist: That's a good sign. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: You haven't been fired. ; Therapist: Have you ever had any type of write-up or somebody discussing something with you? ; Patient: No, I just kind of feel like maybe the climate has changed a little bit at the office after this happened, like maybe other people think I didn't make the right decision. ; Patient: I guess maybe that's part of where all my doubts are coming from, like no one has said to me, and I haven't, you know, my supervisor hasn't called me in and said, I'm concerned about this, but I just feel like maybe other people think that I did something wrong. ; Therapist: All right, so there's no evidence supporting that in a kind of a direct fashion, like a supervisor coming to you, but there's other evidence supporting it based on what you're feeling and how you're maybe perceiving things. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And you're getting this feeling that by the way they're interacting with you, by the way they're relating to you, that... ; Patient: Yeah, which I guess maybe I shouldn't be that freaked out about because there have been other people who have made mistakes and like the supervisors have talked to them and, you know, even then they didn't lose their job, so it's not like, you know, I have, you know, I don't know, I guess it's not like just hearing them or thinking that they're judging me is an indication that something terrible is going to happen or that I made this huge mistake. ; Therapist: All right, so you can see that, from talking this through, you can see that some of this could be feelings, thoughts you're having combined with what you're actually observing. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And it's not like you're filtering your observations in a way that's maybe making them seem a little more destructive, a little more negative. ; Patient: Yeah, it's kind of like I know it's not that big of a deal because, like I said, my supervisor hasn't talked to me and it's not like I've heard anything terrible about anything happening to the kids or anything like that, but I just feel like, you know, I have those thoughts like oh, was she, you know, saying something, you know, when she said that, was she referring to what happened and stuff like that. ; Therapist: Can you provide an example of an interaction with a coworker where they said something that you thought maybe was referring back to this? ; Patient: Yeah, so like we were having like a regular work meeting and we kind of like, you know, discussed how things are going and it's been kind of a big deal, you know, more so than usual because the kids were removed from this family, so, you know, one of my coworkers kind of nudged me and said like, oh, you're the bulldozer, you know, you plowed right through that family and took those kids away and, you know, I think she meant it kind of like as a joke and just, you know, maybe to say like, you know, you did what you needed to do, but it kind of made me feel like, does she think that I'm just callous? ; Patient: Like does she think that I just didn't care and, you know, you get what I'm saying? ; Therapist: Yeah, yeah, so she referred to you as a bulldozer and one way to take that would be powerful, efficient, but another way to take that would be kind of destructive. ; Therapist: We talked about before, destructive, callous, they're mechanical, they don't have a lot of feeling. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So, you don't know exactly how she meant it, but you're thinking maybe it was connected ; Therapist: that way. ; Patient: Yeah, and I guess it kind of like, it goes back to like my fear that I didn't think it through, that I kind of just, you know, I made the report and that was that and, you know, it makes me feel like, was I being mechanical? ; Patient: Did I just, was I just nonchalant about it? ; Patient: Should I have put more thought into it? ; Patient: And it really, you know, it hit me where it hurt, I guess, you know. ; Therapist: So her saying that really kind of brought up this thought that maybe you are, maybe you are not empathetic enough or compassionate enough. ; Patient: Yeah, or even just thoughtful. ; Patient: I guess maybe I was just being, you know, just going about my job without putting a lot of thought into what I was doing. ; Therapist: It's automatic. ; Patient: Which is, exactly. ; Therapist: So maybe one thing you would have done differently in light of that comment, at the time make a decision you would have thought through the steps more? ; Patient: Yeah, maybe taken a little bit more time. ; Patient: But at the same time, I mean, I don't have a ton of time. ; Patient: I've been good at my job. ; Patient: I've been doing things that way, but then it just kind of made me think, have I been missing stuff all along? ; Patient: I don't know.
