He fears of being negative judged by his colleagues. He is concerned about being too mechanical or automatic in his decision-making process. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Stressed

dialogue: Therapist: Hi, August. ; Therapist: I'm Angie. ; Therapist: I'm one of the nurses here. ; Patient: I'm not feeling very well. ; Patient: I'm feeling really sad. ; Patient: I'm scared. ; Patient: And I don't know where to go. ; Therapist: What helps you feel better when you're sad? ; Patient: Coming to the hospital. ; Therapist: Okay, August. ; Therapist: So you've come to the hospital a few times now, saying that you're feeling sad, and you're not getting along with your roommate, right? ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: My roommate is mean to me, rude to me, and I don't know where to go. ; Therapist: Did you talk to your group home worker? ; Patient: Yes. ; Patient: He told me to go for a walk. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: So you came here? ; Therapist: All right, so this might help you feel better for right now, but it doesn't help once you go back home, does it? ; Patient: A little bit. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So I think I should speak to someone in your group home. ; Therapist: Do you know who the manager is? ; Patient: Her name is Kim. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And what's the phone number? ; Therapist: I don't see it in the chart. ; Patient: 416-525-00. ; Patient: I forgot. ; Therapist: Okay, we'll need to find the number. ; Therapist: Can you give me a few minutes, and I'll go call the DSO to find the number for your group home? ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay, August, I just got off the phone with your manager, and we talked about how you've come to the hospital a couple times, several times now, and that you're upset with your roommate. ; Therapist: So we discussed if they could help you make a crisis plan. ; Patient: What is that? ; Therapist: Okay, so it's a plan that reviews how people can help you. ; Therapist: So when you start to get upset or afraid, a crisis, it helps people help you, so that things don't get so bad, you don't feel you need to run away or come to the hospital. ; Patient: Oh, that sounds good. ; Therapist: Okay, so we'll review what we talked about, because I want to make sure that you understand. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay, great. ; Therapist: There's also something called an exit interview that we can go over together. ; Therapist: And in this, we'll go over what brought you here to the hospital, anything that we did today at the hospital, what helped, and also what to do, how to plan after when you get home. ; Therapist: So this needs to go home with you, and we'll put it in this package to take home and go over with your group home worker. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay, and we'll also follow up with the group home worker. ; Therapist: Okay.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name august ; Clinical Identifiers: Hospital ; Therapist Information : Name angie, profession nurse ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms 1 feels sad 2 scared ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior nad; speech incoherent, mood  affect low, thought disorganized, perception distorted, cognitive functions impaired, judgement and insight poor ; Psychotherapy Type: Supportive ; Psychotherapy Technique : Supportive ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Themes discussed in session 1 support nurse trying to support patient by coming to the hospital when feeling sad and scared. 2 problem talked about the difficulties with a roommate in a group home setting, which is a significant source of stress and discomfort. 3 interventions this plan involves identifying triggers and implementing coping mechanisms like take follow-up with the group home worker as well as ongoing support after leaving the hospital. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Not clear ; Action Plan : Planned a follow up with the group home worker.

dialogue: Therapist: Yes, you really get where they're coming from. ; Therapist: You really understand the suffering involved. ; Patient: I guess maybe that's part of where it's so hard for me. ; Patient: I know that I'm causing a lot of suffering for people. ; Therapist: Let's talk about that. ; Therapist: So you're in a position where you have to make some decisions about people's lives. ; Therapist: Sometimes those decisions result in people being separated from their families, sometimes they don't. ; Therapist: Are you really the cause in the larger picture? ; Therapist: Are you really the cause of these families being broken up? ; Patient: I guess not like it's their actions. ; Patient: If they were doing the right things, even if I did come in, their kids wouldn't be removed. ; Patient: But it is still hard to be the one that holds that trigger. ; Therapist: Right, you're the immediate cause, kind of at the end of the whole process. ; Therapist: But the true cause happened years or months before you got there, as people made decisions that maybe weren't the best for their children, for themselves. ; Therapist: So you're really coming in, to some extent, the tail end of a long series of behavioral choices. ; Patient: Yeah, that's true. ; Therapist: Ultimately, for this family that's causing you, like that you're worried about, and kind of looking at it on a long-term lens, do you think the children are better off because they're not with that family right now? ; Patient: Probably. ; Patient: I mean, if they get with a good family, which usually they do, it's good for them. ; Patient: Maybe it could be a wake-up call for the parents, or if not, at least the kids are getting their needs met and stuff like that. ; Patient: It's probably really hard for the kids, and they probably want to go back to their parents, but I think overall, we wouldn't be doing this if we didn't think that it would be best for the kids to go to a place where they're going to be taken care of. ; Therapist: So, immediately there's some pain because you have to break up the family, but in the long run, maybe there's a better result. ; Patient: Yeah, yeah. ; Therapist: Even with that, though, let's talk about the concern you have about making a poor decision. ; Therapist: So, based on what you're describing, do you believe this was actually a poor decision? ; Patient: I guess not. ; Patient: It just feels like it is. ; Therapist: It feels like it is, and it was a tough decision, but looking at it in the way that the evidence, maybe you can appreciate that you might have had to do the same thing even if you go back in time. ; Patient: Yeah, yeah, I think so, and I'm not sure anybody else would have made a different decision either. ; Therapist: So, you really did what you had to do, but because there's still a pain component there for them, you were feeling torn. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And you don't want to go through this again. ; Patient: No, I mean, not this feeling, but I do want to keep doing my job. ; Therapist: But doing your job in a world where you could make a mistake, that's not as appealing. ; Patient: Yeah, I mean, I guess I always knew I could make mistakes, but it just feels really real now, I guess, is the difference. ; Therapist: So, in this particular instance, based on what you're saying, it doesn't seem like a mistake. ; Therapist: Let's consider a situation where you did make a mistake. ; Therapist: That would be the worst case, right? ; Therapist: We're just taking things to the worst case scenario. ; Therapist: Your fear here is that, in a sense, regardless of what already happened, going forward, you would be mortified to make an error, because of this pain you're feeling right now. ; Therapist: It's just unbearable. ; Therapist: And it's thrown everything into chaos for you. ; Therapist: So, looking around, like, where you work, and the history of the profession, what's the mistake you see people make from time to time that you would be frightened of? ; Patient: I guess the biggest mistake you can really make is to miss some form of abuse or something like that. ; Therapist: And then someone's hurt? ; Patient: Okay.
summary: Patient Particulars : Nil ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Nil ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Feelings of guilt ; History: Present history as per patients job a work, she had to take a decision about a family where heshe took the children away for their better future. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behavior patient was cooperative and rapport could be established; mood low; affect restricted ; Psychotherapy Type: Type cbt; mode individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Cognitive restructuring ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patient discussed about her apprehension towards a decision she made about a family where she had to separate the children from their parents and has been feeling guilty ever since. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Nil ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Hey Carly, how are you doing today? ; Patient: I'm good, how are you? ; Therapist: I'm doing well, thanks for asking. ; Therapist: What's been going on this last week? ; Patient: I've just been feeling kind of in a rut. ; Patient: I've been looking for a job and haven't really gotten anywhere. ; Patient: And then I had a drink the other night. ; Patient: And I just felt like me not having a job and me going out and having that drink, it wasn't deserved. ; Patient: And I just felt like such a loser because that was the time that I should have been at work if I had a job. ; Patient: And instead I was at the bar drinking. ; Patient: So I had one drink and then it led to another because then I just felt worse and I figured I had one. ; Therapist: So how much did you drink in total? ; Patient: I think I lost track after four or five. ; Therapist: How long had it been since you had a drink before that? ; Patient: I did really well. ; Patient: It was I think like three weeks or so. ; Therapist: So you did really well and then you had one drink and that just made you feel like you weren't successful. ; Patient: I felt like a loser. ; Therapist: You felt like a loser. ; Therapist: And you feel that kind of led to drinking some more. ; Therapist: So you had a rough time with things. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: How about now? ; Patient: I mean now I just kind of, I don't know, I'm afraid to go back. ; Patient: I'm afraid to go out with some friends. ; Patient: They invite me out to dinner. ; Patient: But I know there's alcohol. ; Therapist: Is that where you were when you had that first drink? ; Therapist: Was out with friends? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: There's a few things going on. ; Therapist: We've talked in the past about separating the behavior from the person. ; Therapist: So behavior is what we do, not who we are. ; Therapist: Do you remember those discussions? ; Therapist: And correct me if I'm wrong, but it sounds like, I'm going to use some different words than you used, but it sounds like when you had that first drink, you're kind of ashamed that you had a drink and you had it during the time when you would have been working. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: That's pretty accurate. ; Therapist: That's pretty accurate. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So taking yourself kind of back to that moment, right, where you had that first drink, like you finished that first drink. ; Therapist: What was your thought at that moment? ; Patient: Just like, shameful. ; Patient: Like I did really, really well and then here I was and I just finished a drink and I knew I wanted another one. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So shameful is kind of like the feeling, but the thought is I did really, really well. ; Therapist: So that's what you were thinking, was I did really, really well. ; Therapist: And was that the end of the thought or was there more before you had that next drink? ; Patient: I guess just I was doing well and then I had a drink and I just felt like an awful person. ; Patient: So I figured what was the hurt in having more. ; Therapist: So the sequence would have been you had the drink, you felt shameful. ; Therapist: At the same time you're thinking that you were doing really well and then just really, as you said before, you just felt like a loser and then you decided might as well just have the second drink. ; Therapist: So another thought might be that, like I might as well just have the second drink. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So you can see how there's some thoughts and some feelings at work right as you finish that first drink. ; Therapist: Was it fairly quick, were those thoughts and feelings fairly, occur very quickly after the drink? ; Patient: Yeah, I would say as I was finishing and then finished. ; Therapist: So right away you regretted it. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: And in that regret, as you thought about it, thought might as well just continue drinking now because you kind of blew it. ; Patient: Yeah, I already messed up, I might as well keep going. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And that's a common cycle to fall into and you had three weeks where you hadn't had a drink prior to that. ; Therapist: So let's look at this, let's try to separate the behavior from yourself a little bit. ; Therapist: If you had a friend who was in the same predicament, right, who had a history of using alcohol and then had three weeks without any alcohol use, and then their behavior was to have a drink, what would you think of them? ; Patient: I would think that they had a rough day or something must have happened where, I mean it's just one drink. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: A rough day with one drink, and what would you think of their behavior? ; Therapist: How would you categorize that behavior? ; Patient: It's just they made a mistake. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: So not ideal. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Depending on their point of view, maybe a little irresponsible. ; Patient: Yeah, I think irresponsible would be... ; Therapist: Irresponsible? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: But you wouldn't necessarily characterize them as a bad person. ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: But their behavior was a bit irresponsible. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: You know, in terms of like their recovery plan, which would be to not drink. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: But when you apply that same examination to your own situation, how do you characterize yourself after you had that first drink? ; Patient: It was my mistake. ; Patient: It was something that... ; Patient: It makes me a worse person for doing it. ; Therapist: So you see how you're being a little, well, it would be quite a bit rougher on yourself. ; Therapist: Like your evaluation of yourself is fairly harsh. ; Therapist: You mentioned loser earlier and ashamed. ; Therapist: Whereas you wouldn't necessarily evaluate somebody else that way. ; Therapist: How would you evaluate your behavior? ; Therapist: How would you judge your behavior taking that first drink? ; Patient: Shameful. ; Patient: I mean, irresponsible. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: And just bad overall. ; Therapist: So bad, irresponsible, shameful. ; Therapist: Is there a way to separate that behavior in terms of your thinking, in terms of the way you evaluate it from yourself? ; Therapist: Like are you in the behavior together, enmeshed, or can you be separated? ; Patient: I think we could be separated. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: But it feels like we're... like I am that behavior. ; Therapist: In that moment, it's very congruent for you. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: The shame matches the behavior. ; Therapist: The behavior matches shame. ; Therapist: Like it's... they're one at that moment. ; Therapist: But really, logically, rationally, you're you. ; Therapist: Right? ; Therapist: Your identity and values and your behavior is something you do. ; Therapist: But in the moment, it's hard for you to see that. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Looking back on it now, are you able to see the distinction between what people do and what they are? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I mean, just because you have one drink doesn't make you a horrible person in the thing, right? ; Therapist: No, certainly not. ; Therapist: And you were clean for three weeks and you had one drink, so really your behavior was a slip. ; Therapist: Right? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: And irresponsible in relationship to your goals, I suppose, but still a slip. ; Therapist: And you could have stopped. ; Therapist: But that shame got a hold of you, right? ; Therapist: That thought, well, now I've done it. ; Patient: I blew it. ; Therapist: Yeah, so with that mentality, you kind of set yourself up for drinking more. ; Therapist: So I think this is important because we've seen this cycle, like where you have weeks of sobriety, and then you'll drink a bit and then have weeks of sobriety. ; Therapist: And I'm wondering if part of the difficulty you're facing is you're not coping with the slips as just slips. ; Patient: No way. ; Therapist: You're allowing them to be gateways into a lot more drinking than a slip. ; Therapist: Does that make sense? ; Patient: That sounds pretty accurate. ; Therapist: And you see how the shameful feelings kind of just interfere with the behavior that's really consistent with your goals, which would be to not continue drinking. ; Therapist: Another piece of this, too, is the associating with friends who drink. ; Therapist: You're putting yourself in a treacherous situation. ; Therapist: And again, that's a behavior, right? ; Therapist: That doesn't make you one way or the other. ; Therapist: It's a behavior. ; Therapist: How would you judge that behavior, going out with friends? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: Difficult because I like being around those people. ; Patient: But I guess it would be risky. ; Therapist: Risky. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: It's a risky behavior. ; Therapist: And what does it make you? ; Therapist: Who are you? ; Therapist: Because you do that behavior. ; Therapist: How do you feel about yourself when you take that risky behavior? ; Patient: Guilty. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So you have guilt and you go out with your friends. ; Therapist: And then you have shame if you drink. ; Therapist: And both, in this case, both emotions that kind of point you in the direction of more drinking. ; Therapist: So part of this behavioral strategy here is to avoid those circumstances, like to recognize that that's a risky behavior which you have. ; Therapist: And the other part would be to deal more effectively if you do so. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: Does that separation of what we do and who we are make sense to you rationally? ; Patient: Kind of. ; Therapist: It feels a little unnatural though. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So maybe as you're confronting similar situations in the course of the next week, you could be aware of behaviors that might put you at risk and try to separate your identity from that behavior. ; Therapist: So just judge the behavior. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: And don't pass any judgment on yourself. ; Therapist: Does that make sense? ; Patient: Kind of, yeah. ; Therapist: It might help you to, since it's a little tough to, because right now the feeling and the judgment are intertwined, right? ; Therapist: It might help to write down when these things happen and kind of write down like one row for, this is how I judge this behavior that I'm thinking about doing and this is how I judge myself. ; Therapist: So if you see a lot of self-judgment, that might be a clue that you're falling into that cycle a little bit. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Where you're making decisions based on that emotion instead of a rational judgment of the behavior. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Would that help a little bit? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I think that would probably be beneficial. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: So that will be our plan going forward until next week is note, document your judgment about your behavior. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And any judgment you may have by yourself. ; Therapist: Right? ; Therapist: And there's some insight that can be gained there. ; Therapist: Right? ; Therapist: You kind of distinguished the two. ; Therapist: And make a note of those and try to use that evidence before making a decision that might put you in a risky spot. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Is that the plan? ; Patient: Yeah, I think I can try that. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Good. ; Therapist: I'll see you next week and we'll see how you did with those goals. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: Bye.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name carla; ; Clinical Identifiers: Setting outpatient ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Follow up session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Acute intoxication due to alcohol ; History: Patient has been trying to find a job but has been unsuccessful so far. She had a drink 3 weeks ago which made her feel like a failure. She again indulged in drinking behavior last week and had more than 4-5 drinks which made her feel defeated and guilty; substance history patient consumes alcohol. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: General behavior patient was cooperative and rapport has been established; mood anxious; affect restricted; thought content- ideas of shame and guilt about oneself; judgement personal judgement impaired; insight grade 5 ; Psychotherapy Type: Type cognitive behavioral therapy; mode individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Cognitive restructuring ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patient expressed her shame that she had been experiencing for not having a job and drinking instead which then makes her feel guilty. ; Reflections by the therapist: Patient has been making hasty decisions which makes her land in a space of shame about herself. She is not holding a job currently, which adds further to the feelings of guilt. She then makes harsh judgement about own self which directly affects her self identity and also about the people who associated with such behaviors. The session revolved around making her more aware of her behaviours and to separate her identity from those behaviors. ; Action Plan : Patient has been told to document her judgement about her behavior to gain more insight. This is to further use it as an evidence before making risky decisions. ; Next session details: After 1 week

dialogue: Therapist: Leigh, I want to thank you for your participation so far in this intake, but I want to move to another section of the intake, specifically your family history, if that's okay with you. ; Therapist: So I'm going to be asking you various questions about your relatives. ; Therapist: Okay? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Are you adopted? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No? ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Are your parents married? ; Patient: They're not married. ; Therapist: They're not married? ; Patient: I mean, to each other. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: No. ; Patient: I mean, my dad, he's now remarried. ; Patient: And while my mom, I mean, which marriage are we talking about? ; Patient: Because she's been married four times. ; Therapist: She's been married four times? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: So. ; Therapist: At what age were you when your parents divorced? ; Patient: I was about 16. ; Therapist: 16? ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: And then your father, you said remarried? ; Patient: He did. ; Therapist: And how long after the divorce? ; Patient: I think it was about 18. ; Therapist: You were about 18? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: And then your mother remarried and was divorced a few times, you're saying? ; Patient: Well, yeah. ; Patient: I mean, it was pretty much right after they got divorced. ; Patient: She married some guy. ; Patient: I don't even know. ; Patient: He was a nice guy. ; Patient: It was like six months after, pretty much like real fast. ; Patient: And then that didn't last very long. ; Patient: Forgive me. ; Patient: I have to remember like how long they were together because there's so many. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: But I believe that they were only together for not even a year. ; Patient: And then she kind of had some time where she just was dating, but it was numerous people. ; Patient: And then she met somebody in her AA meeting and they married. ; Therapist: That lasted, they probably got married, I would say probably two years after the first marriage. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: And then that lasted, I would say roughly about a year and a half to two years. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: And then, yeah, the other one was probably when I was about like 25. ; Patient: And then that one lasted the longest. ; Patient: That was her third marriage. ; Patient: So that was about close to three years. ; Therapist: That was her third? ; Patient: I believe that was her third, yeah. ; Patient: Or her fourth. ; Patient: I can't remember. ; Patient: I don't know. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So it's a, well, she was married to your father. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And then married quickly after that, you said. ; Therapist: And then she met somebody at AA meeting. ; Patient: Yes, that's the third. ; Patient: And then this one would be, oh yeah, the fourth. ; Therapist: The fourth? ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And she married now? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No? ; Patient: Now she's, I don't know, just dating or whatever. ; Therapist: How long did the last marriage last? ; Patient: So that was three years. ; Patient: That was the longest one. ; Therapist: That was the longest. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: How long was your relationship with your father? ; Patient: It's good, I guess. ; Patient: I mean, my dad, he's a real, he's a genuine guy. ; Patient: I would say that he stuck around for a lot of things with my mom. ; Patient: So I would say that he's a pretty good guy. ; Patient: And I think we have a decent relationship considering what we've been through. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: How about your relationship with your mother? ; Patient: It's just, honestly, there's no other way to describe it. ; Patient: It's just chaotic. ; Patient: I mean, she's chaotic. ; Patient: So she's all over the place. ; Patient: And it's just hard to capture on a good day. ; Patient: And when you do, it's just, you know, it's kind of surface, our relationship. ; Patient: So. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So who raised you? ; Patient: My parents raised me. ; Therapist: Yeah? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I mean, they were good parents, I guess, according to my standards, because my mom was just always a mess. ; Patient: So I guess they both did the best that they could given some circumstances. ; Therapist: Do you think the way that you're raised has an impact on who you are now in terms of? ; Patient: I think so. ; Patient: Yeah, definitely. ; Patient: My mom was, and I hate to like blame my mom, but I am because she was just, my mom has done a lot of things because I know it sounds like weird, but she didn't really sleep a lot. ; Therapist: She was constantly spending my dad's money and shopping. ; Patient: So we were always dressed nice constantly. ; Patient: We were always dressed nice. ; Patient: But my mom was just always preoccupied with herself as far as shopping and just looking good and obsessive with cleaning. ; Patient: And I don't know, it just, that's all I know my mom for. ; Patient: I was just shopping and spending my dad's money and them constantly fighting it. ; Patient: They always stayed together, I think for us, but that's really, she was always kind of gone, like hi-bye kind of throughout my childhood. ; Therapist: There's some tough memories in there too. ; Patient: Yeah, yeah, absolutely. ; Therapist: Can you tell me about your siblings? ; Patient: I do. ; Patient: I do. ; Patient: I have two siblings. ; Therapist: Okay, two. ; Patient: I have a brother, Jeff and a sister, Kendra. ; Patient: And I mean, they're, they're, they're good siblings, I guess. ; Patient: We kind of just all go one or separate ways when my parents divorced, I guess just because they were just, you just become frustrated and tired with what you grew up with that you just, I guess you just don't want to relive that memory when we're together, we relive that. ; Therapist: So what's your relationship with them now? ; Therapist: What's it like now? ; Patient: It's okay. ; Patient: You know, I guess, I mean, I don't know. ; Therapist: You mentioned that everybody went their separate ways. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I don't really see them quite honestly. ; Patient: So if I do see them and maybe it's like if I show up at a, at a family party once every five years, but so I think to me that's okay. ; Patient: That's right. ; Therapist: You're satisfied with your relationship with them? ; Patient: I think so. ; Patient: I mean, you know, it's not my fault that they won't accept who I am. ; Therapist: Are you aware of any medical conditions that like your mother and father may have or your grandparents? ; Patient: Like heart disease or anything like that kind of medical? ; Patient: My grandma had like heart disease. ; Patient: My grandfather had cancer, but he beat that colon cancer. ; Patient: It wasn't like the first stage, but he was fine after. ; Patient: But as far as my parents, they don't have any medical issues that I know of. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: How about kind of the same question except for mental health conditions? ; Patient: Oh, just crazy. ; Patient: Like my mom was crazy. ; Patient: She was just completely all over the place, I guess. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Are you aware of any formal diagnosis that she had? ; Patient: She was just manic, like I guess like bipolar, but she never really got like a definitive label as bipolar in like therapy or anything like that. ; Patient: But yeah, she was definitely a mess. ; Patient: Like anxiety and just, you know. ; Therapist: So symptoms of bipolar and anxiety. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Any other mental health conditions in your family? ; Patient: No, just my mom with her, you know, obsessiveness and she'd get depressed after. ; Patient: But as far as any other siblings, no. ; Therapist: Do you have any special family traditions? ; Patient: I mean, we would go on family vacations when I was a kid. ; Patient: We were constantly staying at the best hotels and stuff like that because our mom, you know, would shop around. ; Patient: She actually would book three hotels and just decide which one she liked better when we got there. ; Patient: I don't, I don't know. ; Patient: But anyway, we would do that. ; Patient: We would go on vacations together. ; Patient: We would always go down to the beach. ; Patient: So that was really our family tradition as far as in like holidays. ; Patient: We did when we were younger, we would have like our family over for Christmas and stuff like that. ; Patient: But. ; Therapist: Can you tell me about holidays? ; Therapist: Like what were the most important holidays to your family? ; Patient: Christmas was; Easter. ; Patient: They were the most important and Thanksgiving. ; Therapist: How did you celebrate those holidays? ; Patient: Sometimes we would go to my cousin's house on my dad's side and Christmas would be at my parents' house and then Easter would, it would just vary back and forth between my cousins or my parents who ever wanted to have it. ; Therapist: Can you tell me about your extended family? ; Patient: My extended family, well on my dad's side my uncle, he's super successful and he's a cool guy. ; Patient: I don't really see him now. ; Patient: But when I was a kid I did. ; Patient: But now I don't see him at all. ; Patient: Honestly. ; Patient: I don't really see anybody at all. ; Patient: But yeah, and on my mom's side she has a sister and she's like crazy but she's not as crazy as my mom. ; Patient: But she has two kids and she's actually still married to her husband. ; Patient: They were actually high school sweethearts. ; Patient: So I don't know where my mom came from. ; Patient: And yeah, I haven't seen her probably since I graduated high school. ; Patient: And you know she associates with my mom and they talk amongst themselves so I don't really have a relationship with her either. ; Therapist: Alright, so not many active relationships there in your family history it sounds like. ; Patient: Well yeah, there's not many now. ; Therapist: Is there anything else you want to tell me about your family history? ; Patient: Um, my mom would drink sometimes when I was growing up. ; Patient: But that's why my mom was really friendly to me when she would drink. ; Patient: And yeah, she would drink. ; Patient: I don't know if that's, you know, she was considered an alcoholic but she would drink often. ; Patient: And I think just to come off of her shopping a lot she would drink or vice versa. ; Patient: Sometimes she would drink while shopping or just to calm down she would drink. ; Patient: And sometimes in her drinking habits she would actually be nice to me. ; Patient: So yeah. ; Therapist: Anything else you want to tell me? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: So I want to thank you for helping me complete this family history section of intake. ; Therapist: And if you're okay we'll move on to another section. ; Patient: Definitely. ; Therapist: Alright.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name leigh ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Nil ; History: Family history patients parents have given divorce to each other when she was 16 years old. Their father remarried after two years. Their mother remarried after 6 months of their divorce and has been married four times so far. They shares a cordial relation with her father but not with her mother. Their mother was mostly unavailable and focussed more on how patient and her siblings were dressed. She was mostly occupied with cleaning and shopping. She also used to consume alcohol frequently. Patient has two other siblings, one brother and one sister. All of them went their separate ways after their parents divorce and meet each other occasionally. Patients grandfather had colon cancer and her grandmother had a heart disease. Patient is not much in contact with her extended family now. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behavior patient was cordial and rapport could be established; mood calm; affect broad ; Psychotherapy Type: Type pct; mode individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Active listening, empathy ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Family history was gathered ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Nil ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: So, good to see you again. ; Therapist: Last week we were talking about anxiety. ; Therapist: Do you have your diary card? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay, let's look at it real quick. ; Therapist: Where is it? ; Therapist: Over here, huh? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay, so anxiety is really high. ; Therapist: What happened yesterday? ; Therapist: Anxiety is really high. ; Therapist: Give me a quick summary. ; Patient: Anxiety is always really high, but yesterday was the worst. ; Therapist: Why? ; Patient: I was driving, my dad was driving and I was in the passenger seat and we were in a lot of traffic and that already makes me nervous because I like to be on time. ; Patient: I know, I know. ; Patient: I don't want to be late because then what if I get in trouble? ; Patient: So I was already kind of on edge and then we passed the accident that I guess was causing all the traffic and there were two cars and they were like mashed together like accordions and there was a tarp and I know that under that tarp there was a dead body and the car went right by it. ; Therapist: That's scary. ; Patient: It was horrible. ; Therapist: Kind of explains that number, huh? ; Patient: Yeah, who wouldn't be anxious? ; Patient: That's like a normal thing because there's a dead body. ; Therapist: Well, I'd be anxious, of course, and it's kind of scary to see that and what else did you think when you saw that? ; Patient: Who would drive when there's two cars mashed together like accordions and a dead body? ; Patient: That's insane. ; Patient: It's insane. ; Patient: You have to be insane to drive. ; Therapist: And your family wants you to learn to drive this year because you're 16. ; Patient: They're insane. ; Therapist: Hmm. ; Therapist: And yet you keep complaining how you live in the middle of nowhere and if you had a car you could like go see friends more and get out of your lame old town and get to go do fun things. ; Patient: But I can't see my friends anymore if I'm dead. ; Therapist: True. ; Therapist: That's true and I won't get to see you anymore because you're dead. ; Therapist: I know I don't treat dead people, right? ; Therapist: Remember that? ; Therapist: Yeah, okay. ; Therapist: So on one hand, I know the idea of driving is completely overwhelming and I know you're anxious like all the time. ; Patient: And I get that I have to drive because you're right. ; Patient: It's like the middle of nowhere and I can't just like not go places but... ; Therapist: So I'm wondering if we can bring it back to some of those things you were talking about to help reduce your anxiety. ; Therapist: Maybe that's one idea to help you be able to get in the driver's seat. ; Therapist: What do you think? ; Therapist: So essentially you're practicing getting in the driver's seat by like doing the treatment and getting in the driver's seat of your anxiety as opposed to being a passenger and you're letting your anxiety outside of your life because that's what you're doing. ; Therapist: What do you think? ; Patient: That was a lot of puns, Jen. ; Therapist: I'm punny, aren't I? ; Therapist: So here's an idea. ; Therapist: Let's get on board. ; Therapist: We start treating this anxiety. ; Therapist: We do a really, really good job at it. ; Therapist: We work hard and the idea of driving might not be quite as scary. ; Therapist: And let's face it, being an anxious driver increases your risk of accidents. ; Patient: Well, that's helpful. ; Patient: Thanks. ; Therapist: So reducing your anxiety is going to make you a safer driver. ; Patient: Yeah, but all these things you keep telling me that I have to do to be less anxious, they involve like feeling really anxious. ; Therapist: True. ; Patient: There's no way to like, you're supposed to like just make it go away. ; Patient: You're not supposed to make it worse to make it better. ; Therapist: So, here's something interesting ; Therapist: You're really good at being really anxious. ; Therapist: So you'll be really good at this and it will go away. ; Therapist: I promise you. ; Therapist: Totally promise you. ; Patient: That's so hard. ; Therapist: Well, reality is, you know darn well I'm the expert here of treating anxiety and I promise you it will get better. ; Therapist: I know everything. ; Therapist: I know this. ; Therapist: What do you think? ; Patient: I think it sounds really hard. ; Therapist: It is really hard. ; Therapist: I'm not going to lie to you. ; Therapist: It's totally, totally hard. ; Therapist: But maybe it's just another insane thing that you have to be more anxious to be less anxious. ; Patient: I know. ; Therapist: It is pretty insane, isn't it? ; Therapist: I agree. ; Therapist: Well, another option is you can just be anxious the rest of your life. ; Therapist: Do they have a bus where you live? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: You live with your parents for the rest of your life. ; Patient: I know. ; Therapist: So you can live with your parents for the rest of your life because you're too anxious to leave town. ; Therapist: You won't be able to drive. ; Therapist: So you could just live with your parents, be anxious all the time. ; Therapist: Maybe you could go up with some ideas on how to maintain your anxiety the rest of your life. ; Therapist: You won't need to learn to drive. ; Therapist: I mean, your parents are fairly nice. ; Therapist: They probably drive around for the rest of your life, you know, until they pass away or something. ; Therapist: In the meantime, what about that? ; Therapist: So forget the whole treatment. ; Therapist: I'm pushing you too hard. ; Therapist: Why don't we just talk about how to maintain your anxiety? ; Therapist: You're good at it. ; Patient: No, Jen, that's not funny. ; Therapist: It's not meant to be funny. ; Therapist: What do you think? ; Patient: That's horrible. ; Therapist: I'm trying to help you. ; Therapist: I really want to help you. ; Therapist: I know being anxious every day is really hard. ; Therapist: So one of the options is to really become good at being anxious and do okay and learn to sit with your anxiety. ; Therapist: Another option is, yeah, getting more anxious to reduce your anxiety. ; Patient: So you're saying that kind of no matter what I choose, it's going to involve feeling anxious? ; Therapist: Yeah, but you're practiced at it. ; Patient: Well, I mean, if those are the only options, we might as well do the one that's going to make it eventually go away rather than just be there forever. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Do you want to review what some of the treatment strategies will be? ; Patient: Yeah, I guess. ; Therapist: Okay, let's do that.
summary: Patient Particulars : Age 16 ; Therapist Information : Name jen ; Past Session Information: Follow up session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms death anxiety chief complaints anxious while driving ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behavior coopertive; mood  affect anxious, thought negative, cognitive functions distorted, judgement poor ; Psychotherapy Type: Dynamic supportive analytical ; Psychotherapy Technique : Reflective listening supportive cognitive restructuring ; Issues discussed in Current Session: 1 problem patient experiences chronic, high levels of anxiety like seeing a car accident, increases the anxiety. Family expectations to learn to drive add to the persons anxiety. 2 strategies the therapist suggests facing anxiety to reduce it over time. Discussed about different approaches to managing anxiety, including exposure therapy. Used reassurance, humor, and realistic scenarios to help the person understand their situation and the need for treatment. 3 patients response realizes that facing anxiety is necessary for long-term improvement. The therapist uses ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Anxiety

dialogue: Therapist: In this scenario, a client meets with a domestic violence advocate for a local agency that provides low-cost to no-cost counseling for individuals and their families. ; Therapist: This is the fourth time that they have met. ; Therapist: The client has been in her relationship for two years. ; Therapist: She does not have children. ; Therapist: The violence has taken all shapes and forms. ; Therapist: She wants to break up with her partner and is not quite sure how to do so. ; Therapist: She does not fear for her life if she breaks up, but she is concerned that her partner would make problems for her at work and in her community. ; Therapist: Hi Liv. ; Patient: Hi. ; Therapist: Welcome back. ; Patient: Thank you. ; Therapist: How are you? ; Patient: I'm feeling pretty intense. ; Patient: Things have kind of gone downhill since I was here last time. ; Therapist: Oh, I'm sorry to hear that. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: I know last time we talked, you and Kelly had just gotten engaged and you were rather excited about plans that you had for your life. ; Therapist: So tell me what has happened? ; Therapist: What has shifted? ; Patient: I think that we've just sort of fallen back, you know? ; Patient: I was really hopeful that with the proposal also came the promise to work on the relationship and work on her anger and work on, you know, being the couple that we hope to be. ; Patient: And that's not happening. ; Patient: It's not happening. ; Patient: We're right back to where we were. ; Therapist: I'm sorry to hear that. ; Therapist: I know you were excited. ; Therapist: You were feeling hopeful for change and I don't get that same sense from you right now. ; Therapist: In fact, it seems like you're feeling pretty sad and maybe even a little hopeless about the situation. ; Therapist: Well, how can I be helpful and supportive and useful to you right now? ; Patient: I just, I don't know how to make change. ; Patient: I don't know how to end this. ; Patient: I don't know how to get out. ; Patient: I don't know how to, I just, I can't do it anymore. ; Therapist: So you've decided to make a change. ; Therapist: And in fact, it sounds like you've decided to leave the relationship. ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: I mean, I want to, I don't want to be in it, but I don't, I don't know how to get to not being in it. ; Therapist: So you're thinking about it. ; Therapist: It's not that you've committed or decided that you absolutely want to leave the relationship, but correct me if I'm wrong. ; Therapist: What you're saying is you want to make a change and you don't want this relationship as it is right now. ; Therapist: What, what are you, when you think about changing, what, what ideas, I mean, I guess you mentioned leaving. ; Therapist: What other possibilities or thoughts have you had about change and what that might look like? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: It just feels so overwhelming when I think about it. ; Patient: I just, I can't seem to find a way out of it. ; Patient: And that feels, feels ethical. ; Patient: It feels like it, you know, I don't want to hurt her. ; Patient: I just don't want to be in this relationship anymore. ; Therapist: Why don't you want to be in this relationship anymore? ; Patient: It's not healthy. ; Patient: It's I'm not happy. ; Patient: I can't imagine that she's happy, even though she says she is. ; Patient: It's, you know, we're fighting constantly. ; Patient: I feel like I'm walking on eggshells with her. ; Patient: She's overprotective. ; Patient: She, yeah, it just, it doesn't feel right. ; Patient: It just doesn't feel right. ; Therapist: It doesn't feel right. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: And so, so what would feel right? ; Patient: Oh, that's a huge question. ; Patient: I just don't, I'm not sure. ; Patient: Just this isn't right. ; Therapist: So the way things are is not right. ; Therapist: It's not working. ; Therapist: You don't feel supported. ; Therapist: This isn't the kind of relationship that, that you want or that you had hoped that it would be. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I mean, when we started, it was, it was lovely. ; Patient: She was amazing. ; Patient: She was this super caring and thoughtful woman. ; Patient: And, you know, we were lots of same interests, same friends. ; Patient: It's, you know, she was just fantastic. ; Patient: And I don't know, I don't know where that changed. ; Patient: And I feel like we did this on again, off again stuff. ; Patient: And it was just, it just seems to like, it's just not right. ; Patient: And I know, I know I don't deserve to be treated this way. ; Patient: I know that I'm better than that. ; Therapist: You really value your self and your well being and in your spirit. ; Therapist: And it sounds like you don't feel like you're taking good care of yourself by staying in this relationship. ; Therapist: And even though things started out well, they haven't turned out to be the kind of relationship that you want for yourself. ; Patient: No, but you know, but she's lovely. ; Patient: And I love her. ; Patient: And I can't imagine, I can't imagine my life without her in it. ; Therapist: So you're feeling torn. ; Therapist: Yeah, you're, you're torn between your love and affection for her, and your sense of honoring yourself. ; Therapist: And you've got a lot of mixed feelings. ; Therapist: And you are saying that you need something to change. ; Therapist: That sounds like you're able to kind of hold that complexity, if you will, that you've got these strong feelings for this person. ; Therapist: And you don't feel like this is the good relationship for you. ; Patient: No. ; Patient: I don't think it's good for either one of us. ; Therapist: For both of you. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Well, so so then you've talked a little bit about leaving. ; Therapist: I mean, tell me more about what you've thought about. ; Therapist: And when you think about making a change in terms of leaving, what what might that look like for you? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: I mean, it feels, I just can't imagine my life without her in it. ; Patient: So the idea of not having her there feels really scary. ; Patient: And the idea of staying the way it is, and things not changing, feels even scarier. ; Patient: So I don't, I don't know how to, and I don't even know how I would do that. ; Patient: Our lives are so intertwined. ; Patient: I ; Patient: mean, my business, our friends, the queer community is so small. ; Patient: You know, that's my family. ; Patient: Those are not just my friends. ; Patient: That's my family as well. ; Patient: And so it just, you know, how do you, how do you extract yourself from that, in a way, you know, for me, like, in a way that I feel that I'm doing that with grace and respect for her and respect for myself. ; Therapist: What thoughts do you have about how you do that? ; Therapist: How do you extract yourself? ; Therapist: How might you extract yourself in a way that has some integrity and grace, as you said? ; Patient: I don't even know. ; Patient: I mean, I've talked to my friend Jay about it. ; Patient: And I don't know, he suggested like a break, but I don't know. ; Patient: I just don't want to get caught in that on again, off again before, like, you know, like we've done before. ; Patient: But the idea of a break feels a little less, I don't know, maybe more gentle. ; Patient: I don't know. ; Therapist: Say more, a little more gentle. ; Patient: I don't know, to give us both time to really think about it. ; Patient: And I don't know, maybe, maybe she'll change. ; Patient: Maybe, maybe if I'm, you know, if this is it, if this is it, like if this break is it maybe, maybe she'll be able to change. ; Therapist: I heard you say that living, you know, moving on and having a life without Kelly is really scary. ; Therapist: In fact, it's almost impossible for you to imagine what that would look like, especially with the way that your lives are so intertwined. ; Therapist: I also heard you say that the thought of not making a change is scarier. ; Therapist: And I was wondering if you could say a little bit more about what you mean by that. ; Patient: It's just, I feel exhausted. ; Patient: I feel like I'm not, I'm not who I was when I came into this relationship. ; Patient: I feel like I'm constantly struggling to make her happy and that just doesn't work. ; Patient: There's nothing I can do. ; Patient: And I feel like I've lost my joy. ; Patient: And I don't know. ; Patient: I'm just afraid of what will happen if I just keep staying in a place where I feel like I'm falling apart. ; Patient: Piece by piece. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: So you're concerned about your own well being and your own joy and your, your spirit if you you stay and don't make this change. ; Therapist: And that's the part that's really scary for you. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: You mentioned that your friend suggested possibly taking a little break. ; Therapist: And you said that that was a scary thought for you. ; Therapist: And I guess I'd like to hear more additional thoughts you might have about that as a as an option for you. ; Patient: Well, I did. ; Patient: It seems like I mean, if it could happen, if we could find a way to make it happen that it would be it would just give me some time to think about like what I want and what I need and and you know, I feel like I can't sort out what's me in this anymore. ; Patient: And, and so like if I had that space just to sort of breathe and not have to worry about her feelings and taking care of her and just being able to focus on myself for a little while. ; Patient: I don't know it seems like that would be helpful. ; Therapist: It sounds like you're feeling like you're so in, in it just so in the mixed emotions and the sense of hopelessness and sadness and disappointment that it's really hard for you to see out of it and an advantage, a reason to take a break would be just to give you a moment to breathe and look around and collect yourself and not be so stuck in that ambivalence, if you will, that sense of not knowing. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Well, if you don't mind, I'd love to ask you to take a look at this ruler here. ; Therapist: I just kind of wrote this down really quickly. ; Therapist: But on a scale of zero to 10, zero being not motivated at all and 10 being extremely motivated. ; Therapist: How motivated would you say you are to take a break in your relationship right now? ; Patient: Oh, like six? ; Therapist: Six? Oh, somewhat motivated? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Why a six and not a one? ; Patient: Because I know it needs I need it. ; Patient: I feel like I'm losing myself. ; Patient: So I feel like it's important. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Well, so So why six and not a nine or 10? ; Patient: Because I'm not sure how to make it happen. ; Patient: Yeah, I don't I don't know. ; Therapist: So it's important to you. ; Therapist: And you're not maybe fully confident or sure about the how part. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Well, kind of following up on that on a scale of zero to 10, zero being not confident at all. ; Therapist: 10 being extremely confident. ; Therapist: How confident are you that if you decided to take a break from relationship with Kelly, you would be successful at making that happen? ; Patient: Oh, I don't know, maybe like a three or four. ; Therapist: Okay, so so less confident, a little less confident than you are motivated. ; Therapist: Why a three and not a zero? ; Patient: Because I, I want it. ; Patient: I mean, I do. ; Patient: It's something I want. ; Therapist: And so wanting it makes you feel confident that you confident to some extent that you could actually make it happen. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Why Why three and not an eight or a nine? ; Patient: I can't control her. ; Patient: I don't know how she would react. ; Patient: And I just don't want any more arguments and anger. ; Patient: And yeah, and I don't want to hurt her. ; Patient: So. ; Therapist: So when you think about taking this break, you're also thinking about how she might respond and what she might do. ; Therapist: And that creates this whole other kind of set of worries. ; Therapist: And it undermines your sense of confidence on some level. ; Patient: It creates a lot of anxiety for me. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: What do you think needs to be different in order for you to feel more confident about successfully being able to take a brief break? ; Patient: I think I like maybe a plan, like just knowing, knowing what the rules are sort of like where, where, where I want to go with it and what I'm, I don't know what I want to accomplish. ; Therapist: So thinking through an actual plan, like what you would say, how long, what the boundaries are, might, might help you. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: In that regard. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And then one final question on a scale of zero to 10, zero being not ready at all and 10 being extremely ready. ; Therapist: How ready would you say you are to commit to taking some kind of brief break in the, let's say the next couple of weeks? ; Patient: I think an eight. ; Therapist: An eight? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So, so pretty ready. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And, and you've spoken to this already a little bit, I believe, but I'll ask you again, why an eight and not a one or a two? ; Patient: Because I know if I just let it drag out, that I'm going to be miserable. ; Therapist: So your sense of readiness is actually really connected to your motivation. ; Therapist: That is that this is something you know that you need to do for yourself. ; Therapist: And if you don't, things are not going to get any better. ; Therapist: And that, that makes you both motivated and even more ready. ; Therapist: Well, why, why an eight and not a 10? ; Patient: That's, you know, scary. ; Patient: Change is hard. ; Patient: And thinking about not being with a woman, I thought I was going to marry. ; Patient: It's sad, makes me sad. ; Therapist: So ; Therapist: your emotions, your sense of maybe sadness and, and grief and disappointment around this detract from your sense of readiness in some way. ; Patient: Sort of giving up on a dream. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: And so another aspect then to your whole experience is that you're, you're grieving. ; Therapist: The relationship isn't even over yet, but you're grieving the dream and the hopes that you had. ; Therapist: And that's a, that's a heaviness and certainly a factor in, in what you do next. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Well, if I could take just a moment and make sure I've captured and understood everything you've shared with me. ; Therapist: And I, I know this is really difficult to talk about. ; Therapist: So I really appreciate you spending the time to share with me what, what this has been like for you. ; Therapist: You've been feeling stuck and things were great for a while. ; Therapist: You had some hope that things were going to change. ; Therapist: And now you realizing that Kelly is not going to change and that you were suffering in the process that you are really being kept from your aspirations and your dreams in a lot of different regards. ; Therapist: You know that you need to make a change. ; Therapist: You want to make a change. ; Therapist: And you have a lot of mixed feelings about this change. ; Therapist: You know, it's what you want to do. ; Therapist: It's the right thing for you. ; Therapist: And you still really care and love Kelly. ; Therapist: And you're also concerned kind of on an outer level about your business, about your community, about your family and your friends and how they may be affected by a breakup. ; Therapist: In order to make this more manageable, you're thinking maybe in terms of smaller change, like taking a small break as opposed to breaking off the relationship. ; Therapist: And you feel like you're pretty ready. ; Therapist: You're somewhat, you know, you're motivated and it may be a little less confident, but you also said that if you were able to maybe think through a concrete plan that that might help you feel more confident. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And that's certainly something that we could do together next time we meet. ; Therapist: If that's all right with you, I'd be happy to hear your ideas, maybe even share some suggestions with you about a possible plan. ; Patient: That'd be great. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Thank you very much for your time Liv. ; Therapist: I really appreciate it.

He has a mixed feelings about the relationship, torn between their love and the realization that the relationship is not healthy or fulfilling. 2fear patient is scared about the thought of leaving the relationship and facing the unknown though he feels taking a break to focus on himself can help him to get a clarity about the relationship. 3 sadness he feels sad and grief over the realization that the relationship may not fulfilling which leads him to a sense of loss. 4 desire for change despite the challenges and uncertainties, 5 action plan they both explored his feelings and conflicts about making decisions, and creating a plan for moving forward in a way that feels more authentic and respectful for both as therapist can see a desire for change and a willingness to for improvement. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Mild depression ; Action Plan : They both explored his feelings and conflicts about making decisions, and creating a plan for moving forward in a way that feels more authentic and respectful for both as therapist can see a desire for change and a willingness to for improvement. ; Next session details: Session scheduled.

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Sarah, how are you doing today? ; Patient: I'm okay. ; Patient: It could be better, but it could be worse. ; Patient: I'm hanging in there. ; Therapist: You're hanging in there? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: I understand you've been having some symptoms that have been bothering you. ; Therapist: Can you tell me about those? ; Patient: I'm worried all the time. ; Patient: Just every day, all day, just so worried about everything. ; Patient: I've just started back to school after 20 years. ; Patient: I've been a housewife. ; Patient: The kids are now grown, so why not go back to school? ; Patient: Now, for the past seven, eight months, it's just been nothing but worry, worry, worry, constantly all the time. ; Patient: I'm worried about home, worried about school, and it's affecting my life. ; Therapist: All right, so a lot of worrying. ; Therapist: How many days would you say you worry in a typical week? ; Patient: How many days don't I worry? ; Patient: I'd say most days, Monday through Friday, Saturday, it's just always worrying. ; Patient: On Monday through Friday, I'm worried about school, or when I'm at school, I'm worried about home. ; Patient: Then on the weekends, I know the school week's coming up, and then I'm just worried about managing everything. ; Patient: How am I going to deal with everything? ; Patient: I would say it's a lot. ; Therapist: It's very distressing for you. ; Patient: Very much so. ; Therapist: You mentioned it's impacting school. ; Patient: Well, in school, I'm not doing too well right now. ; Patient: When I was an undergrad, I used to be a straight-A student. ; Patient: I thought I could do it again, just pick up where I left off, but right now, I'm worried so much that I'm so focused on worrying that I'm worried about what assignments to do, worried about, do I have this turned in, that my grades are slipping right now. ; Patient: When I'm in school, I'm so worried about home, what's going on at home, that I can't pay attention in class. ; Patient: It's just all-consuming. ; Therapist: All right, so both at school and at home. ; Patient: Oh, yes, definitely. ; Therapist: You find it difficult to control the anxiety? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: That's affecting in a major way. ; Patient: Yes, very much so. ; Therapist: Let me ask you some other questions that may be tied in with this. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Do you use any alcohol or drugs? ; Patient: Some. ; Therapist: Some? ; Patient: Some. ; Patient: I have a drink occasionally, but I'm so worried right now. ; Patient: My nerves are always on edge right now that I find it helps. ; Patient: I got under control. ; Therapist: It's under control? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: How often would you say you drink? ; Patient: Maybe some here and there every day. ; Therapist: How much would you say you drink? ; Patient: Maybe a few glistens of wine a night, but I'm not an alcoholic or anything. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: How about the drug use? ; Patient: A little pot, but I find it helps my nerves. ; Therapist: Just now and then? ; Patient: Maybe a couple times a week. ; Therapist: A couple times a week. ; Therapist: Have you ever had a panic attack? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No? ; Therapist: Have you ever had any trauma in your history? ; Patient: Well, my grandma, she died when I was young. ; Patient: She used to take care of us. ; Patient: She was like a second mom to me, and I saw her that way. ; Patient: She died when I was young, and she was real young. ; Patient: I was really close to her. ; Patient: I think about her a lot now, especially since I have started back in school. ; Patient: She's always encouraged me, get your education, get it while you can. ; Patient: Now I've been thinking about her a lot. ; Therapist: She's been on your mind. ; Therapist: When you think about her, what's the feeling that comes up? ; Patient: I worry a lot about her, because I'm thinking that I'm upsetting her and her memory. ; Patient: That if I don't do well, then she will be upset. ; Patient: Even though I know she's not here anymore, she'll be upset if I'm not doing well. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: When you're thinking about her, you're having some worry? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: That's been distressing you? ; Patient: Very much, yes. ; Therapist: I'm going to ask you some different symptoms. ; Therapist: Let me know if you have these symptoms as part of what's going on now. ; Therapist: Do you feel restless, keyed up, or on edge? ; Patient: All the time. ; Patient: Just so tense. ; Therapist: How about you feel like you get tired easily? ; Patient: I'm tired all the time. ; Therapist: All the time? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Yes. ; Therapist: How about, do you find your mind going blank or having trouble concentrating? ; Patient: I find I'm trying to think of so many things at once, so I can't focus just on one thing. ; Patient: Yes, definitely having trouble concentrating. ; Therapist: Trouble concentrating. ; Therapist: Have you noticed that you're more irritable? ; Patient: I'm not sleeping a lot, so I'm cranky. ; Therapist: Cranky? ; Patient: I was going to say, according to my husband, a lot irritable. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: You mentioned you're tense all the time. ; Therapist: Is that like a muscle tension? ; Patient: Pretty much so. ; Patient: I feel like my muscles are going to snap. ; Patient: I feel so rigid all the time. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Tell me about your sleep. ; Patient: Sleep's been... what's sleep? ; Patient: It's just like non-existent pretty much right now. ; Patient: I just think trying to go to sleep when you have so much on your mind is hard. ; Therapist: So you have difficulty falling asleep? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: How about once you fall asleep, do you stay asleep? ; Patient: No, because I find like even I'll have nightmares that will just wake me up, and then I just find myself, when I get up, oh my gosh, what do I have to do? ; Patient: What am I forgetting? ; Patient: So I just always feel like there's something always on my mind that just makes it, if I'm asleep, I can't stay asleep because I wake up thinking about it, and I can't go back to sleep. ; Patient: It's just some ugly cycle going on right now. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: All right, so sleep has been a big problem for you. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Sarah, I'd like to get you in to see a counselor. ; Therapist: I can probably get you in to see one in just a couple days if that's okay. ; Patient: Oh, I would appreciate that. ; Therapist: That'd be helpful. ; Patient: Yes, yes. ; Therapist: I want to thank you for answering these questions for me. ; Therapist: This has been really helpful. ; Patient: No, thank you very much. ; Therapist: Thanks, Sarah.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name sarah; sex female; marital status married ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Restlessness 2. Excessive worry 3. Difficulty concentrating 4. Irritability 5. Decreased sleep initiation ; History: Present history patient resumed her studies after 20 years. She has been feeling restless and worrying about her life both at home and work as she is unable to manage. She has started thinking a lot about her grandmother. During patients school years, she used to take care of her and used to encourage her. Patient lost her when she was very young and was deeply affected by it. She now feels guilty that her lack of management will make her grandmother upset; substance use history she consumes alcohol and marijuana a couple of times in a week. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behavior patient was cooperative and rapport could be established; mood anxious; affect restricted; thought content- preoccupation with feelings of guilt ; Psychotherapy Type: Nil ; Psychotherapy Technique : Nil ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patient described her feelings of worry where that she is unable to manage her home and studies after taking a 20 year gap. She feels as if she is upsetting her grandmothers memories this way. She has been sleeping less due to these thoughts and so feels irritable most of the time. She finds it troublesome to concentrate and feels restless all the time. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: F41. 1 generalised anxiety disorder ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: So Bethany, can you tell me what this week has looked like for you? ; Patient: This week? ; Patient: Um, I don't know, I guess it was a little bit more productive than usual, but not really. ; Patient: I'm still just usual. ; Patient: I'm dead to the world. ; Therapist: Dead to the world? ; Patient: Yeah, you know, I'm just in my room most of the day. ; Patient: I'm not really part of the world or part of my family. ; Patient: I'm just closed off in my own little sad universe, I guess. ; Therapist: So you're feeling isolated from your family? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah, I'm just feeling really disconnected. ; Patient: Just really... ; Patient: I don't know, it's just been a really tough week with my husband. ; Patient: We've been fighting a lot, as usual. ; Therapist: So when you say you're feeling disconnected, can you explain to me more what that looks like? ; Patient: Yeah, I guess I'm just so tired all day. ; Patient: I'm just exhausted. ; Patient: He has all these demands and all these things he wants me to do, and I just feel like I'm not capable of doing that. ; Patient: I can't even get myself out of bed. ; Patient: I'm wondering how am I supposed to do all the things he wants me to do. ; Patient: Just last night, he came home at me like usual, and all the dishes were still in the sink, and all the laundry was all in the bed. ; Patient: I couldn't even tell him that I looked online for jobs, which I thought I should be proud of, but I didn't even find a job. ; Patient: So whatever, it's not even that big of a deal. ; Patient: I just thought maybe we could talk about that, but he was just feeling that his shirts need to be ironed, and I just couldn't do any of it. ; Therapist: So you feel that even though you made some progress by looking at them for jobs this week, that you didn't feel much accomplishment from that because your husband didn't acknowledge it or appreciate it. ; Patient: Yeah, he doesn't appreciate anything I do. ; Therapist: How does being unappreciated make you feel inside? ; Patient: It just makes my whole body ache. ; Patient: It just makes me feel empty. ; Patient: If he can't appreciate the things that I do, then why would I be motivated to do the things that he wants me to do? ; Patient: How am I supposed to iron his shirts when I can't even get out of bed in the morning? ; Patient: It just makes me feel really just empty, just miserable. ; Therapist: I hear you saying that you're shutting down, and not only do I hear you saying that, I can see you sitting here with me, with the way you're sitting with your honest cross. ; Therapist: I feel like you're closing yourself off to a lot of things, to a lot of people. ; Patient: Yeah, definitely I am because they don't notice anything I do. ; Patient: On Monday, I actually got out of the house, which I thought was a big deal in the moment, but I took the cat to the groomer. ; Patient: My husband's been bugging me about that for months. ; Patient: I got out of the house, I drove the groomers, I changed in my pajamas. ; Patient: All these things are a big deal to me, but he doesn't even see that as an accomplishment. ; Patient: They didn't even notice. ; Patient: My daughter didn't notice either. ; Patient: She just comes home and slams the door, doesn't even look at me. ; Patient: The cat was all groomed, had a nice little bow, and I haven't even spent five days since then. ; Patient: No one's even said anything since then. ; Therapist: So I feel like I've made this huge accomplishment for myself by getting out of the door, even, and taking the cat to the groomers. ; Therapist: But then when I get home and it's not noticed by anyone, it takes it all away. ; Therapist: It doesn't even matter to me. ; Patient: Exactly. ; Patient: Exactly. ; Therapist: So for things to matter to you, and for you to feel good about the even little steps you're making, you really need to have that acknowledged by your husband and your daughter. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I mean, otherwise what's the point? ; Patient: You know, if they don't have that support, all they do is point out the things I haven't done. ; Patient: They'll do something that it's all about what hasn't been done. ; Patient: Oh, you haven't vacuumed in two months. ; Patient: But they don't notice the things that I actually do. ; Therapist: So I feel, I hear you saying that you're experiencing a lot of hurt. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So Bethany, you're feeling all this hurt. ; Therapist: You're feeling, like, nobody's recognizing who you are. ; Therapist: You have all this laundry, vacuuming to do, all these chores. ; Therapist: It's a lot. ; Therapist: Do you think it's a way for me to put it away somewhere for a little bit, to be able to address other issues? ; Patient: I could try. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Do you trust me to put it in a little jar and be able to put all that hurt in a little jar? ; Patient: It's hard. ; Patient: It feels like there's so much of it in a little bit. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Do you need a bigger space maybe for it? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Alright, let's try putting it in the corner over here. ; Therapist: Let's try one more time. ; Patient: It's hard. ; Patient: It's like it won't disconnect from me. ; Patient: I just can't separate it from myself. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: What do you think that hurts trying to tell you? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Therapist: Let's take a minute and think about it. ; Therapist: We need something. ; Patient: Maybe it's just telling me that it's what I always do. ; Patient: I always try to avoid it. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Well, let's tell the hurt that the hurt is important. ; Therapist: We'll be able to come back to it once you push it away. ; Therapist: So it's not going to be there forever. ; Therapist: So can we do that? ; Patient: I guess we could try. ; Patient: I just know it's trying to tell me that it's not going to work. ; Patient: It's just, yeah, I feel like it's just what I always do with it. ; Patient: I always just try to avoid it. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Alright, well, let's try doing this. ; Therapist: Let's try closing your eyes. ; Therapist: We'll do some breathing exercises here. ; Therapist: Take a deep breath in. ; Therapist: Deep breath out. ; Therapist: Deep breath in. ; Therapist: Deep breath out. ; Therapist: Imagine all the laundry, the husband, the daughter, the cat. ; Therapist: Let's put it outside in the hallway, the very bottom of the hallway. ; Therapist: Breathe in. ; Therapist: Breathe out. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Open your eyes. ; Therapist: How does that feel? ; Patient: I guess I'm feeling a little bit more relaxed, but I still don't feel good. ; Therapist: Is it in the hallway or are you still hanging on to it? ; Patient: I guess it's in the hallway now, just different things kind of coming up. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So what are you feeling? ; Therapist: What do you want to talk about? ; Patient: Oh, no, I guess I'm kind of lost. ; Patient: What should I talk about? ; Therapist: I don't have an agenda today. ; Therapist: So whatever comes to mind, whatever you feel is important. ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: Do you have any suggestions? ; Therapist: We'll take a minute. ; Therapist: We'll think about it. ; Therapist: Close your eyes again. ; Therapist: Think about what you're feeling. ; Therapist: So what are you feeling right now? ; Patient: I guess what it really is is I feel guilty for even letting go of that hurt. ; Patient: Like I need that hurt or that hurt makes me feel guilty. ; Patient: Like I shouldn't be hurting. ; Patient: Like part of me needs the hurt and part of me just feels so bad for even hurting that I should be taking it on my own. ; Patient: I just feel a lot of guilt. ; Therapist: So you feel guilty and you hurt. ; Therapist: I'm not worthy of feeling hurt. ; Therapist: I'm not worthy of feeling good. ; Patient: Yeah, exactly. ; Patient: It's like I feel guilty for even feeling hurt. ; Patient: But I feel guilty for feeling good. ; Patient: It's like I don't deserve happiness, but I know I probably deserve to feel better. ; Patient: It's just no matter what, I just feel guilty. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So I want to kind of delve into that a little bit. ; Therapist: That guilt that you're feeling that's arising into this hurt. ; Therapist: Are you going to be willing to try something with me? ; Patient: Yeah, sure. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So what I'm going to do is I want you to think about this chair. ; Therapist: I want you to picture yourself over here. ; Therapist: This is the side of you that says you don't deserve to be able to feel guilty and that you don't deserve to be hurt. ; Therapist: So I want you to focus on yourself. ; Therapist: Tell yourself about how it makes you feel to be guilty. ; Patient: I just feel like I feel guilty for hurting because it forces me to just stay in bed. ; Patient: And it makes me feel hurt. ; Patient: It makes me feel like I'm incapable of taking care of my family. ; Patient: I need to take care of my family. ; Patient: I just feel guilty because I'm hurting. ; Patient: I can't do that. ; Patient: I can't be there for them. ; Therapist: I closed down when I'm hurt. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: And I deserve more than being hurt. ; Therapist: And you deserve more than being hurt. ; Patient: I deserve more than being hurt. ; Therapist: And you want to be there for your family. ; Patient: I want to be there for my family. ; Therapist: Do you want to share?
