; Patient: I want to share. ; Therapist: You don't deserve to be... feel guilty about being hurt. ; Patient: You don't deserve to feel guilty about being hurt. ; Therapist: You need to take care of your family and stop being so selfish. ; Patient: You need to stop being so selfish. ; Patient: Your family needs you. ; Patient: You've got to take care of them. ; Therapist: And when you don't take care of them, they get upset. ; Patient: That's why they're always mad at you. ; Patient: Because you don't take care of them. ; Patient: You're selfish. ; Patient: I'm not going to go back there. ; Therapist: How does it make you feel when yourself tells you that you're selfish? ; Patient: It hurts. ; Patient: It's really sad. ; Patient: I'm sad. ; Therapist: It makes me... it hurts me more. ; Patient: It hurts me when you tell me I'm selfish. ; Patient: When you tell me I'm not there for my family or I don't care about things. ; Patient: I do care about them so much. ; Patient: I'm trying my best. ; Therapist: Why are you making me feel guilty about being hurt? ; Therapist: I... I have needs too. ; Patient: I have needs I need to be taken care of too. ; Patient: I can't help being hurt. ; Therapist: And you're not taking care of me. ; Therapist: You're not allowing me to feel good. ; Patient: You're not allowing me to feel good. ; Patient: I'm feeling selfish and doesn't allow me to feel good. ; Patient: I can't even be there for my family. ; Patient: I can't even feel good. ; Therapist: How does it feel when you hear that you're hurt... that... that hurts and the pain that you're feeling? ; Patient: It just feels like I need to... I need to step it up and I need to try even harder. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So when you tell yourself that I'm hurt and then you tell yourself I'm selfish, how does that feel inside? ; Patient: It's just really confusing. ; Patient: It's like I need to break out of this guilty feeling and just allow myself to hurt. ; Therapist: I deserve to hurt. ; Therapist: I need to hurt sometimes. ; Therapist: And it's okay. ; Patient: I need to hurt sometimes and that's okay. ; Therapist: I deserve to have my needs met as well. ; Patient: I deserve to have my needs met as well. ; Therapist: So how does it make you feel that your other self understands that you're hurt? ; Patient: Actually it does. ; Patient: I mean it's still hurting but it's on my side. ; Patient: It's okay to hurt now. ; Therapist: I feel better that you're allowing me to hurt. ; Patient: I feel better that you're allowing me to hurt. ; Therapist: I feel validated. ; Patient: I feel validated. ; Therapist: I need to help my family. ; Patient: I need to help my family. ; Patient: I need to hurt and show them that I'm hurting but not feel guilty about it. ; Patient: That way I can be there for them and they can really understand what's going on with them. ; Therapist: I need you. ; Therapist: I need things too. ; Patient: Yeah, I need things too. ; Patient: I have needs too. ; Therapist: So how do you feel inside right now? ; Patient: I almost feel things feel lighter like some of that guilt is gone. ; Patient: Even I'm still really hurt and I feel really sad but it just feels more okay to feel that way. ; Therapist: When you hear that you need things and it's okay to be hurt and I need to be validated, tell yourself how you can maybe do that. ; Therapist: Can you allow it? ; Patient: Yeah, I think I can allow that. ; Patient: I can feel hurt without feeling guilty. ; Patient: I can feel okay about hurting. ; Patient: I can talk about hurting without feeling guilty about it. ; Patient: It's okay to hurt. ; Therapist: And it doesn't make me selfish to be things. ; Patient: Yeah, it doesn't make me selfish to be things. ; Therapist: So now you can come to an agreement with yourself to allow that space to hurt without the guilt? ; Patient: Yeah, well that's sad. ; Therapist: So we're actually out of time for today. ; Therapist: So I want you to take this awareness with you this week and then we'll kick up again next week.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name bethany, sex female ; Past Session Information: Follow up session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms depressed and anxious chief complaints 1 feels guilty 2 tries to please family members 3 hard to acknowledges her own needs 4 feels sad due to the behaviour of her family. ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior nad; speech, mood  affect, depressed, thought negative, cognitive functions slightly impaired, judgement and insight intact ; Psychotherapy Type: Cbt; mode individual behavioral. ; Psychotherapy Technique : Reflective listening thought challenging ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Themes discussed in the session; 1problems patient feels invalidated when her efforts go unnoticed by her family. She feels frustrated and sad. Feels guilty for both experiencing hurt and for feeling good. 2 techniques  therapist asked to visualise and do breathing exercises to temporarily distance herself from her hurt and create a mental space to reflect on her feelings. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Anxiety ; Action Plan : Therapist wanted her to take this awareness with her for the week till the next time they meet. ; Next session details: Next week

dialogue: Therapist: Hello, Liz. ; Therapist: How are you doing today? ; Patient: I'm okay. ; Patient: How are you? ; Therapist: I'm doing well. ; Therapist: Thanks for asking. ; Therapist: How have things been going? ; Patient: They've been all right. ; Therapist: Last time we were talking, it sounded like you were still having some difficulty with the quizzes. ; Therapist: Is that still the case? ; Patient: Yeah, it's still panic when I take them. ; Therapist: You're still in panic? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Can you tell me about the process of taking the quizzes? ; Therapist: I know we've touched on this a little bit before. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: So I'm going to class. ; Patient: I'm fine. ; Patient: I sit down to take the test. ; Patient: I'm fine. ; Patient: The test is in front of me. ; Patient: Question one, I'm not going to get that answer. ; Therapist: So you're looking down. ; Therapist: So you take these quizzes in class? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Like a paper pencil? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: With other students around? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Is having other students around distracting to you? ; Patient: No, it's happened in previous online classes. ; Patient: It's the same. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So you're pretty sure it's the quiz itself and not some external? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So it's paper and pencil. ; Therapist: You're seated. ; Therapist: You're in the room. ; Therapist: The room's relatively distraction-free? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah, everybody's quiet. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: And you're looking down at, really, the first item on the quiz. ; Therapist: And what's happening then as you look down and you read that first item? ; Therapist: What's happening at a thought level? ; Therapist: We'll start at a thought level. ; Therapist: What's happening? ; Therapist: What are you thinking? ; Patient: I'm thinking, I'm reading the question and I'm thinking, oh my God, there's four. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: So it's got to be one of them. ; Patient: And I am not going to pick the right one. ; Patient: I'm going to think I picked the right one. ; Patient: And it's going to be the one of my second choices. ; Patient: And I am not going to pick the right one. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So your thought is that you're going to select the wrong response and therefore get that quiz item wrong. ; Therapist: How about behavior? ; Therapist: Like, do you notice anything physically going on as you're thinking about that quiz item and how you're going to get it wrong? ; Patient: I'd say my palms are probably sweaty. ; Patient: Like, probably a little tense. ; Therapist: A little tense? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: That's really it. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So what it could be is that this thought of, I'm going to get this item wrong, is leading to these uncomfortable feelings, the physical feelings. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So what happens when you answer item one? ; Therapist: Like, you don't know if you have it right or wrong immediately, right? ; Therapist: Because it's a paper and pencil. ; Therapist: So you answer item one and you move on to item two. ; Therapist: What happens then? ; Patient: It starts all over again. ; Patient: I'm already like, well, I already got the first one wrong and now I'm, my chances are higher of getting this one wrong. ; Therapist: So you feel like it because you thought that you got the first one wrong, that your chances of getting the second one wrong actually increase. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: I feel like I got one wrong the whole test. ; Patient: It's all going to be wrong. ; Therapist: Have you ever had a quiz that you've taken where you were confident that you got the first item, right? ; Patient: I'm sure I have. ; Patient: I can't remember any. ; Therapist: But eventually you're going to come to one item that you're going to have these doubts about. ; Patient: Yes. ; Patient: Inevitably it happens. ; Therapist: There's going to be one that's maybe a little more difficult or difficult for you. ; Therapist: So it seems like what you're saying is that when you reach that item where you have that thought, from that point on, the next item is more difficult because you're having a similar thought. ; Therapist: Does that pattern continue? ; Patient: Throughout the test, ; Patient: yes. ; Therapist: So explain to me what, like let's just go with the example of the first item, like just to keep it more simple. ; Therapist: So you have the first item and that didn't work out for you, that thought, right? ; Therapist: The second one you thought was, I have even a greater chance of missing. ; Therapist: So what happens after you respond to that second item? ; Patient: It just compounds. ; Patient: I just start, I feel worse and worse as the quiz, as I continue. ; Therapist: That's awful. ; Therapist: So it's an awful feeling for you, right? ; Therapist: So by the time you get to item five or six. ; Patient: I'm convinced it's over. ; Patient: I've gotten a zero. ; Patient: If it's the first, I've gotten a zero. ; Patient: I've gotten a bad grade. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So that's what's on your mind. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And how about those physical symptoms? ; Therapist: Are they the same, different, are there new symptoms? ; Patient: If it like, if it's, if it like starts early at the beginning of the test, my heart's like pounding at this point, but I still have a sweaty palms. ; Patient: I'm still like tensing. ; Therapist: So it really just gets mentally and physically more unpleasant for you the whole time. ; Therapist: So when you just, when you're saying panic, the panic's really occurring a few items in after you have the first one that you thought you missed. ; Therapist: And this has been happening for a while as you described, right? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Well, how about your grades? ; Therapist: How have you actually been doing on the quizzes? ; Patient: I've been a pretty solid B student. ; Patient: So, and I feel, I wish I did better. ; Patient: I wish I got A's, but I mean, these are fine. ; Patient: But when I take those quizzes, it's not, it doesn't, I don't know how it translates. ; Therapist: How about your study habits? ; Therapist: You consider yourself effective at studying? ; Patient: I've tried, I've taken workshops on studying. ; Patient: I've, I, I think I'm pretty effective at studying. ; Patient: I've found what doesn't work. ; Patient: So I try to study by reading the chapters, taking outlines, reviewing flashcards, which has, I think the best results, but. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So your study habits are good and your quiz scores are good. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: But you're still having these distressing thoughts and these uncomfortable physical sensations when you take the quizzes. ; Therapist: Is that about right? ; Patient: Yeah, that's absolutely right. ; Therapist: So really, you don't necessarily need your performance to change. ; Therapist: You just, you just need your, your thoughts and feelings and behaviors to change. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So how you, how you're reacting to the quizzes, maybe. ; Patient: Yeah, because I get B's, like I said. ; Patient: So yeah. ; Therapist: And B is good. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So, all right. ; Therapist: So I want to take you back to the moment when you're looking at the first item. ; Therapist: Let's go back to that for a second. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So you're taking a quiz and you're having those thoughts surrounding that first item, which I'm not mistaken, the automatic thought. ; Therapist: We talked about this, right, with the cognitive behavioral therapy. ; Therapist: The automatic thought is that I'm, I'm not going to get this one right or something to that effect. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: What does that mean to you? ; Patient: It means once I don't get that right, I'm not going to get anything else right. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So what that thought means to you is that you're going to miss that item and then you're going to miss all the rest of the items. ; Therapist: So you're, you're going to fail the whole quiz. ; Patient: The whole thing. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So looking at that, let's, let's call that an intermediate belief, right? ; Therapist: It's more of a rule or an expectation, right? ; Therapist: What does that mean to you? ; Patient: It just gets worse if I fail the quiz, then I'm like, Oh my God, I'm going to fail the final. ; Patient: I'm going to fail the course. ; Patient: And that's going to affect my GPA. ; Therapist: So it just keeps stacking, right? ; Therapist: So we have other, other beliefs. ; Therapist: So you're going to fail the course and, or you're going to fail the final rather than you're going to fail the course. ; Therapist: So if you failed the course, what would that mean to you? ; Patient: That I'm not going to graduate. ; Therapist: You're not going to graduate. ; Therapist: So we've moved from failing the quiz. ; Therapist: If we just look at the meaning, right, to fail on the final, to fail on the course, and now to not graduating. ; Therapist: So if you didn't graduate, what would that mean to you? ; Patient: I can't, I can't be a teacher. ; Patient: I can't do what I want to do. ; Therapist: So your chosen vocation to be a teacher would be not possible. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: So we go a step further and say, what would it mean to you if you couldn't be a teacher? ; Patient: I don't know who I'd be at that point. ; Patient: That's what I always saw as my career. ; Patient: So I don't know what my future would look like at that point without that. ; Therapist: So if you were to phrase it and kind of, I think back as we, to the CBT techniques and the kind of conceptualization we've covered, if you were to phrase that as an I am statement, right, what would you, what would you be if you couldn't be a teacher? ; Therapist: What would that make you? ; Patient: I am a person who didn't make it. ; Patient: I'm a person that failed, like we said earlier. ; Therapist: I'm a person that didn't make it. ; Therapist: I'm a person who failed. ; Therapist: So in a way you're saying I'm a failure. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: You know, is that, is that close? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So remember we talked before about core beliefs. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: And how these core beliefs drive these intermediate beliefs, which combine with situations like in your case taking a quiz to form these automatic thoughts. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: So one of your core beliefs may be that you're a failure. ; Therapist: You may believe that. ; Therapist: Does that seem like something that you've said to yourself before or thought before? ; Patient: I didn't think about it like that until we did the step up to it now, but I, I can relate to that. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: Because a lot of times I do feel like, oh, I'm not gonna be able to do this. ; Patient: Because it's me, I won't be able to do it. ; Therapist: Not because it's challenging or difficult, but something to do with you. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: So that's where kind of like the, you're personalizing. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: So you're saying to yourself at a variety of levels, I'm gonna be unsuccessful, I'm gonna fail. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Does that make sense? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And you think that's what's happening? ; Patient: It must be. ; Patient: Because like I said, I study. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: I get good grades. ; Patient: I've been tested years ago. ; Patient: I don't have ADHD, anything intrinsic that would prohibit me. ; Therapist: So you're able to focus and concentrate well? ; Patient: Yes. ; Patient: Yes. ; Patient: I can do all of that, but when it comes to it, I'm like, I can't do it. ; Therapist: So somewhere, somewhere is this core belief. ; Therapist: And it's possible that it has something to do with you believing that you are a failure, unsuccessful. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: How do you think your, say, friends or family would interpret that? ; Therapist: Like if, and I'm not suggesting telling them that, but if they were to somehow know that, that you believed you were a failure, how would they react? ; Patient: I don't think they would see the connection. ; Patient: I don't, I think they would be like, well, you do well in school, I don't understand. ; Therapist: So they wouldn't believe that you're a failure? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: You may believe it. ; Patient: Yeah, I, yeah. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: And similarly, if you had a classmate that was in the same situation, and you know, struggled with these disturbing thoughts and feelings and behaviors during quizzes, how would you evaluate them? ; Patient: I guess I'd say the same thing that my family would say, like, you're, look at the evidence, you're not a failure. ; Therapist: You'd say, look at the evidence. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And you'd, you'd evaluate that they weren't a failure. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: But with yourself, you're being a little more harsh. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Which isn't uncommon. ; Therapist: So there's a few levels at which I think we can go after this, what I'll call a problem. ; Therapist: But really, it's a series of thoughts and beliefs. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: The first is that the comic at the ground level. ; Therapist: And that's when you are taking the quiz, and you have that automatic thought that says, I'm, I'm going to miss this item. ; Patient: I'm not gonna get it right. ; Therapist: Yeah, I'm not gonna get it right. ; Therapist: That's your thought. ; Therapist: I'm not gonna get it right. ; Therapist: In these situations, I like to encourage clients to apply what's called an adaptive response or self talk. ; Therapist: So it's a, now if you're in a quiz in a quiet classroom, it wouldn't literally be self-taught. ; Patient: Right, right. ; Therapist: But it's a thought that you're consciously applying. ; Therapist: So the other thought, that's automatic. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: That just pops in your head, right? ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: This one would be one that you deliberately think. ; Patient: I make myself. ; Therapist: So what could you think to yourself that would be a counter to that automatic thought that you're having, that you're gonna get that item wrong? ; Patient: I guess that in my past quizzes, like, chances are, I have a good chance of getting it right. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So just looking at the probabilities based on your past performance, even though I'm thinking I'm going to get it wrong. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: Chances are, I'm gonna get it right. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: Somehow I still have a B. So. ; Therapist: So you are getting most of them, right? ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: So I have a good chance. ; Therapist: So I like that adaptive response, right? ; Therapist: Do you think that makes sense for you? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: I think you did well there. ; Therapist: So the next time you're taking a quiz, I want you to apply that adaptive response. ; Therapist: Now this takes work, right? ; Therapist: So this automatic thought's gonna come upon you, and before you know it, you're gonna have that feeling. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: The physical symptoms you discussed, the sweaty palms, right? ; Therapist: And the feeling of, I think you mentioned, tense. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So don't let it discourage you. ; Therapist: Those symptoms come on so quickly. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Right? ; Therapist: There is an intervening thought, and you've identified it. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So you will have an opportunity, most likely, to apply that automatic thought at some point. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: But the first few times it might be, might be a little rough. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Doesn't count. ; Therapist: I guess the nice thing about a quiz is, I mean, how many items are on these quizzes? ; Patient: Yeah, like 15. ; Therapist: 15 ; Therapist: So you have a few different chances to apply that ; Therapist: adaptive response. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: It's more than one. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: So, you know, you would like to get, on the first time, where you have the automatic thought, where you identify the automatic thought, but if you don't, it's not a big deal. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Right? ; Therapist: So, you know, later on, maybe it takes item two or three, and then you might remember, hey, I have this. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Oh, wait. ; Patient: I'm supposed to be thinking this. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: And my hope is that as you apply this adaptive response more and more, you can reduce the probability that that automatic thought's going to come in. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So that's one level that I want you to go after it. ; Therapist: Does that make sense? ; Patient: It does. ; Patient: I think I can do that. ; Therapist: That's something you feel like you could do? ; Patient: It is. ; Therapist: At the other level, I guess you'd call this a deeper level, but it's all really, you know, in your brain. ; Therapist: Right? ; Therapist: It's this core belief. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And why I use the word deeper is because we think of core beliefs as more stubborn, like they don't change as easily. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: As automatic thoughts might. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: I'd like you to, and this is really just more reflection, reflect on the evidence or evaluate the evidence that supports and refutes this idea that you are unsuccessful, that you're a failure. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Right? ; Therapist: I think cognitively you kind of understand that you're not. ; Therapist: Right? ; Therapist: But in another sense, you feel like you are. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: Right? ; Therapist: So in a way, cognitively, you're... ; Patient: There's that discrepancy. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: There's a little bit of both. ; Therapist: You know, ; Therapist: you can tell me that your family would say that's not the case, but you still... ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: On paper, technically, I would, I'm not, but I still, I guess, feel that way. ; Therapist: There's a part of you that still feels that way. ; Therapist: There's a part of you that still believes that cognitively. ; Therapist: There's also a part of you that thinks through that and says that's not accurate. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: So I want you to weigh the validity of that core belief. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Right? ; Therapist: And actually, I think what this is helpful to write down evidence that would support it. ; Therapist: Right? ; Therapist: And that's certainly something to note, but also, and this is really more important, evidence that refutes it. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Right? ; Therapist: Evidence that runs counter. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: But record both, and we'll meet next time, and we'll look at the evidence. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And we'll evaluate it. ; Patient: Yeah, we can do that. ; Therapist: So there's two steps you feel like you're comfortable with, and they make sense to you. ; Therapist: They make sense to you? ; Patient: Yeah, they do. ; Patient: They do. ; Patient: I definitely think I can do those. ; Therapist: When's the next time you'll be taking a quiz? ; Patient: I think next week. ; Therapist: Next week. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: You have these quizzes often. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So we'll set up a session for next week. ; Therapist: Let's try to get to where it's after your next quiz. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So we'll have that to talk about, because I think that's the next area to make, it sounds like the next area would be good to try to make progress on. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: I mean, it seems like that's what you want to work on. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So we'll go from there. ; Therapist: So I'll set you up an appointment for just after that quiz, try the adaptive response. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And try ; Therapist: evaluating evidence with the core belief. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Does that sound good? ; Patient: I can do that. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: I also have the appointment up, and I appreciate you coming in and working through this. ; Patient: Yeah, thank you so much.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name lewis; sex male ; Clinical Identifiers: Setting outpatient ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Follow up session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Autonomic overactivity sweating, tachycardia 2. Motor tension inability to relax ; History: Present history patient has been an average student in studies. He wishes to perform better and has been consistently facing issues whenever he sits to solve the quiz test on his own. This consists of mcqs. It makes his hands sweaty, heart pounding and an inability to relax. This only happens when he has to solve the quiz. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: General behavior rapport was established and patient was cooperative; mood anxious; affect restricted; thought content- reflected worry about performing well in tests. ; Psychotherapy Type: Type cognitive behavioral therapy; mode individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Reflective listening, validity testing ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: It was discussed that how patients core beliefs for ex, im a failure lead to the intermediate beliefs which combine with situational factors lead to automatic thoughts. ; Reflections by the therapist: Patients negative automatic thought were focused upon. He had been facing cognitive distortion of overgeneralisation and personalisation. Some ways of handling it with respect to adaptive response were focussed upon. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Specific phobia ; Action Plan : Practice positive self talk, maintain a diary showing evidence for the beliefs ; Next session details: After 1 week

dialogue: Therapist: Hi, Sasha ; Therapist: How you doing today? ; Patient: I'm all right. ; Patient: Thanks. ; Patient: How are you? ; Therapist: I'm doing okay. ; Therapist: Thanks for asking. ; Therapist: I understand you've been having some symptoms that have been bothersome to you. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Can you tell me about those? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: For about the last six months or so, I have this position at work where I have to make a weekly presentation to other managers, about ten people. ; Patient: And every time I have to do this, I lose it. ; Therapist: You lose it every time you have to make a presentation? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Tell me what is involved with losing it. ; Patient: I'm usually one of the last people to go. ; Patient: And I just keep feeling more and more and more and more nervous. ; Patient: It starts where I feel like butterflies in my stomach. ; Patient: And that just becomes more intense. ; Patient: I start to just sweat all over. ; Patient: I feel like my face is turning red. ; Patient: My palms get really, really sweaty and I constantly wipe them on my pants. ; Patient: And my heart, it just feels like it's going to just beep right out of my chest. ; Patient: And I just can't. ; Patient: I can't. ; Therapist: It's very distressing. ; Therapist: So tell me about the nature of this meeting that's leading to this anxiety. ; Therapist: So you said it was a, you had to make a presentation. ; Therapist: Tell me about the structure of it. ; Patient: So there's about ten people, the executive director and then the managers of different programs. ; Patient: And we all have to do just kind of like a weekly update report. ; Patient: So none of it's very detailed. ; Patient: So maybe a few minutes each person to go around and just update everybody else on what's going on in all the different programs. ; Patient: And we all take turns. ; Therapist: How long do you have to speak? ; Patient: Usually just a few minutes, maybe five, at most ten, unless there's something major going on in my program. ; Therapist: And when, in the course of like with this meeting occurring, when do you start to feel nervous? ; Patient: Oh, the day before. ; Therapist: The day before? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So ; Therapist: the day before the meeting you start to have similar symptoms, different symptoms? ; Therapist: What do you feel? ; Patient: Yeah, I start to feel nervous. ; Patient: Usually the day before is when I'm pulling together my notes. ; Patient: I make like a few bullet points on stuff that I want to present that I think is relevant. ; Patient: And so the day before when I'm preparing that I start to feel nervous. ; Patient: And then it usually lasts through the rest of the day into the evening. ; Patient: I usually don't sleep well that night. ; Patient: And then by the time I get into work, I'm, you know, that's usually when I'm, you know, feeling, you know, really nervous. ; Patient: But by the time I get into the meeting I'm pretty much panicking. ; Therapist: All right, panicking ; Therapist: As the meeting's starting? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So at the meeting everybody takes a turn and does this brief presentation. ; Therapist: And tell me what's happening as with your feelings as they're moving around, is it a table or? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: As they're moving around the table and coming closer to you. ; Patient: I'm just becoming more and more terrified. ; Patient: I feel like I'm being just drenched in sweat. ; Patient: I'm breathing faster and I feel like everybody notices. ; Patient: I feel like everybody can hear me breathe. ; Patient: I feel like everybody can hear my heart beating. ; Patient: That it's just so loud that it's like any minute everybody's gonna look at me and say, what is wrong with you? ; Therapist: They're gonna notice you. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: And there have been times, especially recently really, you know, it's like I said, I mean this has been going on for at least six months, but especially recently I feel like I've had to like run out of the room. ; Patient: I couldn't take it. ; Therapist: Have you run out of the room? ; Patient: Yes, I have. ; Patient: I ran out and couldn't go back in. ; Patient: I tried and my hands hit the doorknob to go back in the room and I walked out. ; Patient: I couldn't do it. ; Therapist: There's too much anxiety. ; Patient: Yeah, I felt okay, you know, in the hallway and then when I tried to go back in the room, it's everything just right back up again. ; Therapist: Yeah, so you would push that door open. ; Therapist: They would all be looking at you. ; Therapist: They would wonder why you left. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So you just wrote out the meeting somewhere else and did anybody notice after? ; Patient: You know, after a few weeks in a row of running out, yeah, you know, my boss was like, you know, I realized you didn't make your presentation and, you know, I just I made up an excuse. ; Patient: Like I got a phone call or I didn't feel good or, you know, I stumbled through some excuse, but I feel bad because I mean this is my job and I want to do my job and I mean how I've lived with this, I feel like forever, you know, because I had a terrible time making presentations in high school. ; Patient: I had a terrible time making presentations in college and here we are again and I'm trying to be a professional and have a career and make a life and I can't because I can't perform my job. ; Patient: I want to do my job. ; Patient: I like my job. ; Therapist: This is frustrating for you. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Have there been times where you've fled the room and then since then you haven't? ; Patient: There was one time, actually, the very first time I ran out and I didn't go back and nobody noticed and then the second time, that following week, I started to feel that way again and then two of my co-workers, two of the other managers, actually started to get into a fight. ; Patient: One of them wanted more money their program for something or other and the controller was like, no, we have no money, you can't have it, it's a non-profit, so there's no money and it was like getting really intense and I don't know what it was. ; Patient: I just, I was fine. ; Therapist: Something about that intense interaction changed how you're feeling, distracted you, something like that? ; Patient: Yeah, I guess. ; Patient: It just, I don't know, it just didn't, I felt fine, I felt normal. ; Therapist: All right, so from that meeting on, like till now, have you been able to stay in for any other meetings? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Okay, so you've had to leave because of the intensity of the symptoms. ; Patient: Yeah, there have been a couple times where actually I've purposely gone in late and I've said I've had car trouble and I haven't, I've just gone in late or I've actually just called in sick for the day. ; Patient: There was twice I sent somebody else in my place saying that, you know, I was sick but I mean it gets noticed. ; Therapist: Yeah, and you're, you're experiencing symptoms when you avoid that interaction in the room too, right, because you don't feel good about letting them down or? ; Patient: No, no, I want to do my job. ; Patient: I really like my job. ; Patient: I really do and I like where I work and I like the people but the thought of making these presentations every week just terrifies me and I don't want my boss to regret putting me in this position. ; Patient: I don't want to disappoint him. ; Patient: I mean I know he took a big chance, you know, putting me in this position, you know, I don't have a lot of experience doing this and there were, you know, potentially there could have been other people that were better qualified but, you know, he chose me. ; Patient: I don't want to let him down and I feel like I am every week with this meeting. ; Therapist: Right, so with this meeting really you're in a situation where if you go and attend the meeting you're gonna end up leaving it because of the anxiety. ; Therapist: If you don't attend it, you have these concerns about the performance in your jobs, you're kind of, you're kind of stuck, right? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Any other symptoms that you think may or may not be related to this intense anxiety? ; Patient: Um, I guess I mean I'm not sleeping the night before the meetings. ; Patient: I have started to drink a little bit to try and take the edge off. ; Patient: A friend of mine had said before that it's something that she's done to help when she's nervous and so I've tried a shot or two before going into my meeting. ; Therapist: Does that have any effect on you? ; Patient: Probably not a good effect. ; Patient: I mean I was able to sit through the meeting but everybody kept asking if I was okay. ; Therapist: So they're picking up on ; Therapist: the alcohol. ; Patient: Yeah, I really feel like they were and of course I was very, I didn't want anybody to get close to me because I think it's going, yeah, I just, I was too scared to do that again. ; Therapist: Any sadness or anything like that? ; Patient: I'm miserable. ; Patient: Every time I think about, you know, how much I must be disappointing my boss, I just, I feel so, I just feel terrible. ; Therapist: You feel really down? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Sasha, I know it's been tough going through all this and these symptoms have been tough for you. ; Therapist: We'll get you scheduled in here to get treated in a couple days. ; Therapist: We'll get you in a couple days and you can start working with a counselor to address these symptoms. ; Therapist: I appreciate you spending this time with me. ; Therapist: It was helpful to get a better understanding of what you're going through. ; Patient: Thank you. ; Therapist: Thanks.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name sasha ; Past Session Information: Follow up, continuation of file no. 4 ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Continuation of file no. 4 ; History: Continuation of file no. 4 ; Crisis Markers: Continuation of file no. 4 ; Current Mental Status Examination: Continuation of file no. 4 ; Psychotherapy Type: Continuation of file no. 4 ; Psychotherapy Technique : Continuation of file no. 4 ; Assessments: Continuation of file no. 4 ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Continuation of file no. 4 ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Continuation of file no. 4 ; Action Plan : Assigned counselor ; Next session details: Meeting with a counselor in few days.

dialogue: Therapist: How are you doing today? ; Patient: I guess I'm doing pretty good. ; Therapist: Doing pretty good? ; Patient: Well, so I was looking up online during break between my classes. ; Patient: I go to online school. ; Therapist: Like college? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: And they have this, I was looking up my symptoms, I guess. ; Patient: Difficulty paying attention, difficulty staying still, just stuff like that. ; Patient: And I think I might have that one disorder. ; Therapist: ADHD? ; Patient: Yeah, that one. ; Therapist: You think you may have ADHD? ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Are these symptoms bothering you? ; Therapist: You said you go to college online? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Is it bothering you there? ; Patient: Yeah, it does. ; Therapist: It does? ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: I'm going to ask you a few questions and try to get a better understanding of what's going on. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: These symptoms you've been having, at what age did they start? ; Patient: About eight years old. ; Therapist: Eight years old? ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: And you feel like they're bothering you with your classes that you take online? ; Patient: Yes, but I still get good grades. ; Therapist: You still get good grades? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So let me ask you some questions about that. ; Therapist: So I'll specifically be asking about how it affects you in class, but if it affects you in any other area, tell me about that too. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Do you have trouble establishing attention? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: When you have established attention, do you have difficulty holding attention? ; Therapist: Yes. ; Therapist: You do? ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Do you, for example, with the professor, do you listen to the professor in your online classes? ; Patient: Well, I have difficulty listening to them. ; Therapist: That's a problem for you. ; Therapist: How about following through on any instructions that the professor gives you? ; Patient: Oh, it's a real big problem. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Are you organized? ; Patient: I am actually organized. ; Therapist: You are organized? ; Therapist: Do you find yourself avoiding activities that require a lot of mental effort? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: What type of activities do you avoid? ; Patient: Anything that just like riddles. ; Patient: I can't stand them. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: Chess, can't stand it. ; Patient: People try to explain me the rules. ; Patient: I still don't get it. ; Patient: I get a headache and I quit. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Do you ever find yourself losing things that you need for class or any other place? ; Patient: All the time. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Are you easily distracted? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: Big time. ; Therapist: Are you forgetful? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So, I'm going to move to another series of questions. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Do you fidget? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: You do? ; Patient: I do. ; Therapist: Do you find it difficult to stay in your seat? ; Patient: Yes. ; Patient: We have these videos and sometimes I just got to pause them and I just got to walk around my room for a while. ; Patient: You know, I go back, sit down, get it out of my system, click, and we're good. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So, you feel kind of compelled to stand up and walk around? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: And then you can sit down and resume? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: How do you do with quiet activities like reading? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: No, I don't like doing them because I just can't deal with the quiet. ; Therapist: No? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Do you ever feel like you have an internal motor that's always running? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: How about talking? ; Therapist: You find that you talk excessively? ; Patient: Yes, I do. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: How about blurting things out? ; Patient: Yes, but people don't really notice it because, especially at class, I'll like yell out the answer, but you have to hit a button. ; Therapist: Oh, you have to hit a button so that the camera turns on and the audio turns on. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So, you'll blur something out, but they won't hear it. ; Patient: Yeah, they won't. ; Therapist: Because you haven't pressed that key. ; Patient: So, I guess that's good. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: How about interrupting people? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Do you have trouble waiting your turn? ; Patient: Back to the blurting out, I forget to hit the button. ; Patient: I then hit the button to answer and it goes into like this line. ; Patient: I hate waiting for my turn. ; Patient: I can't deal with it. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: That's not a strong suit for you? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No. ; Therapist: All right. ; Patient: Go answer. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So, you mentioned that this is causing some difficulty in school, but you also said that you're doing okay in school. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Is there any other area of your life where this is causing you problems? ; Patient: Not that I can think of, no. ; Therapist: No? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: What else do you do? ; Therapist: So, you go to college. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: What other activities do you engage in? ; Patient: Really nothing. ; Patient: I got a full course load, trying to get it done. ; Patient: Really don't do anything else. ; Patient: I mean, yeah. ; Therapist: How about like relatives? ; Patient: I don't see my relatives a lot. ; Patient: Like my parents retired, they moved, so I don't see them. ; Therapist: Have a friend's. ; Patient: It's kind of embarrassing, but I really don't have any friends. ; Patient: Just kind of live, eat, and breathe school. ; Therapist: Do you ever socialize with any of your classmates from college? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Do you feel that's because of these symptoms or that you wouldn't anyway? ; Patient: Well, I feel bad about it. ; Patient: So, I mean, it's hard for me to get over it because I notice it, but it's hard for me to get out there. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Do you think it's hard for you to engage with your classmates socially because of any concentration or hyperactivity type symptoms? ; Patient: That's what I believe, yeah. ; Therapist: You believe it is because of those symptoms? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: And any other areas like shopping or cleaning the house? ; Patient: No, I'm pretty okay with that. ; Therapist: That works out okay? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Lisa, I'm going to get you in to see a counselor. ; Therapist: It'll just take a couple days to get you in, right? ; Therapist: So, I just had an appointment for a couple days out. ; Therapist: I appreciate you spending this time with me and let me ask these questions. ; Therapist: This was helpful. ; Therapist: All right. ; Patient: Thank you. ; Therapist: Thanks.
summary: Patient Particulars : Nil ; Clinical Identifiers: Setting opd ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Intake session the doctor is going to refer the patient to a counselor ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Inattention and fidgetiness since 8 yrs of age 2. Blurting out answers since 8 years of age ; History: Patient reports that they have difficulty paying attention in online classes. He finds it difficult to sit for long hours and has to get up in the middle of class. He also reports that he talks excessively and has the habit of blurting out answers and interrupting the teacher every now and then. This is why he thinks he has adhd and consulted the doctor. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Nil ; Psychotherapy Type: Nil ; Psychotherapy Technique : Nil ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: The doctor tried to diagnose the condition based on the symptoms reported and matching those with the criteria ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Nil ; Action Plan : To see a counselor after a couple of days ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Sherry. how you're doing today? ; Patient: I'm doing okay. ; Therapist: You're doing okay? ; Therapist: I understand you have been feeling too great lately. ; Patient: I mean, yeah. ; Patient: I'm never like feeling awesome really. ; Patient: But lately it's come to my awareness. ; Patient: But something might be wrong. ; Therapist: Something might be wrong? ; Therapist: In what way? ; Patient: Maybe. ; Patient: Well, it's not anything new. ; Patient: But I have a lot of trouble sleeping. ; Patient: You know, I usually, I don't go to bed early. ; Patient: You know, I might go to bed a little bit late. ; Patient: But then I wake up always really early. ; Patient: Like I'll set my alarm for like eight, but I always wake up at like five or something. ; Patient: And then I can't get back to sleep. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So you're waking up earlier than you want to? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I can't get back to sleep no matter how hard I try. ; Patient: And I'm tired still during the day. ; Patient: You know, I don't have a lot of energy. ; Patient: But it doesn't matter. ; Patient: It's just it's hard for me to go to sleep. ; Patient: And it's been like that for a really long time. ; Patient: Probably since high school. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: But, you know, lately I just, I realize, you know, some days are better than others. ; Patient: But it's been a couple weeks ago that really like made me feel like I should have talked to someone. ; Therapist: What happened? ; Patient: Well, my brother got married. ; Patient: And I'm very close to him. ; Patient: And I was really looking forward to the wedding. ; Patient: And then when I went, I just, I mean, I didn't not enjoy it, but I just didn't have as much fun as I thought I would. ; Patient: And I know it's just because of, you know, my mood, like that I'm always a little gloomy. ; Patient: You know, like, so my brother says I'm like, you're, you know, so like, but I was really looking, like I, you know, I step out of my comfort zone. ; Patient: I like to try new things. ; Patient: And I was really looking forward to this one. ; Patient: I used to love, I love weddings, you know, and it's not that I don't love them now, but I thought I would enjoy it more than I did. ; Patient: And that kind of like freaked me out. ; Therapist: So your mood, your mood didn't elevate like maybe you hoped it would. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I mean, I would have thought that, I mean, I've been looking forward to this wedding for a year and a half, but you know, I've helped, you know, my now sister plan it. ; Patient: And it just wasn't as fun as I wanted it to be, or as I thought it would be, you know. ; Therapist: And realizing this is what brought you in today. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: And like right afterwards, like last week, you know, it was, I had more worse days than better days. ; Patient: And I would go up early the next morning, even though I had been up late at the wedding, and just sat there and thought about it and was really just upset by the whole thing, upset that I couldn't be more happy for, you know, my brother. ; Patient: For me, really, not even for my brother. ; Patient: Because I was happy for him. ; Patient: It just didn't, I didn't feel excited like everyone else. ; Patient: Everyone else around me was having such a good time, and I was just... ; Therapist: More down. ; Patient: Yeah, like I was happier than I would be if I was staying at home by myself, but I wasn't, I wasn't like everyone else. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So you mentioned that this is going on from high school? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So how long would that be? ; Patient: So I mean, I graduated in 2010, so eight years. ; Therapist: So about eight years. ; Therapist: And you've been, you've been feeling down. ; Therapist: Has the, the sleep been a problem for that long? ; Patient: Yeah, I mean, I, a little bit when I was in high school, I thought it was, you know, I thought it was just a quirk or something about staying up late and like hours in high school, but it never like got better. ; Patient: Even when I, you know, started working out of school and stuff, I, my sleep schedule never came to that normal eight hours a night like you're supposed to. ; Patient: I know no one's ever is, but it just never, yeah. ; Patient: So sleep's always been an issue, and I just, like I said, my brother's called me Eeyore for years just because I... ; Therapist: Yeah, you mentioned the word gloomy. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: So low energy's been a problem for that long as well. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: And you've been waking up earlier than you want, want to. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: How about, you, you, you mentioned the depressed mood. ; Therapist: You feel down. ; Therapist: Is that worse than any particular time of the day? ; Patient: Yeah, I mean, it's worse than that in the morning. ; Therapist: In the morning? ; Patient: Especially when I'm just like sitting there with my thoughts, when I can't get back to sleep, it will be bad. ; Patient: And then, you know, it'll be time to get ready for the day, and I'll be angry and mad that it's, you know, that I, I can't sleep, and then depressed about, you know, that I'm like this, that I'm weird. ; Patient: And then, I mean, as the day goes on, I forget about it a little bit, and it gets a little bit better in the afternoons. ; Patient: And nighttime, I'm really like, you know, I enjoy spending time with my family for dinner and stuff like that. ; Patient: So, it gets better as the day goes on, but, you know, in the morning, it's, it's bad because I just spent hours lying there thinking about it. ; Therapist: So, morning, morning's the worst. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So, I'm going to ask you some other questions related to this. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: You mentioned depressed mood, and you mentioned how you reacted to the wedding, how it was and what you hoped. ; Therapist: Have you lost interest in other things that might be fun or pleasurable? ; Patient: I haven't really lost an interest in anything. ; Patient: Like, I still, you know, I still seek out fun activities, and I still participate in them. ; Patient: And, I mean, they'll make me feel better than not doing them. ; Patient: But it's just, I don't know, it's just, I don't, I guess, my response to them isn't as high as I see other people enjoying activities. ; Patient: And I don't, but I do enjoy them. ; Therapist: But it's just not as much. ; Therapist: Not as much. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Any changes to your appetite or weight? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: It stays the same. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Any feelings of restlessness or the opposite, kind of being slowed down? ; Therapist: Anything like that? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No? ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: You ever feel a sense of worthlessness? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Something like that? ; Therapist: How about concentration? ; Therapist: How's that been? ; Patient: Well, it's fine. ; Patient: I can focus on what I need to focus on. ; Therapist: You do okay with that? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Do you ever have thoughts of death or dying? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Any drug or alcohol use? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: How about medical conditions? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Have you ever seen or heard things other people cannot see or hear? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Have you ever had a time, you mentioned your mood is gloomy. ; Therapist: Have you ever had a time when your mood was too happy, like when you're excessively happy, a lot of energy? ; Patient: Not really. ; Patient: I mean, you know, like there's been times where I've like gone on vacation for like a week and I've noticed that I was happier than I had been, but nothing ever more than a couple of days or a week or so. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: You ever been hospitalized before? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Do you have feelings of hopelessness? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: And how's your self-esteem? ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: It's okay? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Pretty good? ; Therapist: All right, Sherry. ; Therapist: I'd like to get you in to see a counselor here at the agency. ; Therapist: It'll probably just take a couple days to get you in with somebody. ; Therapist: Is that okay? ; Patient: Yeah, it's okay. ; Therapist: I appreciate you answering these questions for me. ; Therapist: This has been helpful.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name sherry, sex female ; Past Session Information: Follow up session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms depressed chief complaints 1 low mood 2 sleeplessness 3 lack interest ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior dull; speech slow, mood  affect low, thought negative, cognitive functions; impaired, judgement poor and insight intact ; Issues discussed in Current Session: 1 problem patient struggles with sleep disturbances, low energy and mood, distressing thoughts, and noticeable reduction in the level of enjoyment. She also feels self-doubt at times, though not to the extent of feeling worthless or hopeless. 2 acceptance patient is willing to seek help and agrees for counseling, in managing her symptoms and improving their overall well-being. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Depression ; Action Plan : Assigned a counselor for patient. ; Next session details: Meeting with counselor within a few days

dialogue: Therapist: Hi, this is Dr. Grande. ; Therapist: I hope you find this video useful. ; Therapist: If that's the case, please like it and subscribe to my channel. ; Therapist: As always, thanks for watching. ; Therapist: Would you be okay now, kind of taking a look at some of your thinking, and let's look at the situation from that point of view? ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Some things kind of stand out for me in hearing you talk about what's been happening and your feelings. ; Therapist: I can appreciate it's really painful, and I would say, to the degree that you can step back and try to look at the thoughts, I think that you'll see it's helpful. ; Therapist: Although I know it's a little difficult or unusual to separate feelings from thoughts sometimes. ; Therapist: But I'd like to try to kind of distinguish between the two. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: You said that you've been at your job for about five years. ; Therapist: You really like your job? ; Patient: I used to, yeah. ; Therapist: Tell me about your job, kind of how you felt about it, but frame it in a time before this ever happened. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: I like my job because I felt like I was helping people, so it was meaningful. ; Patient: And when I went there, the time went by fast, so it was kind of like I was enjoying myself. ; Patient: Not super fast, I wasn't having the best time of my life, but it was something where I would go, and I felt like I was doing something important, and the day didn't drag on, and I got along with my co-workers and that kind of thing. ; Patient: So, it felt meaningful to me. ; Therapist: Meaningful. ; Therapist: So, do you remember accomplishing things at that job that you felt benefited society, the people you helped? ; Patient: Yeah, I feel like, you know, doing my job, I got to know people, you know, help people out with things that they needed. ; Patient: You know, when things were bad, I could, you know, get kids out of situations that were really dangerous for them, and, you know, no one else was going to do that for them. ; Patient: I felt like I was the kind of person that was keeping people safe, I guess. ; Therapist: You kept people safe. ; Therapist: And you had a lot of satisfaction from the work you did. ; Therapist: And now, it doesn't feel that way? ; Patient: No, not at all. ; Therapist: The way you described it, it almost sounds like you, well, you talked about how you're afraid of making another mistake. ; Therapist: You're thinking about yourself in a way where you're almost at risk to have... ; Patient: Yeah, I was just about to say, it feels dangerous to be there, like to do my job, it feels dangerous. ; Therapist: Your work right now, even though you have this one situation that's extremely stressful and hard on you, you have other families that you interact with now too, right? ; Therapist: Can you tell me about those interactions? ; Patient: I mean, I guess it's like quantitatively the same as before, I do the same things with families, but now I kind of feel like I can't trust my own judgement. ; Patient: Before, everything just kind of felt a little more black and white, and now it just feels like everything is so much a shade of grey that I just can't tell what's right and what's wrong anymore. ; Patient: And every time I feel like I have a good instinct, I doubt it, I question it, I think I have ideas of, well, if I remove the kids from this family, what if they're not really doing the things I think they're doing? ; Patient: Like, what if the parents are actually good parents? ; Patient: What if the kids get put into a home that's bad for them? ; Therapist: So before, this is maybe what's different, based on what you're saying, from before till now, is decisions seemed clear-cut. ; Patient: Yeah, sometimes it was tougher than others, but it just seemed more like I could make a decision and kind of wipe my hands of it and move on to the next thing, and now I just feel like there's all these doubts in my head and all these questions about if I'm doing the right thing. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: So you're looking inward, you're looking at yourself, a lot of self-doubt, you're looking at decisions as much more difficult, it's much more difficult to come to the right decision, and second-guessing, it sounds like maybe you're second-guessing a bit, when you do make a decision, like playing over it in your mind, what could go wrong here? ; Therapist: Is that the thought you're having? ; Patient: Yeah, yeah, definitely. ; Patient: I feel like I'm second-guessing everything.
summary: Therapist Information : Name dr. Grande ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms fear and anxiety chief complaints 1 self doubt 2 dissatisfaction in job 3 ambiguity ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior tired speech confused mood  affect low and sad thought, perception ambiguous cognitive functions little bit disturbed judgement slightly poor ; Psychotherapy Type: Dynamic analytical ; Psychotherapy Technique : Reflective listening thought challenging ; Issues discussed in Current Session: 1 dissatisfaction patient feels dissatisfied with his job which he used to feel meaningful and satisfying earlier. 2 fear and anxiety patient is afraid and anxious about making mistakes in the job which has created a sense of danger and uncertainty in the work environment, its difficult for him to trust his own judgment. 3 ambiguity and confusion patient feels ambiguous in each situation which leads to more self-doubts and second-guess himself which overwhelms him. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Anxiety

dialogue: Therapist: So Jess, how did the police interview go? ; Therapist: How did that play out? ; Patient: Well they came to my house on Tuesday and I had my mum with me and I had to tell them everything. ; Therapist: Yeah it's hard. ; Patient: Like I had to go into so much detail. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Hey Jess, just come back to me, just come back to the room a little bit. ; Therapist: Can you just look up at me? ; Therapist: What colour eyes do I have? ; Therapist: Can you check that out? ; Patient: I'm brown. ; Therapist: Brown, okay good. ; Therapist: I'm just trying to get you back into the room with me okay. ; Therapist: So just look around the room, can you see maybe this painting that's up here? ; Therapist: What do you see? ; Therapist: Can you tell me what the paintings are? ; Patient: Beach. ; Therapist: Yeah a beach. ; Patient: Sun. ; Therapist: Yeah cool, okay. ; Therapist: Okay, okay. ; Therapist: I want you to do something, I just want you to catch this for me. ; Therapist: See if you can catch it, throw it back to me. ; Therapist: Okay just throw it back to me, that's it, that's it, good, good, good. ; Therapist: Just throw it back to me. ; Therapist: Good, okay. ; Therapist: Just see if you can stay here, stay here in the room with me, yeah? ; Therapist: Yeah? ; Therapist: Hey and also listen, catch that one, that's it. ; Therapist: Okay so just want you to keep in the room with me a bit, I know sometimes it's a bit stressful and a bit overwhelming okay but we're still connected okay? ; Therapist: You're not back there okay? ; Therapist: How are you feeling? ; Patient: Oh. ; Therapist: Just stay with me. ; Therapist: Yeah okay. ; Patient: Yeah really it was, I did, really hard to talk about. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: That stuff. ; Therapist: Yeah it's completely understandable, these are really, really tough moments you know and those sort of conversations with the police sometimes can be very stressful for you yeah? ; Therapist: I get it yeah. ; Therapist: So maybe, how are you feeling now? ; Therapist: Where are you at? ; Patient: Yeah a bit better. ; Therapist: Yeah okay so maybe just, why don't we keep talking and just remember that we're connected okay and you're here with me. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: So tell me a little bit more, so your mum came with you to do the statement? ; Patient: Yeah so mum was with me, they came over and there were two detectives and they just wanted to know everything and it took like hours. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: And how are you feeling now after you've done it? ; Therapist: What's that? ; Patient: Like I'm glad it's over and done with, I didn't realise how hard it would be to talk about it here. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: For some reason I was thinking it was all over and done with. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: But I'm okay now. ; Therapist: Well it's really understandable, it's completely understandable that sometimes it's difficult to talk and sometimes you can avoid back to tough times yeah so why don't we just keep talking, we'll keep talking like this okay? ; Patient: Yeah.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name jess, sex male, mother accompanied him. ; Past Session Information: Follow up session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms ptsd ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior disoriented; speech unclear, mood  affect disturbed, thought, cognitive functions distorted. ; Psychotherapy Type: Cbt; mode individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Supportive ; Issues discussed in Current Session: 1 problem patient has a difficulty to talk about the traumatic event, indicating the stress and emotional toll it took on her. 2 techniques therapist used techniques like asking her to focus on specific details in the room and engaging in a simple activity like catching and throwing an object to help her stay present and grounded. 3 readiness patient feels better after the interview and expresses her readiness to continue talking. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Ptsd

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Chris. ; Patient: Hi. ; Therapist: Thanks for coming in today and filling out our survey. ; Therapist: I wonder if it's okay if I go over a couple of the things that you answered in the survey? ; Patient: Yeah, it's fine. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: One of the things that I noticed is that you are not using any kind of birth control right now. ; Patient: Yeah, I'm not. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And I just wondered if we could talk for a few minutes about some ideas. ; Therapist: And I wonder what your thoughts are about using condoms. ; Patient: Well, I've heard stuff about them that I don't really need them and they're not going to do much for me and it's just kind of a hassle to go out and get them. ; Therapist: So I don't really use them for that reason. ; Therapist: You've heard a lot of negative things about condom usage. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: I'm just going to share with you some of the things that I've learned about condom usage and some of the things that my clients that are around your age have shared with me about condom usage. ; Patient: Yeah, that's fine. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: What some people don't realize and don't know about condoms is that they not only prevent teen pregnancy, but they can also prevent sexually transmitted infections like chlamydia along with HIV. ; Therapist: They're really effective in preventing these things. ; Therapist: There's also a lot of easy ways to get condoms these days that some people don't know. ; Therapist: The local health departments have condoms and many times they're free. ; Therapist: And local pharmacies, drugstores have condoms and there are a lot of clinics that have them as well either for a small fee or sometimes they're actually free. ; Therapist: And there's some ways too that people have found of carrying them around pretty conveniently in their car or in their pockets because they're pretty small. ; Therapist: What does it sound like as I'm talking? ; Therapist: What are some thoughts that are going through your mind? ; Patient: Definitely changing my mind about condoms a little bit. ; Patient: I think there's no hurt in just carrying them with me. ; Patient: And if they do protect against all that stuff that you said, I mean, that sounds a lot better than what I have heard. ; Patient: I definitely want to avoid all those consequences. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: You're not interested in becoming a father right now, I'm guessing. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Great. ; Therapist: Well, can I ask you, so after this conversation today on a scale of zero to 10 with zero being that it's not at all important to you and 10 being that it's extremely important, where do you think you fall with how important taking a chance and using condoms would be to you now? ; Therapist: After everything that you've told me, it sounds pretty important to me, probably like an eight or a nine. ; Patient: Eight or nine. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Well, that's great. ; Therapist: It sounds like you really have a plan in mind. ; Therapist: What do you think you'll do next? ; Therapist: What do you think would be a next step with you as far as contraception and or condoms? ; Patient: Probably go out and look for some condoms. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Have an open mind to them. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Well, we've got some here at the clinic. ; Therapist: Would you like me to give you some on your way out? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: I'll take them with you. ; Therapist: Great. ; Therapist: Well, thank you so much for talking with me today, Chris. ; Therapist: It was nice to meet you. ; Therapist: Thank you.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name chris; sex male ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Nil ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Nil ; History: Nil ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behaviour patient was cooperative and rapport could be established; speech productivity- adequate; mood calm; affect broad ; Psychotherapy Type: Type cbt; mode individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Nil ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Psychoeducation about birth control ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Nil ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Sherry, how are you doing today? ; Patient: Doing okay. ; Therapist: You're doing okay? ; Therapist: I understand you haven't been feeling too well lately. ; Therapist: You've had some symptoms. ; Therapist: Tell me what's going on. ; Patient: So for almost a week now, I've been, you know, every little thing irritates me. ; Patient: It's been, it's distracting how much, you know, little things are bothering me. ; Therapist: Little things are really irritating you? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: For the last week? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: This is the first time this has happened? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: So tell me about the irritation. ; Therapist: What kind of things have been? ; Patient: I mean, so like at work, the guy in the cubicle next to me, like it feels like he either clears his throat or blows his nose every 15 minutes. ; Patient: It drives me crazy. ; Patient: And like then I can't focus on my work because I just hear it so I try to put on music and then my boss will get upset because I have ear buds in but I can't play music out loud because I'm trying to be considerate of other people, unlike my cubicle mate. ; Patient: They've had me at the cubicle. ; Patient: And then, you know, that's just like one example. ; Patient: And then like when I'm driving home, there was this guy walking his dog on the side of the road and like there's no shoulder so it's not a safe place. ; Patient: So like I just feel like he's risking his life and his dog's life and my life. ; Patient: And then I get home and I kept thinking about it and just like everything, everything that people do is just driving me up the wall. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So you really irritated and you feel like these irritating events are distracting you? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Do you feel like your thoughts are racing? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Because like I'll be thinking about, you know, trying to focus on work or whatever I'm doing and all these things that people, other people are doing are irritating. ; Patient: It's not even other people, just like things in general are irritating me and like so my thoughts will race through different things. ; Patient: And it just makes me more frustrated and anxious. ; Therapist: And anxious. ; Therapist: Have you found, you mentioned work, have you found that you're more oriented toward getting goals completed? ; Patient: I mean, no, not anymore so than usual. ; Therapist: No. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Do you find yourself talking more or feeling like you should talk more? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Nothing like that? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: In fact, I don't want to talk to people because I feel like something they're going to say is going to annoy me. ; Therapist: How's your sleep been? ; Patient: Um, fine. ; Patient: Haven't had any disturbances in it. ; Therapist: No? ; Patient: Sometimes like when I'm first going to bed, like my thoughts will take me a while to like get to sleep and like have my thoughts like shut down. ; Patient: But it doesn't take too long. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So your sleep's been okay? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Have you noticed that you're all down or like have depressed mood or anything like that? ; Patient: No, not really. ; Therapist: No? ; Therapist: Are you still finding activities that were pleasurable to be pleasurable now? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Well, I mean, sometimes an activity that I like, something will come along and like I'll get distracted during it by something that like irritates me. ; Patient: But for the most part I can get over it and like enjoy the activity if it's something I genuinely enjoy. ; Therapist: Any change of appetite? ; Patient: Um, no. ; Therapist: How about any feelings of worthlessness? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Nothing like that. ; Therapist: You mentioned that you're being distracted easily. ; Therapist: Is this affecting your concentration? ; Patient: A little bit. ; Therapist: A little bit? ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Do you have any thoughts regarding death or dying? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Like that. ; Therapist: And this irritable mood has been bothering you at work and you mentioned driving home. ; Therapist: Any other places? ; Patient: I mean, yeah, just because it's not just at work and driving home. ; Patient: Like, you know, some of my mom sat on the phone the other day, irritated me and then I cut the phone call short and I get to talk to my dad because I was mad. ; Patient: And so that like affected that. ; Patient: So a little bit of like my personal life too. ; Therapist: Any drug or alcohol usage recently? ; Therapist: Nothing. ; Therapist: Have you ever seen or heard things other people can't see or hear? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: That's never happened? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: I'd like to get you in to see somebody today, if that's okay. ; Therapist: We have a counselor that's available that can talk to you some more about this. ; Therapist: That'd be all right? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So I'll get that arranged and I want to thank you for answering these questions. ; Therapist: It's been helpful.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name; sherry; sex female ; Past Session Information: Follow -up session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting complaint depressed and anxious mood chief complaint 1 social withdrawal 2 fear 3 lack of concentration 4 sleep disturbances 5 irritability ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior  normal; speech slow, mood  affect dull, thought negative, perception, cognitive functions, judgement poor and insight ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Problem irritability, racing thoughts, sleep disturbances and difficulty concentrating contribute to feelings of frustration and anxiety which negatively impacts their daily functioning. She also expresses a desire to avoid social interactions due to fear which leads to social withdrawal. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Depression ; Action Plan : Referred to a counselor.

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Tiffany, how you doing today? ; Patient: Hi. ; Patient: I'm alright. ; Therapist: You alright? ; Patient: Alright. ; Therapist: I understand you've been having some difficulty lately. ; Patient: I wouldn't call it difficulty. ; Therapist: No? ; Therapist: What would you call it? ; Patient: According to my husband, I'm having a little bit of trouble with anger or something like that, but to me it's like... ; Therapist: Alright, so your husband believes you're having some trouble with anger? ; Patient: My husband thinks so, but to me I'm just fine. ; Patient: He's just... ; Patient: I may yell a little here and there at him, but he's a man. ; Patient: He should get over it. ; Patient: He's bigger than me, stronger than me. ; Patient: I got... ; Patient: Look, it's the way I get my point across. ; Patient: It's what I gotta do sometimes. ; Therapist: Alright, so you have a... you feel like you have a relational style that doesn't match what he wants? ; Therapist: Like you're yelling and he's not liking that? ; Patient: It's how I communicate. ; Therapist: It's how you communicate. ; Patient: If he's not happy with it, that's about... he's gonna have to deal with it. ; Therapist: Can you tell me about the yelling? ; Patient: He says this all the time. ; Patient: But to me it's what I do. ; Patient: If I want him to take the trash out, I tell him to take the trash out. ; Patient: He says I yell at him. ; Patient: We get into a fight over it. ; Patient: Just an argument over it. ; Patient: Nothing serious. ; Patient: But he says this for everything I do. ; Patient: Getting the kids ready to school, for school. ; Patient: He says I yell at the kids. ; Patient: He says I can't make anything simple. ; Patient: I can't just make a simple request. ; Patient: He says I have to yell at him. ; Patient: I have to start a fight. ; Patient: I say, he's a man up. ; Therapist: So you don't feel like you have a problem with yelling or anger or anything? ; Patient: I don't think it's a problem, no. ; Therapist: It's just the way you communicate? ; Patient: It's the way I am. ; Therapist: Has it been causing you... it's been causing you some trouble with your husband?
