; Therapist: Any other trouble? ; Patient: Maybe with the husband. ; Patient: You know, I almost got into an argument with the neighbor, but we dealt with that. ; Patient: He told my husband. ; Patient: He agreed with her and, well, he said I should get help. ; Therapist: All right, so it's caused you some difficulties in that way. ; Patient: To me, it's not a difficulty for him. ; Patient: It's more of a difficulty for him than it is for me. ; Therapist: So you're really here today because he's asked you to come in? ; Patient: I'm here. ; Patient: He's my husband. ; Patient: So I respect him. ; Patient: I want to make him happy, so I said I'll go. ; Therapist: All right, but you're really not convinced that you have a problem? ; Patient: I don't see it as a problem. ; Patient: He's more of a problem than I am. ; Therapist: He's convinced you're not? ; Patient: I don't think I'm a problem. ; Patient: I don't think I have a problem. ; Patient: He says it's all the yelling and I need help and it's time I do something about it. ; Patient: I say, all right, fine, I'll go see about it. ; Therapist: Would your relationship be a little easier without the yelling? ; Patient: For him it would be, I guess. ; Patient: But it may be. ; Patient: We could try it, but I don't know. ; Patient: But it's hard, but it's what I do. ; Therapist: Can you tell me about some of the events that you think lead to the yelling? ; Patient: He doesn't get what I'm trying to say. ; Patient: It could be something as he wants to do it his way. ; Patient: We could be driving. ; Patient: All right, no, honey, I said we want to go this way. ; Patient: Oh, wait, why are you going that way? ; Patient: No, look, no one get into a fight in the car. ; Patient: Or, okay, honey, that's not how you do the dishes. ; Patient: It could be something as simple as that. ; Patient: No, you wash out the dishes. ; Patient: No, that's not how you do the dishes. ; Patient: It could be something like that. ; Patient: We get into an argument. ; Patient: It's just over the simplest things. ; Therapist: And in that argument, how do you find the distribution of who's yelling? ; Therapist: Is it mostly you yelling or are you both yelling? ; Patient: I feel like I have to yell to get my point across, but he's not 100% innocent in this either. ; Patient: It's not my fault. ; Patient: I wouldn't have to yell if he listened the first time. ; Therapist: Do you ever find yourself planning to get into an argument, or is it more spontaneous? ; Patient: Spontaneous. ; Patient: I wouldn't plan to get into an argument with him. ; Therapist: It just kind of happens when it's stressful. ; Patient: If he would listen, we wouldn't be fighting so much. ; Patient: Things are fine when he listens, but then it's just, I don't know what it is. ; Patient: The moment I try to tell him something, it just gets to me. ; Therapist: And that's what leads to the... ; Patient: We just start yelling, just start fighting. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So this has been causing you some distress. ; Therapist: Mostly with that relationship. ; Patient: Our relationship could be better if he would listen more, but yes. ; Therapist: Do you have any medical conditions? ; Patient: Nope. ; Therapist: Do you ever use drugs or alcohol? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: I'm not an alcoholic or a drug addict or anything. ; Patient: If you're trying to say that, no. ; Therapist: Nothing like that. ; Therapist: Do you have any other mental health history you should know about, like depression or anxiety? ; Patient: I am as healthy as a horse. ; Therapist: Do you want to see a counselor here to work on the anger, yelling? ; Patient: If it would make him happy. ; Patient: I told him I would see a counselor, so I will see a counselor. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So if you're okay with it, I'll set you up with an appointment to see a counselor here. ; Therapist: And they should be able to see you within a couple days and you can get started. ; Patient: I guess I'm okay with it. ; Therapist: All right. ; Patient: Thanks, Tiffany. ; Therapist: All right.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name tiffany, sex female, marital status married ; Past Session Information: Inatake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms anger chief complaints 1 frustration 2 conflict with her husband ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior angry speech fast mood  affect agitated perception normal cognitive functions normal judgement and insight intact ; Issues discussed in Current Session: 1 relationship dynamics theirs is conflict between the client and her husband where she feels misunderstood and yells in the helplessness to get her point across, leading to tension and arguments. There is a communication gap between both of them. She feels that her husband is physical strong and he should be able to handle her yelling. 2 perception of problem the client doesnt want to accept yelling as a problem, while her husband perceives it as an issue. She denies the impact of her yelling on others which shows her resistance to change. 3 seeking help the client doesnt agree fully to see a counselor as she agrees because of her husbands request. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Anger issues ; Action Plan : Referred to a counselor

dialogue: Therapist: Hi, Alvina. ; Therapist: How are you doing today? ; Therapist: It's good to see you. ; Patient: I'm just tired. ; Therapist: Just tired. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: You know, we did some pre-visit planning with you, and your PHQ-2, which is a short depression screen, was actually positive. ; Therapist: So we asked the nurse to give you a little longer screening tool, which is a PHQ-9. ; Therapist: And that actually did come up with a score of 8, which is in the mild depression range. ; Therapist: So how does that feel? ; Patient: Well, I knew I felt different. ; Patient: I didn't know I was depressed. ; Therapist: But you knew something was wrong. ; Patient: I didn't feel like myself. ; Patient: I haven't been feeling like myself, no. ; Therapist: Tell me a little bit more about not feeling like yourself. ; Patient: Well, you know, I just go to work, and I come home, and I sleep. ; Patient: I wake up in the morning, and I'm still tired. ; Patient: I just have no energy. ; Therapist: So you sleep a lot, but even though you're sleeping, you don't wake up rested. ; Patient: No, not at all. ; Therapist: Doesn't sound like good quality sleep. ; Patient: No. ; Patient: I just have no energy. ; Patient: I don't want to do anything but just sleep. ; Therapist: How long has that been going on? ; Patient: Hmm. ; Patient: I guess a couple months. ; Therapist: Two or three months. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: What else is going on, Albina? ; Patient: Well, you know, I've been drinking more. ; Patient: I mean, I drink socially, but I find myself that when I come home, you know, I have a glass of wine, and then I just go to sleep. ; Therapist: And that's worrisome to you? ; Patient: It is, because I don't usually drink that often during the week. ; Patient: So it's increased. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: I can see where that would be. ; Therapist: Bothersome to you. ; Therapist: What else is going on with you? ; Patient: Well, you know, my mom died a year ago, so Mother's Day is coming up. ; Patient: So, you know, I've been thinking about mom a lot. ; Patient: I miss her a lot. ; Therapist: That anniversary is close. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Well, that's particularly hard when those anniversaries come around for the passings of our parents. ; Therapist: That's a very difficult time. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: And I took care of mom. ; Patient: So that's hard, because for a long time, well, she was sick and she died from cancer, so I took care of her. ; Patient: So for a long time, that's all I did was take care of mom and work. ; Patient: So now that she's gone, it just kind of brings up everything all over again. ; Therapist: There's kind of a hole in your life. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: We were really close. ; Therapist: Well, I'm really sorry for your loss, and thank you for sharing that with me. ; Therapist: I know that's very difficult. ; Therapist: So it sounds like your sleep has really been affected. ; Therapist: You're not getting good quality sleep. ; Therapist: You're really fatigued. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Just kind of going through the motions, it sounds like, during the day. ; Therapist: And then, how's your appetite been? ; Patient: Not really eating that much. ; Patient: You know, because I don't have energy. ; Patient: You know, before I would come home, cook dinner, or, you know, meet some friends after work. ; Patient: But I don't want to do that. ; Patient: I just come home and have a glass of wine and just go to bed. ; Therapist: So you used to be more socially involved than you are now. ; Patient: Yeah, I don't do anything now. ; Therapist: A little more isolated. ; Patient: Yeah, just work and come home and sleep. ; Therapist: So, if there was something that you could do about this, what do you think you might like to do? ; Patient: Well, I don't want to stay like this. ; Patient: This isn't who I am, you know, just sleeping all the time. ; Patient: It's just, I don't want to stay this way. ; Therapist: It kind of feels like you're stuck at this point. ; Patient: Yeah, I just don't want to do anything or go out with my friends anymore and just work and come home and sleep. ; Patient: I don't want to do that. ; Therapist: It's kind of the same old routine. ; Therapist: I wonder if it would be okay if we could talk about some of the options that are out there for folks that have some mild depression. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Would that be all right? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Most of the time, we typically think about medication as a possible answer. ; Patient: Mm. ; Therapist: So, no medication at this point. ; Patient: I don't want any medication. ; Therapist: No. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Then, I think as important, certainly, perhaps more important than medication is counseling and getting you to talk with someone about your feelings on a regular basis and getting some feedback on that. ; Patient: I'm okay with that. ; Patient: You know, when Mom was sick, she was in hospice care, so she had cancer. ; Patient: And the nurses and the doctors had our family talk to someone about what we were feeling, what we had to face. ; Therapist: So that was a pretty good experience? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: To talk to someone that understood what we were going through. ; Therapist: Sure. ; Therapist: Something else might be exercise. ; Therapist: Another possibility would be a natural product. ; Therapist: There are some things over the counter that I think for mild depression may be appropriate. ; Therapist: And that's another thing that we could talk about if you wanted to learn a little bit more about those. ; Patient: Maybe something natural. ; Patient: Exercise. ; Patient: I don't have energy. ; Patient: I don't want to... ; Patient: I just don't feel like doing anything, so I know I'm not going to exercise right now. ; Patient: But if it's something that's natural, you know, I could maybe try that. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: If it's okay, let's go back to talking about the counseling for a minute, and then we can hit some of those other things too. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So, is there a counselor that you know or that you have a relationship with? ; Therapist: This lady that worked with you during your mom's death, is she... ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Someone that's out in the community? ; Patient: She was really nice from... Yeah. ; Patient: I liked her. ; Therapist: So it sounds like you're pretty ready to do that. ; Therapist: Could you say on a scale of 0 to 10, 10 being really ready, 0 being not ready at all, how ready would you be to do some counseling? ; Patient: Maybe like a 6 or a 7. ; Therapist: So a 6 or a 7. ; Therapist: Why a 6 or a 7 and not a 4 or a 5? ; Patient: Well, because I don't want to stay like this, and you know, I've already talked to her before. ; Patient: She was really nice, so I wouldn't mind going back to her, and she told me, you know, when I saw her last time, if ever needed, I could come back. ; Therapist: So it sounds like you've got a connection there already. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: That's really good. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Does that sound like something you're ready to do then and maybe make a plan about that? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I can definitely check with her and see if she can see me again. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Well, if that's okay then, would it be alright if we talked a little bit about the exercise? ; Therapist: I know you said it didn't really sound like an option for you at this time, and that's perfectly fine. ; Therapist: Perfectly fine. ; Therapist: Only you can make those decisions, Alvena. ; Therapist: But if it's okay, I wanted to give you a little bit of information about exercise and its effect on the brain. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Exercise is, again, in a number of studies, has been shown to be as effective as prescription antidepressants. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: I didn't know that. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: It actually raises serotonin. ; Therapist: Have you heard about serotonin? ; Patient: Yeah, I have. ; Therapist: It's kind of a happy hormone. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: So it actually raises serotonin and also something called BDNF, which is, well, it doesn't really matter what it is, but it helps actually your brain actually grow and help repair itself. ; Therapist: So exercise can help in lots of ways by improving serotonin and decreasing stress, certainly, and then actually improving the quality of sleep. ; Therapist: How does that sound at this point? ; Patient: Well, if I try to exercise and if I call her to talk to her again, does that mean I don't have to go on the medication? ; Patient: Right now, we can try that? ; Therapist: Absolutely. ; Therapist: Again, those are your decisions, and I'm here to really support you in those. ; Therapist: So if those sound like things that you might be willing to do, I'm all for it. ; Patient: Well, I'll try that if I don't have to go on the medication. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: I have some friends that exercise and work out that I could probably call and exercise with them. ; Therapist: So you have some friends that are already involved in an exercise program. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Is that something you talk with them about and that you possibly could get into that group? ; Patient: Yeah, I have friends that run and friends that go to the gym. ; Patient: I have some friends that walk after work. ; Therapist: So it sounds like a wide variety of things that you could do. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Which of those tend to interest you most? ; Patient: Well, then also, you know, my church on the weekends, they have exercise classes too. ; Patient: So, yeah, but I think, I guess I don't have energy really to exercise, but I'll try it. ; Patient: But I'll definitely call the person I had talked to when mom passed away, and I'll do that right away. ; Therapist: Very good. ; Therapist: Well, I think it sounds like this is important for you to feel better, and it sounds like you're really ready to kind of make a plan. ; Therapist: How do you see this fitting into your life at this point? ; Therapist: Again, kind of getting back to the counseling and the exercise. ; Patient: Well, when I saw her, I could see her after work. ; Patient: So I can call her and see if I can still see her after work for therapy. ; Patient: And exercise, I mean, I can do that, you know, after work or on the weekends. ; Patient: My friends, they exercise various times. ; Patient: So, yeah. ; Therapist: Let's talk a little bit more about that. ; Therapist: Let's say on a scale of, if we can use another one of those scales, zero being confident that you could start an exercise program, zero being not very confident at all, and ten being very confident. ; Therapist: Tell me where you are in this exercise thing. ; Patient: Honestly, maybe a five. ; Patient: I'll try it. ; Patient: Anything, if I have to do that so I don't have to go on medication, then I'll try it. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: That sounds like a pretty strong commitment. ; Patient: Yes, I'll try it. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And tell me a little bit more about your plan for exercise at this point then. ; Patient: Well, you know, my friends have been calling, but, you know, I'm just sleeping all the time. ; Patient: So when they call, I'm asleep. ; Patient: So I haven't really called them back. ; Patient: But, you know, I can just return their calls and just let them know I'll want to meet up with them and, you know, at least maybe just start walking. ; Therapist: I think that's a great decision. ; Therapist: You have a couple of friends in mind that you could call? ; Patient: Yeah, I have real close friends that live not too far from me. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So tell me about a plan that you would think could perhaps get you going with the exercise. ; Patient: Well, I probably shouldn't come home. ; Patient: I probably would need to call one of my friends and make a plan to maybe walk after work and take a change of clothes and maybe drive to one of my friend's house after work and change with her. ; Therapist: It would be difficult to do it in the morning. ; Therapist: You don't see that happening. ; Patient: No, because it's so hard when I get up in the morning. ; Patient: I'm so tired that I can't see doing it in the morning. ; Therapist: And you think it would be easier to do it after work? ; Patient: Because I'm already out. ; Patient: Yeah, as long as I don't come home. ; Patient: So I come home and want to go to sleep. ; Therapist: Come home, it's over. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: Well, good. ; Therapist: It sounds like we have a plan for the counselor. ; Therapist: And when you check out today, I will put this in your record. ; Therapist: And we'll want to get in touch with the counselor that you worked with when your mom was going through her passing and the grief situation. ; Therapist: And then I'll want to depend upon you to call your friends and then get involved in the exercise program. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: I'll try that. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: And if it's okay, I'd like to call you in a week to one, see how you're feeling and two, if the exercise is helping. ; Therapist: You may really find that after you give the exercise a good trial, you may actually look forward to it. ; Therapist: Because my hope is that it will actually help you feel better and improve your mood. ; Therapist: And then I would also like to see you back in two weeks just to check on things. ; Therapist: Now, we've talked about medication not being on the table at this point. ; Therapist: But I want you to know, you can call anytime and I will work to get you in. ; Therapist: And that might be something that we need to do if our plan is not working. ; Patient: Okay.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name alvina; sex female ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Psychiatrist ; Past Session Information: Follow up session; previous session details assessment phq-2 and phq-9 were conducted to screen depression. ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Fatiguability 3 months 2. Alcohol consumption 3. Decreased sociability 4. Decreased sleep 5. Decreased appetite ; History: Present history patients mother passed away a year ago due to cancer. She misses her a lot and her absence makes a her feel low. Since her death anniversary is near, she has been feeling a lot more tired and doesnt like spending time with any of her friend. She has been sleeping and eating less lately and has been consuming alcohol regularly. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behavior patient was cooperative and rapport could be established; mood dysphoric; affect restricted. ; Psychotherapy Type: Behaviroal therapy ; Psychotherapy Technique : Behavioral activation ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patients reason behind her fatiguability, alcohol consumption and decrease sleep were addresses. Possible potential steps towards her goals were discussed. She was reluctant towards taking medication and wanted to rely on therapy first. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: F32. 0 mild depression ; Action Plan : Patient has to seek her previous counselor to get support. She also has to start with exercising. ; Next session details: After 1 week.

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Jessica, how are you doing? ; Patient: I'm alright, how about you? ; Therapist: I'm doing okay. ; Therapist: So, how have you been doing today? ; Therapist: How's your week been? ; Patient: It's been okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So, in our last session together, we talked about your lack of confidence. ; Therapist: Do you feel like you've made any progress on that? ; Patient: Um, I mean, I've been journaling, like you said. ; Therapist: Good, good. ; Patient: Um, I've spent time helping. ; Patient: Uh, I feel like there's still a lot of room for improvement though. ; Patient: But it has improved slightly. ; Therapist: So, when you said you've been journaling, were you able to, when you had a negative thought, or you know, a situation occurred where you had a negative thought, were you writing down a negative thought? ; Patient: Yeah, um, not automatic. ; Patient: Well, I was thinking what you told me. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And you were able to make it a positive thought? ; Patient: Yeah, I mean, I tried, um, to do that. ; Patient: It helped some, but, uh, I guess any improvement's better. ; Patient: But, uh, I think maybe just to keep doing it, maybe it'll get better. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: But I was more aware of how things are occurring. ; Therapist: Good. ; Patient: I didn't realize how often. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: Sorry. ; Therapist: No, so do you remember kind of what we discussed last time about how CBT works? ; Patient: Um, a little bit. ; Patient: Um, not exactly. ; Patient: But I just remember how my thoughts. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Are causing things. ; Therapist: So would you come out to our view before we actually get into this session? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Would that be okay? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So how it goes is like, say a situation or an event happens, you have a thought, okay? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And like I know last time it was your lack of confidence, and it could be like, I'm not good enough, and that was your thought process last time, correct? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And then so when you have a thought, you have an emotion. ; Therapist: Last time you were saying how it made you feel bad about yourself. ; Therapist: You felt incompetent. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: And then your behavior is you were, you know, you lashed out at others and you were mean. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: So do you feel like that you kind of understand that? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So I know last time, like I said, we talked about your lack of confidence. ; Therapist: So for today, I know you mentioned that you also were having problems with using marijuana and depression, you had problems with depression, and you also had anger issues. ; Therapist: And out of those, which one do you think you'd like to discuss today? ; Patient: Probably the anger issues. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: I feel like that's the biggest problem going on right now. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Tell me a little bit more about your anger issues. ; Patient: I mean, it's not like I'm just like an angry person. ; Patient: It just like snaps at anybody. ; Patient: But I get defensive, I guess. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: I'm very defensive. ; Patient: And then I usually want to lash out. ; Patient: But I've never, I've lashed out at my child, you know, my son or anything. ; Patient: It's usually always my husband. ; Therapist: Can you tell me about the last time you lashed out at your husband? ; Patient: We were unloading the groceries. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: And I actually had just had my hair done and cut and colored and everything. ; Patient: And I was so excited because I thought he was going to love it, you know. ; Patient: And he looked at it and he, of course, he thought, well, how much money did it cost? ; Patient: And, you know, girl, you know, these things are kind of expensive. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: And so I told him, you know, it would have been $60. ; Patient: And he told me that, you know, we've been struggling with money lately a little bit. ; Patient: And that I didn't need to spend that much money and that I was selfish. ; Patient: And then I hit him. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So now what I'm writing down here is kind of like what we talked about, how there's an event or a situation. ; Therapist: You have a thought and you have an emotion. ; Therapist: I know like with what you were just saying, the event or the situation was that you got your hair done. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: And that he was angry about that. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: He was just, yeah, he was just saying mean things. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Now, what did you, in that moment when he was being mean, what was, not how you felt, but what was your actual thought? ; Therapist: Like when he was saying all that stuff and? ; Patient: I'm selfish. ; Therapist: You thought I'm selfish. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Initially, yeah, that was it. ; Patient: He's right. ; Patient: I believe that was selfish. ; Therapist: How did that make you feel when you actually thought I'm selfish? ; Patient: Guilty. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So you felt guilty? ; Patient: Sad. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: And then angry. ; Therapist: Angry. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Very angry. ; Patient: But he made me feel that way. ; Patient: I wasn't feeling that way before he said that. ; Patient: And then once he said that, you know, he put that thought in my head and it made me angry. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: So when he was getting mad at you and then telling you you're selfish and you felt selfish or you thought to yourself, I'm selfish, and then you got angry, what did you do after you got angry? ; Patient: I smacked him. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Yep. ; Therapist: So there was physical contact there. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I hit him upside his head. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: I mean, I felt that afterwards. ; Patient: Me too. ; Patient: It's just I was so mad. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: How do you feel that way? ; Therapist: Uh-huh. ; Patient: I just, I lashed out. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So when he has these, when he kind of gets upset at you for certain things like this, how do you think you could change from you smacking him to having a more calm and positive response? ; Patient: Well, I think if I was able to get his angry. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: How do you think you might be able to do that? ; Therapist: Like this is how we would do it. ; Therapist: With CBT, we would change your thought. ; Therapist: So when he gets upset with you and calls you selfish, you start to feel selfish. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So how could you not feel selfish? ; Therapist: Do you think you could change your thought? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I mean, if I never even thought that I was selfish, then I wouldn't be getting angry. ; Therapist: So do you think you're selfish? ; Patient: I mean, at the time I did that and I felt like awful. ; Patient: But now, like, he says that we're hurting for money, but we're really not. ; Patient: Like, we're able to pay our bills. ; Patient: We're able to do things. ; Patient: I mean, he's just kind of like a cheap person. ; Patient: But we have plenty of money to, we're not hurting at all. ; Patient: And with my self-confidence, I don't think it was selfish in one. ; Patient: Make myself feel prettier, you know? ; Patient: But I think people do other selfish tendencies like that. ; Therapist: So what I'm hearing you say is you don't think you're selfish at all. ; Patient: Well, I mean, I'm selfish. ; Therapist: But in this situation, you don't think you're being selfish. ; Patient: I don't think I'm just wrong. ; Patient: I really don't. ; Patient: Now, if I had gone by a whole new wardrobe, nothing else, none along with it, but I mean, I just did my hair. ; Patient: And he's a real estate agent. ; Patient: He had sold a big house that week, so we had enough money for me to afford it. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: So he's just a pain in the juice sometimes. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So instead of thinking I'm selfish, what could you actually think? ; Patient: That I deserve to spend money on myself. ; Patient: I don't want to spend money on me sometimes. ; Therapist: I deserve this. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: I mean, who doesn't deserve something every now and then, right? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay, so if you were thinking I deserve this, if that was your thought when he was getting in, if you thought, no, I deserve this, how do you think that would actually make you feel? ; Therapist: What kind of emotion would you feel at that point? ; Therapist: Would that make you feel confident? ; Patient: Yeah, confident in my decision. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: I would still feel a little sad that he thought that, but I don't think it would be to the level that it was when I thought I was selfish. ; Therapist: So if you felt confident about your decision because you actually changed your thought, do you think that would in turn change your behavior instead of you actually getting angry, you would think there's no need for this? ; Patient: Yeah, I think it would help me realize that that's his issue and I won't. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: So how do you think you would actually behave then? ; Patient: Walk off. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Or even be able to, this is kind of what I wanted to get to as well, be able to express it in a non-violent manner. ; Patient: Because he didn't deserve for me to hit on him. ; Patient: I mean, he didn't. ; Patient: He said something that upset me, but no one deserves that. ; Patient: Someone's hand is put on him. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: So maybe instead of thinking also that you're selfish when he's getting my back, do you think maybe you could say to yourself instead that maybe he just doesn't understand and maybe I need to tell him that I do deserve this and explain it to him that this makes me feel good about myself? ; Patient: Yeah, yeah, I could try that. ; Therapist: Because you know, you know you're not selfish. ; Therapist: It's just something that makes you feel good. ; Patient: And I think also he understood why I did it. ; Patient: Because I mean, he knows that I have some self-conscious issues, but I don't think he realizes how bad it was or why I got my hair cut. ; Patient: I think he's seen it as just the most girly things. ; Patient: He didn't realize that it made me feel better about myself, you know? ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: So that might help as well. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Which goes back to his presidencies. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So do you think in like the next coming week that you could actually change your thoughts? ; Therapist: In turn to change how you feel? ; Patient: I could try, yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Since we talked about your anger issues, I know you were saying last time that you were also having problems with depression. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: And you were also having problems with your marijuana use. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And either one of those, would you like to discuss that? ; Therapist: Or I mean, would you like to discuss your anger issues further? ; Patient: No, we can talk about the depression. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: What do you think triggers your depression? ; Therapist: What makes you depressed? ; Patient: Well, my son kind of at the age where he doesn't want me to be involved in his life. ; Patient: And I've kind of always been the housewife. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: And he's at, and he's always been my wife, you know? ; Patient: I did everything with him. ; Patient: I went to all his practices with him. ; Patient: And he's mommy's little boy. ; Patient: But he's not mommy's little boy anymore. ; Patient: And so now he's kind of growing up and doing his own thing. ; Patient: And then I'm kind of left alone. ; Therapist: How old is your son? ; Patient: He's 14. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: That's an interesting age. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: And so he's kind of telling me there's any little man who he'll tell him I said that, he'd probably have been there. ; Patient: But, and like, and I don't know if that's where it comes from, but I know that that's here lately. ; Patient: You know, I'm used to him being at home, and now I'm staying with friends, and I'm home by myself a lot. ; Patient: Or he doesn't like for me to call him, or no more kisses, and you know. ; Patient: And I know that it's normal, but it still makes me feel really depressed. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So, the situation here is that your son doesn't want to be involved with you as much. ; Therapist: Do you feel like that's accurate? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: And then he's just growing up. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And what do you think to yourself when he doesn't want to talk to mom anymore, and he doesn't want to be mom's little boy, and he's out doing his own thing? ; Patient: Well, I mean like, this week I was taking on his football schedule. ; Patient: He's a big football player. ; Patient: You wouldn't believe it, but a big old boy came out of me. ; Patient: And, there you go boy. ; Patient: And he, so I was taking on his football schedule, and he got upset at me because he felt like I was getting in his business and trying to mommy him. ; Patient: And I was just trying to make sure that he was going to be able to make it through all the time, that he had all the clothes necessary. ; Patient: And I asked him if he needed a ride and things like that, and he just felt like I was getting into his business. ; Patient: And it just made me feel like I'm not needed anymore. ; Therapist: So when he, what is your exact thought though when this kind of stuff happens? ; Patient: I'm not needed anymore. ; Patient: And that situation is what I thought is I'm not needed anymore. ; Therapist: Yeah, and that's hard when you've always been needed before. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: How does that make you feel? ; Therapist: What kind of emotion? ; Patient: I mean sad. ; Patient: I was really sad. ; Patient: Um, lonely. ; Patient: I felt really lonely. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And then, what did you do? ; Therapist: How did you get into that situation? ; Patient: Um, I actually, I guess, decided to move out a little bit. ; Patient: I spent a couple of drinks. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Do you think you use the marijuana also because you're depressed? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So that it kind of all... ; Patient: Yeah, I mean I never used it before. ; Patient: I mean it just started like when I started to feel sad and depressed. ; Patient: So yeah, I think that it did. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So, and what I'm hearing you saying, correct me if I'm wrong, is that your son doesn't want to be involved anymore. ; Therapist: You don't feel like you're needed. ; Therapist: That's what you say to yourself and that makes you feel sad and lonely. ; Therapist: And then in turn you use marijuana. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So, do you want to use marijuana? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: I mean, I don't want my son, if he ever found out, like, that would be a good influence on him and I don't think that's a good influence. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Sorry. ; Therapist: That's okay. ; Therapist: So what I kind of wanted you to do for the next session is kind of what we were continuing what we were doing last week. ; Therapist: You know how you journaled and when you have a negative thought that you changed it to a positive thought. ; Therapist: And then in turn you saw maybe like how it could change your behavior. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Or your emotional behavior. ; Therapist: So do you think maybe you could do that again? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Like when times such as when your son, you know, is kind of doesn't want to run around, you think instead of I'm not needed, instead of thinking I'm not needed anymore, thinking, you know, he's growing up, that's good. ; Therapist: I've raised, you know, a son that's active and who is enjoying life. ; Therapist: And then how would that make you feel if you actually thought that to yourself? ; Patient: I mean, yeah, I mean, that might make me feel better. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: You know, because he's probably in a good place and active and social and a good person because of you. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So that would make you happy, I would think. ; Therapist: And then, you know, maybe then you could, you know, have a different behavior or do something different. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So journaling, does that sound good? ; Patient: Yeah, I'll try it. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Good.
summary: Patient Particulars : Namejessica; sexfemale; occupation homemaker ; Clinical Identifiers: Settingopd; diagnosis depression ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Follow up session; previous session focus psychoeducation about cognitive model, lack of confidence, anger management; previous session action plan journaling, behavioural analysis abc charting, cognitive restructuring, follow up after 1 week ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Lack of confidencena; episodes of uncontrollable anger na; low moodna; cannabis usena ; History: Patient has been facing low mood and lack of confidence. At times she gets irritable and snaps at her friends or family members which is out of proportion to the situation. She reports that she later regrets getting so angry. When she feels low, she resorts to taking marijuana which makes her feel better for a limited period of time and she forgets about her son ignoring her or not needing her anymore. ; Crisis Markers: Cannabis use ; Current Mental Status Examination: Affect depressed ; Psychotherapy Type: Type cbt; mode individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Journaling, thought challenging, cognitive restructuring ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Analysis of anger episodes in the past week; coping with low mood by cognitive restructuring ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Depression with cluster b traits with cannabis harmful use ; Action Plan : Client has been asked to continue journaling, challenge her dysfunctional thoughts and reframe them in a positive manner ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Kyle, how are you doing today? ; Patient: I'm doing alright. ; Patient: I'm not doing too bad. ; Patient: How are you Dr. Grande? ; Therapist: Not bad, thanks for asking. ; Therapist: What brings you in? ; Patient: So my girlfriend saw your ad in the paper and she saw out of some of the things that you work on, one of them is smoking cessation and it bothers her that I smoke. ; Patient: So she has been nagging me for like weeks to come in and talk to you. ; Patient: So I figured I would just kind of come in just so she would stop bugging me about it. ; Therapist: So you came into therapy today because your girlfriend pressured you? ; Patient: Yeah, I mean it's easier for me like if I come in here and talk to you, I can spend like 45 minutes with you compared to hours of her nagging me through the week. ; Therapist: So you weighed the cost benefit and decided to come in? ; Patient: Yeah, I mean it's covered by insurance, it's just 45 minutes of my time. ; Therapist: And what she would like you to do, and this is her goal, not yours, would be to stop smoking. ; Therapist: Tell me what your goal is. ; Patient: I mean I don't really have one. ; Patient: I don't think smoking is that bad. ; Patient: Well I mean I don't know, smoking could be bad but it's never bothered me. ; Patient: I don't know, I really don't have any goals to come in besides just having her stop bugging me. ; Therapist: So do you have a goal of quitting smoking? ; Patient: No, not at all. ; Patient: There's so many good things about smoking. ; Patient: What really got me into it was I smoke a lot at work because it gives me one-on-one time with the boss. ; Patient: So the fact that I can get that time with my boss is completely worth it. ; Therapist: Can you tell me about some of the other good things about smoking? ; Patient: It's just like, it's how I meet people. ; Patient: So like if I, I'll have cigarettes on me but I don't have a lighter and that kind of keeps me from finishing off a pack. ; Patient: Because I could finish off a pack a day. ; Patient: But if I don't have a lighter then I carry the cigarettes around with me and then if I see other people are smoking I can go and ask for a light. ; Patient: And that's always kind of like a way in to get to these groups. ; Patient: I've just met so many different people from smoking. ; Therapist: So smoking, the way you're presenting it, has been a positive thing in your life? ; Patient: Yeah, I mean I only do it socially. ; Patient: So that's, yeah. ; Therapist: Are there any negative aspects to smoking? ; Patient: I mean yeah, I mean everyone knows smoking is unhealthy but like I don't, I don't smoke a lot. ; Patient: Like I only smoke from time to time and it's mostly just on the weekends. ; Patient: So it's like, I don't know, occasionally if I smoke over the weekends I might have like a cough maybe. ; Patient: Like a heavy cough on Mondays, Tuesdays, it's gone by Wednesdays so it's not really that big of a deal. ; Therapist: So you don't seem like you're too worried about the negative aspects. ; Patient: No, I mean like the, obviously it's unhealthy but like one of the things I'm trying to do in my life now is get out there and meet new people. ; Patient: And like the benefit of being able to do that smoking is better than like giving it up for health reasons I think. ; Therapist: So let me ask you a question. ; Therapist: I want you to give me a response between one and ten. ; Therapist: This is called scaling. ; Therapist: And it's to do with the importance of stopping smoking. ; Therapist: So one would be it's not important to you and ten would be it's extremely important to you. ; Therapist: Where do you think you'd put that number? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: Maybe like a two. ; Patient: Like it'd be cool to get rid of the cough on Mondays but that, getting rid of that is not worth everything else I get from smoking. ; Therapist: So not particularly important? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Now let me ask you the same question except instead of importance, how confident, we're talking about confidence, how confident are you that you could quit smoking? ; Therapist: On a scale of one to ten with one being not confident at all and ten being extremely confident. ; Patient: I could say probably like an eight or a nine. ; Patient: Like I could give it up. ; Patient: Actually I gave it up recently like for like a month and I didn't even crave it. ; Patient: But eventually like just seeing all my friends go out smoking, like I missed that so I just started up again. ; Patient: But I don't know. ; Patient: Like if I really wanted to give it up for good I'm sure I could. ; Therapist: So stopping smoking is not important to you but you're fairly confident you could if you decided to do it. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So based on kind of where you are in terms of it doesn't seem like you're interested in stopping smoking, what would be a goal? ; Therapist: How could we spend this time so that it would be productive? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: Like I guess it would help to be able to like explain to my girlfriend like the stuff that I get from smoking. ; Patient: And like you seem, you kind of seem like you get it. ; Patient: So like I don't know maybe figure out ways to like explain to her the things that I get from smoking to like I don't know just kind of help her like realize why I do it other than just to kill myself. ; Therapist: So to help her to understand why the smoking works for you. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So that's one goal. ; Therapist: Any other goals you could think of? ; Therapist: I mean you came in in part because, well it seemed like you came in completely because your girlfriend pressured you. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So any other relational goals you might want to work on there? ; Patient: Um, I don't know. ; Patient: We haven't really been, like we've been fighting a lot because of the smoking. ; Patient: Um, so I think like maybe figuring out ways, I don't know, like to maybe communicate better or like having like good fights in a way. ; Patient: Like I don't know how to describe that but like having fights that are productive like that just don't always end like with us just like going our separate ways or like one of us leaving the house. ; Patient: But like I guess being able to like wrap up a fight so it doesn't last for like days. ; Therapist: So productive communication and productive arguments. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: So one goal would be to illustrate clearly the advantages of smoking to your girlfriend. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: So she understands how important it is to you. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Because it does seem like it's really important to you. ; Therapist: But another would be to work on your relation, your relational style so that you can end the argument and feel like you're not a stalemate. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah, I think that would be cool. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: Well, you want to make those the goals we work on so we can spend this time productive fast? ; Patient: Yeah, I can deal with that. ; Patient: It's kind of like killing two birds with one stone. ; Therapist: Does that make sense to you? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Well, that's what we'll do. ; Therapist: So what I'd like you to do, I'll see you again in about a week. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: So if you could reflect on some of these changes that you think you can make with this relationship, what you could do in the relationship to be a more effective communicator. ; Therapist: Because a lot of this revolves around communication, right? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Communicating the advantages of smoking but also communicating and the arguing so that you have a productive end to these arguments. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: So really more moving from arguments to collegial conversations that have a positive result. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah, that would be cool if we could do that. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So if you could work on kind of thinking that through and then next time we meet we'll talk about those different goals and maybe ways to make some small changes in that relationship to meet those goals. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Patient: Sounds good. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: Thanks for coming in, Kyle. ; Patient: Yeah, thank you.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name kyle; sex- male; marital status unmarried ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Name dr. Grande ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Arguments with romantic partner ; History: Present history client has been having frequent arguments with his romantic partner over his habit of smoking. He came to therapy under her pressure so he doesnt have to engage in arguments with her. He has been smoking to socialise better with people and doesnt crave for it. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behavior client was cooperative and rapport could e established; mood calm; affect broad; insight- grade 5 ; Psychotherapy Type: Solution focussed therapy ; Psychotherapy Technique : Scaling questions ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Client shared his partners pressure on him for quitting smoking; goals for the therapy were discussed which were majorly about having productive communication and productive arguments with his romantic partner. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Nil ; Action Plan : Client has to explain his primary reason for smoking to his partner to their arguments and improve their relationship ; Next session details: After 1 week

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Jackie, how are you doing today? ; Patient: Alright, how are you? ; Therapist: I'm doing fine, thanks for asking. ; Therapist: I understand you've been having some difficulties that brought you into our agency. ; Patient: Yeah, I'm really worried about my drinking. ; Therapist: You're worried about your drinking? Tell me about your drinking. ; Patient: Well, my family, you know, my family are all big partiers, they all really like to drink. ; Patient: It's something I've been surrounded by a lot, but I've been having these really intense cravings that I really feel like I want to drink. ; Patient: When I'm at work, I'm just like, I could really use a drink right now. ; Patient: That really worries me. ; Patient: I'm just nervous it's becoming a problem. ; Therapist: So, sometimes at work you've been having cravings for alcohol. ; Therapist: Any other times when you've been having cravings? ; Patient: Yeah, it's kind of when I'm at home, you know, not really doing anything. ; Patient: I could go for a beer right now. ; Therapist: So, other than that feeling of having the craving, is there anything you do after you have the craving? ; Patient: Yeah, sometimes I'll have a drink. ; Patient: I just feel like I want to give into it. ; Therapist: How much do you drink? ; Patient: Like a beer or two. ; Therapist: Is this when, do you work in the day? ; Therapist: Is this when you're at work in the day? ; Patient: Oh no, after work I'll go and have a drink. ; Therapist: So, when you're having cravings at work, you're not drinking there? ; Patient: No, no. ; Therapist: So, tell me about your typical alcohol consumption in a week. ; Patient: I like to, on Fridays, after work, after a long week, that's kind of when I really crave it. ; Patient: I go have a drink with some friends. ; Patient: I'll have a drink sometimes with dinner. ; Patient: I'll find that a social event. ; Patient: I kind of feel like I want to have a drink then. ; Patient: And I don't really want to feel that way. ; Patient: I feel like that might be a problem. ; Therapist: You're worried that the craving is indicating that you have an alcohol. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Have you ever tried to cut down your drinking and you're unable to do so? ; Patient: Well, I mean, usually I'm able to limit my days. ; Patient: If I say I'm going to go to a party this weekend, I'll have one. ; Patient: And, you know, usually I can stick to it. ; Patient: I don't really feel to it, I guess. ; Therapist: Do you spend a lot of time trying to obtain alcohol? ; Patient: Um, no. ; Patient: I guess not. ; Patient: I mean, I think about where I could, when I have a craving, I think about when I want to have it. ; Patient: But I don't really spend a lot of time thinking about it or trying to get it. ; Therapist: How about in terms of your responsibilities? ; Therapist: Have you failed to uphold any of your responsibilities because of your drinking? ; Patient: Maybe I haven't gone home from work right away when I have to put my clothes away or do some laundry. ; Patient: You know, because I'd rather just go have a drink with my friends. ; Patient: No major responsibilities, no work responsibilities or anything like that have been missed. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: Do you have any social problems because of your drinking? ; Patient: Well, no, I guess not. ; Patient: I mean, I get really friendly when I have a drink, so I don't really think that's a problem. ; Patient: But, no, I guess not. ; Therapist: It hasn't caused any social problems. ; Therapist: Do you find yourself giving up important activities because you're drinking instead? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: I usually do what I need to do and if I have to go to a shower or something, brown shower, maybe. ; Patient: I usually go to them. ; Patient: Maybe I think about it while I'm there that I'd like to have a beer at this. ; Patient: Why isn't there any beer here? ; Patient: But I still attend the things that I need to attend. ; Therapist: So you're thinking about it, maybe still some craving, but you're still going, you're still participating. ; Patient: Yeah, yeah. ; Therapist: Are you engaging in any activities that are dangerous because of the drinking? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Drinking and driving, anything like that, nothing like that. ; Patient: Well, no. ; Patient: I, no, I guess not. ; Therapist: There's nothing like that? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Do you have any physical or mental health problems that are made worse by the drinking? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: I wouldn't say worse. ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Do you have any medical or mental health problems in general? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Do you find that you have to increase the amount of alcohol you're drinking to get the same effect? ; Patient: I usually have around the same amount every time. ; Patient: So I guess I would say no. ; Patient: I never really go all out, not a ton of drinks, but so, no. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: And you've been drinking, you say you've been drinking about the same amount each time you drink. ; Therapist: Have you noticed that the effect has been diminished? ; Therapist: Like you're not getting the same effect from the alcohol? ; Patient: I usually feel the same. ; Therapist: Feel the same way? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Have you ever noticed any symptoms when you stop drinking, like a withdrawal? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Nothing like that? ; Patient: Well, what do you mean really by withdrawal? ; Therapist: Like when you stop using alcohol, are you finding that you're anxious, depressed, you have physical reactions? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Nothing like that? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Alright, Jackie. ; Therapist: I appreciate you telling me about what's going on and answering my questions. ; Therapist: If you're okay with it, I'll get you in to see a counselor. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: I'll get that scheduled and we can go from there. ; Therapist: Okay, thank you very much.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name jackie ; Clinical Identifiers: Agency ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms substance use chief complaints 1 cravings 2 unable to reduce ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior normal; speech normal, mood  affect low, thought, , judgement poor ; Issues discussed in Current Session: 1 problems patient worries about her drinking habits, her intense cravings for alcohol, both at work and at home. Its difficult to control her cravings and acknowledges instances where she prioritizes drinking over responsibilities. 2 efforts patient maintains that it hasnt led to significant social or functional impairment and also shows willingness to seek help and see a counsellor. ; Action Plan : Referred to a therapist

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Jackie, how you doing today? ; Patient: I'm great. ; Therapist: You're great? ; Patient: Yeah, I am. ; Patient: How are you? ; Therapist: I'm doing okay, thanks for asking. ; Therapist: I see that you signed a release so I could talk to your mother and I see she took you in here today. ; Patient: Yeah, she brought me. ; Therapist: She brought you in? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Can you tell me what's going on? ; Patient: Ah, she's not happy with me. ; Therapist: No? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: She doesn't like how I smoke. ; Therapist: She doesn't like how you smoke? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: But, I don't know. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: You know, it's... ; Patient: I don't want her to be mad at me. ; Patient: But, who cares, you know? ; Therapist: So, you're concerned somewhat, but... ; Patient: Yeah, yeah. ; Patient: I mean, I love my mom, you know, but I just kind of came here to make her happy, so... ; Therapist: And what are you smoking, how is her concerned? ; Patient: Ah, just weed. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: It's no big deal, really. ; Patient: I don't know why she's so upset. ; Therapist: She's upset about that? ; Patient: Yeah, yeah. ; Patient: She's been on me for a while about it, so... ; Therapist: Are there any other drugs or alcohol or anything that you consume? ; Patient: Well, yeah, I drink sometimes, too. ; Therapist: You drink sometimes? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: But, no, like, yeah. ; Therapist: Not something she's concerned with? ; Patient: Um, well, I mean, nah. ; Patient: She's more concerned about the, ah, the weed, so... ; Therapist: Are you concerned with the alcohol or marijuana? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: No. ; Patient: I don't think it's a problem. ; Therapist: You don't think it's a problem? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Can I ask you a few questions about it? ; Patient: Yeah, yeah. ; Patient: Sure. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Of course. ; Therapist: Can you tell me when you first started using it, how that came about? ; Patient: Um, I think it was, ah, like, my sophomore year of high school. ; Patient: One of my friends offered it to me, so, you know, I was kind of feeling, having some anxiety, um, maybe had some anxiety about starting it, but, so I tried it. ; Patient: Um, yeah, it made me feel great. ; Patient: So, it made my anxiety go away, so... ; Therapist: It took the anxiety away? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: Yeah, so I... ; Therapist: How long did you have the anxiety before the marijuana use? ; Patient: You know, probably during my adolescence, a couple years. ; Therapist: A couple years? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: It wasn't anything crazy, but, you know, it affected my life a little bit, so I think it makes me feel a lot better now that I smoke it. ; Patient: It gets rid of that feeling. ; Therapist: So, you started, you started marijuana because a friend offered it to you and because you were anxious? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And then, how about from then on? ; Patient: Um, you know, I don't want to feel that anxiety anymore. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: I don't want to have to take any pills or anything, so I've kind of just kept doing it to make me feel great. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: It's great. ; Patient: Yeah, so, I think it's great. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: When was the last time you used? ; Patient: Mm, this morning. ; Therapist: This morning? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Did anything happen in particular that you think motivated your mother to bring in today? ; Patient: Mm, no, no. ; Patient: I think she kind of wants me to get out and get a job and everything. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: But, you know, I'm living my life. ; Patient: It's perfectly fine, really. ; Patient: I've got a little bit of money, but I'm not worried. ; Therapist: So, what do you want to happen? ; Therapist: What would your goal be? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: I want to make my mom happy, but I don't really want to stop. ; Therapist: In order to make her happy, would you have to stop? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: I guess, but maybe she could learn to deal with it if I just acted a little differently when I was on it. ; Patient: I don't really want to stop because it makes me feel a little better, so. ; Therapist: She wants you to get a job, too? ; Patient: Yeah, ideally she would like me to. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Would employment involve drug screening? ; Patient: I mean, probably some of them. ; Therapist: Some? ; Patient: Some, if I tried, yeah. ; Patient: I haven't really made a big effort to look for anything. ; Therapist: You're not too worried about that right now? ; Patient: No, I mean, I think every day is a new day, a new chance for greatness, and it's going great so far, so. ; Therapist: Do you mind if I ask you a few questions about your marijuana use? ; Patient: Yeah, that's fine. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Have you ever tried to cut down? ; Patient: No, no. ; Therapist: Have you ever taken in larger amounts than you wanted to, or for longer periods? ; Patient: Yeah, I mean, sometimes I'll smoke more than I usually do. ; Patient: If I'm hanging out, or maybe one of those anxiety days are a little worse, I'll smoke some more. ; Therapist: How much time do you spend obtaining, using, recovering from marijuana? ; Patient: A good amount of time. ; Therapist: Yeah? ; Patient: I love it, so it's something I love to do. ; Therapist: It's a big part of your life? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: It's like my best friend. ; Therapist: Do you have a craving for marijuana? ; Patient: Yeah, I would say so. ; Patient: I want to do it, yeah, so. ; Therapist: Has it led to any social problems for you? ; Patient: I used to hang out with my friends a little more than I do, but I guess some of them think I do it a little too much. ; Therapist: Do they? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Has the marijuana use caused you to give up activities that were important to you? ; Patient: It is my important activity, you know? ; Patient: So not really? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Has the marijuana use caused any activity to become dangerous? ; Patient: Like what? ; Therapist: Like driving while under the influence, or anything like that? ; Patient: Yeah, I've done that. ; Patient: That's dangerous, that's no big deal. ; Therapist: That's dangerous? ; Patient: Yeah, I'm fine. ; Patient: I usually drive, but everybody does that. ; Therapist: Everybody does that? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Now your mother, she drove you in today? ; Patient: Yeah, yeah, she came with me. ; Therapist: Was she worried that you were under the influence of marijuana? ; Patient: Probably, but she's kind of a little used to it, I guess. ; Patient: Not used to it, but... ; Therapist: She's aware of it? ; Patient: Yeah, she's, yeah. ; Therapist: Do you have any history of mental health disorders? ; Patient: Just some anxiety. ; Therapist: Just anxiety? ; Therapist: How about medical problems? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No? ; Patient: No, they're the worst. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: Do you notice that when you stop using, you have physical symptoms or anxiety? ; Patient: Well, yeah, I get the anxiety when I stop, you know. ; Therapist: What's the longest you have stopped for? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: Just kidding. ; Patient: Yeah, I smoke every day, so a couple hours when I sleep. ; Therapist: When you sleep? ; Patient: A couple hours throughout the day, you know. ; Therapist: So, it's an everyday activity for you? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And it's been that way for a while? ; Patient: Yeah, yeah. ; Patient: For the past couple years, I would say. ; Therapist: Couple years? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Alright, Jackie, I know that your mom wants you to get counseling here. ; Therapist: Are you open to it? ; Patient: I don't really think I need it. ; Patient: But I'm sure she's, once I leave here, she's going to say you need to come back. ; Patient: So, we'll see, I guess. ; Therapist: You okay with giving it a try? ; Patient: Yeah, we'll see. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: I'll get you scheduled to see a counselor and we'll see where that goes from after your first appointment. ; Patient: Alright, I think. ; Therapist: Is that alright? ; Patient: Yeah, yeah. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: I want to thank you for telling me what's going on, for answering my questions. ; Therapist: It's been helpful. ; Patient: Alright, thank you.
summary: Patient Particulars : Namejackie; mother accompanied her. ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Psychiatrist ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms anxiety and substance use chief complaint 1 anxiety 2 not able to stop using marijuana 3 lack of interest in work and social activities ; History: Past history patient has a history of anxiety since her adolescent age. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior anxious; speech normal, mood  affect depressed, low in energy; thought organized; cognitive functions; normal, judgement and insight intact ; Psychotherapy Type: Nil ; Psychotherapy Technique : Nil ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: There are few issues discussed in the session 1substance use patient has been using marijuana daily for the past couple of years. He has a difficulty stopping his marijuana use. He feels that marijuana helps him to alleviate his anxiety, which he had struggled with since adolescence he is dismissive of the idea of cutting down or quitting marijuana use. His dependency on marijuana shields him to see any dangerous behavior associated with marijuana use. 2 family patient acknowledges that his mother does not approve his marijuana use. He wants to make his mother happy, although he was reluctant to stop using marijuana. 3motivation patient feels a lack of interest in seeking employment and social activities. 4anxiety patient experience anxiety when he stops using marijuana, as he had never stopped it for an extended period. 5 action plan psychiatrist advised him to see a counsellor. Though the patient is hesitant and skeptical about its necessity. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Anxiety and substance use ; Action Plan : Advised to see a counselor for further interventions. ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Hi, this is Dr. Grande. ; Therapist: I hope you find this video useful. ; Therapist: If that's the case, please like it and subscribe to my channel. ; Therapist: As always, thanks for watching. ; Therapist: Hello, Sophia. ; Therapist: How are you doing today? ; Patient: I'm good. How are you? ; Therapist: I'm doing well. ; Therapist: Thanks for asking. ; Therapist: I saw you last time a week ago, and I know you had some concerns with employment, working on employment. ; Therapist: But first, before we get into that, I wanted to check in to see how you're doing emotionally. ; Therapist: I know from last week, on a scale of 1 to 10, you said your depression was about 7. ; Therapist: How is it today? ; Patient: It's been up and down. ; Patient: I think today it's probably a 7 again, but, you know, I've been back down to a 9 lately. ; Patient: I guess maybe I feel a little better because I'm coming here and I know I get to talk about it a little bit. ; Patient: But I guess last time we were talking about me trying to get a job, a full-time job, and I think I just realized last week that it's really hard for me to work full-time. ; Patient: Right now, I'm doing the part-time thing with the work program, and they want us to do volunteer work in the afternoon if we haven't found a full-time job by a certain week. ; Patient: And I'm just, you know, just thinking about it. ; Patient: I just don't think I can do that. ; Patient: I just don't think I can work a full 8 hours every day. ; Patient: It's just too much. ; Therapist: So, you're having some concerns about full-time work and that level of energy you'd have to exert and that commitment. ; Therapist: Alright, so, would it be okay today if we kind of structured what we're going to do for this session? ; Therapist: So, if it's okay with you, I'd like to talk about that and get some more details about what's going on this week and your feelings surrounding that. ; Therapist: And, we touched on this a little bit in the last session, but I'd like to talk about your core beliefs, your central beliefs that might be contributing to some of these feelings of depression. ; Therapist: And then, for the last part, we'll work on, like we did before, some interventions to try to help you with what's going on at work and with your depressed mood. ; Therapist: We can make changes to this as needed. ; Therapist: I just want to start with an outline that we can have going in. ; Therapist: Does that make sense? ; Therapist: Anything you want to add or take away from that? ; Patient: No, I mean, that makes sense. ; Therapist: Okay, great. ; Therapist: So, tell me a little bit more about what's going on with the work. ; Patient: Well, I mean, I don't really know why it is. ; Patient: I know I'm always tired because I just have so much trouble sleeping. ; Patient: As I told you before, it's just, it doesn't matter how tired I am, I can't sleep. ; Patient: But it's just, I go in the morning, you know, 8 to noon, but then in the afternoon, it's just like, it's so hard to keep going on. ; Patient: It's just such a long amount of time and I just feel like, I don't know if I can really do it. ; Patient: Especially in the winter, you know, if you work 8 hours, by the time you get out of work, it's dark out and it just makes my depression so much worse. ; Therapist: So the latter part of the day is more of a struggle for you. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: The latter part of the work day. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So, getting up in the morning, getting to work on time, you do okay with that? ; Patient: It's hard, it's hard, but I feel like I'm better at that. ; Patient: I'm better at it. ; Patient: I'm already up anyway, so, you know, I know I gotta get up, I gotta do what I have to do. ; Therapist: So the work program you're in now, you work in the morning? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: What hours are you there? ; Patient: 8 to noon. ; Therapist: 8 to noon, okay. ; Therapist: And there's some work you have to do in the afternoon? ; Patient: Well, yeah, when, since I've been there for, uh, what is it, 8 weeks, and I haven't found a job yet, they want us to volunteer in the afternoon, and they find us our own place to volunteer, so that's good. ; Patient: I don't have to find that myself, but I guess they want to get you used to doing something for 8 hours a day and maybe have something to put on your resume. ; Patient: I guess when you have like a big gap in your resume, that doesn't look good either, so I'm also being able to say I worked here even though I didn't make money, but just thinking about it, it's so exhausting, and, you know, if I get out of the work program and I think if I had to go to, I can barely make it home, it's just so, all I want to do is go home. ; Therapist: Thinking about it's exhausting. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Can you tell me what type of thoughts you're having? ; Patient: I just don't think I can do it, like, I just don't think I'm the kind of person that can work 8 hours a day, and it just makes me feel like, what's the point? ; Patient: Like, I'm going to work 8 hours a day? ; Patient: I don't think I can. ; Therapist: It's just too many hours. ; Patient: Yeah.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name sophia, sex female ; Clinical Identifiers: Namee dr. Grande ; Past Session Information: Follow up session. ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptom depressed chief complaints 1 daily dysfunctionality 2 hopelessness 3 fatigue 4 struggles with full time job ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior fatigued; speech slow, mood  affect depressed, thought negative, judgement poor. , cognitive functions distorted. ; Psychotherapy Type: Cbt; mode individual. ; Psychotherapy Technique : Thought challenging reflective listening. ; Issues discussed in Current Session: 1 problem she has depressive symptoms fluctuate over time, with periods of improvement followed by relapses into higher levels of distress. Patient finds difficulty in maintaining full-time employment due to her struggles with fatigue, sleep difficulties, and depressive symptoms. Her daily functioning is also impacting. 2 cognition she has negative beliefs about her capabilities and self-worth, questioning her suitability for full-time employment and feels hopelessness about her future. She also has negative beliefs about her ability to work full-time may be influenced by societal stigma surrounding mental illness and perceptions of personal failure. 3 treatment plan therapist developed a treatment plan focused on addressing her employment-related concerns and depressive symptoms. This involves exploring underlying cognitive distortions, implementing coping strategies, and setting achievable goals to improve sophias overall functioning and quality of life. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Depression

dialogue: Therapist: Music ; Therapist: Hi Julie, how are you? ; Patient: Hi, I'm good thanks. ; Therapist: I'm Natasha, welcome to the service. ; Patient: Nice to meet you Natasha. ; Therapist: Nice to meet you too. ; Therapist: Do you want to have a seat? ; Therapist: Thank you for coming today. ; Therapist: How did you get here? ; Therapist: Did you travel by car or train? ; Therapist: How did you find the traffic? ; Patient: Yeah, I drove today and the traffic wasn't too bad actually. ; Patient: I got here in about 15 or 20 minutes. ; Therapist: Oh, that's good. ; Therapist: I was held up. ; Therapist: There was a big smash on the road so it took me a little bit longer. ; Therapist: So I'm glad that you were able to make it in. ; Patient: Thank you. ; Therapist: That's good. ; Therapist: Julie, I'm glad that you've made the effort to come in today. ; Therapist: How did you hear about our service? ; Patient: Well, I was talking to a friend and saying that I thought I might benefit from having a chat to somebody. ; Patient: And she told me that one of her friends had actually come to your service before and said that it was very good. ; Therapist: Excellent. ; Therapist: Well, thank you for coming in. ; Therapist: When you came in, you filled out some forms, which the girls have given me, which is great. ; Therapist: So that gives me a little bit of a background to where you're from and things of that nature. ; Therapist: And I just wanted to start by saying that our service is a counselling service for women. ; Therapist: And therefore you fit that category, which is really good. ; Therapist: Now, I just wanted to let you know that this is our first initial interview, I guess. ; Therapist: So today we will be just setting some, I'll be hearing some of your story. ; Therapist: And we'll work through a little bit of a process. ; Therapist: And then I'm sure we'll get the opportunity to meet again. ; Therapist: Is that okay? ; Patient: That sounds good. ; Patient: Thank you. ; Therapist: Excellent. ; Therapist: Now, within the pack that I've given you, or the girls at the front have given you, Julie, there is some information on how we keep your privacy and confidentiality. ; Therapist: So I just wanted to clarify that before we go into our session today. ; Therapist: So within the community centre here, we do, everything that you say to me today is kept within a confidential environment. ; Therapist: However, I am a mandatory reporter, which means that if you tell me something that I feel that you may be at risk, or you may be at risk of harm to yourself or hurting someone else. ; Therapist: If you have children, if they may be at risk, or if you're participating in illegal activity, I am a mandatory reporter, and I will need to let somebody know about that so that we can try to get you some help and assistance in dealing with that particular situation. ; Therapist: Is that okay? ; Patient: Yes, that's fine. ; Patient: I understand. ; Patient: Thank you. ; Therapist: Excellent. ; Therapist: So Julie, let's just start by, what has brought you here today? ; Patient: Well, my husband and I have been fighting on and off the last couple of months, and I'm just noticing that we can't seem to come to any agreement lately. ; Patient: I'm losing sleep, I'm feeling exhausted, and I'm at a point where I feel like I might like to leave the marriage. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: How long have you been married for? ; Patient: We've been together for eight years. ; Therapist: Oh, wow. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: That's a decent amount of time. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: And do you have any children? ; Patient: Yes, we have three children. ; Patient: I have two little ones that are under five, and we have a seven-year-old who's at school. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So you must be kept busy then? ; Patient: I'm always very busy. ; Patient: There's just always so much to do, and I'm really feeling very tired. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And the children today, whereabouts? ; Therapist: Who's looking after them today for you? ; Patient: Well, my two younger children today are being cared for by my mum, and my oldest one is at school today. ; Therapist: Excellent. ; Therapist: And where's your husband today? ; Patient: He's gone to work. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: That's good. ; Therapist: So it seems as if you're at a point in your marriage where you're feeling as if the marriage has changed a little bit, and it's focused, and you're kind of a little bit worried about what the future holds for yourself and your husband. ; Patient: I am. ; Patient: I feel now that I can't come to any solution with the problems, and he's been drinking a lot, and he always enjoyed a social drink when we first got married, but I'm noticing now that he's drinking more and more. ; Patient: He seems to be drinking most days of the week, and when he does drink, he's very, very difficult to talk to. ; Therapist: So the alcohol seems to be a problem. ; Therapist: Do you think that might be relating to the changing behaviour that you mentioned earlier? ; Patient: Yes, I do. ; Patient: I think that the drinking has definitely changed his behaviour significantly, and he's very unreasonable, and he has a very short fuse. ; Patient: He's very, very easy to make angry over the smallest of things. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: So that must be difficult for you and the children. ; Therapist: Have you noticed if the children have picked up on the change in his behaviour?
