; Patient: Well, he does have a very good relationship with the children, and he actively participates in their daily lives, and the children haven't mentioned anything to me, and they don't seem to have changed their behaviour in any way. ; Patient: The arguments don't tend to happen in front of the children either. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: Are the arguments something that... ; Therapist: Is it over more trivial things, or are there big, key things that you're kind of arguing with him about? ; Patient: Well, the arguments can start over something small. ; Patient: It can be just a simple argument over a task in the house. ; Patient: That can escalate into an argument about his family, or about my mother, or about money issues, and it just seems to escalate out of control. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: So, Julie, have you... ; Therapist: In terms of his drinking, I'm kind of just trying to ascertain maybe what has developed in your marriage that's taken you to the point that potentially, you know, you've come to see me today. ; Therapist: And it appears as if the drinking is really the focus of perhaps your feeling of, you know, wanting to disconnect from the marriage and feeling isolated within the marriage. ; Therapist: Would that be right? ; Patient: That's true. ; Patient: That's right. ; Patient: I think the drinking is my main issue with his behaviour, and I think the drinking is greatly contributing to the way that he's behaving towards me. ; Therapist: Have you spoken to him about this? ; Patient: I have. ; Patient: I've tried to talk to him about the drinking a couple of times, and he just gets very, very defensive with me. ; Therapist: Potentially he's not acknowledging then that he may have a drinking problem. ; Patient: That's true. ; Patient: That's correct. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: I can understand that this must be difficult for you, Julie, and I'm pleased that you've come here today to try to, you know, work through some of these issues. ; Therapist: Now, Julie, in terms of, I guess, your commitment to the marriage, in terms of where you want the marriage kind of to go, do you think that you have a strong base that you can potentially, you know, if we were able to help your husband with the drinking side of things, that your marriage itself might be strong enough to overcome and to move forward in the relationship? ; Therapist: Or, you know, tell me a little bit about what your thoughts are with that. ; Patient: Well, I'm hopeful that we could resolve the issues that we're having, and although at the moment I feel like I need to break away from him, if he was able to get the support that he needed and we were able to get the support together, I think that I would be willing to give the marriage an opportunity to continue and to resolve our issues. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: Julie, in terms of your own support, you mentioned your mum's looking after the children today. ; Therapist: Do you... Would you consider yourself to have friends and family that you... ; Therapist: You know, have you spoken to anyone else about this issue? ; Patient: Well, I have. ; Patient: I spoke to my girlfriend who recommended your service, and she's a very good support to me and to the children. ; Patient: And I have a very supportive family network as well. ; Patient: I have sisters who live in Sydney and also my mum, so they're all around me and they're very, very caring towards me. ; Therapist: Have any of those... ; Therapist: Any of the family or friends noticed a change in your husband's behaviour? ; Patient: Yes, they have. ; Patient: Actually, recently we had a social function and my brother did comment to me on how much alcohol my husband consumed at this social event. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: So this is impacting on you as well as the, I guess, the extended family as well. ; Therapist: Well, it's really good to hear that you do have a support network outside of this room, I guess, which is really, really good. ; Therapist: And it's great that you've got that, and I'd encourage you to use your mum and your family and friends, you know, as a gentle ear to listen, to, you know, to help you support yourself and the children through this phase or this stage in your relationship with your husband. ; Therapist: So, Julie, I'm just trying to think about potentially... ; Therapist: Just to recap, so you're saying that your relationship with your husband has changed from what it was. ; Therapist: You've been with him for about eight years and you have got three children. ; Therapist: You've mentioned that the primary changes his behaviour and that you believe that it probably is linked to his change in drinking habits. ; Patient: That's right. ; Therapist: And from what I understand, you've expressed that you would be happy to potentially work with him to resolve or seek help for him in relation to his drinking habits. ; Therapist: How old do you... Would that be right in what I've said there? ; Patient: Yes, that's right. ; Patient: That's correct. ; Patient: I would be happy to work on things if he was willing to do that as well. ; Therapist: Not knowing your husband, I guess I would probably need to ask you if... ; Therapist: Do you think that your husband would be receptive to maybe some marriage counselling or going to see somebody about his drinking? ; Therapist: Is he the type of person that might be receptive to that or...? ; Patient: I think he would. ; Patient: I think if I was able to approach him when he was calm and relaxed, I think that, yes, he probably would be receptive to that. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: That's positive. ; Therapist: That's really good, because some people that I meet, you know, the answer to that would be quite different. ; Therapist: So I think that's really positive for you, Julie. ; Therapist: I think what we probably need to look at now is maybe continuing this relationship between you and I. ; Therapist: So I'd love to see you again and meet up with you again. ; Therapist: But also, too, I think we probably need to explore that avenue of either getting you some marriage counselling or something along those lines, as well as seeing whether or not your husband might be interested in looking at some services to help him with his drinking issues that he has. ; Therapist: So if it's OK by you, what we might do from here is organise for us to meet again. ; Therapist: What time is best for you? ; Patient: Around this time is a good time for me, and any Thursday or Friday during the day is good. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: So what we'll do is we'll organise maybe for this time next week, and we'll meet again. ; Therapist: But in the meantime, I think we probably need to put you in contact with a relationships counsellor, and we'll try to get that side of things going. ; Therapist: And as a result of that, we'll be able to work out how receptive your husband is of potentially seeking some help for him as well. ; Therapist: I would like to just say that you mentioned that you probably would like to escape a little bit from it at the moment. ; Therapist: So perhaps I might be able to give you some advice or some information on some things that you might be able to do to take yourself away from that situation. ; Therapist: If you feel as if it's a little bit too much, maybe you might like to tap into your mum or your family and friends as well if you don't feel comfortable using some of the other services in the area. ; Therapist: How do you feel about that? ; Patient: That would be good. ; Patient: I'd appreciate that. ; Patient: Thank you. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: Well, thank you, Julie, for taking the time. ; Therapist: I'm really happy that you were able to come in today, and I look forward to going on this journey with you. ; Therapist: It's not a solution. ; Therapist: We can't fix everything here today. ; Therapist: It will be a process. ; Therapist: But hopefully together we can see a really positive outcome for you and your family. ; Patient: Thank you very much for talking to me today. ; Patient: That's been great. ; Patient: Thank you. ; Therapist: And I look forward to seeing you next week. ; Patient: Thank you very much.
summary: Patient Particulars : Sex female, marital status married ; Referral Information : Refrred by a friend ; Past Session Information: Follow up session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms husbands drinking problem and conflict chief complaints 1 lack of sleep 2 exhaustion ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior nad; speech low, mood  affect dull, thought nad, perception nad, cognitive functions fair, judgement and insight intact ; Psychotherapy Type: Dynamic supportive ; Psychotherapy Technique : Reflective listening supportive ; Issues discussed in Current Session: 1 problem patient has marital issues, contemplates of leaving the relationship. She has a problem with her husbands increasing alcohol consumption. Feels exhausted and loss of sleep due to the ongoing stress in her marriage. 2 family dynamics and children julie and her husband have three young children, and while the children have not shown signs of being affected by the arguments, their well-being is a concern for julie. 3 explored areas therapist explored the possibility of marriage counseling and seeking help for her husbands drinking problem. 4 advise therapist suggests organizing further sessions with julie and potentially involving a relationship counsellor. She also advises julie to use her support network to manage stress and take breaks from the situation when needed. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Not clear ; Action Plan : Suggest connecting to a marrige counselor ; Next session details: Next week

dialogue: Therapist: I just want to change gears again. ; Therapist: I want to talk about any potential trauma or abuse. ; Therapist: Are you comfortable with that topic? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: You mentioned earlier that there have been no occasions where you've had non-consensual sexual contact. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: What about physical abuse? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Nothing? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: How about emotional abuse? ; Patient: I don't know if it really counts as emotional abuse. ; Therapist: Well, tell me. ; Patient: My dad can be really intense about things and when you don't necessarily meet his expectations or bring home the grade he was expecting or if you're not as successful as your sister, he can be kind of harsh. ; Therapist: Can you give me an example of something he might have said? ; Patient: Why can't you ever be good enough? ; Patient: Or don't tell people you're my daughter or we go out in public. ; Patient: Or I wish we had two of your sisters and didn't have you. ; Patient: Or they also switched you at the hospital because you couldn't possibly be part of this family. ; Therapist: That sort of thing. ; Therapist: Fairly strong statements. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: What's that feel like when he says things like that? ; Patient: I guess now I'm used to it. ; Patient: Before it was terrible but you just kind of grow numb to stuff like that. ; Therapist: You feel like you're numb to it now? ; Patient: I've heard it enough that I know it's coming so you just kind of get used to it. ; Therapist: Still got to be a little painful. ; Patient: Yeah, it is. ; Patient: But you can only hear things so many times before it's like, all right, well, you're hearing the same stuff. ; Therapist: Has there ever been a change in your anxiety levels or your drinking when he would make comments like that? ; Patient: Sometimes. ; Patient: He got off on a tangent or whatever and got really insulting. ; Patient: Generally I would need to blow some steam and then go out with my friends or whatever. ; Patient: And I think that's when it started to get into the heavier drinking during that time because I would get anxious and stressed out and not thinking clearly. ; Therapist: Would you consider this a significant part of your history? ; Patient: I guess so. ; Therapist: It seems a little upsetting to you, to say the least. ; Patient: Yeah, it is. ; Therapist: Something maybe we can talk about later? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So I want to switch gears again a little bit. ; Therapist: What do you do for fun, for recreation? ; Patient: Other than partying? ; Patient: Well, okay, I'll put that in there. ; Therapist: Partying, that's one thing. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay, yeah, so other than that? ; Patient: I like to shop. ; Therapist: Like to shop? ; Patient: And I like to hike in the mountains. ; Therapist: Hiking? ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: When's the last time you were hiking? ; Patient: Two years ago. ; Patient: It's been a while. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: What else? ; Patient: I like being out with my friends. ; Patient: I like going to see live shows, like music stuff. ; Therapist: Okay, live shows? ; Therapist: Like theater or? ; Patient: Like music, like bands and stuff. ; Therapist: Okay, like music. ; Therapist: When's the last time you've done that? ; Patient: Probably a year. ; Therapist: A year. ; Therapist: Do you consider your life to be fun? ; Patient: Not really. ; Therapist: No? ; Therapist: Has it ever been? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: I can think of instances that were fun. ; Patient: I don't know if I would call my entire life situation fun. ; Therapist: When was the last instance that you could remember? ; Patient: Like when I go out with my friends and blow up steam. ; Patient: That's fun. ; Therapist: So these little moments here and there? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: But consistently, not the case? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: I want to switch gears again and ask you about any type of, or any time in your life when you may have had suicidal thoughts or behaviors. ; Therapist: Have you ever had a time when you contemplated suicide? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Never? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: And right now, it's not something you're thinking about? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: What do you think has protected you against having any type of suicidal thoughts? ; Patient: I want to succeed. ; Patient: I want to do more. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Now how about harm to others? ; Therapist: Have you thought about harming someone else? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Never? ; Therapist: What do you think protects you against that? ; Patient: I think I'm definitely a nice person. ; Therapist: Nice person? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Do you ever get angry? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Who doesn't? ; Therapist: Do you ever translate to anything where you had any desire to hurt anybody? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: So you deal with anger pretty well? ; Patient: I think so, yeah. ; Therapist: Okay, good. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: Again, some of these questions I'm aware of probably don't apply, but I want to go through them just in case. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Has there ever been a time where you heard or saw something that other people did not hear or see? ; Patient: Like a hallucination? ; Therapist: Like a hallucination? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: Other than perhaps some of the influence of alcohol, was there ever a time you felt out of touch with reality? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: How would you describe your judgment? ; Therapist: You make decisions. ; Patient: When I'm sober or when I am? ; Therapist: When you're sober. ; Patient: I think it's pretty good. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Good judgment? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I mean my anxiety plays into it a little bit. ; Patient: But I think generally it's good. ; Therapist: And when you're under the influence? ; Patient: Not as good. ; Therapist: Not as good? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Any questions for me so far? ; Patient: I don't think so. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: I've been asking a lot of questions, huh? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: I know. ; Therapist: We're almost through. ; Therapist: I appreciate you bearing with me. ; Therapist: I'd like to talk about your goals. ; Therapist: And I want to talk about on two levels. ; Therapist: So your goals in life, so these are like your general goals, and then your specific goals for your time with me. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So let's start with your general goals for your life. ; Therapist: What would you like? ; Patient: I want to get a job when I graduate. ; Patient: I want to be self-sufficient. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: I like to not be so worried all the time. ; Patient: I just be kind of more at ease in general. ; Patient: Maybe get my own apartment, live on my own, that type of thing. ; Therapist: Live on your own? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Any other life goals? ; Therapist: Any goals surrounding family or anything like that? ; Patient: Maybe figure out how to communicate better with them, I guess. ; Therapist: How about having your own family? ; Patient: Yeah, for sure. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: If you think of any other goals later on, or answers to these questions in any nature, feel free to just add that in, okay? ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So we can go back and edit this and add to it. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: How about goals for treatment? ; Patient: The drinking is one. ; Patient: The anxiety. ; Patient: Anxiety. ; Patient: Maybe try to graduate. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Graduating college? ; Patient: Yeah, getting through this last year. ; Therapist: What was that last part? ; Patient: Just getting through the last year. ; Therapist: Oh, yeah, surviving the last year of college. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Sure. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Drinking, anxiety, graduating college. ; Therapist: Anything else that would be a goal of therapy? ; Patient: I think those are the big ones I'm really concerned about. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So if you could meet those three goals, you feel like the counseling would have been successful? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So one last area I want to cover with you. ; Therapist: What do you consider your strengths that are going to help you to meet these goals and to meet your life goals? ; Patient: I think I'm ready now. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: You're ready? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: What else? ; Patient: I think I'm dedicated to getting better and dedicated to the future that I want. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: I'm a hard worker. ; Patient: I don't know that I would have made it this far if I wasn't, despite everything else. ; Therapist: Hard worker. ; Therapist: All right. ; Patient: I think I'm pretty understanding. ; Therapist: Understanding? ; Therapist: How about intelligent? ; Patient: I guess so, yeah. ; Therapist: You guess so? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: I never really thought about it. ; Therapist: Never thought about it. ; Therapist: How about social skills? ; Patient: I think I'm good at maintaining my friendships. ; Therapist: Do you think about the future a lot? ; Therapist: What are your futures going to be like? ; Patient: Sometimes. ; Therapist: Yeah? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And how does it look to you right now? ; Patient: Not the way I want it to look. ; Therapist: Yeah? ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Well, we'll try to work on that. ; Therapist: Okay? ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Are there any other questions that you want to ask me before we wrap up intake? ; Patient: I don't think so. ; Patient: That was a lot. ; Therapist: What's that? ; Therapist: That was a lot. ; Therapist: I don't think that was a lot. ; Patient: That was a lot. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: We did cover a lot. ; Therapist: As I mentioned, if you have any other questions about this at any time, we can come back and revisit this. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: We can add on to it. ; Therapist: And likely as we go through the sessions, I'll have even more questions. ; Therapist: Maybe not as intensely packaged all at one time like this was, but I'll have more questions for you. ; Therapist: And I appreciate you answering the questions. ; Therapist: I know some of them are probably a bit challenging to talk about. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So I'm going to finish this up and I'm going to get you scheduled to see it in about a week. ; Therapist: Does that work for you? ; Patient: Yeah, of course. ; Therapist: And we'll get started with the counseling sessions. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: All right, Sam. ; Patient: All right. ; Therapist: Thank you. ; Patient: Thanks.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name bruce ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Follow-up session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms substance use chief complaints 1 unable to quite substance use 2 low motivation 3 feels guilty to when avoids friends ; History: Nil ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior dull; speech low, mood  affect depressed, thought, perception, cognitive functions normal; judgement and insight judgement is affected little bit and insight is intact. ; Psychotherapy Type: Cbt; mode individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Supportive, cognitive restructuring, problem solving and reflective listening. ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: There are few issues discussed in the session 1 substance use patient discussed about the problem facing in reducing marijuana usage. He feels a correlation between not exercising and increased marijuana use, attributing it to seeking alternative activities. 2 guilt he feels difficulty in avoiding friends who use marijuana to prevent hurting them which lead to increase his substance usage. 3 alternative activities patient is hesitant in reconnecting with friends who dont smoke pot, but he accepts the advantages of engaging in healthier activities with them. He wants to have low-commitment pet like a snake or fish as an alternative to a dog. 4willing to change patient joined one meeting earlier but felt disconnected from the group. Although, he acknowledges the potential benefits of relating to others in similar situations and being part of a team. 5 action plan he is willing to try out two different support groups, motivated by the analogy of being part of a team. He rated the current session 8 out of 10 score which proves that he is motivated to bring change in himself. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Substance use disorder. ; Action Plan : Advised to indulge in healthier activities, navigating social relationships, considering alternative commitments, and to join a support group as a team where he can find people like him. ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: So Charles, it sounds like things have been going pretty well recently. ; Patient: Well, they've been going better. ; Patient: Yeah, they have. ; Patient: I did call a friend and we had lunch. ; Patient: I hadn't seen this guy in two or three years and it was good to see him. ; Patient: We contacted again and agreed we'd maybe have lunch from time to time. ; Patient: I got back in the kitchen. ; Patient: I made this pretty good soup. ; Patient: It's an asparagus potato soup. ; Therapist: That sounds great. ; Patient: It's really good. ; Patient: You chop up the asparagus and the potatoes and one small onion and boil them. ; Patient: Then use a blender to give it a real nice texture. ; Patient: Texture a little bit like split pea soup. ; Therapist: Sounds good. ; Patient: Without the split peas. ; Patient: I'm feeling some better. ; Therapist: That's good. ; Therapist: I'm proud of you for taking the initiative. ; Therapist: I know it's been difficult in the past. ; Therapist: You've really championed the things we've talked about. ; Therapist: I'm really proud of you for that. ; Therapist: One thing you did mention was the woodworking shop that we've talked about in the past. ; Therapist: How's that been? ; Patient: Well, that's still a mess. ; Patient: In fact, it's a big mess. ; Patient: It's such a mess that I really can't get in there and do any work. ; Patient: I haven't done that for some time. ; Patient: Every surface, I've got two workbenches and a bandsaw. ; Patient: Every surface has got tools and scraps of wood and plans. ; Patient: Paper plans or instructions. ; Patient: That sort of thing. ; Patient: I did not get into that. ; Therapist: As we've talked about in the past, it's really difficult to get started on some things that we've avoided for quite some time. ; Therapist: In the past, let's brainstorm and try to figure out how we can get some movement in the woodworking shops. ; Therapist: That sound good? ; Patient: Sure. ; Therapist: One thing we've discussed in the past, Charles, that's extremely important is what you're thinking about as you're going into the woodworking shop. ; Therapist: What are your thoughts when you are viewing or looking at the woodworking shop? ; Patient: When I stand there, I feel helpless. ; Patient: It's hopeless, it seems to me, to get it back in shape again. ; Therapist: Let's explore that. ; Therapist: What's the evidence that it's hopeless to do some work in the woodworking shop? ; Patient: Just the mess that it is. ; Patient: How disorganized. ; Patient: Sometimes if I need a tool to do something else in the house, I can't find the tool. ; Patient: I know it's in there, I just don't know where it is. ; Patient: A screwdriver, for example. ; Patient: It takes longer to find it than it's worth taking the time. ; Therapist: It sounds like you're saying it's disorganized and it's a mess. ; Therapist: How do you feel when you think about the woodworking shop that way? ; Patient: Hopeless, I think. ; Patient: I give up on it. ; Therapist: So it prevents you from actually getting things done is what you're saying? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Which makes sense because if I thought about it that way too, Charles, it would be hard for me to initiate any kind of action because if I view it as overwhelming, then I'm probably not going to do anything. ; Therapist: Which makes sense. ; Therapist: So what do you think is an alternative way to view the woodworking shop that would actually be helpful? ; Therapist: What's another way? ; Patient: Well, if I could get one workbench cleaned off, I would have some space to work on. ; Therapist: That's a really good start. ; Therapist: What would that lead to if you had some space to work on? ; Patient: I could make some things that I've been thinking about making for some time. ; Patient: I have the plans in my head. ; Patient: I've thought about a small medieval catapult for my grandson. ; Patient: Maybe a boomerang made out of really nice laminated wood. ; Therapist: That would be cool. ; Patient: So I could get one or both of those built perhaps. ; Therapist: What would that lead to if you got those things built? ; Therapist: Would you have to do anything with those things? ; Patient: Well, if I built those, I would have to get in the car and drive four hours to where my grandkids are and to give them the toys and show them how it works. ; Patient: I'd have to show them how to throw the boomerang. ; Patient: I would spend time with them. ; Therapist: So it sounds like there's a lot of benefit then to clearing out a bench and moving tools which would lead to you getting things done, especially things that would involve your grandkids. ; Therapist: So you'd be able to see them and spend time with them. ; Therapist: You'd feel better about going to do that, but you'd also feel better about the woodworking shop in general. ; Therapist: Is that basically what you're saying? ; Patient: I would, yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Sure. ; Therapist: But as we've talked about in the past, Charles, I know that it still takes steps to get there. ; Therapist: That wouldn't change overnight. ; Therapist: So I think one useful strategy is for you and I to work on a step-by-step plan that would get us to the place of you being able to drive four hours to see your grandkids. ; Therapist: So how about we talk about the first step, which sounds like would be to just move things off one bench. ; Therapist: Does that sound right? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: One, I'd have to start by moving one thing off of that bench. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Which means I'd have to have a place for it to go. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: And once I did that, I could move a second thing off. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So that sounds great. ; Patient: Though sometimes when I think about moving one thing off and it has to have a place to go, I feel like maybe I should build something to make, give it a place to go. ; Patient: And that's another problem. ; Patient: The paper is no problem. ; Patient: I've got a shelf with some woodworking books on it and I could put the plans and the instructions on the shelf. ; Patient: I could pick one place in the shop where I'm going to put the wood scraps. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So let's talk about that then. ; Therapist: Let's sketch out what each day would look like so that we won't feel overwhelmed like we did in the past. ; Therapist: So let's talk about each day and how we would sketch out each day. ; Therapist: Does that sound good? ; Therapist: Sure.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name charles; sex male ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Follow up session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Feelings of hopelessness  helplessness ; History: Nil ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behavior patient was cordial and rapport could be established; mood calm; affect broad ; Psychotherapy Type: Type cbt; mode individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Activity scheduling ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patient reported progress as he was now able to socialise better and also spent some time cooking which made him happy. He was unable to get back to his woodworking shop and he had been avoiding it from some time. This makes him feel helpless, hopeless and overwhelmed. . ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Nil ; Action Plan : Adhere to activity scheduling ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: People your age, it's very different for this generation who they do have a lot of it figured out. ; Therapist: Oh So if I asked you how would you describe yourself and it can be on any dimensions? ; Therapist: How would you describe yourself? ; Patient: I have described myself Are you asking us fires ; Therapist: Any any way that's important to you about knowing who you are ; Patient: I would say I'm a biracial woman And I'm in my 20s that's about it ; Therapist: mm-hmm ; Patient: Nothing to be suspect specific or anything, ; Therapist: but it seems like those three pieces being biracial being a woman and Age-wise those are pieces of just locating yourself yourself in space and time at this point in time ; Patient: You can say so ; Therapist: yeah, what How long have you thought of yourself as a biracial woman ; Patient: well To be honest ; Patient: Miss me prior like third grade. ; Patient: I knew that I was different If I would say that ; Therapist: how'd you know that ? ; Patient: oh ,when my dad came to pick up my report card from school ; Therapist: mm-hmm ; Patient: and Everyone was looking and you know pointing and everything it wasn't a problem For the students it was a problem for the faculty and the teachers ; Therapist: Were you treated differently after that? ; Patient: Yes ; Therapist: Okay, maybe it would be good for me. ; Therapist: Just to stop and ask you what what is your ethnic and racial background? ; Patient: My father's Latino descent my mother's african-american ; Therapist: okay ; Therapist: So after that encounter that's third grade your dad goes He's Latino goes to pick up your report card and to pick up you up How are you treated differently after that ? ; Patient: Well, The next day I went to school. ; Patient: I had a note and back the next day put to your shirt so When I got home of course my mother at the note. ; Patient: They weren't a parent-teacher conference and when we got there I was actually the room and it what I got the just over there told my parents how Me being a mixed-race or by having two different parents at the time could be a bad thing for me Yeah, because I went to a predominantly african-american school The teacher would be something sort of like You know Apples and oranges don't mix you know Not black black history and You know you had to a chance to pick to who you want to be I pick Harriet Tubman No, and it was like you're not black enough to be her you might come around and they had pictures on the wall and look at her She's black You know what are you gonna put black paint on your face, and you don't know it's like to be a slave And things like that so it became up. ; Patient: It wasn't hurting it was I didn't understand right ; Therapist: and you sure none of it hurt at that point ; Patient: I don't think it was a hurt I just didn't understand for a pity party no ; Therapist: But at times that it just sort of get to you really yours because there's an age where the kids get Sort of meaner about the teasing and aren't really even thinking ; Patient: Mmm high school the same thing came up participate in a secret de mayo event and The african-american students had a problem with it so Latino students had a problem with it, and then I'm caught in the middle This is somebody you do. ; Therapist: Do you think she's good? ; Therapist: Yes, I do I think she's emotionally guarded I Think she'll speak to that later in the session You know so it says I think there have been injuries Some of which I'm gonna guess really are related to the the race pieces that she's Experienced where she has felt judged under scrutiny, and it just keeps repeating herself, and it's separate from comportment Accomplishments and so there is a guardedness and there is a sensitivity and the guardedness is her way I think of protecting some of her vulnerability okay.
summary: Patient Particulars : Sex female, age 20s ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms identity crisis chief complaints 1 racial discrimination 2 social pressure 3 vulnerability ; History: Family history fathers latino descent and mother african american. ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior confused; speech slow, mood  affect low, thought negative, perception poor, judgement poor and insight intact ; Psychotherapy Type: Dynamic supportive analytical ; Psychotherapy Technique : Reflective listeningthought challenginganalytical. ; Issues discussed in Current Session: 1 identity crisis patient is feeling difficulty grappling with her identity as a biracial woman. It began in childhood when she first became aware of being different from her peers, faced discrimination and judgment based on her racial background in school and community. 2 social pressure pressured to conform to certain racial stereotypes or expectations for which she had to guard herself. This led her feeling of not fitting in or being misunderstood. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Mild depression

dialogue: Therapist: Hey Lisa, How are you doing today? ; Patient: Good, how are you? ; Therapist: I'm doing well, thanks for asking. ; Therapist: How has the anxiety been going? ; Patient: Since last session it seems to be in check. ; Patient: Nothing really major has been going on with it. ; Patient: I think I'm getting to a point where it's under control. ; Therapist: It's subsided a bit? ; Patient: Yes. ; Patient: That's good. ; Therapist: How has things been going at work lately? ; Patient: Work is a little bit of a different story. ; Patient: We have our daily meetings. ; Patient: I actually had to pull one of my coworkers aside because I feel like they undermine me all the time. ; Patient: They don't give me the respect that I deserve. ; Patient: I took her outside after the meeting and laid into her about it. ; Patient: Afterwards, the next day, because we have these meetings every day, she came back and came at me again. ; Patient: But it was worse, even after talking to her. ; Therapist: So talking to her, that didn't improve your situation? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: So , You have these daily meetings. ; Therapist: You mentioned that she's not showing you respect and that you deserve respect. ; Therapist: Something to that effect. ; Therapist: Tell me about that belief. ; Therapist: Remember we talked about ABC before activating events and beliefs and consequences in REBT. ; Therapist: Tell me about that belief. ; Patient: I just feel that I do a good job and I deserve to be respected by my coworkers. ; Therapist: Are there levels of respect? ; Therapist: Is there a certain level of respect that you demand or need? ; Patient: I don't know if there's a certain level, but I feel just like I deserve it. ; Therapist: What did she do that convinced you that she wasn't meeting that level of respect? ; Patient: She was shooting down my ideas and just kind of made me feel like a fool, basically. ; Patient: So I just didn't understand. ; Therapist: So she had criticisms of your ideas. ; Therapist: A few of them, it sounds like. ; Therapist: That would upset anybody. ; Therapist: But were those criticisms unusual given the tone of these meetings? ; Therapist: Is this a type of meeting where people criticize each other or attempt to in a constructive way? ; Patient: I mean, I guess. ; Therapist: Have you criticized other coworkers? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So do you think that her criticism was within normal limits, like within what you've kind of seen there regularly? ; Patient: I mean, now that you point it out, I mean, I guess I can view it in that way, that it wasn't... ; Therapist: It wasn't too far out of line the first time, right? ; Therapist: But then after you talked to her, you said that it got worse. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: It just felt like she was purposely trying to nitpick, if you will. ; Therapist: Trying to get at you a little bit. ; Therapist: So maybe the second time around, correct me if I'm wrong, maybe she was actively showing you disrespect just because of what you had done, because you came after her and... Or was that within normal limits too? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: I mean, I guess I may have gone at her a little harshly, but I felt at the time that it was reasonable. ; Therapist: At the time when you were... ; Patient: When I was talking to her outside of the meeting. ; Therapist: So you felt that she was a bit harsh, you talked to her about it, but then she's become more harsh. ; Therapist: So where do you stand with her now, like with the meetings and such? ; Patient: Well, I've just been trying not to talk to her. ; Patient: And obviously in a work situation, it doesn't really help. ; Therapist: That's not convenient. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: It might not help. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So let's work this through using the ABC model that we used for the anxiety that you had before. ; Therapist: That was troublesome to you before. ; Therapist: What would the activating event be here in this situation? ; Patient: So I guess the confrontation I had with her. ; Therapist: Well, you could look at that as an activating event. ; Therapist: Another way to look at it is her criticism of you could have been the activating event. ; Therapist: And your conversation with her could have been the consequence. ; Therapist: But these things are cyclical. ; Therapist: So it's sometimes hard to know where to cut in and put the A and the B and the C. ; Therapist: But let's just work it through with the activating event being what she said. ; Therapist: Let's just try that and see how that works out. ; Therapist: Would that be reasonable? ; Therapist: That could have been kind of what started it, was this criticism. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So then what would the belief... ; Therapist: So all activating events are filtered through our belief system. ; Therapist: So what would your beliefs be in that scenario? ; Patient: So she criticized me and I felt disrespected. ; Therapist: That's a feeling. ; Patient: And I feel, or my belief is that I deserve respect. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: And that came first. ; Therapist: So you have the activating event, which is her criticism, processed through your belief, which is that you must have respect, you deserve respect. ; Therapist: You mentioned the feeling. ; Therapist: So tell me about the feelings. ; Patient: So that being upset and disrespected and, you know, aggravation. ; Therapist: It was aggravation. ; Therapist: Frustration. ; Therapist: So that would be one of the consequences of how you processed her behavior. ; Therapist: Does that make sense? ; Therapist: The feeling, the frustration feeling, would be one of the consequences, like an ABC. ; Therapist: So you have the activating event, she criticizes you, your belief is that you deserve respect, and that clearly she violated that belief. ; Therapist: She didn't show you the respect that you deserved according to your belief system. ; Therapist: And then one of the consequences, therefore, was this feeling of frustration. ; Therapist: Were there any other consequences? ; Patient: Well, if we go forward, it's the kind of disarray, or the tension, I guess, now in the office. ; Therapist: So that's definitely a consequence. ; Therapist: I'm thinking there's an intermediate consequence, though. ; Therapist: So you had that feeling of frustration, and what's the next thing you did after that meeting was over? ; Patient: Oh, well, I confronted her. ; Therapist: You confronted her. ; Therapist: So you have kind of those two consequences. ; Therapist: And that confrontation, it would appear, has led her to kind of come on more strongly with her criticisms, which is another activating event. ; Therapist: You could also think of it as a consequence, but like I said, this is cyclical. ; Therapist: So you see how the A and the B and the C, that paradigm, can fit in to what happened here at work for you. ; Therapist: Does that make some sense? ; Patient: It does. ; Patient: Yeah, and I mean, when you put it that way, and then you say it's cyclical, then you just, I can visualize it going around like a carousel. ; Therapist: Sure, exactly. ; Therapist: So it helps you to kind of see what caused what, and maybe what could have been changed, or could be changed in the future, right? ; Therapist: Because we can't go back and change that, but we can work on the future. ; Therapist: So her criticism of you, there's no direct way to change that. ; Therapist: The consequence is a consequence. ; Therapist: So that leaves the belief system, which is the deserving respect. ; Therapist: One of the things we try to do in REBT is help people move from rigid thinking to more flexible thinking. ; Therapist: So kind of a rigid belief system would be, and not that you said it in this way, but I demand and deserve respect. ; Therapist: Right? ; Therapist: At this particular level, and people aren't meeting it. ; Therapist: Would you say that's a fair? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Maybe a more flexible way of thinking would be that you'd like respect, right? ; Therapist: Respect's good, respect's healthy in work environments, certainly, but if you don't get it, you can still function. ; Therapist: And it's tough for you. ; Therapist: I can see that's tough. ; Therapist: Tell me about that. ; Patient: I mean, I understand what you're saying. ; Patient: I get it. ; Patient: I guess it's just kind of like the anxiety, with the anxiety we worked on. ; Patient: It's just getting there. ; Therapist: Are you willing to think of and challenge your beliefs in this instance? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: It's tough though. ; Therapist: As you mentioned, with the anxiety, it's just tough. ; Therapist: How long have you had this belief, kind of this mentality of, I deserve respect? ; Patient: Oh, gosh. ; Patient: Since I was like a teenager. ; Patient: So, a long time. ; Therapist: This has been a relatively persistent part of your life, this belief system. ; Therapist: So, changing it's going to be work. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So, if you can apply a different philosophy, apply more flexible thinking the next time you're in a meeting. ; Therapist: She still criticizes you in the meetings? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So, if you filtered that through a belief system, now your first urge might be, I would think, to be, I'm being disrespected again, right? ; Therapist: It probably comes on that way. ; Therapist: You kind of feel it. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: It starts in my stomach and then goes all the way up. ; Therapist: So, that'll be your first physiological reaction, right? ; Therapist: An emotional reaction. ; Therapist: But if you can kind of pause that moment and apply more flexible thinking, like I talked about, which is, I'd like respect, but I can survive and function without it. ; Therapist: At some level, I can accept that I'm not going to get it all the time. ; Therapist: Are there other areas of your life where you do get respect? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: For my friends and my family, I feel like they give me, it's actually mutual respect. ; Patient: They give me respect, I give them respect. ; Therapist: So, that need, if that's a need, that's being met, right? ; Therapist: Maybe not by this one coworker, right? ; Therapist: So, maybe she's being disrespectful. ; Therapist: Or, as we talked about before, maybe that's the way you're interpreting it and she never really intended to be disrespectful because criticism is part of what happens in those meetings. ; Patient: True. ; Therapist: So, you don't, you know, I don't really know which is which and you may not either at this point. ; Therapist: So, what do you think would happen if you could take that criticism the next time it occurs and run it through that more flexible belief system? ; Therapist: What would be the consequences? ; Patient: Well, I think over time, if I learned to do that, first starting with inside of me, I wouldn't get that initial punch to the gut. ; Patient: And I wouldn't have the urge to lash out at her. ; Patient: Especially if it is trying to be constructive criticism resulting in a situation where there's that tension in our office. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: So, if you could filter through that belief system and it would help if it was constructive, that would help you filter it through that, to be at that belief system. ; Therapist: Functioning in the office would improve for you. ; Therapist: Stress would be reduced for you. ; Therapist: Ultimately. ; Therapist: Is there a way to kind of patch things up with this co-worker to maybe explain that you understand a little more about her criticisms and maybe just try to smooth things over? ; Patient: I think I'd be able to do that. ; Patient: I think I'd be able to approach her and maybe ask her if she'd want to get coffee or something and maybe sit down and kind of talk it over with her. ; Patient: Maybe I misunderstood her in the first meeting and she really didn't mean to undermine me, as I said. ; Patient: And then go from there. ; Therapist: So, I think a good way of gathering the information, meaning having a discussion with her, would be helpful because you may find that you really see things alike and it was just a disagreement in terms of her criticism and the way you interpret it. ; Therapist: Or she may have been trying to be critical and you'll know that too.You really can,t control someone else's behaviour but it would give you an idea of maybe what her intentions were and how you can go forward to repair that relationship so that it functions. Yeah? ; Therapist: So, I think it's a good way to sort out your own. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I certainly don't want our upper management to get involved and there be a bigger issue. ; Therapist: You don't want them to have to come and sort that out. ; Therapist: You can sort out your own. ; Therapist: And that would be a good application of coping skills and flexible thinking. ; Therapist: So, is that something you feel like you can try over the course of the next week? ; Patient: I will definitely try. ; Therapist: So, really our plan moving forward has a couple parts. ; Therapist: So, one would be spoon things over in a sense, discussing this with her, letting her know you're aware of what's going on and you want to try to resolve it. ; Therapist: And the second part would be trying to move a little bit away from the rigid, you know, I deserve respect to, I would like respect but I'll function adequately without respect from everyone. ; Therapist: I know that's tough. ; Therapist: That's going to be the challenge. ; Therapist: But this will be, this will give us good information and give you some practice. ; Therapist: Does it all make sense to you? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: It's pretty clear. ; Patient: You explained it really well. ; Therapist: Thank you. ; Therapist: So, let's work on those two, those two elements. ; Therapist: And next time you come in, we'll check in on those two and make any needed modifications to our strategy and we'll kind of move forward from there. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: That sound good? ; Patient: Sounds great. ; Therapist: Thanks Lisa. ; Patient: Thanks.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name alisa; sex- female ; Clinical Identifiers: Outpatient ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Follow up ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Anxiety ; History: Patient had been facing issues of overthinking about not getting respected from others since teenage years. She has been jumping to the conclusion frequently. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: General behavior- rapport could be established, patient was cooperative; affect- anxious; thought- content reflects overthinking ; Psychotherapy Type: Type cognitive behavioral therapy; mode individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Antecedent, behavior, consequence abc framework ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patient was extremely disturbed by one of her co-workers behaviour. She had tried to talk about it and she came back at her which made her anxiety worse. Since teenage she has had a belief system that others dont respect her the way she deserves and jumps to this conclusion. ; Reflections by the therapist: She is receptive of the therapy. She is able to understand this pattern and has been learning to apply the abc framework and alternate actions she can take to break this pattern. ; Action Plan : Target irrational thoughts and use alternate ways to react in situations which were earlier triggering. ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Hi, how are you doing today? ; Patient: I'm okay. ; Patient: How are you, Dr. Granday? ; Therapist: Not bad. ; Therapist: Thanks for asking. ; Therapist: What's been going on? ; Patient: There's not really a lot of change on the drug front. ; Patient: You know, the Adderall, I'm really struggling. ; Therapist: Still struggling with the Adderall? ; Patient: Yeah I'm not sure what to do because I know that, I mean, I'm having such a hard time with it, but when I don't have it, I'm just not functioning. ; Patient: I'm not able to get as much accomplished. ; Therapist: Alright, so, go ahead. ; Patient: Well, it's like it's always there too. ; Therapist: It's always available to you. ; Patient: It's always available, yeah, or so much of the time. ; Therapist: Alright, so you're having some mixed feelings about it though, I'm sensing. ; Patient: Yeah, yeah, like I know I want to stop, I think. ; Therapist: You think you want to stop? ; Patient: Yeah, no, I do. ; Therapist: You do? ; Patient: Oh my God, see, I feel crazy, but I know it would be good if I didn't have it in my life. ; Therapist: But at the same time, it is in your life. ; Patient: And I don't know how to get out of that. ; Patient: I mean, the one thing, if I didn't live with my roommate, that would be one thing. ; Patient: I wouldn't be in the apartment all the time. ; Therapist: So, you find you have easier access to the Adderall when you're in the house or apartment with your roommate? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So, if you physically weren't there, like with your roommate in that apartment? ; Patient: Yeah, like if I was, oh my God, living at home with my parents again, or even living with somebody else, I guess. ; Patient: Oh my God, don't move. ; Patient: What a hassle, but that's, I mean, that's the problem. ; Patient: It's just there. ; Patient: It's accessible. ; Therapist: So, you're kind of, it sounds like you're recognizing that maybe you don't have the willpower to stop taking the drug when it's right there in front of you. ; Patient: Maybe you're right. ; Patient: That's good. ; Patient: Because before I didn't really want to stop. ; Patient: And sometimes I want to stop. ; Patient: My mind will go back and forth. ; Patient: But for the most part, I would like to be without it. ; Patient: I really don't want to deal with this anymore. ; Therapist: So, mostly, so there's still some feelings where you want to use it, but mostly you would like to stop. ; Patient: Well, it makes it so easy to get stuff done. ; Patient: I mean, I just take a couple and boom, boom, boom. ; Patient: I mean. ; Therapist: So, there's some advantages for you. ; Patient: Yeah, definitely. ; Patient: Definitely. ; Patient: And I'm so used to it, too. ; Patient: It's just comfortable. ; Therapist: It's comfortable and it allows you to be productive. ; Therapist: Are there any downsides to it? ; Patient: Well, yeah. ; Patient: When I don't have it, the crash, it's like a really bad crash. ; Patient: I'm not productive. ; Patient: You know, it's, and it's gotten worse than it used to be. ; Therapist: So, it's painful. ; Patient: Like, I need it. ; Patient: It's painful. ; Patient: Definitely. ; Patient: Definitely. ; Patient: It feels like a trap. ; Patient: And I want out. ; Therapist: And one of the ideas you were having was, it sounded like potentially, was moving out. ; Therapist: Moving out of the apartment. ; Therapist: Because then you wouldn't have access to the, you wouldn't have access to the Adderall anymore. ; Therapist: Or it would be harder to get. ; Patient: Oh my God. ; Patient: Like, sometimes it's really weird. ; Patient: Sometimes it feels like that's a good idea and then sometimes I'm like, no, no. ; Patient: I don't want to be, you know, kind of cut off from it. ; Patient: But, I think I'm ready. ; Therapist: You think you're ready for that? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And that moving out, you really see is what you would need to do. ; Therapist: Because stopping while living there is too difficult. ; Patient: Oh my God. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah, I think you're right. ; Therapist: I remember before you've tried to stop while living there a few times, right? ; Therapist: Or the last few months. ; Therapist: And with your roommate having it, with your roommate being the one that gives it to you, it just appears the temptation is so great for you. ; Patient: Yeah, she really doesn't get it. ; Patient: She doesn't understand, like, what a problem this is for me. ; Patient: She's definitely not supporting me or anything like that. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: God, maybe it would be better. ; Therapist: Well, are there any disadvantages to living with your parents? ; Patient: Living with my parents at my age, it just feels like a little bit humiliating, a lot humiliating. ; Therapist: Okay, so humiliation would be one? ; Patient: Yeah, and just this feeling of failure, embarrassment. ; Patient: And then my mom just is in my business, you know. ; Therapist: So there's some clear disadvantages to moving into parents. ; Therapist: Any advantages other than the obvious, it would sever you from the adderall? ; Patient: My mom would do my laundry, fully stocked fridge. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah, my dad will fill my gas tank up. ; Therapist: Are these things that happened before when you used to live there? ; Patient: Yeah, yeah, not so bad. ; Therapist: So there's some disadvantages to this plan, but there's some advantages and there's a key advantage of being cut off from the adderall. ; Patient: Yeah, and it wouldn't necessarily have to be the rest of my life either. ; Therapist: Hmm. ; Patient: Just for now, just to get me out of that apartment with the drug, right? ; Therapist: That would separate you from the drug and you could potentially move out later on. ; Patient: Oh my God, do I want to? ; Patient: I mean, that's just it. ; Patient: It sounds really good until I really think about it. ; Therapist: So when you really think about it, what comes to mind? ; Patient: Oh, like I start to shake, like that feeling of, you know, when you really want something, you really want something and you can't get to it. ; Patient: And it's just that desperation that, and like right now, I know that I'm living there, it could be my choice. ; Patient: I could take it or I could not take it, you know, but at least when I want it, it's there. ; Patient: If I move out, I'm like making that decision for myself. ; Therapist: That's right, you would be. ; Patient: I don't know. ; Therapist: Is this tough? ; Therapist: Well, before it seemed like you were really more on the side of making this change than not. ; Therapist: But clearly there's still some things you want to consider. ; Patient: No, you know, you're right though. ; Patient: I want out. ; Patient: And it's not really a choice when I'm there. ; Patient: Like I say I have the choice, yes or no, but the choice is always yes. ; Therapist: You always end up using the Adderall. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So, let me make sure I understand the situation overall. ; Therapist: You live with your roommate, she has Adderall, when she makes it available to you, you use it. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: You've tried to stop that behavior, but that's just not working for you. ; Patient: Yeah, yeah, that's so clear. ; Patient: And I don't want to be using it. ; Therapist: You don't want to be using it, but yet you are, especially because the proximity. ; Therapist: Because you're right there and she has it and it's just tough for you to stop that behavior. ; Therapist: There's another possible decision, which is moving back home, which has some disadvantages and advantages. ; Patient: Yeah, that's true. ; Patient: God, it would be nice having that fully stocked fridge. ; Therapist: So, there's an upside to it that would be beyond just not using the drug, which in itself would be a big victory for you. ; Patient: Yeah, and my mom would be there to talk to, yeah. ; Therapist: So, let's do this. ; Therapist: It seems like that's the direction you're moving, right? ; Patient: Okay, yeah. ; Therapist: No pun intended with the word moving, but you're thinking that might be a better way to go. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So, for the next session, let's plan out, and this wouldn't necessarily be doing anything, let's plan out the steps that you'd have to put in place to move back home. ; Therapist: Talking to your parents, whatever financial arrangement you have with your roommate, getting all your stuff out, the logistics of moving, let's just go through the steps. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And try to get a firm plan together. ; Therapist: And of course you can always reevaluate and change your mind. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Right, but all we're doing at this point is just planning and seeing how it would look. ; Patient: This is kind of exciting. ; Patient: Is it exciting? ; Patient: Yeah, it definitely is. ; Patient: I can do that. ; Therapist: Good. ; Therapist: So, I will see you next week. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And we'll pick up right where we left off, and we'll start with the planning, and we'll see what happens with that. ; Patient: Cool. ; Patient: All right. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Thanks, Anne. ; Patient: Sure.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name ann; sex female marital staus unmarried ; Clinical Identifiers: Setting opd ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Name dr grande ; Past Session Information: Nil ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Sense of compulsion to take the drug na 2. Difficulties in controlling substance taking behavior na ; History: Present history patient has been living in an apartment with her friend. She feels that her roommate creates a pressure on her to take the drug and her she herself also feels a lack of willpower to stop oneself; substance use history she has been consuming a drug, adderall. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: General behavior rapport could be established and patient was cooperative; mood euthymic; affect broad; insight grade 5. ; Psychotherapy Type: Type solution focussed brief therapy; mode individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Presupposing change questions, exception questions ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patient discussed her struggle to leave the drug she has been misusing. She feels productive with it and completely opposite otherwise if not. ; Reflections by the therapist: Patient was a somewhere unsure of whether she actually wants to quit taking drugs or not. After asking a few questions, it was established that she has an inclination towards quitting. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Provisional diagnosis f15. 2 dependence syndrome ; Action Plan : To plan steps to move out from the apartment and move in with parents until she completely quits consuming adderall. ; Next session details: After 1 week.

dialogue: Therapist: All right, Liz, how are you? ; Patient: Good. ; Therapist: Good, it's good to see you. ; Therapist: I was just looking at your, the binge record that we've been keeping weekly and I noticed that last week you were at five kind of episodes of binge eating and this week you were down to three. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah, so awesome. ; Therapist: So what, help me understand what's been going on this week. ; Therapist: What was involved with the change? ; Patient: Yeah, I mean, good week with the roommate. ; Patient: I had a good conversation with her about like what times are good for boyfriend to be over and kind of giving her better heads up on when I really need silence. ; Therapist: Well, terrific. ; Therapist: So what was, what specifically, I mean, I know we've talked a lot about that, but what specifically did you say to her or how did you bring it up? ; Patient: I was just telling her that like my studies are really important and I understand like it's also important that she has time with her boyfriend, but that I would really appreciate that this is both our space and that there are times when like we really need to respect each other's space and yeah, she responded really well. ; Patient: She was like, just really give me a good heads up before you, yeah. ; Patient: And that we kind of decided like certain times are more appropriate for them to have the living room and not. ; Therapist: Right, right. ; Therapist: Yeah, because I think that's really similar. ; Therapist: I know we kind of talked about that and as I, you know, you remember like a few sessions ago, I was kind of wondering whether or not she really got it in terms of what you were feeling because it seems like one of the ways that you've, you know, we talked about that before in terms of like, you know, when we were first starting that oftentimes one of the ways that you manage your feelings is you kind of, you think you are letting people know what you're feeling, but it doesn't really come out. ; Therapist: And I know that it was something that you and I had to really like, you know, kind of work out, but it sounds like that you were able to talk with her and that she heard you and as I kind of thought that she was actually really responsive in a very positive way. ; Patient: I think being a little more direct was helpful. ; Therapist: It's really nice. ; Therapist: It's really nice. ; Therapist: Well, I think too, you've been able to do that more with me and I feel like that, I feel like that's been really helpful. ; Therapist: I know they've been kind of pushing you on that and that's been hard, but I feel like it's been really nice because I feel like it's really been helpful with your relationship with Kathy. ; Therapist: So that's fantastic. ; Therapist: And also, you know, again, I know that I've keep, you know, like saying this over and over again, but you know, as you've worked on these things, it's been really notable that it's really had a nice and positive effect on your eating because it seems like it's really, you've really seen a lot of real nice improvements. ; Therapist: So awesome. ; Therapist: Anything else that, you know, so you had a really good conversation with Kathy, anything else going on this week? ; Patient: Yeah, I got to spend some time with Brooke. ; Therapist: Oh nice. ; Patient: I went home for two days and was with my mom and Brooke. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So is she still six or did she have a birthday recently? ; Patient: She's almost seven. ; Therapist: Oh, that's great. ; Therapist: Almost seven. ; Therapist: Great. ; Therapist: Any plans for birthday for her or what do you think she's going to do? ; Patient: She's really into frozen. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Anything frozen is good. ; Patient: Anything frozen is good. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: That sounds terrific. ; Therapist: And so then you spent some time with her. ; Therapist: I'm going to ask you a little bit more about your mom and how that felt positive for you. ; Therapist: Did you, when you were there, did you have any opportunity to visit with your mom or how did that go? ; Patient: I feel like my mom was around. ; Patient: Like we kind of all spent time together and like she asked about school and I was able to like tell her a little more about school and how things are going. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: We didn't really get like one on one time. ; Therapist: How did that feel for you in terms of like, you know, for her, I know that you talked about not really liking that she all of a sudden is deciding now that she wants to really be kind of like, you know, the good mother and kind of like be involved in your life. ; Therapist: But how is it for her to kind of like want to know how things have been going for you? ; Patient: I mean, I've kind of like allowed myself to tell her, I guess, how things have been going. ; Patient: But I mean, like to an extent, like it was like with Brooke and whatnot, like we didn't really sit down just us two together. ; Therapist: So kind of what we had discussed kind of that you've been, you've like, you've been allowing yourself to be more connected with her, but you're still kind of keeping up, keeping a little bit of a boundary. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Well, I'm sure that would be really hard to trust her after everything that's gone on, you know, with, you know, kind of the infidelity issue with your dad, or at least it's just, you know, kind of like the wondering about that. ; Therapist: I mean, I think you kind of know that that was probably what was going on. ; Therapist: But then, you know, and then moving you how harsh and critical she was issues with Brooke, you know, even I still even remember too for her to have gotten to the point where she wouldn't even let you like go to your grandmother's funeral or at least, you know, kind of. ; Therapist: So all those things have been so like, you know, front and center, you know, and so now to feel like that she's made this real dramatic shift and, you know, wanting to start being a mom. ; Therapist: But it sounds like that you're really working to try to manage that in a better way. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I mean, like we still, butt heads a little bit. ; Therapist: I'm sure. ; Therapist: But yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: But when you do butt heads, what is it, how are you, what happens in terms of your eating when you guys kind of like, when you feel like that there's a little bit of a friction? ; Patient: I mean, I guess that's like kind of what leads back to things. ; Patient: Like things were really good this weekend for the most part. ; Patient: And then kind of when I was leaving, she just like, and they're just brought up things about wanting to know more about life and whatnot and what's going on at school and if I'm seeing ; Patient: anyone. ; Patient: Yeah, it's just, I'm like, we don't have that relationship. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: That felt really stressful. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: So I'd say like when I got back to school, like right after that. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: And she like called me. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Well, it makes a lot of sense because again, you know, like, I know that we've really reviewed this quite a bit, but you know, historically that's how it's been, you know, that that's really been a real, and it really clarifies why we're working on this is because it's so clear that when the two of you have like these rough patches that it really all of a sudden evokes all these like negative feelings and that's when food like really, you know, you know, kicks in. ; Patient: Yeah, she makes little comments though, like seeing what I'm wearing, like, ah, that looks ; Patient: cute. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: So it's really hard to, you know, I can understand that it's really hard to let that go. ; Therapist: I mean, because obviously there's a lot of, lot of feelings that you have about that. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: On the other hand too, it seems like that, you know, things have been going really well. ; Therapist: How have things been going in terms of just in general, like school, friendships, you know, anything else that's kind of on the horizon? ; Patient: Yeah, kind of seeing a guy. ; Therapist: Cool. ; Therapist: I won't get too excited about that, but tell me about him. ; Therapist: Tell me about him. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: You sound like my mother. ; Therapist: No, what's his, you have to at least give me his name. ; Therapist: What's his name? ; Patient: His name is Alan. ; Therapist: Alan. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Well, did you like, all right, I'm not going to blow this out of proportion, but how, how, how did that kind of come about? ; Patient: We had a class together and kind of went and studied at a coffee shop. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: And then just kind of asked to like do a movie night and I was like chill and good. ; Therapist: Nice. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: No, like, yeah. ; Therapist: Nice. ; Patient: And I was like, oh, I'm really happy. ; Therapist: That's great. ; Therapist: So a lot of really nice things that are going on. ; Therapist: Yeah, that's terrific. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: So then for you to go like from, you know, cause you know, we kind of got going with this thing. ; Therapist: It was kind of like you were full on binge eating, you know, virtually every day, sometimes twice a day. ; Therapist: And now to be down to, you know, three, like in the space of like, you know, you know, just like seven, eight weeks is pretty remarkable. ; Therapist: So now I'm really pleased with how hard you've been working. ; Therapist: Cause you've really been pushing yourself, you know, I really appreciate it. ; Therapist: And I know this stuff with your mom is particularly hard. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: It's been really hard for you. ; Patient: I guess like not being able to, like, I don't feel comfortable really telling her yet about. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: And you may not, you know, I mean, it's like, you know, I know that we talked about, there's like, maybe there are times when you just don't really want to share some of that stuff, you know, and, and I think sometimes my experience has been some parents, like, you know, the goal is not to make her feel bad. ; Therapist: If you would want to share it, you'd want to share it knowing that she would hold onto that and keep it and really connect with you around it and want to be helpful rather than like, like, Oh yeah, you were so mean to me. ; Therapist: Now I have an eating disorder, you know, cause then that, that feels, you know, that doesn't feel quite right. ; Therapist: And I know that that's, you know, I know that you have a lot of hard feelings, but I don't really feel like that that's how you'd want that to go, you know? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: And I know we've talked about it a lot, but how are things going with your dad? ; Patient: Good. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Good. ; Patient: He's doing well. ; Patient: Uh, hoping that he's coming up here to school to see me. ; Therapist: Oh nice. ; Therapist: When does he plan to visit? ; Patient: A couple of weeks. ; Therapist: Great. ; Therapist: Oh, nice. ; Therapist: That'd be really nice for you to spend time with him. ; Therapist: That's great. ; Therapist: That's really great. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: So let's talk some more about this thing with your mom. ; Therapist: Cause I feel like that, I mean, I know it's tough, but I guess I've been thinking about this a lot. ; Therapist: And especially after last session that, that given the fact that, you know, you and Brooke are so close and it does feel like that your mom is, at least she seems like she's making, she's trying to make an attempt to connect with you. ; Therapist: Um, um, whether or not, you know, at what point would you feel like that you, well, what would you need from her in order to feel like that you could kind of like, maybe not let down the walls, but kind of soften those a little bit. ; Therapist: I mean, is there something, is there something that like, if you could ask her like, okay, mom, if you did this, then I would do this. ; Therapist: Not that you would do that, but I just wondered if like, what would you, ideally, what would you like to see in order to feel like that you could connect with her more? ; Patient: I mean, like, I wish she really recognized like kind of the pressures that she put on me back in the day. ; Patient: Um, yeah. ; Patient: And just like now to just, I don't know, just kind of be there in the moment instead of like trying so hard to like, I don't know, cause things still come out. ; Patient: Like she still makes her little comments about things. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: I know we talked about this, but have you gotten to the point yet where you felt like that you could like even let her know that, that, that puts a lot of pressure on you or that the comment that she makes kind of hurt your feelings? ; Therapist: Cause I know that in the moment you feel it. ; Therapist: Um, but what would it be like for you if you were to just like, yeah, say like, you know, I, I know that you're, I know that you mean well, I mean, maybe she doesn't, but maybe it's sometimes important to approach that way, but it really hurts my feelings or, you know, I feel like that that really puts a lot of pressure on me to look a particular way. ; Patient: And, you know, so I mean, I am seeing that I like starting to see that she does mean well. ; Patient: Uh, yeah, but yeah, I guess I could definitely get to that point of being able to really express that to her. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: Cause I know that you did that. ; Therapist: You've done that with your roommate. ; Therapist: I know there've been other times when people have done that because I know that that's been kind of part of the bigger issue is just knowing what it is you're feeling and also being able to kind of give voice to that. ; Therapist: And you know, I was thinking about that relationship with your mom because it does seem like that every once in a while she kind of like jabs you or she'll send something out and, and, and the way that you take it in is more like harsh, critical, you know, her and um, and I just don't know, like kind of like with Kathy when you finally talk with her, how it's like, it was like, it was like, Oh, of course. ; Therapist: Like, you know, uh, you know, I'll try to be more sensitive and I'm not really sure, you know, whether or not your mom would be, yeah, I mean, I guess that's something that she could do. ; Patient: I guess I worry that cause we've always been kind of defensive towards each other. ; Patient: I just worry that like that will happen again. ; Patient: I mean, I don't know, like it might not because of how things happen. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: But yeah, I guess I'm worried that, yeah. ; Therapist: Well, I think there are times too when I wonder if like, um, maybe if there's a time when you say something like, I know there've been times when you kind of snap back at her, you know, or you'll kind of like, you know, bark or kind of jab her a little bit. ; Therapist: Um, what if, you know, again, what if you thought about like, because it sounds like that you're really aware when you do that because you know that when she says something, you have a tendency to jab back, you could just say, you know, you know, I realized I was, that was a jab at you and I'm really sorry. ; Therapist: I'm aware that sometimes I kind of get really critical with you and I don't feel very good about that. ; Therapist: You know, I wonder how she would, you know, if that would, what that would do. ; Therapist: Maybe it wouldn't do anything or it may make you feel a little bit too vulnerable, but you think about it. ; Therapist: I mean, and, um, you know, kind of mull that over in your mind about what that might be like because my experience has been that sometimes, you know, I hate the phrase be a bigger person because I, you know, I didn't want that to come across that way, but sometimes in order to change relationships, somebody has to be willing to kind of like kind of be willing to do something just a little different. ; Therapist: And since it seems like you have a growing awareness of, you know, the re interactions that you have with her, I wonder if that might be worthwhile. ; Therapist: Yeah, yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Mull it over and think about it and, um, and we'll keep talking about it. ; Therapist: Um, but yeah, it sounds like it was a really terrific week and, um, been working really hard and it really pays off because again, the more you've done that, we've seen real positive impact on your eating. ; Therapist: So nice. ; Therapist: Nice.
