summary: Patient Particulars : Name liz ; Past Session Information: Follow -up session. ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms conflict between she and her mother chief complaints 1 binge eating ; History: Has difficulty relationship with her mother. ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior cooperative ; Psychotherapy Type: Cbt; mode individual. ; Psychotherapy Technique : Reflective listening ; Issues discussed in Current Session: 1 improvements patient talks about reduction in binge eating episodes, improved communication with her roommate. 2 family dynamics relationship with her mother is complex. Session explores the historical pressures and criticisms from her mother and the current attempts to rebuild a relationship. 3 advise therapist is validating her feelings and efforts, providing encouragement and reinforcing the positive changes she has made. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Not clear

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Jo, how are you doing today? ; Patient: I'm alright. ; Therapist: Just alright? ; Patient: I mean, obviously I'm not doing great. ; Patient: I asked you to have this session. ; Patient: We weren't scheduled for today. ; Patient: I just, I don't know, I just, I'm feeling, you know, depressed as usual, but it's just, it's stronger and I'm just feeling, I just don't want to wake up. ; Patient: I just, you know. ; Therapist: You had a rough time with things? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Do you know what's causing it? ; Patient: Not really, I mean, it's just the same, except worse, you know, like I just, I feel like what's the point. ; Patient: I don't feel like continuing on. ; Therapist: You don't feel like continuing with your life? ; Patient: Yeah, kind of. ; Therapist: Have you been having thoughts of suicide? ; Patient: I mean, I think about what it would be like to just end things. ; Patient: I think it would be a lot easier, but at the same time, like, I can't imagine doing it, but, you know, I can't say I haven't thought about it. ; Therapist: You have had some thoughts about it. ; Therapist: What prevents you from doing it? ; Patient: I don't know, I mean, I guess I know what it would be like for my family. ; Patient: I don't want to hurt them. ; Therapist: And they would be hurt? ; Patient: Yes, and it's scary, I mean, the thought of dying is scary, but the thought of going on is painful. ; Therapist: So it almost sounds as if, you know, life's wearing you down a bit. ; Patient: Yeah, I kind of feel like I'm stuck between a rock and a hard place, like I just don't know where to go from here. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: Have you worked out any specific plan to hurt yourself? ; Patient: No, I mean, you know, I've thought, like, if I were to do it, you know, ways, but not specific because I just don't think that I could do it, you know, like I don't, I've thought about suicide, but I don't, like, seriously consider it as an option, but it's starting to, like, creep into my thoughts. ; Patient: And it never has before, so I'm, like, kind of concerned about that. ; Patient: Like, I guess I know sometimes people, like, really plan it, but for me, I've never really considered it before, so it's really scary for me. ; Therapist: Alright, so, in this, how long has this been on, these feelings? ; Patient: I think, like, in the past couple of days, it started, you know, more so, and then, like, the day, it was just, like, the first thought in my head, and I couldn't stop thinking about it, and that's why I wanted to see you, because I'm just feeling, I'm starting to feel, like, a little bit out of control. ; Therapist: Okay, so, in today, and maybe the past few days, been kind of a new feeling that, a new thought, you don't want to continue life, you want to continue living, but at the same time, you don't want to commit suicide, you don't have a plan. ; Patient: Yeah, I don't want to, I really don't want to, but, you know, like I said, I feel like I'm stuck between a rock and a hard place, like, it's not, I know it's not a good option, I just, like, sometimes I feel like I'm so stuck, I just don't know where else to go. ; Therapist: So if, we'll call it a feeling depression, right, because that's what we've talked about before, if the depression would go away, do you think that would change your outlook on? ; Patient: Definitely, I think that is, like, the reason why I, the reason why the thought of not living anymore comes into my head is because of my depression, because I just feel so, like, my emotions are out of control because I wake up feeling so down and so useless and pointless that it makes me wish that I was dead. ; Patient: But if I didn't have that feeling, then I wouldn't wish that I was dead, because I know that my life has value and I know that my family would want me around and I know there's a future for me, but my feelings make me feel like my future is just dark and pointless. ; Therapist: Alright, these suicidal ideations, I know you're telling me you haven't had them before, so I can appreciate that they're scary, they'd be scary even if you hadn't had them before, are fairly common with depression. ; Therapist: And you've, it sounds like what you're really saying is you're frustrated and you're tired of being sick. ; Therapist: And I think that you make a valid point when you say your family would be upset if anything happened to you, because we talked about your family before and it would seem to be very upset, right, so your life has value. ; Therapist: I want you to try to hang on to that thought. ; Therapist: After we're done here today, tell me what you have planned for us today. ; Patient: Well, I didn't really have plans because I kind of, you know, came here feeling like I really needed to see you, so I kind of put things on hold, but I mean, I guess I would go home and, you know, I'm not really sure. ; Therapist: Is anybody else at home? ; Patient: No, but I mean, I probably could go to my parents' house if I needed to, I could probably call them and see if, you know, it's getting close to the afternoon so they can get off work soon. ; Therapist: Can you do that for me? ; Therapist: Can you go there? ; Patient: Yeah, I think that's a good idea. ; Therapist: And we'll kind of play it by ear from that point. ; Therapist: I'm going to see you today, we'll do some work today, well I'll see you again tomorrow, alright, so if you could spend a night there, I think that would be a wiser choice given your thoughts and your feelings right now. ; Therapist: Have you ever had me use the term contract for safety? ; Patient: I think you mentioned it before, I'm not really sure. ; Therapist: Okay, so what it means is you kind of, and only if it's authentic, I want this to be true, it's kind of where you promised to me that you're going to be safe until I see you again, right, for the foreseeable future, that you don't have any intent or plan to harm yourself. ; Therapist: Can you make that promise to me now? ; Patient: I can. ; Therapist: Alright, so give me a minute and I'll come back and we'll work a little bit today and then I'm going to schedule you to see you tomorrow as well, okay? ; Patient: Thank you. ; Therapist: Alright, thanks Jill.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name jill ; Clinical Identifiers: Setting opd ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Follow up session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Suicidal ideations 2. Feelings of worthlessness ; History: Patient has been feeling low due thoughts of worthless and as if somewhere is stuck in life. They feels that their emotions are getting out of control and has started having suicidal ideations. ; Crisis Markers: Suicidal ideation; level of risk mild ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behaviour patient was cooperative and rapport could be established; mood depressed; affect restricted; thought preoccupation with thoughts of ending life and hopelessness ; Psychotherapy Type: Type pct; mode individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Reflective listening, crisis intervention ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patient consulted before the scheduled session as he was having recurrent suicidal thoughts. Overall severity of these ideations was understood and no suicide contract was signed. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Nil ; Action Plan : Patient has been told to spend time with parents and stay their for a night to see if there is any improvement ; Next session details: Next day

dialogue: Therapist: Hi, Lucy. ; Therapist: Nice to meet you. ; Patient: Hi. ; Therapist: So I understand that you were referred here by your GP because you've been feeling quite down recently. ; Patient: Yeah, I thought I should. ; Patient: I've been feeling quite bad for quite a while. ; Patient: So I thought maybe it's time to see someone about it because I don't want to feel like this anymore. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So from your notes, I saw that you saw the GP about three months ago. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So how long have you been feeling down altogether? ; Patient: Quite a few months before that as well, actually. ; Patient: But it's gotten pretty bad these past few months. ; Patient: So that's kind of why I came. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So has it got worse since you saw your GP? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So tell me, how are things at the moment? ; Patient: Well, it kind of started just feeling a bit low and wound up about things. ; Patient: But I don't know, just recently I just can't really be bothered to do anything at all. ; Patient: I kind of find it hard to get motivated for things. ; Patient: And I want to be, I really want to be better, but it's just kind of reaching the end now where I just want to do something about it. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So you said that you're feeling really down, really sad. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And you feel like you haven't got any motivation. ; Therapist: But are you okay? ; Patient: Yeah, I'm fine. ; Patient: Sorry. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And you haven't got any motivation, but it sounds like you put quite a lot of pressure on yourself to try and feel a bit better. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I just, it's kind of hard as well because there's not really anyone to talk about. ; Patient: So I just kind of stay on my own trying to, I don't like to think about it, but I don't know. ; Therapist: So you say you've been, you're feeling quite isolated. ; Therapist: There's not many people around. ; Patient: Yeah, there's no one I can talk to about it. ; Patient: No one would listen or understand anyway. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So I'm just going to try and find out a little bit more about you. ; Therapist: So I understand that you're an English student at uni. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And you live away from home with some friends. ; Therapist: Is that right? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I live here. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So you don't live far from the uni. ; Therapist: But you say you feel like you live with your friends, but you don't feel like you can talk to them. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I mean, they're lovely. ; Patient: I get on really well with them, but I don't know. ; Patient: I just recently, whenever they want to go out or stuff, I just, I don't want to bring them down. ; Patient: I can't, they don't understand what I'm going through. ; Patient: They kind of, I don't know, they don't make fun of how I feel, but they don't really understand what it's like. ; Patient: I just, I don't want to go out with them and bring them down or stuff. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So it sounds, do you try and hide the way you're feeling from them? ; Patient: I guess. ; Patient: I mean, it's easier to hide it than to try and explain it all the time when no one really wants to know. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So it sounds like you've been feeling down. ; Therapist: You've been feeling unmotivated. ; Therapist: You feel like you want to be better, but actually it sounds like you feel like you can't reach out for help. ; Therapist: You can't speak to anybody. ; Patient: No. ; Patient: I don't really talk to my parents a lot either. ; Patient: So that's kind of hard. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: I'm just going to go back in time a little bit. ; Therapist: I suppose I'm just wondering when, when did all of this start? ; Therapist: You said it's been going on for quite a few months. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Um, I guess it kind of started, uh, when I was actually, when I was revising for my exams, um, I guess the stress, I put a lot of stress on myself. ; Patient: I think I've always wanted to do well for me and I guess for my parents. ; Patient: So the stress of exams and it was also kind of hard because my parents were going through a bit of a troubled time then. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So this would be like last March, last April? ; Therapist: Uh, yeah, I think so. ; Therapist: Around that time. ; Therapist: So about six months-ish. ; Therapist: And it sounds like a lot was happening. ; Therapist: So you had a lot of uni pressure on and, um, and you said that your parents were having marital problems. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And it sounds like that was a real shock to you. ; Patient: Yeah, I guess it was hard as well because I wasn't doing well at uni. ; Patient: I guess I just felt a bit guilty. ; Patient: I know it sounds silly, but I felt like maybe if I could do better, then they would get better. ; Patient: But it just wasn't really happening. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So it sounds like you were trying to work hard and be more successful because you thought that that would make them happier and try and fix things. ; Patient: Yeah, I wanted to make them feel better, but it just kind of backfired a little, I guess. ; Therapist: How did it backfire? ; Patient: It just ended up with them getting worse and I've just been feeling worse since then. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So after the summer, after the exam period, and how did that exam period go for you in the end? ; Patient: Not very well. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: That's an awful lot of pressure to put on yourself. ; Therapist: I suppose to think... ; Patient: It's just annoying because I know I should have done better and I just didn't. ; Patient: And I guess I beat myself up a lot about it. ; Therapist: So you say, I know, I know I should have done better. ; Therapist: I mean, I suppose hearing it from my perspective, I'm thinking it sounds like you had an awful lot going on at the time. ; Therapist: It'd be understandable, absolutely, that you wouldn't do as well as normal. ; Therapist: I suppose I'm just wondering if you have very high standards for yourself. ; Patient: Probably maybe more than other people. ; Patient: My parents have always kind of taught me, not in a loving way, I guess, but that you should do your best, but also get the best. ; Patient: And I agree with that. ; Patient: I think that's the right thing to think. ; Patient: But when I don't do that, I don't know. ; Patient: It annoys me a lot and I worry that it annoys them. ; Therapist: So it sounds like you feel you should always do your best. ; Therapist: Is that the word you used? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: And that there isn't any kind of exceptions for that? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So I can see then that that was a really difficult time for you. ; Therapist: And that was when your mood started to get lower and things are still quite bad now. ; Therapist: I mean, what's the situation with your parents at the moment? ; Patient: I think it doesn't sound good. ; Patient: I don't really talk to them a lot, but I don't think they're going through very good. ; Patient: I don't like to talk to them about it because it just makes me feel worse. ; Patient: But I don't think it's getting any better. ; Therapist: Were you home over the summer? ; Patient: For a little bit, yeah. ; Therapist: And how was that? ; Patient: Not very fun. ; Therapist: No. ; Patient: It was quite tense all the time. ; Patient: It stressed me out more than relaxed me over the summer, I guess. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay, so it sounds then like quite a lot has been happening. ; Therapist: You've been feeling very low. ; Therapist: You've had uni pressure on. ; Therapist: You've had problems with your parents' marriage. ; Therapist: And it sounds like you feel like you can't really reach out to anyone, like you can't understand, but you can't really reach out to your parents right now. ; Therapist: You can't really confide in your friends. ; Therapist: So I suppose I'm just wondering if you can tell me a bit more about how you've been feeling, I mean, say this past week. ; Patient: Really not good, to be honest. ; Patient: I actually, if I don't have to, then I don't really leave the house or get out of. ; Patient: But I just, I can't find the motivation for the things I used to join. ; Patient: I used to love doing sports or going out, and now I just prefer to lie and better not really do anything. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: I missed a few lectures this week that I should have gone to, but... ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: So I suppose I'm just wondering then, let's see if we can think about one thing, say a lecture. ; Therapist: What kind of thoughts do you have about going to that lecture before it happens? ; Patient: I don't really see the point anymore. ; Patient: If I can't do as well as I should be doing, then what's the point in putting myself in those positions? ; Patient: I just, I can't be bothered anymore to try. ; Patient: It just stresses me out more than I need to. ; Therapist: Okay, so it sounds like the kind of thoughts you've got in your head are, it's pointless, it's not worth it. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Do you have any other thoughts in your head when you're just at that point before you go to the lecture? ; Patient: I feel like, I don't know, I don't really even deserve to be here if I can't do well enough. ; Patient: I see all these other students who are doing well and doing better and want to be there. ; Patient: I don't know why I'm here even at uni, to be honest. ; Therapist: So it sounds like you feel like you're not as good as other people here. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: I'm just, sorry, is it okay if I take notes as we go through? ; Therapist: It's just I'm trying to, I guess, understand what you're telling me and it helps me just to write it down and I'll share this with you later. ; Therapist: Okay, so it sounds like those are some quite negative thoughts to have. ; Therapist: You're kind of saying, you know, it feels like it's pointless, it's more effort than it's worth, and I don't deserve to be here. ; Therapist: I mean, when you have those thoughts, how do you feel? ; Patient: Very unworthy probably would be the best way to put it, kind of, I don't know, lower than normal. ; Patient: Because then it makes me think about all the things that I should have been doing better. ; Therapist: Okay, so what you described there then, you said, I'm unworthy, I should be doing lots of things better. ; Therapist: Those are kind of what I would call thoughts, actually. ; Therapist: I suppose I'm trying to understand what it feels like in your gut. ; Therapist: What kind of emotions do you feel? ; Therapist: Happier? ; Therapist: Do you feel sad? ; Therapist: What kind of emotions are you feeling when you have those thoughts? ; Patient: Sad. ; Patient: Not happiness. ; Patient: No, sad. ; Patient: A bit of anger and frustration as well. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: I know you're just kind of telling me this, and I know this is quite a heavy topic, but you're kind of laughing. ; Therapist: And I suppose I wonder a little bit, are you a bit, you know, how do you feel about having these emotions, talking about these emotions? ; Patient: I guess, embarrassed. ; Patient: I've never yet talked about it, so it's quite uncomfortable to be in this situation. ; Therapist: Okay, well you're doing a great job, because I know that this can be difficult. ; Therapist: Okay, so it sounds like some of the thoughts you're describing are, it's pointless, it's more than it's worth, I don't deserve to be here, I'm unworthy. ; Therapist: And those kind of thoughts, it sounds like they just flip through your mind. ; Therapist: And then you're kind of describing different emotions that those lead to. ; Therapist: You're kind of describing sad, anger, frustration, embarrassed. ; Therapist: What about in your body, what happens? ; Therapist: How do you feel, kind of physically? ; Patient: I used to be, I think from those emotions, very wound up, very kind of stressed all the time. ; Patient: But recently it's just been a lot more draining than anything. ; Patient: Just quite lethargic, and I just can't be bothered anymore, and my body reflects that. ; Patient: But then when I try and sleep I just can't seem to have a satisfied night's sleep. ; Patient: It's really, really frustrating. ; Therapist: So it sounds like this is affecting you, it's draining you of your energy, like your body can't be bothered. ; Therapist: I think that's a really good way of describing it. ; Therapist: And you're noticing sleep problems as well. ; Therapist: And then, what do you do? ; Therapist: So this is, so we're back to the point before the lecture. ; Therapist: So you start having these thoughts, these emotions, and you know, your body, I guess it sounds like those thoughts are quite draining, so it'll be draining your energy. ; Therapist: What then happens, what do you do next? ; Patient: I kind of focus on the negative thoughts, and I probably should not think about them, ; Patient: but I focus on them and then I don't really want to do anything. ; Patient: I kind of stay in bed or... ; Therapist: So you think even more about those kind of worries that you have, so you do a bit of dwelling and you stay in bed. ; Therapist: And it sounds like you don't, you haven't tried speaking to your friends about it. ; Patient: No, I haven't. ; Therapist: Or speaking to family. ; Therapist: Okay, and then after you've done that, so after you've not gone to the lecture, you've stayed in bed, you've kind of spent time, as you said, focusing on those thoughts, those negative thoughts. ; Therapist: How do you feel after that? ; Therapist: Do you feel better or do you feel worse? ; Patient: I guess I feel slightly worse, but then a bit numb, in a way, kind of, I don't know. ; Patient: Once you've felt that, because I do feel tired all the time, I just try and push it out and then you don't really think about anything, and it's almost nicer that way than to keep focusing on how much you're getting wrong and how much you can't do stuff. ; Patient: Sometimes it's better just to not think about it at all. ; Therapist: So it sounds like in some ways it's a bit of a relief to do that. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: But in other ways maybe you think it might make things worse. ; Patient: Probably in the long run, yeah.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name lucy; sex female; marital status unmarried; education graduation pursuing; occupation student ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Referred by general practitioner ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Low mood 2. Lack of motivation 3. Feelings of worthlessness 4. Fatiguability 5. Disturbed sleep quality ; History: Precipitating factor exam stress; total duration 6 months; present history patient was maintaining well until 6 months ago when she took a lot of stress for exams as she wanted to perform well. Her parents were having a hard time with their marriage which added to her stress. She has been living away from home with her university friends. She has been feeling low and doesnt share this with anyone; premorbid personality use of leisure time- going out, sports ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behaviour patient was cooperative and rapport could be established; mood depressed; affect restricted; thought content- reflected worthlessness ; Psychotherapy Type: Type cbt; mode individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Reflective listening, psychoeducation ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patient expressed experiencing low mood, fatiguability and feelings of worthlessness most of the time. It started during her exams when she took a lot of stress about it. During the same time her parents also started having marital issues which made things worse for the patient and she felt guilty about it. She has been facing decreased sleep quality and feelings of isolation. She refrains from spend time or talking with her parents as it makes her feel bad. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: F32. 0 major depressive disorder, single episode mild ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Hi, Louise. ; Therapist: How you doing today? ; Patient: Doing pretty well, but I'm kind of concerned about something. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: I'm aware you have some symptoms that have been bothering you. ; Therapist: Can you tell me about those? ; Patient: Sometimes I have problems with my attention and I was looking it up online and I'm really worried that I might have ADHD. ; Therapist: ADHD? ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So we'll talk about that. ; Therapist: Let me ask you a few quick questions before we get to that. ; Therapist: Do you ever feel depressed? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No? ; Therapist: Anxious? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Any trouble with drugs or alcohol or anything like that? ; Patient: Oh, no. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Why do you think you have ADHD? ; Patient: Oh, because I mean I've always had a problem with my attention and I can get distracted pretty easily. ; Therapist: So trouble establishing attention? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: How about difficulty in holding attention, like once you have established it? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Trouble with both of those? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: And you mentioned the word distracted? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: So you find yourself easily distracted? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: You do? ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: How about, well, give me an idea of the setting. ; Therapist: So is this at work or school? ; Patient: Oh, it's everywhere. ; Therapist: It's everywhere? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So do you work? ; Patient: Yes, I do. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Do you go to school? ; Patient: Yes, I do. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: How old are you? ; Patient: I'm 24. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: And this problem with the attention affects you at work and at school? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: And you said everywhere? ; Patient: Yeah, pretty much. ; Patient: It's part of my everyday life now. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: You're 24 now. ; Therapist: When did you first notice the attention problems? ; Patient: Oh, I've always had that. ; Patient: I mean, even when I was in like elementary school, you know, I was always that kid. ; Therapist: You've had it for a long time? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: How about how disturbing it is? ; Therapist: Like, how much is it interfering with your functioning? ; Patient: It really, it really does. ; Therapist: It's really problematic? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So I'm going to ask you a few other questions here. ; Therapist: We talked about the attention, so it's hard for you to give attention and hold attention. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Let's go with the school environment for now. ; Therapist: Let's talk about school. ; Therapist: How about listening in class? ; Patient: No, I don't really have a problem with that. ; Therapist: That's not a problem for you? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: How about following instructions? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Tell me about your organizational skills. ; Patient: I'm very organized. ; Therapist: You're very organized? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I have to be in college. ; Therapist: Do you find yourself avoiding activities that require a lot of mental investment, mental energy? ; Patient: No, not really. ; Therapist: No? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Do you move toward those types of activities? ; Patient: Oh, I'm not opposed to them. ; Patient: Like, I like chess and checkers. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Do you ever find yourself losing things that you need to complete different jobs or tasks? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No? ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: I'm going to change gears and ask you some other questions around a different area. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Do you ever find yourself fidgeting, tough to stay still? ; Patient: Not really, no. ; Therapist: No? ; Therapist: In school, again, we'll kind of stick with the school environment. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Do you find it difficult to stay seated? ; Patient: No, not at all. ; Therapist: How do you do when you are engaging in a quiet activity? ; Patient: I do pretty well. ; Therapist: You do okay with that? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: You don't find yourself wandering off with that? ; Patient: No, not at all. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Do you ever feel like internally there's a motor running and you can't shut it off? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No? ; Therapist: How about being talkative? ; Therapist: Do you find yourself talkative? ; Patient: I'm very talkative. ; Therapist: You're very talkative? ; Patient: Sometimes I end up being rude and I interrupt people. ; Patient: I just, I gotta get it out. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So you feel like you talk a lot and that you interrupt? ; Patient: Yes, I do. ; Therapist: Interrupt people. ; Therapist: In a situation where it would be traditional to like wait in line or wait your turn, do you find that's difficult for you? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No? ; Therapist: Do you ever find yourself, like for example in class, just saying something, like blurting something out without giving it much thought? ; Patient: No, not really. ; Therapist: No? ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: I think I have what I need here and I want to get you in to see a counselor. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: If that works for you. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Because you did mention this was affecting your functioning. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: So I want to make sure you get to see a counselor. ; Therapist: It will just take a couple days to get you in to see somebody if that works for you. ; Patient: That's great. ; Patient: Thank you. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: I appreciate you taking this time with me. ; Therapist: This information has been helpful. ; Patient: Thank you very much. ; Therapist: Thanks, Louise.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name lisa; sex female; age24yrs ; Clinical Identifiers: Setting opd ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Problems with attention and concentration sinve childhood 2. Talking excessively na ; History: Pt reports that she has problems in focusing and holding attention since childhood. There is no problem in being seated for long hours, shes organised and can engage well in quiet activities. She denies having any low mood or anxiety or using any psychoactive substance. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Nil ; Psychotherapy Type: Nil ; Psychotherapy Technique : Nil ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: The doctor focussed on the symptoms and making a diagnosis ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Adhd, inattention type ; Action Plan : To send the patient to a counselor ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Elise, how you doing today? ; Patient: I'm good, but there has been an issue, you know how we've been working on like my motivation? ; Therapist: Sure. ; Patient: Well, it's kind of related to that. ; Patient: So I'm in school and every few weeks we have like papers to write. ; Patient: And I know I know it, I know I can do it. ; Patient: It's just actually sitting down and doing it. ; Therapist: All right, well tell me about the papers. ; Patient: Well, they're usually about five pages long. ; Patient: And I just look at it and I'm like, it's five pages. ; Patient: But I'm like, okay, so I go sit down, you know, at my computer, I'm like, all right, I'm going to start on references. ; Patient: So I get, you know, I start off good. ; Patient: I do the references, but then it's like, I get sidetracked so easily. ; Patient: And then I end up killing like two hours checking the news, checking, and then it goes to my phone and then just looking at recipes. ; Patient: I mean, it gets really off topic. ; Patient: And then I realized, you know, I haven't done anything. ; Therapist: All right, so you have a five page paper, you sit down to work on it. ; Therapist: You have the references, you get that part taken care of. ; Therapist: But then it sounds like you kind of wander off a little bit. ; Patient: Oh, big time. ; Therapist: Yeah, okay. ; Therapist: And then what happens after you are done wandering a little bit? ; Patient: Well, I get kind of annoyed with it. ; Patient: And then I'm like, well, you know, I've already, you know, it's already nighttime, I'll try to do it tomorrow. ; Patient: And then, you know, either tomorrow doesn't happen or the same thing happens. ; Patient: And then I end up rushing right at the end of, you know, the do tomorrow and getting all these five pages done. ; Patient: It's really hard for me. ; Therapist: So you are finishing the assignment on time. ; Therapist: So the problem isn't lateness. ; Patient: No, I mean, I get it done. ; Therapist: You get it done. ; Patient: It's just all at the last minute. ; Therapist: So it's really how the time breaks out isn't working out well for you. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: You'd rather not be doing it at the last moment. ; Patient: No, I mean, I try not to. ; Patient: I mean, I set time aside to go sit down. ; Patient: I'm like, all right, you know, we're going to start on this paper, then sidetracked. ; Patient: I'm watching TV. ; Patient: I'm on my phone. ; Patient: I'm on some other website. ; Therapist: So these activities that you're engaging in between when you start the work and before you start writing, so we're gathering the references before you start writing. ; Therapist: You said check an email. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And other kind of, it sounds like unplanned small activities. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I mean, there's small things that keep my attention, but that's not where my attention needs to go. ; Therapist: These aren't particularly engaging activities, like something you need to do at that moment? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: No, I mean, I look up, you know, I start on one reference and then, ooh, this article looks cool. ; Patient: Ooh, this article. ; Patient: I'm researching octopuses or something. ; Therapist: So like distracted? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Distracted is a good word. ; Therapist: And then there's a moment when you kind of catch yourself and realize you haven't really started writing. ; Patient: Yeah, but it's like two hours late. ; Therapist: It's too late. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So you're consuming time there. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So you have a few different levels of activity here. ; Therapist: You have the paper, which it sounds like you're okay writing, but you're maybe not highly motivated to write. ; Therapist: But you seem to be getting the references done okay. ; Patient: Yeah, I mean, I get the references done okay. ; Therapist: You collect the material and then the writing part. ; Patient: That's the difficult part. ; Therapist: And then you have these behaviors in the middle, which you enjoy doing a little, but they're not something that... ; Patient: I mean, they're not something that I'm jumping for joy about. ; Patient: It's just something to procrastinate so I don't have to do my paper. ; Patient: I don't think that. ; Patient: I'm not like, oh, I need to check my email so I don't have to do my paper. ; Patient: It's just, oh, I should check my email. ; Patient: Oh, I should check my phone. ; Patient: Oh, I haven't done this in a while. ; Patient: Oh, I haven't seen this in a while. ; Therapist: But these behaviors still fulfill a purpose. ; Therapist: They do delay the writing of the paper. ; Patient: Yeah, that's true. ; Therapist: You may not be fully aware of that in the moment, but then you kind of become aware of that later, that that's the purpose that those behaviors accomplished. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: And the other thing that I noticed was that they kept you distracted from the writing. ; Patient: That's true. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So the writing of the paper is an activity. ; Therapist: That's a behavior that's something you're not really looking forward to. ; Therapist: What's a behavior that... ; Therapist: What's an activity that you really do look forward to, that you kind of think about and some level of engagement is there? ; Patient: Well, there is this new TV show out that they just started a new season and I have it all recorded, like 24 episodes, but I can't find time to watch it. ; Patient: But I'm really, you know, I've seen the first season, I'm so interested in it. ; Patient: I can't wait to see the next one. ; Patient: I guess that's what makes me really happy right now. ; Therapist: So you're excited about this television show and you have the episodes already recorded. ; Therapist: And maybe one of the reasons you can't find the time is because the time you're using between the two parts of writing this paper. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I mean, this paper's taken me a lot longer than it should. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So let's try this. ; Therapist: When you do write the paper, you're really writing it, the writing part, not the preparing part, but the writing part kind of all at the end, right? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: You're getting it done, but it's the night before it's due. ; Patient: Oh, yeah. ; Therapist: So I want to try a couple of different behavioral strategies here. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And these might be similar to what we tried before working with motivation. ; Therapist: One is I think that it might be helpful, and I want you to let me know if I'm right here, to break, if it's a five-page paper, to break it up into more than one night. ; Therapist: Because right now, functionally, at least a lot of it you're doing on the last night. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay? ; Therapist: What would be a more comfortable pace? ; Therapist: For example, how long does it take you to write one page? ; Patient: About an hour, hour and a half. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So around an hour to an hour and a half, you can complete one page, edit it, proofread? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So it would take about five days for you to complete the whole paper. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: If you did an hour and a half each day, an hour to an hour and a half each day. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: What do you have from when the paper's assigned to when it's due? ; Patient: They give us about a week and a half to do it. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So around 10 days? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So if you could maintain the pace of an hour to an hour and a half a day, you would be done in plenty of time. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Is there a good time to write, like to start writing? ; Patient: I guess around six o'clock, because then I'm already done eating, I'm home from work, and I've kind of de-stressed already. ; Patient: Six o'clock's a pretty good time. ; Therapist: So if you could work without distraction, you would be done by around 7.30 at the latest? ; Therapist: With just one page? ; Patient: Yeah, with one page. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So no distractions and just one page? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So talk about the episodes, the TV episodes that you want to watch. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: How long are they? ; Patient: They're an hour. ; Therapist: They're an hour? ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And what's a time that you could watch those or you get the maximum enjoyment out of watching them? ; Therapist: Like no distractions? ; Patient: I guess around eight o'clock, because that's when I'm starting to get ready for bed and starting to really relax. ; Patient: And my husband's home by that time, and we can watch it together. ; Patient: He loves the show too. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So eight o'clock's a really good time for you to maximize what you'll get out of the show, the enjoyment you'll get out of the show. ; Therapist: So what I want to do is try to pair these behaviors together, the behavior of writing, which is not something that you're necessarily thrilled about all the time, but you are getting it done just not in the time schedule you like. ; Therapist: And the behavior of watching the show is you are more or less excited about it. ; Patient: I mean, I'm very interested in that. ; Therapist: That's a great motivator for you. ; Therapist: And I want to try to use it as a motivator, kind of like a reward. ; Therapist: So what I'd like you to try to do is when you get one of these papers assigned, the five page papers, pick the five nights that you want to work on it. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: It could be Monday through Friday or whatever works for you. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: All right? ; Therapist: Clearly within the 10 day window though. ; Patient: All right. ; Therapist: So five days within the 10 day window do you have to turn in. ; Therapist: And then set that time at six o'clock is when you're going to start because that's a good time for you to work. ; Therapist: And when you try to work straight through to seven or seven thirty, I know that's a challenge, right? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: When that period of distraction might encroach, right? ; Therapist: We know that might happen. ; Therapist: Focus on, I really want to watch that show at eight o'clock. ; Patient: So just keep thinking about that when I feel like I'm getting off track? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: That's your, in a way, that's your reward. ; Therapist: That's your motivation. ; Therapist: That's kind of what you're looking forward to, to get through something that you don't necessarily enjoy a lot. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: You're going to be using what you do enjoy a lot to help push you through that. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay? ; Therapist: In the process, I hope that the writing becomes more enjoyable. ; Therapist: You know, we'll see. ; Therapist: But whether it does or it doesn't, you still want to be able to complete it. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And not have to stress right at the end. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And not waste that time in the middle. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Right? ; Therapist: That's really eating more time than your show takes. ; Patient: Really, it is. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: I mean, you're right. ; Patient: I could watch that show with the amount of time I waste just doing other things. ; Therapist: So the key here is to try to keep it structured. ; Therapist: Like if that plan that I've laid out works for you, does that make sense for you? ; Patient: It does. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Because we can modify it if it doesn't. ; Therapist: Try that now and we can always change it up. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: If we need to. ; Therapist: But I think that does make sense and it gives you time to finish the paper. ; Therapist: And I think it divides it into manageable periods of time. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: But the key is here to start on time, six o'clock, and to intend to and try to start the show on time at eight o'clock. ; Therapist: Try to keep that structure. ; Therapist: So you have the behavior that's not necessarily too excited about but you kind of have to do at some point. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And that show that you're really looking forward to. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: You're going to pair those together. ; Patient: No, I see where you're getting at. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Does this make sense to you? ; Therapist: Do you understand kind of? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: You know, that'd help me power through and not do things unrelated. ; Patient: You might think, well, if I get this paper done, this page done, I get to watch my show later. ; Therapist: And I think that's a helpful way to think about it. ; Therapist: And that's the cognitive part of this. ; Therapist: So this is a behavioral strategy because we talked about these in the past, right? ; Therapist: This is a behavioral strategy. ; Therapist: The cognitive piece is when you find yourself wandering, right, that you have to detect that. ; Therapist: And I think you have some level of awareness that's happening. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: You have to detect that and say, oh, I want to watch my show. ; Therapist: I'm really looking forward to it. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Right? ; Therapist: And that's your motivation to move it through the paper and then you know when eight o'clock comes. ; Patient: I get to watch my show. ; Therapist: You get to watch your show! ; Patient: All right. ; Patient: That sounds like a plan. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Very good. ; Therapist: So let's try that for, I'll see you again in roughly two weeks. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Do you have a paper assigned between now and then? ; Patient: I actually do. ; Therapist: You do? ; Therapist: So let's try it with this next paper. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: The one that will be assigned before I see you again. ; Therapist: And let's try the five day and we'll evaluate how it goes and make any changes if we need to. ; Patient: All right. ; Therapist: Sound good? ; Patient: Yep. ; Therapist: All right. ; Patient: All right. ; Patient: Thank you! ; Therapist: I'll see you in a few weeks.
summary: Patient Particulars : Female; married ; Clinical Identifiers: Outpatient ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Follow-up session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Attention and concentration deficits ; History: Patient reports that she finds it difficult to maintain focus and concentration once she starts working on writing her papers or completing her assignments. Even though she begins by gathering references, she easily gets distracted by checking the news, using phone, or browsing unrelated websites, which hampers her productivity. This results in stress to complete the papers within tight deadlines. She reports that she is unable to control herself from wandering away from the topic on which she is working at that point of time. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Affect seems to be anxious; at time patient replies to the therapist before heshe finishes the question or provides an opinion; there is no evidence of any perceptual abnormality. ; Psychotherapy Type: Type cbt; mode individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Reflective listening, problem solving, contingency management ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: The focus of the current session was completing a paper well before the deadline ; Reflections by the therapist: The patient was co-operative during the interview and actively involved in the session. At times, she would jump to answer to the questions asked before the question being completed. However, she understood the homework given to her well. She had been receptive to the therapists advise in her past sessions as well. ; Action Plan : Reinforcement of the act of completing her paper writing by providing a reward in the form of watching episodes with her husband only after she completes writing 1 page, thought monitoring ; Next session details: Next session is to be taken after 2 weeks

dialogue: Therapist: Counselors and other school personnel often have the opportunity to discuss risk behaviors with students, like drinking alcohol. ; Therapist: They have a unique role as both representatives of the school and professionals whose job it is to advocate for the students. ; Therapist: The counselor's approach and tone throughout such conversations are likely to influence the degree with which students trust them. ; Therapist: Watch what happens when this counselor uses a judgmental stance and lectures the student about school policies and the dangers of drinking. ; Therapist: Hi Laura, so thanks for coming in. ; Therapist: I'm not sure how much you know about why you're here or what we're supposed to talk about. ; Therapist: So basically I'm going to be meeting with all the students in the school, usually once or twice per semester. ; Therapist: And we're going to talk about whatever's kind of going on in your life. ; Therapist: I'll ask you some questions about your goals and what you like to do for fun and those sorts of things. ; Therapist: And then we'll talk a little bit about different behaviors and stuff like that. ; Therapist: And so it's pretty casual, pretty informal, just sort of a chance for me to get to know you. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Why don't we start by just having you tell me a little bit about yourself? ; Patient: Okay, my name is Laura and I'm 17 and I'm a senior in high school. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And what do you like to do for fun? ; Patient: Mostly just hang out with my friends and stuff on the weekends, things like that. ; Therapist: And when you and your friends are hanging out, what do you do? ; Therapist: Go to football games, go to parties? ; Patient: Yeah, if it's school related, maybe like a game or two or go to the mall to shop or go to the movies or something. ; Patient: And at night maybe like a party or something if someone's throwing. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And what kinds of hobbies do you have? ; Patient: I like to read and I like to go outside and take walks and hike and stuff. ; Patient: I'm very outdoorsy. ; Therapist: Oh, cool. ; Therapist: What are your plans for after high school? ; Patient: Well, I plan to apply to college and maybe, you know, have a good career and something like that, hopefully. ; Therapist: That's great. ; Therapist: What do you think you'll study? ; Patient: Well, I'm looking into journalism, maybe pre-law. ; Therapist: Oh, neat. ; Patient: Which is a little different, but. ; Therapist: Yeah, that's great. ; Therapist: That's a really good goal. ; Patient: Yeah, thanks. ; Therapist: That's hard work to get into law school. ; Therapist: Are you doing well in school? ; Therapist: What kind of grades do you get? ; Patient: Yeah, I'm doing okay. ; Patient: I'm getting mostly A's and B's, so I'm pretty good. ; Patient: I'm okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: What grades are you not getting A's and B's in? ; Patient: I think all my grades are A's and B's. ; Therapist: Oh, okay. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And do you know where you're going to apply to college? ; Therapist: I'm not sure yet, but I'm looking into schools like in the area, so maybe, I don't know, maybe I'll leave home or something. ; Therapist: Okay, cool. ; Therapist: And, you know, what made you decide maybe law school or journalism? ; Patient: Well, I'm definitely not a math or science person, so I started off by there and then I started looking at careers that maybe I would like, so. ; Therapist: Okay, great. ; Therapist: Sounds like you have, like I said, really good goals and you're working hard in school. ; Therapist: You said that when you're going out with your friends, you like to hang out and shop and stuff like that and also go to parties, so do you drink alcohol? ; Patient: Not really, maybe one or two drinks at a party, that's the most. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And how often do you think you drink? ; Patient: Maybe like once or twice a month at the most. ; Therapist: So like once or twice a month you're having alcohol? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And so that's maybe like 20 times a year? ; Patient: Possibly, yeah. ; Therapist: So that's actually kind of a lot of drinking then. ; Patient: Yeah, I guess you can say that. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: What do you think is the most you've ever had? ; Patient: Just two drinks at a party at the most. ; Patient: I don't like to drink a lot. ; Patient: Getting drunk is not something that appeals to me, so I just have like a drink in my hand so my friends won't bug me about not drinking, just like to look like I'm actually doing something. ; Patient: Most of the time I don't even drink at all. ; Therapist: But you've been drunk before? ; Patient: No, not really, maybe tipsy but not like drunk. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So the most you've ever, ever had is two drinks in a day? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay, interesting. ; Therapist: So do you know all the bad stuff about alcohol? ; Patient: Yeah, yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So one of the things that, you know, is really important to talk to teenagers about is drinking and driving. ; Therapist: So you know, that's actually a really big problem and even around here we have kids die every year from getting in a drunk driving accident. ; Therapist: So that's something that you really need to make sure you're not doing. ; Therapist: Have you ever done that? ; Therapist: Have you ever gotten in a car? ; Patient: No, I've never drunk driven and I've never gotten in a car with a drunk driver. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: How much do your friends drink? ; Patient: I mean, I have some friends that drink some more than others. ; Patient: My close group of friends don't really drink as much because I'm not really interested in that but I know that there are people that drink a lot more. ; Therapist: What about at these parties you're going to? ; Therapist: Are there other kids there who are drinking a lot? ; Patient: Yeah, there are kids that drink a lot more than I do, definitely. ; Therapist: And do you hang out with them? ; Patient: Not really closely. ; Patient: Like I know who they are and I'll say hi but they're not really like close friends of mine. ; Therapist: So, you know, even just hanging out around kids who are drinking a lot actually puts you at a lot more risk. ; Therapist: Did you know that? ; Patient: Yeah, that makes sense. ; Therapist: Yeah, so there's, I mean, a lot of the other dangers of drinking, like not just car accidents but you can have other accidents. ; Therapist: You know, people, you know, will fall or, you know, break things or a lot of people actually end up breaking their bones and ending up in the emergency room because they've been drunk and fallen down. ; Therapist: As a girl, it's really important too that you're careful because you could be sexually assaulted. ; Therapist: You know, especially if you've been drinking then you're at a lot more risk because a guy can take advantage of you. ; Therapist: Have you thought about that? ; Patient: Yeah, yeah, I have. ; Patient: That's one of the main reasons I don't like to drink that much. ; Therapist: And then, you know, people get in fights more often when they've been drinking too. ; Therapist: Also, you know, there have been a lot of kids even at this school who have gotten in trouble because they were drinking and someone took pictures with their cell phone and put it up on Facebook and then their parents find out or school finds out and, you know, we have a no tolerance policy here about drugs and alcohol and really can get you into trouble and could put your whole college career in jeopardy. ; Therapist: Have you thought about that? ; Patient: Yeah, definitely, yeah. ; Therapist: But you're still drinking. ; Patient: Yeah, I mean, I guess it's the thing to do at a party, so. ; Therapist: So, I mean, do you think it's the thing to do if you want to be an attorney? ; Patient: Definitely not. ; Patient: That's why I don't try to drink that much. ; Patient: Just make it look like I am kind of. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So, I mean, I guess what we need to do then is kind of talk about some goals for how to be safer. ; Therapist: Obviously, you shouldn't be drinking at all. ; Therapist: What do you think about that? ; Patient: I definitely agree. ; Patient: I know that there are some other risks involved in alcohol other than the ones you mentioned like health wise and things like that. ; Patient: So I agree that alcohol may not be the best thing. ; Therapist: So do you think you can quit? ; Patient: Yeah, I mean, it's not like a really big part of my life, so. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So I'm going to write down then that you've decided to quit. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And that's going to be your goal. ; Therapist: And that's great. ; Therapist: That's really why we're here is to talk about that and make sure that you come to that decision. ; Therapist: So, I guess, can you quit this weekend then? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah, definitely. ; Patient: I'll just not have a drink. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And then what about your friends who are still drinking? ; Patient: I really can't control what they do, but I'll definitely try to get my closest friends to maybe stop like I will. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And what if they won't? ; Patient: Well, then I guess I'll just try to hang around them less or something or try to find things for us to do that don't involve alcohol like a party or anything. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Probably if your friends won't quit drinking, you should just find new friends. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Because, you know, the problem is if they're drinking, they're going to pressure you into drinking, and then you're going to feel awkward, and, you know, you're going to be stuck and not know what to do and really just be better off probably without them if they're the kind of people who are going to keep drinking. ; Therapist: They're probably not a good influence. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And then you'll be better set for college too because, you know, the issue is you're getting good grades now, but when you get to college, it's a lot harder. ; Therapist: And, you know, if you're needing really good grades to get into law school, which you will be, then you really can't be distracted by alcohol. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Definitely. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So that's great because it pretty much covers all the stuff that I think I needed to go over with you. ; Therapist: Let's see. ; Therapist: I guess we didn't talk about what would happen if your parents found out you were drinking. ; Patient: They would be pretty upset. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: They don't really condone alcohol use. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So, yeah, just another reason why you probably need to just quit then. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So, like I said, I'm going to write down here that you've decided to quit and, you know, I'm going to be meeting with you again probably next semester sometime so we can kind of check in and make sure that, you know, that's still going well and you're still not drinking and not hanging out with any people who are drinking. ; Therapist: Is there anything else you'd like to talk about while you're here? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: No. ; Patient: I think I'm good. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Any questions or anything like that? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: I have no questions. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: You're sure? ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Well, that's probably it then. ; Therapist: You can head back to class and thanks for coming in. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: Thank you.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name- laura; age 17years; sex- female; education- high school ; Clinical Identifiers: School counselling room ; Referral Information : School ; Therapist Information : Setting opd ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Nil ; History: Personal history education- she is good at studies, and wishes get into law school, social relations- she is able to make and sustain social relations, use of leisure time she likes to spend time with her friends, go for hiking and reading; substance use history she occasionally consumes alcohol ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behavior client was conscious and in touch with her surroundings, her behaviour towards the therapist was cooperative, rapport could be established; though content- reflected growth ambition for career; mood calm; affect broad; insight- grade 6 ; Psychotherapy Type: Motivational interviewing ; Psychotherapy Technique : Open questions, reflective listening ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Clients occasional drinking habits were discussed for which motivational interviewing was conducted to assess as well encourage the client to quit drinking in order to focus non career goals. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Nil ; Action Plan : Client has to quit drinking and leave the company of people consuming alcohol ; Next session details: Next semester

dialogue: Therapist: So, I want to change gears a little and talk about your family. ; Therapist: Is that okay? ; Patient: Oh, that's a lot, but it's all right. ; Therapist: A lot of information there, huh? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So, can we start with your parents and tell me, will you feel comfortable telling me about ; Therapist: them? ; Patient: Well, my father was incarcerated when I was four for drug trafficking. ; Therapist: Drug trafficking? ; Patient: Yep. ; Patient: And he died a few years ago from a stroke. ; Therapist: How many years ago? ; Patient: About three years ago. ; Therapist: Three years. ; Therapist: At what age was he when he passed away? ; Patient: To be honest, I don't even remember. ; Patient: I don't really talk to him. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: How about your mother? ; Patient: My mom is crazy. ; Patient: She's always been very, like, eccentric, I guess would be the word. ; Therapist: Eccentric? ; Patient: We don't talk anymore because she has chosen gambling over the family. ; Therapist: Tell me about that. ; Patient: When I was in high school and I would, you know, still live with her, sometimes I would come home and there was no running water, there was no electricity, there was no nothing. ; Patient: She had gambled the money away. ; Patient: We've had several times where I've had to hide the cars in fear of them being repossessed. ; Patient: And I couldn't take it after a while and I moved out when I was about 16. ; Patient: She calls me every now and then, sometimes for money, sometimes to talk. ; Patient: I don't really talk to her though. ; Therapist: So how would you describe the quality of your relationship right now with her? ; Patient: Not good. ; Therapist: Not good? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: And it sounds like there's not much communication. ; Patient: Not anymore, no. ; Patient: She's dry, but I refuse to speak to her. ; Therapist: Do you know if your father or mother, either one, has any history of mental illness? ; Patient: My mom was diagnosed as bipolar. ; Patient: My father, like I said, I don't know much about him. ; Patient: I know he had a problem with anger too. ; Therapist: You remember that? ; Patient: Yeah, I do. ; Patient: But he would physically abuse us. ; Therapist: He physically abused you? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: From what I remember of him. ; Therapist: Alright, so that's your father and your mother. ; Therapist: How about any siblings? ; Patient: I have an older sister and a younger sister. ; Therapist: Two sisters? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Tell me about them. ; Patient: Well, my older sister pretty much raised me and my younger sister since mom was never around and dad was in jail. ; Patient: I love her to death. ; Patient: She's the godmother of my kids. ; Patient: She's my best friend. ; Therapist: This is your older sister? ; Patient: Yeah, my older sister. ; Therapist: How about your younger sister? ; Patient: My younger sister, we don't talk very much. ; Patient: She doesn't want to talk to me. ; Patient: She says I'm a bad influence. ; Therapist: A bad influence on her? ; Patient: Her, her friends. ; Patient: I think she's kind of stuck up. ; Therapist: What makes you think that? ; Patient: Because she thinks she's better than me. ; Patient: Just because, ooh, she went to college. ; Patient: Well, good for you. ; Therapist: All right, so it sounds like you have a positive relationship, kind of admire your older sister. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Is that right? ; Patient: Yeah, I love my older sister. ; Therapist: And the relationship with your younger sister is a little bit different. ; Patient: I mean, I love her too and I can deal with her in small things, but that's pretty much ; Patient: it. ; Therapist: How often do you communicate with each one? ; Patient: My older sister I talk to like almost every day. ; Patient: You know, she's always there, you know, shoulder to cry on or, you know, if I'm in a bind and I need some money, she's always willing to help me out. ; Patient: She can watch the kids if I need to go somewhere. ; Patient: She's my rock. ; Patient: The younger one, I mean, we talk maybe every other week. ; Patient: Let us know what each other's up to. ; Patient: Maybe we'll go to dinner. ; Therapist: All right, so quite a bit closer to your older sister than your younger sister. ; Therapist: Any mental health history with either sister? ; Patient: My older sister was depressed and had a lot of anxiety when she was young because she dealt with more of my dad than I did. ; Patient: The younger one, I really don't know. ; Patient: I don't know. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So does your older sister or your younger sister for that matter know that you're here? ; Patient: My older sister does. ; Patient: My older sister, I haven't spoken to her this week yet, so. ; Therapist: Are you planning on telling her? ; Patient: No, I don't see why not. ; Patient: No, maybe it'll kind of humanize her a little bit and like I'm not as bad as the person she thinks I am. ; Therapist: Do you feel a need to make a positive impression on her? ; Patient: No, but I think sometimes it's easier. ; Therapist: It's easier? ; Patient: Yeah, it's easier. ; Patient: Not being the bad sister. ; Therapist: That's how you believe you're viewed? ; Patient: Yeah, by her. ; Therapist: By her, okay. ; Therapist: All right, how about grandparents? ; Patient: My dad's side of the family we don't really know about. ; Patient: Grandma died before I was born. ; Patient: Grandpa wasn't in the picture. ; Patient: On my mom's side, grandpa died before I was born and grandma lived in a nursing home and was kind of like out of it by then. ; Therapist: Any mental health history with any grandparents that you're aware of? ; Patient: I mean, the one grandma that was still alive, she had like some kind of dementia or something. ; Patient: Alzheimer's, dementia. ; Therapist: How about aunts, uncles, cousins, anybody have a note? ; Patient: I had a lot of cousins. ; Patient: A lot of cousins in and out of the house at various points in the, even in the day sometimes I leave for school there'd be a certain set of cousins there come home from school, completely different set. ; Patient: We were like the family central. ; Therapist: Do you have contact with any of them? ; Patient: They're like social media and stuff. ; Patient: I mean, they're all spread out over the country now, but I keep in contact with them as much as I can. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: How about children? ; Patient: I have two children. ; Therapist: Okay, tell me about them. ; Patient: They are the loves of my life. ; Patient: And one is in second grade, the other is in kindergarten right now. ; Patient: The one in kindergarten though, he's kind of a handful. ; Patient: He recently is at a stage where he gets mad if I try to change his diapers, but will let my sister do it. ; Patient: I don't know why that's going on, but. ; Therapist: Which sister? ; Patient: My older sister. ; Patient: She watches them when I'm off. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So one in kindergarten. ; Patient: One in kindergarten, the other in second grade. ; Therapist: In second grade. ; Therapist: And you mentioned the one in kindergarten is a son. ; Therapist: And how about the one in second grade? ; Patient: My daughter. ; Therapist: Tell me about her. ; Patient: She comes home with like, they have like, not demerits, but like little referrals. ; Patient: She likes to be kind of a pushover. ; Patient: Not pushover, but like a bully at school. ; Therapist: A bully? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I've gotten several calls from the principal and our teachers saying, oh, she pushed another kid. ; Patient: Oh, another kid asked if he could have a piece of paper and she yelled and screamed. ; Patient: And you know, she comes home and I'll yell at her too. ; Patient: Do you like this? ; Patient: Do you like me yelling at you? ; Patient: Why would you yell at somebody else? ; Patient: She just doesn't get it. ; Therapist: What kind of problem were you? ; Therapist: Her behavior? ; Patient: Well, yeah. ; Patient: I mean, I got in trouble at school too. ; Patient: Not when I was her age. ; Patient: I was kind of better at school when I was at her age, but I don't want her to go down the same path. ; Therapist: But you're a little worried about that. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: How often do you see them? ; Patient: I see them, I mean, I work, so I don't see them when I'm there. ; Patient: They go to daycare, but sometimes if I like go out to a party or something where I know some stuff is going to be there or there's parties over at my house where I know some stuff is going to be there, I drop them off with my sister. ; Patient: You know, try to keep them away from that. ; Patient: I don't want them to be exposed to that. ; Therapist: When you say stuff, just so I'm clear, you mean drugs? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Drugs, alcohol, you know. ; Patient: I'd rather my kids not see me like that, so I save them from it. ; Therapist: So you're protecting them from that. ; Patient: Oh yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah.

Hisher mother used to gamble a lot. Heshe doesnt share a cordial relation with her. Patients mother was diagnosed with bipolar disorder and his father had anger issues. Patient has two more siblings, an elder and an older sister. Heshe is more close to the younger sibling. Patients grandmother had dementia. Heshe has two children, one is in kindergarten and the other is in second grade; substance use history patient consumes alcohol and drugs occasionally. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: General behavior patient was cooperative and rapport was established; mood calm; affect broad. ; Psychotherapy Type: Nil ; Psychotherapy Technique : Active listening ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Current sessions was focussed on gathering family history. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Nil ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Between here and there, obviously if it were easy, you wouldn't need me. ; Therapist: You wouldn't have had 13 therapists. ; Therapist: If this were easy, you would have been to a life you wanted a long time ago. ; Therapist: So it's obvious that if it were easy, it would already be done because it sounds like you're a person with a lot of motivation who works really hard because there are very few people who wouldn't have quit before 13 therapists. ; Therapist: So that's a very good quality. ; Therapist: The very fact that you've gone through all these therapists is a good sign for us. ; Therapist: Nonetheless, it is difficult. ; Therapist: Between here and there, there's going to be hell. ; Patient: Exactly. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: So I figure our number one priority has to be to get you to stay alive through hell so that we can get to the life you want. ; Therapist: And that's where we're at now. ; Therapist: We've got to have some sort of agreement, not by writing a contract or because I'll fire you if you try to kill yourself, but because we both sort of have to face the fact that to get there, you've got to go through there. ; Therapist: And to go through there, you've got to stay alive. ; Patient: Okay, I'll make you a deal. ; Therapist: Okay, what? ; Patient: You guarantee that you can get, you can help me, and I'll guarantee I'll look at myself. ; Therapist: What are you going to do if I fail? ; Patient: Well, then... ; Therapist: If I break my... ; Patient: All bets are off. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So if I don't help you, you'll kill yourself? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay, but if I do help you, you won't? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I think so. ; Patient: I mean, yeah. ; Patient: If you can help me, no, I won't kill myself. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Then how long are you going to give me to try? ; Patient: Well, I don't know.
summary: Past Session Information: Follow up sesssion ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms suicidal ; History: History of seeing 13 therapists in past ; Crisis Markers: Suicidal ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior; speech fast, mood  affect angry, thought, perception distrorted, cognitive functions impaired, judgement and insight poor. ; Psychotherapy Type: Supportive; mode individual. ; Psychotherapy Technique : Supportive ; Issues discussed in Current Session: 1 problem patient seeks a guarantee from the therapist that they can help her, and in return, she promises to look at herself and stay committed to the process and she will not kill herself. 2 objective of session the primary focus is on ensuring to stays alive through the difficult process of therapy. Therapist is straightforward about the difficulties and the need for commitment. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Sucidality

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Sam, how are you doing today? ; Patient: Alright. ; Therapist: You doing alright? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: I see that this is the first time you've come in, you've filled out some of the other paperwork. ; Patient: Yeah, 20 of them. ; Therapist: A lot of pages? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: How'd that go? ; Patient: I mean I've seen that stuff before, but it wasn't too bad. ; Therapist: Nothing surprising in there? ; Patient: No, pretty standard. ; Therapist: Pretty standard. ; Therapist: Nothing distressing? ; Patient: Not yet. ; Therapist: Not yet? ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: I'm going to ask you a series of questions as part of a process called intake. ; Therapist: So this document that I'll be making notes on will go in your chart and it'll help guide your care for the time that you're with me. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Alright? ; Therapist: So these questions are going to be more detailed and more emotionally oriented than a lot of those questions that you were answering on the forms you filled out before. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: That was more like factual information that we need for insurance or record keeping. ; Therapist: This is more about you and what you've been going through. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: You comfortable with that? ; Patient: Yeah, it's okay. ; Therapist: It's okay? ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: If at any time you don't like one of the questions or you don't want to answer one of the questions, just let me know and we'll just skip over that. ; Patient: Okay, fair enough. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: So what brings you in today? ; Patient: I brought myself in. ; Patient: Things have just not been fantastic so I figured I might as well get some help. ; Patient: Before it got worse. ; Therapist: Things haven't been fantastic? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And you're worried they're going to get worse? ; Patient: Seems like it, yeah. ; Therapist: What would you say that your main problem is that motivates you to come in? ; Patient: Probably my anxiety. ; Patient: I'm just nervous about a lot of things a lot of the time and it's kind of trickling into every area of my life now. ; Therapist: So anxiety? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: You said it's like a nervousness? ; Patient: Yeah, just like nervousness about going places, nervousness about doing things or school or work or you know graduating college. ; Patient: Just kind of that whole stage and it's been like that for a while. ; Therapist: How long? ; Patient: I can remember as far back as like 13 or 14 maybe. ; Therapist: How old are you now? ; Patient: 23 ; Therapist: So this is around 10 years you've been coping with this? ; Patient: Yeah, off and on, yeah. ; Therapist: Off and on? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So there's times when you're not anxious? ; Patient: Not as bad. ; Patient: I mean I'm still anxious but not as extreme or I don't deal with it in the same way. ; Therapist: If you were to rate your anxiety on a scale of 1 to 10 with 1 being really no anxiety and 10 being the worst it's been in the last 10 years, how much anxiety do you have right ; Therapist: now? ; Patient: I think a 6. ; Therapist: When was the last time you were a 10? ; Patient: Last weekend? ; Therapist: When was the last time you were a 1? ; Patient: I'm not really sure. ; Therapist: Approximately? ; Patient: Maybe like a couple months ago when I was just hanging out with my friends. ; Patient: We went out and we were partying a little bit and it was nice. ; Patient: I wasn't too anxious. ; Therapist: About a couple months ago? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So the anxiety is one problem. ; Therapist: Any other problems? ; Patient: I don't think it's a huge problem but I have been drinking a lot. ; Patient: But it helps with the anxiety but it makes going out and you know I'm more relaxed that way. ; Patient: But I can be kind of a compulsive person so once I start I keep going. ; Patient: So it's not all the time. ; Patient: It's just happening when I'm going out but I end up drinking too much. ; Therapist: So sometimes when you go out you drink more than you want to? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: What happens then? ; Patient: I make bad decisions or I get sick or the next morning I'm showing up hungover going to class. ; Patient: If I make class and you know it's fun for the time being but it's not fun afterwards. ; Therapist: So the consequences of drinking in the longer run. ; Therapist: You're not too fond of those but in the short run. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: It helps in the moment. ; Therapist: So you want the anxiety to be lessened. ; Therapist: Do you want the drinking to be lessened?
