; Patient: Probably. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I mean I'd like to still have fun in college but I would like to not be like blacking out or being able to stop would be nice. ; Therapist: Is that what happens now? ; Therapist: You black out? ; Patient: Occasionally. ; Patient: Not every time but sometimes. ; Therapist: Sometimes? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Do you remember the last time you blacked out? ; Patient: Maybe a month ago. ; Therapist: Month ago? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: It's not all the time though. ; Therapist: What age did you start drinking? ; Patient: 14 ; Therapist: 14? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: Any other problems? ; Therapist: You have anxiety ; Therapist: You have drinking alcohol ; Therapist: Any other problems? ; Patient: I don't think so. ; Therapist: So those are the two main things that are bothering you. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: So I want to ask you some questions about your history. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: And I'm going to try to divide this up into different areas and just kind of move from one area to the next. ; Therapist: There will be some overlap. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So if I ask you the same question more than once it's just kind of part of that overlap that occurs. ; Therapist: First I'd like to cover your family history. ; Therapist: So can you tell me about your immediate family? ; Patient: I have one sister. ; Patient: Mom and dad. ; Patient: Pretty typical. ; Patient: My sister is really successful. ; Patient: She's a doctor. ; Patient: Though are my parents really successful too. ; Patient: So basic family. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: What type of relationship do you have with your sister? ; Patient: Kind of like a Merry Christmas, Happy Easter type of relationship. ; Patient: We're more like acquaintances than we are siblings. ; Therapist: Would you describe it as distant? ; Patient: Yeah, I'd say so. ; Patient: I mean we're nice. ; Patient: We're not like, but we're not going to be like involved in each other's lives really. ; Therapist: Do you know what caused the relationship to end up that way? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: She was always kind of the ideal child. ; Patient: She went and did everything that she was supposed to do and it was easy for her. ; Patient: So constantly being compared to that doesn't really foster a great relationship. ; Therapist: Who compared you to your sister? ; Patient: My dad usually. ; Patient: Sometimes my mom. ; Patient: Depends on the day. ; Therapist: Was this a frequent occurrence, the comparison? ; Patient: Yeah, for sure. ; Therapist: Do you feel like it had an impact on you? ; Patient: Probably. ; Patient: It wasn't like I wasn't trying, but not everything can be as easy as it is for some people. ; Patient: So a little acknowledgement might be nice. ; Therapist: Alright, so let's move out a little further. ; Therapist: So you talked about your mother, your father, your sister. ; Therapist: Any other siblings? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: How about grandparents? ; Patient: They're around. ; Patient: Typical grandparents, not super involved, but they're there sometimes. ; Therapist: Good relationship? ; Patient: Yeah, I mean, you know, grandparents show up and it's always like, hi, how's it going? ; Patient: And you see them at the next holiday type of thing. ; Therapist: Alright, so there's not one grandparent you're particularly close to? ; Patient: I do have one grandfather I talk to on a more personal level than I would my other ones. ; Patient: But that's gotten more distant in the past couple of years. ; Therapist: How about aunts, uncles, cousins? ; Patient: I have a couple of cousins that I would hang out with or I'll see out when I'm hanging out with my friends or whatever. ; Patient: So we'll hang out if we run into each other. ; Patient: Aunts and uncles I do have. ; Patient: They're not super involved either, but everybody's cordial. ; Therapist: Everybody's cordial? ; Patient: Yeah, nice when they see you type of thing. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: So when's the last time you spoke, say for example, with one of your cousins? ; Patient: I think I ran into one of them only two weeks ago, or just out. ; Therapist: A couple weeks ago? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: Do any of the relatives that you mentioned, are any of them aware of your anxiety and or your drinking? ; Patient: My parents are. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Nobody else? ; Patient: My sister knows about the anxiety part of it. ; Patient: And I think, I'm pretty sure she knows about the drinking, but she doesn't bring it up. ; Patient: But if my parents know, I'm sure she knows. ; Therapist: Hmm. ; Therapist: So you believe that they told her? ; Patient: I'm sure. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: But she's not mentioned that to you directly? ; Patient: No, we don't have those types of conversations. ; Patient: It's more like, oh, she messed up again, and it's just sort of like this funny thing and then they move on. ; Therapist: Hmm. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: So you see this bothers you? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: It's annoying. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Some of these topics that we're going to touch on in this intake, we can talk about in greater detail later on. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Alright, so, and maybe your relationship with your mother and father and your sister would be topics we could touch on later on, maybe not, but I want to let you know that we can come back to anything and review it. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: So I want to move kind of out of family history a bit and through to social relationships. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: Again, it's kind of similar, a little bit of overlap here. ; Therapist: Can you tell me about any romantic interests, friends, anything like that? ; Patient: Yeah, I have a guy I've been seeing for like six months, so it's pretty serious for college. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: And some of my college friends I'm really close with, so they're there with me for a lot. ; Therapist: About how many? ; Patient: There's three girls that I'm super close with. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: And, you know, college, there's a lot of people I'm acquaintances with or I'll see or talk to in class or whatever, but those three girls are kind of the ones I would go to if I needed something. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: And then you have some other friends that you're not as close to? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I mean, we're nice and we have fun and, you know, I'm sure if something happened they would bail me out, but they're not like people I'm going to talk to about my problems or anything like that. ; Therapist: Do they know about your problems? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: I guess you could know, like, when I show up to class if I'm over, but I'm sure I'm not the only one doing that, so. ; Therapist: And how about the guy you've seen for six months, does he know about your problems? ; Patient: Somewhat, yeah. ; Patient: He knows about, definitely knows about the anxiety and he's with me a lot when I go out, so if something does happen he's usually helping me out or making sure I get home or whatever. ; Therapist: So he's supportive? ; Patient: Yeah, really supportive. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: So some of the questions I'm going to ask you, this gives me a good opportunity to talk about this, I probably could guess the answer to, but I still want to ask, not be presumptuous. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Do you have any children? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Okay, how about nieces or nephews? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No. ; Therapist: Any other social relationships that I've missed here that are important to you? ; Patient: I don't think so, those are the main ones right now. ; Therapist: Yeah? ; Therapist: Alright, she said you were 23. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: I'm going to ask you some questions about your medical history. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Have you had any surgeries in your lifetime? ; Patient: I got my appendix removed. ; Therapist: Appendix removed? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Any other serious medical conditions? ; Patient: No, I've had my wisdom teeth taken out. ; Therapist: Wisdom teeth extracted? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Are you on any medications for physical problems? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: How about your activity level? ; Therapist: Do you stay fairly active? ; Patient: Yeah, I try to. ; Therapist: Yeah? ; Patient: I go to the gym like twice a week or whatever, and I go to yoga sometimes, so yeah, I try to get out. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: So you consider yourself an active person? ; Patient: Yeah, I try to be in between classes and everything else, but when I do have the time, I enjoy going out and doing things. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Would you generally say you're in good health then? ; Patient: Yeah, physically, yeah. ; Therapist: Physically? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: No other illnesses, surgeries, procedures, with no? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: So I want to shift gears a little bit again and now talk about psychiatric history. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: And what I'm getting at here is kind of a history of any diagnoses, medications, other times have been treated by a counselor or somebody like a counselor. ; Therapist: Let's start with medications. ; Therapist: Are you on any medications? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Mental health? ; Patient: No? ; Therapist: How about history of diagnoses? ; Therapist: Have you ever been diagnosed with a mental health condition? ; Patient: Yeah, I was. ; Patient: I was seeing a therapist before a couple years ago. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: And I saw him a couple of times and I think he said I had some sort of anxiety disorder or something. ; Therapist: Do you remember specifically what he said? ; Patient: Something more general. ; Patient: So, like it wasn't about any particular thing. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: So I saw him for a little while but I just really wasn't on board with local therapy at that point and I didn't think it was going to help. ; Therapist: How old were you, yourself? ; Patient: 15 or 16. ; Patient: 15 ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Alright, so and that was a counselor? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Alright, so you saw the counselor. ; Therapist: The counselor indicated you had some type of anxiety disorder. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Do you feel that was a fair assessment? ; Patient: I think so. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And how long did you see the counselor? ; Patient: I think about five or six times maybe. ; Therapist: Five or six sessions? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And why did you discontinue the treatment? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: I just didn't really feel like I was really involved in it and it felt like it was more a waste of my time and his. ; Patient: I wasn't ready. ; Patient: I don't know that I was super on board with the whole anxiety thing at that point. ; Patient: I mean he was nice. ; Patient: There wasn't like an issue with him. ; Patient: I just don't, I wasn't there. ; Therapist: And you mentioned at that time about the drinking? ; Patient: I think I brought it up but I didn't really see it as an issue then. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: How about other mental health professionals like a psychiatrist, a psychologist, a marriage and family therapist? ; Patient: My parents told me to see a psychiatrist like maybe once or twice but didn't really stick with that either. ; Therapist: You weren't prescribed any medication? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: And what do you think happened there that you didn't stick with that? ; Patient: I think kind of the same thing. ; Patient: I knew that obviously there was something going on but I don't think I was ready to deal with it. ; Patient: And I kind of felt like I had it under control at that point. ; Therapist: Can you tell me about when you saw the psychiatrist in relation to when you saw the counselor? ; Patient: It was all within that same time period. ; Patient: I think I saw the counselor first and then maybe the psychiatrist like a week or two later and then followed up with the counselor but I just wasn't really present during any of it. ; Therapist: Do you feel you're in a different state of mind now? ; Patient: Yeah, I think so. ; Therapist: Tell me about that. ; Patient: I realize now that I'm not handling it like I thought I was and it's affecting other areas of my life. ; Patient: And you know in my senior year of college I need to get my life together and I'm not really doing that too often, so I think it's time to figure something out. ; Therapist: Alright, so you feel like you're ready to commit the treatment a little more vigorously at this point? ; Patient: Yeah, I want the help now. ; Therapist: And back then? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No? Okay. ; Therapist: And no other treatment providers? ; Patient: No, just those. ; Therapist: Okay, just those two.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name elizabeth; sex- female; ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Past session- diagnostic assessment for eating disorder ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Irresistible craving for food 2. Repeated bouts of overeating 3. Episodes of self-induced vomiting 4. Preoccupation with control of body weight associated disturbance- reduced self-confidence ; History: Present history episodes of bulimia; onset- chronic; course- continuous; past history index patient was 10 years old when her parents got divorced. She continued living with her mother. Her parents got remarried after 2 years. Patient was more close to her father and her paternal grandmother. She moved to a different town after her mother remarried which led to a change in her school from a public to a private one. Patient couldnt fit well in the pre-existing social groups in her new school. She also went through critical remarks from her mother about her body and eating habits. She also pressurised her to fit in the social circle in her new school. It was during her 9th std, when she was around 14 years, that she first engaged in restricted food intake. She also learnt about self-induced vomiting as an option to control body weight and started practicing that. Every time she felt stressed or had argument with her mother, her binge eating and purging episodes would increase; family history patients parents got divorced when she was 10years old. She lived with her mother and continued meeting her father fairly often. Her mother remarried after 2 years and took a second divorce when patient was 17 years old. Patient has a step sister from her mothers second marriage. She shares a strained relationship with her mother. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: General behavior patient was conscious and touch with her surroundings. She was cooperative and rapport could be established; mood- dysphoric; affect restricted; insight grade 5 ; Psychotherapy Type: Interpersonal therapy ; Psychotherapy Technique : Psychoeducation, reflective listening ; Assessments: Diagnostic assessment for eating disorder ; Issues discussed in Current Session: 1. Major focus on first and most recent episode 2. Exploration of childhood experiences, especially with parents 3. Understanding support systems patient relied on in the past 4. Understanding reaction patterns to stress ; Reflections by the therapist: Patient was cordial and rapport could be easily established. She came with a rough idea of the disorder and was psychoeducated. She comprehended the information well. Reflective listening was used by paraphrasing and summarising which helped in improving the communication. Her complaints were understood more in terms of a social or interpersonal context. ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Hi, Jackie. ; Therapist: How are you doing today? ; Therapist: I guess okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: I understand you've had some recent difficulties that have brought you in here today. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: Well, my physician, I've been seeing her, meeting with her. ; Therapist: She suggested I come see you, so. ; Patient: Why do you think she did that? ; Patient: Well, I'm sick, I think. ; Patient: So we've been running some tests and things, and she couldn't find anything. ; Patient: So she's already working on it. ; Patient: I'm not sure what she's doing. ; Patient: We've been running some tests and things, and she couldn't find anything. ; Patient: So she thought maybe I should come talk to you. ; Patient: I guess maybe my concerns are, you know, coming from somewhere else, I think, is what she thinks. ; Patient: But I don't know. ; Patient: Maybe whatever illness I have is making me feel this way. ; Therapist: So you believe you have a physical illness? ; Patient: Yeah, I just know there's something not right. ; Therapist: And your physician has run a series of tests? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: We've done like blood work and all the scans and everything. ; Patient: She said she didn't find anything, but I just know there's something there. ; Therapist: So what was her, other than coming to see me, what was her suggestion for treatment? ; Therapist: So she ran tests, she didn't find anything? ; Patient: Well, yeah, she didn't have anything for me. ; Therapist: So she's saying there's no physical illness? ; Patient: Yeah, that's what she says. ; Therapist: You're not as sure? ; Patient: No, I think she's missing something. ; Patient: So... ; Therapist: How long have you believed that you had a physical illness? ; Patient: About a year, I think, is when my first appointment with my physician was. ; Patient: Yeah, when she started running some tests and things. ; Therapist: So about a year ago, you went to her. ; Therapist: She started running tests and there was no findings of a disorder? ; Patient: No, she hasn't found anything yet. ; Therapist: Was it just one disorder that you thought you had or have there been several? ; Patient: You know, I kind of started with MS. ; Patient: I read some things about that and about how people just, people my age, they've had it and they don't even know that they have it and then all of a sudden their life is changed by it. ; Patient: So I was concerned about that. ; Patient: And then I guess after some tests and things, I kind of, I don't know, I guess I started to think maybe it wasn't that and it was something else. ; Patient: I think it's cancer. ; Patient: That's what I'm worried about. ; Patient: You think it's cancer? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: You know, even though I don't really have some of the symptoms, I can just lie in you and you have no idea and just one day, you know. ; Therapist: And your physicians run tests for all these disorders you thought you had or you think you had? ; Patient: Yeah, yeah. ; Patient: But I mean, what if that test that I took a year ago, what if it didn't show up on that because it hasn't gotten that severe yet and now it is? ; Therapist: So you're worried? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So you saw the physician for the first time regarding this a year ago. ; Therapist: Did you have anxiety or worry before that? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: I'm just worried that it started, got that feeling that I was sick. ; Patient: So that was just what I was worried about. ; Patient: But nothing other than that. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: But you were worried about the illness? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Nothing else though? ; Therapist: No. ; Therapist: Do you have any physical symptoms? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: But that happens to people. ; Patient: They don't experience any symptoms. ; Patient: They have no idea. ; Patient: No idea. ; Patient: And then it just, you're dead. ; Therapist: Do you find yourself checking often to see if you have physical symptoms? ; Patient: Yeah, yeah. ; Patient: I've read a lot of stuff, a lot of different people's stories. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: Go to the internet, check the symptoms, and I keep track of that, make sure I'm not having anything that they list. ; Therapist: Are you active on the internet forums where they discuss illnesses? ; Patient: Yeah, yeah. ; Patient: I've read a lot of people's stories on there about how they had maybe one symptom, but they didn't really think anything of it, you know, and then they have a severe diagnosis. ; Patient: So I'm just worried I'm going to miss something, you know, so I check a lot and check to make sure. ; Therapist: So you read the forms a lot. ; Therapist: Do you ever post? ; Patient: Yeah, yeah, about my concerns. ; Patient: Sometimes people get a little frustrated with me. ; Patient: They're not very nice. ; Therapist: Tell me about that. ; Patient: Just because I'm not really experiencing anything. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: They think that I don't have anything to worry about, and they keep telling me, but I think I do have something to worry about. ; Patient: I just have this feeling that there's something wrong. ; Patient: I just know it. ; Therapist: What would you like us to do here at the agency? ; Patient: I would just like to feel comfortable that I'm not sick. ; Patient: I don't want to worry anymore, but I just really think there's something wrong. ; Therapist: Yeah, you're worried you have a physical health disorder. ; Therapist: Are you worried you have a mental health disorder? ; Therapist: Maybe. ; Patient: Some people have said that. ; Patient: Are you worried about that? ; Patient: It's a little concern that I might be feeling a little extra worried. ; Patient: Maybe that's a symptom of the whatever illness I have. ; Therapist: So you're concerned that the worry could be a symptom of a physical illness? ; Therapist: Mm-hmm, yeah. ; Therapist: So again, what would your goal be here? ; Therapist: What do you want to change through counseling? ; Patient: I guess my worry. ; Patient: It doesn't make me feel good. ; Therapist: You want to worry less? ; Patient: Yeah, yeah. ; Patient: I don't want to be sick. ; Patient: I don't want to be mentally ill either. ; Therapist: All right, so you've had worry for at least a year, specifically about being physically ill. ; Therapist: There have been no findings of physical illness, but you're still worried about it. ; Therapist: And you might be a little worried that you have a mental health disorder. ; Patient: Yeah, I think something might be off. ; Patient: Something might be going on. ; Therapist: And you want to be able to stop worrying about the physical health disorders? ; Therapist: Mm-hmm, yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Are you worried right now that you have a physical health disorder? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: What disorder do you think you might have now? ; Patient: Cancer, I think. ; Patient: Some part of my body that is worried that it's spreading. ; Therapist: And you've been tested for this by your physician? ; Patient: Yeah, but sometimes tests don't find things. ; Therapist: Are you ever reassured when you get negative test results back, when they say there's nothing going on? ; Patient: No, I think they might have missed something. ; Patient: My family physician, she's really frustrated with me because she won't even see me anymore, honestly. ; Patient: She's not very nice when I go in. ; Patient: But I want her to do those tests again. ; Therapist: You want her to rerun tests? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: And look again? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So, you're open to counseling here? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah, I think maybe you can help me a little bit and find out what's wrong and what's going on. ; Therapist: Would you be okay signing release so that I could talk to your physician? ; Patient: Yeah, yeah, that's fine. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So, I'll get you scheduled. ; Therapist: Now, I'll schedule you either way, whether you want to sign a release or not. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: But that's just something I think might be helpful for me to better understand what's going on. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: But I'll get you in to see a counselor. ; Therapist: It'll just take a couple days. ; Therapist: We'll get that worked out now. ; Therapist: Okay, great. ; Patient: All right? ; Patient: Thank you. ; Therapist: Thanks.
summary: Patient Particulars : Nil ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Referred by physician; reason for referral preoccupation with having a disease ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Persistent preoccupation with having a disease 1 year 2. Refusal to accept negative findings in tests 1 year ; History: Present history patient has been seeking medical advice from past 1 year about having a disease. She has underwent multiple tests and none showed any positive findings. Despite that patient feels that she has some disease probably cancer and it is spreading in her body without her knowing and that the test results are old so she doesnt want to rely on them. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behavior patient was cooperative and rapport could be established; thought content- preoccupation with having a disease ; Psychotherapy Type: Nil ; Psychotherapy Technique : Nil ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patient concern of having a disease was discussed and her previous history was understood. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: F45. 2 hypochondriacal disorder ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Hi, this is Dr. Grande. ; Therapist: I hope you find this video useful. ; Therapist: If that's the case, please like it and subscribe to my channel. ; Therapist: As always, thanks for watching. ; Therapist: Let's say you go into a house. ; Therapist: Do you go into the community? ; Therapist: Do you go into a house and have an off day? ; Therapist: Maybe worried about making mistakes, maybe stressed about that, maybe tired. ; Therapist: And there's some evidence there that you should be able to pick up, but you just don't. ; Therapist: Somebody lies to you about what the conditions there are, and you kind of realize that they might not be telling the truth, but you're ready to get home. ; Therapist: So you leave and then somebody's hurt. ; Therapist: Would that be kind of a worst case? ; Therapist: That's the type of mistake you're afraid of making. ; Therapist: What would that feel like to make that mistake? ; Patient: It would feel terrible. ; Patient: It would feel like, you know, I had a role in that kind of thing happening to somebody. ; Patient: Like, it was... I'm partially to blame for somebody being harmed. ; Patient: And that is like the exact opposite of what my job is supposed to be. ; Therapist: If there were to be a worst case outcome, you would be extremely upset. ; Therapist: You're extremely upset now. ; Therapist: Well, you're a 5 out of 10 right now, but you're an 8 when you're in bed in the morning. ; Therapist: Is it reasonable that a professional makes a mistake like that? ; Therapist: This is a mistake of kind of missing something that normally would be caught. ; Therapist: Is it reasonable that they continue on in the field and try to learn from that? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: I mean... ; Patient: I'd like to think that... I guess it's not possible to make that kind of mistake, but I think that that's naive. ; Patient: I think it is possible. ; Patient: And I would like to learn from that, but I don't know what other people would do. ; Patient: Like, I don't know if I would lose my job or anything. ; Therapist: Right, there might be consequences for that type of error. ; Therapist: It's not intentional. ; Therapist: Something that, like many mistakes, would happen due to a confluence of circumstances. ; Therapist: You being tired, it being the end of the day, them not being honest. ; Therapist: There's mitigation there. ; Therapist: But still, I can appreciate you wouldn't want to make that mistake either way. ; Therapist: After making a mistake like that, what would your thought be? ; Therapist: What would you be thinking? ; Patient: I would be thinking, I don't know how this will ever be better. ; Patient: I don't know how I'm ever going to feel okay about what I did. ; Therapist: So by extension, I'll never feel okay about what I did. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And what do you think you would do then in terms of your reaction to that thought? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: I mean, I guess ideally I would say to myself it's going to get better, and this will pass and everything, but I don't know. ; Patient: It's just hard. ; Therapist: What do you think it would do to your work performance? ; Patient: I think I would probably have to take some time off. ; Patient: I mean, it's just like I would be so stressed afterwards. ; Patient: I'm worried I would make another mistake because I'm so stressed out and having trouble focusing. ; Therapist: So, in a strange way, the anxiety, the thoughts you're having now, and the resulting anxiety are leaving you more at risk to make a mistake. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I mean, I guess I never thought about it like that, although that makes a lot of sense. ; Patient: Like, if I just calm down and try to let it go, then I'll do my job better and I won't have that risk as much. ; Patient: But if I keep feeling like this, I'm not focusing, and then I could make a bigger mistake because of it. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: So, one of the thoughts you're having now is, I can't make a mistake because it would be too devastating. ; Therapist: And that type... Is that kind of a thought that you're having? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So, it's like, I can't make a mistake. ; Therapist: And this is leaving you emotionally less prepared, and probably increased risk of making a mistake.
summary: Patient Particulars : Nil ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Name dr grande ; Past Session Information: Nil ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Excessive worry 2. Difficulty concentrating ; History: Present history patient has been having excessive worry and stress about making a mistake and then feeling guilty afterwards. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behavior patient was cordial and rapport could be established; mood tensed; affect restricted ; Psychotherapy Type: Type cbt; mode individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Cognitive restructuring ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patient has been getting apprehensive about making a mistake which keeps her under stress and trouble focussing. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Nil ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Hi, Lucy. ; Therapist: Nice to meet you. ; Patient: Hi. ; Therapist: So I understand that you were referred here by your GP because you've been feeling quite down recently. ; Patient: Yeah, I thought I should. ; Patient: I've been feeling quite bad for quite a while. ; Patient: So I thought maybe it's time to see someone about it because I don't want to feel like this anymore. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So from your notes, I saw that you saw the GP about three months ago. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So how long have you been feeling down altogether? ; Patient: Quite a few months before that as well, actually. ; Patient: But it's gotten pretty bad these past few months. ; Patient: So that's kind of why I came. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So has it got worse since you saw your GP? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So tell me, how are things at the moment? ; Patient: Well, it kind of started just feeling a bit low and wound up about things. ; Patient: But I don't know, just recently I just can't really be bothered to do anything at all. ; Patient: I kind of find it hard to get motivated for things. ; Patient: And I want to be, I really want to be better, but it's just kind of reaching the end now where I just want to do something about it. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So you said that you're feeling really down, really sad. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And you feel like you haven't got any motivation. ; Therapist: But, are you okay? ; Patient: Yeah, I'm fine. ; Patient: Sorry. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And you haven't got any motivation, but it sounds like you put quite a lot of pressure on yourself to try and feel a bit better. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I just, it's kind of hard as well because there's not really anyone to talk to about it. ; Patient: So I just kind of stay on my own trying to, I don't like to think about it, but I don't know. ; Therapist: So you say you've been, you're feeling quite isolated. ; Therapist: There's not many people around. ; Patient: Yeah, there's no one I can talk to about it. ; Patient: No one would listen or understand anyway. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So I'm just going to try and find out a little bit more about you. ; Therapist: So I understand that you're an English student at uni. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And you live away from home with some friends. ; Therapist: Is that right? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I live here. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So you don't live far from the uni. ; Therapist: But you say you feel like you live with your friends, but you don't feel like you can talk to them. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I mean, they're lovely. ; Patient: I get on really well with them, but I don't know. ; Patient: I just recently, whenever they want to go out or stuff, I just, I don't want to bring them down. ; Patient: I can't, they don't understand what I'm going through. ; Patient: They kind of, I don't know, they don't make fun of how I feel, but they don't really understand what it's like. ; Patient: I just, I don't want to go out with them and bring them down or stuff. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So it sounds, do you try and hide the way you're feeling from them? ; Patient: I guess. ; Patient: I mean, it's easier to hide it than to try and explain it all the time when no one really wants to know. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So it sounds like you've been feeling down. ; Therapist: You've been feeling unmotivated. ; Therapist: You feel like you want to be better, but actually it sounds like you feel like you can't reach out for help. ; Therapist: You can't speak to anybody. ; Patient: No. ; Patient: I don't really talk to my parents a lot either. ; Patient: So that's kind of hard. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: I'm just going to go back in time a little bit. ; Therapist: I suppose I'm just wondering when, when did all of this start? ; Therapist: You said it's been going on for quite a few months. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Um, I guess it kind of started, uh, when I was actually, when I was revising for my exams, um, I guess the stress, I put a lot of stress on myself. ; Patient: I think I've always wanted to do well for me and I guess for my parents. ; Patient: So the stress of exams and it was also kind of hard because my parents were going through a bit of a troubled time then. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So this would be like last March, last April? ; Patient: Uh, yeah, I think so. ; Therapist: Around that time. ; Therapist: So about six months-ish. ; Therapist: And it sounds like a lot was happening. ; Therapist: So you had a lot of uni pressure on and, um, and you said that your parents were having marital problems. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And it sounds like that was a real shock to you. ; Patient: Yeah, I guess it was hard as well because I wasn't doing well at uni. ; Patient: I guess I just felt a bit guilty. ; Patient: I know it sounds silly, but I felt like maybe if I could do better, then they would get better. ; Patient: But it just wasn't really happening. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So it sounds like you were trying to work hard and be more successful because you thought that that would make them happier and try and fix things. ; Patient: Yeah, I wanted to make them feel better, but it just kind of backfired a little, I guess. ; Therapist: How did it backfire? ; Patient: It just ended up with them getting worse and I've just been feeling worse since then. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So after the summer, after the exam period, and how did that exam period go for you in the end? ; Patient: Not very well. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: That's an awful lot of pressure to put on yourself. ; Therapist: I suppose to think... ; Patient: It's just annoying because I know I should have done better and I just didn't. ; Patient: And I guess I beat myself up a lot about it. ; Therapist: So you say, I know, I know I should have done better. ; Therapist: I mean, I suppose hearing it from my perspective, I'm thinking it sounds like you had an awful lot going on at the time. ; Therapist: It'd be understandable, absolutely, that you wouldn't do as well as normal. ; Therapist: I suppose I'm just wondering if you have very high standards for yourself. ; Patient: Probably maybe more than other people. ; Patient: My parents have always kind of taught me, not in a loving way, I guess, but that you should do your best, but also get the best. ; Patient: And I agree with that. ; Patient: I think that's the right thing to think. ; Patient: But when I don't do that, I don't know. ; Patient: It annoys me a lot and I worry that it annoys them. ; Therapist: So it sounds like you feel you should always do your best. ; Therapist: Is that the word you used? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And that there isn't any kind of exceptions for that? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So I can see then that that was a really difficult time for you. ; Therapist: And that was when your mood started to get lower and things are still quite bad now. ; Therapist: I mean, what's the situation with your parents at the moment? ; Patient: I think it doesn't sound good. ; Patient: I don't really talk to them a lot, but I don't think they're going through very good. ; Patient: I don't like to talk to them about it because it just makes me feel worse. ; Patient: But I don't think it's getting any better. ; Therapist: Were you home over the summer? ; Patient: For a little bit, yeah. ; Therapist: And how was that? ; Patient: Not very fun. ; Patient: No. ; Patient: It was quite tense all the time. ; Patient: It stressed me out more than relaxed me over the summer, I guess. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay, so it sounds then like quite a lot has been happening. ; Therapist: You've been feeling very low. ; Therapist: You've had uni pressure on. ; Therapist: You've had problems with your parents' marriage. ; Therapist: And it sounds like you feel like you can't really reach out to anyone, like you can't understand, but you can't really reach out to your parents right now. ; Therapist: You can't really confide in your friends. ; Therapist: So I suppose I'm just wondering if you can tell me a bit more about how you've been feeling, I mean, say this past week. ; Patient: Really not good, to be honest. ; Patient: I actually, if I don't have to, then I don't really leave the house or get out of. ; Patient: But I just, I can't find the motivation for the things I used to join. ; Patient: I used to love doing sports or going out, and now I just prefer to lie in bed and not really do anything. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: I missed a few lectures this week that I should have gone to, but... ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: So I suppose I'm just wondering then, let's see if we can think about one thing, say a lecture. ; Therapist: What kind of thoughts do you have about going to that lecture before it happens? ; Patient: I don't really see the point anymore. ; Patient: If I can't do as well as I should be doing, then what's the point in putting myself in those positions? ; Patient: I just, I can't be bothered anymore to try. ; Patient: It just stresses me out more than I need to. ; Therapist: Okay, so it sounds like the kind of thoughts you've got in your head are, it's pointless, it's not worth it. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Do you have any other thoughts in your head when you're just at that point before you go to the lecture? ; Patient: I feel like, I don't know, I don't really even deserve to be here if I can't do well enough. ; Patient: I see all these other students who are doing well and doing better and want to be there. ; Patient: I don't know why I'm here even at uni, to be honest. ; Therapist: So it sounds like you feel like you're not as good as other people here. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: I'm just, sorry, is it okay if I take notes as we go through? ; Therapist: It's just I'm trying to, I guess, understand what you're telling me and it helps me just to write it down and I'll share this with you later. ; Therapist: Okay, so it sounds like those are some quite negative thoughts to have. ; Therapist: You're kind of saying, you know, it feels like it's pointless, it's more effort than it's worth, and I don't deserve to be here. ; Therapist: I mean, when you have those thoughts, how do you feel? ; Patient: Very unworthy probably would be the best way to put it, kind of, I don't know, lower than normal. ; Patient: Because then it makes me think about all the things that I should have been doing better. ; Therapist: Okay, so what you described there then, you said, I'm unworthy, I should be doing lots of things better. ; Therapist: Those are kind of what I would call thoughts, actually. ; Therapist: I suppose I'm trying to understand what it feels like in your gut. ; Therapist: What kind of emotions do you feel? ; Therapist: Happier? ; Therapist: Do you feel sad? ; Therapist: What kind of emotions are you feeling when you have those thoughts? ; Patient: Sad. ; Patient: Not happiness. ; Patient: No, sad. ; Patient: A bit of anger and frustration as well. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: I know you're just kind of telling me this, and I know this is quite a heavy topic, but you're kind of laughing. ; Therapist: And I suppose I wonder a little bit, are you a bit, you know, how do you feel about having these emotions, talking about these emotions? ; Patient: I guess, embarrassed. ; Patient: I've never yet talked about it, so it's quite uncomfortable to be in this situation. ; Therapist: Okay, well you're doing a great job, because I know that this can be difficult. ; Therapist: Okay, so it sounds like some of the thoughts you're describing are, it's pointless, it's more than it's worth, I don't deserve to be here, I'm unworthy. ; Therapist: And those kind of thoughts, it sounds like they just flip through your mind. ; Therapist: And then you're kind of describing different emotions that those lead to. ; Therapist: You're kind of describing sad, anger, frustration, embarrassed. ; Therapist: What about in your body, what happens? ; Therapist: How do you feel, kind of physically? ; Patient: I used to be, I think from those emotions, very wound up, very kind of stressed all the time. ; Patient: But recently it's just been a lot more draining than anything. ; Patient: Just quite lethargic, and I just can't be bothered anymore, and my body reflects that. ; Patient: But then when I try and sleep I just can't seem to have a satisfied night's sleep. ; Patient: It's really, really frustrating. ; Therapist: So it sounds like this is affecting you, it's draining you of your energy, like your body can't be bothered. ; Therapist: I think that's a really good way of describing it. ; Therapist: And you're noticing sleep problems as well. ; Therapist: And then, what do you do? ; Therapist: So this is, so we're back to the point before the lecture. ; Therapist: So you start having these thoughts, these emotions, and you know, your body, I guess it sounds like those thoughts are quite draining, so it'll be draining your energy. ; Therapist: What then happens, what do you do next? ; Patient: I kind of focus on the negative thoughts, and I probably should not think about them, ; Patient: but I focus on them and then I don't really want to do anything. ; Patient: I kind of stay in bed or... ; Therapist: So you think even more about those kind of worries that you have, so you do a bit of dwelling and you stay in bed. ; Therapist: And it sounds like you don't, you haven't tried speaking to your friends about it. ; Patient: No, I haven't. ; Therapist: Or speaking to family. ; Therapist: Okay, and then after you've done that, so after you've not gone to the lecture, you've stayed in bed, you've kind of spent time, as you said, focusing on those thoughts, those negative thoughts. ; Therapist: How do you feel after that? ; Therapist: Do you feel better or do you feel worse? ; Patient: I guess I feel slightly worse, but then a bit numb, in a way, kind of, I don't know. ; Patient: Once you've felt that, because I do feel tired all the time, I just try and push it out and then you don't really think about anything, and it's almost nicer that way than to keep focusing on how much you're getting wrong and how much you can't do stuff. ; Patient: Sometimes it's better just to not think about it at all. ; Therapist: So it sounds like in some ways it's a bit of a relief to do that. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: But in other ways maybe you think it might make things worse. ; Patient: Probably in the long run, yeah.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name gabriela; sex female; education medical student; marital status unmarried ; Clinical Identifiers: Outpatient ; Referral Information : Referred by gp; reason for referral low mood, decreased interest ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Low mood 2 months; 2. Low confidence2months; 3. Decreased attention and concentrationna ; History: The patient was apparently maintaining well 2 months back when she would be regularly attending her med school, interacting well with friends and family members. Her biological functions were within normal limits. 2 months back, she started feeling that her modd would remain low throughout the day and she would have to puch herself to go to her college and interact with people. She reports that her energy would be low and she found it difficult to get up from bed and take a bath which was unlike her usual self. 1 week back, during her summer break, when she was delivering orders at a restaurant she got confused with the orders and made mistakes in remembering them. She reports that she is unable to concentrate and forgets a lot these days. Thus made her lose confidence even more. She reports having thoughts like shes the cause of inconvenience to her mother and everyone else. 2 months back when her mother started noticing changes in her behaviour, she told her to consult a doctor. On her mothers insistence she visited a gp who referred her to the psychologist. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Affect sad; speech decreased rate, volume; thought ideas of guilt, worthlessness; attention and concentration aroused but ill sustained; judgement im not very sure about returning to the uni, i guess thats the best for me but i feel lonely and weak inside so i dont know yet ; Psychotherapy Type: Typecbt; mode individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Reflective listening ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Nil ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Gp depression ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Now, one thing I thought we might do today is to get an example of one of these situations in which you get really anxious and try to see if we can understand more about how you think and how you feel when you're in the middle of one of those situations. ; Therapist: So can you think of an example of something that's happened recently? ; Patient: My daughter has been, she's actually been sick, and so she had a fever yesterday and they started her on an antibiotic and I had to go pick it up from the drugstore. ; Patient: And that's like, I don't usually go there. ; Patient: It's hard to get there. ; Patient: Like, it's not right in the neighborhood. ; Patient: So... ; Therapist: Any expressways or bridges to get there? ; Patient: Not expressways, but it's busy. ; Patient: It's busier and it's like in a mall, so you know, there's like... ; Therapist: Any four lanes or a six lane? ; Patient: Four lanes, yeah. ; Therapist: Four lane. ; Patient: So it just, it's not someplace I usually would go. ; Patient: And if I was going to go, usually I would either have her go with me or my husband go with me. ; Patient: But she was sick and he was at work and... ; Therapist: So to try to understand what goes through your mind, let's try to take you back. ; Therapist: And now you know that the prescription's there and your daughter's sick and I guess you don't want to ask her to drive over there. ; Patient: I sort of did. ; Therapist: Yeah, probably not the wisest idea. ; Therapist: So you're thinking about doing the drive and what's going through your mind? ; Therapist: What are the thoughts that are churning inside? ; Patient: I'm just, you know, I'm sort of thinking about going there and I'm already starting to think, well, you know, what if, you know, what if... ; Therapist: What if what? ; Patient: I'm driving and somebody crashes into me? ; Patient: What if I'm driving and I can't do it? ; Patient: You know, what if I just have to stop because I can't do it anymore? ; Patient: And, you know, it was raining and I'm sort of like I've got this picture of myself like out in the middle of the road and, you know... ; Therapist: What's the picture look like? ; Therapist: You're out in the middle of the road and it's raining. ; Patient: I'm stranded and it's dark and my, you know, it's, you know, my shoes are gone. ; Patient: I'm just like, it's like I, it would be a million miles to get back home. ; Therapist: Pretty miserable. ; Patient: Yeah, yeah. ; Therapist: Pretty scary. ; Patient: Oh, terrifying. ; Therapist: Yeah, yeah. ; Patient: And I just, it's so hard to get there. ; Therapist: And Kate, as you put yourself back into that situation and have those thoughts going through your mind, what kinds of feelings go along with it? ; Therapist: You know, by feelings, I mean, things are inside like fear... ; Patient: Like the physical? ; Therapist: Anxiety, physical things are going on. ; Patient: Well, fear and anxiety and I just feel really shaky and I feel really like lightheaded and dizzy and I just don't feel like I can breathe very well and I feel like I'm gonna like fall over. ; Therapist: Is this a panic attack now? ; Therapist: You told me about having some panic attacks. ; Patient: I've had worse ones, but it's getting there. ; Therapist: Not quite to a panic, but you know, it's brewing. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Yeah, it feels like it might. ; Therapist: Yeah, yeah. ; Therapist: Well, what I think we might do to try to move things along toward getting a plan of attack on this... ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: ...is to actually sketch this out. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And see if we can figure out some things we might be able to start doing to give you a better handle on it that you have right now. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So let's put some boxes here and one of them is gonna be event. ; Therapist: These are the things that trigger your anxiety. ; Therapist: And in this case, the event was... ; Patient: The driving, having to drive to the... ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: ...to the pharmacy. ; Therapist: Drive to pharmacy. ; Therapist: And then this next box I'm gonna label something we call automatic thoughts. ; Therapist: And by automatic, I mean that they occur relatively automatically. ; Therapist: They just sort of pop into your mind and you don't stop to check them out. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And we all have these kinds of automatic thoughts. ; Therapist: You know, I have them, everybody I know has them. ; Therapist: They're inner thoughts. ; Therapist: In fact, if you think about it for a minute, we probably have a lot more thoughts we don't speak out loud that are part of our inner dialogue than thoughts we actually end up speaking aloud to other people. ; Therapist: And I suspect that you have lots of those thoughts and you just gave me some examples of them. ; Therapist: So that's why we call them automatic. ; Patient: So the... ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: ...like the what ifs. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: So let's put a couple of those down in this box. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: In the automatic thought box. ; Therapist: And they are... ; Patient: What if someone runs into me? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: What if... what else? ; Patient: What if I get stranded? ; Therapist: Get stranded. ; Patient: Um, I can't do it. ; Therapist: I can't do it. ; Therapist: And there was this image about the rainstorm and you don't have your shoes on and so forth. ; Therapist: What should we put down for that? ; Patient: I think what if I... what if I can't get back home? ; Therapist: I can't get back home. ; Therapist: Sort of lost. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: What if I end up on this road forever? ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: And then we're going to put another box. ; Therapist: There's a sort of a chain of events here. ; Patient: Uh-huh. ; Therapist: The event can make you think in ways that stir up feelings of anxiety and so forth. ; Therapist: So if you're thinking like this, it makes sense that you'd be feeling pretty nervous inside and you might have some of these physical reactions. ; Therapist: So let's put those in here. ; Therapist: This is the emotions box. ; Therapist: And they are much shaky, you said. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: A lot of fear. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: If we're going to rate that fear on a zero to 100 scale and zero is none at all and 100 is the maximum anyone could ever get, where would you be at this point? ; Patient: Oh, I'd say about an 80. ; Therapist: 80 ; Therapist: Pretty high. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: It's gone higher though, I suspect. ; Patient: Oh, yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: But at this point it's an 80. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And then you had some other feelings inside? ; Patient: Well, yeah. ; Patient: I sort of felt like I might fall over. ; Therapist: What else? ; Patient: My heart was pounding and I didn't feel like I couldn't breathe very well. ; Therapist: How about your stomach? ; Therapist: Any flip-flops in your stomach or anything like that? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So a lot going on here. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And a pretty high level of distress. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: And then we're going to complete this loop by putting a box we're going to call behavior. ; Therapist: This is how you actually acted when you were in the situation. ; Therapist: So what did you do after you had these thoughts and you had these feelings? ; Patient: I went to the pharmacy. ; Therapist: You did do it? ; Patient: I had to. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And what was it like for you when you were going to the pharmacy and driving there? ; Patient: It was so bad. ; Patient: I just, you know, I think I left permanent marks on the steering wheel because I was holding on to it so tight. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So in this case you actually did go to the pharmacy. ; Therapist: But you maybe did some damage to the steering wheel. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: I hope not. ; Patient: But I really had no choice. ; Patient: I mean, I think usually I wouldn't go to the pharmacy. ; Patient: Usually I would call my husband and say, can you pick it up on your way home? ; Therapist: Get an escape route if you would. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So usually you would avoid this. ; Therapist: If we looked at this as a model for many of these situations about driving and feeling anxious, the usual behavior would be to try to get out of it or avoid it. ; Therapist: Is that right? ; Patient: Oh, yeah. ; Patient: Oh, yeah. ; Therapist: And so if you do avoid it, then what happens? ; Patient: Well, I feel better. ; Therapist: You feel better? ; Patient: It's like such a relief. ; Therapist: Better relief. ; Therapist: The emotions calm down now, right? ; Patient: Well, yeah, because I don't have to worry about it. ; Therapist: So that's what happens for a single episode of this anxiety. ; Therapist: I'm wondering, though, if we look at the impact on you of avoiding and getting relief overall as far as managing driving, what do you think it does there? ; Patient: Well, I feel like I don't really have much confidence when it comes to this, to being able to do it. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So in a way, it decreases your confidence over time. ; Patient: I think so. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: I suspect that not doing it repeatedly gives you this belief about your capacity to do these driving things. ; Therapist: And what's that belief? ; Patient: Yeah, I don't feel like I can do it. ; Therapist: I can't do it. ; Patient: I can't do it. ; Patient: I can't do it. ; Patient: And I don't do it. ; Therapist: So it really comes back to this thought, I can't do it. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And you can't do it and you don't do it. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: So here's this chain of events. ; Therapist: Events trigger thoughts. ; Therapist: We call them automatic thoughts. ; Therapist: And then they influence your emotions, these feelings you have. ; Therapist: And then that influences how you handle the situation. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Now let's think together for a moment before we wrap up of what's happening in this and before we wrap up of how we might proceed to try to give you some help with this. ; Therapist: So let's take a look at these thoughts for a minute. ; Therapist: Do you know anybody else that drives regularly that might think differently than you? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: What would be an example? ; Patient: I mean, I think almost everybody. ; Patient: I think most people drive without too much problem. ; Patient: But my sister loves to drive. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: I mean, she drives every opportunity she gets. ; Therapist: So for some reason, we don't know exactly why, but the key thing here is not looking at why, but to help you with actually making change in this. ; Therapist: But you do have some differences in the way you think about driving that might be something that we could begin to work on in our sessions. ; Therapist: We might, for example, check it out. ; Therapist: What's the chances of someone slamming into you? ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Or what's the chances of you being stranded out there on the highway? ; Therapist: And even if you were stranded, is there a way you could cope with that or manage that so you can get back home? ; Therapist: So these are some things that we could begin to do. ; Patient: Yeah. Okay. ; Therapist: So I'm going to mark here, we could work on these thoughts. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And then by working on the thoughts, we might be able to help you reduce the emotions. ; Therapist: But there are also some things that I might be able to teach you that you could use to reduce this level of distress that you have. ; Patient: Oh, that would be really nice. ; Therapist: To be able to calm yourself down in situations. ; Therapist: So we'll have some, try to build some skills to manage your emotions. ; Therapist: And then on this behavior side, one thing that we might begin to work on is helping you gradually begin to take on some of these driving things so that you can build your confidence back up. ; Therapist: And again, build your skills to do it. ; Therapist: And I can see that that causes a little bit of edginess here. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: What were you thinking when I mentioned that? ; Patient: I was thinking that I hope that this doesn't make me worse. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Like trying to do some of these things. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Well, I'm glad you gave me that feedback. ; Therapist: That's an example, by the way, of me wanting to hear from you about the way you're responding to what I'm saying. ; Therapist: I certainly wouldn't want to do anything to make you worse. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: But it causes you too much anxiety. ; Therapist: And what we'll try to do is pace it just to the level that's right for you. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So that you can make some progress and get to the place you want to be, which is to be able to drive to your new office, cross that big bridge, and maybe even drive those couple of hours to... ; Patient: Visit my son. ; Therapist: Visit your son. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So what do you think? ; Patient: Well, I think that that would... ; Patient: If I could do those things, it would be really nice. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: I think it'd be really nice too. ; Therapist: So that would be our goal. ; Patient: Yeah.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name kate ; Past Session Information: Follow -up session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms 1 anxiety chief complaints 1 anxiety while driving 2 creates what-if scenarios ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior nad; speech coherent, mood  affect anxious, thought negative, perception distorted, cognitive functions disorganized, judgement and insight poor and intact. ; Psychotherapy Type: Cbt; mode individual. ; Psychotherapy Technique : Thought challenging cognitive restructuring ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Themes involved in the session 1 fear patient has a fear of driving to unfamiliar places, especially in busy or challenging traffic situations. She feels panic, light-headedness, dizziness, and difficulty breathing. 2 technique used therapist restructured patients automatic thoughts to develop more realistic, balanced, and adaptive thinking patterns. Also helped him to regulate his emotions relaxation exercises, mindfulness practices, deep breathing techniques, and visualization exercises to promote a sense of calm and control. 3 goal setting established specific goals related to driving, such as driving short distances to familiar locations or practicing relaxation techniques during driving, which helps individuals in their progress and celebrate successes along the way. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Anxiety ; Action Plan : Therapist asks patient to get the place you want to be, which is to be able to drive to her new office, cross that big bridge, and maybe even drive those couple of hours to visit her son. ; Next session details: Na

dialogue: Therapist: Vanessa, hi. ; Therapist: It's nice to see you again. ; Patient: It's good to see you. ; Therapist: Yeah, how are you? ; Patient: I'm doing okay. ; Patient: You know, things have been settling down a bit, I think. ; Therapist: Yeah, the last time we saw, things were pretty chaotic and hectic when you were being released from the, discharged from the hospital about a week ago. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: How's your injury? ; Patient: It's pretty pain, you know, had a lot of pain in it. ; Patient: I've been kind of trying not to take too much pain medication and just kind of trying to keep busy and focus on things that are happening. ; Patient: I've been busy with my church duties and with my kids. ; Therapist: You've been trying to stay busy? ; Patient: Yeah, yeah. ; Patient: It's been hard to think about myself when I have so many other things that are way more important than me to deal with. ; Therapist: How are your kids doing? ; Patient: They're doing okay. ; Patient: You know, the little ones were pretty kind of stressed out when I first got home and they were a little unsure of themselves and what was going to happen, but the older kids have helped out quite a bit, so I think they're pulling together. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: I imagine that there's some, you know, period of readjustment and healing and sadness or as in, it sounds like also just trying to get things done. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I mean, my motto is just to keep moving, you know, moving as fast as I can, trying to get, you know, keep the house clean and be good, you know, with my duties with my church and trying to keep the kids focused on their activities and not to be too focused on what's happening in me and Paul's life because, you know, there's nothing they can do about that. ; Therapist: So you're taking care of a lot of people, your community, your kids, all the while trying to take care of yourself. ; Therapist: That's a lot. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: I really appreciate you showing up today given how much you have on your plate and how much you have going on. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Well, you know, last time that we met, you had talked about how important it is for you to do what you can to keep your kids and yourself safe. ; Therapist: And I was wondering if you'd be interested in talking a little bit more about that today or perhaps if there's something else that you would rather talk about. ; Patient: No, I, you know, I made time today to talk about this. ; Patient: I think it's really important to try to figure something out. ; Patient: Things got very out of hand there. ; Patient: And so it's, I'm looking forward to thinking about what things I can do. ; Therapist: So you were scared. ; Therapist: It sounds like you were scared. ; Patient: It was terrifying. ; Patient: I mean, we, police were called, you know, we ended up having to call the police and Paul was arrested and spent some time in jail. ; Patient: I had child welfare folks crawling all over my house and my mom was upset and neighbors were all being nosy and gossiping. ; Patient: And it was just very scary. ; Therapist: So a lot of things were turned upside down. ; Therapist: And when you say it was scary, I hear you saying on some level it was scary for you and your safety, but it also sounds like it was scary because all these other variables or elements were put in motion that were disruptive. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: I mean, it was, you know, we had people come into the house calling and, you know, checking in, are you okay? ; Patient: Or can you get a restraining order? ; Patient: And my mom was trying to get me to move in with her and, you know, it's just too many, you know, too many cooks in the kitchen. ; Therapist: So a lot of people ; Therapist: have some ideas about what you should be doing. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: So I'm just really, I'm not, I'm not going to do that. ; Patient: I'm not going to get a restraining order. ; Patient: I'm not going to call the police. ; Patient: You know, he knows where I live. ; Therapist: So say more about that. ; Therapist: Say more about why you, why you don't want to call the police or you don't want to get a restraining order. ; Patient: They were, they were throwing him on the ground. ; Patient: They were holding his arms behind his back and, and they had their guns and, you know, that kind of, you never know what the police are going to do to a black man. ; Patient: You never know whether he's going to make it to the jail safely. ; Patient: So I was, I was terrified for him. ; Patient: And then the next day, you know, child welfare call in the house. ; Therapist: It sounds like that was a very scary experience and moment for you. ; Patient: Yeah, because I'm a good mom. ; Therapist: And given that experience, you're, it sounds like you're probably, you're maybe not as inclined to think about calling the police again. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: No, no. ; Patient: I've, I've told my mom that that's, you know, that's a last resort and that I'm going to be meeting with some folks and thinking about other options. ; Therapist: And that's what you'd like to talk about today, is alternatives to calling the police. ; Patient: Absolutely. ; Therapist: Well, what have you thought about so far? ; Therapist: What other ideas do you have about what you might do in a serious moment where you're scared for your, your wellbeing and that of your kids? ; Patient: I think I'm most afraid, you know, that something might happen that will be really crazy and really out of control. ; Patient: And so I've been thinking about what kinds of things I could do if things are crazy and out of control. ; Patient: And I've just thought about maybe talking to somebody or talking to my minister about it. ; Patient: It came to my mind because he's somebody who we've talked to before. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: So your minister, someone that you're thinking about, talking to a little bit about what's going on in your relationship. ; Therapist: What are your thoughts? ; Therapist: What would you, what would you say to your minister? ; Therapist: What would you like to tell your minister? ; Patient: I'm really, I'm really interested in telling him more of the truth of what's happening in my relationship. ; Patient: He doesn't know about, he has no idea that Paul has threatened to kill me and they threatened to kill himself and the children. ; Patient: He knows we've had some marital problems, some financial problems. ; Patient: He knows that Paul's had some drinking problems. ; Patient: So there's some of that, but he doesn't know about him threatening to kill us or that he's been hitting me or his rages. ; Patient: So I feel like, you know, that it's time to tell the minister, you know, tell him some of that stuff. ; Therapist: You feel like you've been keeping some significant information from your, what would be some reasons why you would tell him these things? ; Therapist: What might be some advantages or reasons to do that? ; Patient: He's been helpful before. ; Patient: He's really helped us a lot. ; Patient: We've, we've had counseling with him over the last five years, numerous times, and he's been very helpful. ; Therapist: So it's someone that you trust, someone that you ; Therapist: have a relationship with, and he's been helpful. ; Therapist: In what ways has he been helpful? ; Patient: You know, I think Paul respects him as a man and I think he cares about Paul. ; Patient: So he's not, you know, my mom and my dad and my friends, they, they're, they're really bordering on hating Paul and they don't, I don't feel like they have any objectivity when it comes to working with him. ; Patient: But my pastor has some objectivity and I think he cares about Paul. ; Therapist: It sounds like your pastor is able to see him as a whole complicated human being in the same ways that, that you do, perhaps, that there's this side of him that's scary and that you don't like, and then there's this other aspect of him that you, you really do appreciate and you feel like your pastor would likely be able to do that as well. ; Therapist: What would be another reason to talk to your pastor in addition to this being someone you trust and that Paul might listen to? ; Therapist: What would be another advantage? ; Patient: Well, I don't think that he's going to likely go storming into, you know, our pastor's house. ; Patient: Paul, Paul won't. ; Patient: That Paul won't, you know, he's going to, you know, he comes banging at my mom's door and he goes, you know, storming over to my girlfriend's house, but he's not likely to do that. ; Patient: Yeah, I don't think he will. ; Therapist: So, so, so your pastor's home actually might be a physically safe place for you all to go, ; Patient: right, should things get cool off because things got so out of control and crazy, you know, and, and that's not going to happen again. ; Therapist: So you've said that a few times now that things got so out of control and crazy. ; Therapist: Tell me, tell me a little bit more about how, what that was. ; Patient: You know, you know, my eldest son got involved. ; Patient: My arm was, was, was harmed. ; Patient: Things were broken. ; Patient: He threatened to kill me and he threatened to kill all of us. ; Patient: And I had to call the police and I had to, you know, have people coming into my house, tromping through my house, grabbing Paul, hurting him. ; Patient: You know, he called me from jail and how can you do this? ; Patient: You know, what have you done? ; Patient: You know, I felt like, what have I done? ; Patient: How can I do this? ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: So, so not only was it so scary in the heat of the moment where you feared for your life and the life of your children, but afterwards it was scary as well because of all the things that happened. ; Patient: All that fallout. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: So, so, so going to your pastors, talking to your pastor, possibly seeing if his house might be a place that you could run to temporarily might be something to explore. ; Therapist: And those are advantages. ; Therapist: Are there any disadvantages? ; Therapist: Like what would be some possible disadvantages to talking to your pastor about what's been going on in your relationship? ; Patient: That Paul will know. ; Patient: You know, if he finds out that I've talked to our minister about this, you know, I have no doubt how angry he will be. ; Therapist: So this could really be a trigger, a significant trigger. ; Patient: Yes, if he finds out about it. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So that's a little bit of a difficult situation. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: As you think about this particular part of a safety plan, on the one hand, there's potentially some real advantages and positives to speaking to your minister. ; Therapist: And at the same time, there's this possible significant risk. ; Therapist: When you think about, you know, the pros and the cons in this situation, what do you, what do you make of that? ; Therapist: What do you, where do you go with that? ; Patient: It's, it's a risk I'm willing to take. ; Patient: You know, I have thought about this and it was, you know, things got so out of control and I feel like it's time to do something different and to think about how we're going to do this differently. ; Therapist: You're, you're really concerned. ; Therapist: Yes. ; Therapist: A part of you is really worried about the next time. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: And you appreciate that there are some risks involved in some of the safety planning and you also feel like it's a risk that you're, you're willing to take given what is at stake. ; Therapist: And really it sounds like you feel like your life and your children's lives may be at stake. ; Therapist: Yes. ; Patient: You know, I think that things can't continue the way that they are. ; Patient: I have to figure out something that's going to work for me and for my kids and for Paul. ; Therapist: Would it be alright with you if I offered just a suggestion or a thought, something to think about in terms of kids and safety planning? ; Therapist: Yes. ; Therapist: This is something that I know other moms in a similar, in situations similar to yours have done and that is sit down and have a conversation with their kids about identifying a safe person to either call or run to in the moment when things are, if things get really crazy and out of hand. ; Therapist: I'd be curious to hear what your thoughts are about doing that with your kids. ; Patient: I think my oldest, my oldest son, that would be a really helpful thing for him because he wants to know what he can do. ; Patient: He wants to do something. ; Patient: He's always jumping in. ; Patient: That's how I got hurt in the first place is he was jumping in. ; Patient: So helping him identify something that he can do that will keep us safe and to keep him safe would be a great idea. ; Therapist: Yeah, so you see this perhaps as a way of kind of not pulling him out of a violent situation but having him turn away from a violent situation as opposed to turn into it which is what he's done. ; Patient: Yeah, he's becoming a man now too. ; Patient: He needs to have an option of what he can do to keep his family safe. ; Therapist: And as he's becoming a man and thinking about how to protect you, you're also really concerned about protecting him and keeping him safe. ; Therapist: I've heard you identify a few things that you're thinking about doing or would like to do and things that you feel like you actually do have control over. ; Therapist: Last time we talked you were very clear about the fact that you can't control Paul when he's in his fury and his rage and being violent. ; Therapist: And what I've heard you very clearly say that you want is to figure out what you can control. ; Therapist: You can't control him but there are some things you have control over and specifically for you that is maybe talking to possibly a safe person, your minister and having that conversation to see if that might be a safe person and place to go to and then the other piece is maybe having a conversation with your oldest child at least about who to call in the moment. ; Therapist: And I'm confident Vanessa that you will be able to put a plan together that will work for you and your family and I'm here to support you in any way that I can and if it's at all helpful I'd be happy to follow up with you in a few days and see if you feel the need to talk about it some more. ; Patient: Thank you I'd appreciate that. ; Therapist: Thanks for your time. ; Patient: Thank you.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name vanessa ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Follow-up session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms anxiety and fear chief complaints 1anxiety 2 unsafety 3 threatened 4 fear ; History: Nil ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior anxious and fearful; speech, mood  affect; low, thought, perception normal, cognitive functions normal; judgement and insight intact ; Psychotherapy Type: Cbt; mode individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Supportive problem solving ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: There are various issues can be seen in the session 1 fear patient is afraid and traumatized of violent behavior of her partner. She feels terrified of involving the police and child welfare services in her situation. She is hesitant to involve the police or obtain a restraining order due to fears of escalation and potential harm to partner. 2safety concerns patient is concerned about the safety of her children and hers and want a safety plan to prevent future harm. 3 protection patient trusts her minister and believes that he could provide valuable support and guidance. She feels that he can offer a balanced perspective and potentially intervene in this crisis. Though she weighs the risks and benefits of disclosing sensitive information about her relationship to her minister. 4 family her son shows interest to intervene in violent situations.
