She considers involving her children in the safety planning process and empowering them to seek help if needed. Plan despite the potential consequences, she prioritizes her and her childrens safety and is willing to take necessary risks to implement a safety plan. 5 control and agency patients shows a desire to regain control over her circumstances. She acknowledges the limitations of controlling her partners behavior but focuses on finding strategies to protect herself and her children. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Anxiety and fear ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Watch what happens this time when the provider cues into what the parent is saying, empathizes with her situation, and attempts to work with the parent to find a solution that fits her needs. ; Therapist: So I wrote a prescription for antibiotics for Aiden. ; Therapist: I did want to talk to you though, I'm a little bit concerned looking through his chart at how many ear infections he's had recently and I noticed that you had checked the box that someone's smoking in the home so I was wondering if you could tell me a little more about that. ; Patient: Well, it's just me and him and I do smoke. ; Patient: I try really hard not to smoke around him. ; Patient: But I've been smoking for 10 years except when I was pregnant with him. ; Patient: But everything is so stressful being a single mom and my having a full time job. ; Patient: So it's just, that's why I started smoking again. ; Therapist: You have a lot of things going on and smoking is kind of a way to relax and de-stress. ; Patient: Yes. ; Patient: Some people have a glass of wine, I have a cigarette. ; Therapist: And it sounds like you're trying not to smoke around him. ; Therapist: Why did you make that decision? ; Patient: I know it's not good for him. ; Patient: I mean I've read those things about ear infections and asthma and stuff. ; Patient: But other kids have ear infections and their parents don't smoke. ; Therapist: So on the one hand you're worried about how your smoking might be affecting him and on the other hand you're not so sure if it's really the smoking that's causing these problems. ; Patient: Right, yeah. ; Patient: I mean he doesn't have asthma. ; Patient: He hasn't had a lot of other problems that his other friends have. ; Patient: And I've thought about quitting before in the past but I just don't see how it's possible right now. ; Therapist: What made you decide to quit smoking when you were pregnant? ; Patient: Well, he was inside me and we were sharing everything and I knew that he would get some of that and I didn't think I could live with myself if something happened to him. ; Therapist: Right now though it feels almost too difficult to even manage or even to try. ; Patient: Yeah, exactly. ; Therapist: How were you successful when you quit before? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: I think about it now I don't even know how I did it. ; Patient: I just did it. ; Patient: I just couldn't imagine him not being born or going into labor early and him having problems and stuff like that. ; Patient: All the stuff that they talk about with women who smoke. ; Patient: So that was just enough to say, okay you know what, I'm not going to risk that. ; Therapist: The risks were so scary then that you were able to stop. ; Therapist: But they don't feel as scary to you now. ; Patient: No, I mean we're two separate people and like I said I try really hard not to smoke around him. ; Patient: I'm pretty good about that. ; Patient: I don't let other people smoke around him. ; Therapist: You're doing the best you can do. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Okay, but it sounds to me too like part of you really does want to quit. ; Patient: Yeah, I know that I need to and I keep every new year I say, okay this year I'm going to quit smoking. ; Patient: But then something happens and it just doesn't. ; Therapist: It's on your to-do list. ; Therapist: It's just not making it to the top. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: If you did decide to quit, on a scale of one to ten where one is not at all confident and you don't think you could do it and ten is you feel pretty certain that you could, where do you think you fall right now? ; Patient: Probably like a five. ; Patient: Kind of in the unsure area. ; Patient: I know I've done it before so I know I can do it. ; Patient: But at the same time it just seems really hard and it's not the same situation. ; Therapist: Well what made you say five rather than two or three? ; Patient: I know all the ways it's bad for me and I don't want him to grow up thinking that it's okay to smoke. ; Patient: I don't want him to use any kind of, I don't want him to chew or anything like that. ; Patient: So I know I need to especially before he gets old enough to understand what mommy's doing but I just don't know if I can do it. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So it sounds like you have a lot of reasons why you'd like to quit. ; Therapist: You have been successful quitting in the past and right now you're just feeling a little bit hesitant about your ability to do it. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Where do you think we should go from here? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: I'd like some help. ; Patient: I just don't know what kind of help I need. ; Therapist: Sure. ; Therapist: Well if you'd be interested that's something I can definitely talk to you about. ; Therapist: There are a lot of new options that can actually help people be way more successful in their attempt at quitting. ; Therapist: There's different medications you can try. ; Patient: I don't like medicine. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: There's also a lot of support groups and classes that you can take where you have other people to go through it with you and sometimes just having that support can be a big part of it especially for people like you where smoking is such a stress reliever. ; Patient: That sounds nice but I'm not sure if I have the time for all that. ; Therapist: Sure. ; Therapist: It feels like something that would take up a lot of time and maybe not fit into your life. ; Therapist: I wonder if we could talk about some options that might fit into your life. ; Patient: That would be really nice. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Well if you're willing then we could set up another appointment where you could come in and we could talk more about that. ; Patient: I would like that. ; Patient: That would be great. ; Therapist: Great. ; Patient: Thank you. ; Therapist: Sure. ; Therapist: This time the provider had the same agenda to talk to this parent about the dangers of secondhand smoke and a counsel heard her quit smoking. ; Therapist: However, this time the provider's focus was on the parent's own view of the issue. ; Therapist: By giving the parent an opportunity to reflect on her situation the provider was able to elicit reasons for change from the parent herself. ; Therapist: There was no need to lecture or scold because the parent was making her own case against smoking. ; Therapist: Many times our patients already have the information that we try to give them. ; Therapist: What they really need is someone to listen to them and to help them sort out a plan that will fit in their life. ; Therapist: By accepting and respecting our patients, even with their faults, we communicate our genuine desire to help them make positive changes in their lives. ; Therapist: During this interaction the provider demonstrated that she understood the parent's struggle and that she still wanted to help. ; Therapist: As a result, this single parent found she finally had someone on her team. ; Therapist: This increased both her interest and willingness to try working further with the provider to find a solution that would fit in her life.
summary: Patient Particulars : Sex female, single mother ; Past Session Information: Follow up session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms, substance use chief complaints, 1 stress 2 worry ; History: Substance use history she has been smoking for 10 years except when she was pregnant. ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior worried; speech anxious, mood  affect low, cognitive functions, judgement and insight good ; Issues discussed in Current Session: 1 problem patient is concerned about the impact of her smoking on her childs health. She struggles with finding the motivation and confidence to take action which gives her stress as she is a single parent with a full-time job. 2 acceptance patient expresses a willingness to seek help and explore options for quitting smoking. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Substance use ; Next session details: Scheduled next appointment

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Emma, how are you doing today? ; Patient: I'm good, thanks. ; Patient: How are you? ; Therapist: I'm doing well. ; Therapist: Thank you for asking. ; Therapist: I understand you've been having some symptoms that are bothersome to you. ; Therapist: Can you tell me about what's going on? ; Patient: I moved into my apartment about a year ago and I've been having anxious thoughts and sometimes I'm scared I'm going to lose my apartment. ; Therapist: So you've been having anxiety, you've been having thoughts about possibly losing your apartment. ; Therapist: Tell me more about that. ; Patient: When I ran out my check for the rent, I usually would pay it online but then I would click the button and it would submit it a couple times. ; Patient: I just wanted to make sure I got paid. ; Patient: So then I started to actually go in person and pay it. ; Patient: But then I would check my statement just to make sure they cashed it and they got it. ; Therapist: To make sure they really received your payment. ; Patient: I'm also nervous that something might happen where I leave my straightener on and the apartment burns down. ; Therapist: Do you find yourself acting on that thought, say specifically that thought with the straightener? ; Patient: I'll check it and I'll just make sure that it's unplugged and then I look around and make sure everything's unplugged because I don't want anything getting caught. ; Therapist: When you say everything, what do you mean? ; Patient: The toaster, my computer, my laptop charger, my cell phone, the charger for that, and just anything that's plugged in like the television. ; Patient: I just want to make sure everything's unplugged before I leave. ; Therapist: Before you leave your apartment. ; Therapist: What do you do when you come back? ; Patient: I check to make sure they're still unplugged but then when I need to use it, I plug it back in. ; Therapist: If you need to use, for instance, television, do you plug it in and watch it and then unplug it immediately or only before you leave? ; Patient: Before I leave. ; Therapist: So you leave it plugged in while you're there. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: When did you first notice the anxiety? ; Patient: I guess like six months ago. ; Therapist: About six months ago? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: How did it start out? ; Patient: It started with just thinking about things, thinking about leaving the door unlocked or being unsure if I paid bills. ; Patient: Just thinking about it and then I would have to double check it and triple check in and just kind of make sure. ; Therapist: Did it start with that? ; Therapist: Did it start with the door locks? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: It started with just thinking and making sure the door was locked. ; Therapist: Do you still do that now? ; Therapist: Do you check the door several times? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I just make sure it's locked. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: How do you do that? ; Therapist: Do you get up and look at it and see if it's locked and then go sit down and think about it and come back? ; Therapist: Or do you operate the mechanism back and forth? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I just go in. ; Patient: I look in and make sure it's locked and then I'll go back down and I'll just sit back down and I'll be okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: For a while? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: And does that thought ever come back and you have to go check it again? ; Patient: Sometimes. ; Patient: Not really. ; Therapist: Not really. ; Patient: I'll just check in and it's fine. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Do you have kind of a checklist in your mind for when you leave your apartment? ; Therapist: Do you do like unplug everything in roughly the same order and check everything in a similar order? ; Patient: I haven't really thought about it but I make sure everything's unplugged. ; Patient: Like I know what needs to be unplugged. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So you do have kind of a list in your mind of what has to be unplugged. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And you'll make sure it's all unplugged. ; Patient: Exactly. ; Therapist: And how about when you lock your door from the outside when you're leaving? ; Therapist: Do you check that? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I'll check it and then if I'm sitting in my car, I just might go back just to double check it and just make sure. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So you're checking the door. ; Therapist: You're unplugging various items that may create heat. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: You're careful with your paying your rent. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So fear and anxiety surrounding losing the apartment in some manner. ; Therapist: How is this affecting your daily life, these symptoms? ; Patient: Well, I mean it's time consuming. ; Patient: Sometimes I'm late for work because I think I left something plugged in and I have to go back inside. ; Patient: Sometimes I'll lock the door and have to go back and make sure it's locked. ; Patient: So I'm usually late for things because I'm double checking. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So it's causing some problems getting places on time. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: How about your level of anxiety or worry? ; Therapist: How high would you say that is? ; Patient: I guess it would be like high I guess, thinking about it. ; Therapist: It's troubling for you? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: If you think about from when it started, it started out, it sounds like with a few thoughts, right? ; Therapist: If we say that's relative to low anxiety, yeah, how would what you have now compare to that? ; Patient: I guess moderate, like in the, a little higher. ; Therapist: Just a little higher? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: But you have noticed it's worsened over the six months. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Is it the most anxiety you've ever experienced? ; Patient: I kind of consider myself an anxious person. ; Patient: So I guess, yeah. ; Therapist: This is the most you've experienced? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: So this is particularly troubling? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: And you said you've always been, you said anxious person? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Tell me about that. ; Patient: Just like group settings or, I remember just something when I was younger. ; Patient: I was like just playing with the door or something like that and my parents took me to some, I don't know, some doctor and they just said I was anxious. ; Therapist: Did they give you any treatment? ; Patient: I don't, no, I don't think so. ; Patient: They just said I was anxious. ; Therapist: So other than saying you're anxious, was there any diagnosis provided? ; Patient: No, not really. ; Therapist: Have you ever had any mental health diagnosis? ; Patient: Just, I guess just feeling anxious but not necessarily like a diagnosis. ; Therapist: Not from a provider? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: How about any medical conditions? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: None? ; Therapist: No. ; Therapist: Have you ever been to the hospital or anything? ; Patient: Just to like get my tonsils taken out but not like anything else. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: How about drugs or alcohol? ; Therapist: Any usage of those? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Never? ; Patient: Uh-uh. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: Emma, I'm going to have you see a counselor here. ; Therapist: I think it's just scheduled to see somebody. ; Therapist: I appreciate you taking this time with me, explaining the symptoms. ; Therapist: It's been helpful. ; Patient: Thank you. ; Therapist: Thanks.

dialogue: Patient: Come in. ; Therapist: Ms. ; Therapist: Bellamy? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Hi, I'm Connie Harris. ; Therapist: I'll be your doctor today. ; Therapist: Let me just wash my hands really quick. ; Therapist: Would you prefer Ms. ; Therapist: Bellamy or can I call you Pat? ; Patient: Pat's fine. ; Therapist: Great. ; Therapist: Well, it's nice to meet you. ; Patient: Nice to meet you. ; Therapist: Can you tell me why you're here today? ; Patient: I have a terrible headache. ; Therapist: It looks really bad. ; Patient: Yeah, it is. ; Therapist: Is there anything else besides your headache that you want to address here today at the clinical department? ; Patient: No, it's just that, except I am concerned. ; Patient: I just recently changed insurance companies and I'm not sure this is going to be covered yet. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Was there anything, because what we can do is while we're talking and I'm doing your history and physical, I'll have my office secretary look into the insurance plan that you have. ; Patient: All right. ; Therapist: So you don't have to worry about that. ; Patient: Yeah, that sounds good. ; Therapist: Okay, sounds great. ; Therapist: Is there anything else? ; Patient: No, I just, this is just really bad. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So what I'd like to do today, and let's take a look at what's causing your headache. ; Therapist: I will go over history, physical, and then we'll do again a physical exam, and then we will look into your insurance policy and make sure that's all, you know, taken care of. ; Therapist: Does that sound like a good plan for you? ; Patient: That's good. ; Therapist: Perfect. ; Therapist: So tell me a little bit more about this, the head pain that you're having. ; Patient: Well, it started about three days ago, and nothing has helped it. ; Patient: It's just laid me flat. ; Patient: I haven't been able to go to work. ; Patient: Nothing's helped. ; Patient: It's all over. ; Patient: It's really bad when I move, so I'm trying not to move too much, and the light is bothering me a lot. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Unfortunately, I can't dim the lights in this room, but I'll try to go quickly, and it would be okay if I took some notes. ; Patient: Oh, sure. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So you said this headache started about three days ago. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Was there anything that brought it on, anything unusual that happened maybe three days ago? ; Patient: Not really, no. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Can you tell me anything that makes it better? ; Patient: Nothing's made it better. ; Patient: I took some Tylenol. ; Patient: I tried Motrin. ; Patient: Nothing. ; Patient: I just try not to move too much. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Is there anything that makes it worse? ; Patient: Yeah, movement and light. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: And it's just constant, though. ; Patient: It's just constant. ; Patient: It's all over. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So if you had to rate it on a pain scale, zero being no pain, 10 being the worst pain you ever had. ; Patient: It's a 10. ; Therapist: A 10? ; Patient: Yeah, it's a headache like this. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Yeah, that sounds really bad. ; Therapist: Now, as far as radiation, does that move? ; Therapist: You said the pain is all up here in the front of your head? ; Patient: It's kind of all over. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: But also, I've got this shooting pain down my neck, and my neck is very stiff. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: But it's not, it's the entire head. ; Therapist: Entire head? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: As far as in the timing, you said that it started three days ago, but you said it's a constant. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: It comes and goes. ; Patient: It started gradually, but once it got there, it hasn't gone away. ; Patient: It doesn't get better. ; Patient: It doesn't get worse. ; Patient: It's just the same. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So what I want to get is your perception of what you think is going on. ; Patient: Oh, I don't know. ; Patient: I just, I can hardly think. ; Patient: It's so painful. ; Patient: I just, because it's so bad, I was afraid. ; Patient: My neighbor had a headache and ignored it last year, and he suddenly started having seizures and it turns out he had a brain tumor, so I thought I just should come in and look ; Patient: at it. ; Therapist: Yeah, I can understand your concern. ; Therapist: How is it impacting your daily life? ; Patient: I can't go to work. ; Patient: I can't do anything. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So it sounds like it's really impacting your life. ; Patient: Yeah, I can't. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: If it's okay, I would like to go talk a little bit about your medical history and your social history. ; Patient: Okay, sure. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Can you tell me as far as your medical history, do you have any medical conditions I should be aware of? ; Patient: I was diagnosed with high blood pressure about three years ago, but we've been addressing it with diet changes and it's been monitored. ; Therapist: Okay, so it's controlled with diet? ; Patient: Yeah, I go in yearly, I had been just, and it's been well controlled, so I haven't been on medication. ; Therapist: No meds for that. ; Patient: But other than that, I haven't had any problems. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Any surgical history? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Any hospitalizations? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: And you said the only medicine you're taking was Tylenol and Montreux, but it doesn't help? ; Patient: Yeah, and they didn't help, yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: I just wanted to verify. ; Therapist: Do you have any drug allergies? ; Patient: No, no. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: What about family history? ; Therapist: Do you have any medical history of headaches or- ; Patient: In my family? ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: What about your father's history? ; Patient: You know, my mom said she used to get migraines when she was in her 20s and 30s. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: I don't remember her saying anything else about it. ; Patient: My sister, I have one sister, she's healthy. ; Patient: My dad, he has high blood pressure, but other than that, he's healthy. ; Patient: And that's about it. ; Patient: I don't have any kids. ; Therapist: All right. ; Patient: It's all right. ; Therapist: I would like to ask you some social history questions that, just for, there are records. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Do you smoke? ; Patient: Yeah, I do. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Is it cigarettes or chewing? ; Patient: Yeah, cigarettes. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: And how much do you smoke? ; Patient: About a half a pack a day. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: What about alcohol? ; Patient: I don't drink. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Also, are you married? ; Patient: Yeah, I'm married. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And children? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And just some additional questions is looking at your kind of GYN history, are you- Are you last menstrual period? ; Patient: Oh, I'm in menopause. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: So going back into the history again, have you, you said your mom had migraines earlier on. ; Therapist: Have you been around and no other, you haven't been nauseous or have you been in other cities? ; Patient: Yeah, I've been nauseous. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: In fact, I threw up twice early on. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Because when I move, it makes me nauseous. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Nothing out of the ordinary over the past couple of weeks. ; Therapist: Have you been on any trips or anything? ; Patient: Mm. ; Therapist: Or- ; Patient: Actually, a week ago I was in North Carolina for a family reunion. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: And there was a four-year-old who was sick there. ; Patient: I don't know what they had, but they- Okay. ; Patient: I guess they ended up taking him into emergency. ; Therapist: All right. ; Patient: I don't know. ; Therapist: So let me just summarize to make sure I've got everything straight so far is you started hitting an onset of a severe headache about three days ago. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: It's worse with movement. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Light really makes it hurt bad. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: It's a 10 out of 10 pain, and you're also complaining of a stiff neck with that. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: It came on gradually, and it's been constant pain in the frontal area. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Medical history, you're in hyper, you have high blood pressure, but that's controlled with diet. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: No surgical history, no really hospitalizations. ; Therapist: The pain, though, isn't really impacting your day-to-day living and daily life. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: You tried Tylenol and Moltren, it didn't help. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Otherwise, no medications. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: You've got the family history of your mom with migraines, otherwise your family is healthy. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: You smoke about a half a pack a day. ; Therapist: You don't drink. ; Therapist: And then you were, you said you took a trip about a week ago? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Or two weeks ago? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Yeah, I don't know. ; Patient: It was in North Carolina. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Yeah, I can understand your concern about your friend. ; Therapist: You said that he was having seizures. ; Patient: I've just never had this kind of pain before. ; Therapist: Yeah, and I can understand that. ; Therapist: And, you know, so what I would like to do is, we've pretty much gone over your history. ; Therapist: What I'd like to do is complete a physical exam. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Do some testing. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: And I want to ask, too, if there's any other concerns I need to address before we get to that final exam. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: Yep, that sounds good. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Sounds great. ; Patient: Okay.

dialogue: Therapist: So Jess, how did the police interview go? ; Therapist: How did that play out? ; Patient: Well they came to my house on Tuesday and I had my mum with me and I had to tell them everything. ; Therapist: Yeah it's hard. ; Patient: Like I had to go into so much detail. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Hey Jess, just come back to me, just come back to the room a little bit. ; Therapist: Can you just look up at me? ; Therapist: What colour eyes do I have? ; Therapist: Can you check that out? ; Patient: Um, brown. ; Therapist: Brown, okay good. ; Therapist: I'm just trying to get you back into the room with me okay. ; Therapist: So just look around the room, can you see maybe this painting that's up here? ; Therapist: What do you see? ; Therapist: Can you tell me what the paintings are? ; Patient: Beach. ; Therapist: Yeah a beach. ; Patient: Sun. ; Therapist: Yeah cool, okay. ; Therapist: Okay, okay. ; Therapist: I want you to do something, I just want you to catch this for me. ; Therapist: See if you can catch it, throw it back to me. ; Therapist: Okay just throw it back to me, that's it, that's it, good, good, good. ; Therapist: Just throw it back to me. ; Therapist: Good, okay. ; Therapist: Just see if you can stay here, stay here in the room with me, yeah? ; Therapist: Yeah? ; Therapist: Hey and also listen, catch that one, that's it. ; Therapist: Okay so just want you to keep in the room with me a bit, I know sometimes it's a bit stressful and a bit overwhelming okay but we're still connected okay? ; Therapist: You're not back there okay? ; Therapist: How are you feeling? ; Patient: Oh. ; Therapist: Just stay with me. ; Therapist: Yeah okay. ; Patient: Yeah really it was, I did, really hard to talk about. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: That stuff. ; Therapist: Yeah it's completely understandable, these are really, really tough moments you know and those sort of conversations with the police sometimes can be very stressful for you yeah? ; Therapist: I get it yeah. ; Therapist: So maybe, how are you feeling now? ; Therapist: Where are you at? ; Patient: Yeah a bit better. ; Therapist: Yeah okay so maybe just, why don't we keep talking and just remember that we're connected okay and you're here with me. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah? ; Therapist: So tell me a little bit more, so your mum came with you to do the statement? ; Patient: Yeah so mum was with me, they came over and there were two detectives and they just wanted to know everything and it took like hours. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And how are you feeling now after you've done it? ; Therapist: What's that? ; Patient: Like I'm glad it's over and done with, I didn't realise how hard it would be to talk about it here. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: For some reason I was thinking it was all over and done with. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: But I'm okay now. ; Therapist: Well it's really understandable, it's completely understandable that sometimes it's difficult to talk and sometimes you can avoid back to tough times yeah so why don't we just keep talking, we'll keep talking like this okay? ; Patient: Yeah.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name jess, sex female ; Therapist Information : Name brown ; Past Session Information: Follow up session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms anxiety chief complaints anxiety ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior lost; speech slow, mood  affect depressed, thought negative, perception congruent, cognitive functions disorganized, judgement and insight poor and intact ; Psychotherapy Type: Cbt; mode individual. ; Psychotherapy Technique : Supportive problem solving ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Techniques used therapists tried grounding techniques to help patient stay present and connected to the current environment. He also tried to validate and empathize with patient by normalizing and encourage his thoughts. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Anxiety

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Jill, how you doing today? ; Patient: I'm doing okay. ; Therapist: Just okay? ; Patient: Well, I know we've talked before about me thinking about suicide and I'm starting to think about it a little bit stronger than before, I think a little bit more clearly. ; Therapist: Can you tell me a little bit more about that? ; Patient: Well, when we've talked before, I've had the feelings and the thoughts of suicide, but now it's kind of starting to like, I'm thinking about it more often. ; Patient: I'm thinking about it a little more clearly and that's alarming to me. ; Therapist: Do you want to die? ; Patient: Yeah, yeah, sometimes. ; Therapist: Sometimes? ; Patient: I mean, you know, sometimes I know it would be scary to try it and my husband would be so hurt, but at the same time, I want to end this. ; Patient: I want to end the feeling that I'm having. ; Therapist: Depression? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Do you have any plan as to how you would end your life if you decided to do that? ; Patient: I mean, I know if I wanted to that we have pills in the cabinet, so it wouldn't be that hard. ; Patient: I could just take the bottle and... ; Therapist: The same pills that you prescribed for the depression? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Do you feel like you're going to carry out that plan? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: I mean, part of it, that's why I'm nervous because like I'm worried that I might, but at the same time, you know, I'm afraid to. ; Patient: Sometimes I think that I might and sometimes I think I won't. ; Patient: I don't want to, but sometimes I get scared that I will. ; Therapist: Today you're a little worried that you will or you're a little closer to it than usual. ; Therapist: Right? ; Therapist: We've talked about this before in the past. ; Therapist: You've come in, you've had kind of that same plan with the pills and the thoughts. ; Therapist: And what stopped you those times? ; Therapist: What stopped you in the past? ; Patient: In the past, I thought, this will get better. ; Patient: I just have to keep trying. ; Patient: I thought, what will my husband feel when I'm gone? ; Patient: And my family, my parents, my brother and sister. ; Patient: I thought that this is as bad as it can get and it has to get better eventually, but now I'm just starting to feel like I don't think it's going to get better. ; Therapist: All right, so those times before when you had the same feeling, right, you felt just as bad as you feel now, really down, a little hopeless. ; Therapist: What happened a few days after that, after the thoughts, suicide went away? ; Therapist: What was your outlook on life then? ; Patient: I mean, I feel a little better, you know, and then I'd say to myself, that was silly, you know. ; Patient: I don't want to do that. ; Patient: I don't want to end things, you know. ; Patient: It's too rash. ; Patient: But, you know, it's starting to feel like a permanent problem. ; Therapist: So you feel like this time, these suicidal thoughts, they're markedly different than what you've experienced before? ; Patient: I wouldn't say markedly, but I would say they're different. ; Patient: They're a little, they're stronger. ; Therapist: More intense this time? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: What do you think brought these feelings on? ; Therapist: Before we talked about it, I know this relationship, surrounding relationships, they're the same thing this time. ; Patient: I mean, I guess that has something to do with it. ; Patient: I guess it's just like when I look to everything, like everything that could be good or everything, just everything like life, my relationships, the future. ; Patient: I just look at it and I see despair. ; Patient: I just see everything going wrong and I just don't see how it could get better. ; Patient: I just don't see it. ; Therapist: You know, a sense of hopelessness. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So this time is different because you feel it's maybe less situational, less tied up to relationships and more, well, philosophical. ; Therapist: You're looking at your outlook and you're saying it's not going to get you better. ; Therapist: That's the point, don't you know what? ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So this is a little bit of new territory for you. ; Therapist: How long have you been feeling this way with the intensity you have right now? ; Patient: Probably a week, maybe, no less. ; Therapist: What has prevented you from hurting yourself? ; Therapist: That was last week. ; Patient: I'm afraid to do it. ; Patient: I'm just scared. ; Patient: It's like jumping off a diving board. ; Patient: Like you get up to the edge and you stand there. ; Patient: That's where I'm at. ; Therapist: Have you made any gestures to harm yourself? ; Therapist: Like if you went and grabbed the pills or went to the medicine cabinet and looked at the pills, anything like that? ; Patient: Yes. ; Patient: Sometimes I look at them. ; Therapist: You look at them. ; Therapist: Have you done anything further than look at them? ; Patient: Well, I mean, so I have to take them. ; Patient: It's my prescription. ; Patient: So when it's time I start thinking about it, like it's more, I think about my, like the ideations come even more because it's like a trigger. ; Patient: It's like I'm thinking about the pills. ; Patient: So I go to the cabinet and I get my pills and I take the one that I'm supposed to, but I just look at the bottle and I kind of stand there and I just think instead of putting the bottle back, I could take it with me. ; Therapist: And what do you end up doing? ; Patient: It takes a while, but I put it back. ; Patient: It's scary. ; Patient: Like I look into the bottle and I'm afraid because dying is scary, but. ; Therapist: And how about the pain that you would cause your husband and the rest of your family? ; Patient: Yeah, I don't want to do that. ; Therapist: You don't want that? ; Patient: I don't, I don't, I don't want my husband to find me. ; Patient: I don't want him to feel like this is his fault. ; Patient: I don't want him to be sad that I'm gone. ; Patient: I don't want him to feel like I feel. ; Therapist: And when relatives of somebody that committed suicide hear about the suicide, who do they blame? ; Therapist: The suicide. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: And it's not their fault. ; Patient: It's not their fault. ; Patient: And I know that they wouldn't be able to get over it. ; Patient: And I know that they'll be thinking about how bad I felt. ; Patient: They'll have to know what it really felt like for me. ; Patient: So I know this is a tough time, right? ; Therapist: But the good news is you're here talking to me about it. ; Therapist: Right? ; Therapist: And you're talking about it, I'm going to guess that you want to do something for bad to feel better. ; Therapist: Are you going to carry out your plan? ; Therapist: Are you going to hurt yourself? ; Patient: I don't want to. ; Therapist: Are you going to? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: I think, I think, I think, I think, I think, I think, I think, I think, I think, I think, I think if I can just remember what it'll be like for them that will keep me from doing it. ; Patient: You know it's the times that I forget to think about how they're going to feel, that I get closer to the edge. ; Patient: But when I remember, you know, like it upsets me to think about what it'll be like for them. ; Patient: So if I can remember to think about that, then it'll help me not do that. ; Patient: But I think having the pills there in the cabinet like that is a big temptation for me. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So can we do this? ; Therapist: Your husband's at home, as I mentioned. ; Therapist: You take the pills once a day? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: Before bed? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Can we, would you be willing to sign a release so I can talk to him and he can hold onto those pills and just give you the pill each night? ; Therapist: You take one a night? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Would that be okay? ; Patient: Yeah, I think that would be a good idea. ; Therapist: Is there anything else in the medicine cabinet or anywhere else in the house that could be of danger to you? ; Patient: I think, yeah, I think it would be a good idea to just make sure that everything that was in the medicine cabinet. ; Therapist: All the pills? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Would he be willing to do that? ; Patient: Yeah, I think, yeah, I think that he would be willing to do that. ; Patient: He doesn't, he wants me to get through this. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And if I get a release to talk, I might go sign it? ; Patient: Yeah, I'll do that. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: I was really before, or you're familiar rather with this concept that we talked about before, contracting for safety. ; Therapist: I remember the prior times when you've been in the state. ; Therapist: Similar to this. ; Therapist: Can you promise me that you're going to not harm yourself? ; Patient: I can, yeah, I can do that. ; Patient: At least until next week when we meet again, I promise. ; Therapist: Let's be a little searing that. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Set something up for Ammar. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Yeah, I can definitely do that. ; Therapist: I can do that. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: This is a rough time. ; Therapist: I'm trying to appreciate how rough it is for you. ; Therapist: I want you to keep in mind how you felt after the times before and how you do tend to pull out of this and you look back at it a lot differently, but in the moment it's hard to see that. ; Therapist: It doesn't necessarily make this any easier, but if you can hang on until we can get through this cycle of depression, you'll probably have a different outlook. ; Therapist: If history is any evidence, right? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Does that kind of make sense? ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So, what do you have planned for the rest of the day after you leave here? ; Patient: You know, I'm just going to go home. ; Patient: My husband will be home from work and have dinner, watch TV. ; Patient: He'll be there, so. ; Therapist: Are you going to be alone at any time between when you leave here and when you come and see me tomorrow? ; Patient: Um, yeah. ; Patient: I'll probably be home for a little while in the morning, but I have to work so I won't have, you know, I'll be busy. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: If these feelings intensify to where you do feel you're going to act on them, would you promise to call me? ; Therapist: If you can't get along with me, call 911? ; Patient: Yeah, I'll do that. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: I'm going to go get that released so we can talk to your husband and then I'll see you for a few minutes and we'll set up a plan for tomorrow. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: All right? ; Therapist: Thank you. ; Patient: Thanks, Joe.
summary: Patient Particulars : Sex - female; marital status married ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Phone number- 911 ; Past Session Information: Follow -up ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms depression and suicidality chief complaints 1 hopelessness 2 wants to end life 3despair ; History: Nil ; Crisis Markers: Suicidal ideations ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior depressed; speech dull, mood  affect low, thought negative, perception normal, cognitive functions clouded, judgement impaired. ; Psychotherapy Type: Supportive cbt; mode individual. ; Psychotherapy Technique : Supportive ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Following issues arising in the session 1 suicidal ideation patient has an increased frequency and intensity of suicidal thoughts, indicating a heightened level of distress and hopelessness. She feels sense of hopelessness and despair. 2 risk assessment therapist assessed the presence of a specific plan and the clients intention to carry it out. 3 coping strategies therapist explores few coping mechanisms to control her suicidal thoughts. Also discussed safety planning such as medications and involving a trusted support person like her husband. 4 action plan patient agreed to refrain from self-harm or suicide until the next therapy session and ensured that she has access to immediate support if needed, such as contacting the therapist or emergency services. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Depression and suicidality ; Action Plan : The therapist made patient understand the importance of follow-up. Next session has scheduled and ensured patient to access for an immediate support if needed, such as contacting the therapist or emergency services. ; Next session details: Next session scheduled. .

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Jesse, how are you doing today? ; Patient: Not too good, Dr. Grande. ; Therapist: Not so good? ; Patient: No, I just got into a fight with my parents. ; Therapist: What's been going on? ; Patient: I've been doing heroin for a few months now. ; Patient: I didn't think my parents knew, but I guess they found a needle in my room. ; Patient: They knew what I was doing. ; Patient: They told me that I have to start shaping up and I need to stop doing any kind of drugs. ; Patient: They said the next time they find any kind of drugs, that's it. ; Patient: They're going to kick me out of the house. ; Therapist: So they're at the point where anything else happens and they discover it and you're out on the street. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: What are your feelings about being out on the street? ; Patient: I don't want to be out there. ; Patient: I don't know who would be. ; Patient: It would be hard just to stop cold turkey. ; Patient: I know a couple of buddies that did that and it's not good when you get junk sick. ; Patient: I'm kind of stuck because I don't want to be out on the streets, but it's just going to be so hard to give it up. ; Therapist: There are conflicting feelings here. ; Therapist: You don't want to be out on the street, but you don't want to give up the heroin at the same time. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: I just don't want to give it up, but I kind of know I have to. ; Patient: I'm a young guy. ; Patient: I couldn't make it outside of my parents' house and I definitely don't want to be out on the streets. ; Therapist: You want to stop to avoid the consequences that could happen. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: But to this point you haven't been able to? ; Patient: I guess at this point I really haven't had something that would make me. ; Patient: I've been doing it for a while and it's been pretty great, but I never really had any kind of problem with it. ; Patient: Nothing too bad has happened, so this is kind of the first time something has hit me where it's like, man, I really got to stop it. ; Therapist: So this is the first consequence or potential consequence that's motivated you since you started using. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: How strong is the craving to use? ; Patient: I mean, when I first started it was pretty freaking great. ; Patient: The rush that you get from it, it's just mind-numbing. ; Patient: It's just amazing. ; Patient: But I've noticed recently that the rush isn't as intense anymore and it's even kind of starting to backfire a little bit where I actually feel a little sick without using it. ; Patient: And that kind of scares me, but the crazy things are definitely still there. ; Therapist: So when you try to cut back, have you tried to cut back? ; Patient: I have before, but there was no reason to, so I didn't try very hard. ; Therapist: When you did try, did you have the feeling where you were getting sick? ; Patient: I did, yeah. ; Patient: It wasn't as bad as any of my buddies, but I definitely didn't feel well. ; Therapist: Have your parents given you any options in terms of, like, do they understand that it seems like you're a little dependent on...? ; Patient: Yeah, I mean, they do. ; Patient: I definitely, like, I don't hold anything against my parents. ; Patient: I actually have a pretty good relationship with them. ; Patient: I know what I'm doing isn't good for me. ; Patient: And they said that they would completely support me. ; Patient: They told me that they have a place picked out where I can go and that they'd be willing to pay for it and everything. ; Patient: But they said if I don't meet them halfway, then that's it. ; Patient: They're done. ; Therapist: Alright, so they have a solution, in a sense, for what's going on. ; Therapist: Is it like a detox? ; Patient: It is, yeah. ; Therapist: So they have a solution to help get you off the heroin. ; Therapist: But is there still a part of you that doesn't want to go that route? ; Patient: I mean, I think I'm starting to come to terms that it's time to stop. ; Patient: And it might be good that maybe I'm stopping so early. ; Patient: I know my friends have been doing it for a lot longer than I have. ; Patient: But I just, I don't know if the detox is going to work. ; Patient: I mean, it's hard for me to focus on, like, anything until, sometimes until I get my next fix. ; Therapist: Alright, so there's a few problems here. ; Therapist: So one is can you commit to going to detox? ; Therapist: And the second is, even if you successfully complete that, when you come back out, you can be able to avoid the heroin. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: It's tough right now because actually my dealer lives in my neighborhood. ; Patient: I mean, he's just a few houses down. ; Patient: My girlfriend lives in our community too. ; Patient: And, like, he's on the way to her house. ; Patient: So, like, I'll kind of just maybe pick it up on my way and throw it in my book bag and then get hanging out with my girlfriend a bit. ; Patient: And then maybe on my way back home I'll shoot up the buddy. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: So, really, you're running into him as you walk to your girlfriend's house. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah, and he's there and the temptation is great. ; Patient: I mean, it's, like, that house is kind of, that's actually where I shoot up a lot. ; Patient: So it's like whenever I'm... ; Patient: I was in his house. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: So it's like whenever I'm coming up to his house, I'm like, I start getting excited, you know, like, I start anticipating how great it's going to feel the next time. ; Patient: And it's, I don't know, it's like stuck with me. ; Patient: I get excited when I see his house. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: So you have a feeling. ; Therapist: So, let's explore this. ; Therapist: So as you're walking up to the, well, as you're getting ready to pass his house, like, to point your way to your girlfriend, you divert to kind of go to his house and you have this feeling of excitement. ; Therapist: What's the thought that's going through your mind? ; Patient: I, like, I kind of, I just can't wait for the next hit. ; Patient: Now, like, I've passed his house since my parents had given me the ultimatum. ; Patient: And now it's kind of mixed because I'm like, oh, man, if I get to do that and somehow they find out, like, it's kind of all over for me. ; Patient: And then, but on the other hand, I'm thinking about how great it's going to be. ; Patient: I'm just kind of like, I'm playing in my mind how much I'm going to do and like, what kind of plans we'll have for the rest of the night. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So you have a few things going on. ; Therapist: Do you think, like, is your plan right now to go into the detox? ; Patient: It is, yeah. ; Patient: It's, yeah, I mean, my definite plan is to go into the detox. ; Patient: And if the detox works, like, I mean, I think I could be done with it. ; Patient: But it's just, I don't know if the detox can work. ; Patient: And I mean, I've never, I only tried to cut back that one time. ; Patient: I mean, I don't know how good I'll be at it, you know. ; Therapist: Let's presume for a second that the detox would be successful and you wouldn't be, well, you mean you wouldn't be on heroin coming out of detox, right? ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: Are you worried at that point that you'll go right back? ; Patient: I don't know if I'll go right back. ; Patient: Like, I think if I can get off it, if the detox actually works, like they say I do, I think I can stay off it. ; Patient: I think, like, my, I think my cravings will still always be there. ; Patient: But now that it's, like, now that I've come to the realization that some of the stuff that I can lose if I get caught, I mean, if I can get off it for good, I don't, I don't think I'd go back. ; Patient: It might be hard, like, if I run into my buddy or something. ; Therapist: That's the point of worry, right? ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: So there is a concern that you'll, you could, you could go back if you run into him. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: But if you could stay away from him, you think you'd increase your chances of being successful? ; Patient: Well, I mean, yeah, definitely. ; Patient: I won't, like, there's, there's so many, like, experiences in this house that, that kind of feed into the anticipation and the cravings. ; Patient: So, I mean, if that doesn't happen, you know, it'll probably help. ; Therapist: When are your plans in terms of going into detox? ; Patient: Pretty soon. ; Patient: I think I'm supposed to go on Monday after the weekend. ; Patient: So, like, three days. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So it, it, it actually sounds like what your parents have put in place, you believe will work, right? ; Therapist: You have confidence it'll work. ; Therapist: And that your, your worry is, what worry you have is when you get out, can you avoid, can you avoid your friend? ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: You don't buy from anybody else other than your friend? ; Patient: No, no, no. ; Therapist: So, so that's really becomes the, you know, maybe one of your key goals here since, since you're kind of, sound like you're committed to the detox part. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: I mean, unless I'm, I'm reading that incorrectly, that, that seems to be something you're- ; Patient: No, yeah, if it works, I mean, I can try. ; Therapist: So it's, it's preparing for life after detox. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: And avoiding, well, you've heard the phrase, people, places, things, with the, you know, addictions or, or substance use. ; Therapist: So in this case, you need to avoid, it would seem, your friend. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: And, and where he lives. ; Therapist: Right, which is unfortunately not far from you and in between, like his house is in between your house and your girlfriend's. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: Right, so, is there a way, this may seem a little odd, but is there a way to walk around the block where you can completely avoid his house and still get to your girlfriend's house? ; Patient: Yeah, I mean, there is, it's kind of out of the way, but I think, yeah, I could go, there's like a, like a horseshoe path, I could, yeah, I could, I could like go up the block and then like around the horseshoe and then, and then I could like turn right and get to her house there. ; Patient: And then, yeah. ; Therapist: So you would never even see his house. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: How about other options as well, like, so there's that option, how about her coming over to where your parents live, has that ever happened before? ; Patient: I mean, yeah, she's, she's come over, so maybe if like, maybe if I tell her that it'll, it'll help me out, she can, like she can make that walk and it'll be, like it'll be easier. ; Therapist: Because she can walk right by that house without a problem. ; Patient: Right, right, and I mean, if I start walking out of the house, it'll be harder for me to actually do what I'm supposed to, so if I like can't even leave and she comes, that might be best. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And to get to work, do you have to pass his house? ; Patient: No, not at all. ; Patient: I, like I work down the road, so I just drive, like I drive the other way out the, out the community. ; Therapist: Right, so there's kind of some, like really there's a physical kind of slash behavioral strategy here, which is just physically keeping you away. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: From having to go buy his house and it sounds like the only reason other than to, to buy and use drugs is to see your girlfriend. ; Patient: Right, yeah. ; Therapist: And there's an alternative strategy here, right? ; Therapist: She, she can come to you or you could go all the way, all the way around and then all the way around back. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: To return it and to get back and forth to work, you don't have to go buy his house at all. ; Patient: Yeah, yeah, I could do that actually. ; Patient: I don't know where. ; Therapist: Is there ever a time where he comes to you? ; Patient: Honestly, not that much. ; Patient: Now, he, obviously he doesn't, he doesn't really like to leave his house much. ; Patient: He's, he's kind of the only one who lives there. ; Patient: So that's kind of, he just deals out of there and then shoots up there, so he, he stays in his house most of the time, so now he doesn't even come out. ; Therapist: And we, you know, we, we know that there's automatic thoughts, we talked about this before, right? ; Therapist: There's automatic thoughts that lead to feelings and behaviors. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: Right? ; Therapist: And can you identify a specific thought that may occur or maybe has occurred not related to walking by his house but when you've been in your house? ; Therapist: Like, that maybe has motivated you to go walk to his house? ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: I'm bored. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Yeah, just straight up, I mean when, when there's nothing to do in the house, my parents are gone. ; Patient: So it's a, it's the best way to have fun. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: So you've identified a thought that, that directly connects to a behavior you want to avoid, right? ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: So I'm bored leads to using the drugs, right? ; Therapist: Because that would alleviate the boredom, right? ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: Is there an adaptive response that you can put in right there that you can interject right at that moment when you say, I'm bored? ; Therapist: Is there an adaptive response you can apply? ; Therapist: Let's assume this is post detox, right? ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: Okay, that's your plan. ; Therapist: You're sitting in your house, detox is done. ; Therapist: There's no more, you know, we would hope withdrawal type symptoms. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: The thought comes upon you, I'm bored. ; Therapist: What's a, what's a self-talk piece that could be interjected there? ; Patient: I think like if I, if I remember to think what I don't want to do when I think that I'm bored, like I just kind of come up with something else. ; Patient: So like right now my, usually my two choices when I'm bored are either to go to my buddy's house or go to my girl's house who's, you know, across from my buddy's. ; Patient: So maybe that could just be like one of the times where I call my girl and be like, hey, can you just like come over, we can do something. ; Patient: Like just to kind of distract me from, from like wanting to go over to his place, you know. ; Therapist: So, so the, the adaptive response is I'll call my girlfriend. ; Patient: Right, yeah. ; Therapist: So I'm bored and, and she, you know, it sounds like what you said, she's really supportive of you quitting. ; Patient: Yeah, I mean she wasn't too happy with me doing it. ; Patient: She doesn't use, so I mean there's, there's that. ; Patient: So she'll be all, she'll be all on board for that. ; Therapist: It seems like consequences motivate you, right? ; Therapist: I mean that's what brought you in today, like to talk about this anyway. ; Therapist: So I'm wondering if another adaptive response, response couldn't involve, you know, I don't want any, any trouble. ; Therapist: You know, and you can substitute a lot of words in for trouble. ; Therapist: There's all kinds of trouble that can occur from use and error, right? ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: So getting kicked out of your house, I don't want to, you know, I don't want to get kicked out of my house. ; Therapist: I'm clean and there's something else I can do here other than drugs, right? ; Therapist: Like I'm thinking in times when your girlfriend might not be around. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Right, so you still want to have, you want to have an adaptive response that's not necessarily tied to a person in case she isn't around. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: So you can use that one, certainly, and that's a good one. ; Therapist: But when she's not around and you kind of revisit those consequences in your adaptive response, do you think that's going to be enough motivation to keep you from going to the house? ; Patient: Yeah, I do. ; Patient: I mean, I, like as of right now, work's going good, like school is going good. ; Patient: I don't, like I really don't want any problems. ; Patient: And I think like now I'm starting to realize that if I, if I do keep using it's not just going to be something like that I do when I'm bored or like that I'm doing for fun. ; Patient: It's going to turn into like a problem that's going to kind of affect everything else. ; Patient: So I think like if I just remember to tell myself, like when I'm feeling bored, if I just remember to tell myself like I don't, I don't want to be out in the streets and like especially I don't want to lose my job. ; Patient: Like I think telling myself those things, it'll help remind me like kind of what's at stake, you know. ; Therapist: Good, good. ; Therapist: So it sounds like you have some adaptive responses to use. ; Therapist: Another thing that occurs to me is your parents around much? ; Patient: Yeah, I mean they're, my dad works a lot, my mom's usually at home. ; Patient: She works too, it's like a part-time job so she's usually like home at night. ; Therapist: And is it at night one of the times when you have gone over to your friend's house? ; Therapist: Well it's actually, it's more during the day. ; Therapist: More during the day. ; Therapist: So she could be an asset in terms of trying to stop you from leaving the house but only when she's there. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: And similar to your father, you know. ; Therapist: So it's really, I guess we kind of narrow it down to when you're at home alone and particularly when your girlfriend's not available, that's your high-risk time. ; Patient: Right, yeah. ; Therapist: So we have the cognitive adaptive responses to come in and play. ; Therapist: But what if there's anything more behavioral we can do like can you go somewhere else? ; Patient: Well I think like one of the other things I do to kind of clear my head is I always go for a drive. ; Patient: So like if I start feeling bored, I think maybe if I like get in my car and like I sat on the bus past his house, if I just drive away, like just physically leave the temptation. ; Patient: And then like from there I can go to a bookstore or like a comic book store. ; Patient: I could spend hours in there. ; Patient: So maybe if I can like, I can remind myself to drive away, go to those stores and like maybe I can just kind of stay out there late enough until either like my girlfriend's home or my parents come home. ; Therapist: I think that's a good plan. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: And remember that the more we apply these adaptive responses, right, what we hope is that you, the risk decreases, like your craving decreases, your motivation to stay clean increases. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: So while it may be a little inconvenient to drive someplace every time no one's available and you get that thought, that might not be something you have to do forever. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: But that'll minimize the risk for now and we want to focus on the short term first and then we'll worry more about the mid-term and long-term. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: Circumstances may change. ; Therapist: Maybe people reside there forever. ; Therapist: Maybe somebody's work schedule will change. ; Therapist: Maybe there are other adaptations you can make. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: But for now, I think this would be a good way to go, just keeping you away from the circumstance that you definitely don't want. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: So good. ; Therapist: There's a few behavioral pieces we have in here and then a few cognitive as well. ; Therapist: So I want to see you in a couple of days before we go into detox so that we can practice some of these adaptive responses. ; Therapist: I'd like you to practice them at home between now and then as well. ; Therapist: Right? ; Therapist: And these behavioral responses as well. ; Therapist: But we'll try to get them shored up right before detox and I'll see it right after you come out as well. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And we'll make sure that we just keep working on applying and refining these adaptive cognitive responses and these adaptive behavioral responses. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: Does that sound like a plan? ; Patient: Yeah, definitely. ; Patient: I think that will definitely help, especially being with your adaptive detox. ; Patient: That will definitely be the best. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: I appreciate you coming in, Jesse, and I'll see you in a couple of days. ; Patient: Yeah, thank you. ; Patient: Thank you. ; Therapist: Thanks.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name kyle; sex male ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Follow- up ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms substance use chief complaints 1 craving and withdrawal symptoms when he stop substance use. 2 uncontrollable temptation for substance ; History: Nil ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior; normal speech normal; mood  affect low. ; Psychotherapy Type: Cbt; mode individual. ; Psychotherapy Technique : Thought challenging and problem solving ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Issues discussed in the session 1. Problems patient struggles with heroin addiction. He experiences cravings and withdrawal symptoms when he tries to stop heroin use. 2. Fear patient fears that parents found out about this and has to bear consequences for it. He is motivated to stop using heroin because of this potential consequences of getting kicked out of his parents house and losing his job. 3. Support system parents and girlfriend have offered to help him get into detox. 4. Strategies therapist discussed behavioural strategies to avoid triggers and temptations and finding alternative activities to alleviate boredom. He helped him to identify adaptive responses to counter negative thoughts and cravings, such as reminding himself of the consequences and focusing on his future goals. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Substance use ; Action Plan : Therapist asked him to identify adaptive responses to counter negative thoughts and cravings like reminding himself the consequences of drug use and focusing on his goals for the future. Also introduced short-term and long-term goals like successfully completing detox and maintain sobriety. ; Next session details: Session scheduled after couple of days

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Susan, how are you doing today? ; Patient: I'm doing good, how are you? ; Therapist: I'm doing well, thanks for asking. ; Therapist: I want to give you a brief assessment to help measure functions like memory and thinking. ; Therapist: Is that okay with you? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: So the first part of this assessment, we're going to be handing the sheet back and forth. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: I have a table there so you can write on it. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And for the second part I'll get that out of your way and I'll work on some other parts of it. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Does that sound good? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So I want you to take a look at this section right here. ; Therapist: Okay, I have my finger pointed. ; Therapist: Please draw a line going from a number to a letter in ascending order. ; Therapist: I want you to begin here and draw a line from one, then to A, then to two, and so on, and end here. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Thank you. ; Therapist: I want you to copy this drawing as accurately as you can in the space below. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Thank you. ; Therapist: So in this empty space here, I'd like you to draw a clock, put in all the numbers, and set the time to five past four. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Thank you for drawing this clock. ; Therapist: You're welcome. ; Therapist: Can you tell me the name of this animal? ; Patient: Giraffe. ; Therapist: And how about the name of this animal? ; Patient: Bear. ; Therapist: And the name of that animal? ; Patient: Hippopotamus. ; Therapist: Thank you. ; Patient: You're welcome. ; Therapist: This is a memory test. ; Therapist: I'm going to read a list of words that you will have to remember now and later on. ; Therapist: Listen carefully. ; Therapist: When I'm through, tell me as many words as you can remember. ; Therapist: It does not matter in what order you say them. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Truck, banana, violin, barn, green. ; Patient: Banana, truck, violin, green, barn. ; Therapist: Thank you. ; Patient: You're welcome. ; Therapist: I'm going to read the same list for a second time. ; Therapist: Try to remember and tell me as many words as you can, including words you said the first time. ; Therapist: Truck, banana, violin, barn, green. ; Patient: Truck, banana, violin, barn, green. ; Therapist: Thank you. ; Therapist: I will ask you to recall those words again at the end of the test. ; Therapist: I am going to say some numbers when I'm through. ; Therapist: Repeat them to me exactly as I have said them. ; Therapist: Three, two, nine, six, five. ; Patient: Three, two, nine, six, five. ; Therapist: Thank you. ; Patient: You're welcome. ; Therapist: Now I'm going to say some more numbers, but when I'm through, you must repeat them to me in the backwards order. ; Therapist: Eight, five, two. ; Patient: Two, five, eight. ; Therapist: Thank you. ; Therapist: I'm going to read a sequence of letters. ; Therapist: Every time I say the letter A, tap your hand once. ; Therapist: If I say a different letter, do not tap your hand. ; Therapist: F B A C M N A A J K L B A F A K D E A A A J A M O F A J K L B A F A K D E A A A J A M O F A A B. Thank you. ; Therapist: Now I ask you to count by subtracting seven from ninety, and then keep subtracting seven from your answer until I tell you to stop. ; Patient: So starting with ninety and then going down seven. ; Therapist: That's correct. ; Patient: Ninety, eighty-three, seventy-six, sixty-nine, sixty-two, fifty-five. ; Therapist: That's good. ; Therapist: Thank you. ; Therapist: I'm going to read you a sentence. ; Therapist: Repeat it after me exactly as I say it. ; Therapist: A bird can fly into closed windows when it's dark and windy. ; Patient: A bird can fly into closed windows when it's dark and windy. ; Therapist: Thank you. ; Therapist: Now I'm going to read you another sentence. ; Therapist: Repeat it after me exactly as I say it. ; Therapist: The caring grandmother sent groceries over a week ago. ; Patient: The caring grandmother sent groceries over a week ago. ; Therapist: Thank you. ; Therapist: Tell me as many words as you can think of that begin with a certain letter of the alphabet that I will tell you in a moment. ; Therapist: You can say any kind of word you want except for proper nouns like Bob or Boston, numbers, or words that begin with the same sound but have a different suffix. ; Therapist: For example, love, lover, loving. ; Therapist: I will tell you to stop after one minute. ; Therapist: Are you ready? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Now tell me as many words as you can think of that begin with the letter S. ; Patient: Shoes, socks, stockings, sweater, shirt, stripes, suitcase, safe, strategic, surly, sweet, super, ; Therapist: and ; Therapist: Tell me how a carrot and a potato are like. ; Patient: They're both vegetables. ; Therapist: Can you tell me how a diamond and a ruby are like? ; Patient: They're both stones. ; Therapist: And a cannon and a rifle, how are they like? ; Patient: They're both weapons. ; Therapist: I read some words to you earlier which I ask you to remember. ; Therapist: Tell me as many of those words as you can remember. ; Patient: Banana, truck, green, barn, violet. ; Therapist: Can you tell me today's date? ; Patient: February 10th, 2015. ; Therapist: Can you tell me what day of the week it is? ; Patient: Tuesday. ; Therapist: Can you tell me what place we're in right now? ; Patient: Wilmington University. ; Therapist: And what city we're in? ; Patient: Dover. ; Therapist: Thank you Susan, you did very well.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name susan ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Wilmington university, dover ; Past Session Information: Session for assessment of cognitive functions ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Nil ; History: Nil ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behaviour patient was cooperative throughout the assessment and rapport could be established ; Psychotherapy Type: Nil ; Psychotherapy Technique : Nil ; Assessments: Montreal cognitive assessment ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Nil ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Nil ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Hi cinderella. well we have about half an hour together this time And how are you feeling right now? ; Therapist: What's your awareness? ; Therapist: Is a bit of a kind of situation different from last time? ; Patient: No, I'm still feeling the same. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: Just, yeah. ; Therapist: You said you were going to watch. ; Patient: Just a little frustrated at the moment, that's all. ; Therapist: What is the frustration like for you? ; Patient: It's just a tight feeling that I have. ; Patient: I just, yeah, it's very, it's difficult to put into words, but just, it just doesn't feel good. ; Therapist: So, let's shift it to your body. ; Therapist: Where in your body do you feel this tight feeling? ; Patient: I think it's in my chest. ; Therapist: So that's the heart area. ; Therapist: It's the feeling around the heart. ; Therapist: Yeah, right. ; Therapist: And what is there in that heart when you pay attention to that area in your heart? ; Therapist: What do you find there? ; Therapist: What sort of thing do you find there? ; Patient: Yes, it's just a really, just a compressing feeling. ; Therapist: I noticed that you have been saying it when you talked about your feelings. ; Therapist: And I would like to suggest if you can say I instead of it and see what happens in your body. ; Therapist: So go ahead. ; Patient: You actually want me to say? ; Therapist: Yes, yes, yes. ; Patient: My chest feels very tired. ; Patient: I feel very frustrated, angry. ; Therapist: Angry. ; Therapist: So that's what's coming out, frustration, anger. ; Therapist: So what are you doing in this moment with your anger as you are sensing it right here in your chest? ; Therapist: In this moment? ; Patient: I'm just accepting it. ; Patient: It's just there. ; Therapist: So you're accepting it. ; Therapist: And once you accept that anger inside you, what else do you do with that anger, having accepted it? ; Patient: It's just a part of me. ; Therapist: You notice you are saying it again? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: I am angry. ; Therapist: Use the word I. ; Therapist: I. ; Therapist: It's a thing to acknowledge this is you, not something out there. ; Therapist: You do it a lot. ; Therapist: And you think it's something very strong, you put it out there. ; Therapist: So it's a safe way to put it. ; Therapist: If you say I feel angry. ; Patient: I feel angry. ; Therapist: And who do you feel angry at? ; Patient: My ex-husband, yes. ; Therapist: Your ex-husband. ; Therapist: Sandra, having just explored some of your feelings around the situation you have, I'm going to suggest that you speak to Jeff on an empty chair. ; Therapist: This may be a little uncomfortable, but it helped me to facilitate a process where I become an observer and you'll be dialoguing with the party that you are actually having to deal with. ; Therapist: And I'll be facilitating for you the process and then pointing out some of the things that we could do to change the process. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Let's bring Jeff, in your imagination, that you ask if Jeff were here. ; Therapist: I'll bring a chair. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Welcome, Jeff. ; Therapist: I mean, I welcome Jeff. ; Therapist: You don't have to. ; Therapist: And there's Jeff. ; Therapist: So imagine his face, how he looks like, how you remember him now. ; Therapist: And bring him in in your fantasy. ; Therapist: And then when you're ready, just say whatever comes to you at that moment, this moment spontaneously. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: Jeff, I feel very frustrated about the situation that you have left me and the children in. ; Patient: I don't think you understand how hard it is at times and the things that I have to explain to them about this situation. ; Patient: It bothers me that you don't go out of your way to spend extra time with the children. ; Patient: And I really believe that in the future they will come to really resent that and not look at you as their father. ; Patient: I honestly can't understand why you don't want to spend more time with them. ; Patient: And irrespective of what's happened between us and you moving on and so forth, I just don't think that your children and my children should really suffer in that way. ; Patient: I would like them to have as normal a life as possible and be able to be with both of their parents. ; Patient: And what is so important rather than them wanting to be with them. ; Patient: It's just very hard. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So there's a kind of question. ; Therapist: You understand why this happened, et cetera, right? ; Therapist: So what next thing we'll do, you'll sit over there and you will be Jeff and see what Jeff can answer to you as to where he is at. ; Therapist: That may be a little bit difficult, but let's do a dialogue. ; Therapist: I see if he were here. ; Therapist: He's not here anyway. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So we'll be having a dialogue between Jeff, the imaginary Jeff that you have, and you in the present here and now. ; Therapist: Okay? ; Patient: And what is he saying? ; Therapist: Well, go ahead. ; Therapist: I'm going to suggest instead of over there. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: The moment you sit over there, you become Jeff. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And whatever Jeff says to the statement that you made, go ahead, Jeff. ; Patient: Sandra, I know that it must have been hard on you and the kids with me leaving. ; Patient: And it's not that I don't want to spend more time with them, but I am very busy with work and a few other things that are going on in my life. ; Patient: Sandra, my children do mean a lot to me. ; Patient: And if I was to spend more time with them, though, when I contact you about it, I don't want you to be short and rude. ; Patient: And I want you to be open to the opportunity. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: I'll stop you, Jeff, and say, Sandra, the children really mean a lot to me. ; Therapist: Just say that to her again, the statement. ; Patient: Sandra, the children really do mean a lot to me. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So go back to there. ; Therapist: So check your frustration over there. ; Therapist: How do you feel different about him now that he really cares for the children? ; Therapist: And there is a future maybe with him and them? ; Therapist: Do you feel that? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: So have you any appreciations to Jeff? ; Therapist: I know there are the hurts and frustration and anger, but any appreciation that he still cares for these children as a father? ;
