Patient: I really don't have any appreciation for that because the reason that you've given, that you're busy, like I'm busy in my life and I still give our children priority, they still take precedence in my life. ; Patient: And I just don't think that that's right. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And your father, he should be. ; Therapist: To the children. ; Patient: You should be proactive in wanting to see them. ; Patient: And I wouldn't mind if you wanted to see them more than what we have agreed. ; Patient: If there are times when you want to do something spontaneous and see them, then feel free to contact us and see if it's okay. ; Therapist: Good. ; Therapist: Good. ; Therapist: Good. ; Therapist: Come over there. ; Therapist: You sound like a very good idea. ; Therapist: Good offer. ; Therapist: Is it, Jeff, are you prepared to take that offer off for the kids' sake? ; Patient: Well, Sandra, I'm glad that you said that. ; Patient: And I think that's something. ; Patient: That's something that I could look at. ; Patient: But when I contact you, I don't want you to be to be short with me or rude. ; Patient: I want you to consider it and and to be honest. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Great. ; Therapist: Go over there. ; Therapist: So you're aware what's going on here? ; Therapist: The contract's happening. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: You're aware that it seems the two parties seem to be agreeing, beginning to agree to something important. ; Therapist: And that's the children. ; Therapist: So the children will not suffer. ; Therapist: They will actually benefit from that agreement if you two can really, really come to a mutual agreement to what, how are we going to take care of the children? ; Therapist: Because this thing, no matter how, in my view, no matter how people live together as a couple, separate together, the contract, life contract is I'm still my father to my children, you're still my mother to my children. ; Therapist: We could only get that anger out, frustration out. ; Therapist: We can come to an agreement as to how we're going to work together. ; Therapist: Even if we may not live together, we will live with the kids and they'll be happy. ; Therapist: Does that make sense to you? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: There's a but. ; Patient: But how do I? ; Patient: It's a question. ; Therapist: Good, good, good. ; Patient: This is in a counseling session and he hasn't really participated in informing this contract. ; Therapist: Yes, but you hear that this happened for you? ; Therapist: Yes. ; Therapist: And you've done it. ; Therapist: So is there something that now you have that you can begin to negotiate with him, no matter how he is? ; Therapist: Because there's now a new realization that the children need that father and mother. ; Therapist: How's that for you? ; Patient: Yes, maybe I just need to let him know that and just extend the invitation of having more ; Patient: time. ; Therapist: Without that. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Remember? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: And you're good at that. ; Therapist: You're very good. ; Therapist: Watching you working here, you're very good at creating contracts and very clear about what you want. ; Therapist: It's a question of how you can, the two parties can get to that agreement together. ; Therapist: What do you think? ; Therapist: Great. ; Therapist: Because this is a rehearsal for what's going to happen. ; Patient: Okay.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name sandra; sex female; marital status divorced ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Follow up session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Feelings of frustration and anger ; History: Progress static; present history patient and her husband got separated and both are busy with their lives. She is angry with her ex-husband for not taking out of enough time to spend with their children as she feels that children need their father; personal history family history- patient is divorced and is living with her children. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behaviour she was cooperative and rapport could be established; mood frustrated; affect broad; thought content- reflected annoyance towards ex-husband ; Psychotherapy Type: Type gestalt therapy; mode- individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Locating emotion; words and language i statements, empty chair, here and now ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patient expressed that she was angry with her ex-husband for not spending time with their children. Techniques were introduced by the therapist to acknowledge these feelings and react accordingly. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Nil ; Action Plan : Patient has to talk with her ex-husband on the basis of the insights she gained from the session. ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Patient: Each of the programs I spent one day, and none of them worked. ; Patient: And it was so frustrating because I took so much time out of my work to go, and I still couldn't find an appropriate placement for her. ; Therapist: My advice would be for you or your daughter to at least spend a week at the program. ; Therapist: Again, she needs to get the feel. ; Patient: No, we can't do that. ; Patient: There's no way I can take her, I couldn't drag her back there. ; Patient: Either any of those programs. ; Therapist: So what are you looking for then? ; Therapist: I need your help to find a program that fits her. ; Therapist: If I give you three more programs, will that work? ; Patient: But what if they don't work? ; Patient: How about if I... ; Therapist: You need to give it a chance. ; Therapist: You need to go and visit again. ; Patient: I know. ; Therapist: And take at least one out of your busy schedule. ; Patient: I actually came across a program which is perfect for her, and I really would like for you to help me see if this could work. ; Patient: I'd rather for you to try to do that instead of me shopping around for other programs because so far the ones that have been offered me have not worked. ; Therapist: So the program that you're interested in, you want me to go with you, or you want me to... ; Patient: I want you... ; Therapist: What do you want me to do? ; Patient: I want you to know if I could choose that program instead of one of the others that you have offered. ; Therapist: Okay, well looking at my schedule, it probably won't be until maybe two weeks. ; Therapist: My schedule is pretty much tied up. ; Therapist: The case just got transferred to me, so I'm not very familiar with your situation. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: Well, my daughter's 17 years old. ; Patient: She's actually very high functioning, thankfully. ; Patient: I went to three of these programs and none of them worked. ; Therapist: So you're looking for a day program. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: And something that really is good for your daughter. ; Patient: Right, right. ; Patient: And I was looking for a program that would stimulate her, that she'd really enjoy going to. ; Patient: But they were either babysitting programs or they were just... ; Patient: The participants were all at different developmental levels so that she couldn't really... ; Patient: She couldn't make friends. ; Patient: Yeah, they were not good for her. ; Therapist: While you were there, it was difficult. ; Therapist: Your daughter didn't really kind of fit in or connect with anybody while you were visiting. ; Patient: No, she did not. ; Patient: There just wasn't that sense of that common commonality. ; Patient: There was no basis for friendships. ; Patient: There were some young people there who were screaming, yelling, and who were talking to themselves. ; Patient: And she didn't know how to engage. ; Therapist: So just there wasn't... ; Therapist: When you visited, they didn't sort of... ; Therapist: The program didn't help you to connect or help your daughter to connect to anything that was going on. ; Therapist: You were just sort of viewing it. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: I observed for a whole day each of these programs, which was... ; Patient: It took a lot of time. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: I work full time and I don't... ; Patient: It was very difficult to schedule time to go to these places. ; Patient: Once I did, it was just so disappointing.
summary: Patient Particulars : Age 17 years; sex female; marital status unmarried; informant parent ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Nil ; History: Nil ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Nil ; Psychotherapy Type: Nil ; Psychotherapy Technique : Nil ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patients was accompanied by her parent who was looking to admit the patient in a program. Patient was unable to fit into the previously enrolled programs as she found it hard to make friends and it wasnt according to her developmental stage. Patient is high functioning as reported by the informant. Informant wanted the therapist to accompany them in choosing the right program for the patient. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Nil ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Andrea, thanks for coming in. ; Patient: Thank you. ; Therapist: So I don't know how much you know already about sort of my role here and why you're even here, so I thought I'd start by telling you a little bit about myself, basically. ; Therapist: My job is to meet with all of the students. ; Therapist: I meet with everybody about once or twice a semester and just talk with you a little bit about how things are going, different behaviors that you might be engaging in, and thinking about any changes you might want to make for your life if you decide that you do. ; Therapist: It's not my job to change you. ; Therapist: I couldn't even if I wanted to. ; Therapist: That's not my role at all. ; Therapist: It's really to help you think about how things are going for you and how you might like making changes or moving forward. ; Therapist: Does that sound okay? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right, so why don't we start by you telling me a little bit about yourself. ; Patient: Sure. ; Patient: As you know, I'm Andrea. ; Patient: I'm a junior. ; Patient: I'm in the marching band. ; Patient: I play the center sax. ; Therapist: Oh, neat. ; Patient: Yeah, I'm also in the, I'm a little bit of a band geek. ; Patient: I play, you know, the wind ensemble and the jazz band, things like that. ; Therapist: Wow, you really are involved in music. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: When did you start? ; Patient: I started playing about ten years ago, actually. ; Therapist: Wow. ; Patient: Yeah, I started on the violin first, and then I went on, explored a little with the piano, clarinet, finally found the tenor sax. ; Therapist: Very cool. ; Therapist: I've always wanted to be good at music. ; Therapist: All right, so it sounds like you're in band and a few other musical ensembles. ; Therapist: Any other hobbies you have or things you like to do for fun? ; Patient: You know, just hanging out with my friends or go to the beach, things like that. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Just kind of everyday sort of stuff. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Tell me a little bit about your family. ; Patient: Well, I have one older brother. ; Patient: He's about eight and a half years older than me, my parents, and I have a dog. ; Therapist: Cute. ; Therapist: What kind of dog? ; Patient: He's a golden retriever. ; Therapist: Oh, nice. ; Patient: My big boy. ; Therapist: Very fun. ; Therapist: All right, and how are things going in school for you? ; Patient: Pretty good. ; Patient: Grades have been pretty all right. ; Patient: Still like 3.7-ish. ; Therapist: Okay, great. ; Therapist: So you're doing well. ; Therapist: What sorts of goals do you have for after college or after high school? ; Patient: I'd like to, you know, I'd like to, of course, graduate high school, hopefully go to a nice Ivy League school. ; Therapist: Oh, all right. ; Patient: I mean, that might not happen, and then I'd like to go on and become a doctor, study psychology, maybe become a psychiatrist or something. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: You have some pretty big dreams. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: That's great. ; Therapist: That's really exciting to think about that and sort of be looking forward to the future and those things. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Well, one thing I'm going to ask you about is, you know, different people have sort of different things that they really value in their life, whether it's, you know, their cultural identity or their family or their friends or job or hobbies, things like that. ; Therapist: So here's a little sheet that goes through just some basic values that might be more or less important to certain people, like belonging or sense of community, again, cultural identity or family, friendship, modesty, religion, respect, self-determination and spirituality. ; Therapist: So when you think about yourself, which of these are kind of most important to you in terms of your life? ; Patient: I think a sense of community and belonging. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: I think those two and respect. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Can you tell me a little bit about why you picked those three? ; Patient: Yeah, well, I think community and belonging, I kind of related them. ; Patient: You know how I said I was in the marching band. ; Patient: I really, you know, I really enjoyed being in like that team setting of, you know, being with other people and all working together towards that one goal. ; Patient: And then in terms of respect, I kind of view that as one of like my major like rules. ; Patient: Like I really do think respect is important to respect myself and respect those around me. ; Patient: So I place great importance in that. ; Therapist: Okay, great. ; Therapist: So sort of being a part of a group and being a part of a team gives you a sense of belonging, like you said, and sort of a sense of purpose in a way. ; Therapist: And then the respect is really sort of all encompassing, not just authority, but respecting yourself, respecting your teammates or your bandmates and other people around you. ; Therapist: Okay, that's great. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Well, one of the things I want to talk to you about sort of relates to belonging and your friends. ; Therapist: So what kinds of things do you like to do when you get together with your friends? ; Patient: Sometimes we just, you know, go to the movies, go to the beach, like I had said, or sometimes we just get together at someone's house, play some board games and hang out. ; Therapist: And when you're hanging out with friends, is there ever alcohol involved? ; Patient: Yeah, sometimes. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Can you tell me a little bit about how alcohol fits into sort of your social scene? ; Patient: Well, it's mostly just for parties or party settings. ; Patient: It's kind of to get things going and get everything loosened up, as they say. ; Therapist: And so when you go to parties, most of the time there's alcohol there. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And how often do you think you would say you're drinking? ; Patient: I'd say on a not busy month, for instance. ; Patient: I'd say about like two weekends out of the month, two or three. ; Therapist: So about half the time you're drinking and half the time you're not. ; Therapist: Can you tell me what's different about the days when you choose to drink versus not to drink? ; Patient: The days that we drink are mostly, like I said, they're parties. ; Patient: So it's more of that whole partying and dancing and, you know, having everyone have fun. ; Patient: And then when we don't, it's a lot more relaxed. ; Patient: It's a lot more hanging out, playing board games, watching a movie. ; Patient: It's not, yeah. ; Therapist: So it really depends on what the activity is, whether or not alcohol is going to be there. ; Patient: Definitely. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And do you notice a big difference or can you tell me about the difference in your enjoyment level at, say, a party versus the night you're playing board games? ; Patient: I think of them as different. ; Patient: I think, you know, like in playing board games and things, it's meant to be relaxing. ; Patient: So it's nice to have like that kind of breather versus with a party it's a lot more energetic. ; Patient: After it all it's very draining. ; Patient: But in the moment it's quite fun to dance and have fun. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So there's sort of pros and cons on both sides. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: What are the things that you like about drinking or like about alcohol? ; Patient: It's, you know, when we drink we tend to have more fun because I guess we're not, you know, everyone's drinking together. ; Patient: We're a lot more loosened up and relaxed. ; Patient: And not really thinking about stresses or things like that. ; Patient: But it can be, when it's too much drinking, it can be obviously bad. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So sort of in the too much drinking or at times, can you tell me some of the less good things or not so good things about alcohol? ; Patient: A lot of times it will make people stupid. ; Patient: Yeah, you know, people make dumb decisions and things like that. ; Patient: We usually try to be as safe about it as possible. ; Patient: So we'll like sleep over a friend's house and so that we're not driving. ; Patient: And it's mostly within our friend group so we're not worried about strangers putting weird things in our drinks. ; Patient: But definitely some of the ideas people can have when they're drunk can be really stupid. ; Therapist: So you're trying to, like you said, not engage in really dangerous activities. ; Therapist: You're trying to stay put. ; Therapist: You're not driving. ; Therapist: You're trying to stay with people that you trust. ; Therapist: But yeah, it sounds like there's still some things happening from time to time. ; Patient: Sometimes, yeah. ; Therapist: Can you tell me a little bit about that? ; Patient: Well, I especially don't like it whenever me or one of my friends, like we drink too much and we end up like throwing up or things like that. ; Patient: That, I don't, that's not fun. ; Therapist: Yeah, throwing up is never fun. ; Patient: It's not. ; Therapist: And how often do you think that happens? ; Patient: For me, that's happened to me once. ; Patient: It was the first time I ever drank and it was a lot. ; Patient: I didn't know what I was doing. ; Patient: I was mixing all kinds of weird things and just kind of taking anything anyone gave me. ; Patient: That didn't end well. ; Patient: But after that, I haven't, but I do have friends that still do sometimes, so I'll end up like having to take care of them or something. ; Patient: It kind of puts it down around my fun. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So on the one side, some of the fun things associated with alcohol are people are just more relaxed, sort of carefree, can kind of let loose a little bit more. ; Therapist: But on the other hand, there's a little bit more, I guess, planning involved because you have to make sure that you're doing it safely or as safe as you can. ; Therapist: And then there can be some other consequences like throwing up or even if it's not you that sometimes you're stuck, your fun is sort of ruined when you're stuck dealing with a friend who drank too much. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Any other not so good things about the alcohol? ; Patient: Yeah, people can get a little sloppy, I guess. ; Patient: They're all loose with people in corners doing things that should be done in private and that kind of stuff. ; Therapist: So you're kind of stuck being exposed to things you don't need to see. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Got it. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Well, you mentioned a couple of times that you've made a few decisions to try and limit the dangerous aspect of the drinking. ; Therapist: Why did you make those decisions? ; Patient: I just, I have an aunt who is an alcoholic, so I see the issues that are involved in movies and things. ; Patient: I know that junk driving is an issue. ; Patient: So I want to be as safe as possible in those terms and be in a setting where we can let loose but still be safe, like at someone's house or someone's parent's home or something. ; Patient: So I know that there are dangers involved and I guess I want to limit that and still be able to have fun. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: It sounds kind of similar to your value of respect too. ; Therapist: So on the one hand, the drinking maybe helps with the belonging community to start. ; Therapist: If there's too much, then it sort ofcourse. ; Patient: Then it kind of defeats the purpose. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: And then with the respect, one of the things you mentioned is really wanting to respect yourself and not sort of cross boundaries, not sort of cross lines. ; Therapist: How do you think that the drinking fits in with that? ; Patient: In terms of what? ; Patient: In terms of respect? ; Patient: I think, well in a way I do think that drinking is probably a form of disrespect to my own body because I'm not putting things, I'm putting things in it that shouldn't be there. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: And then, but in terms of ways I am respecting myself, I am respecting myself by trying to stay in someone's house and trying to limit my drinking so I don't get to that blacked out, throwing up and everything. ; Patient: And try to, you know, let loose but still be in control of my behavior so I'm not going to go with some random person I met into I don't know where to do I don't know what and things like that. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So you're sort of looking for that balance of how much you can drink to have some of the positive benefit but not crossover. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And what have you come up with at this point? ; Therapist: Do you have sort of a limit that you stick to or are you? ; Patient: I usually, well I start off by make sure that I make my own drink so I know what's in it and how much is in it so that way I control how much I drink. ; Patient: So I'll usually just, you know, get one of those cups and then make one drink and then I'll try to make it last as long as possible and I'll be like alright this is my one drink and I'm good. ; Patient: And that way I still have something in my cup so people aren't going to be like oh here I have some more. ; Patient: I'll be like no I'm good I have mine and I'll still be, you know, having some to like let loose a little. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And do you feel that that's working pretty well for you or do you sometimes exceed that limit or what do you think? ; Patient: For the most part it works pretty well because like I said people, you know, if people come asking me trying to pressure me I'll be like no I'm good I have, you know, I still have some like I'll get some later and then never end up getting anything. ; Patient: But sometimes they'll be like hey let's take a shot and everyone's gathered around like the kitchen or something ready to take a shot and then at that point I'll be like oh well maybe I can take one more and that's when I start, you know, falling into the too much. ; Therapist: So a portion of the time it's working well for you and another portion of the time maybe you'd like to make some adjustments to make it a little smoother. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So kind of thinking along those lines how important is it to you to make some changes or make some adjustments to your drinking to sort of fit with your values and your goals for yourself? ; Patient: I'd like to make sure that I, you know, in terms of respecting myself and my body I'd like to, you know, try to drink less. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Like I, you know, it is nice to let loose and have fun but I'd also like it to be so, you know, I'm not damaging my body and I'm like my liver doesn't work by the time I'm like 22. ; Patient: And, you know, have my friends on board with a similar mentality so we can kind of work at it together as a group, as a community. ; Therapist: Uh huh. ; Therapist: So kind of combining those goals. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So you have a goal it sounds like of actually cutting back on your drinking. ; Therapist: How important is it to you to work on that goal on a scale of one to ten where one is not at all important and ten is it's the most important thing right now? ; Patient: I'd say about like a six or a seven. ; Therapist: Oh okay. ; Patient: I'd like to work on it but, you know, if I get around to it I get around to it. ; Patient: If I don't I don't. ; Therapist: Uh huh. ; Therapist: Well why'd you say six or seven rather than like a four? ; Patient: Because I still think it's important. ; Therapist: Uh huh. ; Patient: I still, you know, like I said I don't want my body to, especially going to med school, like I know how things affect your body and also affect your social and your school work and things like that. ; Patient: I know that once I get to college it's not, it's not gonna work out, you know, drinking every weekend and then like trying to wake up early and go to school, take an exam. ; Patient: I know that's not feasible. ; Patient: It's not a good idea. ; Therapist: Yeah, looking ahead you can't keep drinking this way and reach the goals that you have for yourself. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Well how confident are you that you could cut down if you wanted to? ; Patient: I think. ; Therapist: On that same scale from one to ten. ; Patient: I think if I made the decision I was going to for sure then I think definitely like a ten. ; Patient: I know I'd be really sure. ; Therapist: Oh wow. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Why'd you say ten? ; Patient: It's just because I know that once I make the decision I know I can do it. ; Therapist: Uh huh. ; Patient: It's making the decision in the first place. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Whether. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And so you mentioned, you know, quite a few reasons why you would like to cut down. ; Therapist: Have you thought at all about how you might go about doing that? ; Patient: Um, I'm thinking of maybe like trying to convince my friends without sounding, you know, dorky or something. ; Patient: Be like, hey, you know, let's just stay in today. ; Patient: Like let's not go out or something. ; Patient: Or just be like, hey, I'm not, like, I'm not going to drink today. ; Patient: And even if my friends do, like being okay with them drinking around me and not doing it and then them being okay with me drinking, me not drinking and them doing whatever they want. ; Therapist: So sort of trying to plan more activities that don't involve alcohol and then also trying to participate in activities without drinking yourself or maybe even drinking less than you're drinking. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Does that sound like a goal you want to work on now or? ; Patient: I think so. ; Patient: I think it's very feasible. ; Patient: I think it's possible. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Um, so I guess we'll talk about, um, less alcohol activities. ; Therapist: I'm just making some notes to myself and then maybe, um, reducing the amount of drinking that you're doing if alcohol is involved. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Um, so that's, that goal sounds feasible. ; Therapist: You said, would it be okay if we met in a couple weeks to sort of see how it's going? ; Patient: I think so. ; Patient: I think that's good. ; Therapist: Does that sound like something you'd like to do? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Well, I really appreciate you spending the time talking to me. ; Therapist: You know, it sounds like you have a lot of really good goals for yourself, really ambitious goals of going to medical school and, you know, becoming a psychiatrist or, um, some, some other form of physician. ; Therapist: Um, you're really looking forward to doing well in school so you can get there. ; Therapist: And it sounds like you have a pretty active social life and a lot of friends who you feel probably would be supportive even if you cut down on alcohol. ; Therapist: And that, you know, there's a lot of benefits you see both to your body and your health, um, your school performance and even some of the social stuff in terms of feeling a sense of belonging without having to deal with some of the gross consequences of, of, um, drinking too much. ; Therapist: Um, so yeah, you know, it really sounds to me like you have a good plan in place and as long as you're willing and interested in meeting again, I'd be very excited to be able to talk with you about how it's going. ; Patient: Yeah, I'd like to. ; Therapist: All right, great. ; Therapist: So I'll, I'll plan to see you then in a few more weeks. ; Patient: Perfect. ; Therapist: Thanks. ; Therapist: Great. ; Therapist: This time, the counselor began by setting the agenda and emphasizing the student's autonomy right away. ; Therapist: She used open questions and reflections to build rapport, then turned to a focus on Andrea's values in order to deepen the connection. ; Therapist: This led easily into a discussion of Andrea's social life and an open question about the role that alcohol plays in it. ; Therapist: Skillful use of reflections guided the conversation while encouraging the student to open up to the counselor. ; Therapist: By using a decisional balance, the counselor was able to assess barriers to change as well as to elicit reasons for change and opportunities to affirm Andrea's good decisions. ; Therapist: She was then able to ask Andrea to expand on her reasons for setting limits with her drinking, which highlighted some of the consequences of alcohol use without using lectures or scolding the student. ; Therapist: The counselor also tied the drinking behavior to Andrea's values, helping to develop a discrepancy between her personal goals and actions. ; Therapist: This set the stage for clarification of goals and beginning discussion of a change plan. ; Therapist: However, the counselor encouraged the student to choose her own behavior or change goal in order to ensure it was something Andrea felt confident she could achieve. ; Therapist: She ended the session with a summary of their discussion, expressed appreciation for Andrea's participation, and communicated optimism about the plan and her desire to continue working with her in the future. ; Therapist: .
summary: Patient Particulars : Name andrea; sex- female ; Clinical Identifiers: Setting school counseling room ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Therapist at school ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Nil ; History: Present history client attends parties every weekend where half the times they are about activities without alcohol like board games and remaining half times it involves alcohol. She enjoys both of them stating board game non-alcoholic parties are enjoyable and relaxing whereas parties involving alcohol are fun but tiring; family history client lives with her father, mother, elder brother and a dog. Her brother is 8. 5 years elder to her. One of her aunts consumes alcohol frequently; personal history- use of leisure time client has an inclination towards music since the age of 10 years and is a part of a band; fantasy life she wishes to enter a medical school for her career. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: General behavior rapport formation was initiated and was established and client was cooperative; mood calm; affect broad ; Psychotherapy Type: Type school counseling; mode individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Psychoeducation, paraphrasing ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Clients general interests, hobbies and leisure time activities were discussed. Her psychoactive substance consumption especially alcohol was also explored. It was established she drinks occasionally in parties and her consumption is in safe boundaries. ; Reflections by the therapist: Client was aware of the harmful consequences of drinking. Her alcohol consumption has safe boundaries and she is ambitious. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Nil ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Hi, Lisa. ; Therapist: How you doing today? ; Patient: I'm doing okay. ; Therapist: You're doing okay? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: I understand you're here to receive counseling services. ; Patient: My boss sent me here. ; Therapist: Your boss sent you here? ; Therapist: What's going on with you and your boss? ; Patient: It's not even between me and my boss. ; Patient: I'm a good worker at my job. ; Patient: I get everything done on time, but they're calling me inflexible and a perfectionist. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So who's calling you inflexible and a perfectionist? ; Patient: Well, my boss has called me that. ; Patient: I've had several coworkers. ; Patient: There was a recent incident where somebody wanted to change days with me, but I told them the schedule's out. ; Patient: I'm supposed to be here on Wednesday. ; Patient: You can't change it. ; Patient: It's right there. ; Patient: Black and white. ; Patient: I work Wednesday. ; Patient: You can't change that. ; Therapist: And they felt that it would have been more reasonable to change? ; Patient: Well, they wanted to change, and I really don't agree with that. ; Patient: If they needed a certain day off, they need to go through the order of command and ask for a day off. ; Therapist: And they didn't do that and said they asked you to switch days. ; Patient: And then they called me inflexible because I got upset about it. ; Therapist: In what way did you get upset? ; Patient: Well, I told them. ; Patient: I said that's irresponsible, that they didn't think ahead, that they wanted to change with me. ; Patient: I am there at a certain time. ; Patient: I am there from 8 in the morning till 5 in the afternoon. ; Patient: I take my lunch at 12 o'clock. ; Patient: That is my Wednesday. ; Patient: That's always been my Wednesday. ; Patient: I don't know why they want to upset that. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So that upset you and that upset them, that whole incident? ; Therapist: Yes. ; Therapist: Anything else that your boss may have as a reason for...? ; Patient: They call me a perfectionist because I like the things done by the book, which I think makes me a great worker. ; Patient: Because I get everything done on deadlines. ; Patient: Not before, not after. ; Patient: Right on the deadline. ; Patient: And everything is just exactly, you know, everything's filed, everything's organized. ; Patient: And some people like to, you know, take a file, oh, well, I need this to fill out a report. ; Patient: No, no, no. ; Patient: It's there. ; Patient: It's in the file. ; Patient: You can't touch it, you can't move it. ; Patient: That's where it needs to be. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So you consider yourself fairly well organized as an employee? ; Patient: Oh, absolutely. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Absolutely. ; Therapist: And you mentioned you're there from 8 to 5. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: You take your lunch from 12 to 1230? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: How many days in the last, say, three months have you been late, left early? ; Patient: Oh, zero. ; Therapist: Zero? ; Patient: Zero. ; Patient: No, I'm there 8 to 5. ; Patient: 8 o'clock in the morning to 5. ; Patient: I wake up at 6. ; Patient: I get ready. ; Patient: I leave for work at 7. ; Patient: I get there at 8. ; Patient: The whole day has a schedule. ; Patient: And I meet that schedule. ; Patient: And it's the best thing for me. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So this is frustrating for you that your coworkers can't understand where you're coming from? ; Patient: I just don't get it. ; Patient: You know, I'm doing everything by the book, by the rules. ; Patient: And I'm in trouble somehow? ; Patient: Something's wrong with me because I do it right. ; Patient: I do it the right way and that's wrong somehow. ; Patient: And I don't get it. ; Therapist: Have you ever had to work in a group, like a team with any of your coworkers? ; Patient: They've made me. ; Patient: But I don't like it. ; Therapist: Tell me. ; Patient: Because I know the way we need to do things. ; Patient: If we're given a project, okay. ; Patient: It starts with A, B, C, D, and then no. ; Patient: Everybody wants, oh, let's do C, O, D, and then F. ; Patient: No. ; Patient: No, no, no. ; Patient: A, B, C, D. There is no deviation from that. ; Patient: And then they get mad at me. ; Therapist: So working in groups hasn't worked out too well for you? ; Patient: Not really. ; Patient: Not unless people listen to me. ; Therapist: So in instances where people listen to you, how have things worked out? ; Patient: If I oversee everything, I still get uncomfortable because they're out of my sight. ; Patient: I don't know what they're doing sometimes. ; Patient: I have to watch one person, other person's over there. ; Patient: I don't know what they're doing. ; Patient: And if it's not done right, it's not done right. ; Patient: And that's bad. ; Therapist: Can you tell me anything about your mood in general in terms of have you felt sad or anxious? ; Therapist: Anything like that recently? ; Patient: Not particularly. ; Patient: I guess I feel anxious sometimes when things aren't going the way they need to go. ; Patient: Because then it puts off the whole day. ; Patient: And I guess I would consider that anxiety. ; Patient: Because if it's not going the right way, one thing goes wrong, the whole day is thrown off. ; Patient: And then now I have to deal with that. ; Patient: Now I have to adjust my whole schedule, even by a minute. ; Patient: And that does cause me anxiety. ; Therapist: Even by a minute? ; Patient: Even by a minute. ; Therapist: So if your day is not going the way you planned it for it to go, you're feeling some anxiety from that? ; Patient: Absolutely. ; Therapist: Does your employer ever have unscheduled meetings or anything like that that happens? ; Patient: He does. ; Patient: He will schedule some unscheduled meetings. ; Patient: And I've calmly, I've tried to calmly approach him and say, you know, there's a meeting, we need to know about it. ; Patient: I need to schedule my day around the meeting. ; Patient: He once scheduled a meeting at 12.20 and I told him, I'm at lunch 12 to 12.30. ; Patient: Why do you think that's appropriate? ; Patient: I mean, sometimes I feel like I'm the only smart person there. ; Patient: I'm the only person who knows how this needs to run. ; Therapist: Alright, so you have some different stressors at work. ; Therapist: And some disagreements with your co-workers. ; Therapist: Can you tell me anything about your home life? ; Patient: I personally consider my home life very neat. ; Patient: You know, if you go into my home, everything's nice. ; Patient: Everything's where it needs to be. ; Patient: I have my meals scheduled out. ; Patient: I have a nice little calendar. ; Patient: Everything's planned. ; Patient: Thursday's chicken, Fridays, tamales, and so on and so forth. ; Therapist: So your home life's a bit like your work life in terms of being organized. ; Patient: That's the right way to do it. ; Therapist: Do you ever, in terms of your home life, do you ever collect anything? ; Patient: Yeah, I do. ; Therapist: Tell me about that. ; Patient: I guess that does also cause me some anxiety because I do like to collect things. ; Patient: If I have a good day, I like to keep the newspaper on the day that I had a good day. ; Patient: And I have newspapers from years ago. ; Patient: With no important news on them. ; Patient: But I just can't seem to let it go. ; Therapist: So you keep them in your home? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So newspapers, anything else that you collect? ; Patient: Receipts. ; Therapist: Receipts? ; Patient: Well, it says to keep, I mean, I've always known you have to keep receipts. ; Patient: You don't know when you're ever going to have to prove that you purchased something or when you have to return something. ; Therapist: So what percentage of the receipts that you're given do you think that you keep? ; Patient: All of them. ; Therapist: All of them? ; Patient: Every single one. ; Patient: I get very upset if I go to McDonald's or Food Fast Food Place, I want my receipt. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: I'm going to ask you some questions. ; Therapist: We'll go back to work, kind of regarding your work schedule. ; Therapist: Do you wash your hands regularly at work? ; Patient: I wash my hands before I eat. ; Patient: After I eat. ; Patient: After I use the restroom for 30 seconds. ; Patient: Every time. ; Therapist: Do you ever find yourself like having washed your hands and then going back and washing them several other times? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: There's no need to do that. ; Therapist: No need to do that? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: You wash your hands 30 seconds. ; Patient: That's it. ; Patient: That's all you need to do. ; Therapist: Do you have any particular concerns about germs or anything like that? ; Patient: I try to keep neat, but not particularly, no. ; Therapist: Have you ever found yourself in a situation where touching something repeatedly like a doorknob or operating a light switch seems to lower your anxiety, like repeatedly doing that? ; Patient: Not at all. ; Patient: That seems like a waste of time. ; Therapist: That would be inefficient? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: There's no need to do that. ; Therapist: How about double checking, for example, light switches to make sure the doors are locked? ; Patient: I make sure my doors are locked the first time. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So you check, but just the one time? ; Patient: Well, I do it when I come in the door. ; Patient: Lock the door. ; Patient: That's it. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So what do you think the solution here is? ; Therapist: Your employer sends you in for counseling. ; Therapist: What would you like to change? ; Patient: He wants me to be more flexible. ; Patient: To not get as upset if there is an unscheduled meeting. ; Patient: If somebody wants to switch shifts with me. ; Patient: I don't really understand it, but I'm in trouble at work, so I have to look into it. ; Therapist: You like your job? ; Patient: I do like my job. ; Patient: I like being able to have everything I need. ; Patient: If somebody calls for something, you know, oh, it's right here. ; Patient: If somebody calls for something, oh, it's right here. ; Patient: I love it. ; Patient: It's like a machine. ; Therapist: So you like your job. ; Therapist: You like how you're able to be organized there. ; Therapist: But there's some conflict with coworkers and your boss. ; Therapist: You want to try to work that out. ; Patient: I guess. ; Patient: I mean, I don't want to lose my job. ; Patient: And if this is a problem, the right thing to do would be to come speak to you. ; Therapist: Alright, so you're open to attending counseling sessions and taking a look at what's going on here? ; Patient: Absolutely. ; Patient: If my boss requires it, if my boss requires it, then that's the right thing to do. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: I want to appreciate you answering my questions. ; Therapist: It's been very helpful. ; Therapist: We'll get you on the schedule to see a counselor here. ; Therapist: It might take about a week. ; Therapist: And we'll go from there. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: See you in a week. ; Patient: Alright, thank you. ; Patient: Thanks.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name lisa ; Referral Information : Boss ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms anxiety at work chief complaints 1 stress at work 2 fear of losing control ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behavior cooperative; speech, mood  affect anxious, thought negative, judgement poor ; Issues discussed in Current Session: 1 workplace conflict patient experiences tension with coworkers, particularly around scheduling and adherence to procedures, it causes her significant anxiety. 2 openness to counseling she is willing to engage in counseling as required by her boss. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Anxiety ; Action Plan : Referred to a counselor

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Sherry, how you're doing today? ; Patient: I'm doing okay. ; Therapist: You're doing okay? ; Therapist: I understand your father brought you in today. ; Therapist: He was a little worried about how you might be feeling. ; Patient: Yeah, I mean he's worried that I'm depressed, but I'm not. ; Therapist: Yeah, he had mentioned that you had some concerns about some things going on in your neighborhood and that you called the police a few times. ; Patient: He told you that? ; Therapist: He told me about that. ; Patient: Well, yeah, I mean I had called, I've called the police a few times because there's something going on in my neighborhood. ; Patient: And it makes me seem like I'm depressed, but I'm not. ; Patient: I just, I'm concerned about what's going on. ; Therapist: So you're not depressed, you're more concerned. ; Therapist: So what's going on where you live that's leading to these feelings? ; Patient: Well, it's actually very scary. ; Patient: There, I know about the government has been kidnapping girls in this area and taking them away for sex trafficking and prostitution. ; Therapist: So you believe the government is apprehending people in the area where you live? ; Patient: I know they are. ; Therapist: You know they are? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: And did you see things that specifically led you to believe this? ; Patient: Yeah, yes. ; Patient: So there specifically were two girls that lived down the street and I saw a van come down the street and the girls were taken and that's when I initially called the police, but I found that they're in on it too. ; Patient: They... ; Therapist: The police are in on it too? ; Patient: Yes. ; Patient: They tried to tell me that the girls are just, were, they're safe and with their aunt, but ; Patient: I know they're not. ; Therapist: So they investigated what you saw and they came back and told you that... ; Patient: They pretended to. ; Therapist: They pretended to investigate? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And they came back and told you everything was okay, but you're not... ; Patient: I mean I know it's a lie because I saw the girls, I haven't seen the girls since. ; Patient: I saw the girls on the street, the van came, the girls were not there and they told me everything's fine, but I know that's a lie and I won't go back to the police again because I know that they're now in on it. ; Therapist: They're in on the... ; Patient: What the government's been doing. ; Therapist: What the government's been doing. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: What do you think of your father's concerns with, you know, he's concerned that you're, that you're down, you're depressed and that your thinking hasn't been, been clear? ; Therapist: What do you think about his concerns? ; Patient: I mean, I know he's worried about me, but you know, it's... ; Patient: He just doesn't understand the severity of the situation and you know, it's hard, it's hard to sleep when I'm thinking about these poor girls and you know, it's the government. ; Patient: Like the government has cameras everywhere and they can watch what I'm doing at all times and it's, you know, it's exhausting. ; Patient: So I can see how he would think I'm depressed because you know, I'm worried, I'm not sleeping well and I'm not eating because what if they poisoned my food? ; Patient: You know, they're poisoning water all the time. ; Patient: So you know, it is, it's scary and it is affecting you, but it's not depression. ; Therapist: You're not, you're not depressed? ; Patient: No, I'm sad for those girls and I'm scared for, for me and like what's going on. ; Patient: But you know, I want to make sure that this doesn't happen again because you know, I can't let it happen. ; Patient: I can't let this continue. ; Patient: So that's, that's what's taking up my time right now. ; Therapist: And how long has this been going on? ; Patient: Um, for a few months. ; Therapist: A few months. ; Therapist: Is that when you first saw what you, what you believe to be the kidnapping? ; Patient: When I saw the kidnapping, yes. ; Therapist: That was a few months ago. ; Therapist: Were there any beliefs like this before two months? ; Patient: Um, I mean, yes. ; Patient: I've always been aware that the government, you know, is probably up to things that they probably shouldn't be and that they have access and abilities beyond, you know, the normal person. ; Patient: But after I saw the kidnapping, um, I had proof and so it's, it's gotten worse because I feel like they know that I know. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So you, you felt this way for a while, but seeing what you saw two months ago, that, that made you more sure? ; Patient: Yes. ; Patient: Because now I have proof. ; Therapist: Because now you have proof. ; Therapist: Have you ever been treated for depression in the past? ; Patient: Um, yes. ; Patient: Um, my dad has taken me before when he was worried about me. ; Patient: Um, but I, you know, it's never really been depression. ; Patient: It's always been something else. ; Patient: Like, I'm fine. ; Patient: I just, I'm aware of what's going on around me. ; Patient: And I don't think my dad understands that. ; Patient: I don't think, um, the places he takes me understands that. ; Patient: So. ; Therapist: What have, uh, the people at the places where he has taken you, what have, what have they said about your condition? ; Patient: Um, you know, they, they try to say the same thing that, you know, I'm depressed or, um, whatever. ; Patient: But, you know, I know, I know the truth. ; Patient: And sometimes I just have to play along. ; Therapist: You just play along with it? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Because, you know, this is what the government wants. ; Patient: They want me to look crazy. ; Patient: So, there's something I can do about it. ; Therapist: So you think they want to, like, discredit, discredit you? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Because if I, if, you know, it's kind of like smearing my good name. ; Patient: They see me, um, in and out of different agencies and appearing crazy, you know, or, obviously, a lot of people don't believe the story. ; Patient: They choose not to believe or they get paid off. ; Patient: And they write what they write on my file, but it's not true. ; Patient: I'm, I just know what's going on. ; Therapist: And because you know what's going on, that's what's led to all, um, these occurrences. ; Therapist: This has led to the symptoms. ; Patient: Yeah, like lately, yeah. ; Patient: Like, you know, I haven't been able to sleep, you know, and, you know, I feel guilty about what's going on around me and that I know and that, you know, I feel it's hard for me to help them, like, with, you know, cameras everywhere. ; Patient: I can't even go to the grocery store without being watched. ; Patient: And I know they're watching me. ; Patient: So, you know, I do everything I'm supposed to, you know, like I go to work, I do the chores because I have to make sure they see me going to work and doing the chores. ; Therapist: So you, so you kind of play along? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So do you ever have any thoughts related to death or dying or anything like that? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: No, like I'm worried. ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: You're worried about what? ; Patient: I mean, I'm worried about the government, you know, destroying my life, you know, but I don't want to die and I don't think they're going to kill me. ; Patient: I think that would be too easy and it would just be more proof, so. ; Therapist: That would be more proof that what you've seen is real? ; Patient: Correct. ; Patient: Because obviously I'm trying to tell people about it. ; Patient: And if I suddenly show up missing, like, people are going to know. ; Patient: So I know that they're not going to hurt me, but they could make me look crazy and I'm worried about my life, like, they're worrying about my life. ; Therapist: About it in that way. ; Therapist: How about any drug or alcohol abuse or anything like that? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: Nothing? ; Patient: I don't like to use those things. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Any medical conditions? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Has there ever been a time when you felt, like, really very happy? ; Therapist: Like, a lot of energy and it was, you were very happy for several days? ; Patient: Not really. ; Therapist: That's never happened? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Have you ever heard or seen things other people can't hear or see? ; Patient: I think that I'm aware of things that people don't know, like. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Have you been hospitalized before? ; Patient: Yes. ; Patient: But again, it was, I tried to initially tell my dad about some things that I knew about, and he had taken me to the hospital, but that was before. ; Therapist: So I would like to get you in a talk to a counselor today. ; Therapist: How do you feel about that? ; Patient: Is it really necessary today? ; Patient: Like, can I come back another day? ; Therapist: I think it would be helpful if we had a counselor talk to you today. ; Patient: Well, I understand that's what you need to do, so I guess, you know, if that's what we need to do to get this over with, that's fine. ; Therapist: You can be okay with that? ; Patient: I can play along. ; Therapist: You can play along? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Sherry, I want to thank you for answering these questions. ; Therapist: I know this is a tough experience for you, and having a tough time with everything that's going on that you've described. ; Therapist: So it's been helpful for you to answer these questions for me. ; Therapist: And I'll just need a couple minutes, and I'll get you over to see a counselor, and we'll kind of go from there. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Thank you, Sherry. ; Patient: You're welcome.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name- sherry; accompanied by- father ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Persecutory delusions 2. Decreased sleep ; History: Course- episodic; present history patients current complaints have been present from past few months with beliefs that the government has been kidnapping girls for sex trafficking and prostitution. Patient tried calling the police but later established that the police is also involved in this. Patients sleep has been disturbed as he gets worried due to this situation; past history hospitalisation due to a similar episode in the past. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: General behaviour cooperative, rapport established; speech productivity increased; thought- content false, unshakeable beliefs; insight grade 1 ; Psychotherapy Type: Humanistic therapy ; Psychotherapy Technique : Reflective listening ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patient discussed about hisher belief that government has been involved in kidnapping and sex trafficking and that heshe is being misunderstood for being depressed by hisher father. Patient did not have insight of hisher current state. ; Reflections by the therapist: Patient was cooperative and rapport could be established. It was strengthened when the patient disclosed about hisher acting along with other people when it came to trusting them. Patient had a strong conviction about hisher beliefs beliefs and it was observed that heshe did not have any insight of it. Heshe was not receptive of therapy and believed that it would be better if hisher father would take it. ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: I want to thank you for continuing to participate in this intake. ; Therapist: As I mentioned, I want to move to a new section now. ; Therapist: This one's about your social relationships. ; Therapist: Are you okay with answering some questions about your social relationships? ; Patient: Yeah, sure. ; Patient: Why not? ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Tell me about your friends. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: From when I was in high school or now? ; Therapist: You can start with high school. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: Well, I had a lot of friends in high school. ; Patient: I mean, you know, I guess you could say I was popular in high school. ; Patient: I was constantly at parties and hanging out with people. ; Patient: And then as the years went by, they slowly started to peel off for whatever reason. ; Patient: I guess my behavior could have turned them off. ; Patient: Who knows? ; Therapist: What behavior do you think did that? ; Patient: I guess my gambling and my promiscuity, you know, like for instance, well, I mean, this one friend from high school, we were really close and I ended up getting with her boyfriend when they were together. ; Patient: But I mean, you know, people forgive each other, like what's the big deal? ; Patient: She couldn't get over it. ; Patient: And then the other, my other friend got mad at me for that because I slept with her boyfriend, but I was drunk. ; Patient: And I mean, I was gambling that night, so really who cares? ; Patient: But I don't know. ; Patient: And then I would post on Facebook and just constantly post just about different guys or that I was gambling and that I was winning. ; Patient: You know, I didn't think it turned some people off, I guess, but I don't know why it would because it was just having a good time. ; Therapist: And this was all back in high school? ; Patient: No, no, no. ; Patient: This was like just this couple, past couple, you know. ; Therapist: Oh, recently. ; Patient: Oh yeah. ; Patient: I mean, cause they were my friends in high school of through the years. ; Patient: They kind of just peeled off. ; Therapist: So, so you had a good number of friends in high school because of certain occurrences. ; Therapist: You don't have as many now. ; Therapist: About how many close friends would you say you had back in high school? ; Patient: There was like eight of us in a group of girlfriends that we were really close. ; Therapist: And how about now? ; Patient: I don't have any of those friends. ; Therapist: How many close friends do you have? ; Patient: I don't, I don't, I don't really have any close friends. ; Patient: I mean just acquaintances really. ; Patient: I kind of just like doing it that way better. ; Therapist: Sure. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: How many acquaintances? ; Patient: Um, men or women, like just as friends or. ; Therapist: Well, how many women? ; Patient: For friends, um, maybe like two at work if they're like my acquaintance. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And how about men? ; Patient: For men there's, there's, there's a lot, like 10 that I see. ; Therapist: Fairly regularly? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Can you describe to me your relationship with these, these 12 acquaintances? ; Patient: Um, well, women at work, like I usually just tell them about like my fun, you know, times that I'm like gambling and meeting men and you know, them buying me things and me buying them things and winning all this money. ; Patient: And then I usually go back to work and tell them that, you know, I don't have any money left cause I used it all, you know, first because I'm gambling, second because I want to show off for the guys and just the thrill of it. ; Patient: So that's just usually what I talk to them about. ; Patient: Um, and the men usually are just that I encounter a while gambling or shopping or, um, when I'm drinking and I could just meet them just at, you know, the, the blackjack table or whatever, I can just meet them there. ; Patient: Um, or just online. ; Therapist: So you mentioned social media before. ; Therapist: Can you tell me about your interaction with social media? ; Therapist: Your use of it? ; Patient: Um, I actually enjoy social media a lot. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I think it's, it's great. ; Patient: It's a great outlet, especially when you have a lot of ideas and you just want to get it out there. ; Patient: Um, and I think that it's really great for me to express my ideas and stuff like that. ; Patient: I'm just, what I'm going through. ; Patient: And so I use it a lot. ; Therapist: A lot. ; Patient: I do. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I mean, especially when I'm out, like, I mean, I don't know if you're familiar with like, like Facebook and tweeting or Twitter. ; Patient: Um, like on Facebook, I mean, I'll post like every, I would say every 10 minutes when I'm out, I just will post about like my night or just a cool idea I had about, um, just starting a business or anything like that. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: And I'll post a lot and like Twitter, it's pretty much like every two minutes cause it's super fast. ; Patient: So I'll do that like every two minutes when I'm out. ; Patient: So, ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Do a lot of people follow or read the posts? ; Patient: Oh, they do. ; Patient: A lot of people do. ; Patient: And some people are like, Oh, that's a great idea. ; Patient: And then like, you know, an hour later they're just like, are you like, is everything okay? ; Patient: Like, are you fine? ; Patient: You know, I quickly unfriend them because they're not like following what I'm saying. ; Patient: And then I have people that unfriend me because they don't like that I'm posting all the time. ; Patient: But really that's what it's there for. ; Patient: And it's there for me to express myself and if they can handle it, then well, ; Therapist: How about, uh, I want to ask you about interests like sports, music, the arts, television. ; Therapist: You have any, you mentioned social media. ; Therapist: It seems like an interest. ; Therapist: Any other interests? ; Patient: Um, like hobbies, like, Oh, interests. ; Patient: I like shopping. ; Patient: I love shopping. ; Patient: Um, going away. ; Patient: I like vacationing in nice places. ; Patient: Um, just enjoying myself. ; Patient: Um, and obviously gambling is one of my favorite things. ; Patient: I like to do that. ; Patient: It's a great social outlet for me. ; Patient: Um, I mean a lot of people and it's, it fulfills me at certain times in my life, you know, ; Therapist: How about, uh, talents? ; Therapist: Do you have particular talents? ; Patient: Talents? ; Patient: I think just meeting people. ; Patient: I have like really good talents with meeting people. ; Patient: Um, you know, especially when I feel really good. ; Patient: I have this ability to just talk to everybody and they seem to like me. ; Patient: So it's, you know, it works. ; Patient: And I think that's one of my talents, one of my strong points, which is why I probably do really good in sales because I'm in sales. ; Patient: So I think that that, yeah, that's one of my strong points. ; Therapist: So you have a talent for meeting people and having like charismatic. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Any other talents you'd like to tell me about? ; Patient: Um, not really. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So anything regarding social relationships like your friends, interests, talents, social media, anything you want to tell me on this before we move to the other section? ; Patient: Um, no, that, that I just like to have a good time and I just want people to understand that. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: So that's it really. ; Therapist: Do you feel like people like the people you mentioned that would see you on social media or your acquaintances, do you feel like they understand you? ; Patient: Um, no, because they've all unfriended me. ; Patient: So I guess they don't understand me. ; Patient: They just don't get it, you know, which sucks. ; Patient: But all of them are, there's some that's, there's some like that I'm still friends with, but you know, I mean, they'll just people that I went to high school with or college day of all in front of me. ; Therapist: do you have any friends that are willing to engage with you at certain times but not others? ; Patient: I do. ; Patient: I do. ; Patient: I think when I start to like post a lot when I'm out and drinking and like, um, you know, gambling, um, I think that they get like frustrated with me, but there could be times where I'm not doing that. ; Patient: And, um, actually times when I'm depressed or just even keel, which I could be both, trust me, I can be both. ; Patient: But when I'm even and I just have a little bit of energy and a little bit of like sadness and I'm just this even person, um, I think that I'm able to have better conversations with people. ; Patient: I think I'm more tolerable, I guess you could say. ; Patient: So where I won't go on Facebook as much and I'll just post about like, um, did anybody watch this show or something? ; Patient: You know, I think that people respond better, more even keel. ; Therapist: I want to thank you for helping me complete this section of the intake and if you're okay, we'll move on to the next section.
summary: Patient Particulars : Sex female ; Past Session Information: Follow -up ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms emotional instability and gambling chief complaints, 1 interpersonal conflict 2 social disconnection ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior excited; speech fast, mood  affect hyper, thought fast, perception poor, cognitive functions impaired, judgement poor ; Psychotherapy Type: Cbt; mode individual ; Issues discussed in Current Session: 1 problems patient feels decrease social connections as in past has caused conflicts within her social circle which led to the erosion of friendships and a decrease in social support. She prefers to maintain superficial relationships with acquaintances rather than deep, meaningful friendships. 2 social media use extensive usage of social media regarding her nightlife activities, gambling, and interactions with men. 3 interests prefers immediate pleasure and gratification, such as shopping, vacationing, and gambling. She perceives herself as successful in sales. 4 mood feels fluctuations in her mood, alternating between periods of high energy and sociability and episodes of sadness or depression. 5 willings for therapy expresses a desire for others to understand her and accept her for who she is. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Ocd and bipolar like symptoms ; Action Plan : Planned to move on to the next section in the upcoming session. ; Next session details: Na

dialogue: Therapist: Good morning Curtis, it's good seeing you again. ; Therapist: Go ahead and have a seat. ; Therapist: How are you doing today? ; Patient: I'm doing very well. ; Therapist: I'm doing good. ; Therapist: So today's your first visit with me today. ; Therapist: Were you okay with traffic? ; Therapist: Were you able to find the slaves? ; Patient: Yes, I was. ; Patient: I was a little shaky. ; Therapist: Did you find parking okay? ; Patient: I did. ; Therapist: I just wanted to interview you. ; Therapist: I know you had some concerns. ; Therapist: You called me so we're going to go over that today. ; Therapist: What I wanted to do first of all was ask you what brings you here today to my office? ; Patient: I think I need like therapeutic help. ; Therapist: Looking into some therapy classes. ; Therapist: What kind of classes are you looking for? ; Patient: Drug and alcohol perhaps. ; Therapist: Right now today are you using any drugs today? ; Patient: Not as much as I used to honestly. ; Patient: At least I go out and party with my friends and use a lot. ; Patient: Like almost on a daily basis but I do it as much. ; Therapist: What is your number one drug of choice right now? ; Patient: Weed. ; Therapist: You smoke a lot of weed. ; Therapist: Now do you smoke it with friends by yourself? ; Patient: Yes, usually with friends actually. ; Therapist: Do you find yourself doing it at home or do you go out? ; Patient: No, I go out because my mom doesn't allow it. ; Therapist: I usually go out to the park or after school or something like that. ; Therapist: Do you feel that that's something that you need to help you function or is it something that I have? ; Patient: It's a habit and it helps me relax honestly. ; Patient: It keeps me down. ; Therapist: Now do you go smoke weed with other friends or by yourself? ; Patient: I usually go with my other friends because they are my influences to be with. ; Therapist: Right, okay. ; Therapist: So do you feel that it helps you function better or is it just something that you're just experimenting with or what exactly do you? ; Patient: It actually helps me function better, a lot better actually. ; Patient: I know it's not the right choice or anything but it's what I'm kind of getting into therapy. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: I can find out what it's like. ; Therapist: Do you find yourself spending a lot of money on marijuana? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: How much do you spend a week or what's your habit like right now? ; Patient: About $100 a week. ; Therapist: $100 a week. ; Therapist: Okay, so that's pretty much equivalent to about maybe $10 to $15 a day. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Alright, okay. ; Therapist: Alright, well you know what we want to do is just be able to help you maybe create some steps to help you begin to phase out in time. ; Patient: I want to pretty much identify the problem and that's the marijuana. ; Therapist: Would you say that maybe there's events in your life that trigger your use? ; Therapist: Is there something that which I wanted to ask you, what's your family structure like right now? ; Patient: You know what, I get along with my family. ; Patient: I have a foster family because I was born and when I was born it was kind of separated from my biological family so it kind of put me in foster care. ; Patient: I was like that since I was two years old and from two to thirteen I lived with my two other siblings. ; Patient: Yeah, that's funny. ; Therapist: So pretty much you've been raised by your foster parents and your biological parents are not in the picture? ; Patient: No, they're not actually. ; Therapist: Okay, now in your family how many siblings do you have? ; Patient: Six. ; Patient: Oh, I'm raised with two. ; Therapist: And what number are you? ; Patient: I'm actually the oldest. ; Patient: You're the oldest of the six siblings. ; Therapist: So do you feel maybe there was added responsibility put on you? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Did you guys live together or were you all pretty much separated? ; Patient: There was only two of us. ; Patient: One of my sisters and one of the, yeah two of my sisters. ; Patient: We just lived together and I didn't have full responsibility. ; Patient: I was just kind of. ; Therapist: Right, and so your other four siblings where did they go? ; Patient: You know what, I have no problem. ; Therapist: So you've been separated since birth pretty much and you were raised by your foster parents. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And how do you feel about that? ; Therapist: I mean how does that make you feel as far as you were raised by your foster parents? ; Patient: I used to get made fun of when I was in school and it was a little bit harder on me but I'm kind of getting over it now. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: I tried to contact them but it's not working out. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: So they're pretty much your biological parents are not in your life? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And your foster parents are pretty much the ones that raised you. ; Therapist: Those are your parents? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I would say my mom. ; Therapist: Your mom and dad. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And then also as you were living together at home, how were you disciplined? ; Therapist: Or who were you disciplined by? ; Therapist: Who disciplined? ; Patient: My mom, not so much of my dad. ; Patient: He was kind of laid back, cool, relaxed. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: You know, my mom sure disciplined. ; Patient: It can go from being grounded, from a weapon, you know, from show and take our equipment like PlayStations or phones or. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: So that was pretty much a consequence for your behavior. ; Patient: Exactly. ; Patient: For that behavior equal to consequence. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Would you say that mom was consistent? ; Therapist: She pretty much disciplined everybody? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: She disciplined everybody the same. ; Therapist: That's good. ; Therapist: So growing up, do you feel the discipline helped you? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I do. ; Patient: I live in this whole drug use. ; Patient: Other than that, I think it helped me a lot. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: It kind of set some boundaries for you. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Exactly. ; Therapist: Does your mother know that you smoke marijuana? ; Patient: She doesn't know that I do it at this exact moment because a while ago I kind of stopped. ; Patient: Didn't I do it as much? ; Patient: I told her that. ; Patient: So she doesn't really know that I'm doing it as much right now. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: The reason why I'm asking is because in order for us to help you, we want to be able to develop a good support system. ; Therapist: So we want to, you know, maybe in time we'll include, you know, your mom and let her know, you know, you're getting some help and getting some treatment. ; Therapist: But that was, you know, some of the questions I had for, as far as, you know, your family, how you were raised. ; Therapist: And now tell me a little bit about yourself when you were growing up. ; Therapist: Were you more of an introvert or an extrovert? ; Patient: Meaning, you know, were you outgoing? ; Patient: Yeah, I was more outgoing. ; Patient: I wanted to be, you know, in the center, in the spot, you know. ; Therapist: Yeah, attention. ; Patient: Yeah, exactly. ; Patient: That's what, you know. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: That makes people laugh. ; Patient: Attention seeker, class clown, you know. ; Patient: I was that type of person. ; Therapist: That kind of explains why, you know, this conversation is going well. ; Therapist: You're pretty much open. ; Therapist: Now, right now, how old are you Curtis? ; Patient: Twenty actually. ; Therapist: You're twenty years old. ; Therapist: And do you have any, do you have a girlfriend? ; Patient: I do. ; Patient: I have a girlfriend. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So you have a girlfriend. ; Therapist: And how old is your girlfriend? ; Patient: She's seventeen. ; Therapist: Seventeen. ; Therapist: And how long, when does she turn eighteen? ; Patient: Eighteen, actually in like three weeks. ; Therapist: Oh, pretty much eighteen years old. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And do you have, how long have you known her? ; Therapist: How long have you been together as boyfriend and girlfriend? ; Patient: Not that long, for like two months. ; Patient: I've been off and on with girlfriends because it's kind of been like all drug use and they don't like to deal with it. ; Patient: So I've been kind of off and on in relationships and sometimes single, sometimes off. ; Patient: And it's been, you know, not that good for me. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: So your past relationship's pretty much? ; Patient: Been gone. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Well, due to my drug program. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And your past relationships, did the, did your partners know that you were smoking marijuana? ; Therapist: Did they? ; Therapist: They came out? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Were you upfront with them or is this something they found out and therefore they said, you know, I don't want to be part of this? ; Patient: Yeah, yeah, exactly. ; Patient: It was. ; Therapist: Okay, found out. ; Therapist: So some of your choices and some of your decisions had a consequence? ; Patient: Yeah, bad choices, bad decisions. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So what we want to do, we want to be able to identify, you know, your problem and that's, you know, the marijuana use and then maybe what triggers, you know, you to go use marijuana. ; Therapist: And then maybe then begin to identify some of the emotions that are behind it. ; Therapist: But, you know, you growing up with six siblings, did you, all of you go to the same school? ; Therapist: Were you in different schools? ; Therapist: I mean, tell me a little bit about your school history. ; Patient: You know, I had a sister who is one year younger than me, so we were kind of on the same, you know, grade level. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: You know, me and her went to the same school for a while and she got into this honor class. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: And so she moved into an honor school and I was kind of at school by myself. ; Patient: And I went through seven. ; Therapist: And this was a younger sister? ; Patient: Yeah, this was one, she was only one year younger. ; Therapist: So you were pretty close to her. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: And then during high school, I moved to seven different high schools. ; Therapist: Seven? ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: It's been hard. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: But I got together just a little bit. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: Around two years ago and I got my high school diploma and graduated. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: Now, in high school, how did that affect you being moved around seven times? ; Therapist: Was your foster parent moving you? ; Therapist: Did you move physically in your house? ; Patient: You know what, it was actually when I was 13, as I told you, when I was 13, I moved from my foster parents. ; Patient: And when I was 13, I went to a group home. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: So, you know, when I moved from place to place, from group home to group home, the area of the city would vary, so it would kind of like be different schools. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: So then you had to make a whole new set of friends. ; Patient: Exactly. ; Therapist: And that was the challenge with meeting new friends, not knowing who your friends are, what they do. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: What are some of the subjects that maybe were, that came easy to you, that you enjoyed, that were, you know, where you did well?
