; Therapist: What were some of the areas that you excelled in? ; Patient: Spelling. ; Patient: I like spelling. ; Patient: I was in every spelling bee. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: Never won, but I was in every spelling bee. ; Therapist: You were there. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: I like reading. ; Patient: I like spelling. ; Therapist: So spelling and reading are your strong points. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: That kind of explains why you're, you're, you're pretty good as far as, you know, being vocal. ; Therapist: You're okay. ; Therapist: You like to talk to people. ; Therapist: You engage well with people. ; Therapist: So, spelling, English, and what were some of the classes that maybe you didn't really enjoy or you had a challenge with? ; Patient: Math, science, PE, um, that's about it. ; Patient: Math, science, and PE.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name curtis; age 20yrs; sex male; education graduate ; Clinical Identifiers: Setting opd ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Alcohol use 7yrs 2. Cannabis use 7yrs ; History: Pt was apparently maintaining well until 13yrs of age when he was in school. When he turned 13 he was sent to group homes for studies and during this time he made new friends. His friends used to have alcohol and smoke weed and offered him too. Earlier he would take these substances ocassionally on birthday parties and festivities but currently he has to smoke daily spending around 200 daily. Past history na family history pt was raised by his foster parents. Has 6 siblings. He has 1 sister who is 1 year younger to him ; Crisis Markers: Daily marijauana use ; Current Mental Status Examination: Nil ; Psychotherapy Type: Nil ; Psychotherapy Technique : Nil ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: The current session was an introductory session to get to know about the patient and his presenting complaints ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Mental and behavioral disorders due to use of cannabinoids ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Music ; Therapist: Okay Marsha, so how can I help you today? ; Patient: Well, I'm working full time, I'm a part time student. ; Patient: I've just gotten engaged and I live at home. ; Patient: There's just so much stress in my life, I have everything happening all at once. ; Patient: Just to top it all off, I failed an exam, a really big exam. ; Patient: And I just feel like I can't do anything anymore, I can't do anything right. ; Patient: I've just got so much stress and I feel like such a disappointment, such a failure. ; Patient: And I've embarrassed my family by failing. ; Patient: I just don't know what to do anymore. ; Patient: I guess I've come here today to tell you I want to leave uni. ; Patient: I guess that's why I've come here today. ; Therapist: So it sounds like a whole lot of stuff is on top of you at the moment? ; Patient: Yeah, just so much, just all piling on. ; Therapist: So you're working full time, plus part time study, and then you've got your wedding preparation. ; Patient: Yeah, just got engaged and wedding's just a month away now. ; Patient: So I've just got so much happening. ; Patient: Work is really demanding. ; Patient: Just failed this exam, don't know what to do. ; Patient: All too much. ; Therapist: So I imagine you've been sweating on this for a while and it's all been swirling around in your head? ; Patient: Yes, just been building up and building up. ; Patient: And so much pressure with everything. ; Patient: I'm living at home, so my parents, a lot of pressure. ; Patient: I need to do everything right. ; Patient: By failing this, I feel like I've just embarrassed them and disappointed them. ; Patient: I just don't feel like I'm good enough to go on studying. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Have they said much to you about failing your exam? ; Patient: They haven't said much. ; Patient: I was really scared to tell them actually, because I knew they'd just be so disappointed and just embarrassed by the fact that I did fail. ; Patient: Yeah, I've never failed anything before. ; Therapist: Wow. ; Patient: It's really hard. ; Therapist: Yeah, so it's new and you don't like it at all? ; Patient: Not at all, no. ; Patient: I think leaving uni will just be the way out, just so I don't have to go through it again. ; Therapist: Right, okay. ; Therapist: Well, I'm glad you've come to counselling, because it's good for us to get an outsider's opinion when we've got so much on our plate and we're confused as to what to do and our emotions can get in the way. ; Therapist: And you've just said earlier that a whole lot of stuff's on your plate at the moment. ; Patient: Yeah, a lot of stuff, yeah. ; Therapist: So I'm glad you've come here. ; Therapist: Here at the clinic, we use the ABC model, which is a cognitive behavioural therapy model. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So, Marsha, some counsellors have put together a list of beliefs that we often use and we don't realise that we're using those beliefs and they tend to be faulty ones. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Here's the list here. ; Therapist: Have a look through that to see if there are any beliefs that you might be operating on at the moment. ; Patient: I think number two. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Read that one out for me. ; Patient: That it's necessary to have a high degree of order and certainty in order to be happy and perform well. ; Therapist: Yeah, yeah, you mentioned that earlier. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Number four. ; Patient: That it's necessary to be competent and successful in all those things which are attempted. ; Therapist: Yeah, that's an expectation from your family. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Possibly number eight. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: That life should be entirely pleasant and enjoyable and that any frustration, discomfort or pain would be unbearable. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Which one of those stands out the most for you at the moment, Marsha? ; Patient: Probably number four. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: How would you put that in your own words? ; Patient: That I need to be successful all the time in everything that I do. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: And is that different from what's happening in your life at the moment? ; Patient: Well, failing that exam, I mean, I wasn't successful with that. ; Patient: So, yeah, I mean, it just throws out, I guess even number two, because it throws out all the order in my life. ; Patient: I need to have everything, you know, so I need to know what I'm doing, where I'm going. ; Patient: Yeah, so. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So if number four is an expectation that your family have and that you have of yourself, how do you measure up next to number four? ; Patient: I don't feel like I'm good enough. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Well, what I'd like to do is put some of those ideas on the board under the ABC and I'll explain as we go along. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So what do you think the trigger point might be or the activating event for you at the moment? ; Patient: I mean, there are a lot of things, but I think obviously failing the exam was the main one. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: And the consequence is you thinking of leaving? ; Patient: Leaving uni, yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: And that statement that you made earlier about I'm not good enough? ; Patient: I'm not good enough, yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah, that's the B one. ; Therapist: That's the crucial one. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And I'll explain it shortly when I get up to the board. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: I think I'll put it up there now for you so we can work through that. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: So, Marsha, the activating event, which is what you stated earlier. ; Patient: I failed my exam. ; Therapist: That's right. ; Therapist: And the kind of decision that you're thinking about is? ; Patient: Leaving uni. ; Therapist: That's right, yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So it's important that we consider the jump from here over to here and the kind of thinking that you've been swirling around in your head affects the consequence. ; Therapist: And you've mentioned earlier that number four seems to fit. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: And you put that in your own words. ; Therapist: What were your words before? ; Patient: That I'm not good enough. ; Therapist: Yeah, good. ; Therapist: It's really important for us to consider that kind of thinking. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Okay, Marsha, it's good that we've got those things on the board. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: And what I'd like to do now is focus stepping out a bit from your situation and looking at it from another point of view. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: To me it sounds like you're doing a whole lot of things really well. ; Therapist: Can you list all of the things that you're doing really well? ; Patient: I'm working. ; Patient: It's a really demanding job and I'm keeping up with it. ; Therapist: Great, yeah. ; Patient: So I guess work. ; Patient: Things with my fiance, I mean, we're engaged, so planning the wedding. ; Patient: That's going really well. ; Patient: It's stressful, but it's going well. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: And all of your other university subjects? ; Patient: Yeah, I've never failed anything before. ; Patient: This is the first one, so I guess all the other subjects, yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah, yeah. ; Therapist: And you're succeeding in all of those things. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Put together. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: You're juggling it and it's a lot on your plate at the moment, but it sounds like you've been able to cope up until this point of the one exam. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: This one just threw me off balance. ; Patient: Yeah, just failing, yeah. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: So would you describe yourself as successful most of the time? ; Patient: Yeah, most of the time. ; Therapist: Yeah? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And what's the evidence for that? ; Patient: Passing all my exams all the time. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: Just passing my subjects, not just exams. ; Therapist: Yeah, that's right. ; Patient: Getting that full-time job, it's a great job that I'm doing. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: You're getting married. ; Therapist: Yeah, that's right. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So how do all of those successes compare to that belief that I've written on the board for you? ; Patient: I guess in comparison, I am good enough. ; Therapist: Yeah, that's right. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: And all the evidence is there. ; Therapist: All of the subjects that you've passed in first year and now second year. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: You're a full-time job. ; Therapist: That's a success. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: It's great. ; Therapist: Yeah, good. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Well, what I'd like to do is get you to write that on the board. ; Patient: All right. ; Therapist: To dispute that belief. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Would you do that? ; Patient: All right. ; Therapist: Well done, Marsha. ; Therapist: That's a powerful statement. ; Therapist: What kind of decision goes along with that? ; Patient: Staying at uni. ; Therapist: Good. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Write that on the board for us. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Great. ; Therapist: That's good. ; Therapist: Good. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So you've made a bit of a decision there, haven't you? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Tell me about it. ; Therapist: Does it feel okay? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I feel like I should stay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Why is that? ; Patient: I can try again. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: I mean, everything doesn't have to be 100% all the time. ; Therapist: Good, good. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: So, I mean, I could re-sit the exam. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Yeah, yeah. ; Therapist: And we've talked about all your successes. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So it's harder now to believe that top statement that I'm not good enough. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I mean, I am good enough compared to all the things that you helped me realize with all the successes that I've had. ; Therapist: That's right. ; Patient: I am good enough. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Good. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And so this idea about staying at uni, tell me about that. ; Patient: Yeah, I'll stay. ; Patient: I mean, I am good enough, so I'm sure I can give it another go and see how I go from there. ; Patient: I can re-sit the exam and I'm sure I'll be fine. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Good. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: What I'd like you to do is to keep saying that statement, I am good enough. ; Therapist: Say it in front of the mirror two or three times a day so that you build up your confidence because it's going to take some time to reprogram your computer up here with that kind of positive belief about yourself rather than carrying around that other belief. ; Therapist: And we tend to carry those other beliefs for years and years and years, and so it's going to take a bit of work on your part to deliberately change your thinking and change your belief system. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: But you've made a great start here today, so congratulations. ; Patient: Thank you! ; Therapist: Bye.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name marsha, education part time student ; Clinical Identifiers: Clinic ; Therapist Information : Clinic ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms 1 stress 2 anxiety chief complaints 1 fear of failure 2 negative self-talk 3 poor decision making 4 anxiety for being perfect ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior nad; speech confused, mood  affect anxious, thought negative, perception distorted, cognitive functions disturbed, judgement and insight poor and intact. ; Psychotherapy Type: Cbt; mode individual. ; Psychotherapy Technique : Thought challenging cognitive restructuring problem solving ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Themes discussed in the session 1 anxiety patient feels stressed because of her full-time job, part-time studies, and impending wedding preparations. Difficult for her to take responsibility and cope with the situation effectively. 2 fear of failure failing an important exam has triggered feelings of inadequacy and self-doubt in marsha. She feels like shes let herself and her family down, and this fear of failure has become a significant barrier to her academic pursuits. 3 perfectionism patient has the need to be successful in all aspects of her life which makes her feel disappointed. 4 negative perception patient feels not good enough, low self-esteem and worthlessness. 5 technique used counselor used the abc model of cbt to help her identify and challenge her faulty beliefs. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Anxiety

dialogue: Therapist: How are you doing today? ; Patient: I'm doing okay. ; Therapist: Doing okay? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: What's been going on? ; Patient: Well nothing too bad. ; Patient: I kind of got in a little bit of a bender bender accident. ; Therapist: A car accident? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: What happened? ; Patient: Well, we were at a stop sign and there was one car here, another car here, and then I was here, another car was coming up behind me, and then they hit me and then I hit the car in front of me. ; Therapist: Oh. ; Patient: I kind of, you know, just the usual- Rock back and forth. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: But other than that you're okay? ; Patient: I got a couple, you know, little bruises from like hitting the steering wheel. ; Patient: I'm like, yeah, but I'm okay. ; Patient: My body's okay. ; Therapist: So physically you feel okay? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Were you like checked out by your physician or anything? ; Patient: Yeah, everything's okay here. ; Patient: I didn't break anything or pull anything or anything. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Emotionally? ; Patient: It's been kind of hard to like get in my car again afterwards. ; Patient: Like I've still been going to work and everything, but like I realized last night, like my boyfriend was like, oh, do you want to go on a trip this weekend? ; Patient: And I was kind of like, maybe not. ; Patient: Like I'm kind of like hesitant to get back in the car. ; Therapist: So when he said that about the trip, what was the thought that came in your mind? ; Patient: I'm going to get hurt. ; Therapist: So it was really all about the car? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: It wasn't anything else about the trip? ; Patient: No, it was being in the car, driving the car. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And your thought was you're going to get hurt? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I'm going to get hit, I'm going to get hurt. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Any other areas that disrupted that trip? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So you normally would have went on a trip? ; Patient: Oh, definitely. ; Patient: I was kind of excited about it. ; Patient: But now I'm just like, no, I don't know. ; Patient: Or even like coming here, I was like, well, maybe I can reschedule. ; Patient: Like I was just like, oh, I don't want to drive. ; Patient: I don't want to be behind the wheel. ; Patient: I don't want to drive. ; Patient: And like when I did drive, I was fine coming. ; Patient: Like I drove the way I normally do, but I was a little bit more aware. ; Patient: But I wasn't driving extra slow. ; Patient: I wasn't driving extra fast or anything. ; Patient: But like I was checking a lot more. ; Patient: But very nervous. ; Patient: Much more nervous than usual. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: How did you feel about driving cars prior to this accident? ; Patient: I was fine. ; Patient: I mean, whenever like my friends would go anywhere, I would always volunteer to drive. ; Patient: Like I enjoyed driving. ; Patient: I liked listening to the radio. ; Patient: You know, I liked my family and I always went on trips. ; Patient: And like as soon as I turned 16, like I always had a turn. ; Patient: I enjoyed it. ; Patient: I liked going on drives, just looking around. ; Patient: But now I don't, too scared. ; Patient: It doesn't even come in my mind anymore as like a thing I would want to do. ; Patient: If I can avoid it, I will. ; Therapist: So you're taking every opportunity to avoid driving. ; Therapist: So far getting like here today and getting to work, essential functions you've been able to do. ; Patient: Yeah, it takes me a while to actually, like okay, like I have to. ; Patient: And then I just kind of do. ; Therapist: So what do you tell yourself to motivate yourself to get into the car? ; Therapist: Like to come here today for instance? ; Patient: Well, it takes me, I have to kind of think about it for a long time. ; Patient: But I mean, I'm very nervous. ; Patient: I mean, I don't, I can't really think of what I tell myself. ; Patient: It just kind of happens. ; Therapist: And when you get in the car, like when you kind of work past that nervousness to get in the car, how do you feel then? ; Patient: Still pretty scared. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah, I'm, you know, I'm pretty scared throughout the whole thing. ; Patient: I'm, you know, I'm always worried that like if I can go away that I know that doesn't have any stop lights, I'll try to go that way. ; Patient: Even if it takes me an extra half hour. ; Therapist: Oh, that long. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Well, how about now? ; Therapist: Like you've driven here. ; Therapist: I presume you're going to drive your own car to wherever you're going next. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So does that kind of generate those same feelings and nervousness? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Like you just reminded me of that. ; Therapist: You could feel it. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So this is, this is disturbing for you. ; Therapist: This is painful for you. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: It's scary. ; Therapist: But it hasn't yet infringed on a crucial area of functioning like your job or something. ; Patient: Not yet. ; Therapist: But you're worried it might. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So prior to this car accident, how many car accidents have you been in? ; Patient: Maybe one small little thing, but this is the worst one I've been in. ; Therapist: The other one didn't bother you like this one did? ; Therapist: No. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: How long ago was the other one? ; Patient: Maybe like four or five years ago. ; Therapist: Were you hurting that? ; Therapist: No. ; Therapist: Were you driving? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: So something about this one has triggered this nervousness. ; Patient: The other one didn't. ; Therapist: What do you think is going on? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: This one it was different because I was by myself. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: It was rainy, so maybe that, it wasn't, and it wasn't the other before, but. ; Therapist: So it was raining in the recent accident. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: And I was by myself, and then the other one I had somebody with me. ; Patient: So this one maybe, I don't know. ; Therapist: Did the driver that hit you tell you what happened? ; Therapist: Like why they? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: They just, they kind of, they left pretty quickly afterwards actually, and I was just kind of left to deal with it. ; Patient: Before the police got there? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Really? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So this really shook you up. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And your worries can interfere with other areas. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So your thinking is that you're going to get hurt, you're going to get hit if you get into a car again. ; Therapist: And you're thinking it before you get into a car and really. ; Patient: During, and even after it still kind of feels like, I don't know, even though I'm not in the car anymore I'm still like, kind of worried about it. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And it's really worried about another accident. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So let's look at that. ; Therapist: You were wearing your seatbelt. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: And you were driving, it was a little rainy. ; Therapist: Was it day or night? ; Patient: It was like five. ; Patient: It was getting ready to be dark but it wasn't dark yet. ; Patient: It wasn't dark, it was still daytime. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So what you're nervous about driving, I mean driving does carry risk. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So I can't tell you that there's a way to completely eliminate risk with driving a car. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: And you know this. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: Having just been in an accident. ; Patient: But there are certainly things you can do to minimize the risks. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: What do you think some of those things are you could do? ; Patient: Always wearing my seatbelt is pretty good. ; Therapist: Good idea. ; Patient: Well, I mean like I said, I try to go ways that don't have stop signs for stop lights, which is hard but... ; Patient: That's difficult. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And I'm not sure that would really reduce the risk because you're driving longer. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So you'd have to look at that case by case. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: But I see your point. ; Therapist: What else? ; Patient: Oh, I don't know. ; Patient: Drive when there aren't cars around. ; Therapist: What's that? ; Patient: Drive when there aren't other cars around. ; Therapist: Which again, probably is a good idea but it would be hard to practically implement, right? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Because you're driving to work in rush hour and driving home in rush hour. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So what about driving habits that you can use? ; Patient: Make sure I don't go too fast or too slow. ; Patient: Make sure that I have space around my car. ; Patient: Make sure all my lights are working, things like that. ; Patient: Make sure I don't have gas so I don't run out of gas or have to stop or something like that. ; Therapist: So follow all applicable traffic laws. ; Therapist: Keep aware of your environment. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Right? ; Therapist: You can do things that will not eliminate but will reduce the risk of an accident. ; Therapist: Now you were hit while at a red light, right? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: That one, of course, the seat belt would be helpful. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Have a car that has airbags maybe? ; Therapist: Certainly the safety of your vehicle, right? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: A vehicle that's safer than average would be more ideal. ; Therapist: Ultimately, I think it's a good idea to be safe, to be aware, to do your best to minimize risk. ; Therapist: And at the same time recognize that you can't eliminate it. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: So there's going to be a point where we have to really work through this nervousness. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: It's probably actually, I mean, in a way, you're looking around more. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: But ultimately, it's probably going to hinder your life. ; Patient: Probably. ; Therapist: Because you're restricting where you go and all that. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And eventually, if it gets in the way of getting to work. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Or you might lose my job or my boyfriend wasn't very happy when I said I didn't want to go. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Yeah, so you don't want it to interfere anymore. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So what can you tell yourself? ; Therapist: We talked about automatic thoughts, right? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: Like I'm going to get in an accident, which really that's one of the automatic thoughts. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: What are some of the adaptive responses that you could apply when that thought comes in? ; Therapist: Right, so the adaptive response is that self-talk, that message that you say to yourself. ; Therapist: What can you say to yourself? ; Patient: Like I'm doing everything I can to make sure that I'm safe. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: Like I might not be able to prevent getting hit, but I can maybe, like at least maybe I will get hurt. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: You can take every precaution. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Like it's going to be okay. ; Patient: Like I don't know. ; Patient: Like you're safe, you're okay, it's okay. ; Patient: Like okay, they stopped like just to try to, like if I see somebody coming behind me and they, I'm still worried about it, like noticing that they did stop and reassuring myself that it's going to be okay. ; Patient: Yeah, it's hard because it's still, you know, fresh. ; Therapist: Yeah, it's, yeah, thoughts are strong and you believe them and you believe that you're going to get hurt. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: It's very real to you. ; Therapist: And still there's always that possibility, so as I mentioned, you can't eliminate the ; Therapist: risk. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: So maybe one way to look at this is that you've only been in one other accident. ; Therapist: How many trips have you taken in your life in a car? ; Patient: Like a lot. ; Patient: I don't know, too many to count. ; Therapist: So it's, so the accidents are low probability events. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Scary, certainly, definitely not fun. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: But they haven't happened too often considering the number of trips you've taken. ; Patient: That's true. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: So another thing you could do is another adaptive response would be that I'm about to drive a car and there is an element of risk, but statistically. ; Patient: You probably won't get an accident compared to all the other times I've driven and not been in an accident. ; Therapist: Yeah, you probably won't. ; Patient: Yeah, that's true. ; Therapist: And you can reduce the risk by... ; Patient: Being careful. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So, there's a part that you can, of this anxiety, I guess, that you can satisfy. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Meaning you could say, well, I can really reduce the risks and I know my chances are low in any particular one drive. ; Therapist: But there's another part of this that you, of this you kind of have to accept, which is you could be an accident. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And that's not what you want and you'll do your best to avoid it, but that could still happen. ; Therapist: Do you feel like, because I know this is all very fresh with the accident being recent, do you feel like you can apply those adaptive responses when you identify an automatic drop coming in? ; Patient: I can try. ; Patient: I mean, like I can think of the times where they've come into my head and they're like, oh, no. ; Patient: And then when I realize I'm getting ready to think that, I'll be like, well, actually, it's going to be okay. ; Patient: And I can try. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So, I'd like to give you some homework. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Around this anxiety. ; Therapist: We talked about the thought record, which is like where you fill out the back thought and how much it distresses you. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: In this case, it might be good to know what it's preventing you from doing. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Because your thoughts actually stopping you from. ; Therapist: Yeah, going anywhere. ; Therapist: Part of the functioning. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And then you also put the adaptive response that you applied, like what you're able to ; Therapist: say to yourself. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And then how you felt after that. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So, what we hope is by repeatedly using the thought record and applying the adaptive response, that we'll see improvement. ; Therapist: Because the way of measuring, it's therapeutic, but it's also a way of measuring how well you're dealing with it. ; Patient: Sure. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So, that's kind of, you know, there's the attacking that automatic thought, disputing that automatic thought piece to this. ; Therapist: And then there's kind of the acceptance piece of it. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: So, there's that low but definite probability of an accident. ; Therapist: You have to kind of accept that. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: At some level. ; Therapist: And you have to pay with that. ; Therapist: And then the rest of it, you know, would be acknowledging that the probability is low, and that's good, and that you're likely not to get into an accident. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Do you feel like you can complete a few thought records between now and the next session? ; Therapist: Yeah, I think so. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So, let's do that. ; Therapist: If you feel like that's something you can be all right with. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Let's meet again in a week. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And if you can have, say, two thought records. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So, if that's two times and the thought came up, and then you've seen the thought record, you fill in each column. ; Therapist: And then we'll review that, and we'll see, you know, over the next few weeks if we can decrease these symptoms of nervousness and worry. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: That'd be good. ; Therapist: That'd be all right? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Thanks, Rebecca, and I'll see you in a week. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Bye. ; Patient: Bye.
summary: Patient Particulars : Education currently in college, 1 semester left to finish ; Clinical Identifiers: Settingopd; diagnosis anxiety; session no4 ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Currently 4th session follow-up session; in the previous session patient was psychoeducated about anxiety and gradual exposure. Heshe was asked to go to a mall and observe their thoughts but they couldnt do so ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Anxiety in crowded places na 2. Associated physical autonomic symptoms like chest tightness, breathlessness na ; History: Patient reports that since their childhood, whenever they visits any place where they are surrounded by people, they would feel anxious with chest tightness and breathlessness. Gradually they started avoiding going to places where there would be a lot of people around. Currently they get out of the car but as soon as they notice a crowd inside, they do not enter the front door and return from the gate itself. This is causing significant socio- occupational dysfunction in the patients life which brought them here. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Affect anxious; thought content preoccupation with getting anxious in crowd ; Psychotherapy Type: Type cbt; mode individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Problem solving, exposure, mindfulness ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Anxiety in crowded places ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Agoraphobia ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Sarah, how are you doing today? ; Patient: I'm doing okay. ; Patient: Could be a little better but I could always be worse but I'm doing okay. ; Therapist: Doing okay. ; Therapist: I understand you have some symptoms that have been bothering you? ; Patient: They have been bothering me. ; Patient: Well, I just started back to school last year. ; Patient: I was staying at home while my husband was working but the kids are crawling out of the house. ; Patient: So I said I was going to go back to school. ; Patient: I haven't been in school in 20 years and I thought I could handle it. ; Patient: But right now I just find myself so anxious and just so worried all the time. ; Patient: And I just don't know what to do with it. ; Patient: It's been going on for around the past 7, 8 months now. ; Therapist: About 7 or 8 months. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Would you say that this anxiety has been affecting you more days than it doesn't? ; Patient: I would say it's been affecting me, yes. ; Patient: For some time though, yes. ; Patient: More often than not, yes. ; Therapist: More often than not, yeah. ; Therapist: Do you find yourself struggling to control the anxiety? ; Patient: To control it? ; Patient: I'm just anxious all the time. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: So it sounds like you are struggling to get under control? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Tell me about how it's been affecting, you mentioned school. ; Patient: I'm not doing too well in school right now. ; Patient: Not at all. ; Therapist: In what way? ; Patient: I thought I would be a better student. ; Patient: I was always a straight A student back before when I was an undergrad. ; Patient: I was always a straight A student. ; Patient: But now I'm failing and I just can't concentrate in school. ; Patient: I'm failing. ; Patient: I'm just so worried all the time about how I'm going to do in this class. ; Therapist: What assignments are due. ; Patient: If I'm getting the work done in time. ; Patient: It's just controlling, it's taking over everything I do in school. ; Patient: So I'm more worried about how I'm going to do than having time to focus on my grades. ; Patient: It's just to that level. ; Therapist: That's really distressing for you. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: And as a school, how about at home? ; Patient: At home, I'm so worried about school that it's affecting my life at home. ; Patient: Like, I have this assignment, but then, oh my goodness, I'm so focused on this assignment. ; Patient: Will I have time to make dinner for the kids? ; Patient: My husband's going, oh, the house is such a mess all the time. ; Patient: And it's just causing so much conflict at home. ; Patient: My husband thinks I should be doing my housework and I'm so consumed with school. ; Patient: And then it's just such a big mess right now. ; Patient: So I'm constantly worried. ; Patient: When I'm at school, I'm worried about home. ; Patient: And when I'm home, I'm worried about school. ; Therapist: So a good deal of worrying. ; Patient: All the time. ; Therapist: All the time. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So I want to ask you a few questions about this and some that might be related. ; Therapist: Do you drink or use any drugs? ; Patient: No, not at all. ; Therapist: Not at all. ; Therapist: Do you have any medical conditions? ; Patient: No, not at all. ; Therapist: Nothing? ; Therapist: Have you ever been diagnosed with any other mental health disorders? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: None? ; Therapist: Do you ever have panic attacks? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Have you ever had one in the past? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: So a lot of anxiety but no panic? ; Patient: Just anxiety, like overwhelming anxiety. ; Therapist: Intense anxiety. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: But never a situation where you felt you had to flee from a room or anything like that? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No. ; Therapist: Any past trauma? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: Nothing like that. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Do you sometimes feel keyed up, on edge, or restless? ; Patient: Restless, yes. ; Therapist: Restless? ; Patient: Restless. ; Therapist: Do you find yourself easily fatigued? ; Patient: Tired all the time. ; Therapist: Tired all the time? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Do you have any trouble concentrating or finding your mind going blank? ; Patient: No, not really. ; Therapist: No? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: How about irritability? ; Therapist: Do you find yourself irritable? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No? ; Patient: Not really irritable. ; Therapist: Any muscle tension? ; Patient: No, not really. ; Therapist: No? ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: How about, I need trouble sleeping. ; Therapist: So this would be falling asleep, staying asleep, having unsatisfying sleep, anything like that? ; Patient: Well, I have unsatisfying sleep but we just moved and we live next to a factory. ; Patient: There's trucks in and out all the time. ; Patient: Who can sleep with that? ; Patient: Just chronic, just noise. ; Therapist: So you think that might be causing your sleep disturbance? ; Patient: Well, it's entirely possible. ; Patient: It's like who can sleep when you have trucks in and out all hours of the night or overnight in the wee hours of the morning. ; Patient: So it's pretty much impossible to fall asleep when you have just this noise. ; Therapist: How about before you moved there? ; Patient: I don't remember. ; Therapist: You don't remember? ; Patient: I really don't remember. ; Therapist: How long ago was it that you moved to the 4-hour now? ; Patient: A couple of years. ; Therapist: A couple of years? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: So you've had this noise at night for a couple of years. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: And the symptoms started 8 months ago. ; Patient: Yes. ; Patient: So I don't know if it's made it worse or if the noise has just been, so I don't know if it's the noise or what. ; Patient: I can't sleep through a truck. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: How about any vacations or anything? ; Patient: I'm sorry. ; Patient: No vacations. ; Therapist: No. ; Patient: No vacations. ; Therapist: So you've pretty much been sleeping at your home every night for as long as these symptoms have been around. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: All right, Sarah. ; Therapist: I appreciate you answering these questions for me. ; Therapist: This has been helpful. ; Therapist: I'm going to get you a schedule with a counselor and they should be able to see you in a couple of days. ; Patient: Oh, thank you. ; Therapist: Thank you. ; Therapist: I would so appreciate it just to get this under control. ; Patient: Absolutely. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Take care, Sarah. ; Patient: Thank you.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name sarah; sex- female; marital status- married; education- post graduation pursuing ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Persistent feeling of restlessness 2. Apprehension about future misfortunes 3. Difficulty concentrating 4. Fatiguability ; History: Course- continuous; duration- 8months; progress- deteriorating patient finds it difficult to perform well at school. It constantly bothers her and as a result she is unable to concentrate and failing at school. She is also finding it difficult manage things at home as she constantly feels tired. Earlier she was a good student but now she struggles with completion of assignments, nervous about the deadlines and classes, as she fails that she will fail. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Thought- content worry about managing household chores and studies; mood- anxious; affect- restricted; insight- grade 4 ; Psychotherapy Type: Person centered therapy ; Psychotherapy Technique : Active listening ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patients thought content reflected constant anxiety. She was apprehensive about her performance in her studies which affected her ongoing performance and her household responsibilities. She felt under constant anxiety, fatiguability and difficulty concentrating. ; Reflections by the therapist: Patient was cooperative and rapport was established. Her participation in the session was active. She was actively involved in explaining her past and current state and also reflected a willingness to take therapy. ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Okay, Mia, great job on your homework. ; Therapist: That was really excellent. ; Therapist: You listened to the imaginal exposure recording about six times, and you did the in vivo exposure of walking around and touching things like doorknobs and other surfaces and objects you normally wouldn't touch, both at your house and other places you went. ; Therapist: And you sat down on the floor, and you even ate lunch off the floor at your house and at your mom's house. ; Therapist: And no washing. ; Patient: No washing. ; Therapist: No hand washing, no extra washing. ; Therapist: Perfect. ; Therapist: Good for you. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So what did you learn from all that, do you think, over the course of the time you've ; Therapist: done that? ; Patient: It just, it got easier. ; Patient: At the beginning it was really hard, and I feel like my stats were much higher than at the end. ; Patient: So I guess that was what we talked about, the habituation. ; Therapist: Habituation, right. ; Therapist: The fact that when you do something like that that initially makes you anxious, and you do it repeatedly, especially in prolonged periods of time, your anxiety comes down. ; Therapist: We're just not built to stay indefinitely anxious. ; Therapist: You notice any other changes or anything else? ; Patient: I noticed that before doing the exposures I was really, really anxious. ; Patient: And then it kind of went down, like the anticipatory anxiety that we also discussed. ; Therapist: Did that change by, say, yesterday? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Also. ; Patient: The stats were initially really high before the exposure, and then they went down the more I did them. ; Therapist: So you're saying you not only noticed that it went down during the exposure, but you started feeling less anxious even approaching these tests. ; Therapist: Good. ; Therapist: Perfect. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: All right, good. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: All right, so you're doing so well, we're going to take another step up the hierarchy today like we planned, right? ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So this is the dog leash day, right? ; Therapist: Did you bring it? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay, good. ; Therapist: All right, we'll get to that later in the session. ; Therapist: First we're going to do some imaginal exposure, okay? ; Therapist: And you remember what the purpose of that is? ; Therapist: Why are we going to do imaginal? ; Patient: That way I can kind of relive a story or a situation that would make me really anxious and eventually deal with the fear consequence. ; Therapist: Exactly. ; Patient: Of getting sick in my case. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: So the idea is this is how we are able to have you have exposure to or sort of a confrontation in imagination with the consequences you fear of touching things that are contaminated and not washing, not doing your rituals, right? ; Therapist: Okay, perfect. ; Therapist: So did you write the story? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay, let me see. ; Therapist: All right, good. ; Therapist: All about taking the dog for a walk without leash and what happens because of it. ; Therapist: Excellent. ; Therapist: Okay, good. ; Therapist: You know this so I'm not going to ask you to read it. ; Therapist: Okay, so in a minute when we start, what I'm going to ask you to do is to close your eyes and to sort of narrate or describe this scene that you thought about it this week and wrote out where you're handling the dog leash and very aware of the way it's contaminated and I want you to describe in the story not just what you're doing but also what you're kind of feeling and what you're thinking as you do this and then also leading to the consequences you fear from handling the dog leash and not washing. ; Therapist: Good. ; Therapist: Any questions before you start? ; Therapist: Okay, so what's your level right now? ; Patient: I would say like a 70. ; Therapist: 70, okay. ; Therapist: All right, go ahead and start when you're ready. ; Patient: Should we press play? ; Therapist: Oh, thank you for reminding me. ; Therapist: We'll start the recording so you have that for homework. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: So, I'm in my house and the dog starts barking and I know that that means that I have to take him out. ; Patient: Really don't want to so I'm thinking maybe I should wait until Joe gets home and he can do it but I know if the dog keeps barking he's going to wake up the baby. ; Patient: So I decide to go to the front door and get the leash. ; Patient: I'm not going to wear the gloves I usually wear so I fully experience touching the leash but I'm already feeling really anxious and I look at the leash and I see that it's gross and it's full of hair and the dog has been biting on it and it probably has saliva and other things and I see stains and I start thinking what if that's dog poop and I get sick and I just feel myself shaking and really sweaty and my heart is beating really fast. ; Patient: So I'm feeling really, really anxious but I push myself and I grab the leash and I get the dog, open the door, go out and grab the leash. ; Therapist: What's your level now Mia? ; Therapist: Just real quick. ; Patient: Like 90. ; Therapist: 90 ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: You're doing great. ; Therapist: Just keep going. ; Patient: So I grab the leash and the dog is pulling and I feel the leash kind of pushing through my skin and I'm thinking all the bacteria that's getting there and I'm going to get sick. ; Patient: I want to vomit but I just keep going. ; Patient: So I walk the dog, come back home and I just leave the leash in the front door and I'm thinking I'm probably going to get sick. ; Patient: I really want to wash my hands, really want to take a shower but I try not to and I stop myself and I'm feeling really, really anxious so I can't stop thinking about washing. ; Patient: So I try to go to bed, decide to fall asleep. ; Patient: The next morning I wake up and I already feel sick. ; Patient: I know I'm sick. ; Patient: I'm shivering and I feel like I have a fever and I'm shaking again and I'm really nauseated so I go to the bathroom, start vomiting and I know I'm sick. ; Patient: I already got something I should have washed. ; Patient: I start thinking about that. ; Patient: Going to get the baby sick and I feel really, really sick. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Great job. ; Therapist: What's your level now? ; Patient: Like 80. ; Therapist: 80 ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So just keep visualizing this. ; Therapist: I'm going to describe it now and you just stay with that image as much as you can. ; Therapist: So you're in the house and the baby's sleeping and you're trying to get some housework done and do things for dinner. ; Therapist: Suddenly you hear the dog at the front door barking and barking and immediately your heart rate kind of jumps up and you get upset and anxious because you know that means he needs to go out and Joe's not going to be home for hours and you really don't want to take him out but you have to and it makes you scared and upset because you're not going to use the gloves that you always use when you have to take him out. ; Therapist: So you walk toward the door and you think well maybe I'll just make him wait but you realize he'll wake the baby up if you don't take him. ; Therapist: So you go toward the leash and it just makes you even more anxious to see it and it's dirty and it's chewed up and it's gross and you see stains on it and you think about what those are from and maybe they're from dog poop and that's going to get on you. ; Therapist: And you pick it up anyway and snap it on his collar and as you go out the door and he lunges outside he pulls that leash into your hand and you feel the contamination from the leash entering your body through the pores of your skin and you feel like it's just running up your arm through your bloodstream and you keep thinking oh my god what if I get sick from this what if there's some germs in this or bacteria but you keep walking him until he finishes what he has to do and you bring him back inside the house take the leash off and the urge to wash is so powerful so strong you want to go scrub your hands and get in the shower and wash your whole body and do it quickly and get all these germs off from the leash but you don't do that you don't you make yourself not do the ritual and then you go back in and just keep doing the housework and keep doing things but that's the sense of feeling sick is staying with you and worrying about what's going to happen if you picked up germs from the leash. ; Therapist: That night you go to sleep still anxious still upset about what happened wake up in the morning and then before you have your eyes open even a couple minutes you know that you're sick you can feel your body being sick you rush to the bathroom and vomit you can feel the fever and your body is just not right you're sick and you know it's because you handled that leash and didn't wash you didn't do the washing you needed to do and now you're sick and the baby will probably get sick and if only you had done the washing. ; Therapist: What's your level now? ; Patient: Like 80. ; Therapist: 80 okay okay you take it back and you do it again okay good job. ; Patient: Okay so I'm home and the dog starts barking.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name mia ; Past Session Information: Follow up session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms anxiety and obsession chief complaints feels contaminated and nauseous ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behavior cooperative; speech, mood  affect anxious, thought obsessive, perception distorted, cognitive functions impaired, judgement poor ; Psychotherapy Type: Erp, mode individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Thought challenging cognitive restructuring ; Issues discussed in Current Session: 1 problems feels contamination entering her body through the skin, has a strong urge to wash. 2 technique therapist is using erp to make her observes the leash is dirty, full of hair, dog saliva, and possibly stained with dog poop. Helped to reduce her anxiety level. 3 goal continue imaginal exposure to further reduce anxiety. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Ocd ; Action Plan : Next exposure handling the dog leash without gloves, incorporating this into real-life situations gradually.

dialogue: Therapist: All right, Chris, so I need to talk to you because, as you know, we have a zero tolerance policy for drugs and alcohol at this school, and as athletic director, it's my job to check in with our student athletes and make sure everyone's adhering to that rule. ; Therapist: And I've been hearing some chatter from some of the other kids about a party this weekend, and from what I hear, you were there, and I can't confirm or deny anything, so I'm not at the point where I can give you consequences, but I do want to talk to you about whether or not you're drinking and how you really can't be doing this as a member of one of our teams. ; Patient: Right, actually, I do want to speak to you about something that happened during this past weekend. ; Patient: Usually, as you know, I'm an honor student. ; Patient: I usually am studying over the weekend, and my parents don't let me go out to parties, but I kind of use that to my advantage to convince my parents to go to this party that my friends were pressuring me to go to. ; Patient: And when I got there, I'm not used to this party environment where everything that you see in the movies is kind of what happens, where you have people just drinking out of the bottle or playing random games with alcohol just to get drunk for no reason. ; Patient: Because I was there in the moment, I felt pressured to do and conform to what everyone else was doing, so I wouldn't be ostracized. ; Therapist: I get it. ; Therapist: We've all been there, okay? ; Therapist: I was in high school once, too. ; Therapist: I drank, too. ; Therapist: I get it. ; Therapist: There's not a ton to do in this town, and kids drink. ; Therapist: But the problem is we have these rules, and if you're on a team, you have to stick by the rules. ; Patient: I know that it's bad for me. ; Patient: It's bad for my body. ; Patient: It's bad for being on a team, for being an athlete. ; Patient: It hinders my performance. ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: I feel that my friends pressure me. ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: I feel I should go with different friend groups, maybe. ; Patient: I don't know. ; Therapist: Chris, come on. ; Therapist: You're getting peer pressure. ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: Being in a sports team, you have to be unified with the group. ; Therapist: Yeah, but you're one of the leaders. ; Patient: Right, and as being one of the leaders, my fellow teammates expect me to be ... expect them to lead not only in the sports, but also in social environments. ; Patient: If that's social, that's a social custom in our society. ; Therapist: Well, maybe you can start leading as a non-drinker, then. ; Patient: I could, but that could also backfire on me, I feel, that I could be ridiculed for having a stick up my butt. ; Therapist: You're a star player. ; Therapist: Who's going to pick on you? ; Patient: I mean, I'm just one person. ; Patient: It's the voice of the mob. ; Therapist: Yeah, so the issue again is I can't be hearing reports about you drinking. ; Therapist: I can't be hearing that you're at parties. ; Therapist: I can't be seeing pictures on Facebook. ; Therapist: There are rules at this school, and in my job, I have to enforce them. ; Therapist: Like I said, I get it. ; Therapist: I understand. ; Therapist: I know what it's like. ; Therapist: I get that you want to have fun. ; Therapist: Your teenage years. ; Therapist: I get that, but you are a star player. ; Therapist: We want to keep you on the team. ; Therapist: We got to figure out a way to get through this. ; Patient: Well, I'll dedicate the time not to party. ; Patient: Not party, but you get involved with alcohol to that extent, and have it publicized on the internet. ; Therapist: What do you mean? ; Patient: Like on Facebook, all the pictures that you saw on the internet. ; Patient: I'll avoid those situations where I have to go to a party where I feel pressured to actually drink alcohol and allow what I do in my own private time put on the internet so others can see. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Yeah, I mean, we got to have a deal here if you're going to be on the team, okay? ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: I will stop. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: You promise? ; Patient: I promise. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Shake? ; Patient: Shake. ; Therapist: We'll see you later. ; Patient: See you later. ; Therapist: All right.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name chris; sex- male; education high school; marital status unmarried ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Athletic director ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Alcohol consumption under peer pressure ; History: Present history client went to attend a party where he conformed to his friends and consumed alcohol under pressure so he doesnt get ostracized. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: General behavior client was cooperative and rapport could be established; mood tensed; affect restricted ; Psychotherapy Type: Person centered therapy ; Psychotherapy Technique : Motivational interviewing ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Clients alcohol consumption was discussed as it was against schools policy of zero tolerance for alcohol and drug. It was found that client was doing it under peer pressure and was told to skip going to such parties so he doesnt have to conform. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Nil ; Action Plan : Client has been told to avoid going to parties where there will be alcohol ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Michelle, how are you doing today? ; Patient: I'm kind of doing, I'm feeling a little bit stressed out. ; Therapist: Stressed? ; Patient: Yeah, I feel like I have a lot on my plate. ; Patient: I have this test that I have to take for work. ; Therapist: What kind of test? ; Patient: It's like an aptitude test. ; Patient: It has math problems on it and scenarios in order for me to move up to the assistant manager position. ; Therapist: Right, and that's a job that you've been interested in for a while. ; Therapist: Yes, it is. ; Patient: That's what you've been talking about. ; Patient: Yes. ; Patient: So, I've been just feeling a lot of anxiety about taking the test and then they actually scheduled for me to take the test and I just got really overwhelmed and I started, I felt my heart was racing, I felt like my hands were shaking and I just really couldn't concentrate on the test even though the night before me and my friend did practice problems and I knew all the answers with no problem, like I didn't miss any of the questions. ; Therapist: You know the material on this test pretty well. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: But the feelings and that physiological response to heart rate and the sweating, the feelings of anxiety plus those physiological responses, they got in the way of you completing it, if you were able to complete it? ; Patient: No, I wasn't able to complete it and thankfully they gave me a chance to come back. ; Patient: I just told them I didn't feel well. ; Patient: So they rescheduled. ; Patient: So now I'm feeling a lot of anxiety because I'm scared the same thing is going to happen when I go back. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So you weren't feeling great about taking the test in the first place? ; Patient: The day, the night before I felt like I know all the answers but the minute I walked into the room, all of a sudden all these fears kind of took over. ; Therapist: But did you know that was coming? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: You did? ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: So you had some anxiety in advance? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Or not? ; Therapist: You did? ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: I had some anxiety the day before but when I reviewed it with my friend, I'm like, oh, I know the answers. ; Patient: I thought that would kind of push it down but I think once I got there, it all came back up to the surface. ; Therapist: It erupted in that moment and that prevented you. ; Therapist: What do you think is leading to this? ; Patient: Well, I've always kind of struggled with tests. ; Patient: Like I can remember when I was in third grade, I had to take this test because I was really struggling in math. ; Patient: And I had to pass this test in order to move to the next grade. ; Patient: And I thought just like this test that I was ready for it. ; Patient: I had to tutor and I felt really prepared for it. ; Patient: And then when I took it, I failed and I was held back. ; Patient: And I feel like, you know, that was so, it was really embarrassing for me to be held back. ; Patient: I felt like, I don't want to say but I did feel like a failure at the time because I felt like I really did know this so I don't know why I couldn't pass the test. ; Therapist: And since that, so this was third grade? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: And since that, they had testing experience. ; Therapist: Have you had trouble with tests since? ; Patient: Yes. ; Patient: I always feel really anxious. ; Patient: I mean, I'm able to pass tests obviously because I graduated from grade school and went on to high school. ; Patient: But it's so hard for me because of this anxiety that I feel that even though I may think I know it, I may still fail the test anyway. ; Patient: Maybe like a repeat of what happened. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So in third grade, you had a really bad testing experience. ; Therapist: And as you moved forward from there, you've never really been thrilled about taking tests. ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: But you've been able to adapt. ; Therapist: You've been able to take them and still pass them. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I mean, sometimes I get an A. ; Therapist: That's good, right? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I mean, yeah, it is good. ; Patient: But yeah, it's good. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: But with this particular test, which is not for school, which is for work, this one, this is more a stumbling block for you. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Do you have any ideas as to what may be making this test such a point of anxiety for you? ; Patient: I think it's just the fact that it's this promotion. ; Patient: It's almost like the same thing. ; Patient: If I fail, I'm being held back. ; Patient: And I feel like it's reliving that moment of being held back. ; Patient: And that's like a fear that I have that by not being able to pass these tests, they're holding me back. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So really that same feeling you had in third grade, that's coming up with this test now. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I mean, I didn't put them together until now, but yeah. ; Therapist: And the other test you'd taken throughout the rest of grade school and high school, they didn't have that same value attached to them. ; Patient: No, because they didn't have all that pressure that it was either win or lose, basically. ; Therapist: You could take them again or take that course again. ; Patient: Or I could take another test to raise the grade if I didn't do good on that test. ; Therapist: So you maybe had more options in school. ; Patient: Yes. ; Patient: It wasn't pass or fail. ; Therapist: So it's the pressure. ; Therapist: It's the pressure of you need to get through this. ; Therapist: You don't have the safety nets that you had in school. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: If I fail it, then I'm not going to be able to get the promotion. ; Patient: I would have to wait just like I did. ; Patient: I'm going to have to wait a certain amount of time, I think an year before I could take it again. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So that is a lot of pressure. ; Therapist: That is a lot of pressure. ; Patient: Yeah, it is. ; Therapist: So is there any time limit to this test for work? ; Patient: No, there isn't. ; Therapist: There's no time limit? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: And how many, is it like a multiple choice? ; Patient: Yes, it is. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And you seem like, like you said you were studying the night before with your friend. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: You're really well prepared for it. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: So I have a few thoughts about this. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: One is I'm wondering, you know, we've talked before about cognitive therapy, about the core beliefs. ; Therapist: So I'm curious as to what you think about like what core belief may be operating for you now with this test, this work test. ; Patient: That I could fail, and then if I fail, I could end up being a failure at all, you know, the things that I try. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So something like I'm a failure or I'm bound to be a failure, I'm destined to be a failure. ; Patient: I would say like I'm destined to be a failure. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So I'm destined to be a failure. ; Therapist: So that potentially is a core belief, right, that's operating. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I mean, that's what scares me. ; Patient: That's exactly the thought that I'm thinking when I'm about to take the test, that if I don't pass it, it's just going to have like this domino effect of failure. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So it could be a core belief, but it's also, it seems like it's still an automatic thought. ; Therapist: Like as you get ready to take that test, you're thinking, I'm destined to be a failure. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: And you're having what sounds like a panic response, right, with the heart racing. ; Patient: Yeah, and my hands shaking. ; Therapist: Hands shaking. ; Therapist: Are you in the room alone when you're taking the test? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: You are. ; Therapist: So no one's really seeing you have this, I wouldn't want to call it a panic attack yet. ; Therapist: We haven't really gotten that far into it, but it sounds like it has some panic-like features. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Because it's not, it's interfering with you thinking clearly enough to get through the items. ; Therapist: So okay. ; Therapist: So one thought I have is, have you ever had panic attacks in the past or anything like this? ; Patient: Only when I'm... ; Therapist: Other than the third grade thing? ; Patient: No, not really. ; Patient: I mean, sometimes I get worked up when I'm about to take a test. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: But it's only around tests. ; Therapist: And what happens once you get worked up? ; Therapist: Like once your heart rate increases and you have the other physiological symptoms, what... ; Patient: When I actually do take the test? ; Patient: I kind of try to work through it and start trying to answer one question at a time to get to the last question. ; Therapist: So one possible strategy here is, we talked about the adaptive response, right? ; Therapist: So which is that thought that you say to yourself, that self-talk. ; Therapist: I wonder if your adaptive response couldn't be, I can ride this out. ; Therapist: Like you have no time to go on a test. ; Patient: Yeah, that's true. ; Therapist: I mean, the panic response is only maintained for so long. ; Patient: And I could also choose maybe questions that I know the answer to automatically. ; Patient: So that could help maybe relieve some of that stress. ; Therapist: To get some, in a sense, to get some minor victories under your belt by answering those right, you know you're closer to achieving your goal. ; Patient: Yes. ; Patient: And then I feel like I know, at least I know that they'll validate the feeling that maybe I can pass this test. ; Therapist: So the more items you answer correctly, the less anxious you're going to feel because you're closer to the end of. ; Patient: Yeah, definitely. ; Patient: Because then I start to feel more calm because I know that, I know these questions are definitely going to be right. ; Therapist: So that's one, well that's a cognitive and behavioral strategy, right? ; Therapist: Like you can wait out the panic. ; Therapist: I mean, you're in the room alone. ; Patient: Yeah, that's true. ; Patient: Nobody's there. ; Patient: Nobody's going to see me if I'm kind of trying to get myself together. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Now the panic's painful, right? ; Therapist: The panic symptoms are painful. ; Therapist: So what you could tell yourself is, yeah, this is unpleasant, but I can ride out these symptoms because they only last so long. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: So I could use like self-talk. ; Therapist: Exactly. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Because usually I mean panic symptoms can run, you know, five minutes, 10 minutes, 15 minutes, but you have no time limit. ; Patient: So I can take a, yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: So if you can just kind of use that time to focus on the items, as you mentioned, that you could get right and kind of at the same time be telling yourself, I can ride this out. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I mean, I've done that in the past, so I can apply it to this test. ; Therapist: So that's worked for you? ; Patient: Yes, that has worked for me in the past. ; Therapist: So that's certainly one adaptive response to try, right? ; Therapist: Another one could be that although it wouldn't be great to fail, you can retake the test in a year, right? ; Therapist: You could try again. ; Patient: Yeah, that's true. ; Therapist: I mean, I know that's not what you want, but the alternative is kind of buying into that automatic thought. ; Therapist: We know that's not working, right? ; Therapist: I'm destined, that was the word, right? ; Therapist: Like I'm destined to be a failure. ; Therapist: We know that's not working for you. ; Patient: So even if I have to take the test again in a year, then I'm not going to be a failure because I still have the chance to take it again. ; Patient: It's not like I'll never be able to take this test again. ; Therapist: Yeah, you just have another year to study, right? ; Therapist: And of course, you wouldn't have that promotion that time, and that would be an outcome I know you don't want, but it's not the end of your career. ; Therapist: It's not like something so drastic, right? ; Therapist: It's important to you, and I can appreciate that, but it's not the end of your career. ; Therapist: You're not going to be unemployed. ; Patient: No, no, definitely not. ; Patient: And just thinking back and relating it back to the third grade, even though I had to stay back, I still managed to do well the next year and keep moving up. ; Patient: And it hasn't really, in the long run, prevented me from doing anything that I wanted to do. ; Therapist: So that's great. ; Therapist: That's another adaptive response, which is I've survived this before. ; Patient: Yes, I definitely have. ; Therapist: So this one event, I mean, I know you had the incident in third grade with the unpleasant experience, but this one event, you don't want to let this kind of fashion, well, use your word, your destiny, right? ; Therapist: This was one unpleasant event that seemed to catch you off guard with the panic-like symptoms, and fortunately, your employer is going to give you a chance to try this again. ; Therapist: I imagine you can ride out these symptoms, and I think you have the other adaptive response, which is I've been successful with this before. ; Patient: Yes. ; Patient: Definitely, I feel a lot better now because I just know that no matter what happens, I've been here before, and I can get through it as opposed to that feeling that I'm going to just fail altogether. ; Therapist: All right, so what we'll do is, when do you have to take the test? ; Patient: Next week, next Wednesday. ; Therapist: Next week. ; Therapist: All right, so let's schedule one more appointment right before that. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: We'll make sure that you have these adaptive responses down and you're ready to go. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And really, we'll kind of focus on the positive outcome, right? ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Which is just taking this test, taking one item at a time, and fighting through some of these physical symptoms you're having. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And fighting through the unuseful thoughts. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Does that make sense? ; Patient: I mean, that sounds good because it helped me prepare for the test. ; Therapist: Great. ; Therapist: So, Michelle, I'll see you then and we'll work through it. ; Therapist: I really appreciate you coming in today. ; Patient: Okay, thank you.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name michelle; sex female ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Follow-up session. ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms anxiety chief complaints 1 anxious for his upcoming aptitude test for a promotion at work. 2 fear of failure. 3 racing heart and shaking hands during anxiety ; History: Past history patient has a history of failure in third grade which stayed with him and was an embarrassing experience for him. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior anxious; speech normal, mood  affect depressed; thought worrisome and ruminated, perception normal cognitive functions mildly clouded, judgement and insight intact ; Psychotherapy Type: Cbt; mode individual. ; Psychotherapy Technique : Reflective listening, cognitive restructuring, problem solving and thought challenging. ; Assessments: Aptitude test ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Following are the issues discussed in session 1anxiety patient feels stressed and anxious about an upcoming aptitude test for a promotion at work. She experiences physical symptoms such as a racing heart and shaking hands. 2past-history patient has negative experience with testing in third grade, where she got failed in a math test. This experience stayed with her and lead to anxiety and fear of failure when it comes to tests. This has become her core belief that she is destined to be a failure. 3strategies therapist suggests adaptive responses cope with her anxiety during the test which includes self-talk to reduce panic symptoms, focusing on answering questions one at a time, and accepting that the failure on the test is not a failure of life. Also, he suggested her to focus on past successes to motivate herself. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Anxiety ; Action Plan : The therapist suggests adaptive responses to cope with her anxiety during the test which include using self-talk, focusing on answering questions one at a time, and understanding that failure on the test does not equate to overall failure in life or career. ; Next session details: Next session planned. .

dialogue: Therapist: Hi, this is Dr. Grande. ; Therapist: I hope you find this video useful. ; Therapist: If that's the case, please like it and subscribe to my channel. ; Therapist: As always, thanks for watching. ; Therapist: Hi, Sue. ; Therapist: It's good to see you again. ; Patient: You too. ; Therapist: I was hoping today I could give you a test of your memory. ; Therapist: Would you be okay with that? ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: All right. ; Therapist: Is that all right? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So I'm going to read a series of questions and ask you to do some different things. ; Therapist: And this will just take a few minutes. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: All right? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Sue, what is today's date? ; Patient: I think it's the 10th. ; Patient: I think it's the 10th. ; Therapist: The 10th? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: What is today's year? ; Patient: 2016 ; Therapist: What is the month? ; Patient: It's January. ; Patient: It's 2017. ; Patient: It's January. ; Therapist: What day is today? ; Patient: It's the 10th. ; Therapist: Can you also tell me what season it is? ; Therapist: Can you also tell me the name of this clinic? ; Patient: Oh, God. ; Patient: What was it? ; Patient: I saw it when I came in. ; Patient: Oh. ; Patient: I don't remember. ; Therapist: What floor are we on? ; Patient: Red. ; Patient: That's a red floor. ; Therapist: Red? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Red carpet. ; Therapist: What city are we in? ; Patient: Dover. ; Therapist: Dover? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: What county are we in? ; Patient: Dover County. ; Therapist: Dover County? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: What state are we in? ; Patient: Delaware. ; Therapist: Delaware? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: So, I'm going to test your memory. ; Therapist: I want to read these three words. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And I want you to repeat them back to me. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Ball, flag, tree. ; Therapist: Can you repeat those back? ; Patient: Ball, frog. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Let me do that again. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Ball, flag, and tree. ; Patient: Ball, flag, and tree. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: I want you to remember those because I'm going to ask you to repeat them again later on. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Can you begin with the number 100 and count backwards by seven? ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: So, 100. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: 100 ; Patient: 93 ; Therapist: Continue. ; Patient: Mm. ; Patient: 85 ; Patient: 79 ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: 72 ; Patient: 65 ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: That's good. ; Therapist: Thank you. ; Therapist: Can you spell the word world backwards? ; Patient: World. ; Patient: L-R. ; Patient: No. ; Patient: D-R-L-W. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: I want you to name the three words that I asked you to remember a few months ago. ; Patient: Ball, frog. ; Patient: I think that was it. ; Therapist: You think that was it? ; Therapist: Can you tell me what this is? ; Patient: A watch. ; Therapist: A watch. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Can you tell me what this is? ; Patient: A pen. ; Therapist: I'm going to say a phrase, and I'd like you to repeat it back to me exactly as I say it. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: The phrase is, no ifs, ands, or buts. ; Patient: No ifs and buts. ; Therapist: Are you right-handed or left-handed? ; Therapist: Right-handed? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: I'd like you to take this piece of paper from me in your right hand, fold the paper in half, and put the paper on the floor. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: I can only fold it with my right hand. ; Therapist: You can use both hands. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: You're done?
