; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: I'm going to hold up a piece of paper with instructions, and I'd like you to follow those instructions. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Thank you. ; Therapist: With the blank sheet of paper that I gave you a moment ago, can you write on that a complete sentence? ; Patient: Just anything? ; Therapist: Anything complete sentence? ; Patient: Anything? ; Therapist: Any complete sentence? ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Thank you. ; Therapist: I'm going to show you a drawing. ; Therapist: I'd like you to copy the drawing on that same piece of paper. ; Patient: It's kind of hard. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Thank you. ; Therapist: Sue, I want to thank you for participating in this memory test. ; Therapist: It's been very helpful.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name sue ; Clinical Identifiers: Name dr. Grande. ; Past Session Information: Follow up session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms mental retardation psychosis ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior nad; speech slow, mood  affect low, thought confused, perception distorted; cognitive functions disorganized, judgement and insight poor ; Assessments: Memory test ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Themes used in session 1 orientation patient struggled with identifying the current date, year, month, and day and location which could be indicative of memory impairment or confusion. 2 test used through various memory tests therapist tried to identify few aspects of her memory like attention and concentration, verbal memory, executive functioning, motor skills, and writing abilities. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Mental retardation psychosis

dialogue: Therapist: Hi, Jackie. ; Therapist: How are you doing today? ; Patient: I'm all right. ; Therapist: You're all right? ; Patient: Yeah, I've been having a rough time. ; Therapist: Having a rough time? ; Therapist: I understand there have been some difficulties lately that brought you into the agency. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Tell me what's going on. ; Patient: About a week ago, I went out with some friends to a boxing match. ; Patient: I didn't really want to go. ; Patient: I've never really been to one. ; Patient: It's not really something I'm interested in. ; Patient: But I went just to hang out with my friends and stuff. ; Patient: I watched a few fights, and this one fight, this guy, nothing was really happening. ; Patient: I wasn't really into it, but this guy got knocked out right in front of me. ; Patient: It was really close to the ring. ; Patient: He got knocked out right in front of me, fell right on his face, and I just saw him lifeless in front of me. ; Patient: And I just ever since then, it's happened the same. ; Patient: I had to leave right away. ; Patient: I just couldn't be there anymore. ; Therapist: What did you notice right away? ; Therapist: One of the boxers was knocked out. ; Therapist: You saw that. ; Therapist: What did you notice right away that was happening? ; Patient: I just felt really, really scared. ; Patient: My heart started racing. ; Patient: I couldn't focus on what was going on around me. ; Patient: I just had to get out of there. ; Patient: So I don't even really know what happened to him, if he was okay or not. ; Patient: So I just couldn't handle how I was feeling, so I had to leave. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So you left, and the symptoms, they continued? ; Patient: Yeah, pretty much daily for the past week. ; Patient: I got home that night. ; Patient: I couldn't sleep. ; Patient: It took me almost all night to fall asleep. ; Patient: And then at work on Monday, I was having a lot of problems there. ; Therapist: What kind of problems? ; Patient: I couldn't focus when anyone was talking to me. ; Patient: I had a meeting on Tuesday, and my boss was talking for a while. ; Patient: I felt like I couldn't concentrate at all. ; Patient: Everything was just a blur around me. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Do you find that you're having memories of the incident at the boxing match that are intrusive? ; Patient: Yeah, I think about it a lot, pretty much all the time. ; Therapist: And it's bothersome for you? ; Patient: Yeah, if I'm at work trying to get some paperwork done or something, it just pops in my mind, and I can't make it go away. ; Therapist: And you try, but the memories stay there. ; Therapist: Any dreams related to the... ; Patient: No, I haven't really been dreaming about it. ; Patient: I'm barely sleeping, so... ; Therapist: Any times when you feel like you're reliving what you saw, like you're seeing it again? ; Patient: No, not really. ; Patient: I just think about it a lot. ; Therapist: You think about it? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Is anything reminding you of the boxing match, and then that's causing you to have symptoms? ; Patient: At the end of my meeting, people started clapping, you know, this big cheering, and that kind of made me feel really bad. ; Patient: Again, my heart was racing. ; Patient: I started sweating. ; Patient: It just kind of reminded me of being there, and I started thinking about it again. ; Patient: So things like that, you know, I pump up music when it comes on the radio, same kind of music they played there. ; Patient: That kind of makes me feel the same way. ; Patient: My heart starts to race. ; Patient: I just kind of feel like I need to get away from it. ; Therapist: Do you find yourself working to avoid, like, music that was similar? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I've been trying to really avoid the radio, because you never know what's going to come on on the radio. ; Patient: So I've been avoiding listening to music in case something like that happens and avoiding crowds. ; Therapist: Do you find that you've had any trouble remembering what happened? ; Patient: No, I can pretty vividly remember it. ; Therapist: It's pretty clear to you? ; Patient: Yeah, when I think about it. ; Therapist: Have you been irritable at all since the... ; Patient: Yeah, you know, just out of nowhere. ; Patient: If something doesn't go the way I want it to, I just kind of snap on people. ; Patient: And that's not like me at all. ; Patient: I usually am pretty easygoing. ; Patient: And, you know, people, my boyfriend, for instance, I yelled at him the other day for not putting the toilet paper on the roll. ; Patient: And that's not something I'd usually care about. ; Patient: It's just, it's not me. ; Therapist: How about your awareness level of what's around you? ; Therapist: Do you find that your awareness level has increased, that you're more aware? ; Patient: Um, it kind of depends. ; Patient: Sometimes I kind of feel like I'm in a daze and don't really know what's going on around me. ; Patient: But, um, I've been, um, one of the students that I work with, he popped out from behind the door, which he would do all the time. ; Patient: And, you know, typically I would laugh and think it was funny before, but he did it the other day and I just could not control myself afterwards. ; Patient: Like, I couldn't calm myself down. ; Patient: You know, I didn't think it was funny at all. ; Patient: It really, really scared me. ; Patient: And that went on for about 10, 15 minutes and I just, my heart was racing. ; Patient: I had to go take a walk. ; Patient: And it was just really hard to relax again after that. ; Therapist: So you feel like your reaction to that was stronger than it normally would have been? ; Patient: Definitely. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Have you used drugs or alcohol recently? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No. ; Therapist: Any medical problems? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No. ; Therapist: So Jackie, I'm going to get you in to see a counselor here at the agency if that's something that you're okay with. ; Patient: Yeah, I think that would be really helpful. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: Just take a couple days to get you on the, to get you in to see somebody, to get you on the schedule and get you in to see somebody. ; Therapist: And I'll get that arranged. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Thank you. ; Patient: Thanks.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name jackie; sex female; marital status unmarried ; Clinical Identifiers: Counseling agency ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Frequent thoughts 2. Irritability 3. Palpitations ; History: Present history patient was asymptomatic until a week ago. During that time she went to see a boxing match with her friends where she got extremely scared when one of the boxers in the ring got knocked out. Soon after she left as she could not handle her emotions that time. She continued feeling scared and had a racing heart even after leaving and couldnt sleep that night. Next day, she found it difficult to concentrate at work. She has been frequently getting memories of the incident and certain triggers like same music on the radio, people cheering him etc make her feel scared and she feels a racing heart. She has been getting irritated by people over trivial matters. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behavior patient was cooperative and rapport could be established; mood tensed; affect restricted ; Psychotherapy Type: Nil ; Psychotherapy Technique : Active listening ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patient shared a recent incident where she went to see a boxing match and felt extremely scared and anxious due to the fight and has been feeling irritable, thinking more than usual and palpitations frequently. She is also unable to sleep properly. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: F41. 0 panic disorder ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Music ; Therapist: Okay Marsha, so how can I help you today? ; Patient: Well, I'm working full time, I'm a part time student. ; Patient: I've just gotten engaged and I live at home. ; Patient: There's just so much stress in my life, I have everything happening all at once. ; Patient: Just to top it all off, I failed an exam, a really big exam. ; Patient: And I just feel like I can't do anything anymore, I can't do anything right. ; Patient: I've just got so much stress and I feel like such a disappointment, such a failure. ; Patient: And I've embarrassed my family by failing. ; Patient: I just don't know what to do anymore. ; Patient: I guess I've come here today to tell you I want to leave uni. ; Patient: I guess that's why I've come here today. ; Therapist: So it sounds like a whole lot of stuff is on top of you at the moment? ; Patient: Yeah, just so much, just all piling on. ; Therapist: So you're working full time, plus part time study, and then you've got your wedding preparation. ; Patient: Yeah, just got engaged and wedding's just a month away now. ; Patient: So I've just got so much happening. ; Patient: Work is really demanding. ; Patient: Just failed this exam, don't know what to do. ; Therapist: All too much. ; Patient: So I imagine you've been sweating on this for a while and it's all been swirling around in your head? ; Patient: Yes, just been building up and building up. ; Patient: And so much pressure with everything. ; Patient: I'm living at home, so my parents, a lot of pressure. ; Patient: I need to do everything right. ; Patient: By failing this, I feel like I've just embarrassed them and disappointed them. ; Patient: I just don't feel like I'm good enough to go on studying. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Have they said much to you about failing your exam? ; Patient: They haven't said much. ; Patient: I was really scared to tell them actually, because I knew they'd just be so disappointed and just embarrassed by the fact that I did fail. ; Patient: Yeah, I've never failed anything before. ; Therapist: Wow. ; Patient: It's really hard. ; Patient: Yeah, so it's new and you don't like it at all? ; Patient: Not at all, no. ; Patient: I think leaving uni will just be the way out, just so I don't have to go through it again. ; Therapist: Right, okay. ; Therapist: Well, I'm glad you've come to counselling, because it's good for us to get an outsider's opinion when we've got so much on our plate and we're confused as to what to do and our emotions can get in the way. ; Therapist: And you've just said earlier that a whole lot of stuff's on your plate at the moment. ; Patient: Yeah, a lot of stuff, yeah. ; Therapist: So I'm glad you've come here. ; Therapist: Here at the clinic, we use the ABC model, which is a cognitive behavioural therapy model. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So, Marsha, some counsellors have put together a list of beliefs that we often use and we don't realise that we're using those beliefs and they tend to be faulty ones. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Here's the list here. ; Therapist: Have a look through that to see if there are any beliefs that you might be operating on at the moment. ; Patient: I think number two. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Read that one out for me. ; Patient: That it's necessary to have a high degree of order and certainty in order to be happy and perform well. ; Therapist: Yeah, yeah, you mentioned that earlier. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: Number four. ; Patient: That it's necessary to be competent and successful in all those things which are attempted. ; Therapist: Yeah, that's an expectation from your family. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Possibly number eight. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: That life should be entirely pleasant and enjoyable and that any frustration, discomfort or pain would be unbearable. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Which one of those stands out the most for you at the moment, Marsha? ; Patient: Probably number four. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: How would you put that in your own words? ; Patient: That I need to be successful all the time in everything that I do. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: And is that different from what's happening in your life at the moment? ; Patient: Well, failing that exam, I mean, I wasn't successful with that. ; Patient: So, yeah, I mean, it just throws out, I guess even number two, because it throws out all the order in my life. ; Patient: I need to have everything, you know, so I need to know what I'm doing, where I'm going. ; Patient: Yeah, so. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So if number four is an expectation that your family have and that you have of yourself, how do you measure up next to number four? ; Patient: I don't feel like I'm good enough. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Well, what I'd like to do is put some of those ideas on the board under the ABC and I'll explain as we go along. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: So what do you think the trigger point might be or the activating event for you at the moment? ; Patient: I mean, there are a lot of things, but I think obviously failing the exam was the main one. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: And the consequence is you thinking of leaving? ; Patient: I live in uni, yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: And that statement that you made earlier about I'm not good enough. ; Patient: I'm not good enough, yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah, that's the B one. ; Therapist: That's the crucial one. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And I'll explain it shortly when I get up to the board. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: I think I'll put it up there now for you so we can work through that. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: So, Marsha, the activating event, which is what you stated earlier. ; Patient: I failed my exam. ; Therapist: That's right. ; Therapist: And the kind of decision that you're thinking about is? ; Patient: Leaving uni. ; Therapist: That's right, yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So it's important that we consider the jump from here over to here and the kind of thinking that you've been swirling around in your head affects the consequence. ; Therapist: And you've mentioned earlier that number four seems to fit. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: And you put that in your own words. ; Therapist: What were your words before? ; Patient: That I'm not good enough. ; Therapist: Yeah, good. ; Therapist: It's really important for us to consider that kind of thinking. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Okay, Marsha, it's good that we've got those things on the board. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: And what I'd like to do now is focus stepping out a bit from your situation and looking at it from another point of view. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: To me it sounds like you're doing a whole lot of things really well. ; Therapist: Can you list all of the things that you're doing really well? ; Patient: I'm working. ; Patient: It's a really demanding job and I'm keeping up with it. ; Therapist: Great, yeah. ; Patient: So I guess work. ; Patient: Things with my fiance, I mean, we're engaged, so planning the wedding. ; Patient: That's going really well. ; Patient: It's stressful, but it's going well. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: And all of your other university subjects? ; Patient: Yeah, I've never felt anything before. ; Patient: This is the first one, so I guess all the other subjects, yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah, yeah. ; Therapist: And you're succeeding in all of those things. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Put together. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: You're juggling it and it's a lot on your plate at the moment, but it sounds like you've been able to cope up until this point of the one exam. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: This one just threw me off balance. ; Patient: Yeah, just failing, yeah. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: So would you describe yourself as successful most of the time? ; Patient: Yeah, most of the time. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: And what's the evidence for that? ; Patient: Passing all my exams all the time. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: Just passing my subjects, not just exams. ; Therapist: Yeah, that's right. ; Patient: Getting that full-time job, it's a great job that I'm doing. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: You're getting married. ; Patient: Yeah, that's right. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: So how do all of those successes compare to that belief that I've written on the board for you? ; Patient: I guess in comparison, I am good enough. ; Therapist: Yeah, that's right. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And all the evidence is there. ; Therapist: All of the subjects that you've passed in first year and now second year. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: You're a full-time job. ; Therapist: That's a success. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: It's great. ; Therapist: Yeah, good. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Well, what I'd like to do is get you to write that on the board. ; Patient: All right. ; Therapist: To dispute that belief. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Would you do that? ; Patient: All right. ; Therapist: Well done, Marsha. ; Therapist: That's a powerful statement. ; Therapist: What kind of decision goes along with that? ; Patient: Staying at uni. ; Therapist: Good. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Write that on the board for us. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Great. ; Therapist: That's good. ; Therapist: Good. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So you've made a bit of a decision there, haven't you? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Tell me about it. ; Therapist: Does it feel okay? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I feel like I should stay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Why is that? ; Patient: I can try again. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: I mean, everything doesn't have to be 100% all the time. ; Therapist: Good, good. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: So, I mean, I could re-sit the exam. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Yeah, yeah. ; Therapist: And we've talked about all your successes. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So it's harder now to believe that top statement that I'm not good enough. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I mean, I am good enough compared to all the things that you helped me realize with all the successes that I've had. ; Therapist: That's right. ; Patient: I am good enough. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Good. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And so this idea about staying at uni, tell me about that. ; Patient: Yeah, I'll say. ; Patient: I mean, I am good enough, so I'm sure I can give it another go and see how I go from there. ; Patient: I can re-sit the exam and I'm sure I'll be fine. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Good. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: What I'd like you to do is to keep saying that statement, I am good enough. ; Therapist: Say it in front of the mirror two or three times a day so that you build up your confidence because it's going to take some time to reprogram your computer up here with that kind of positive belief about yourself rather than carrying around that other belief. ; Therapist: And we tend to carry those other beliefs for years and years and years, and so it's going to take a bit of work on your part to deliberately change your thinking and change your belief system. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: But you've made a great start here today, so congratulations. ; Patient: Thank you. ; Therapist: Bye.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name marsha; sex female; marital status engaged; occupation full time jobjob description not mentioned ; Clinical Identifiers: Setting opd ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Lack of confidence after failing an exam ; History: Patient reports that she recently failed an exam at her university which to her was quite important. Following this event she has lost confidence in herself and is unable to cope with the stress at work and took a decision to leave the university. With these complaints, she consulted the therapist no past, family or substance use history mentioned in the dialogue. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Nil ; Psychotherapy Type: Type cbt; mode individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Abc analysis, reflective listening, thought challenging, cognitive restructuring ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Identification of cognitive distortions and challenging faulty beliefs ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Nil ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Okay Charles, let's take a look at your homework from last week, the activity schedule. ; Patient: Not very much on it. ; Therapist: I'll take a look at it, let's see. ; Therapist: Well, you did complete most of it. ; Therapist: Okay, I don't see mastery ratings, but you have pleasure ratings for everything. ; Therapist: So that's good. ; Therapist: So let's see, you woke up at eight, you drank coffee and read the paper and you rated that as a two for pleasure. ; Therapist: You went to the grocery store, rated that as a three. ; Therapist: Let's see, at noon you ate a sandwich and watched TV and you rated that as a two for pleasure. ; Therapist: You took a nap and then the mail arrived and you looked at bills and you rated that as a two for pleasure. ; Therapist: You ate dinner at a Chinese place and rated that as a three and then you watched some more TV and rated that as a two. ; Therapist: Okay, so tell me about the mastery ratings, Charles. ; Therapist: What made it difficult to complete those? ; Patient: I don't see the point. ; Patient: And I mean, how do you master watching TV or eating a meal? ; Patient: If I had tried to use chopsticks, I suppose it would have some mastery involved in that. ; Patient: But I didn't mess with chopsticks. ; Patient: Food was okay, but not great. ; Therapist: So it was tough. ; Therapist: And I just want to be clear though, Charles, that this is very typical though for many people that we work with. ; Therapist: It's very difficult to complete homework worksheets because things happen, right? ; Therapist: I don't feel that well sometimes, things getting in the way. ; Therapist: There's things that just prevent me from doing that. ; Therapist: So I think our job together is to try to figure out what are the sort of barriers that make these sort of things difficult. ; Therapist: So what would you say, what would be some barriers that made it difficult to complete your mastery ratings? ; Patient: I don't enjoy anything. ; Patient: And I used to enjoy a lot of things. ; Patient: But I don't even look forward to breakfast particularly. ; Patient: A cup of coffee. ; Patient: The news is mostly bad if there is news. ; Patient: The paper doesn't carry much national news anymore. ; Patient: So I mean I have to eat, but I really don't see the point of a lot of things. ; Therapist: Okay, okay. ; Therapist: Well I think something that will be useful for both of us, Charles, is to collaboratively work together and figure out how we can look at the perceived benefit of doing some of these things versus the cons. ; Therapist: So there's a worksheet that I have called a decisional balance worksheet. ; Therapist: And it basically takes two separate decisions. ; Therapist: One decision is to engage in activities and there's some benefit to doing that. ; Therapist: And then another decision would be to not engage in activities. ; Therapist: There's benefit to that. ; Therapist: But there's also cost to both of those decisions. ; Therapist: So I think one objective way for you and I to look at this worksheet would be to determine what are the sort of things you could do and determine whether there's more benefit or cost to completing that. ; Therapist: What do you think about that? ; Patient: Okay, sure. ; Patient: That sounds okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So let's take a look at this decisional analysis and I'll explain it to you. ; Therapist: Okay, so here's the worksheet. ; Therapist: Here's a pen. ; Therapist: As you can see, Charles, there's four boxes. ; Therapist: And at the top of the boxes, there's one decision which is to change. ; Therapist: So it's the decision to engage in activities. ; Therapist: Well, if we're honest about it, there are benefits to doing that. ; Therapist: If you look at the right box, there's also cons and costs to doing that. ; Therapist: At the bottom of the worksheet, the other decision is to stay the same. ; Therapist: And if we're honest, there's benefits to staying the same. ; Therapist: Right? ; Therapist: But there's also cons or costs to staying the same in the right-hand box. ; Therapist: So our decision, our job together is to try to figure out which makes the most sense for you. ; Therapist: So let's start with the most obvious one and that would be to engage in activities since that's what we've been talking about. ; Therapist: So what would be some perceived benefit of engaging in certain activities to you? ; Patient: Well, that would depend on the activity, I know. ; Patient: But I could get in touch with somebody. ; Patient: I could call a friend, maybe try to meet somebody for lunch. ; Therapist: Okay, that's a great idea. ; Therapist: So what would be a benefit of calling a friend or meeting someone for lunch? ; Patient: Well, I would enjoy the company. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: And I wouldn't be as lonely, I suppose. ; Therapist: Okay, that sounds great. ; Therapist: So it sounds like one benefit would be you'd enjoy the company. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And you wouldn't be as lonely. ; Therapist: So I'd write that down. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Those are really good. ; Patient: Company. ; Therapist: Company. ; Therapist: And you said not as lonely. ; Patient: Not lonely. ; Therapist: That's good. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay, can you think of the downside to potentially doing that? ; Patient: Well, one downside might be that he wouldn't be interested in having lunch with me. ; Patient: I haven't been a whole lot of fun lately. ; Patient: Or he might be busy and might not be able to have lunch. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Or he might want to talk about what's going on in my life and I really don't want to talk about that with somebody. ; Patient: Talk about it with you, of course. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So it sounds like the most practical one of those would be that he may be busy. ; Therapist: That could be the downside is that he could be busy. ; Patient: Right, okay. ; Patient: Might not be able to come. ; Therapist: Sure. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So I'd write that. ; Therapist: So great job, Charles, with the top two boxes with the first decision. ; Therapist: So let's move to the second decision, which would be to stay the same. ; Therapist: And there's some benefit to that and there's some cost to that as well. ; Patient: Sure. ; Therapist: Okay, Charles, so we completed the worksheet. ; Therapist: So what's your overall impression about the benefits of changing versus the cons and staying the same? ; Patient: Well, it makes sure that the benefits outweigh the cons if I make the change. ; Patient: If I don't make the change, I'll be doing just what I've been doing and I'll be getting up wondering what's the point and will still be lonely. ; Patient: And if I do call somebody and if they do say sure, then I'd have at least some time with somebody else whose company I enjoy. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Those are good observations, Charles. ; Therapist: So which activity does it make the most sense to try for homework this week? ; Patient: Well, I called somebody, I think. ; Therapist: Okay, that's a good observation. ; Therapist: So let's say for homework, then you try to call someone to get together with a friend. ; Therapist: And how about also trying to complete a full day of the activity schedule and completing both the mastery and the pleasure ratings? ; Therapist: What do you think about that? ; Patient: Sure. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And if it gets difficult, which again, that's pretty normal for that to take place. ; Therapist: If it gets hard, we can talk about it next time and we can problem solve together and figure out how to remove those barriers. ; Therapist: Does that sound good? ; Patient: Sure. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name charles ; Past Session Information: Follow-up session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting complaints loneliness chief complaints 1 withdrawal 2 lack of motivation 3 difficulty in taking decision ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior depressed; speech normal, mood  affect, low ; Psychotherapy Type: Cbt; mode individual. ; Psychotherapy Technique : Thought challenging reflective listening ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Loneliness the client feels loneliness and isolation, which is a sign that she needs social connection. Therapist encourages the client to anticipate potential obstacles to activity engagement and offers support in problem-solving and developing coping strategies goal setting therapists helps patient to identify benefits of changing routine, engaging in activities in combating the feelings of loneliness. Homework  reaching out to a friend for social interaction and completing a daily activity schedule with mastery and pleasure ratings, promoting self-monitoring and accountability in the therapeutic process. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Depression ; Action Plan : Therapist planned for time to solve problem together and figure out how to remove the barriers

dialogue: Therapist: How are you doing today? ; Patient: Good, thanks. ; Patient: How are you? ; Therapist: I'm doing well. ; Therapist: Thanks for asking. ; Therapist: I understand you had some symptoms recently that have been bothering you. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Could you tell me about those? ; Patient: Yeah, probably for the last eight months, maybe a year even, I have this position at work where I have to make these weekly presentations and it's killing me. ; Patient: I can't do it anymore. ; Therapist: Tell me about how these presentations are set up. ; Patient: So it's the executive director and it's ten managers and we're kind of sitting in a circle and everybody goes around and does like a weekly program update. ; Patient: Five minutes or so, maybe ten at the most if there's an issue that kind of needs to be discussed. ; Patient: But everybody takes turns speaking and it goes around, kind of around in a circle. ; Patient: And depending on where you sit is what order you present in basically. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: And you say that this situation with the presentation, you said it's killing you. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: What do you have in it? ; Patient: I feel like it's constantly on my mind. ; Patient: I'm constantly worried about this presentation and even though I only have to speak for like five minutes, I'm so consumed by this part of my job that I can't do anything else. ; Patient: And I normally, I feel like I do good in my job but this. ; Patient: And it builds up more like every day. ; Patient: The day before is really bad because I'm prepping for the meeting and so it really starts to consume me then. ; Patient: I don't sleep the night before and then by the time I get to the meeting, I'm so anxious and so nervous. ; Patient: I'm panicking. ; Therapist: You're panicking. ; Patient: And I just can't. ; Patient: I just can't. ; Therapist: So this is distressing for you. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And this is probably difficult to talk about. ; Therapist: At the beginning of the meeting, what would be your anxiety level? ; Therapist: What's going on then? ; Patient: By the beginning of the meeting, when I've sat down, I feel like I'm breathing harder. ; Patient: I'm starting to sweat and I feel like my face is turning red. ; Patient: My palms are really sweaty. ; Patient: I'm constantly having to wipe them off on my pants. ; Patient: My heart is racing and I feel like, you know, the closer it gets to being my turn, I feel like everything just gets worse. ; Patient: I feel like I'm breathing harder and my heart is beating faster and louder. ; Patient: I feel like everybody can hear it. ; Patient: My stomach just gets in knots. ; Patient: I feel nauseous. ; Patient: There have been times that I've managed to just hold my hands still and just sit really still and I've tried some deep breathing and just sat and have made it through and have made it to my presentation and been able to speak. ; Patient: But even then when I speak, I stutter and I stammer over my words and I don't say everything I need to even though I have a cheat sheet essentially and I can read from it. ; Patient: I still feel like I'm missing things and I'm leaving things out. ; Patient: My voice doesn't project so I end up speaking very softly and like I said, I'm stuttering. ; Patient: I just can't get it even then, but it's still, I feel like it's still a mess. ; Therapist: So you're not happy with the quality of your presentation? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Even when you're able to kind of stay there and conduct it. ; Therapist: So I want to divide this into the stages. ; Therapist: So we talked about the very beginning. ; Therapist: So you're already having anxiety. ; Therapist: It sounds like it's fairly intense at that point. ; Therapist: Tell me about as they go around the table and give their brief presentations, tell me about what you're feeling as the presentations come around to you. ; Patient: Well, if I manage somehow to get there early enough and I can get an early enough seat like to sit like right next to my boss or like one or two away, then I'm actually pretty okay because I can kind of get it over and done. ; Patient: But so many times I'm so nervous and honestly a bit hungover because I've been drinking to try and I don't feel anxious when I drink. ; Patient: So there have been a lot of times that I've woken up a little bit late because I've been drinking and so by the time I get there, I'm like one of the last, it's one of the last seats, so I'm one of the last to go. ; Patient: And so as it gets closer and closer to me, I just feel more and more anxious and panicky and here in the, especially in the last few weeks, I've had to leave. ; Patient: I can stay. ; Patient: I've had to go. ; Therapist: So before the presentations come around to you, you get up and leave the room. ; Therapist: So in those times when you've stayed in the room and you've done the presentation, so the anxiety, the panic, the heart rate, the sweaty palms, all these symptoms are increasing as they go around the table or the room. ; Therapist: And when it comes to you actually giving your presentation, you're not happy with it, but what's your anxiety level like during your presentation? ; Patient: I feel like during the presentation, I feel almost like everything, it's like everything stops and then when it's done and it goes to whoever's next, it's like, it's almost like a physical sense of relief, like, okay, that's over and everything starts to relax and calm down, but then I feel miserable. ; Patient: I am so, so upset with how I performed that more than anybody else that, well, really that everybody is like, what is wrong with her, but that my boss especially is like, why did I give her this job again? ; Patient: And I feel so, so miserable that I feel like I've disappointed him and so I've disappointed me. ; Patient: And I mean, this has always, always happened to me for as long as I can remember. ; Patient: I've never been able to speak in front of groups. ; Patient: And from back in college, if I had to make a presentation, I would ask the teacher if there was a way out of it. ; Patient: And if they refused, then I wouldn't present. ; Patient: And I had a teacher who insisted that I make the presentation and I dropped the class and I took it again with a different teacher that wouldn't make me present because I couldn't do it. ; Patient: And high school was the same, that I would, you know, I just wouldn't do it. ; Patient: And actually, this is ridiculous. ; Patient: You know, I mentioned drinking. ; Patient: I've been drinking for a really long time. ; Patient: And when I was like, I don't know, like 13 or 14, I got busted for underage drinking and I had to do some like adolescent treatment and I had to do this like group therapy with these other kids and I couldn't do that. ; Patient: I bolted out of the room. ; Patient: And so I've never been able to do this, ever. ; Therapist: So you've had these symptoms for a long time. ; Therapist: They've been frustrating you for a long time. ; Therapist: How about periods of time where you haven't had to be in front of other people? ; Patient: Well, if I haven't had to be in front of other people, I've been kind of okay. ; Patient: You know, I can go to the movies, but I like to sit on the end. ; Patient: You know, I can go out with my family and my friends and we can go shopping, but I don't like to go to new places. ; Patient: I like to go kind of like the same places that I've been. ; Therapist: Familiar with them. ; Patient: Yeah, yeah. ; Patient: Because then I know them. ; Patient: You know, I know the layout of stores and things like that. ; Therapist: All right, so it interferes with your functioning maybe a little bit, but if you're not having to present, it's not as big a deal as it is now for you with this job. ; Therapist: This is really affecting you. ; Therapist: So are you taking any measures or have you taken any measures other than the drinking you mentioned to avoid the situation? ; Patient: Oh, definitely. ; Patient: I mean, there's, like I said, I mean, I've run out of the meetings. ; Patient: There's been times that I've called in sick when I haven't been. ; Patient: There's been times when I've said I've had car trouble, arrived so late that it was unreasonable to make my presentation. ; Patient: I've actually talked to my boss about possibly not doing the presentation and just giving my notes to him or to brief him before or after. ; Patient: Because I don't want to say that I have this problem. ; Patient: I mean, normal people don't do this, right? ; Patient: I mean, normal people can make these presentations. ; Patient: I mean, the rest of the staff can do it. ; Patient: Why can't I? ; Patient: And so I don't want to tell him that, you know, that there's something wrong with me. ; Patient: I mean, it's gotten to the point that I've talked to him about, you know, this other position that's in another department and transferring so that I won't have to do this anymore. ; Patient: And it would be a pay cut. ; Patient: I mean, it's a demotion. ; Patient: But I can't live like this. ; Therapist: This is too painful. ; Therapist: If you had the other job, this other job would involve presentations. ; Therapist: So you'd be happier. ; Therapist: You'd have fewer symptoms in that job. ; Therapist: What's been the result of that discussion? ; Therapist: Has there been anything that's happened as far as? ; Patient: Well, he's told me that he thinks I'm doing a good job. ; Patient: Excuse me. ; Patient: And he doesn't want me to change positions. ; Patient: But I can't do this anymore. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So you've tried to cope with anxiety. ; Therapist: You've had to leave, call in sick or come in late. ; Therapist: You've looked for a different position where it doesn't involve presenting. ; Therapist: You've had this problem in other circumstances, the group therapy and in presentations before. ; Therapist: Do you or have you seen any symptoms like this in your parents? ; Patient: Yeah, both of my parents and my sister actually. ; Patient: We would kind of joke about it sometimes that we all get so nervous. ; Patient: And my sister, I don't know how, but she managed to find a job where she doesn't interact with anybody. ; Patient: It's her in her office with her computer by herself. ; Patient: And it's just her. ; Patient: I don't know how she pulled it off. ; Patient: I mean, she hardly talks on the phone. ; Patient: And she's really happy. ; Patient: And my parents, they actually met in college. ; Patient: When my dad, after my mom made a presentation, my dad, I guess, leaned over and was like, you know, I could tell you were really nervous, but you did great. ; Patient: And they just, they seemed to bond over this nervousness that they both had. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So there may be a history, a family history of symptoms like these. ; Therapist: This is distressing for you. ; Therapist: You tried to avoid it and deal with it, but you haven't been, you don't feel you've been very successful coping with it. ; Therapist: We'll get you in for treatment. ; Therapist: We'll get you in the next couple of days to see a counselor, if that's what you'd like to do. ; Patient: Yes, please. ; Therapist: I think that could help. ; Therapist: And I want to thank you for spending this time with me. ; Therapist: It's really helped me to understand better what you're facing. ; Patient: Thank you. ; Therapist: Thanks, Sasha.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name sasha ; Past Session Information: Follow up session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms social anxiety chief anxiety 1 self dobut 2 negative thinking 3 dysfunctionality in daily life. ; History: Family history reports a family history of social anxiety. ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior anxious; speech fast, mood  affect low, thought fast n negative, cognitive functions poor, judgement poor. ; Psychotherapy Type: Cbt; mode individua ; Psychotherapy Technique : Thought challenging cognitive restructuring problem solving ; Issues discussed in Current Session: 1 social anxiety client experiences anxiety in social situations and has symptoms such as sweating, rapid heartbeat, and nausea which leads to avoidance behaviors. 2 perception feels self-doubt and compares herself with others. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Social anxiety

dialogue: Therapist: Hello, my name is Dr. Todd Brondet. ; Therapist: Welcome to part two in my series on clinical interviewing. ; Therapist: This is a role play exercise. ; Therapist: I'm here with Nell Kelly, a graduate assistant here at Wilmington University, and she'll be role playing the same character, Anne, in part two and all the parts of these videos. ; Therapist: So I want to remind you that this is just for educational purposes and your agency may have different requirements when it comes to what needs to be included in a clinical interview. ; Therapist: And remember, all clients are individuals, so you may need to add or subtract different elements to provide a ethical and appropriate clinical interview. ; Therapist: So I'll turn it over to Nell to introduce some of the elements you'll be seeing in part two. ; Patient: In this second section of the intake interview, Dr. Brondet will be eliciting information about the client's childhood, relationship history, and spirituality. ; Patient: Let's get started. ; Therapist: Okay, Anne, so I'm going to ask you some questions about your developmental history. ; Therapist: Some of these you might have already answered during the screening, but it's important that I capture them here as well. ; Therapist: What city and state were you born in? ; Patient: Wilmington, Delaware. ; Therapist: Okay, and how about what city and state were you raised in? ; Patient: Wellington, Delaware. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Do you speak any other languages other than English? ; Patient: Spanish. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Not fluently, pretty well. ; Therapist: Pretty well? ; Therapist: Can you tell me who raised you? ; Patient: My parents. ; Therapist: Your biological parents? ; Patient: My dad. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: At any point during childhood were you ever raised by anybody else temporarily? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No, okay. ; Patient: My grandmother lived with us for a little while, but we had like middle school through high school. ; Therapist: Can you tell me briefly what your life was like growing up? ; Patient: Yeah, it was pretty normal childhood I guess. ; Patient: My mom was, she was kind of angry, an angry person. ; Patient: But it was, you know, my two sisters and me and my parents. ; Patient: We didn't want for anything. ; Patient: My parents loved us pretty much. ; Patient: And you know, we went to good schools. ; Patient: My mom, you know, my mom was pretty angry. ; Patient: Well at least towards me. ; Therapist: Not so much toward you? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: I mean sometimes my sisters and my dad, she was like angry in general. ; Patient: I guess I got the most of it. ; Patient: I kind of think, I don't know, I was wondering if it was connected to my boss and the women at work. ; Patient: I don't know, that's kind of why I'm here. ; Patient: And it happened in the neighborhood too, the women in the neighborhood after we moved to this new neighborhood. ; Patient: And I'm really feeling like it's me and groups of women. ; Patient: And is there, I don't know, I don't know, you're the expert. ; Patient: But you asked me what my childhood was like. ; Patient: Like I can't complain. ; Patient: I wasn't like abused. ; Patient: Like I said, I was hit sometimes, but that was the way, I was hit more than my sisters for sure, was the oldest. ; Patient: My sisters were, I was the oldest. ; Patient: My middle sister was, I don't know, do you want this? ; Patient: Did I answer your question? ; Therapist: No, no, please go on. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: My sisters were perfect. ; Patient: You know, my middle sister was, you know, she always got good grades. ; Patient: She did exactly what my parents wanted. ; Patient: She was the one, like, she'd wake up by herself several hours before school started and get herself all ready, make herself breakfast, you know. ; Patient: And she was just always a good girl. ; Patient: And I mean, I wasn't a bad girl or anything, but I don't know. ; Therapist: So the family dynamic you're speaking about, when did that change? ; Therapist: Or has it changed? ; Therapist: It hasn't changed. ; Patient: I don't think so. ; Therapist: At what age did you move out of your home? ; Patient: College. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: She'd be around 19, something like that? ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: We talked about this a little bit earlier, about how your experiences when you were young, how were you disciplined as a child? ; Patient: You know, yelling. ; Patient: My mom yelled a lot. ; Patient: And like I said, she didn't hold back from, you know, smacking my face or pulling my hair or something like that. ; Patient: When I was younger, when I got older, she didn't do it as much. ; Patient: You know, I could kind of push her away. ; Patient: But it wasn't, you know, I don't know. ; Patient: Yeah, that was it. ; Patient: Or, you know, other than that. ; Therapist: How was your father? ; Patient: He was kind of quiet. ; Therapist: He didn't get involved in the discipline component? ; Patient: No, I mean, that was Mom. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: I want to move on now to relationship history. ; Therapist: I'm going to be switching gears a little bit again. ; Therapist: You mentioned that you're married. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Have you been married before? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: What's your sexual orientation? ; Patient: Heterosexual. ; Therapist: Heterosexual. ; Therapist: At what age did you get married? ; Patient: 27 ; Therapist: Can you describe your marriage to me? ; Patient: Yeah, it's happy. ; Therapist: Happy. ; Patient: It's a happy marriage. ; Patient: I mean, he gets concerned about me. ; Patient: You know, when I go through my sad periods or whatever. ; Patient: But no, it's basically a happy marriage. ; Patient: He's a good guy. ; Patient: I'm lucky. ; Therapist: Does he know that you're safe in council? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Is he supportive of that? ; Patient: Yeah, he, it was kind of his idea. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: At first. ; Patient: I thought he was right. ; Patient: I wanted to try it again. ; Therapist: At some point, and I don't know this yet, but at some point, if appropriate, would he be willing to come in for a session with you? ; Patient: Definitely. ; Therapist: Would you be okay with that? ; Patient: Yeah, sure. ; Therapist: Does your spouse have any trouble with any of the following? ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Substances, gambling, mental health, medical? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Nothing? ; Therapist: And how long have they been married? ; Patient: Um, fifteen years. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Can you tell me about any previous relationships you might have before marriage? ; Therapist: Like a boyfriend or something like that? ; Patient: Um, yeah. ; Patient: I had a pretty serious boyfriend in graduate school. ; Patient: And then in college, you know, I dated a couple guys. ; Patient: And in high school, I had one boyfriend through high school. ; Patient: But we broke up. ; Patient: And when we both went off to college. ; Therapist: So I'm going to switch now to parental history. ; Therapist: Do you have any children? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Son and a daughter. ; Therapist: Okay, son and daughter. ; Therapist: How old is your son? ; Patient: He's twelve. ; Therapist: And your daughter? ; Patient: Ten. ; Therapist: And where do they live? ; Therapist: Like with you? ; Patient: With my husband and me. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: How often do you see them? ; Patient: Every day. ; Therapist: Every day. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: Are there any substance use, mental health, or medical concerns regarding your children? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Have you ever been involved with child protective services? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And I think you mentioned earlier you never had a traumatic loss. ; Therapist: You haven't lost a child? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Can you describe your relationship with your children to me? ; Patient: Yeah, it's a good relationship. ; Therapist: Do you have any more? ; Patient: Um, well I, I try, I mean I said when I have kids I was not going to be like my mom. ; Patient: So I don't yell. ; Patient: And I don't let my husband yell at them. ; Patient: So, you know, my relationship with my kids is hugely important to me. ; Patient: And we always spend a lot of time as a family. ; Patient: We vacation together, we have family game nights. ; Patient: I help them with their homework. ; Patient: You know, toddler years were tough. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: They were, you know, that was challenging for us but we got through that. ; Therapist: Did they do well in school? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: They did? ; Patient: Yeah, on a roll. ; Therapist: Right? ; Therapist: Now you mentioned you have a daughter. ; Therapist: And I know you talked earlier about your relationship with your mother. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Do you see any of that, what happened there playing out between you and your daughter? ; Patient: Um, not really because I try so hard. ; Patient: I mean I get mad sometimes. ; Patient: I can feel myself flare up and, um, but, uh, I don't know. ; Patient: You know, I don't, I don't, I don't think so. ; Therapist: You don't think so? ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Anything else about your children you want to tell me? ; Patient: Um, well, a couple of years ago when I was kind of in one of these periods, um, my son's teacher, he was in second grade at the time and she said she was concerned about him that he was, um, kind of hanging out away from the other kids. ; Patient: Um, she thought he might be depressed, um, is what she said. ; Patient: So we took him to see somebody a couple times but, you know, he was okay. ; Therapist: He's okay now? ; Patient: He's okay now, yeah. ; Therapist: It had you worried a bit though? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: In the situation? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: I'm going to switch gears again. ; Therapist: Are you still comfortable moving forward? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: This concludes part two of my video series on clinical interviewing. ; Therapist: As always, I hope that you found my video useful. ; Therapist: If you have any questions or concerns, feel free to contact me. ; Therapist: I'll be happy to assist you. ; Therapist: At your convenience, I would encourage you to now move on to part three to watch the conclusion of the video series. ; Therapist: Thanks.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name nell kelly; age 42 years; sex female; education graduation; occupation assistant at university; marital status married ; Clinical Identifiers: Setting wilmington university ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Name dr. Todd brondet ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Nil ; History: Family history patients family consists of of two sisters and parents. She is the eldest born. She was more close with her father as she felt that her mother used to be angry most of the time. She is currently living with her husband and her two children. Her son is 12 years old and her daughter is 10 years old; personal history marital history- patient got married at the age of 27 years. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behaviour patient was cooperative and rapport could be established; mood calm; affect broad ; Psychotherapy Type: Nil ; Psychotherapy Technique : Nil ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Clinical interview was conducted to gather information about the patient. Major focus was on the family and personal history. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Nil ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Hi, Shari. ; Therapist: How you doing today? ; Patient: Great. ; Patient: How are you? ; Therapist: I'm doing well. ; Therapist: Thanks for asking. ; Patient: That's awesome. ; Therapist: So you're doing great? ; Patient: I am doing awesome. ; Therapist: I know your brother brought you in today and he had expressed some concerns about your ; Therapist: mood. ; Therapist: Do you know what that's about? ; Patient: I think he's worrying for no reason because I, you know, I, for the last like week and a half, I have been following my passion, which is baking. ; Patient: And I didn't realize this before because I worked in an office and I just realized that that's not what I want to do with my life. ; Patient: And I know what I want to do with my life now and I've never known before. ; Patient: So this is an amazing feeling. ; Patient: And what I want to do is I want to start my own baking business. ; Patient: So what happened was that a couple, like two weeks ago, my nephew had a bake sale and I've always, you know, I've always been like like baking, but I've always been like from the box or like from, you know, whatever. ; Patient: So I tried for the first time making brownies from scratch and they were amazing and everyone loved them at the bake sale and they sold out and my nephew thought I was a hero. ; Patient: Basically I was. ; Patient: And so now it made me realize like I could do this for a living and it would make me feel amazing and make me feel like a hero for all these people. ; Patient: And I live by a college campus, so it'd be kind of cool if I could like put up something about like delivering the bakery, like to dorms or like baked goods to dorms because you know college students love that type of thing. ; Patient: But so anyway, so I was thinking about, long story short, having this business and I would bake all these cookies and I'm just going to put up flyers because I don't, I'm not like at the point where I can get like an office space, but I don't need an office space because I have my apartment and I have everything I need in my apartment to bake everything I need. ; Patient: And I can also, I'm a BJ's membership, so I can go to BJ's and I can get everything I need in bulk, so like all the flour and butter and sugar and all that stuff. ; Patient: So it's not an issue if I just do it from my apartment. ; Patient: And so I was putting up flyers and trying to promote my business and that's what I've been working on for the last week and a half and I feel great and it's amazing. ; Patient: And that's basically it. ; Therapist: Alright, so you feel like everything's kind of going your way and you're really excited about the new business idea. ; Therapist: I know your brother was a little concerned with how much you've been spending on the business idea and he mentioned some things about different relationships you've had that are new. ; Patient: Okay, so there's a couple things with that. ; Patient: So with the spending, like I don't think my brother recognizes that when you start a business like you need to invest in it to begin. ; Patient: And I understand why he's worried because like, so at work, well at the office job that I had, I got in trouble because obviously you need to make flyers and I was like, oh he doesn't realize I'm frugal, I'm smart, so I was like I'll make the flyers at work and put them out at the work computer so that I'm not having to pay like wherever, like staples or something to go ahead and put them out for me. ; Patient: So I got in trouble because it was like for personal use and I was using the work whatever. ; Patient: But like that's what annoys me about my brother because like the new guy that I met, which is the other thing with the relationships, like this new guy is so supportive of my ideas. ; Patient: I met him actually in a bakery, which is like destiny, and he was so supportive when I told him about what I was planning and actually the other guy that I was talking to before, and I've been talking to him for a while, he was kind of like my brother and was like, are you sure this is something you want to do? ; Patient: And like I don't understand why you would say that to someone who's obviously sure of what they want to do. ; Patient: Like I know I can do it, I know that I'll be successful, like did they not taste the brownies at the bake sale? ; Patient: Like they were amazing. ; Patient: And so that's kind of where I am and that's why my brother's worried, but he shouldn't be because like I had all this planned out. ; Therapist: Alright, he's worried that you don't, one of the things was the new relationship that you don't know the guy too well. ; Patient: Well, I mean, I've hooked up with him a few times, like I know him pretty well and I don't think he understands like the connection that we have. ; Patient: Like it's a pretty strong one. ; Therapist: Alright, so your brother just doesn't, in your mind, he just doesn't get it. ; Patient: No, and like he doesn't like pay attention to me when I talk. ; Patient: Like I'll be trying to tell him about like the bake sale and, well not the bake sale, well a little bit about the bake sale, like I tried to tell him about how successful it was and he just thought that I was like bragging, but I wasn't. ; Patient: Like it was genuinely like a success. ; Patient: And then I tried to tell him about my business idea and like he's like trying to like brush it off like it's not a good idea and that's why. ; Patient: So he just doesn't listen to me, so sometimes I try not to talk to him about it. ; Therapist: Alright, have you noticed through all this any change in sleep patterns? ; Patient: I haven't been sleeping as much, but I think that's just because I'm so excited about this and like so I've been like staying up late and waking up early and like looking at recipes and honestly it hasn't really been an issue because I haven't been tired at all. ; Patient: I've really, yeah I haven't, I've felt rested. ; Patient: I get enough. ; Therapist: Alright, so you do feel rested. ; Therapist: But you haven't been sleeping as much. ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: And you clearly seem like you're in a good mood, no sadness or anything like that. ; Patient: No, like you're not going to have sadness when you're following your passion. ; Therapist: Alright, so you're doing pretty well that way. ; Therapist: Have you ever been down or depressed? ; Patient: Yeah, in the past I have been. ; Patient: Actually not too long ago, about four months ago, I was hospitalized because I was so down. ; Patient: But you know, and I don't feel like that now and I know what it feels like to be down and I don't have any of that stuff. ; Patient: Like I feel so much more hopeful and happy and just great with where my life is going right now. ; Therapist: Alright, do you ever feel this way before? ; Therapist: Kind of in a really good mood? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Nothing like this? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: So what do you think brought all this on? ; Patient: Honestly I just think it's like getting to know myself and getting to know like what I want to do which is this, you know, culinary arts. ; Therapist: It's kind of realizing that's kind of changed your life? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: For the better, like really for the better. ; Therapist: Alright, and you mentioned before that you got in some trouble at work, right? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: How bad did that turn out? ; Patient: Pretty bad. ; Patient: Like it was like a final written notice so if any little thing at this point could make me lose my job but I'm not too worried about it because at this point I'm putting so much time into the baking business that if something goes wrong with my like office job like I'll have this. ; Patient: Like in, I'm sure that in as short as a month like I'll be making money soon and a lot of money because I know how much time I'm going to be putting into this, how passionate I am about it and I know that like I'll be able to make the money back that I've put into it so I'm not worried about it. ; Therapist: Alright, but you're not too worried about that. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Any medical conditions you know of? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: How about drug and alcohol you say? ; Patient: No, I don't use anything like that. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Are you seeing or hearing anything that other people can't see or hear? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No, nothing like that? ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: Sherry, so I know that you're feeling pretty well but I would like you to see a counselor maybe help you as you contemplate these different things we've been talking about if you'd be okay with talking to a counselor. ; Patient: I guess I'd be fine. ; Therapist: You'd be okay with that? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: I'll get that set up. ; Therapist: It'll just take a moment and I want to thank you for answering my questions. ; Therapist: This has been helpful. ; Patient: You're welcome.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name shari; sex female; marital status unmarried ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Increased talkativeness 2. Increased goal-directed activity 3. Decreased need for sleep ; History: Present history patient was always fond of baking. Around two weeks ago she tried making some desserts which were later appreciated by his nephew and others. It boosted her confidence to change her career and plans to establish a business by opening a bakery near college campus for better sale. She also has been sleeping less without getting tired as she spends most of her time in her business idea; past history she was hospitalised around 4 months ago as she was experiencing low mood; personal history she recently got into trouble at her work as she was trying to promote her business at her workplace. She later got a notice warning her against losing her job. She is less bothered about it as she is completely indulged in planning for her bakery. She met a man who supported her idea and got into a romantic relationship with him soon after; substance use history she does not consume any psychoactive substance. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behavior patient was cooperative and rapport could be established; speech productivity- increased; mood elevated; affect broad; insight grade 1 ; Psychotherapy Type: Nil ; Psychotherapy Technique : Active listening ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patient was brought by her brother. She has been talking a lot than usual, been overly indulged in her business idea, sleeps less and spends time on the same but doesnt feel tired. She was admitted in a hospital earlier as she was experiencing a low mood. She discussed about her business idea in detail. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: F31. 1 bipolar affective disorder, current episode mania without psychotic symptoms ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Lisa, how are you doing today? ; Patient: I'm doing okay. ; Therapist: Did you make it here okay to the office? ; Patient: I did. ; Patient: Traffic wasn't too bad. ; Therapist: Good, good. ; Therapist: So I understand that you've come to see me because you have a situation. ; Patient: Yeah, I'm just been a lot of anxiety right now. ; Patient: My oldest child is moving out and I know as a mom that that's the goal is to let them be independent and start on their own but still a little concerned that it's going to work out and that he's in a good place and living where he should and going to eat dinner and do those things that you worry about them doing. ; Therapist: Okay, I'll try to help you with that. ; Therapist: I'm sure your year gets started. ; Patient: Absolutely. ; Patient: The sooner the better. ; Therapist: Good. ; Therapist: I want to make sure I go over a few disclosures about the counseling relationship before we get into assessment which is the first stage. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: We'll ask you a lot of questions. ; Patient: Alright. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: About your past and what's going on now and then after assessment we'll move into counseling. ; Therapist: So we'll come in roughly once a week. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And then we'll get through kind of a piece on confidentiality. ; Patient: Okay, so like attorneys what you can do and not do and... ; Therapist: Kind of. ; Therapist: I'm glad you brought that up about attorneys. ; Therapist: Attorneys and clients have confidentiality and counselors and clients have confidentiality but the two types are different. ; Therapist: So I'll explain to you how it will work between you and I but know that is a little bit different than it works between attorney and their client. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: Can you explain the differences to me? ; Therapist: Absolutely. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So you want to think about a counseling relationship all this time you spend here, the notes that I'll take during the assessment and the progress notes later on because I'll have a chart with your name on it and it will be stored in a secure place. ; Therapist: All that is confidential and next to that word confidential is an asterisk. ; Therapist: Right? ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: There's exceptions. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And what I'm saying to you are those exceptions to confidentiality because confidentiality isn't absolute. ; Patient: So there's times you might tell someone else something that I said? ; Therapist: Yes. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Yeah, but there are very specific situations that occur that permit that or mandate that. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And I want to review those with you before we move on. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Does that make sense? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I'd like to know that before I tell you anything. ; Therapist: I agree. ; Therapist: That's a good way to look at it. ; Therapist: So the first exception to confidentiality is when you give me permission to release information that you've disclosed and interactions we've had in counseling. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: This is actually fairly common. ; Therapist: For example, do you have a primary care physician? ; Patient: I do, yes. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: So depending on what we talk about, you may want him or her to know about our discussions. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And then you would have to sign a release that gives that physician the right to talk to me directly. ; Patient: That makes sense. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Furthermore, your issues with or part of your concern is with your son. ; Therapist: So say, and I don't necessarily foresee this, but say later on as we work together, you want him to come in for a session just to talk about something. ; Therapist: Right? ; Therapist: And then you would have to sign a release to that confidentiality so he could be here and talk with me. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Does that make sense? ; Patient: That makes a lot of sense. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: The other exceptions are you have an insurance company. ; Therapist: So when you fill out your screen packet, insurance companies have access to progress notes, the assessment, anything on the chart. ; Therapist: And they're generally responsible for this information. ; Therapist: I don't know of any instances where they're irresponsible with it. ; Therapist: But I just think it's important that you know that anything I write in the chart, anything in the chart itself, technically the insurance company can ask for it. ; Therapist: And periodically could review. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Again, I've never seen in my career any difficulty with that. ; Therapist: But I just want to let you know that information would be transmitted offsite, so to speak. ; Therapist: And when this agency bills, it would be transmitted, your information would be transmitted offsite to the insurance company. ; Patient: So it goes automatically, whatever progress notes you have automatically go to the insurance company? ; Therapist: The progress notes don't for standard billing, but information about the type of session we had, the length of the session, and some other personal information about you to identify, you would go to them. ; Patient: Oh, okay. ; Therapist: So they know a service was provided. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: But like I said, they're generally very responsible for that information. ; Therapist: Large companies have done this for a while. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: They get all your medical stuff too, so they have it up. ; Therapist: They have access to a lot of different types of data. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Another exception to confidentiality, and again, I don't foresee necessarily any of this happening, but I want to tell you about the limits of it, is in the event that I feel that you're going to harm, or there's a high potential that you're going to harm yourself or someone else. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: In that instance, I'm obligated to act. ; Therapist: Now we're going to probably talk about a lot of different elements of your life through the next however many weeks we're together. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: When, and if, and again, I don't predict this, you have some sort of suicidal ideation or you want to harm somebody else. ; Therapist: In the unlikely event that happens, I would only release the information I have to release to protect you or the person that I'm worried about that you might harm. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So if you reveal a lot of like deep, dark secrets, and then you tell me that you want to go harm a relative of yours, right? ; Therapist: I have a duty to warn that relative of what you plan on doing, where you are at the moment, what threats you've made, but I'm certainly not going to tell them about your deepest darkest secrets you revealed. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Unless they're directly relevant to protecting them. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: That's very unlikely they would be. ; Patient: I'm not planning on hurting anybody, but we should be good. ; Therapist: I know. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: I know that this confidentiality, the information I release, is limited to just what I need to release. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Similarly, if you have any type of suicidal ideation and I had to contact somebody to come pick you up, like law enforcement, I would only tell them what I needed to tell them for them to get you to the hospital and get you in a safe environment. ; Therapist: This I want to take an opportunity to talk about the suicidal ideation to let you know that just because you have suicidal ideation, like thoughts, a lot of people think about suicide from time to time, or even homicidal ideation or thoughts you're going to harm someone, not necessarily you're going to kill, but it's harm, does not by any means automatically mean I'm going to call the police. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Think of it as something that opens a discussion, certainly, about your safety and someone else's safety, but that's not, we don't go automatically from there, that is, if you have any thoughts, suicide to the hospital. ; Therapist: There's a discussion and many, most, the vast majority actually of people that have suicidal ideation do not have any intent or plan to commit suicide. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Does that make sense? ; Patient: So you say, so if someone's thinking about it, you are not just going to call the police and send you to the hospital, you're going to try to get to the bottom of it first. ; Therapist: Absolutely. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: That, you know, I have a responsibility to make sure you're safe and I feel like I can do that if we talk through an issue and you don't have any, you don't have any reason to believe you're going to harm yourself, but just have a suicidal thought. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: That's a lot different than you came into me and told me about a detailed plan and you really seem like you're going to do it, then I'd be a lot more worried. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: That makes sense. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So that exception of confidentiality is really used in the most extreme cases of suicidal ideation. ; Therapist: Another exception in this state that I want to let you know about is if I have any reason to believe that a child or an elderly person is being abused, I have to report it. ; Therapist: It's called a mandated reporter. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Now I'm sure that you're not abusing and it's older than anyone. ; Patient: No, I'm not abusing anyone. ; Therapist: Or elderly people. ; Therapist: But I want to explain how this exception works because it's a little more far reaching than you may think. ; Therapist: So say that you come in and you discuss with me a neighbor that seemingly has nothing to do with your treatment. ; Therapist: I just casually mention that something's going on and that discussion leads me to believe that your neighbor's abusing their child. ; Therapist: I still have to report that. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Even though it has really nothing to do with you directly, it's something you just told me in passing, I'd have to act on it. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And again, I would only release the information necessary to protect that child's safety. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Does that make sense? ; Patient: It does, yes. ; Therapist: So no matter how I find out about it or who it is, I have to act on that. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And then the last exception I want to review is, again, as with many of these, very unlikely. ; Therapist: But if for some reason you're involved in a type of civil or criminal litigation and a judge orders me to testify, I have to testify. ; Therapist: I can tell you this happens very rarely, but it can happen. ; Therapist: And I can and will try not to disclose. ; Therapist: I'll ask the judge to not disclose if you don't want me to. ; Therapist: But ultimately a judge can't order me and I have to. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So in the end it's up to the judge. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: I understand that. ; Therapist: So again, most of these pretty unlikely. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: But I'd rather you have all the information going forward so you don't have any concerns about where the information you're revealing or talking about, where the information is going. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Do you have any questions about that? ; Patient: I don't think so. ; Patient: It seems pretty clear. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Well, I appreciate you sitting through that talk on confidentiality. ; Therapist: So we're going to get started now with the assessment. ; Patient: Okay.
