summary: Patient Particulars : Name lisa, ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms anxiety chief complaints 1 stress 2 anxiety ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior nad; speech nad, mood  affect anxious, thought negative, perception, cognitive functions fair, judgement and insight intact ; Psychotherapy Type: Cbt; mode individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Reflective listening ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Themes discussed in the session 1 problem patient feels anxiety due to her oldest child moving out 2 counseling process the counsellor provides support and reassurance. Also, it includes the initial assessment phase, ongoing weekly sessions, and the goal of addressing anxiety. 3 details about therapy therapist explained about confidentiality e. G. , permission from the client, risk of harm, abuse, legal obligations. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Anxiety ; Action Plan : Staring assessment

dialogue: Therapist: Liz, how are you? ; Patient: Good. ; Therapist: Good. ; Therapist: It's good to see you. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Again, your binge record this week is the last week as well. ; Therapist: It's like kind of squeaky clean. ; Therapist: So how's it been feeling? ; Patient: Feels really good. ; Therapist: I'm sure it does. ; Therapist: It really does. ; Therapist: Yeah, it's been really a process. ; Therapist: So that's fantastic. ; Therapist: Tell me about what's been going on this week. ; Patient: I had a good conversation with my mom. ; Therapist: Oh, nice. ; Patient: Yes, so it feels good. ; Therapist: Tell me about it. ; Patient: We, so I just talked with her on the phone. ; Patient: And yeah, it just went really well. ; Patient: And we actually, after that, we planned a Skype meeting. ; Patient: So we had a Skype meeting last night, I guess it was. ; Patient: And yeah, caught up a little bit and kind of talked about some things. ; Therapist: Great. ; Therapist: Oh, nice. ; Therapist: Nice. ; Therapist: I'm happy to hear about that. ; Therapist: And I don't remember, I'm trying to think from last time, like any Alan updates or? ; Patient: Still seeing Alan. ; Therapist: Oh, nice. ; Therapist: Nice. ; Therapist: Things going OK? ; Therapist: Good. ; Therapist: Well, I'm happy to hear that. ; Therapist: And then I guess the other thing that I wanted to talk with you about, I know that we kind of had mentioned it briefly, but today kind of marks the kind of beginning of that kind of final phase for us. ; Therapist: So then over the next three sessions, we're going to be starting to kind of wrap up our work together. ; Therapist: And yeah, I've been feeling that way too, because it's hard to want to bring that up, because it's been really just great working with you. ; Therapist: And so I really don't want to see that come to an end. ; Therapist: But I thought one of the things that's really important is maybe just to get us starting to talk about, and again, we don't have to do it all today, but just at least get us starting to talk about some of the changes that you've made, things that have gone really well for you, and really maybe kind of recap how it is that you've gone from almost like binging daily to almost now you're not at all. ; Therapist: And maybe we can kind of talk about how that's gone. ; Therapist: Because I think the other thing that's really important is not only the things that you've done in terms of how things have gotten better for you, but I also want us to start thinking about too, like, OK, what's going to happen when we kind of get to the end of our work together and beyond? ; Therapist: So in terms of how you will kind of keep the work going. ; Therapist: And so I kind of thought, I feel like I'm kind of being like a wet blanket here. ; Therapist: You've had a really great week, and now I'm bringing up our kind of departure. ; Therapist: But I think it's really important to kind of mark that and mark that transition, and also to mark it too by having things go so well. ; Therapist: I think it's really important. ; Therapist: And I guess the first thing I want to talk about is I guess I'm pointing my pad of paper, because it's like it's so filled with just all the different things that have occurred for you over the last several weeks. ; Therapist: And I think the first thing that's really notable to me is I really have really appreciated your willingness to engage your mom, because I know that that's been so hard for you, and it's been so painful, the way that she's treated you in the past. ; Therapist: But that I guess I'm even getting kind of emotional talking about it, because it's just been so rich, the transition you've made in terms of the way you've engaged her in a more genuine way and allowed her kind of back into your life. ; Therapist: And it seems like that that's been really vital to your getting better. ; Therapist: So what's, in terms of like from your perspective, kind of what's that been like for you, kind of emotionally? ; Patient: And it feels good. ; Patient: It's nice not butting heads with her. ; Therapist: Yeah, I'm sure. ; Patient: I want a good relationship with my mom. ; Patient: I don't choose purposefully to not have a good relationship with her. ; Patient: Yeah, it feels really good. ; Patient: And I feel like I can have better relationships other places as well now, because that's healthy. ; Therapist: Right, right. ; Therapist: And also too, I think along with that is that kind of the strategies I think that you've, my hunch would be is that some of the strategies that you've used to engage your mom in a more meaningful way have really kind of come in handy in some respects in terms of like some of the other relationships that you've had. ; Therapist: Especially I know that you and Kathy have gotten a lot closer, and even the fact that you've allowed yourself to kind of connect with somebody else, like with Alan. ; Therapist: I know that you were talking with me the other day about some other friends that you've met and people that you've really gotten a little bit closer to. ; Therapist: So that's been really exciting. ; Therapist: Yeah, yeah, yeah. ; Patient: It feels good to not go home and feel terrible. ; Therapist: Right, yeah, yeah. ; Therapist: So then kind of from your perspective again, we'll talk more about this. ; Therapist: I mean, I realize I'm kind of putting you on the spot, but as you've kind of have thought about it or thinking about it, and maybe you can think about it too even from now into the next couple of sessions, but just starting to think about like what is it that you've really done that you really feel like it's been really, that's really helped you make changes in the way in which you've managed your food or your binge eating? ; Patient: I mean, just really trying to be more positive within my relationships and being more open and communicating, not keeping things in. ; Patient: I feel like when I kept things in, it kind of boiled up and that's what made me want to use something that made me feel better. ; Therapist: Right, right. ; Patient: And that, yeah, I mean like if something bothers me to like immediately express it instead of holding it in. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: You know, I've noticed that as well and it seems like that that's been one of the important things that you've done that's really helped with the changes that you've made. ; Therapist: What else feels like that? ; Therapist: I mean, obviously that's been really important, but what are the other things that you've noticed in terms of like how it's been going? ; Patient: I feel better about myself and like not having comments from my mom anymore and having a guy in my life who really likes how I look and yeah, just yeah, feeling happier with myself and grades are good. ; Therapist: Yeah, I know, you know, things like we're really in a good space. ; Therapist: And I think the other thing too I was aware of that we, you know, that you had mentioned to me in particular last time was that, and I didn't get a chance really to talk with you as much about it because I think we had so much to talk about last session, but I was really struck by the fact that you, it seems like you haven't been as body conscious as you have been in the past and I didn't know if you've noticed that. ; Patient: Yeah, I know. ; Patient: I feel like I've noticed, like a little bit noticed it, yeah, especially that you bring it up. ; Patient: It's true. ; Therapist: Yeah, because I know like initially and even like there have been times even along the way when you'll make like, you know, I didn't feel like it looked very good or I felt like something felt really tight on me or, you know, I just felt like that other people were looking at me or maybe judging me. ; Therapist: But it seems like that as we've kind of moved along that there's really been, I've really noticed a real kind of a little bit of a shift in the way in which you've kind of been regarding yourself and it seems like it's been a little bit different. ; Patient: And not hearing like any comments at all from my mom about any of that stuff or I feel like I've gotten to the point where I'm not concerned like that I'm going to hear a comment either. ; Therapist: Right, right. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay, so I'm going to go ahead and make you talk about it anyway, but what did you do in order to be able to get those comments though to stop? ; Therapist: Because obviously I think you did something really significant with her. ; Patient: Yes. ; Patient: I mean I thought about what you said about really acknowledging that that put a lot of pain on me and stress and weight and yeah, no, I was able to let her know that. ; Patient: It was hard. ; Patient: I was scared to tell her that, but I mean she recognized that. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: And yeah, she kind of explained how she thought that she was helping me or she wanted me to have a lot of friends in high school. ; Therapist: Right, right. ; Patient: And that's what she, I mean she kind of said like her mom said the same thing to her. ; Therapist: Right, right. ; Therapist: Yeah, yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah, well you know and that's really not uncommon when you have, it's funny that just even like, not to be a big research head, but it seems like that that's pretty consistent that kind of like mothers to daughters who become mothers to daughters, like sometimes it's kind of what we call this intergenerational transmission of like kind of criticality about shape and weight. ; Therapist: And so I'm really proud of you that you kind of had the courage to address it with her directly and just let her know how you feel. ; Therapist: Because I think as a parent I know that you always, I always want to try to do the right thing and I always, I don't purposely want to try to inflict pain on my children even though my daughters would suggest that I probably do. ; Therapist: But in general I don't, that's not my goal is to be harsh and critical. ; Therapist: In fact, I really always try to really be helpful. ; Therapist: I think most parents try to do the right thing, but I, and I think maybe your mom just didn't realize the degree to which that really bothered you and how much that hurt. ; Therapist: And in many respects how much that kind of really drove you to really take it out on yourself so to speak. ; Therapist: And so for you to have the courage to bring that up I think was really helpful. ; Therapist: Yeah, yeah. ; Therapist: So I really think that that made a lot of differences as well as kind of reaching out to others and again, just the open expression of your feelings. ; Therapist: So yeah. ; Therapist: So yeah, I think the things that we're doing like now I think I'd really like to see us kind of continue to, you know, obviously you still are doing a lot of really good work in terms of like the things that you're talking about. ; Therapist: But yet I am also aware that as we're over the next couple sessions we can kind of keep doing a few of these things kind of wrapping up. ; Therapist: And then our last session we can more or less kind of formally say goodbye and talk about kind of like what the next steps are and some things that you might want to be paying attention to or things you might want to be mindful of. ; Therapist: But we'll get there. ; Therapist: So yeah. ; Therapist: Great. ; Therapist: Great.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name liz, sex female ; Past Session Information: Follow -up ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Final phase of therapy, issues have resolved. ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior happy; speech normal, mood  affect good, thought positive, judgement and insight intact ; Psychotherapy Type: Cbt; mode individual. ; Psychotherapy Technique : Supportive ; Issues discussed in Current Session: 1improvement patient feels improvement in relationship dynamics, developed healthy boundaries with her mothers critical comments about her body, enhanced self-image and confidence and learned effective communication strategies. 2journey in therapy it involves introspection and self-discovery, gained deeper understanding of herself and cultivates self-awareness, which facilitates positive changes in her life. 3towards termination the session is in the final phase of therapy where both discussed the therapeutic journey and a preparation for the transition beyond therapy. ; Action Plan : Prepared for the last session in therapy. .

dialogue: Therapist: Any other evidence that points toward you being an imposter? ; Patient: Besides my bad grade that I got that one time. ; Patient: Not a whole lot. ; Therapist: So it would be safe to say that a lot of that thought of I'm not good enough is kind of based on these feelings of anxiety. ; Patient: Which are really intense, like panic almost in the moment. ; Therapist: So in a way, you're believing what the anxiety would lead you to believe. ; Patient: Yeah, definitely. ; Therapist: But in the bright light of scrutiny, there aren't a lot of facts to support the worst case which is you don't deserve it. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: How about evidence that refutes that you're not good enough? ; Patient: I would say that, you know, I was accepted into the program. ; Patient: Like there's kind of like a pretty rigorous sort of testing and stuff which I passed to get in interviews and such to get into the program. ; Patient: So I did that. ; Patient: Like I said, I'm a pretty good student all considering, you know, before this kind of like was happening. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So you got through a rigorous process to become a student, you're doing well. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: You mentioned before just the one bad grade, right? ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So if, you know, you have friends in this program, right? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: If one of them came to you with this balance of, you know, one bad grade and some anxiety versus passing, you know, rigorous standards and doing well otherwise, what advice would you give them? ; Patient: I mean now that you're kind of like talking about it like a, you know, this or that sort of thing, it makes sense I would probably say that, well, you seem to be doing pretty well so far, you know, that anyone evaluating would look at all of the cumulative how you're doing your performance rather than that of weight. ; Therapist: Would you feel comfortable giving advice to yourself? ; Patient: I think I try to sometimes, but my anxiety symptoms kind of like really like you were saying your anxiety tells you sort of, I think I can think that, but I think my anxiety symptoms are such in the moment that it's really hard, you know, and I'm replaying what happened before in my head, anticipation, predicting that it will happen again. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So let's look at the thought and the feeling. ; Therapist: If you had to rate the percentage that you believed, this thought, this belief that you are not good enough to be in the program, like right now. ; Patient: Right now. ; Therapist: So if you're here with me, how much of your mind believes that that's true? ; Patient: I would say like, you know, a two or a three, like not very, I don't believe it very much right now because, you know, I'm not presenting and it's just you and I, not like a group full of people. ; Patient: So that's, that pressure is not there here. ; Therapist: So right now you're really not buying the idea that you're not good enough? ; Patient: Yeah, correct. ; Therapist: To be in the program. ; Therapist: So now let's move to, let's say right in the, near the end of like presentation when that anxiety is there and the classmates, they could be looking at you, they could be negatively evaluating you, like that's what you're worried about. ; Therapist: How much do you believe, believe that thought then? ; Patient: I want to feel really confident in that moment. ; Patient: It feels very real. ; Patient: Like like any moment they're going to kick me out. ; Patient: Like I'm like, I'm just not doing well. ; Therapist: It's that bad. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Really intense. ; Therapist: So would you, would you think that you were a more accurate evaluator of what's true or not now or when you're in that state of anxiety? ; Patient: Definitely now. ; Patient: Now when that anxiety and that, you know, heart rate and sweating is not there. ; Therapist: So this evaluation, the percent that you believe that thought is true, this evaluation is more accurate? ; Patient: Yes, I think so. ; Therapist: And how much time in any given day would you spend kind of in a mood you're in now where you can evaluate accurately? ; Patient: I would say, you know, when I'm not at risk of presenting, like I feel like I spend the majority of my time, like it's not something I worry about all the time just leading up to and then mostly that day. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So the, so you're able to evaluate the way you are now the vast majority of the time. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: There's a limited amount of time when you're not, when there's a lot of emotions going through. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: And in those times you're maybe a little less reliable. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: Like my judgment is clouded. ; Therapist: However in that moment you still, those beliefs are strong, right? ; Patient: Yes. ; Patient: Buried. ; Therapist: And troubling. ; Therapist: Even though it's a small percentage, it's intense and you kind of carry that around with you a little bit. ; Patient: Yeah, exactly. ; Therapist: So I can see how this is frustrating for you. ; Patient: Right.
summary: Past Session Information: Follow -up ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms anxiety chief complaints 1 emotional instability 2 self-doubt 3 cognitive distortions ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior anxious; speech fast, mood  affect low, thought negative, perception, cognitive functions distorted, judgement poor. ; Psychotherapy Type: Cbt; mode individual. ; Psychotherapy Technique : Reflective listening thought challenging ; Issues discussed in Current Session: 1 problem patient experiences inadequate and doubting his abilities. He feels anxious and insecure where its difficult to distinguish between rational evaluation and emotional responses. 2 perception patient struggles with intrusive doubts and negative self-talk during heightened anxiety which impacts his emotional well-being and self-perception. 3 awareness patient has self-awareness and insight into his thought processes. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Anxiety

dialogue: Therapist: How are you doing today? ; Patient: I'm doing okay. ; Therapist: Doing okay? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: What's been going on? ; Patient: Well nothing too bad. ; Patient: I kind of got in a little bit of a bender bender accident. ; Therapist: A car accident? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: What happened? ; Patient: Well, we were at a stop sign and there was one car here, another car here, and then I was here, another car was coming up behind me, and then they hit me and then I hit the car in front of me. ; Therapist: Oh. ; Patient: I kind of, you know, just the usual- Rock back and forth. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: But other than that you're okay? ; Patient: No, they're- ; Patient: I got a couple, you know, little bruises from like hitting the steering wheel. ; Patient: I'm like, yeah, but I'm okay. ; Patient: My body's okay. ; Therapist: So physically you feel okay? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Were you like checked out by your physician or anything? ; Patient: Yeah, everything's okay here. ; Patient: I didn't break anything or pull anything or anything. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Emotionally? ; Patient: It's been kind of hard to like get in my car again afterwards. ; Patient: Like I've still been going to work and everything, but like I realized last night, like my boyfriend was like, oh, do you want to go on a trip this weekend? ; Patient: And I was kind of like, maybe not. ; Patient: Like I'm kind of like hesitant to get back in the car. ; Patient: So when he said that about the trip, what was the thought that came in your mind? ; Patient: I'm going to get hurt. ; Therapist: So it was really all about the car? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: It wasn't anything else about the trip? ; Patient: No, it was being in the car, driving the car. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: And your thought was you're going to get hurt? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I'm going to get hit, I'm going to get hurt. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Any other areas that disrupted that trip? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So you normally would have went on a trip? ; Patient: Oh, definitely. ; Patient: I was kind of excited about it. ; Patient: But now I'm just like, no, I don't know. ; Patient: Or even like coming here, I was like, well, maybe I can reschedule. ; Patient: Like I was just like, oh, I don't want to drive. ; Patient: I don't want to be behind the wheel. ; Patient: I don't want to drive. ; Patient: And like when I did drive, I was fine coming. ; Patient: Like I drove the way I normally do, but I was a little bit more aware. ; Patient: But I wasn't driving extra slow. ; Patient: I wasn't driving extra fast or anything. ; Patient: But like I was checking a lot more. ; Therapist: But very nervous. ; Patient: Much more nervous than usual. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: How did you feel about driving cars prior to this accident? ; Patient: I was fine. ; Patient: I mean, whenever like my friends would go anywhere, I would always volunteer to drive. ; Patient: Like I enjoyed driving. ; Patient: I liked listening to the radio. ; Patient: You know, I liked my family and I always went on trips. ; Patient: And like as soon as I turned 16, like I always had a turn. ; Patient: I enjoyed it. ; Patient: I liked going on drives, just looking around. ; Patient: But now I don't, too scared. ; Patient: It doesn't even come in my mind anymore as like a thing I would want to do. ; Patient: If I can avoid it, I will. ; Therapist: So you're taking every opportunity to avoid driving. ; Therapist: So far getting like here today and getting to work, essential functions you've been able to do. ; Patient: Yeah, it takes me a while to actually, like okay, like I have to. ; Patient: And then I just kind of do. ; Therapist: So what do you tell yourself to motivate yourself to get into the car? ; Therapist: Like to come here today for instance? ; Patient: Well, it takes me, I have to kind of think about it for a long time. ; Patient: But I mean, I'm very nervous. ; Patient: I mean, I don't, I can't really think of what I tell myself. ; Patient: It just kind of happens. ; Therapist: And when you get in the car, like when you kind of work past that nervousness to get in the car, how do you feel then? ; Patient: Still pretty scared. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah, I'm, you know, I'm pretty scared throughout the whole thing. ; Patient: I'm, you know, I'm always worried that like if I can go away that I know that doesn't have any stop lights, I'll try to go that way. ; Patient: Even if it takes me an extra half hour. ; Therapist: Oh, that long. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Well, how about now? ; Therapist: Like you've driven here. ; Therapist: I presume you're going to drive your own car to wherever you're going next. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So does that kind of generate those same feelings and nervousness? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Like you just reminded me of that. ; Patient: Like, oh no. ; Therapist: You could feel it. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So this is, this is disturbing for you. ; Therapist: This is painful for you. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: It's scary. ; Therapist: But it hasn't yet infringed on a crucial area of functioning like your job or something. ; Patient: Not yet. ; Therapist: But you're worried it might. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So prior to this car accident, how many car accidents have you been in? ; Patient: Maybe one small little thing, but this is the worst one I've been in. ; Therapist: The other one didn't bother you like this one did? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: How long ago was the other one? ; Patient: Maybe like four or five years ago. ; Therapist: Were you hurting that? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Were you driving? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So something about this one has triggered this nervousness. ; Therapist: The other one didn't. ; Therapist: What do you think is going on? ; Therapist: I don't know. ; Patient: This one it was different because I was by myself. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: It was rainy, so maybe that, it wasn't, and it wasn't the other before, but. ; Therapist: So it was raining in the recent accident. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: And I was by myself, and then the other one I had somebody with me. ; Therapist: So this one maybe, I don't know. ; Therapist: Did the driver that hit you tell you what happened? ; Therapist: Like why they? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: They just, they kind of, they left pretty quickly afterwards actually, and I was just kind of left to deal with it. ; Therapist: Before the police got there? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Really? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So this really shook you up. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And your worries can interfere with other areas. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So your thinking is that you're going to get hurt, you're going to get hit if you get into a car again. ; Therapist: And you're thinking it before you get into a car and really. ; Patient: During, and even after it still kind of feels like, I don't know, even though I'm not in the car anymore I'm still like, kind of worried about it. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: And it's really worried about another accident. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So let's look at that. ; Therapist: You were wearing your seatbelt. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: And you were driving, it was a little rainy. ; Therapist: Was it day or night? ; Patient: It was like five. ; Patient: It was getting ready to be dark but it wasn't dark yet. ; Patient: It wasn't dark, it was still daytime. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So what you're nervous about driving, I mean driving does carry risk. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: So I can't tell you that there's a way to completely eliminate risk with driving a car. ; Patient: Yes. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: And you know this. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Having just been in an accident. ; Therapist: But there are certainly things you can do to minimize the risks. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: What do you think some of those things are you could do? ; Patient: Always wearing my seatbelt is pretty good. ; Therapist: Good idea. ; Patient: Well, I mean like I said, I try to go ways that don't have stop signs for stop lights, which is hard but... ; Therapist: That's difficult. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And I'm not sure that would really reduce the risk because you're driving longer. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So you'd have to look at that case by case. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: But I see your point. ; Therapist: What else? ; Therapist: Oh, I don't know. ; Patient: Drive when there aren't cars around. ; Therapist: What's that? ; Patient: Drive when there aren't other cars around. ; Patient: Which again, probably is a good idea but it would be hard to practically implement, right? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Because you're driving to work in rush hour and driving home in rush hour. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So what about driving habits that you can use? ; Patient: Make sure I don't go too fast or too slow. ; Patient: Make sure that I have space around my car. ; Patient: Make sure all my lights are working, things like that. ; Patient: Make sure I don't have gas so I don't run out of gas or have to stop or something like that. ; Therapist: So follow all applicable traffic laws. ; Therapist: Keep aware of your environment. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Right? ; Therapist: You can do things that will not eliminate but will reduce the risk of an accident. ; Therapist: Now you were hit while at a red light, right? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: That one, of course, the seat belt would be helpful. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Have a car that has airbags maybe? ; Therapist: Certainly the safety of your vehicle, right? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: A vehicle that's safer than average would be more ideal. ; Therapist: Ultimately, I think it's a good idea to be safe, to be aware, to do your best to minimize risk. ; Therapist: And at the same time recognize that you can't eliminate it. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: So there's going to be a point where we have to really work through this nervousness. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: It's probably actually, I mean, in a way, you're looking around more. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: But ultimately, it's probably going to hinder your life. ; Patient: Probably. ; Therapist: Right? ; Therapist: Because you're restricting where you go and all that. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And eventually, if it gets in the way of getting to work. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Or you might lose my job or my boyfriend wasn't very happy when I said I didn't want to go. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Yeah, so you don't want it to interfere anymore. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So what can you tell yourself? ; Therapist: We talked about automatic thoughts, right? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Like I'm going to get in an accident, which really that's one of the automatic thoughts. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: What are some of the adaptive responses that you could apply when that thought comes in? ; Therapist: Right, so the adaptive response is that self-talk, that message that you say to yourself. ; Therapist: What can you say to yourself? ; Patient: Like I'm doing everything I can to make sure that I'm safe. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: Like I might not be able to prevent getting hit, but I can maybe, like at least maybe I will get hurt. ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: You can take every precaution. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Like it's going to be okay. ; Patient: Like I don't know. ; Patient: Like you're safe, you're okay, it's okay. ; Patient: Like okay, they stopped like just to try to, like if I see somebody coming behind me and they, I'm still worried about it, like noticing that they did stop and reassuring myself that it's going to be okay. ; Patient: Yeah, it's hard because it's still, you know, fresh. ; Therapist: Yeah, it's, yeah, thoughts are strong and you believe them and you believe that you're going to get hurt. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: It's very real to you. ; Therapist: And still there's always that possibility, so as I mentioned, you can't eliminate the ; Patient: risk. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: So maybe one way to look at this is that you've only been in one other accident. ; Therapist: How many trips have you taken in your life in a car? ; Patient: Like a lot. ; Patient: I don't know, too many to count. ; Therapist: So it's, so the accidents are low probability events. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Scary, certainly, definitely not fun. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: But they haven't happened too often considering the number of trips you've taken. ; Patient: That's true. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: So another thing you could do is another adaptive response would be that I'm about to drive a car and there is an element of risk, but statistically. ; Patient: You probably won't get an accident compared to all the other times I've driven and not been in an accident. ; Therapist: Yeah, you probably won't. ; Patient: Yeah, that's true. ; Therapist: And you can reduce the risk by... ; Patient: Being careful. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So, there's a part that you can, of this anxiety, I guess, that you can satisfy. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Meaning you could say, well, I can really reduce the risks and I know my chances are low in any particular one drive. ; Therapist: But there's another part of this that you, of this you kind of have to accept, which is you could be an accident. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: And that's not what you want and you'll do your best to avoid it, but that could still happen. ; Therapist: Do you feel like, because I know this is all very fresh with the accident being recent, do you feel like you can apply those adaptive responses when you identify an automatic drop coming in? ; Patient: I can try. ; Patient: I mean, like I can think of the times where they've come into my head and they're like, oh, no. ; Patient: And then when I realize I'm getting ready to think that, I'll be like, well, actually, it's going to be okay. ; Patient: And I can try. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So, I'd like to give you some homework. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Around this anxiety. ; Therapist: We talked about the thought record, which is like where you fill out the back thought and how much it distresses you. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: In this case, it might be good to know what it's preventing you from doing. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Because your thoughts actually stopping you from. ; Therapist: Yeah, going anywhere. ; Therapist: Part of the functioning. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And then you also put the adaptive response that you applied, like what you're able to ; Therapist: say to yourself. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And then how you felt after that. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So, what we hope is by repeatedly using the thought record and applying the adaptive response, that we'll see improvement. ; Therapist: Because the way of measuring, it's therapeutic, but it's also a way of measuring how well you're dealing with it. ; Patient: Sure. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So, that's kind of, you know, there's the attacking that automatic thought, disputing that automatic thought piece to this. ; Therapist: And then there's kind of the acceptance piece of it. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: So, there's that low but definite probability of an accident. ; Therapist: You have to kind of accept that. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: At some level. ; Therapist: And you have to pay with that. ; Therapist: And then the rest of it, you know, would be acknowledging that the probability is low, and that's good, and that you're likely not to get into an accident. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Do you feel like you can complete a few thought records between now and the next session? ; Patient: Yeah, I think so. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So, let's do that. ; Therapist: If you feel like that's something you can be all right with. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Let's meet again in a week. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And if you can have, say, two thought records. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So, if that's two times and the thought came up, and then you've seen the thought record, you fill in each column. ; Therapist: And then we'll review that, and we'll see, you know, over the next few weeks if we can decrease these symptoms of nervousness and worry. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: That'd be good. ; Therapist: That'd be all right? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Thanks, Rebecca, and I'll see you in a week. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Bye. ; Patient: Bye. ; Therapist: Bye.
summary: Patient Particulars : Nil ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Agency ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting complaint substance use chief complaint 1 fear to go to rehab 2 difficulty in stopping substance use 3 anxiety ; History: Nil ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior anxious; speech understandable; mood  affect anxious and sad; thought and perception; normal; , cognitive functions; there is no impairment, judgement and insight intact ; Psychotherapy Type: Dynamicsupportive; mode individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Supportive and problem solving based. ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: There are few issues discussed in the session  1. Current issue patient discusses and acknowledges the recent arrest for driving under the influence of alcohol and marijuana. 2. Awareness of the problem patients understands the negative consequences of their substance use, including legal issues. 3. Resistance towards treatment and change  there is a resistance to stop substance abuse as it is helpful to reduce pain and to alleviate anxiety, also he is unsure if he can succeed or if he truly wants to stop. He is reluctant to go to rehab and seeking treatment from there. 4. Reasons for substance use alcohol and marijuana helps in pain relief and forgetting his problems about problems. Drinking with friends on weekends is also a reason for not quitting. 5. Exploring solutions the therapist explores the possibility of reducing substance use and avoiding risky behaviors to improve the individuals legal situation. Patients also taking this incident as a potential opportunity to re-evaluate his substance use and consider making positive changes. 9. Action plan discussed about the upcoming court hearings and explore strategies for managing substance use and improving their mindset before the next session. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Substance abuse and depressed mood ; Action Plan : Discussed about the upcoming court hearings and explore strategies for managing substance use and about improving the mindset before the next session. ; Next session details: Second week

dialogue: Therapist: Well Mr. Smith that's your medication sorted out. ; Therapist: Blood pressure is a little on the high side. ; Therapist: I wonder if I could raise the subject of your weight. ; Patient: What? ; Therapist: I wondered if we could spend just a couple of minutes talking about your weight. ; Patient: You are joking aren't you? ; Patient: I mean look I've made time in my day to come here. ; Patient: I'm kept in your waiting room for 45 minutes. ; Patient: It's not acceptable. ; Patient: If I make an appointment with a client for 10 I expect them to start at 10 not quarter to 11. ; Therapist: Right and so you're busy enough. ; Patient: Yeah I've got other things to do. ; Patient: I've got counts to do. ; Patient: I've got clients that are coming in. ; Therapist: And it wasn't necessarily easy for you to make the time to come down and you had to wait in the waiting room and now I raise the subject of weight. ; Patient: Yeah I mean okay fair enough I've got to have my blood pressure medication change but I really haven't got time to talk about my weight. ; Patient: I mean you know I'm aware of my weight. ; Patient: I'm aware of the problems and I'm also aware of the solutions. ; Patient: So I don't really need a discussion. ; Patient: It's just I've got too much to do at the moment you know. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: It's been a bit of a rush for you coming in. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And I'm sorry about the weight in the waiting room. ; Patient: It's bad form you know. ; Therapist: Yeah that's not easy for you because you'd like to go really soon and here I am asking you to spend just a couple of minutes with me. ; Patient: Yeah but basically I've got things to do. ; Patient: I've got to get back to the office. ; Patient: I've got a pile of work that I've got to deal with. ; Patient: And every time every moment out of my day means I have to work in the evening or weekends. ; Therapist: It counts. ; Patient: Or when you're self-employed you haven't got a choice. ; Therapist: Exactly. ; Therapist: Exactly. ; Therapist: It's up to you. ; Therapist: Just a couple of minutes. ; Patient: Well I'm here now so yeah okay if it's a couple of minutes yeah. ; Therapist: I promise. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: I really must get on. ; Therapist: I want to simply ask you how you feel about it. ; Patient: About what? ; Patient: Losing weight? ; Patient: Well obviously I want to. ; Patient: Yeah I mean who doesn't? ; Patient: I mean I'm aware that I'm over my balance weight but I know that it's causing problems. ; Patient: I mean obviously I get out of breath if I have to do something about how I realize that I'm on this blood pressure. ; Patient: And maybe that's probably contributing to it. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: So you can see the links between your weight and your health and you'd like things to be a bit better. ; Patient: Yeah I mean there are other things but I mean yeah the weight is something I would like to get hold of. ; Patient: You'd get on, get on the handle. ; Therapist: You'd like to if you could. ; Patient: Yeah I mean I know the theories of a bit of exercise on a regular basis, a balanced diet but unfortunately because of my lifestyle, because of being self-employed as an accountant it's finding the time to exercise but also finding the time to sort of think okay I'm going to go shopping for this, that and the other. ; Patient: I'm going to prepare a meal. ; Patient: With me it's very often ready meals and that sort of thing. ; Patient: Yeah food on the run, you know, grazing. ; Therapist: Let me see if I can summarize what you've said and then we'll see what next. ; Therapist: You lead a busy life. ; Therapist: You run a business and you've got a lot to do. ; Therapist: You're aware of the links between your health and your weight and you are concerned to some extent about that and ideally it sounds like you'd like to do something about it. ; Therapist: It's just that your life is busy and rushed and you tend to use convenience foods in order to get the work done. ; Patient: Yeah I mean to a certain extent because of my lifestyle food is just fuel. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: You know because I'm juggling all these balls and I don't want to drop any. ; Therapist: I get it, I get it. ; Therapist: And so if you could fit it in you would like things to be different but that's not so easy. ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Can I suggest that you come back and see me in a couple of weeks time just to chat about this? ; Patient: Okay, I'm up for that but it's going to be the same problem of A finding time and B if I make an appointment I don't expect to be kept waiting for half an hour or whatever because it's... ; Therapist: Exactly. ; Therapist: I'll tell you what might be a nice solution is if you come down first appointment and I give you an appointment at 8.30. ; Patient: That'd be good. ; Therapist: Then there'll be absolutely no waiting. ; Therapist: And the purpose of that visit will be to have a look at how you really feel about how you could move forward and somehow fit in a more healthier lifestyle into the busy work life that you've got. ; Patient: I'll maybe have a look at my schedules, see whether anything can be arranged or I can pass something on to some... ; Patient: And so it's not a wasted interview. ; Patient: So I can come here and say okay I've looked at my schedules, I've looked at things. ; Therapist: Good. ; Patient: Whatever. ; Therapist: Good. ; Therapist: So give some thought to what we've talked about. ; Patient: Yeah, of course. ; Patient: Good stuff. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Okay, thanks. ; Patient: Sorry I went off a bit.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name mr smith; sex male ; Clinical Identifiers: Setting opd ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Follow up ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Increased body weight 2. Hypertension ; History: Present history patient leads a busy life due to his self employment due to which he relies on convenience food for his meals which has been affecting his body weight; medical history hypertension ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behaviour patient was angry due to waiting time; speech productivity- increased; mood angry; affect restricted ; Psychotherapy Type: Person centered therapy; mode individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Active listening ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patient has been facing difficulty with his weight and blood pressure due to their linkage being directly affected by an unhealthy lifestyle. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Nil ; Action Plan : Patient has to think for some adjustments in his schedule to have a healthy lifestyle ; Next session details: After a couple of weeks at 830

dialogue: Therapist: Hi, this is Dr. Grande. ; Therapist: I hope you find this video useful. ; Therapist: If that's the case, please like it and subscribe to my channel. ; Therapist: As always, thanks for watching. ; Therapist: So can you think of another case you're working on, another family different than the one that we've initially talked about, where you've made a decision that seemed like it was fairly clear cut, like one you would have made before, and yet you're thinking about it, replaying it? ; Patient: Yeah, I had this case recently where it's a single dad. ; Patient: The mom passed away, and I go in and check on him and his son, and things are going well, but I think the dad has a hard time, so it's not like it was before when the mom was there. ; Patient: I wasn't there before that, but you can just tell that things are a little different. ; Patient: Obviously my decision is that things are going well for the kid. ; Patient: He's going to stay there, and dad is stable, but I just worry, like, is the dad under too much stress? ; Patient: Is he really taking care of the kid as good as, you know, what if he's just cleaning up the house and doing the right things while I'm there? ; Patient: While I'm not there, you know, does he have the energy to take care of his kid? ; Patient: Is everything really the way it appears, or is there more going on? ; Patient: I just don't know. ; Therapist: All right, so you're handling it to the best of your ability, but there's still these thoughts that are coming up, kind of encouraging you to second guess your judgment. ; Patient: Yeah, and it's like I can't let it go. ; Patient: I saw him two weeks ago, and I still wonder, and I have other cases like that. ; Patient: It's like they're all running through my head, and I have these thoughts like, did I do the right thing? ; Patient: Then I do the right thing. ; Therapist: Maybe what if the worst happens? ; Patient: And I didn't see it. ; Patient: Like, what if something terrible happens, and I should have known better? ; Therapist: So it speaks back to your competency as a professional again. ; Therapist: So that seems to be kind of core of this. ; Therapist: A lot of things you, or several things you talk about seem to connect back to, are you capable to be in this field, and should you be trusted? ; Patient: Yeah, definitely. ; Therapist: So on the, kind of moving back to thinking, there are errors in thinking that all people make. ; Therapist: And when these errors become repetitive, and you can kind of see them applied in more than one area of somebody's life, we refer to that as a cognitive distortion. ; Therapist: It's not bad or good, it's just how people think. ; Therapist: It's just patterns that people fall into. ; Therapist: And there are several different cognitive distortions, there are several patterns that we kind of see come up often in this work, as a counselor. ; Therapist: I'm wondering, in this situation where you're thinking the worst possible outcome is unbearable, or likely, or both, if you may be really focusing and emphasizing on that to the exclusion of other evidence that suggests you made a good decision. ; Therapist: So you're really focused on the negative outcome, the worst possible, and maybe even unlikely outcome. ; Therapist: And maybe not weighing all the evidence with the same weight, like you're putting more weight on the negative. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Does that kind of make sense? ; Patient: Yeah, I mean, I think that that's probably true, because before I felt fine, and now I just feel like everything's falling apart, and not that much has changed, and so it kind of makes me think that that's probably what's going on. ; Patient: But I don't know how to change that. ; Therapist: This is frustrating for you. ; Therapist: This self-doubt and this worry.
summary: Therapist Information : Name grande ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms anxiety chief complaints 1 frustration 2 fear for worst outcome 3 self doubt ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behavior cooperative; speech, mood  affect, thought catastrophizing, cognitive functions distorted, judgement poor ; Psychotherapy Type: Cbt; mode individual. ; Psychotherapy Technique : Supportive ; Issues discussed in Current Session: 1 problem patient feels that the constant worry and self-doubt are affecting their mental state and professional confidence. Patient feels stress, frustration and tends to be second-guessing decisions every time. 2 exploration therapist is trying to explore cognitive distortions, such as catastrophizing. Therapist is trying to reassurance and strategies his thoughts to improve his confidence in his professional decisions ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Anxiety

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Kyle, how are you doing today? ; Patient: I'm doing alright. ; Patient: I'm not doing too bad. ; Patient: How are you Dr. Grande? ; Therapist: Not bad, thanks for asking. ; Therapist: What brings you in? ; Patient: So my girlfriend saw your ad in the paper and she saw out of some of the things that you work on, one of them is smoking cessation and it bothers her that I smoke. ; Patient: So she has been nagging me for like weeks to come in and talk to you. ; Patient: So I figured I would just kind of come in just so she would stop bugging me about it. ; Therapist: So you came into therapy today because your girlfriend pressured you? ; Patient: Yeah, I mean it's easier for me like if I come in here and talk to you, I can spend like 45 minutes with you compared to hours of her nagging me through the week. ; Therapist: So you weighed the cost benefit and decided to come in? ; Patient: Yeah, I mean it's covered by insurance, it's just 45 minutes of my time. ; Therapist: And what she would like you to do, and this is her goal, not yours, would be to stop smoking. ; Therapist: Tell me what your goal is. ; Patient: I mean I don't really have one. ; Patient: I don't think smoking is that bad. ; Patient: Well I mean I don't know, smoking could be bad but it's never bothered me. ; Patient: I don't know, I really don't have any goals to come in besides just having her stop bugging me. ; Therapist: So do you have a goal of quitting smoking? ; Patient: No, not at all. ; Patient: There's so many good things about smoking. ; Patient: What really got me into it was I smoke a lot at work because it gives me one-on-one time with the boss. ; Patient: So the fact that I can get that time with my boss is completely worth it. ; Therapist: Can you tell me about some of the other good things about smoking? ; Patient: It's just like, it's how I meet people. ; Patient: So like if I, I'll have cigarettes on me but I don't have a lighter and that kind of keeps me from finishing off a pack. ; Patient: Because I could finish off a pack a day. ; Patient: But if I don't have a lighter then I carry the cigarettes around with me and then if I see other people are smoking I can go and ask for a light. ; Patient: And that's always kind of like a way in to get to these groups. ; Patient: I've just met so many different people from smoking. ; Patient: So smoking, the way you're presenting it, has been a positive thing in your life? ; Patient: Yeah, I mean I only do it socially. ; Patient: So that's, yeah. ; Therapist: Are there any negative aspects to smoking? ; Patient: I mean yeah, I mean everyone knows smoking is unhealthy but like I don't, I don't smoke a lot. ; Patient: Like I only smoke from time to time and it's mostly just on the weekends. ; Patient: So it's like, I don't know, occasionally if I smoke over the weekends I might have like a cough maybe. ; Patient: Like a heavy cough on Mondays, Tuesdays, it's gone by Wednesdays so it's not really that big of a deal. ; Therapist: So you don't seem like you're too worried about the negative aspects. ; Patient: No, I mean like the, obviously it's unhealthy but like one of the things I'm trying to do in my life now is get out there and meet new people. ; Patient: And like the benefit of being able to do that smoking is better than like giving it up for health reasons I think. ; Therapist: So let me ask you a question. ; Therapist: I want you to give me a response between one and ten. ; Therapist: This is called scaling. ; Therapist: And it's to do with the importance of stopping smoking. ; Therapist: So one would be it's not important to you and ten would be it's extremely important to you. ; Therapist: Where do you think you'd put that number? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: Maybe like a two. ; Patient: Like it'd be cool to get rid of the cough on Mondays but that, getting rid of that is not worth everything else I get from smoking. ; Therapist: So not particularly important? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Now let me ask you the same question except instead of importance, how confident, we're talking about confidence, how confident are you that you could quit smoking? ; Therapist: On a scale of one to ten with one being not confident at all and ten being extremely confident. ; Patient: I could say probably like an eight or a nine. ; Patient: Like I could give it up. ; Patient: Actually I gave it up recently like for like a month and I didn't even crave it. ; Patient: But eventually like just seeing all my friends go out smoking, like I missed that so I just started up again. ; Patient: But I don't know. ; Patient: Like if I really wanted to give it up for good I'm sure I could. ; Therapist: So stopping smoking is not important to you but you're fairly confident you could if you decided to do it. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So based on kind of where you are in terms of it doesn't seem like you're interested in stopping smoking, what would be a goal? ; Therapist: How could we spend this time so that it would be productive? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: Like I guess it would help to be able to like explain to my girlfriend like the stuff that I get from smoking. ; Patient: And like you seem, you kind of seem like you get it. ; Patient: So like I don't know maybe figure out ways to like explain to her the things that I get from smoking to like I don't know just kind of help her like realize why I do it other than just to kill myself. ; Therapist: So to help her to understand why the smoking works for you. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So that's one goal. ; Therapist: Any other goals you could think of? ; Therapist: I mean you came in in part because, well it seemed like you came in completely because your girlfriend pressured you. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So any other relational goals you might want to work on there? ; Patient: Um, I don't know. ; Patient: We haven't really been, like we've been fighting a lot because of the smoking. ; Patient: Um, so I think like maybe figuring out ways, I don't know, like to maybe communicate better or like having like good fights in a way. ; Patient: Like I don't know how to describe that but like having fights that are productive like that just don't always end like with us just like going our separate ways or like one of us leaving the house. ; Patient: But like I guess being able to like wrap up a fight so it doesn't last for like days. ; Therapist: So productive communication and productive arguments. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: So one goal would be to illustrate clearly the advantages of smoking to your girlfriend. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: So she understands how important it is to you. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Because it does seem like it's really important to you. ; Therapist: But another would be to work on your relation, your relational style so that you can end the argument and feel like you're not a stalemate. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah, I think that would be cool. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: Well, you want to make those the goals we work on so we can spend this time productive fast? ; Patient: Yeah, I can deal with that. ; Patient: It's kind of like killing two birds with one stone. ; Therapist: Does that make sense to you? ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Well, that's what we'll do. ; Therapist: So what I'd like you to do, I'll see you again in about a week. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: So if you could reflect on some of these changes that you think you can make with this relationship, what you could do in the relationship to be a more effective communicator. ; Therapist: Because a lot of this revolves around communication, right? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Communicating the advantages of smoking but also communicating and the arguing so that you have a productive end to these arguments. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: So really more moving from arguments to collegial conversations that have a positive result. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah, that would be cool if we could do that. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So if you could work on kind of thinking that through and then next time we meet we'll talk about those different goals and maybe ways to make some small changes in that relationship to meet those goals. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: Alright. ; Patient: Sounds good. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: Thanks for coming in, Kyle. ; Patient: Yeah, thank you.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name ann; sex female; marital status married ; Clinical Identifiers: Setting opd ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Name dr grande ; Past Session Information: Follow up session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Desire to take percocet drug 2. Difficulty in controlling intake of drug 3. Tolerance of dosage of the drug 4. Difficulty sustaining concentration ; History: Present history patient has been seeking treatment from last 6 months to quit on her drug consuming habit; past history she used to indulge in gambling; substance use history she has been taking percocet drug. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: General behavior rapport was established and patient was cooperative; mood anxious; affect restricted; thought content reflected stress about quitting the drug and reduced confidence; judgement personal judgement was impaired. ; Psychotherapy Type: Type supportive psychotherapy; mode of therapy individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Encouragement, active listening, empathy ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patient expressed her inability to concentrate well on her work. She also feels shameful knowing that her co-workers might have started noticing her drug intake. dialogue: Therapist: Hi Jackie, how are you doing today? ; Patient: I'm okay, how about you? ; Therapist: I'm doing well, thanks for asking. ; Therapist: I understand you've been having some difficulties recently that have brought you into the agency. ; Patient: Yeah, I'm recently married, and so my husband and I moved in together, and up until then I've lived by myself my whole adult life. ; Patient: So apparently the craziest things have been happening while I've been sleeping. ; Patient: Several nights I've woken him up screaming, I'm screaming. ; Patient: Apparently very vulgar, profanity words. ; Patient: So that's a little alarming to him. ; Patient: And I've even been hitting him in the middle of the night. ; Patient: He's waking up with these huge bruises on his arms. ; Patient: So yeah, apparently my behavior in the middle of the night is a little out of hand. ; Therapist: So I can understand why that would be distressing. ; Therapist: Have you seen a physician about this? ; Patient: Yes, I participated in a sleep study. ; Therapist: What did they say? ; Patient: They ruled out some other things and thought that maybe it was a behavior sleep disorder. ; Patient: So they referred me to you. ; Patient: I'm still working with them, they're still running some tests and everything. ; Patient: But they thought maybe there were some other stressors or underlying things. ; Therapist: That might be going on? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: So what would you like from counseling? ; Therapist: What would a goal be? ; Patient: Well, I'm just a little worried that it's going to affect my marriage and that my husband will not be able to deal with it. ; Patient: So I would just really like to figure out how to keep my relationship with him successful with it. ; Patient: And overcome these issues. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So after you were yelling things or you hit him, like you're asleep during this time, when you wake up, what's going through your mind then? ; Patient: Usually I wake up and he's like, what are you doing? ; Patient: I was having the worst dream. ; Patient: So those dreams are kind of what he's telling me are aligning what my behavior is. ; Patient: My dreams are aligning with those. ; Patient: So I don't feel anything. ; Patient: It doesn't feel like I've been doing anything. ; Patient: I have fallen out of bed a couple times and woken up, but no people do that. ; Patient: So I didn't really think anything of it. ; Therapist: But now you're starting to wonder. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: It's a little strange. ; Patient: It's a little concerning. ; Therapist: You're starting to wonder if you didn't have this disorder before. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I mean, I wouldn't have known. ; Patient: I've lived by myself. ; Patient: But before I had fallen out of bed a couple times and my sheets and pillows are always everywhere when I wake up. ; Patient: But I didn't really think anything of it. ; Patient: So I'm kind of making the connections now. ; Therapist: So he's been paying attention to what's going on with your sleep. ; Therapist: Does the episode of yelling or moving around, does it happen in a certain time limit? ; Therapist: Does it happen right after you go to sleep or a while after you go to sleep? ; Patient: In the middle of the night, he said at first he thought I was joking around. ; Patient: But yeah, in the middle of the night I'm just waking him up. ; Therapist: Does it ever happen when you take a nap, like a short nap? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: It's never happened then. ; Patient: Not that I know of anyway. ; Patient: He's usually around when I'm on the couch napping and he says it hasn't happened then. ; Therapist: So only at night when you're sleeping overnight and in the middle of that sleep. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Would you be okay with signing a lease so I can communicate with your physician? ; Patient: Of course. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And do you want your husband to be part of the counseling? ; Patient: Yeah, that would probably be helpful for him to come in. ; Patient: He can get his side of things too. ; Therapist: And you'd be okay signing a lease for him? ; Patient: Yes, yes, of course. ; Therapist: So I'll get you scheduled in to see a counselor. ; Therapist: I appreciate you telling me what's going on. ; Therapist: It's been helpful. ; Patient: Thank you.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name jackie; sex female; marital status married ; Clinical Identifiers: Setting counseling agency ; Referral Information : Referred by physician; reason for referral sleep disorder ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Episodes of screaming and hitting in sleep 2. Having no memory of these episodes ; History: Present history patient recently got married and started living with her husband where it was found that she wakes up every night and starts behaving indifferent. She screams, yells, hits her husband and also abuses him. Many times it has happened that her husband gets bruised due to the same. She had been living alone for a long time and so never realised that it has been happening to her. She remembered having her sheets pillows were always disorganised whenever she woke up but didnt pay attention to it that time. She consulted a physician recently where is a part of a study for behavioral sleep disorder. She was referred to seek counseling simultaneously to understand stressors or reasons behind. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behavior patient was cooperative and rapport could be established; mood calm; affect broad. ; Psychotherapy Type: Nil ; Psychotherapy Technique : Nil ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patients behavior after sleeping were discussed. She often wakes up at night and acts indifferently by screaming abuses and hitting her husband. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Nil ; Action Plan : To include her husband in the therapy and also work in liaison with her physician. ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Patient: So I'd like to talk about being cognitively active. ; Patient: So you're retired now. ; Patient: What did you used to do? ; Therapist: I was a nurse for 44 years. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: And presumably that kept you very busy. ; Therapist: It did. ; Therapist: It did. ; Therapist: It wasn't just that. ; Therapist: I had five children and I helped my husband run a post office. ; Therapist: So I was working a 70 hour week in those days because I did two nights night duty. ; Therapist: They were 12 hour shifts separated and then I worked in the shop. ; Therapist: So for five years I did that. ; Therapist: So that was, you know, and looked after the children in the house and that. ; Patient: And do you do any, now that you've retired, do you do any voluntary work or anything else? ; Therapist: Yeah, I've got involved with things around the church with visiting the housebound and taking them out and things like that. ; Therapist: And I still, and one of my daughters decided to get me a job as a transport passenger assistant for special needs on the mini buses that go around needs. ; Therapist: So they were desperate for them and she said, you'd be good at that mum. ; Therapist: So that was, she signed me up cause she was the manager. ; Therapist: So I did that until I was 77. ; Therapist: And I also did the 11 weeks of the stewarding for the ABRSM music exams. ; Patient: Would you say that keeping busy is important to you? ; Therapist: Well I'm just a busy person. ; Therapist: So it just comes natural to me. ; Therapist: I can't sit really for long. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: And have you always been like that? ; Therapist: Yes. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: Yes. ; Patient: Do you have a lot of social support? ; Therapist: Yes I do. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Well even more so now, now that the children have press ganged me into Facebook and WhatsApp. ; Therapist: Wow. ; Therapist: I mean it's just, it's just full on around the world, you know. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: You're international friends. ; Therapist: Yes. ; Therapist: Yes. ; Therapist: Yes. ; Patient: And I believe that you are an Airbnb host. ; Therapist: Yes I do. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So the world comes to me that way. ; Patient: Excellent. ; Patient: And you enjoy that. ; Therapist: And then I'm Facebook friends when they go home apparently in China and Brazil and Rome. ; Patient: Any invitations to visit? ; Therapist: Yes. ; Therapist: Yes. ; Therapist: Brazil. ; Therapist: Yes. ; Patient: Wow. ; Patient: And you said you've got grandchildren. ; Therapist: And great grandchildren. ; Patient: And great grandchildren. Do you think that intergenerational contact is a good thing? ; Therapist: Very important. ; Patient: Why? ; Therapist: Because you, when you're busy bringing up children you haven't time to see the world ; Therapist: through their eyes or even really listen to them because you're too busy and preoccupied. ; Therapist: But then grandchildren come along and more importantly now great grandchildren and seeing the world fresh through these new eyes is just, it's quite mind blowing actually. ; Therapist: So I've learned a lot. ; Therapist: In the old days grandchildren used to learn at their grandparents knee. ; Therapist: But nowadays it's the grandparents learning at the grandchildren's knees now. ; Patient: Oh, do you think? ; Therapist: Definitely. ; Therapist: Oh yes. ; Therapist: Yes. ; Patient: And do you think that it also benefits them to spend time with people of different generations, different ages? ; Therapist: Well, as I said, they don't use age, you see, which is very releasing because, well, it just is, you know, after my generation, the way I was brought up to be seen and not heard and to sit in the parlour with all these old people. ; Therapist: And now, well, you're going around flipping parks, you know, the adventure things and they're saying, come on the slide with us and all this, you know, which I do. ; Therapist: Which I do. ; Therapist: I don't turn anything down. ; Therapist: That's the secret. ; Patient: Not turn anything down. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: I say yes, yes. ; Patient: Good philosophy. ; Therapist: Except drugs. ; Therapist: Try everything once. ; Therapist: Try everything once. ; Patient: What's your view on nutrition and kind of, you know, having a so-called healthy diet? ; Therapist: I think the younger generation stress on it too much, far too much. ; Therapist: When you think that if my generation are living to be 100 and we were brought up with dripping sandwiches, meat with marbling in, etc, etc, full cream milk, all the rest of it, why get stressed out? ; Therapist: You know, just eat everything in moderation and enjoy life for goodness sake. ; Patient: I like that philosophy. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: How do you minimise the effects of stress? ; Patient: Do you have any, you know, did you have any techniques or if something stressful happens, is there anything particular that you do? ; Therapist: Gin and tonic or wine. ; Patient: Okay, yeah. ; Therapist: I've got a very good thing. ; Therapist: If I'm really cross with somebody and I'd really like to speak my mind to them, I'm very good at writing letters. ; Therapist: I don't send the letter to them, but I do write it down and get it out of my system and I keep it in a drawer in case one day I might need to plonk it down in front of them. ; Therapist: But it's, you know, it's off, it's out of my head. ; Therapist: And if I need to go to the doctor about anything, I will write down what I want to say to him because I don't believe they listen to you all the time, especially a woman, if it's a man doctor. ; Therapist: Well, you know, it's her, they think, oh God, it's her again, you know? ; Therapist: So I think, put this down and smile at him. ; Therapist: He's got to read it. ; Patient: I think you're in your seventies now. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: Do you enjoy being in your seventies? ; Patient: What was your favourite period of, you know, in life? ; Patient: If you can, if there's an answer to that. ; Therapist: No there isn't. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: You should just enjoy every day as it comes and not get hung up about age. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Because I'm surrounded by 90 year olds now and honestly, they're like nine years old. ; Therapist: We have the biggest laughs and they do the silliest things and you know, we feel as if we've been set free from actual age, you know, you're a mother, set an example to the children or you're a daughter, you know. ; Patient: So do you think it makes a difference, kind of moving on from those responsibilities, kind of times of life? ; Patient: So when you are looking after your children, is that what you mean by you feel a sense of relief later? ; Therapist: Yes, because you're not, no one's judging you, except that you're hanging around too long. ; Therapist: But apart from that, no, it's good. ; Therapist: I mean, I was brought up by a Victorian father who was a bank manager and it was always, just remember who I am in this town. ; Therapist: You know, they were somebody in those days. ; Therapist: You're my children. ; Therapist: And then I went to a convent grammar. ; Therapist: Just remember who you are, girls. ; Therapist: You're a convent grammar school girl. ; Therapist: You know, so it didn't leave much to sin, did it? ; Therapist: It didn't leave much to... ; Patient: It's a pressure to... ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: So yeah, there's all these pressures as you're going through life. ; Therapist: So it's nice to be. ; Therapist: My husband died in his 50s, so I had to reinvent myself, which was scary, very scary after being a wife and mother all those years. ; Therapist: But my goodness me. ; Patient: I think it was either earlier this year or last year you did something quite big for a stranger? ; Therapist: Oh, the kidney donation, yes, in February. ; Therapist: February this year? ; Therapist: Yes. ; Patient: You donated a kidney to a stranger? ; Therapist: Yeah, a gentleman, I believe. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: How did you decide to do that or find out about that and then decide? ; Therapist: I found out on Facebook. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Don't ask me what the heading was, but I'm already, like most people, donated after death, you know, everything. ; Therapist: I mean, I'm leaving my body to leave medical school as well, which hasn't pleased one of my daughters, but there you go. ; Therapist: How can we grieve if you're still hanging around? ; Therapist: She said, so, so yes. ; Therapist: So some of them were for it and some of them weren't. ; Patient: And going through the transplant, the operation, it's quite a big thing to go through. ; Therapist: Well, I think all last year I was doing tests, you know, everything from psychological tests to all the physical tests and brain scans and everything scanned. ; Therapist: It was better than a thousand mile service and I thought, well, I'm doing this for the right reasons, I know that, but who knows? ; Therapist: They might find something totally wrong with me and that's the way I found out. ; Therapist: So it's a win-win situation, I believe. ; Therapist: And you know that if they do accept you, and I was the oldest one that they've ever had, they said, and it'll last 20 years, apparently, a kidney can last 20 years. ; Therapist: That was good. ; Therapist: So it's a win-win. ; Patient: I think I've asked most things on my list that I wanted to talk about. ; Patient: Is there anything that you think that I've missed that is worth covering in terms of the theme of living well for longer? ; Therapist: Well, I think if you can do something for somebody else, for whatever reason, however tiny, the comeback to yourself is just huge. ; Therapist: But as long as you don't look for that comeback, but it just is. ; Therapist: And it also consolidates the reason why you're still alive, that you're not just taking up space on the planet, and that you should do something, like in January, hopefully, tandem parachute jump for Alzheimer's. ; Patient: Oh, is that the plan? ; Therapist: That's the plan when I'm 80. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: To raise money for Alzheimer's. ; Therapist: For Alzheimer's. ; Patient: Tandem jump out of the plane. ; Therapist: Yeah, yeah. ; Patient: Wow. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: That's really good. ; Patient: Is there any advice that you would give to yourself, age 20, or any of our students? ; Therapist: Not to have taken life so seriously. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: Well, one, you don't know how long you're here for. ; Therapist: And two, nobody's that important. ; Therapist: You know, you're not the centre of the universe, for goodness sake. ; Therapist: So just get on with things. ; Therapist: It's like, I feel sorry with Facebook, you know, if they don't get enough likes. ; Therapist: You know, it must ruin the day, some people. ; Therapist: Well, this is all false. ; Therapist: It's all smoke and murder. ; Therapist: One thing a friend did say to me that was very important, and I very proudly was saying that I now owned my own house, you see. ; Therapist: And she just laughed and she said, do you think you'd, really? ; Therapist: I went, yes, you know. ; Therapist: Oh, you're taking it with you, are you? ; Therapist: She said, you don't own anything, she said. ; Therapist: Smoke and mirrors, all of it. ; Therapist: And it's true, isn't it? ; Therapist: So just laugh and get on with it. ; Patient: Thank you.
summary: Past Session Information: Follow up ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior normal; speech nad, mood  affect happy, thought nad, perception normal, cognitive functions organized, judgement and insight intact ; Psychotherapy Type: Dynamic supportive ; Psychotherapy Technique : Reflective listening ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Themes covered in the session 1 activity patient is highly active and engaged in various activities. She values social support and maintains strong connections with friends and family. 2 outlook and mindset she has positive outlook towards the life. She demonstrates resilience and adaptability in navigating life transitions and finding purpose and meaning in her activities. Also, challenges societal norms and expectations. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Seems like a final session

dialogue: Therapist: Hi, Sasha. ; Therapist: How you doing today? ; Patient: I'm all right, thanks. ; Patient: How are you? ; Therapist: I'm doing okay. ; Therapist: Thank you for asking. ; Therapist: I understand that you've been having some difficulty with some symptoms. ; Therapist: Is that right?
