; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Can you tell me about what's been going on? ; Patient: Yeah, for the past maybe couple weeks, I guess, few weeks, I have these morning meetings once a week at work and I have to make a presentation. ; Patient: And every time I go to present, it's my turn and I start getting really nervous. ; Therapist: Start getting really nervous. ; Therapist: So, morning meeting at work and so does each person at the meeting present in a row? ; Patient: Yeah, yeah. ; Patient: We all take turns. ; Therapist: You all take turns. ; Therapist: And when you start to feel nervous when it's your time to talk or before or after that? ; Patient: No, usually the kind at the start of the meeting because I know I'm going to have to. ; Patient: All right. ; Patient: There's about 10 of us and I always seem to be one of the last few to go like six or seven kind of in line to present. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So, there's around 10 people at the meeting? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And as luck would have it, you tend to be toward the end. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So, can you describe what's happening, let's say, from the beginning of the meeting in terms of what you're experiencing? ; Patient: So, when I walk in, I'm usually okay and say good morning to everybody and then my boss calls me to order and that's usually when it starts. ; Patient: It kind of starts like maybe like butterflies in my stomach kind of. ; Patient: And then after he makes his report and then it just starts going around the room and my heart starts to beat faster, my palms get sweaty and I just start to feel really nervous. ; Patient: I've realized that I might be, I kind of, I start to tune out some of the other presentations because I start to become focused on how I'm ; Patient: feeling. ; Therapist: So, you're focused on the physical sensation of being nervous and the mental sensation and you're not really hearing what they're saying? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Is that what they're saying? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So, go on. ; Therapist: So, you have these physical symptoms, this nervousness, what happens then? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: By the time it's my turn to present, I start, I just, I'm almost like just almost shaking. ; Patient: I notice that my hands are a little off and so I'll keep my hands down like in my lap and just so that I don't want anybody to see them shaking like that. ; Patient: I have a paper in front of me that I just kind of read from but when I start reading, my voice is a little shaky and I kind of stutter and trip over my words and I just, I feel like I'm not making good presentations and that it's not looking good to my boss. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So, in the moment when it's your turn to present, you're still feeling that same nervousness like that doesn't go away at all. ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: And you're trying to hold your body kind of still like almost like keep control. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And then your voice is kind of, sounds like crackly or breaking up as you're trying to present like bullet points like on a... ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Like an outline. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: What happens when you have read the last point? ; Patient: Well, when I'm done, it takes a little bit for everything to calm down but then I'm consumed by the idea that my boss thinks I did a terrible job and that he's regretting putting me in this position and that I can't make good reports or that I didn't report the right stuff, the right information to him and so it doesn't really go away. ; Patient: It's almost like my mind just shifts on what I'm anxious about. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So, the nervousness, that stronger feeling of nervousness, that goes away. ; Therapist: It's replaced by a more general feeling of nervousness about how your boss will think of you. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Because of the presentation quality. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Because as you're presenting and kind of staying still and your voice is crackling, he's picking up on that and you're aware of that. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: How long have you noticed these symptoms that appear in this way? ; Patient: You know, when I was an undergrad in college, I had to make some presentations from time to time and I would get nervous when I would make the presentations and I just, maybe most people are afraid of public speaking so I kind of thought that maybe that's what it was, you know, just doing a presentation in front of like 30 something people and so it didn't really bother me then. ; Patient: I figured it was just normal and I always got decent grades on my presentation so it never really bothered me. ; Patient: So I really feel like it's only been an issue in the last few weeks. ; Therapist: The last few weeks is when you noticed this. ; Therapist: You had some nervousness before presenting. ; Therapist: You were in college but you just kind of thought of it as normal. ; Therapist: It didn't really impair your ability to present. ; Therapist: It didn't affect your grades or anything. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Do you have any other symptoms that you think may be related or even unrelated to what's going on? ; Patient: I'm not sure if it has any bearing. ; Patient: My mom, she doesn't like to speak in public. ; Patient: I know I used to talk to her about how I feel nervous about making presentations in school and she would say, oh, you come by as honest honey ,and so I don't know if that means anything. ; Therapist: So whatever you have going on, you think that maybe she has that going on too. ; Patient: Maybe. ; Therapist: The same set of symptoms at least. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I mean I've asked her, I've told her about this and she hasn't been in a situation where she's had to do this kind of presentations like in a small group like this and so I can't compare it to that but I mean she has said that she's gotten nervous before. ; Therapist: Any feelings of sadness or anything like that? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Like after I make the presentation at work and then I do start feeling really sad, like I said, because then I feel like my boss isn't satisfied with my performance and that he's going to regret his decision to give me this position and so yeah, it definitely makes me sad. ; Patient: I feel disappointed in myself. ; Therapist: Do you have any substance use going on, alcohol, anything else? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: I have a drink every now and then. ; Patient: It's very, very rare. ; Therapist: I know this is something recent for you but in these meetings so far, has the nervousness ever caused you to leave the room before they came around to your turn? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: I've managed to control it I guess to where I can stay there. ; Patient: Like I said, I've zoned out sometimes when other people have been presenting and I feel bad about that too because I feel like they have important information to share with me and I should give them the same respect of paying attention but I become focused on what's going on inside like my heart beating and my hands and so I zone out on them sometimes but no, I push through it and I do my presentation. ; Therapist: Are you ever worried about what they're thinking about? ; Therapist: You mentioned what your boss could be thinking about you. ; Therapist: Have you ever worried about what the other workers at the table are thinking about you? ; Patient: Yeah, sometimes because I feel like I'm the newest member of the management team and so I feel like they're kind of like, what is up with this chick? ; Patient: Why can't she get it together? ; Patient: But there's been one person who's been really supportive and she's been like, hey, you did great today and great information and things like that so that kind of helps me feel better but I guess at the end of the day to me, it's really my boss's opinion that matters because he's my boss. ; Therapist: Have you ever felt, you mentioned you were nervous at the beginning of the meeting. ; Therapist: Have you ever felt nervous well in advance of the meeting? ; Patient: When I'm preparing like that morning to go to work and it's one of those like, okay, I got this meeting at nine and I start to think about it like on my way into work but I don't start feeling anything until I'm actually in the room. ; Therapist: Alright, so you have this nervousness, it's fairly intense, pretty much only at these meetings. ; Therapist: It's been bothering you for a few weeks. ; Therapist: Something new, something a little frightening for you. ; Therapist: Alright, we'll get you set up with treatment. ; Therapist: I'll get you in to see somebody in the next few days if that works for you. ; Patient: Yeah, that'd be great. ; Therapist: And I appreciate you spending this time with me. ; Therapist: It's been helpful. ; Patient: Thank you. ; Therapist: Thanks, Sasha.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name sasha, sex female ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms anxiety of public speaking chief complaints nervouness ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behavior coopertaive; , mood  affect sad, thought negative, cognitive functions distorted, judgement poor ; Issues discussed in Current Session: 1 problem patient feels nervousness experienced during weekly work meetings, particularly when its the speakers turn to present which led to feelings of self-doubt and sadness. 2 advise patient is open to seeking help and acknowledges the need for treatment. The session concludes with a plan to set up treatment within a few days. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Anxiety ; Action Plan : Referred to a counselor

dialogue: Therapist: Oh, hello there. ; Therapist: Mrs Dawes, is that right? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Oh, good. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: I'm Dr David. ; Therapist: How can I help you today? ; Patient: I'm sorry I might be wasting your time a bit but I've come because I'm not sleeping very well. ; Patient: I'm just exhausted and I just wondered if you could give me something, anything to help me sleep, some sleeping tablets. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: It would really help me if I could ask a few more questions about how you're feeling and some of your symptoms and then we can sort of see how I can help you. ; Therapist: Would that be okay? ; Patient: Yeah, that's fine. ; Patient: Thank you. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: So why don't you tell me a bit more about what's brought you here today? ; Patient: About a year ago my husband was split up and since then I've just not been coping very much. ; Therapist: I'm sorry to hear that. ; Patient: I'm just tired all the time and the kids and the job and I just don't feel like managing very well. ; Patient: I can't sleep. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Well, why don't we just look at one of those things at a time? ; Therapist: Tell me a bit more about, um, you say having trouble sleeping. ; Patient: I just lie awake at night. ; Patient: I don't know what time it is, but just seems to go on and on and on the night. ; Patient: I know I must've got sleep in the morning. ; Patient: I just feel so dreadful. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And you having problems with your appetite? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I make the kids to dinner, but I just can't be bothered. ; Patient: Not bothered at all about it. ; Therapist: And what about sort of life in general? ; Therapist: Have you kind of lost your get up and go? ; Patient: Sorry, I don't understand. ; Therapist: You get up and go, your energy levels, have you found that they're kind of low? ; Patient: Um, yeah, I used to enjoy swimming with the kids and stuff, but I just want to be on my own. ; Patient: I just can't be bothered. ; Patient: I just, I'm just not been a very good mum at the moment as well. ; Patient: I just so exhausted really. ; Therapist: Can you just going back to your sleep, can you tell me a bit more about that? ; Therapist: How much sleep you're getting each night? ; Patient: I just lie awake and just think about him and her together, things that we used to do. ; Patient: I just wake up exhausted. ; Therapist: Sounds like your lack of energy and lack of sleep and lack of appetite. ; Therapist: It seems to me that things seem to be really getting you down. ; Patient: I'm just such a mess at the moment. ; Patient: I'm just not coping, I'm just exhausted. ; Therapist: You say you're a mess. ; Patient: Well, look at me. ; Patient: I just, you know, I just need some sleep. ; Therapist: It would be helpful for me just to sort of find out a bit more about home life and work life and ask a few questions in that area. ; Therapist: Would that be okay? ; Patient: Yeah, it's fine. ; Patient: Sorry. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So, so do you work? ; Patient: Um, I work in a job centre. ; Patient: It gets a bit stressful at times. ; Patient: Um, we've got to see so many people. ; Patient: Of course they're stressed. ; Therapist: Um, I've got some patients who work in the same environment. ; Therapist: It's very high pressure, isn't it? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Um, someone is, I just can't be bothered to get out of bed and um, it's um, that's worrying me because I've fallen sick and you know, it's not good to have a sick record, is it? ; Patient: It's not like me. ; Therapist: And who else is at home with you? ; Patient: I've got two kids. ; Patient: Um, one's one girl, one boy. ; Patient: Richard is the youngest. ; Patient: He's seven. ; Patient: Anne-Marie, she's nine. ; Therapist: Do they get to their father much? ; Patient: Um, no, he can't be bothered now. ; Patient: He's got a new family. ; Patient: He doesn't see them at all. ; Patient: They're very good kids. ; Therapist: It must be quite hard on both you and them. ; Patient: I try and be a good mum but it's very difficult. ; Therapist: Do you get any help or support from anyone else? ; Patient: My mum, she's wonderful but she has arthritis. ; Patient: So she, you know, she does what she can. ; Therapist: Does she live locally? ; Patient: Yeah, she's just around the corner and she picks the kids up from school. ; Patient: And um, yeah, she's an angel. ; Patient: She helps me a lot. ; Therapist: What about you? ; Therapist: What about your hobbies and things you enjoy doing? ; Patient: I used to enjoy going to the cinema with my friends. ; Patient: Even line dancing, we used to go down to the village for line dancing. ; Patient: But that's been a while ago. ; Patient: I just, nobody wants a bit of misery around, do they? ; Patient: And I'd rather be on my own now. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Thank you. ; Therapist: Well, I know you've, you're not a doctor and, but you must have had thoughts about what's causing all these feelings. ; Therapist: Um, had you thought about, about these, those type of things? ; Patient: I guess I was on automatic pilot when he first left. ; Patient: I guess that's why I'm in the state I am now. ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: Could I resent the kids? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: But I suppose that's why I keep going down and I just feel everything's useless. ; Patient: I can't sleep, you know. ; Therapist: What tends to bother you the most? ; Therapist: Is it the sleep or the, your appetite or the energy or not coping with the kids? ; Patient: Sleep, I just feel if I had a bit more energy, if I could just have something just to, you know, help me out with them so I can do the normal things. ; Therapist: That was going to be really what I was going to ask next. ; Therapist: I mean, what, what were your thoughts about how he could help you today? ; Patient: Well, I just thought with, with one of these other things, but sleeping tablets, I thought they might help. ; Therapist: Would it be a good idea perhaps if we think about all the options and available to you and then decide which, which ones may be best for you? ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: What, what, what are the other options? ; Therapist: Well, you might have heard of some of the, the talking therapies, um, being able to sit down and talk with a sort of a trained counsellor about, about your feelings and about what's been happening. ; Patient: People that help my sleep, will that make me be able to cope the next day through sleep? ; Therapist: It may help you deal with some of your feelings. ; Therapist: Um, I take on board about the thought about using a sleeping tablet. ; Therapist: I think that could be another option. ; Therapist: Um, obviously one of the concerns we have is that we don't want to have you on sleeping tablets for a long period of time because there are issues about becoming dependent on them and reliant on them. ; Therapist: We can use them for a short period of time, say for a week to help you get back into a bit more of a normal sleep pattern. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Um, that sounds good. ; Therapist: I mean, what about those two options as the option, the counsellor or perhaps trying to short course of sleeping? ; Patient: She had counselling. ; Patient: She had counselling. ; Patient: Um, I'd like, I mean, I just feel if I had some sleeping tablets, that might just, just give me a spur really. ; Patient: And, and, and, and I'm quite happy with the counselling as well. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So you'd like to try both. ; Therapist: Um, I think that, that, that, that sounds a good idea. ; Therapist: Uh, would you be happy to the counsellor here at the surgery? ; Patient: Yes, that'd be fine. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So I can organise that. ; Therapist: I can speak to her and ask her to contact you to make an appointment. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Um, it'd also be really helpful for me as well if you could complete, uh, one of our HADS questionnaires. ; Patient: What's, what's a HADS, what's a question, HADS questionnaire? ; Therapist: Uh, sorry. ; Therapist: It's a short questionnaire. ; Therapist: Just, um, asking some questions about your feelings and it'll help me to find out, um, if there's any more help I can give you when I next see you. ; Therapist: Is that okay? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: From what you've told me today, I mean, it sounds ready for the last 12 months or so you felt really low since split from your husband. ; Therapist: Your sleep's not been good. ; Therapist: Your appetite's not been good. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I'm a mess. ; Therapist: Um, it sounds to me your self esteem's taken a real knock, hasn't it? ; Therapist: Um, I certainly think the help we can give you with some counselling, which we have a counsellor that comes here in the surgery that will be, I think will be a benefit to you. ; Therapist: And then we'll try this short course of a sleeping tablet to try and get you back into a sleep pattern. ; Therapist: And then maybe I can see you in about two, three weeks time. ; Therapist: And I don't want you to think that you have to sort of manage all this by yourself. ; Therapist: I mean, that's why we're here. ; Therapist: We're here to help and support you further. ; Therapist: Let me do the prescription then. ; Therapist: It's 12 Hadfield Close. ; Patient: Yep. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So that's gone to reception now so you can put that up on the way out. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And um, I'll give you one of the Had's questionnaires as well. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Complete that before we see you next time. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: Thank you doctor. ; Patient: Thank you for that. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: See you next time. ; Therapist: Thank you. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Bye bye.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name dorsey; sex female; marital status divorced ; Clinical Identifiers: Setting opd ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Lack of energy1 yr 2. Sleep disturbances1 yr 3. Lack of appetite 1 yr precipitating factor seperation from husband ; History: Patient was apparently maintaining well till 1 yrs back. She used to enjoy watching movies, go for swimming, interacted well with friends and family members. Biological functions were wnl. 1 yr back after she got divorced, she started experiencing difficulty in sleeping. She would lie on her bed awake turning and tossing until morning. Gradually her appetite also reduced. She reports that for the past 1 yr she doesnt feel energetic and its difficult for her to get up from bed and get going. Family history mother, living nearby, ho arthritis marital history pt got divorced 1 yr back has 2 kids, elder daughter and younger son ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Nil ; Psychotherapy Type: Nil ; Psychotherapy Technique : Nil ; Assessments: Hads scale ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Sleep disturbances ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Adjustment disorder with prolonged depressive reaction ; Action Plan : The doctor prescribed some sleep medication and asked her to come after 2 weeks following which therapy will be started ; Next session details: After 2 weeks

dialogue: Therapist: Hi, Jackie. ; Therapist: How are you doing today? ; Patient: I'm pretty good, yes. ; Patient: How about you? ; Therapist: I'm doing okay. ; Therapist: Thanks for asking. ; Therapist: I understand you've been having some difficulties that have facilitated you to come into our agency. ; Patient: Yeah, well, I mean I've been drinking a lot more than usual, but it's kind of just part of my life. ; Patient: But I don't know, I think there is an increase, so it's worrying me a little bit. ; Therapist: So you feel like you're drinking more than usual? ; Therapist: How much are you drinking now? ; Patient: I go out with my friends a couple nights a week, and then about once a week I'll go out with my co-workers. ; Patient: So, yeah, maybe three, four nights a week. ; Therapist: Three or four nights a week you're drinking? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And how much are you drinking each time you go out? ; Patient: It kind of depends on who I'm with, but usually when I go out with my friends on the weekend I'll stay for a pretty long time. ; Patient: I mean, I think the problem is when I'm going out during the week with my co-workers, I'll stay longer than I want to, and then when I have to get up in the morning it's kind of like, ugh, I should have gone home a little earlier. ; Patient: But, no, they're all out with me, so when I get there they understand. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So do you know how much alcohol, like you were talking about the time period, do you know how much you're actually drinking each night approximately? ; Patient: Well, before I used to drink maybe two beers an hour, but they really like to party, so, and I'm trying to keep up with them, so ; Therapist: You're friends? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: So I've been drinking a shot with the beers I have, so maybe like three or four drinks an hour. ; Therapist: Do you find that you need to drink more to get the desired effect? ; Patient: Yeah, you know, everyone else is getting to that level, so I feel like I need to keep up with them, and usually before I would get that from maybe one or two drinks, so now I've been drinking a little bit more, I think, to get there. ; Therapist: Have you made any attempts to cut down on the consumption? ; Patient: You know, at the beginning of the week I would kind of say, you know, I'm only going to go out twice this week. ; Patient: But then they invite me and I'm kind of like, oh, well, I don't want to miss out, they're my friends, you know. ; Patient: This might show my social time during the week, so I usually go. ; Patient: I don't really stick to the plan. ; Patient: So that's kind of been a little frustrating, but I don't know, I still think it's okay. ; Therapist: So I want to talk about the time you spent using alcohol. ; Therapist: Are you okay with the amount of time? ; Therapist: You mentioned that you're using it for a longer period, but are you okay with that? ; Therapist: Or is that something that's distressing you? ; Patient: You know, I think I could probably be doing better things with my time, but this is not a huge problem. ; Patient: I think a lot of people do it, so, you know. ; Therapist: Do you find that you have a craving for alcohol? ; Patient: Yeah, yeah. ; Therapist: Tell me about that. ; Patient: I would say, like, when I'm at work, I'm just ready to get finished so I can go to happy hour with my co-workers, or, you know, if I'm just kind of at a barbecue or something with family, think about how I want a beer. ; Patient: So, yeah, I have cravings, but, you know, everyone kind of does that, like, oh, I could go for a beer right now. ; Therapist: So you're thinking about it, but you're also feeling the craving? ; Patient: Yeah, yeah, yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: You mentioned work. ; Therapist: Are you having trouble with responsibilities at work or any other area? ; Patient: No, my work life has been pretty, going pretty well. ; Patient: I haven't missed work because of it or anything like that, so. ; Therapist: Because of the drinking? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: How about any social problems due to the alcohol? ; Patient: No, I think my social life is actually great because of it, you know, hanging out with my friends and we all get along really well, so, yeah, it's my social time. ; Therapist: All right, so no social problems? ; Patient: No, no problems. ; Therapist: Have you had to give up any important activities because of the alcohol use? ; Patient: Important activities, well, usually the important activities involve drinking, so. ; Patient: I haven't given up important activities that don't involve drinking, but that's been pretty easy because there's usually alcohol at the important things, so. ; Therapist: I see you haven't missed any important activities because of that. ; Therapist: How about engaging in any activities that are physically dangerous because alcohol is involved? ; Patient: No, no, I'm usually pretty safe, yeah. ; Therapist: Safe? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Do you have any medical or mental health history? ; Patient: Well, like when I was a kid I was diagnosed with, I think, maybe ADHD or something like that, but I think my teachers were annoyed by me because I just like to have a good time, so. ; Patient: But that's not really been an issue lately. ; Therapist: That's not been an issue? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Has any medical problem or mental health problem become worse because of the alcohol? ; Patient: No, you know, I started drinking after that, so. ; Patient: No, it's not become an issue with it. ; Therapist: So you mentioned alcohol use. ; Therapist: Has there been any drug use? ; Patient: No, not with my drinking or anything. ; Patient: You know, typical teenage smoking marijuana and stuff when I was younger, but I don't anymore, so. ; Therapist: So it's just alcohol now? ; Patient: Yeah, just alcohol. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: Do you have, when you stop drinking, do you have any physical symptoms or anxiety, any symptoms of withdrawal? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: I usually feel fine afterwards. ; Patient: I can go a few days without drinking. ; Therapist: Okay, so that's not a problem for you? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: Jackie, are you open to receiving counseling services or agency? ; Patient: Yeah, I don't see why it would hurt anything. ; Patient: I don't really know if I need it, but. ; Therapist: But you'll be okay with trying? ; Patient: Yeah, I think it would be okay. ; Therapist: Alright, I'm going to get you scheduled in to see a counselor. ; Therapist: I want to thank you for telling me about what's going on and for answering my questions. ; Therapist: It's been helpful. ; Patient: Yeah, sure. ; Patient: Yeah, thank you.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name jackie; sex male ; Clinical Identifiers: Setting counseling agency ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Strong desire to take alcohol 2. Increased frequency alcohol consumption 3. Difficulty controlling alcohol consumtpion 4. Increased tolerance alcohol ; History: Present history patient has been distressed due to his increased alcohol consumption despite trying to cut it down. His tolerance for the amount of it has also increased with time. He drinks to not miss on social activities; substance use history he has been consuming alcohol 3 to 4 nights a week and takes 3 to 4 drinks in an hour. He used to smoke marijuana during his teenage but quit later on. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behavior patient was cordial and rapport could be established; mood calm; affect broad; thought content- reflected worry due to increase in alcohol consumption ; Psychotherapy Type: Nil ; Psychotherapy Technique : Nil ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: History was gathered from the patient where his drinking habits were discussed. He had been experiencing a strong desire to consume alcohol where the frequency of intake has also increased along with the tolerance. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: F10. 2 dependence syndrome ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Jason, how are you doing today? ; Patient: I'm here. ; Therapist: You're good? ; Patient: I'm here, that's all I can say. ; Patient: I'm just here. ; Therapist: You're here? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: What's been going on? ; Patient: So I've been made to come in and talk to you because something happened on the bus and I might have said something to somebody and they're just like, oh you can't say that. ; Patient: So they actually said, Doug, we're going to take you to jail. ; Patient: From jail they just called me here. ; Therapist: Do you know what you're charged with? ; Patient: They didn't explain anything. ; Patient: The government never explains anything. ; Patient: They just don't want me to understand what's going on because they just want to keep me held in captivity. ; Therapist: The government? ; Therapist: Do you have anybody specific? ; Patient: No, it's the entire government. ; Therapist: The entire government? ; Patient: The entire government. ; Therapist: And how long have they been wanting to do this to you? ; Patient: All my life. ; Patient: They've done this all my life. ; Patient: They're always listening, they're always around, they're always there. ; Therapist: Always there? ; Patient: Always there. ; Patient: Like for example, they're in the lights right now. ; Patient: They're listening to everything that we're talking about so that's the reason why I really want to talk about what happened on the bus because they're just going to use that again today and then it's going to lock me up again and make me take more minutes. ; Therapist: You've been taking medications? ; Patient: Yes, I take the medication because if I don't take the medication, the government comes and takes me away and puts me into a hospital where they force feed me the medication and then the lights are always on and they can always hear everything that I'm saying and what I'm thinking and what I'm going to do. ; Therapist: Do you know what they want to do with that information? ; Patient: They want to use it to take over the world. ; Therapist: To take over the world? ; Patient: To take over the world, of course. ; Patient: They want to use everything and use everything that everybody knows to use it against them so that they can actually have the world that they want and that they need and make everybody pretend that they don't know what's going on. ; Patient: So therefore they're using everybody's thoughts against themselves so that the government can use it to their benefit. ; Therapist: So what can you do in this situation? ; Patient: What do you mean? ; Patient: What can I do? ; Therapist: Well, you said the government's monitoring everything and that they want to put you in jail. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: If you don't take your medication, do you have any options? ; Therapist: Are you stuck? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: When I'm home, I think I'm perfectly fine because I set up my house and my room to actually make it government-approved so that nobody can actually hear or see what's going on in there. ; Patient: So when I'm home, I'm perfectly fine. ; Therapist: So one option is that being home. ; Patient: Being home, you're safe. ; Patient: Being home, I'm safe. ; Patient: Being home, I'm safe. ; Patient: My mom's safe. ; Patient: My brother's safe. ; Patient: Everybody's safe. ; Patient: And being out in the world, I'm not safe. ; Patient: Nobody's safe. ; Therapist: Are you safe here? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: I told you they are in the light and they can hear everything that we're saying right now. ; Patient: So no, we're not safe here. ; Therapist: So it's not safe here. ; Therapist: It's not safe out in the world. ; Therapist: At home, you're safe. ; Patient: At home, I'm safe in my room that I made government-approved. ; Therapist: So if you could have your way, you would just stay home most of the time, all the time? ; Patient: I would stay home all of the time, but I can't stay home because I need to go and see doctors. ; Patient: And talk to people and do things that the government needs me or wants me to do. ; Patient: But I don't want to do those things because it's using my thoughts and they're trying to use everybody against me. ; Patient: And I just can't deal with that. ; Therapist: So how do you know that they're in the lights? ; Therapist: How did you discover that? ; Patient: Everybody knows that they're in the lights. ; Therapist: It's common knowledge? ; Patient: It's common knowledge. ; Therapist: Do you ever hear things that other people can't hear or see things that other people can't see? ; Patient: No, of course. ; Patient: Everybody hears the lights talking to you. ; Patient: I don't know what you're talking about. ; Patient: Like, everybody hears it. ; Patient: Sometimes it's a whisper for some people. ; Patient: Sometimes it's a yell. ; Patient: And if you want to not pay attention to what the lights are saying to you, then I don't know what's wrong with you, but everybody can hear it. ; Therapist: Everybody can hear it? ; Patient: Everybody can. ; Therapist: What's it sound like to you? ; Patient: It just sounds like a robot talking. ; Patient: It sounds like we need to know this information. ; Patient: We need to... ; Patient: What are you doing? ; Therapist: Oh, just making some notes. ; Therapist: Just making some progress notes. ; Therapist: Is it working? ; Patient: Yes. ; Patient: Where are your notes going to go? ; Therapist: Well, this chart will get locked in the chart room down the hall. ; Patient: Who has access to the chart room? ; Therapist: Mostly everybody works here. ; Patient: Oh. ; Patient: Can I get a copy of your notes after you're done? ; Therapist: Does it worry that there's notes? ; Patient: Yes, because I might trust you, and I don't know if I do yet, but I don't trust the other people who work here because I don't know if they're working for the government, which they probably are working for the government. ; Patient: So they can actually have access to all of my notes and the things that you're writing down, which I don't know what they are because you're not going to get me a copy of it yet. ; Patient: And I just don't trust that they can actually get that information in because they're going to use it to their advantage, and they're going to give it to the government, which I can't have that happening. ; Patient: So could you please not take notes? ; Therapist: I can not take notes. ; Therapist: What kind of information and notes are you worried that the government's going to get? ; Patient: Well, because I made my room at home government-proof, I think they're going to get a copy of my notes and I'm going to try to steal that technology that I actually created so that they can then disrupt my room and then everybody else's rooms who are just like mine so that they can then use their mind control to then control me to do the things that they want me to do. ; Therapist: So without the protection that your house offers, they could control your mind? ; Patient: Correct. ; Patient: Without my room and without the technology and the systems and the things that I created, then the government will be able to control everything that I do. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So can you tell me about your mood through all this? ; Therapist: So this sounds really stressful. ; Therapist: You're describing an environment where the government's frequently looking at what you're doing. ; Therapist: What are the feelings there? ; Therapist: Do you feel sad or angry? ; Patient: I feel fine. ; Therapist: You feel fine? ; Patient: I feel fine. ; Patient: I don't really have – yeah, I just feel fine. ; Patient: I don't feel happy, I don't feel sad. ; Patient: I just – I'm just here. ; Therapist: Kind of resigned that the government's going to do this? ; Patient: Well, the government's going to do what they're going to do anyway, so it doesn't matter if I'm happy, sad, pissed off, angry, any of that. ; Patient: The government's going to make me do what they want me to do anyway, so it doesn't matter how I feel. ; Therapist: Are you worried that something is going to happen that's similar to what happened on the bus? ; Patient: No, because I've learned my lesson to not say those things out loud and to talk about what the government's doing because I can't actually inform anybody else because nobody's listening to me because they're already controlled by the government because they don't have a room like I do at home. ; Therapist: So you avoid that in the future because it didn't really work? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: You weren't able to help them understand what's going on? ; Patient: Well, if people don't understand what's going on, then that's their fault and that's their problem. ; Patient: They should have listened to me. ; Patient: I could have actually gave them the technology that they needed to actually create the room so that the government can't hear them. ; Therapist: But they weren't open to that idea? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Quite the opposite. ; Patient: Completely the opposite. ; Therapist: How are your family relationships? ; Therapist: How's that going? ; Patient: They're okay. ; Patient: I live with my mom. ; Patient: She does what she's supposed to. ; Patient: She doesn't go in my room because she knows that if she goes into the room, it's going to mess up the technology so she stays out. ; Therapist: So you get along with her okay? ; Patient: We're fine. ; Therapist: Anybody else you have contact with? ; Therapist: Friends, family? ; Patient: No, just I talk to people all the time but they're just in my head. ; Patient: We have conversations all the time about how we can actually make the world a better place and then how we can actually go through and then destroy the government. ; Patient: But yeah, I just talk to them in my head. ; Therapist: Alright Jason, I'm sorry to hear that you're under stress. ; Therapist: I'm glad to hear you feel like your mood's okay if you're not down or anxious or anything. ; Therapist: This, answering these questions for me, this has been helpful and I'm going to recommend you continue to see a counselor here if that's okay. ; Therapist: I realize you're court ordered. ; Patient: Can this counselor be you? ; Therapist: It could be me. ; Therapist: Would that make you feel more comfortable? ; Patient: That would make me feel much better. ; Therapist: Well then I'll put on the schedule, we'll set a time up front where I'll see you, let's say in three days. ; Therapist: That works? ; Patient: Three days works. ; Therapist: And we'll go from there. ; Therapist: Thanks Jason.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name jason; sex male ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Suspiciousness on government 2. Voices coming from lights ; History: Present history patient believes that government is spying on him all the time to take over the world. He believes that they keep an eye on him through lights. He also hears robotic voice and whispers from there. For the same, has made some changes to his room to protect himself from the government; past history patient has been admitted to the hospital multiple times as he shared his suspiciousness on government in public; family history patient lives with his family including his mother, brother and others. He hasnt allowed anybody to enter his room as he has made changes there to keep him safe so that government doesnt spy on him. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behavior he was cooperative. He was unable to fully trust the therapist and requested not to make any notes of the session; speech productivity- increased; mood low; affect restricted; thought content- preoccupation with beliefs that government is spying on him; insight grade 1 ; Psychotherapy Type: Nil ; Psychotherapy Technique : Nil ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patient shared his suspicion on government in a public bus and so was first taken to jail and then to the session. He believes that government has always been spying on him through lights. He also hears some robotic voices and whispers from the lights. He has been admitted in the hospital multiple times before and so he takes his medication to avoid the hospital admission. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: F20. 0 paranoid schizophrenia ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Lisa, how are you doing today? ; Patient: I'm well, how are you? ; Therapist: I'm doing well, thanks for asking. ; Therapist: It's nice to meet you, I'm glad you could come in to the agency. ; Therapist: Could you tell me what brings you here today? ; Patient: Um, well, I am here now because I was caught stealing money. ; Patient: And now I have to pay the price I guess. ; Therapist: Alright, so were you ordered by a court? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: How long ago did the crime occur? ; Patient: About a month ago. ; Therapist: About a month ago? ; Therapist: So I'm going to try to get an idea of what's going on with you to see where you fit in in terms of treatment. ; Therapist: So it's an assessment, so I'll be asking you some questions about your history and things that you've done, any feelings you've had, thoughts you've had. ; Patient: Like diagnosing? ; Therapist: Like diagnosing. ; Therapist: Is that okay with you? ; Patient: Sure. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: So how old are you now? ; Patient: 25 ; Therapist: 25? ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: So you say about a month ago you got in some trouble, can you tell me what happened there? ; Patient: Um, well I stole money from a friend of mine and you know, I just needed the money. ; Patient: They had more money than me so I took it. ; Therapist: So you needed the money? ; Patient: Mm hmm. ; Therapist: And this was a friend of yours? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: How do things stand between you and your friend now? ; Patient: Well, she turned me in so we're no longer friends. ; Therapist: No longer friends. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: Have you had any other trouble with the law? ; Patient: Well, basically when I was younger, I got, I used to get into a lot of fights. ; Therapist: Mm hmm. ; Therapist: Um, who's they? ; Patient: My family. ; Patient: Um, I used to get into a lot of physical altercations and there was this one time when I beat this girl up and they told me that they had to pull me off of her. ; Patient: So. ; Therapist: You remember doing it? ; Patient: Uh, yeah I remember doing it. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: Mm hmm. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: And how old are you when that happened? ; Therapist: Do you remember? ; Patient: I was about 12. ; Therapist: About 12 years old. ; Therapist: Were you ever treated for that? ; Therapist: Like any type of mental health treatment? ; Patient: Uh, well, they put me in some sort of detention center. ; Therapist: Mm hmm. ; Patient: Um, and I guess they gave me some sort of therapy one on one. ; Patient: But nothing any, like nothing serious or like I'm doing now. ; Therapist: Are you aware of any diagnosis that you've been given related to mental health in the past? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No? ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: So you got into the, sounds like a fairly serious fight when you were 12. ; Patient: Mm hmm. ; Therapist: And you're 25 now. ; Therapist: Can you tell me what's happened in terms of any other problems between 12 and 15? ; Patient: Um, I guess the usual. ; Patient: I mean, I drank and got into some drugs and would use and do stuff like that. ; Patient: So. ; Therapist: Any other thefts or, or assaults or anything? ; Patient: I mean, yeah, I still kept getting into fights and stuff. ; Patient: But, yeah, I think my last real fight was when I was about 20. ; Patient: So, yeah. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: Um, and how much danger were the people that you were fighting? ; Patient: Um. ; Therapist: Like, did you seriously hurt them? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: How many times did that happen where you seriously hurt somebody? ; Patient: Probably every fight that I ever gotten into. ; Patient: So, many. ; Patient: Um, I don't have a number. ; Patient: But. ; Therapist: Can you explain what happened? ; Therapist: Like, what caused the fight? ; Patient: So, the one girl, she just, I felt looked at me wrong and I didn't like it. ; Patient: So, I punched her in the mouth. ; Patient: And continued to do so. ; Patient: Until she was on the ground. ; Patient: And then I still continued to do so. ; Therapist: What are your feelings about that? ; Patient: She deserved it. ; Therapist: Because of the way she looked at you? ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: Do you ever, um, have any feelings of guilt or remorse about it? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Have you ever apologized to any people that were hurt? ; Patient: I've apologized, but just to appease, uh, people so that I didn't get into any more trouble. ; Patient: Also, in some of these situations apologizing was kind of required? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: So, you apologized to them but you didn't, didn't really mean it? ; Therapist: Or what were you thinking? ; Patient: I didn't mean it. ; Therapist: You didn't mean it? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: It was just to get out of trouble and go on with myself. ; Therapist: Were you successful in getting out of trouble? ; Patient: Absolutely. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: You say that, um, kind of with a little pride. ; Patient: Something to take pride in? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah? ; Therapist: Being able to get out of trouble? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: I mean, wouldn't you? ; Therapist: So that's like something you look at as like a skill that you have? ; Patient: Absolutely. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: Have you ever, for like the theft type activities, you ever felt any guilt or remorse there? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: It's kind of the same thing? ; Patient: Same thing. ; Patient: They, I mean, they had more money than me, so why not? ; Patient: They probably would have done the same thing to me. ; Patient: So, I did it to them before they could do it to me. ; Therapist: Were you ever the victim of a crime? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: I'm smarter than most people, so I can probably, I can one-up people. ; Patient: So. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Do you feel that you're good in working with people, like in terms of social skills? ; Patient: I mean, getting what I want. ; Patient: I can always get what I want. ; Therapist: So you're effective at managing relationships to get what you want? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: How would you describe your mood most of the time? ; Patient: Hmm. ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: I guess I can get a little irritable. ; Therapist: A little irritable? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: How often does that happen? ; Patient: A few times a week. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: Does that irritability ever lead to, or has ever led to some of the aggressiveness? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So you're more likely to be aggressive when you've been irritable for a while? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: When was the last time you were involved in a physical fight? ; Patient: So that was around 20. ; Therapist: About five years ago? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: What do you think has caused that to stop? ; Patient: Uh, I guess I'm moving on to bigger and better things. ; Therapist: What type of things? ; Patient: Um, stealing. ; Therapist: So the stealing's more gratifying than the fighting? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: So irritable, and any other emotions, any other feelings? ; Patient: Uh, I'm not sure. ; Therapist: Not sure? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: You have a job? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Well, I did. ; Therapist: You did? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Can you tell me about your work performance and your experience there? ; Patient: Well, you know, I show up when I need to most of the time, and do what I have to do. ; Therapist: You show up most of the time? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: How would your employer describe you as an employee? ; Patient: I mean, I'm pretty good at doing what I do, but I guess my boss would like me to be there more. ; Patient: But when I'm not there, they'll go on without me. ; Patient: So... ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: So in terms of your feelings about missing work, that's not too worrisome for you? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No? ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: How many jobs have you had? ; Patient: Probably, like, six. ; Therapist: Six jobs? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: What age did you first start working? ; Patient: Um, 19. ; Therapist: 19 ; Therapist: So six jobs in about six years? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And would you say that your experience with all the employers was the same in terms of how you showed up for work and missing work? ; Therapist: Were any of them different? ; Patient: They wanted me... they tried to get me to conform, I feel. ; Patient: And I'm just not a conformist. ; Therapist: Kind of doing things your own way? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: What do you want to gain out of treatment here? ; Patient: I just want to get out of trouble. ; Therapist: You're in trouble now? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: And you like to get out of trouble? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: Lisa, this has been helpful. ; Therapist: I'm going to get you scheduled for treatment. ; Therapist: And they'll probably get you in about a week. ; Therapist: And we can go from there. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Thank you. ; Patient: Thank you.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name lisa; age25; sex female ; Clinical Identifiers: Setting agency ; Referral Information : Referred by court; reason stealing money ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Irritability since adolescence; 2. Anger outburst since adolescence ; History: Present complaints irritability, aggressiveness, repeated physical fights, lack of remorse, deceitfulness, failure to sustain employment, failure to conform to societal norms ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Affect irritable; thought lack of remorse ; Psychotherapy Type: Nil ; Psychotherapy Technique : Nil ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Various aspects of personality to come to a diagnosis ; Reflections by the therapist: Nl ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Antisocial personality disorder ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Well, hello Susan. ; Patient: Hello. ; Therapist: Good to see you today. ; Patient: Thanks. ; Therapist: So, tell me what brings you here. ; Patient: Well, I have an anxiety issue. ; Patient: There are a lot of things that make me anxious and I gotta do something different because I can't, I'm really not functioning at the level I need to be functioning at. ; Patient: My anxiety just really impacts a lot of my life. ; Patient: So I need help with managing it. ; Therapist: Okay, so tell me what that looks like for your anxiety in that situation. ; Patient: Let's see, riding here, I mean on the interstate, I'm just panicking constantly about the cars. ; Patient: Granted, I've had a couple of accidents and people have hit me, but I'm constantly thinking, okay that person is about to pull over and hit me. ; Patient: Okay, that person is going too fast. ; Patient: Okay, they're going to hit me from behind. ; Patient: I'm just really anxious. ; Patient: I'm driving about all cars hitting me. ; Patient: I'm in school and tests. ; Patient: I get really anxious when I take a test. ; Patient: I mean I know I know the information and I sit down and take the test and it's like, I can't. ; Patient: I can't recall because I'm so anxious about this test even though I know the information. ; Therapist: So is it physical? ; Therapist: Is it a lot of thoughts in my head? ; Patient: Yeah, I think it's a lot of thoughts in my head and it is very physical. ; Patient: I mean I get sweaty palms, my heart starts racing, I get tense. ; Patient: So it is physical. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: What are the thoughts going on in your head? ; Patient: My thoughts are, like if I'm in the car, I'm going to get hit. ; Patient: If I'm taking a test, it's like, okay I've got to do well on this test. ; Patient: I've got to remember this. ; Patient: There's so much to remember and I just kind of, brain is freezing a little bit and I'm panicking because I can't remember. ; Patient: So I guess I'll allow that. ; Therapist: And so, like with the test, have you found that being a problem as far as not being able to complete the test or not doing well on the test? ; Therapist: Or is it like once you go through it then you're fine? ; Patient: Isn't it like anxiety over when I finish the test? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah, after I'm finished. ; Patient: I mean I know I could perform better if I wasn't so anxious. ; Patient: I know it wouldn't take me as long if I wasn't anxious. ; Patient: It seems to, I mean these are like time tests and so when it's over, whether it's an hour or two hours or however long it is, I mean when it's over, you know I'm anxious during it, but when it's over, yeah it kind of subsides. ; Patient: Just like in the car, when I get to the place after I'm off the interstate and stuff, it seems to subside. ; Patient: So when the situation is over, it seems to go down. ; Therapist: So it sounds like you might need to find something that helps you just. ; Patient: Yeah, I want something at the time to help me in the moment because these are things that I mean I can't avoid. ; Patient: I mean even in my job too, I've got to go in my field placement, I've got to do these group settings, you know I've got to do. ; Patient: Some kids are crazy, they're just respectful, it's like okay. ; Patient: I've got to do it though. ; Patient: All these things I have to do, I can't change them in my life right now. ; Patient: So I've got to figure out how to deal with it better. ; Therapist: Okay, well would you like to learn a skill? ; Patient: Yeah, I'm very eager to learn something that can make a difference. ; Therapist: Okay, well there's something called grounding, have you heard that? ; Patient: Grounding, no just electricity, grounding, you know that third plug thing. ; Patient: That's the only grounding I know. ; Patient: Don't be grounded, that sounds good, bring it on. ; Therapist: Being grounded is kind of like working my ego, it's kind of getting to that level place. ; Therapist: So with grounding, a lot of people have a lot of emotions, it's okay to have emotions, but for some people it gets really intense, like you and the inside and it's just a lot. ; Therapist: And so with grounding we're trying to learn ways to bring that down to more of a calm place. ; Therapist: So it doesn't necessarily solve the problem, like there's still traffic, there's still things going on, it just helps you get to a calm place to deal with it. ; Patient: That sounds good. ; Therapist: So I'm going to introduce a grounding technique to you. ; Therapist: It involves some deep breathing, some closing of the eyes, getting to your senses. ; Therapist: So I have a little script to you that I'm going to read to you. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And we'll go through this and you'll tell me after if you like it. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: But to begin I just want you to relax and be comfortable and try to get as comfortable as you can. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And now rest your hands on your back, on the side, whatever is more comfortable for you. ; Patient: Okay, that's okay. ; Therapist: I want you to just breathe. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Try to do the deep, the chest rises and breathe in. ; Therapist: Breathe that out. ; Patient: That's good. ; Therapist: So don't worry about doing the breathing light, just whatever is comfortable. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Now we're going to engage in using each of the five senses. ; Therapist: And so for that I want you to close your eyes. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: I just want you to listen to my voice and hear my instructions. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So just begin to relax by just noticing all the sounds around you. ; Therapist: And start with hearing. ; Therapist: And whenever you're comfortable you can tell me what you hear. ; Therapist: Any sound. ; Patient: Kind of hear my breath a little bit. ; Patient: I hear the air conditioning going. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: Or the heat, whatever that is. ; Patient: The air coming through the mouth. ; Patient: I hear that. ; Therapist: With the constant noise? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: That's kind of all I'm hearing right now. ; Therapist: Do you think you noticed the sound before of the air belt? ; Patient: Mm-mm. ; Patient: No. ; Patient: I'm just hearing it now. ; Therapist: Starting to hear more now. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Let's move on to smell. ; Therapist: Do you smell anything in that body? ; Patient: Hmm. ; Patient: I don't think I smell much. ; Patient: Hmm. ; Therapist: It's just totally okay. ; Patient: I don't smell a lot. ; Patient: You know, there's not a lot of scents right now in this room for smelling. ; Patient: There's not a lot of smelling. ; Patient: Foul and bad or good. ; Patient: It's just kind of normal. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: No smells? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: No unusual smells. ; Therapist: No smell of air. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Now I would like for you to open your eyes up. ; Therapist: I'm going to talk about sight. ; Therapist: So just list me some things that you can see in this room right now. ; Patient: I see you. ; Patient: I see that picture right there. ; Patient: I see that sofa right there. ; Patient: And some books and flowers. ; Patient: And I see that deer or whatever it is over there. ; Therapist: Yeah, that's okay. ; Patient: So those are some of the things that I see. ; Therapist: What about the colors of what you see? ; Patient: Um, blue and red and a lot of beige. ; Patient: Orange. ; Patient: Clashing colors. ; Patient: Red and orange. ; Patient: It's one of those go together. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: That's when you first came here. ; Therapist: Did you notice anything? ; Patient: Well, you know, I thought, I mean I might have noticed some of it. ; Patient: But I'm obviously more aware because I'm really focusing on it right now. ; Patient: So I'm definitely more aware of it right now. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And so next with taste. ; Therapist: Notice I can just tell you if you're in some other situation you can take the time to eat a big snack or something. ; Therapist: Talk about the taste, the textures. ; Therapist: Really slowly eat the food and feel how it is in your mouth and how it tastes and things like that. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: But you can still do it even without food. ; Therapist: Just simply taste enough saliva in your mouth. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: I feel kind of dry at the moment. ; Therapist: A little dry? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Are there any tastes you could think of? ; Therapist: Maybe something you ate this morning? ; Patient: Well, I had a granola bar and a banana earlier. ; Patient: So I've had some tea. ; Patient: The flavor right now in my mouth is probably the tea that I just had most recently. ; Patient: So that's the tea. ; Therapist: So that's your taste? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And then finally the touch. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: The final sense. ; Therapist: So where do your hands are right now? ; Patient: Well, I've had it. ; Patient: This is kind of a habit of mine. ; Patient: So I was feeling my hands. ; Patient: Maybe my hands are supposed to be here. ; Therapist: I just want to put your hands on that. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So describe to me how it feels. ; Patient: It feels solid. ; Patient: Feels soft. ; Patient: And it's not rough or wrinkly or anything like that. ; Patient: It feels secure. ; Patient: Like okay, this is going to hold me. ; Patient: It's a good feeling. ; Patient: I'm comfortable. ; Patient: It feels comfortable. ; Therapist: Well, that's something else I know. ; Therapist: Maybe your phone or something. ; Therapist: Describe that to me. ; Patient: This is hard. ; Patient: And I've got this cushy case on it. ; Patient: So it's kind of feeling a little cushy. ; Patient: But it's hard. ; Therapist: What about the paper? ; Therapist: More like this paper? ; Patient: Soaky and smooth and bendable and thin and slick. ; Patient: Just trying to know how that feels. ; Patient: Is that it? ; Patient: Mmhmm. ; Therapist: Just feel like I want you to be comfortable and I want you to take a deep breath three times. ; Therapist: Take your time. ; Therapist: Now, I'd like for us to go with your eyes closed and come up with a statement. ; Therapist: Say to yourself, I'm going to be okay scripture anu words like that. ; Therapist: Do you want to be okay? ; Therapist: Let's see. ; Patient: You do need to encourage yourself. ; Patient: You can do it. ; Therapist: If you feel that it's good, I'll just step aside and be okay. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: Mmhmm. ; Therapist: So I want you to say your statement out loud. ; Therapist: I can do it. ; Patient: I can do it. ; Therapist: Same with confidence. ; Patient: I can do it. ; Therapist: Okay, then you can open your eyes now. ; Therapist: So what we just did, we just went through each of the senses as a way of, a bit of a distraction from what we know. ; Therapist: It's also can be common for you to just focus your mind on things and not go into the details of something else going on. ; Therapist: It's really important that you breathe through it and at the end you can say, I can do it. ; Therapist: So how was that for you? ; Patient: Well, wow. ; Patient: It kind of did calm you down. ; Patient: I was kind of getting anxious telling you what made me anxious and so I was kind of rubbed up and then I kind of forgot about it. ; Patient: Because I was focusing on what I was seeing and what I was feeling and what I was, you know, all my senses. ; Patient: So it was very distracting in a good way. ; Patient: It got my mind off that and kind of got me onto something else. ; Patient: And then, yeah, it really did calm me down. ; Therapist: Was there a certain sense that you liked, that you found the most helpful? ; Patient: Probably right here, since I'm not eating, probably what I'm seeing and what I'm hearing. ; Patient: Those two things seem to be most helpful in this situation. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: That feeling too. ; Therapist: So let's think about how we can use this when you're driving. ; Therapist: Because obviously you can't close your eyes. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: True, true, true, true. ; Therapist: So what can you do while you're driving? ; Therapist: What senses can you use? ; Patient: Seeing, obviously. ; Patient: My eyes better be open, I better be observant about what I'm seeing. ; Patient: Feeling, I've got my hands on the wheel so I'm going to be feeling something. ; Patient: So, and hearing. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So what kind of hearing do you have, any kind of peaceful music you can listen to? ; Patient: Well, that's a good idea. ; Patient: A lot of times I'm going to listen to NPR. ; Patient: And sometimes that's good, sometimes that's not good. ; Patient: It doesn't necessarily calm me down. ; Patient: Sometimes I can, yeah, so I can listen to some more soothing music. ; Patient: Something that calms me down more. ; Therapist: Also, not having the music, just the sound of the world. ; Patient: Yeah, yeah. ; Therapist: The car is going by. ; Patient: Yeah, I think the music might help me more. ; Patient: Because, not that I want to be distracted from the cars, but I think the music might calm me down more than having nothing. ; Patient: You know, like quiet and hearing the cars and the road. ; Patient: I can see that might make me nervous. ; Patient: I need to be aware of them, but I think I want to hear music. ; Patient: So, I'll try that. ; Therapist: And then I'll always be the sight. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Getting the camera too distracted while I drive. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Focusing on the car in front of you. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Not necessarily the one behind me that might hit me. ; Patient: Because I can't do anything too much about that. ; Patient: So, okay, okay. ; Therapist: Now let's think about when, I've only taken the test. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So, what senses can we tap into there? ; Patient: Well, what I'm looking at definitely I need to focus on. ; Patient: Because I'm reading something of course and I'm feeling my pen. ; Patient: Most of it's on the computer, so I'm feeling the typewriter, typewriter keyboard. ; Patient: So, that's a sense, a touching thing that I've got to focus on and seeing as paying attention to the words on the front of me. ; Therapist: The hearing. ; Patient: The hearing. ; Patient: I like to be kind of quiet. ; Therapist: But just like today, when you can hear the... ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: To try to hear the... ; Patient: That's it to hear. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Because for us to not think too much about the function of things or, you know, like when you're tapping people you don't really have to type a word. ; Therapist: You're just feeling the keyboard. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: You know, it's your arms. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: Kind of being aware that it is there and this is there. ; Therapist: Okay? ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So, the next time when you're feeling that, try to tap into the senses. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: If you want to take just a five minute break and so for each sense, like dedicate one minute to the sense. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: Like before I start the test or before I start to drive or something. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Before you start to drive. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Start the test. ; Patient: Kind of do that. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And also remember at the end your statement. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Which is... ; Patient: I can do this. ; Therapist: Yes. ; Patient: That's it. ; Patient: Gasto. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: I can do this. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So, when do you think the next time you could do this? ; Patient: Well, I got to drive home. ; Patient: So, probably today when I drive home I could do that. ; Patient: A test. ; Patient: I don't really have a test until next week but I drive all the time and so every day I could try this. ; Therapist: So, what about before you even leave? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: To drive like when you're sitting. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: Get ready in the parking lot. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Take that time to go on yourself. ; Patient: I take a few minutes to go through all the senses. ; Patient: Focus on that. ; Patient: Put some soothing music on. ; Patient: Say, I can do it and then proceed. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: That's my little homework assignment for you. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: I'll try that. ; Therapist: You can try that. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And see how it goes. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And we'll talk about it. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: That's so we can see how it is for you. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: Cool. ; Patient: Thanks. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Sure. ; Patient: I'll take some practice but. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Because different situations, you might not use all the senses. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Don't try to focus too much on doing it absolutely right. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Just anything that can make you aware of your surroundings. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: And calm you down. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: That's good. ; Therapist: Well, thank you for coming in today. ; Patient: All right. ; Patient: Well, thanks for that. ; Patient: I'll try and get it out. ; Therapist: All right.
summary: Patient Particulars : Namesusan; sex female ; Clinical Identifiers: Setting opd ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Preoccupation with untoward happenings in futurena; racing heart, sweaty palms na ; History: The patient reports that whenever she is driving, she gets thoughts about meeting with an accident. She does not consider the thought as being irrational or against her wishes because she has had a couple of accidents before. Patient reports that whenever she has such thoughts of cars hitting her, her heart starts beating faster and her palms get sweaty. She reports that this continues throughout the way until she reached her destination. Similarly while taking any tests she would worry if shell be able to perform well and feels that her heart is pacing. However these thoughts and physical symptoms get relieved once the test is over. Due to the above complaints patient reports that her life is getting affected and she would have performed better on the tests if she was calmer while attempting the questions. With these complaints she visited the therapist. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Thought worries about meeting with an accident ; Psychotherapy Type: Type mindfulness; mode individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Grounding ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Session focussed on decreasing the anxiety symptoms ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Anxiety nos ; Action Plan : Application of the grounding technique taught in the session while driving ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Sam, how are you doing today? ; Patient: I'm good, how are you? ; Therapist: I'm doing well, thanks for asking. ; Therapist: So you're here at the agency today to seek counseling services? ; Patient: Yeah, my boss sent me over, so I figured I'd come. ; Therapist: Your boss sent you over? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: What reason do you think your boss had for doing that? ; Patient: There was this issue with a couple of the people I wanted to team with. ; Patient: They couldn't relate to my ideas, and my boss saw it as being kind of, you know, not working super well, so she wanted me to come over and talk about it. ; Therapist: She wanted you to come over and talk about your relationship with your coworkers? ; Patient: I think more just so that, you know, my ideas were just kind of higher than what they could really understand, so maybe learn how to talk to other people so that they can understand me. ; Therapist: Okay, and what do you mean by higher? ; Therapist: Like, your ideas were higher? ; Patient: You know, just a little bit more intelligent. ; Patient: You know, I'm just at a level that other people can't always reach to. ; Patient: You know, just a little bit higher, sometimes a lot higher, but just on this team, they just couldn't understand, you know, my language or what I was saying, and I couldn't see the vision that I had. ; Therapist: Okay, so they were unable to reach your level of expression for this, it was like a project you were working on? ; Patient: Yeah, yeah. ; Therapist: Was it? ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And your boss recognized this difference and thought that the counseling may be helpful? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Do you think, you know, counseling will be helpful? ; Patient: I think it's good, you know, so that my boss is happy that I went, but I think it could also be useful in the sense of, you know, other people are just jealous of me a lot and they just can't really relate to me, so it might be, you know, great to learn how to really, you know, like, kind of understand what they're going through at their level. ; Therapist: Again, you say at their level, so are you meaning, again, that they're kind of below you with your skills and- ; Patient: Yeah, they're just, they haven't accomplished as much, you know, they don't know as many people, ; Patient: they're not hanging out with those prestigious ranks, you know, they haven't been educated to the quality that I have been, so they just, sometimes it's hard for them to understand where I'm coming from or, you know, what I can see happening. ; Therapist: Okay, so counseling can help you bridge that gap? ; Therapist: Okay, so counseling can help you bridge that gap to communicate more effectively? ; Patient: Yeah, so I can, you know, so I can be even better. ; Patient: You know, I'm here, but I want to be like here. ; Therapist: Alright, so when you say you're here at the first level- Not first, but like, still more. ; Patient: Still more. ; Patient: Still more. ; Therapist: So like, where you are, tell me where you are currently in terms of how you perceive yourself, like how you look at yourself. ; Patient: Maybe like a seven, but I want to like blow it out of the park. ; Patient: You know, like if ten is here, I want to be higher than that. ; Therapist: How would you plan on accomplishing that? ; Patient: Well, you know, I'm always getting recruited for these really prestigious classes and to speak places and people are always calling. ; Patient: I have a really large social media presence, so people are constantly asking me for advice, you know, just about everything. ; Patient: Because, you know, I've just accomplished so much that I'm just, I can really help people because I just, you know, I've just been really lucky to just be good at so many things. ; Therapist: Okay, so it sounds like you have a lot of strengths. ; Patient: Yeah, yeah. ; Therapist: And that maybe from your understanding that people are just getting jealous because you seem to succeed in so many things. ; Patient: Yeah, you know, like sometimes people just, it's hard to admit that you're just not as good, or like you can't do it. ; Patient: Maybe people don't want to admit that and I think I make them uncomfortable because I can. ; Therapist: So counseling will help you to relate to them in a way that, so how would they, in a more productive way, how would they describe you, you know, given this level of difference that you're talking about, how would they describe you if I were to ask them, if I could ask them, could you describe Sam what they say? ; Patient: I think they would say that I have a lot of people that look up to me, that I'm excellent at my job, that, you know, like I should really be vice president, if not president, but I mean I don't own the company, but I should really have a more significant position. ; Patient: That a lot of the presentations that are happening that I could probably do, but they don't want to, you know, other people need opportunities, but it would be clear for everyone if I just did them. ; Therapist: It would be easier? ; Patient: Yeah, you know, easier, better, more people, it would just be, it would be a great presentation if I did it, so it would just cut away all the other stuff. ; Therapist: All the other stuff, that's what your co-workers would include? ; Patient: Yeah, yeah. ; Therapist: Things that maybe detract from the... ; Patient: Right, like if, you know, if I was doing the sales pitches, we would blow it out of the park. ; Patient: I mean, we'd be multi-millionaires by now. ; Patient: So, you know, it would get rid of all that, you know, the grunt work type of stuff if I just did it myself. ; Therapist: Does it frustrate you that you're not called on for every task? ; Therapist: Are you not recognized? ; Patient: Sometimes, but I've gotten really good at reminding people that they should be calling on me for every task, because, you know, sometimes you just have to show them, you know, I'm better than that person or I could do it better, and I'm really good at that type of communication, so I've been able to secure a lot of positions that weren't given to me at first because they realize, like, oh, she's better at it. ; Therapist: So they can see your talent. ; Therapist: So they recognize you much of the time? ; Patient: I mean, most of the time. ; Patient: Most of the time. ; Patient: Yeah, definitely. ; Therapist: How long have you been with this particular employer? ; Patient: Maybe like six months. ; Patient: Six months. ; Patient: Maybe eight. ; Therapist: Eight months, okay. ; Therapist: Can you tell me about the job you had prior, like what happened there?
