; Patient: I outgrew them. ; Patient: So I got it to a really, you know, large leadership position, and then, you know, the other VP couldn't really see what I was going for. ; Patient: She couldn't relate to me, and she, you know, she wasn't from the same type of like collegiate background, so that was kind of an issue. ; Patient: So I just outgrew what they had to offer, and then this company came in and made this tremendous offer with, you know, it was just fantastic. ; Patient: So I just had to make a move that was more strategic for me, and, you know, that I could even reach more. ; Patient: You know, I didn't want to be satisfied there. ; Therapist: You wanted to shoot higher. ; Therapist: You wanted to accomplish something greater. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And you still wanted to. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I want to be remembered, legendary, you know. ; Patient: I want my name to be out there. ; Patient: It's already out there, but more so. ; Patient: But more so. ; Therapist: More so. ; Therapist: You've already achieved some level of popularity. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: More than most people my age. ; Therapist: More than most people your age, and you really want to take it further. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: You know, like even with like my social media platforms or whatever, people really rely on what I have to say, you know. ; Patient: So the more people that are following me, the more people that are with me, you know, that's what I need. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So your last employer, the one before the place you work now, you just outgrew that. ; Therapist: Can you tell me how that interaction went? ; Patient: Like did you quit or did they kind of encourage you to leave? ; Therapist: Like what happened kind of at the last moments of that job? ; Patient: Well, I mean, I mean I quit. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I mean like, yeah, I quit. ; Patient: I was the one that initiated that. ; Patient: I mean they had some issues, but I was the one that initiated it because I needed to go elsewhere. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So you initiated it and you quit. ; Patient: At the same time, they had a few issues. ; Therapist: What type of issues did they have? ; Patient: They just said I talked too much or something like that or I think there was an issue with somebody I was working with or something. ; Patient: But it was really, it was another situation that just didn't, we just weren't communicating well. ; Patient: But in the end, I had to do what was best for me. ; Patient: So, because afterwards they were calling me and trying to get me back, but I was already here, so I wasn't going to go back there. ; Therapist: So after you quit, they pursued you to come work for them again? ; Patient: Yeah, which I told them was going to happen. ; Therapist: You had predicted that when you left? ; Patient: Yeah, yeah. ; Patient: I was like, you're going to miss me because I'm the reason this company is flourishing. ; Therapist: So what did you tell them when they offered you the job back? ; Patient: That I was, had gotten a phenomenal job and it was way better and that they lost it and they could just deal with it. ; Therapist: So you rejected them at that point? ; Patient: Oh yeah. ; Therapist: So, you feel as though you could benefit from the counseling here to better relate to people who are different levels, different ability levels? ; Patient: Yeah, and I, you know, I want to make my boss happy, but I feel like it would be good, you know, I don't want to make people feel bad because they're inferior to me and because they're not as successful, so if I could learn how to, you know, talk with them so that I'm not, you know, so they don't feel bad about themselves. ; Therapist: Is your boss putting, I mean, she encouraged you to come here today. ; Therapist: Is she putting any pressure on you? ; Therapist: Like, is this something that's strongly encouraged, mandatory? ; Patient: I think it's, I think it's strongly encouraged, but I think she has a promotion for me in mind, so it's probably just to set me up for that. ; Patient: So she's trying to help you for the future for another advancement. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So Sam, I'm going to get you on the calendar as to see a counselor. ; Therapist: I'm hoping later this week. ; Therapist: Does that work for you? ; Patient: Yeah, okay. ; Therapist: That does? ; Therapist: Are you sure? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So I'll get you set up for that. ; Therapist: I really appreciate you taking the time with me. ; Therapist: It was helpful. ; Therapist: We'll get you into see a counselor and we'll go from there. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Thanks. ; Patient: Thank you.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name sam; sex- male ; Clinical Identifiers: Counseling agency ; Referral Information : Referred by office ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Increased sense of self importance 2. Feelings of envy from others 3. Fantasies about having power ; History: Personal history occupation history- patient earlier quit his job as he felt that he outgrew his colleagues ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behavior patient was cordial and rapport could be established; speech productivity- increased; thought content- reflected grandiose self esteem; judgement- social impaired ; Psychotherapy Type: Mode individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Active listening ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patient is unable to work in a team as he feels superior to his other colleagues. He was encouraged to take therapy by his head. He is seeking therapy to improve his communication skills when people are inferior to him and to make his boss happy. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: F60. 81 narcissistic personality disorder ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: Within a week

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Andy, do you want to come on in and have a seat? ; Therapist: I'm Dr Taylor, I'm the on-call psychiatrist for this afternoon. ; Therapist: I got a call this morning from your family doctor, because I think you went to see him this morning along with your mum, and I gather that things have been a little bit difficult for you, you've had some other distressing experiences, so I think your doctor thought it might be helpful for us to have a bit of a discussion about that, to see if I could help. ; Therapist: Would that be alright with you? ; Patient: No, it's fine. ; Therapist: Would it be alright Andy for you to tell me a little bit about what's been going on? ; Patient: Well, you're going to think it sounds stupid, but my housemates are working for MI5, and they're doing stuff to my brain, and they're out to get me. ; Therapist: OK, that must be very difficult for you. ; Therapist: How long has this been going on for Andy? ; Patient: About two months. ; Therapist: And how did you first work out that this was happening? ; Patient: I came home one time and moved the TV to the other side of the room, and I knew then. ; Therapist: What was it that you knew at that moment? ; Patient: That they were for MI5. ; Therapist: Right, OK. ; Therapist: So it's been going on a couple of months? ; Patient: Yeah, this new lecturer started at uni, and he worked for MI5, and he basically drafted me housemates in, turned them against me. ; Therapist: OK, OK. ; Therapist: Now I've noticed a couple of times while we've been talking that you've sort of looked round you into the room as if you're checking for something. ; Therapist: Could I ask you what's happening at those times? ; Patient: Well, I can hear them talking about me. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: Who is it you can hear? ; Patient: My housemates. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: So that you recognise it as their voices? ; Patient: Yeah, I can hear them all the time. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: How many voices can you hear, Andy? ; Patient: Three, there's three of them. ; Therapist: OK, and do they sound real, like my voice sounds, talking to you now? ; Patient: Yeah, it's odd. ; Patient: It's like I can hear them when they're not here. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: So when they're not in the house with you? ; Patient: Yeah, it's like they're in the other room or something. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: And can you hear what they're actually saying? ; Patient: Yeah, they're talking about me. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: They're always talking about me. ; Patient: They're always commenting on everything that I'm doing. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: Can you give me an example of what they would say? ; Patient: Well, like if I'm packing me back to go to uni or something, they'll comment on that, like you've left the house now. ; Therapist: OK. ; Patient: OK. ; Therapist: Anything else? ; Therapist: Do they ever talk to each other, perhaps, about you? ; Patient: Yeah, that's what they do. ; Patient: I mean, and now they know the sort of twig that I know about them now. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: They're saying like I'm making trouble. ; Therapist: OK. ; Patient: And that they're going to sort me out. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: What about actually talking directly to you in the way that I'm talking to you now? ; Therapist: Does that ever happen, Andy? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: So you've been hearing the voices of your housemates. ; Therapist: Have there been any other changes? ; Therapist: Have there been any changes, perhaps, to the way you're thinking? ; Therapist: Sometimes people tell us that they're thinking changes in some way. ; Therapist: So, for example, they might feel that they're getting thoughts put into their head that aren't their own. ; Therapist: Have you had any experiences like that? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I do think things that aren't me. ; Patient: OK. ; Patient: Like they're putting stuff in my brain. ; Patient: It's not me. ; Patient: I'm not thinking. ; Patient: So different thoughts in your brain. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: It's stupid stuff as well. ; Patient: It's like the other day I suddenly just started thinking about some woman in Carnation Street. ; Patient: I don't watch any of that crap. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: It's not your kind of thing normally. ; Patient: They're not my thoughts. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: And do you have any idea how that's happening? ; Therapist: Or who's responsible? ; Patient: It's MI5. ; Patient: It's this chip they're putting in my head. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: OK. ; Patient: And I can feel it all the time. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: So you're getting thoughts put into your brain that aren't your own. ; Therapist: What about a different sort of experience? ; Therapist: What about the experience that somehow other people are able to know what you're thinking even though you haven't actually told them? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: Nothing like that? ; Patient: They're just putting stuff in my head. ; Therapist: Just putting stuff. ; Therapist: And can I just check Andy as well that you're not getting the experience when your thoughts just stop altogether like you have no thoughts left? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: If anything, there's too much in there. ; Patient: I wish I could unplug it. ; Patient: OK. ; Patient: OK. ; Patient: Just get this thing out of my head. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: And you mentioned this chip or this device in your brain. ; Therapist: Do you want to tell me a bit more about that? ; Patient: Well, it's a tracking device so they know where I am at all times and I can feel it moving around, like rotating around. ; Therapist: So you can feel the physical sensation in your brain? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: That must be very difficult for you. ; Patient: I don't know why they're doing this to me. ; Patient: I've done nothing wrong. ; Patient: OK. ; Therapist: Can I just check? ; Therapist: Are there any problems, Andy, with the rest of your body? ; Therapist: Any changes in sensation or any bits that feel different in any way? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: I feel fine. ; Patient: I'm not ill or anything. ; Patient: I just want this thing out of my head. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: It sounds like a very difficult time for you. ; Therapist: Can I ask you, Andy, how are you coping with all this? ; Therapist: How is it affecting you? ; Patient: Well, I know we're leaving my room much and I sort of have to wait until they go out to go down and get some food. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: But they've been doing stuff to my food now. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: What do you think is happening to your food? ; Patient: The poison in it. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: Are you actually eating much at the moment? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: Now, with all this happening, and this sounds like you don't feel very safe, have I got that right? ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: Have you felt the need, I don't know, to take steps to protect yourself in any way? ; Patient: Well, I've got a knife. ; Patient: OK. ; Patient: And I've got like a baseball bat. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: It's just in case they get in my room. ; Patient: I just don't want to hurt anyone. ; Patient: I just feel like I've got to protect myself. ; Patient: It's like cornering me to do this. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: Have you felt the need to use either the knife or the baseball bat so far? ; Therapist: I'll take it out with you for protection. ; Patient: No. ; Patient: No, I don't want to get caught. ; Patient: OK. ; Patient: No. ; Patient: It's just in my room. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: Has it ever got so bad, Andy, that you've felt the need to hurt yourself or even kill yourself as the only way out, the only way of coping with this? ; Patient: Well, I thought about getting some pills, but I couldn't leave the house, so I didn't get anything. ; Therapist: And when you say getting some pills, would that be to take an overdose of tablets? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: But you've not actually done anything about that so far. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: In the past, have you ever had any problems either with your temper or getting into fights, being aggressive, either with your housemates or anybody else? ; Patient: No, I'm not that kind of person. ; Patient: I don't want to hurt anybody. ; Patient: They're just driving me to this. ; Therapist: And can I just check again? ; Therapist: You've not been in trouble with the police or anything like that? ; Therapist: No, never. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: With all this that's going on, is there anywhere at the moment, Andy, that you feel safe? ; Patient: My parents' house. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: And have you seen much of your parents recently? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I thought about going back there, but I don't want to drag them into this. ; Patient: I don't want them or if I've known about them. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: And throughout this last couple of months, when you've had all these worries, have you ever worried that your parents might in some way be involved in this? ; Therapist: I thought about it, but no. ; Patient: OK. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: Can I just check out a couple of background things with you, Andy? ; Therapist: You're general health. ; Therapist: Is that OK? ; Therapist: You generally fit and well? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: I'm not ill. ; Patient: There's nothing wrong with me. ; Patient: It's just this thing in my head. ; Therapist: And you're not on any regular medication from your own doctor at this stage? ; Patient: No, I don't take any pills. ; Patient: OK. ; Therapist: What about other drugs? ; Therapist: And by that I'm meaning alcohol, cannabis, pills, anything else? ; Patient: I don't drink much alcohol. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: And what about drugs like cannabis? ; Patient: Is my mum going to know about this? ; Therapist: No, I think it's something that's important that I hear about, but this wouldn't be something we'd be discussing with your mum. ; Patient: I smoke a bit of weed. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: Would that be regularly for most days? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And how much would you be spending on weed? ; Patient: I get like a ten bag, it lasts me a day or so. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: So you have a ten bag lasting you a day of weed. ; Therapist: Any other drugs? ; Therapist: I'm thinking in particular things like speed or pills. ; Patient: I've done a bit of speed. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: Is that on a regular basis, Andy? ; Patient: I was grabbing my mates for the weekend, we'd do a bit, but... ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: When was the last time, Andy, that you would have had any speed? ; Patient: About a week or so ago. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: Any other drugs at all? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: No. ; Patient: No. ; Patient: But I know what you're getting at, though. ; Patient: It's not the drugs. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: This is... It doesn't matter how out my face I get, this is constantly there, it's always there. ; Patient: OK. ; Therapist: I guess the reason I was checking, I think is what you've picked up on, is that sometimes when people are having the kinds of experiences that you are, they find if they take certain drugs it can make things feel a lot worse. ; Therapist: I just wanted to check if that hadn't been your experience. ; Therapist: No. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: I appreciate from what you're saying that you're really very worried about this MI5 conspiracy and that that's the cause of the difficulties that you're having at the moment. ; Therapist: I just wanted to check with you. ; Therapist: Do you think it could be due to anything else? ; Therapist: I mean, I've obviously met other people who've had similar experiences and sometimes they're extremely stressed, some people might be actually mentally unwell. ; Therapist: And just whether any of these things might be relevant to you at the moment? ; Patient: No, because I'm not ill. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: It's them and I've read books on this as well. ; Patient: I don't... The government know about them. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: They know that they do this to loads of people. ; Patient: I don't know how they can get away with it. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: I've done nothing wrong. ; Patient: I don't know why they're doing this to me. ; Patient: OK. ; Therapist: I just want it... I just want it to stop. ; Patient: OK. ; Patient: Sure. ; Patient: And I think I can appreciate that. ; Therapist: I guess what I'm wondering is whether you think there's anything that someone like me might be able to do to help you as a doctor that sometimes meeting with someone like I've met with someone who's been in the hospital for a long time, I think, is a really important thing. ; Therapist: Meeting with someone like a psychiatrist or having medication or for some people even coming into hospital for a short time might be helpful. ; Therapist: Do you think any of those things would help you at the moment? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: I mean, I'm only here really because of my mum. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: I tried to... I don't want to worry her. ; Patient: I've tried to talk to her about it and she doesn't understand. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: She doesn't really believe me. ; Patient: I mean... ; Patient: Do you believe me? ; Therapist: Well, I certainly believe that you're having a really difficult time at the moment. ; Therapist: I guess what I'm not as sure about is what's causing this and I'm less sure this is due to MI5. ; Therapist: I guess what I'm wondering is that perhaps you're not as well as you might be at the moment. ; Therapist: I mean, we've been through a lot of questions and what I'm thinking is we need to try and come up with a way of supporting you through this. ; Therapist: So I'm wondering, because I know your mum is... I think she's waiting in the waiting room. ; Therapist: It might be a good chance now to get your mum in and then perhaps the three of us can put our heads together, have a bit of a discussion about where to go from here and try and think of getting you some proper support. ; Therapist: Would that be alright if I got your mum in? ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: If you want to sit there then, Andy, I'll just get your mum. ; Therapist: Okay.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name georgia; sex female; family members parents, sister and a dog ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Follow-up session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptom anxiety chief complaint 1 anxiety leaving for work 2 fear of leaving parents and dog at home 3 unable to go on trips 4 feels guilty ; History: Family history father has a history of heart attack. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior anxious; speech normal; mood  affect, thought disorganized; cognitive functions disturbed; judgement and insight judgement is poor and insight is intact ; Psychotherapy Type: Cbt; mode individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Reflective listening, cognitive restructuring, journaling, thought challenging. ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: There are few themes which are discussed in the session 1. Fear and anxiety patient has anxiety when she leaves home, be it for work or for short trips. She feels concerned about the well-being of her aging parents, and pets. She feels afraid of thinking potential negative events occurring while she is away, like her pet getting sick or her house being damaged. 2. Guilt and responsibility she always felt nervous to leave home since the time of her late teenage year as she feels guilty leaving their loved ones and pets behind and has a strong sense of responsibility for their well-being and fearing the consequences of not being there if something goes wrong. 3. Willingness to change patient is trying to engage in some adaptive responses, such as verbal reassurances to themselves and their pets, and making practical preparations before leaving like putting camera in the house. 4. Techniques therapist used cbt model where he tried to formalize and expanded upon her adaptive responses by consciously challenging automatic negative thoughts with deliberate, positive self-talk. She was encouraged to develop and practice these adaptive responses to reduce anxiety. 5. Action plan patient is advised to rate her anxiety levels before and after applying adaptive responses to assess their effectiveness over time which will help her to track her progress and determine the effectiveness of the intervention. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Anxiety ; Action Plan : Patient is advised to measure her anxiety levels before and after applying adaptive responses to see the effects in her behavior which will help her track progress and determine the effectiveness of the intervention. ; Next session details: Next session has scheduled.

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Daisy, how you're doing today? ; Patient: Not well. ; Therapist: Not well? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: What's going on? ; Patient: Well, remember I had told you that they were downsizing at my job. ; Therapist: I remember that. ; Patient: So I've been there 20 years at my job. ; Therapist: A long time. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: And they're downsizing lately and they let me go. ; Therapist: Well, that's terrible. ; Therapist: I'm sorry to hear that. ; Patient: Thanks. ; Therapist: Do you have any type of severance or anything like that? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: So yeah, it's just, you know, they let me go. ; Patient: I have really nothing to go on. ; Patient: I don't know what to do. ; Patient: I've been at that job so long. ; Patient: I really don't know how to do anything else. ; Therapist: You used to talk about that job. ; Therapist: You were happy there. ; Patient: Yeah, I was. ; Patient: I thought, you know, I envisioned doing that job forever, for a long time. ; Patient: So, you know. ; Therapist: And that's not going to happen now? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: How does this affect your financial outlook, like your bills and such? ; Patient: Oh, it's awful. ; Patient: I mean, we definitely, my husband and I, it's really spiraled out of control. ; Patient: My husband and I have kind of like joined. ; Patient: We pay the bills together and so this was half of our income and that's gone. ; Patient: And because it was kind of more sudden, we didn't really have time to do anything else. ; Patient: You know, time to prepare. ; Therapist: So it definitely caught you off guard. ; Therapist: Do you have enough income with your husband's job to cover your basic bills? ; Patient: We're a little bit behind. ; Therapist: A little bit behind? ; Patient: Yeah, so far. ; Patient: But if I don't find a job soon, then I don't know what's going to happen. ; Patient: I don't know how bad it's going to get. ; Therapist: Do you know about how long you have before you fail to meet any financial commitments? ; Patient: My husband usually deals with the bills, so I'm not quite sure. ; Patient: But probably in another month or so, it's going to get really bad. ; Therapist: About a month? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: What thoughts have you been having? ; Patient: All sorts. ; Patient: I mean, I worry that, you know, like my husband and I are arguing because we're under all this stress. ; Patient: I worry we're going to lose our house. ; Patient: You know, I'm worried about going to be homeless. ; Patient: You know, it's embarrassing. ; Patient: I don't have a job now. ; Patient: What if I don't find another job? ; Patient: You know, what are my kids going to do? ; Patient: My kids are, you know, relying on us to meet their needs. ; Therapist: They depend on you. ; Patient: Yeah, so I mean, we could be homeless. ; Patient: I might not ever get a job again. ; Patient: You know, I'm not getting any younger. ; Patient: So I just, I'm afraid that I won't get another job. ; Therapist: Now you said you were laid off, right? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: From the position. ; Therapist: Are you eligible for an unemployment? ; Patient: I'm not sure. ; Patient: I'm still looking into that. ; Therapist: Because if you were, I mean, I'm not a labor law expert. ; Therapist: I think if you're laid off, there's probably a decent probability you could get unemployment. ; Therapist: How much of your education are you? ; Patient: I just have my bachelor's. ; Therapist: Well, that's more than most, right? ; Therapist: Your bachelor's degree. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: You just haven't had to look for a job in a long time. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: 20 years, right? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: Because I'm guessing you thought you were going to retire. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: There, right. ; Therapist: So this is upsetting for a lot of reasons. ; Therapist: So you have the financial stressors, right? ; Therapist: That can't be minimized. ; Therapist: The relational stressors. ; Therapist: You mentioned it's kind of embarrassing. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So it's more like an identity thing, right? ; Therapist: So you identify with what you did. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: And now you don't as much because you're not actively working on it. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Did you ever have any coworkers who voluntarily left for other jobs? ; Patient: Not that I know of. ; Therapist: Not the time you worked there? ; Patient: Not that I was aware of. ; Patient: I don't think. ; Patient: Maybe like one a while ago, but it was a pretty good job, so. ; Therapist: So a lot of people stayed. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Have you ever known anybody who worked for a similar company or in the same field who changed jobs? ; Patient: Yeah, one of my friends was in a similar field and left the job and eventually found another job. ; Therapist: Yeah, how long it took them? ; Patient: It took a while. ; Patient: It took a while. ; Patient: Like maybe like two years or so at least. ; Therapist: A long while. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: It was a struggle for their family, so I think about that. ; Therapist: Would you need to replace that full income to pay your bills or part of that income? ; Patient: I mean, probably part of it. ; Patient: Maybe full would be ideal because, you know, we were comfortable the way we were living. ; Patient: So full would be ideal, but, you know, we could probably survive on part of it. ; Patient: It's just not as well as we were living. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So we've talked about problem solving skills before in earlier sessions, right? ; Therapist: So have you applied any of those concepts to what's going on now? ; Patient: I mean, I've been trying to think of, you know, different opportunities that might be open to me now and, you know, being able to spend more time with my kids and things like that. ; Patient: I've been trying to think of it other ways, my situation. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So there's an upside in that sense, the time part. ; Therapist: At some point you need to replace the income. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: It's very pragmatic. ; Therapist: You need the money. ; Therapist: Have you considered that if you attempted to seek a full time job, didn't work out, you could look at part time jobs? ; Patient: I've thought about it, but I'm really having a hard time with it. ; Therapist: What would it mean about you, what would it say about you if you had to take a part time job instead of finding another full time job that's so much of the one you lost? ; Patient: What would it mean about me? ; Therapist: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: That I think if I only had a part time job that I wasn't qualified, that I wasn't good enough for a full time job. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So you would internalize that and the meaning would be that you're not as valuable? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So it speaks to self worth. ; Therapist: That kind of thinking we've talked about before, right, in other situations can impede you trying to meet your goal. ; Therapist: So what do you do when you're feeling not worthy, when you're feeling worthless? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: What do you do? ; Patient: Well, right now it's not going well. ; Patient: I mean, I've been arguing with my husband. ; Patient: I've been drinking a lot more. ; Patient: You know, the depression has come back a lot worse. ; Patient: So it's just starting to become this cycle where I'm drinking and getting into arguments and situations are not getting better and it just keeps snowballing. ; Therapist: Keeps snowballing. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And these behaviors are all things that potentially could impede your goal. ; Therapist: So in a way, there's kind of like a self-fulfilling prophecy element to this. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: You agonize, you worry, invest in these thoughts. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: And then to temporarily take away the pain you drink that ends up in more dysfunction, right, with the relationship with your husband. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: I imagine if you're intoxicated, you're not looking for new work. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: That wouldn't be ideal timing. ; Therapist: So in a sense, you're not helping things to improve and it all kind of starts with that thinking. ; Patient: But it's hard when I'm really depressed and the situation's not getting better and I'm just home sitting about drinking while everyone else is carrying on with their life and I'm stuck here. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: And that ties into that kind of worthless type thought, right? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So you're fulfilling that role of being worthless. ; Therapist: That's how it's manifesting for you. ; Therapist: And that's one thing you can do. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: That's an option. ; Therapist: You can drink and you can have relational struggles. ; Therapist: But is that really what you want out of all this? ; Therapist: Is that the most useful? ; Patient: No, I know it's not helping. ; Therapist: How do you think you could break that cycle? ; Patient: I've been thinking about trying to get more organized, like we talked about before with the finances, and trying to figure out exactly how much income we need to be where we want, but to do it maybe by baby steps. ; Patient: So it's not so overwhelming for me, this thought of getting a new job and making enough money and providing for my family. ; Patient: It's kind of like breaking it down. ; Therapist: Well, that makes sense. ; Therapist: So your first step would be figuring out what's the minimum amount you really need. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: So you'll shoot for hire, you'll go for it full time, but you realize that you kind of need to know what the minimum is because you know what job offer you could accept and what job offer you'd have to decline. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: So that makes sense. ; Therapist: So armed with that information, then you could go out to the workplace. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: And maybe with a little less anxiety, kind of just know, well, this job's going to, if I get it, that's good. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: Or I might as well not apply to this one because it's not going to work. ; Therapist: So it's efficient, it's time-saving. ; Therapist: It's good. ; Therapist: That sounds logical. ; Therapist: What do you think could get in the way of those steps? ; Therapist: What obstacles are you seeing? ; Patient: I think just sometimes like the fear of the unknown, like worry about what if this never happens for me? ; Patient: You know, what if I don't get a job? ; Patient: You know, what if we lose our house? ; Patient: What if? ; Therapist: That worry's nagging. ; Patient: What if? ; Therapist: Yeah, that worry's nagging. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So I think it's pretty likely that with a bachelor's degree, in the background we've talked about other sessions, that you'll get a job. ; Therapist: Let's go with the scenario that you don't. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: And with the understanding that's a pretty low probability event. ; Therapist: Let's just say, okay, what happens then? ; Therapist: Say you never find another job. ; Therapist: That's the worst case. ; Therapist: Like we would agree that's the worst case. ; Patient: Yeah, it's pretty awful. ; Therapist: That's pretty awful. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: That's the worst case scenario. ; Therapist: Can't get any worse than that. ; Therapist: What would happen? ; Patient: I mean, worst case, if we don't get a job, I mean, we would probably, I don't know, like get a smaller house or find a way around it. ; Patient: I mean, we've been through some tough times. ; Therapist: It would be difficult, right? ; Therapist: To be fair, right? ; Therapist: It would be difficult, but you would adapt. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: So, like, it would be difficult, but I think if I really thought about it, you know, we would probably get through it. ; Therapist: So, if we pick up with that, if we say that's really an adaptive response. ; Therapist: Remember we talked about adaptive responses. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: To automatic thoughts, right? ; Therapist: So, if you're telling yourself that you have the depression and certain anxiety, the craving to drink, you tell yourself, well, the worst that could happen is I don't work for the rest of my life. ; Therapist: Again, acknowledging that's pretty unlikely, right? ; Therapist: But the worst that could happen is I won't work again, and I might have to adapt. ; Therapist: I might have to have a simpler life in terms of material goods and a smaller house, but I would survive. ; Therapist: What effect might that have on your mood or your thoughts? ; Patient: I mean, I think when I really think about it, you know, like you said, I think I'm less depressed or think that I'm more able to cope with it, you know, knowing, okay, well, this is the worst that could happen, but maybe it's not as bad as I thought it would be in my head. ; Therapist: So, there's a piece that comes with clarity that comes with accepting what the worst case scenario could be. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: And probably another part of the adaptive response could be, you know, I could live through the worst case scenario, but I think it's important though to acknowledge that it's unlikely. ; Therapist: That's still unlikely. ; Therapist: So, statistics, probability is on your side here. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: So, as you go out into the workplace, the workforce and seek employment, you'll probably have some interviews where you don't get job offers, right? ; Therapist: But eventually, you'll find out when you do. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: It's just math. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: If you can accept the worst case, then maybe reduce or eliminate that alcohol consumption, maybe reduce that depression, reduce that anxiety. ; Therapist: Does that make sense? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: It makes a lot of sense. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So, let's end there for today, but I want you to try for the next week, I want you to try applying that adaptive response. ; Therapist: Actually, there's two we talked about, right? ; Therapist: One is you could survive the worst case scenario. ; Therapist: Another one is that probabilistically, it won't happen. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: So, you have kind of two, well, you do have two adaptive responses I want you to apply. ; Therapist: When those automatic thoughts come up, like, I'm never going to work again. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: This is a catastrophe. ; Patient: So, like that self-talk. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Apply that self-talk. ; Therapist: So, identify that automatic thought, because we talked about that skill, right? ; Therapist: And then apply that self-talk right away. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: And let's see, you have the thought record? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So, when that, you know, when you can, fill one of those out, okay, when that happens. ; Therapist: When you have the automatic thought, then you apply the adaptive response. ; Therapist: Even if you can't get it completely filled out, I understand that. ; Therapist: I know there's a lot on there. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Just what you can get done on that. ; Therapist: Anything you can do on that would be helpful. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Does that sound good? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So, I'll schedule you for one week, okay? ; Therapist: So, I'll see you then. ; Therapist: We'll see how this goes. ; Therapist: See what progress we can make on this, on the alcohol, on the depression and anxiety. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Thanks.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name daisy; sex female; education graduation; occupation unemployed; marital history married ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Follow up session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Low mood 2. Feelings of worthlessness 4. Apprehension about future 3. Increased alcohol consumption precipitating factor job loss; associated disturbance argument with spouse ; History: Present history patient had been working in a company for 20 years and was well settled in this job. Her company downsized hence, she was made to leave. She has been under under unemployment stress as she is unable to manage her finances and her children are still dependent on the couple; past history patient was diagnosed with depression; substance use history she has engaged in frequent alcohol consumption ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behavior patient was cordial and rapport could be established; mood tensed; affect restricted; thought content- reflected her stress regarding job loss and associated low self worth ; Psychotherapy Type: Type cbt; mode individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Cognitive restructuring ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patient recently lost her job which has made her feel stressed. Her alcohol consumption has also increased and she engaged in frequent arguments with her husband. She was made aware of her cognitive distortions during the session and a more active approach towards problem solving was adopted. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Nil ; Action Plan : Maintain thought records ; Next session details: After 1 week

dialogue: Therapist: you worry a lot about how you come across in social situations. ; Patient: Yeah, it really makes me feel really anxious, like what I look like and what people are thinking. ; Therapist: Yeah, you said that you worry that you visibly shake. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Are there any other things that you worry that people will notice? ; Patient: I think obviously the shaking, I think my hands and legs shaking and kind of going really red and sweating and just looking really weird. ; Therapist: So it sounds like you have quite a strong mental image of how you see yourself when you're in these social situations. ; Patient: Yeah, definitely. ; Therapist: So you go red, you shake. ; Therapist: Is there anything else that you think that you do? ; Therapist: I mean, describe yourself. ; Therapist: How do you think you look when you're in these situations? ; Patient: Just like, I think I just look really obviously weird and out of place and like really red and just visibly shaking and sweating and kind of not being able to communicate properly with people. ; Therapist: Is there anything that you do to try and kind of defend against these things to manage these problems? ; Patient: I guess like when I'm holding the camera, I just grip onto it really, really tight or I kind of clench on my muscles and just find something that I can focus on and to kind of try and make myself shake less and not go as red and stuff. ; Therapist: So you focus on something, you grip onto the camera. ; Therapist: Do you make eye contact with people? ; Patient: No, I just tend to just look down. ; Therapist: Okay, so you also avoid eye contact. ; Therapist: Is there anything else that you do to manage the sweating, for example? ; Patient: Just kind of looking down and wearing all black so it's less obvious or kind of wearing just more layers and all black so you just can't tell. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: What do you think would happen if you stopped doing these things, if you stopped gripping onto the camera or you start to make eye contact and not looking down? ; Therapist: What do you think would happen? ; Patient: I think it would be so much worse. ; Patient: I think I would just shake even more and be more anxious and look more obviously kind of weird and out of place. ; Therapist: What I'm thinking now is how do you feel about if we did an experiment to test out your thoughts on what would happen if you stopped doing these things? ; Therapist: If we did a bit of a role play where we pretended to enact a situation at work? ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: If we did this maybe twice in the first time, you do all the things that you normally do. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: You grip onto something, look down. ; Therapist: Is there anything else that you do when you're in these situations, these work conversations to try and cope? ; Patient: I just kind of fumble and kind of just clench whatever it is I'm holding just really tight and just make sure I don't make any eye contact. ; Patient: I'll just kind of get through it. ; Therapist: Okay, so in the first time I want you to do those things as much as you normally would. ; Therapist: In fact, maybe even slightly more than you normally would. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And then the second time I want you to drop doing those things altogether. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: How does that sound? ; Patient: I'll try my best. ; Therapist: How would you feel about if we filmed this so you could actually see what you looked like? ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Do you have a camera with you that we could video on? ; Patient: Yeah, is my phone okay? ; Therapist: Yeah, we'll use that in just a sec. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Before we do this then, we're just going to fill out this form. ; Therapist: What we're doing now is an experiment. ; Therapist: We call it a behavioural experiment to see what happens when you change the way that you're behaving. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: Okay, so the first column says I need to fill out an experiment to test this thought that you have. ; Therapist: So our experiment is going to be that we do a conversation at work. ; Therapist: Who should I play? ; Therapist: If you're playing yourself in this role play, who should I be? ; Patient: Maybe like a client at work. ; Patient: At work I always have to sit down with clients before we do the shoot and get to know a little bit more about what they want. ; Therapist: Okay, so would it work if I was maybe having a wedding and I was hiring you to be a wedding photographer? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: What kind of problems do you see coming up in this conversation that we have? ; Therapist: Like what will you see yourself doing on camera? ; Patient: Shaking, like being really obviously shaking and bright red. ; Therapist: Okay, so visibly shaking. ; Therapist: So how much will you be shaking? ; Therapist: If 100 is like shaking uncontrollably and zero is not shaking at all, how visibly shaking will you be? ; Patient: 90 ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Sorry, what was the other thing that you just said? ; Patient: Like I go really red. ; Therapist: Okay, so you're going to go red? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: How red will you go? ; Therapist: I mean if we look around this room. ; Patient: Probably like the chairs. ; Therapist: Okay, so you're going to be as kind of brightly pink as these chairs are? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay, so out of 100 then how pink would you say these chairs are? ; Patient: 90 out of 100. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: What else are you worried is going to happen when we have these conversations? ; Patient: Just worried I'll say something stupid and not be able to kind of get what I'm trying to say across properly. ; Therapist: Okay, and how stupid out of 100 if 100 is ridiculously stupid? ; Patient: Probably like similar 90 I'd say. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: What else are you worried will happen when we have this conversation? ; Therapist: What else might you see on the camera? ; Patient: I think you'll probably be able to see that I'm a bit sweating and... ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And how much will you be sweating? ; Patient: Again, 90 I think. ; Therapist: Like visibly sweating down the face? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And what do you think will happen the second time around when you stop kind of doing the things you normally do to cope when you maybe start to make eye contact and you're not gripping onto something? ; Patient: I think it'll be even worse. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: How much worse? ; Therapist: Slightly worse. ; Therapist: Like twice as bad. ; Patient: Twice as bad. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Right, can you give me your phone and we'll... ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Should I just use this? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: It's probably best. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Hi. ; Therapist: So I was just wondering if I could talk to you about maybe doing my wedding photography. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: What kind of, kind of, what kind of things do you see? ; Patient: How do you want it to be like? ; Therapist: I suppose I'd like lots of shots of our family and our friends. ; Therapist: Quite a lot of natural shots. ; Therapist: You know, people talking when they're having drinks. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: Do you want it, like, do you kind of see it being outside? ; Patient: Is that something that you're interested in? ; Patient: Outside shots? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: It's going to be a summer wedding. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So we'd quite like a lot of outdoors shots. ; Therapist: If possible, you know, if it's not raining, that would be quite nice. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Quite some arty ones if that's possible. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah, that would be, I've done quite a few things like that before. ; Therapist: Have you got anything that you could show me about your past work? ; Patient: Yeah, I recently did some shoots outside, kind of in like a wood environment, so that I could show you that maybe it would kind of help with some ideas. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Great. ; Therapist: Right, let's do the second one now. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay, you ready to put down the bottle and just to make eye contact? ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Hi, so I was just wondering if I could speak to you about doing my wedding photography? ; Patient: Yeah, yeah. ; Patient: What kind of thing are you looking at? ; Patient: How do you want it to be like? ; Therapist: I'd like kind of lots of shots of family and friends and quite a lot of natural shots, you know. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: Are you interested in having things outside maybe? ; Patient: I know you said you wanted it to be natural. ; Therapist: Yeah, because it's going to be a summer wedding and, you know, weather dependent, of course. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: It would be really great if we could kind of get lots of shots, you know, outdoors. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Yeah, people chatting and maybe some quite arty ones as well. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Have you got anything that you could show me about your past work? ; Patient: Yeah, actually it's kind of a lot of the things I do are outside and I'm really interested in getting natural shots. ; Patient: So I could show you some of my work and we could kind of see if we could kind of develop something from that. ; Patient: Could be quite good. ; Therapist: Okay, let's pause it there. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Right, I'm just going to give you this back now to look at. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And I just want you to watch that. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And then we'll chat about it in a moment. ; Patient: Okay. ; Patient: It's weird seeing it. ; Therapist: So if we just go back to the things that you predicted then. ; Therapist: You said that you thought you were going to shake, visibly shake. ; Therapist: Could you see yourself shaking on the video? ; Patient: Definitely not as much as I thought. ; Patient: I think it's obvious that I'm obviously quite anxious but I don't think you can tell I'm shaking that much. ; Therapist: So you said that you were going to shake 90 out of 100. ; Therapist: How much shaking would you say that you saw there in the end? ; Patient: Maybe like less than 30. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: You said that you were going to go red or pink, as pink as these chairs, 90 out of 100. ; Therapist: Did you notice yourself going pink? ; Patient: Not really. ; Therapist: Actually definitely less than I thought. ; Therapist: Yeah, not as much. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: You said that you were worried that you were going to say something stupid. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: 90 out of 100. ; Therapist: Did you notice yourself say anything stupid? ; Patient: Not really. ; Patient: Yeah, I thought it was going to be a lot worse than actually it was. ; Therapist: So you thought you were going to say something that was 90% stupid. ; Therapist: That's really quite strong. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: In the end, did you pick up anything that, so could we maybe put that as a zero? ; Patient: Maybe like less than 10 maybe. ; Therapist: You said that you thought you were going to be sweating. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And that you were going to be visibly sweating. ; Therapist: Did you notice yourself sweating in the end? ; Patient: Not really. ; Patient: Definitely not as bad as I thought. ; Therapist: Again, you thought you were going to be like 90 out of 100, like seriously visibly sweating. ; Therapist: So what score would you actually give it in the end? ; Patient: Maybe again, less than 10. ; Patient: I don't think you could tell at all. ; Therapist: You also said that you thought it was going to be twice as bad when you stopped using your normal strategies. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: What did you notice watching that video? ; Patient: It was actually probably better when I wasn't doing any of those things. ; Patient: I think I looked a lot more natural and I was able to say what I was trying to say. ; Patient: I think I'd just come across more personable when I'm not kind of looking down and stuff.
summary: Patient Particulars : Nil ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: This session seems like a follow-up session as there is no details of initial introductory conversation between both the parties. Also, there is no information regarding the last session as well. ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptom anxiety majorly in social situations. Chief complaints 1. Sweating, 2. Body shaking 3. Heat in body which makes him visibly red, 4. Body stiffness clench. ; History: Nil ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance and behaviour there is no description of patients appearance in this session. He seemed cooperative and attentive. Its difficult to say through only transcripts as the therapist is trying to know the details of his social anxiety and fears around it. He seems more interested in knowing his cognition and his own mental image about himself than his current experience especially in the initial part of the session; speech patients speech was fluent and coherent as he was replying and obeying to what therapist was saying regarding the experiment; mood and affect as per this transcript its hard to say about his mood and affect, though he sounds concerned and embarrassed about his current problems he is facing in social situations; thought thoughts are coherent and logical; perception the individual holds a negative self-perception, believing they appear weird and out of place in social situations. They worry about appearing visibly anxious and fear saying something stupid; cognitive functions his attention span and concentration seems fine. He had an orientation of time and space. His memory also seems fine; judgement and insight he has an insight of his problem as he is able to explain all the details and understands it very well. His judgement is poor as its quite difficult for him to separate himself from his own imagined reality where he feels that if he wont clench his body then people will find him weird, out of the place and will see will his disturbed condition. ; Psychotherapy Type: Type cbt; mode individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : 1 reflective listening therapist is trying to give back whatever the patient is saying and making him think and listen to what he is saying. 2 thought challenging- here therapist tried to challenge his thought about his experience of anxiety and asked him to participate in the experiment to see whether he can experience any change in his body. 3 cognitive restructuring- here after the experiment, therapist pointed out a change in his behaviour during the experiment and asked him to rate his anxiety again which helped in restructuring his cognition. ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: There are few issues discussed in the session which are as follows 1. Social anxiety the first theme can be seen is that the patient experiences significant anxiety about how they come across in social situations, particularly at work. This anxiety manifests in physical symptoms such as shaking, sweating, and blushing. 2. Behavioural experiment the therapist introduced an experiment to challenge patients beliefs about their social performance in which they do a role play of a work conversation twice, once with their usual coping mechanisms and once without using anything. 3. Reality check this experiment helped him to challenge his reality and see it objectively. It was discovered that his anxiety symptoms are less severe than anticipated and that he can engage in a conversation more naturally when he tries to minimise or stops his coping strategies. 4. Changed perception the video in the experiment made him see and reevaluates his perceptions of his performance. He can see a visible change in his anxiety and noticed that it was not as evident to others as he had feared. This made him realise that he can be more effective in his communication when he does not try to change or control himself. Copying mechanisms gripping onto objects tightly, avoiding eye contact, and wearing black clothes to hide sweating. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Social anxiety ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Well, let's talk about then how you ended up cutting yourself. ; Patient: I'm pretty obvious. ; Therapist: So what happened? ; Therapist: First of all, tell me what you did exactly. ; Patient: What do you mean what I did? ; Therapist: Well, I mean, where'd you cut yourself? ; Therapist: I know you said you cut yourself in a way. ; Patient: Same as always. ; Patient: Same as always. ; Therapist: On your arm? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Where'd you cut yourself with? ; Patient: A razor. ; Therapist: How deep? ; Patient: You want to see it? ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Let me see. ; Therapist: You know, those look to me like they, did you go to the, it doesn't look like you went and got any stitches, but that looks to me like you could have used them. ; Therapist: What do you think? ; Patient: I think if you've ever been to a ER when you cut yourself, you'll know why don't go. ; Therapist: OK, but part of the problem is those look deep and like you're going to have significant scars. ; Therapist: So my suggestion is in the future if you do it, is that you put some sort of bandaid on it to keep it closed. ; Therapist: But let's talk about how this happened. ; Therapist: First of all, tell me. ; Therapist: You were telling me on the phone that you wanted to die, but was this a suicide attempt or do you think it was just a cutting? ; Therapist: Were you thinking about killing yourself or wanting to kill yourself or wanting to die when you did it? ; Patient: I was thinking about killing myself. ; Patient: I thought you would help me and you didn't. ; Patient: That's what I want to talk about. ; Patient: I want to talk about how it is that my life is not going better and you are not helping me and you are not available to me when I need help. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: So it sounds like was me not being available to you related to you cutting yourself? ; Patient: I cut myself the first time. ; Patient: I called you thinking you would help me. ; Patient: You wouldn't help me. ; Patient: So then I figured, what the hell? ; Patient: I might as well just go all the way. ; Patient: And so that's why I cut myself that deep.
summary: Past Session Information: Follow -up ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms self harm and suicidal ideation chief complaints 1 breakdown 2 abandonment issues 3 self-harm ; Crisis Markers: Self-harm and suicidal ideations ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior disturbed; speech unclear, mood  affect sad and aggressive, thought negative, perception poor, cognitive functions distorted, judgement poor and insight intact ; Psychotherapy Type: Supportive; mode individual. ; Psychotherapy Technique : Supportive ; Issues discussed in Current Session: 1 problem patient has self-harm tendencies, use cutting, as a coping mechanism for dealing with emotional distress as she feels sense of betrayal and abandonment even by the counselor. She also breakdown in communication between the conversation in therapy 2 willingness patient shows a desire for support in addressing their emotional struggles. 3need for immediate intervention therapist sees the severity of the patients emotional crisis and their expressed intent to harm themselves necessitate immediate intervention to ensure their safety and provide appropriate mental health support. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Anxiety and sucidality

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Andy, do you want to come on in and have a seat? ; Therapist: I'm Dr Taylor, I'm the on-call psychiatrist for this afternoon. ; Therapist: I got a call this morning from your family doctor, because I think you went to see him this morning along with your mum, and I gather that things have been a little bit difficult for you, you've had some other distressing experiences, so I think your doctor thought it might be helpful for us to have a bit of a discussion about that, to see if I could help. ; Therapist: Would that be alright with you? ; Patient: No, it's fine. ; Therapist: Would it be alright Andy for you to tell me a little bit about what's been going on? ; Patient: Well, you're going to think it sounds stupid, but my housemates are working for MI5, and they're doing stuff to my brain, and they're out to get me. ; Therapist: OK, that must be very difficult for you. ; Therapist: How long has this been going on for Andy? ; Patient: About two months. ; Therapist: And how did you first work out that this was happening? ; Patient: I came home one time and moved the TV to the other side of the room, and I knew then. ; Therapist: What was it that you knew at that moment? ; Patient: That they were for MI5. ; Therapist: Right, OK. ; Therapist: So it's been going on a couple of months? ; Patient: Yeah, this new lecturer started at uni, and he worked for MI5, and he basically drafted me housemates in, turned them against me. ; Therapist: OK, OK. ; Therapist: Now I've noticed a couple of times while we've been talking that you've sort of looked round you into the room as if you're checking for something. ; Therapist: Could I ask you what's happening at those times? ; Patient: Well, I can hear them talking about me. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: Who is it you can hear? ; Patient: My housemates. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: So that you recognise it as their voices? ; Patient: Yeah, I can hear them all the time. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: How many voices can you hear, Andy? ; Patient: Three, there's three of them. ; Therapist: OK, and do they sound real, like my voice sounds, talking to you now? ; Patient: Yeah, it's odd. ; Patient: It's like I can hear them when they're not here. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: So when they're not in the house with you? ; Patient: Yeah, it's like they're in the other room or something. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: And can you hear what they're actually saying? ; Patient: Yeah, they're talking about me. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: They're always talking about me. ; Patient: They're always commenting on everything that I'm doing. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: Can you give me an example of what they would say? ; Patient: Well, like if I'm packing me back to go to uni or something, they'll comment on that, like you've left the house now. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: Anything else? ; Therapist: Do they ever talk to each other, perhaps, about you? ; Patient: Yeah, that's what they do. ; Patient: I mean, and now they know the sort of twig that I know about them now. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: They're saying like I'm making trouble. ; Therapist: OK. ; Patient: And that they're going to sort me out. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: What about actually talking directly to you in the way that I'm talking to you now? ; Therapist: Does that ever happen, Andy? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: So you've been hearing the voices of your housemates. ; Therapist: Have there been any other changes? ; Therapist: Have there been any changes, perhaps, to the way you're thinking? ; Therapist: Sometimes people tell us that they're thinking changes in some way. ; Therapist: So, for example, they might feel that they're getting thoughts put into their head that aren't their own. ; Therapist: Have you had any experiences like that? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I do think things that aren't me. ; Therapist: OK. ; Patient: Like they're putting stuff in my brain. ; Patient: It's not me. ; Patient: I'm not thinking. ; Therapist: So different thoughts in your brain. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: It's stupid stuff as well. ; Patient: It's like the other day I suddenly just started thinking about some woman in Carnation Street. ; Patient: I don't watch any of that crap. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: It's not your kind of thing normally. ; Patient: They're not my thoughts. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: And do you have any idea how that's happening? ; Therapist: Or who's responsible? ; Patient: It's MI5. ; Patient: It's this chip they're putting in my head. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: OK. ; Patient: And I can feel it all the time. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: So you're getting thoughts put into your brain that aren't your own. ; Therapist: What about a different sort of experience? ; Therapist: What about the experience that somehow other people are able to know what you're thinking even though you haven't actually told them? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Nothing like that? ; Patient: They're just putting stuff in my head. ; Therapist: Just putting stuff. ; Therapist: And can I just check Andy as well that you're not getting the experience when your thoughts just stop altogether like you have no thoughts left? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: If anything, there's too much in there. ; Patient: I wish I could unplug it. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: OK. ; Patient: Just get this thing out of my head. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: And you mentioned this chip or this device in your brain. ; Therapist: Do you want to tell me a bit more about that? ; Patient: Well, it's a tracking device so they know where I am at all times and I can feel it moving around, like rotating around. ; Therapist: So you can feel the physical sensation in your brain? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: That must be very difficult for you. ; Patient: I don't know why they're doing this to me. ; Patient: I've done nothing wrong. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: Can I just check? ; Therapist: Are there any problems, Andy, with the rest of your body? ; Therapist: Any changes in sensation or any bits that feel different in any way? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: I feel fine. ; Patient: I'm not ill or anything. ; Patient: I just want this thing out of my head. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: It sounds like a very difficult time for you. ; Therapist: Can I ask you, Andy, how are you coping with all this? ; Therapist: How is it affecting you? ; Patient: Well, I know we're leaving my room much and I sort of have to wait until they go out to go down and get some food. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: But they've been doing stuff to my food now. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: What do you think is happening to your food? ; Patient: The poison in it. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: Are you actually eating much at the moment? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: Now, with all this happening, and this sounds like you don't feel very safe, have I got that right? ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: Have you felt the need, I don't know, to take steps to protect yourself in any way? ; Patient: Well, I've got a knife. ; Therapist: OK. ; Patient: And I've got like a baseball bat. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: It's just in case they get in my room. ; Patient: I just don't want to hurt anyone. ; Patient: I just feel like I've got to protect myself. ; Patient: It's like cornering me to do this. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: Have you felt the need to use either the knife or the baseball bat so far? ; Therapist: I'll take it out with you for protection. ; Patient: No. ; Patient: No, I don't want to get caught. ; Therapist: OK. ; Patient: No. ; Patient: It's just in my room. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: Has it ever got so bad, Andy, that you've felt the need to hurt yourself or even kill yourself as the only way out, the only way of coping with this? ; Patient: Well, I thought about getting some pills, but I couldn't leave the house, so I didn't get anything. ; Therapist: And when you say getting some pills, would that be to take an overdose of tablets? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: But you've not actually done anything about that so far. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: In the past, have you ever had any problems either with your temper or getting into fights, being aggressive, either with your housemates or anybody else? ; Patient: No, I'm not that kind of person. ; Patient: I don't want to hurt anybody. ; Patient: They're just driving me to this. ; Therapist: And can I just check again? ; Therapist: You've not been in trouble with the police or anything like that? ; Patient: No, never. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: With all this that's going on, is there anywhere at the moment, Andy, that you feel safe? ; Patient: My parents' house. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: And have you seen much of your parents recently? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I thought about going back there, but I don't want to drag them into this. ; Patient: I don't want them or if I've known about them. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: And throughout this last couple of months, when you've had all these worries, have you ever worried that your parents might in some way be involved in this? ; Patient: I thought about it, but no. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: Can I just check out a couple of background things with you, Andy? ; Therapist: You're general health. ; Therapist: Is that OK? ; Therapist: You generally fit and well? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I'm not ill. ; Patient: There's nothing wrong with me. ; Patient: It's just this thing in my head. ; Therapist: And you're not on any regular medication from your own doctor at this stage? ; Patient: No, I don't take any pills. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: What about other drugs? ; Therapist: And by that I'm meaning alcohol, cannabis, pills, anything else? ; Patient: I don't drink much alcohol. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: And what about drugs like cannabis? ; Patient: Is my mum going to know about this? ; Therapist: No, I think it's something that's important that I hear about, but this wouldn't be something we'd be discussing with your mum. ; Patient: I smoke a bit of weed. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: Would that be regularly for most days? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And how much would you be spending on weed? ; Patient: I get like a ten bag, it lasts me a day or so. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: So you have a ten bag lasting you a day of weed. ; Therapist: Any other drugs? ; Therapist: I'm thinking in particular things like speed or pills. ; Patient: I've done a bit of speed. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: Is that on a regular basis, Andy? ; Patient: I was grabbing my mates for the weekend, we'd do a bit, but... ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: When was the last time, Andy, that you would have had any speed? ; Patient: About a week or so ago. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: Any other drugs at all? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: No. ; Patient: No. ; Patient: But I know what you're getting at, though. ; Patient: It's not the drugs. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: This is... It doesn't matter how out my face I get, this is constantly there, it's always there. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: I guess the reason I was checking, I think is what you've picked up on, is that sometimes when people are having the kinds of experiences that you are, they find if they take certain drugs it can make things feel a lot worse. ; Therapist: I just wanted to check if that hadn't been your experience. ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: I appreciate from what you're saying that you're really very worried about this MI5 conspiracy and that that's the cause of the difficulties that you're having at the moment. ; Therapist: I just wanted to check with you. ; Therapist: Do you think it could be due to anything else? ; Therapist: I mean, I've obviously met other people who've had similar experiences and sometimes they're extremely stressed, some people might be actually mentally unwell. ; Therapist: And just whether any of these things might be relevant to you at the moment? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: Because I'm not ill. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: It's them and I've read books on this as well. ; Patient: I don't... The government know about them. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: They know that they do this to loads of people. ; Patient: I don't know how they can get away with it. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: OK. ; Patient: I've done nothing wrong. ; Patient: I don't know why they're doing this to me. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: I just want it... I just want it to stop. ; Therapist: OK. ; Therapist: Sure. ; Therapist: And I think I can appreciate that. ; Therapist: I guess what I'm wondering is whether you think there's anything that someone like me might be able to do to help you as a doctor, that sometimes meeting with someone like a psychiatrist or having medication or for some people even coming into hospital for a short time might be helpful. ; Therapist: Do you think any of those things would help you at the moment? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: I mean, I'm only here really because I'm a warm-up. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: I've tried to... I don't want to worry her. ; Patient: I've tried to talk to her about it and she doesn't understand. ; Patient: She doesn't really believe me. ; Patient: I mean... ; Patient: Do you believe me? ; Therapist: Well, I certainly believe that you're having a really difficult time at the moment. ; Therapist: I guess what I'm not as sure about is what's causing this and I'm less sure this is due to MI5. ; Therapist: I guess what I'm wondering is that perhaps you're not as well as you might be at the moment. ; Therapist: I mean, we've been through a lot of questions and what I'm thinking is we need to try and come up with a way of supporting you through this. ; Therapist: So I'm wondering, because I know your mum is... I think she's waiting in the waiting room. ; Therapist: It might be a good chance now to get your mum in and then perhaps the three of us can put our heads together, have a bit of a discussion about where to go from here and try and think of getting you some proper support. ; Therapist: Would that be alright if I got your mum in? ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: If you want to sit there then, Andy, I'll just get your mum. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Okay.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name amy; sex female; marital status unmarried ; Clinical Identifiers: Setting opd ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Name denis ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Consistent worry about child  work ; History: Present history patient was in a romantic relationship with a man with whom she got pregnant after a few months of dating. She has been facing difficulty in her relationship as he has not been consistently active in their relationship. There was a recent incident where her partner felt insecure and got physically violent with her on impulse which scared both of them; personal history occupation- patient used to work earlier but left due to pregnancy. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: General behavior patient was cooperative and rapport was established; thought content- reflected disappointment in her partner. ; Psychotherapy Type: Type person centered therapy; mode individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Reflective listening, empathy, ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patient expressed her need to get a job and start working again to manage finances for herself as well as her baby. She was in a dilemma of being a good mother and leaving the child behind to work. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Nil ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: Next session will include discussion around safety of the patient and her child as well as plan more about her steps to get and manage with a new job.

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Sharon, how are you doing today? ; Patient: Well, I'm alright. ; Patient: My counselor, you know, my counselor sent me over because she's a little worried about me that I might hurt myself. ; Therapist: She's a little worried about you? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: What does she think is going to happen? ; Patient: I mean, I don't know, I guess she thinks that, I guess the things that I'm thinking are dangerous. ; Therapist: You mind if I do an assessment to measure your risk of harm? ; Patient: That's fine. ; Therapist: Okay, alright. ; Therapist: Sharon, how old are you? ; Patient: 28 ; Therapist: Now, think about your family for a moment. ; Therapist: Is there any history of suicide or any type of suicidal behavior in your family? ; Patient: Yeah, my dad committed suicide. ; Therapist: Your father committed suicide? ; Therapist: Any other? ; Patient: I mean, I think that my sister has had an attempt. ; Therapist: Attempt? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: How long ago did your father commit suicide? ; Patient: Like 15 years ago, I think. ; Therapist: 15 years ago? ; Patient: Yeah, something like that. ; Therapist: How many think about that? ; Patient: I try not to think about it. ; Patient: I don't know. ; Therapist: That must be hard though. ; Patient: Yeah, I mean, yeah, it's hard. ; Therapist: Is that on your mind now? ; Patient: No, that we're talking about it, yes. ; Therapist: Is that on your mind before we talk about it? ; Patient: Not really, no, not really. ; Therapist: Are there any mental health disorders that you're aware of in your family or that you suspect in your family? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: I mean, I don't know. ; Therapist: You're not aware of any? ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Can you tell me about any disorders you've been diagnosed with? ; Patient: Well right now I think that I've been diagnosed with depression and in the past I've had some problems with anxiety. ; Therapist: And how about now? ; Patient: How about now, am I having problems with anxiety? ; Patient: Not as bad as in the past. ; Therapist: And how about depression? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Right now? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And how bad?
