; Patient: Pretty bad. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: On a scale of one to ten, with ten being the worst it's ever been, how depressed are you ; Patient: now? ; Patient: Probably like an eight or a nine. ; Therapist: Eight or a nine. ; Therapist: That's depressed. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: How about anxiety at the same scale? ; Patient: Probably like a four or a five. ; Therapist: Four or five. ; Therapist: So not quite as bad anxiety? ; Patient: Not as bad as it's been, but it's getting up there. ; Therapist: It's getting worse lately? ; Patient: Yeah, I think it'll be, yeah. ; Patient: It's been worse lately. ; Therapist: So if you were to think back, say a couple days ago, how bad was the anxiety and depression? ; Patient: Anxiety, probably like a three or a four. ; Patient: Depression about an eight or a nine. ; Patient: Still, same. ; Therapist: Same intensity? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: Do you have any medical illnesses? ; Patient: Um, no. ; Therapist: None? ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Do you live alone? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: You do? ; Therapist: How often do you see your relatives? ; Patient: Probably see my relatives like every, like maybe once a month maybe. ; Therapist: How about friends? ; Patient: Friends, it depends. ; Patient: Not as much lately. ; Patient: Um, I used to be better friends with my coworkers and I lost my job so I haven't seen them as much and so probably maybe like once a week maybe. ; Therapist: Once a week? ; Patient: Depends on the week. ; Therapist: How long ago did you lose your child? ; Patient: About, uh, two months ago. ; Therapist: Two months ago? ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Therapist: I'm sorry to hear that happen to you. ; Therapist: How would you characterize the strength of your social network? ; Therapist: Like is it as strong as you want it to be? ; Patient: No, sometimes I feel pretty alone. ; Therapist: Do you? ; Patient: Yeah, I feel like, you know, nobody really wants me around, nobody really needs me, so yeah, I feel pretty alone a lot of the time. ; Patient: Sometimes even when I'm with other people. ; Therapist: So you're with people and you still feel isolated? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: When you are with people and you're not feeling isolated, how would you characterize the quality of the relationships you have? ; Therapist: Let's start with your family. ; Therapist: How good do you think those relationships are? ; Patient: Um, I mean, they're okay, like not really that great, but everybody has like trouble with their family I guess, so I don't know. ; Therapist: You think it was more or less normal? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah? ; Therapist: How about with your friends? ; Patient: It's okay. ; Patient: You know, I guess I'm always like second guessing everything, like do they really like me? ; Patient: Do they really want to spend time with me? ; Patient: I know I'm bothering them, that kind of thing, but I mean it's not, for the most part, I mean I think they care about me. ; Patient: It's a pretty, you know, we have a good time I think when we're together for the most part, but. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: For the most part, positive? ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: Do you have any conflict or crisis going on right now? ; Therapist: You mentioned the loss of your job. ; Patient: Yeah, um, I'm going to be evicted from my house or, you know, my apartment because I can't pay my bills because I lost my job, so I really don't know what I'm going to do or where I'm going to go. ; Patient: I just don't know what to do. ; Patient: I'm feeling really lost and like helpless and like everything's just pointless. ; Therapist: I'm sorry to hear that. ; Therapist: When are you going to be evicted? ; Patient: Um, well I'm not quite sure. ; Patient: Um, it sounds like it's going to be at the end of the month. ; Therapist: So at the end of the month you're going to be evicted from the house or apartment? ; Patient: It's an apartment. ; Patient: Apartment. ; Therapist: And when did you find this out? ; Patient: Um, well, you know, before I lost my job I had had some trouble paying the rent as it was, so, um, you know, the last time I missed my rent was probably like a month and a half ago. ; Patient: My landlord kind of told me that I couldn't live there anymore but I didn't know, you know, how much stock to put in that and now at the beginning of the month he said, you know, you have to, you're going to have to get out of here. ; Therapist: You're going to be evicted. ; Patient: We're going to change the locks. ; Therapist: Alright, so it's all fairly recent. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I guess that's why I'm having more anxiety than before because like it feels really out of control and I don't know what is going to happen, like when he's going to do it, you know, for sure and how, you know, what I'm going to do, so. ; Therapist: There's a lot of uncertainty around when it's going to happen and then what's going to happen to you. ; Patient: Exactly. ; Therapist: Have you in the past thought about suicide? ; Patient: Yeah, yeah, definitely. ; Therapist: Can you tell me about how many times or about how often? ; Patient: Probably like every time I get depressed like this I, you know, have those thoughts so I ; Patient: don't know. ; Therapist: I mean, how often. ; Patient: That's a really hard question. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: Have you ever attempted to commit suicide? ; Patient: Yeah, one time, probably like four years ago. ; Therapist: What did you do? ; Patient: I cut my wrists but it wasn't, you know, nothing really happened. ; Patient: Like I just put a, I just wrapped them up. ; Patient: It wasn't really that bad. ; Therapist: You didn't go to the hospital or anything? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Have you ever thought about committing suicide and were about to attempt and stopped? ; Patient: Yeah, yeah. ; Therapist: Like when you make a plan? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: How many times has that happened? ; Patient: Um, maybe like three or four. ; Patient: It's hard to remember because sometimes it's a long time ago but more recently, like maybe once or twice at least. ; Therapist: So once or twice in the recent past? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Have you ever injured yourself intentionally? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Can you tell me about that? ; Patient: Well, there was that time that I tried to commit suicide and then there have been times before that where I like, you know, kind of like tested the waters, like, you know, just cut myself a little bit to see what it would be like and that kind of thing. ; Therapist: When's the last time you've done that? ; Patient: Um, it would be the last time I tried to commit suicide, like that time I was telling you about it because it really freaked me out. ; Patient: So I don't think I would try that again. ; Therapist: You don't think you'd try that again? ; Patient: Not like cutting myself. ; Therapist: Not cutting, okay. ; Therapist: Have you ever been abused physically, sexually, emotionally? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Therapist: You don't know? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: I guess like I had a really hard childhood with my mom and everything and that's part of the reason why being evicted is so scary because I really don't want to move back in with her. ; Patient: You know, we got in a lot of fights and it was just a really bad environment and I really, really, really, really don't want to go live with her. ; Therapist: So if you get evicted, you're worried you'd have to live with your mother? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And you guys had a rough time in the past? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: You don't want to repeat that? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: I don't want to live like that. ; Therapist: What is your attitude towards suicide? ; Therapist: What are your feelings about suicide as a concept in general? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: I mean I guess it's really sad like nobody wants that, you know, whenever you hear somebody committed suicide everybody's really sad about it but sometimes it just feels like what else is there, you know? ; Patient: Like I don't know how I can go on like this. ; Patient: Like things just keep getting worse and worse and I don't know what to do. ; Patient: So I mean I'm sure like it's not a great thing but at the same time I don't know. ; Therapist: You disapprove of it but you're considering it because you're running out of options. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Have you ever been impulsive in the past? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: Like I guess not really because there have been times when I've like thought about committing suicide and getting really close and still haven't done it, you know? ; Patient: I have but in other areas other than suicide. ; Therapist: Are you generally impulsive? ; Patient: I don't think so. ; Therapist: Ever violent or aggressive? ; Patient: Not really, no. ; Therapist: Have you ever experienced what we call hallucinations which would be like hearing things other people can't hear or seeing things other people can't see? ; Patient: I don't think so. ; Therapist: You don't think so? ; Patient: No, I mean it's hard to tell what other people can't hear when no one's around to tell you whether they can hear it or not but I don't think that I have. ; Therapist: You're fairly certain you have it? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Can you tell me about any alcohol or drug use? ; Patient: Sometimes I drink, you know, alone when I'm in my house because like I said I don't see a lot of other people. ; Patient: I don't really do any drugs. ; Therapist: When's the last time you had a drink? ; Patient: Last night. ; Therapist: How much did you have? ; Patient: Probably like a bottle of wine. ; Therapist: A bottle of wine? ; Therapist: Is that typical for you? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: It is? ; Patient: It is? ; Therapist: How often would you say you drink a bottle of wine? ; Patient: Maybe like three or four times a week. ; Therapist: Three or four times a week? ; Therapist: So I want to ask you about the suicidal thoughts that you're having now. ; Therapist: How frequently are you having the thoughts? ; Patient: Like really often. ; Therapist: Yeah, kind of like all the time? ; Patient: Pretty much, yeah. ; Therapist: How intense would you say the thoughts are? ; Patient: Fairly intense, like it's scary the thought of it, you know, but at the same time like I'm having them so much it's, I don't know. ; Therapist: It's frightening for you? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Do you have a plan laid out if you try to commit suicide? ; Patient: I guess I would just drink a bottle of wine like I usually do and then maybe take some pills. ; Therapist: What kind of pills? ; Patient: There's like ibuprofen in my medicine cabinet. ; Patient: That's like the only thing I have in there other than vitamins so I guess I just take that. ; Patient: I don't know how many but a lot I guess, I don't know. ; Therapist: So you drink a bottle of wine and take a lot of ibuprofen? ; Therapist: Do you have an intent to commit suicide? ; Therapist: Are you going to follow through? ; Patient: I don't know, like sometimes I think about it, I get really close to doing it but I, you know, I haven't like taken any pills so I guess yeah, like I think about it a lot and I've gotten close to doing it so yeah I guess yeah, I guess so. ; Therapist: So you feel like you have an intent? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Can you tell me about some of the reasons for staying alive for not committing suicide? ; Patient: Well I don't really want to die. ; Patient: I guess my family would be really upset and probably my friends too. ; Patient: I don't know. ; Therapist: Do you have any religious or cultural values surrounding suicide? ; Patient: Not really. ; Patient: Not really. ; Therapist: Do you have any pets at home? ; Patient: I have a cat, yeah. ; Therapist: What would happen to your cat? ; Patient: I'd give her to my sister. ; Patient: She already has a couple cats so you know I've already asked her if anything were to happen to me, you know just in general if she would take the cat. ; Therapist: When did you ask for that? ; Patient: Um, probably like two months ago. ; Therapist: So not related to what's going on now? ; Patient: No, I guess not. ; Patient: I mean I don't know, I just asked her in general if anything happened to me so. ; Therapist: Do you have any other reasons for living? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: I mean I lost my job, I live alone, I don't know. ; Patient: Like I'm going to have to move out and I don't even know where I'm going to go. ; Therapist: That's scary for you. ; Therapist: And anxiety-provoking. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: What did you do when you worked? ; Patient: I just, you mean like what kind of job did I do? ; Patient: Oh, okay. ; Patient: I worked at a gas station. ; Therapist: Did you like to work? ; Patient: I liked it, you know we had some regular customers and kind of get to know them. ; Patient: It's a little, I don't know, just you know, my coworkers they were nice and you know we had not like great benefits but there was a lot of work. ; Patient: There was some stuff, you know you could get like a couple vacation days and stuff so. ; Therapist: Do you ever look forward to getting another job? ; Patient: I just don't see how I would. ; Therapist: Why's that? ; Patient: I mean I lost this job, so why would I be good enough to get another job? ; Therapist: What caused you to lose this job? ; Patient: I, I, I went to work drunk. ; Therapist: Can you tell me about some of your strengths? ; Therapist: What are some of your positive qualities? ; Therapist: Can't think of any? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Therapist: What would, what would your family say your strengths are? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: Um, screaming and yelling? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Therapist: Your strengths are screaming and yelling? ; Patient: Yeah, I don't know. ; Patient: I mean I don't know. ; Patient: I don't know. ; Therapist: It's hard for you to think positively right now, isn't it? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Alright Sharon, here's what we're going to do. ; Therapist: I'm going to, well I appreciate you allowing me to complete this assessment. ; Therapist: I'm going to bring you back over to your counselor and we're going to put together a plan to keep you safe right now. ; Therapist: Alright, so I'm going to take care of this for a minute. ; Therapist: Is that okay? ; Patient: Mm hm. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: Thank you. ; Patient: Thanks.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name sharon; age 28 years; marital status unmarried ; Clinical Identifiers: Setting outpatient ; Referral Information : Referred from a counsellor; reason for referral risk assessment ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Nil ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Depressed mood 2. Ideas of unworthiness 3. Ideas and acts of self harm and suicide 4. Feelings of loneliness 5. Worries about future misfortunes ; History: Present history patient lost his job around 2 months ago which keeps him under stress. He is unable to manage his expenses to the point that his apartment may get seized; past history he was earlier diagnosed with depression and had experienced anxiety; family history patient shares a strained relation with his mother; personal history occupation- he used to work at a gas station earlier; substance use history he consumes alcohol 3 to 4 times a week. ; Crisis Markers: Suicidal ideations active he has initiated the attempts once or twice recently. He also has. A rough plan for it; suicide attempt patient tried committing suicide 4 years ago by cutting his wrist; family history patients father had committed suicide 15 years ago, his sister attempted to commit suicide. ; Current Mental Status Examination: General behavior rapport could be established and patient was cooperative. Mood dysphoric; affect restricted; thought content- ideas of hopelessness and worthlessness, judgement personal judgement was impaired. ; Psychotherapy Type: Humanistic approach ; Psychotherapy Technique : Active listening, empathy ; Assessments: Risk assessment for suicidal tendencies ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patients intent and plan about suicide were tapped upon. He had been feeling extremely low and hopeless about losing his job and his alcohol intake has also increased. ; Reflections by the therapist: Patient was able to trust the therapist and rapport was established. It was observed that patient disapproves the idea of suicide but also felt as if it were the only option left for him. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Provisional diagnosis depressive episode ; Action Plan : There will be discussion with the referrer counselor to formulate a plan to keep the patient safe. ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Jason, how are you doing today? ; Therapist: I'm okay. ; Patient: I'm alright. ; Therapist: You're alright? ; Patient: I'm just here. ; Therapist: You're just here? ; Patient: Just here. ; Therapist: I understand that you were in the hospital a couple of weeks ago. ; Patient: Yeah, I was in the hospital about two weeks ago. ; Patient: I did something and I had to go to the hospital afterwards. ; Therapist: You tell me about it? ; Patient: Yeah, so about two weeks ago I was finishing up this wonderful machine that I was creating in my room so that the government can't hear my thoughts or my actions or my behaviors and I was just trying to finish up my last little bit that I needed to build. ; Patient: I went over to the neighbor because their garage was open and I just picked out a tool and I brought it back to the house and when I was in the house working on my room, the cops came and picked me up and took me to the hospital and I was just like, see, the government's at it again. ; Therapist: What do you think the government's trying to do? ; Patient: They're trying to stop me from actually creating my room because they're creating this new order where they want everybody to follow them and I'm not a follower. ; Patient: I know what I want and I know what I need and I know what my family wants and I know what they need and I'm just trying to protect them by creating my room. ; Therapist: And tell me about your room. ; Therapist: What are you doing there that makes that special? ; Patient: So I'm smart enough to know that there are frequencies and waves that are out there that the government is actually sending through the lights and also through the TV and through every electronic apparatus that is out there and I'm actually creating a doll or a wave neutralizer so that it can actually stop that from happening so that you can actually live the life that you want and be happy and youthful and joyful all the time. ; Therapist: Is that how you were feeling when you were building it? ; Patient: Yeah, because I created this prototype in my room and any time I'm basically in there, it was good. ; Patient: I had energy. ; Patient: I did everything that I wanted but my prototype was running out of fuel and so I needed to make it bigger and larger so it can run longer. ; Therapist: That's what you're trying to do when you... ; Patient: Yeah, that's what I was trying to do when I wasn't borrowed the tools from my neighbor. ; Patient: And then also I was ordering some things that were online and they were also supposed to be shipped in so that the base piece that I was creating that I used the tools from my neighbor's house, it could have been all perfect and set so that when all of the hard drives and the electrical wiring and all of that stuff came in, I could just plug it in and then not only have my room covered but also my house is covered and then all of my family, they could just be happy. ; Therapist: They could be happy? ; Patient: They could be happy. ; Therapist: Like you were happy. ; Patient: Like I was happy. ; Patient: So two weeks ago, I was good. ; Patient: I was up. ; Patient: I did all the calculations that I needed to create so I could actually build my base and my system but then I also did the calculations about the different types of waves being in the house but then also out of the house. ; Patient: Then I also had the opportunity to just not sleep because who needs sleep? ; Patient: I wasn't tired. ; Patient: If I did sleep, I slept for like 15 minutes just because I needed to finish what I was going to do. ; Patient: I was so close to finishing and my neighbor called the cops. ; Therapist: So you had a period of time. ; Therapist: We had like a lot of energy and you weren't really sleeping much? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Did you need to... ; Patient: Doesn't everybody do that? ; Therapist: You were also happy and felt satisfied? ; Patient: I felt good. ; Patient: Like when I sleep, I don't like when I sleep because it just feels wrong. ; Patient: I'm not actually using my time wisely. ; Patient: So those last two weeks or two weeks ago, it was perfect. ; Patient: It was the best time of my life. ; Patient: Like I was living the same living life to your fullest. ; Patient: I was living life to my fullest then. ; Patient: It was perfect. ; Therapist: How do you feel now in comparison? ; Patient: I'm all right. ; Therapist: You're all right? ; Patient: I'm all right. ; Patient: Just all right right now. ; Patient: The government made me go on different medication. ; Patient: So just all right. ; Patient: Not that happy. ; Patient: Not that excited. ; Therapist: So not happy? ; Therapist: How about sad? ; Patient: No, I'm not sad either. ; Patient: It's just... ; Therapist: Kind of in the middle? ; Patient: In the middle. ; Therapist: Do you want to get back to that happiness? ; Patient: Of course. ; Patient: Who doesn't want to get back to the happiness of their life? ; Patient: That's the reason why I need to finish my machine. ; Therapist: The machine? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Now you mentioned you'd ordered some products online. ; Therapist: How much did you order? ; Patient: I think I ordered probably... ; Patient: No, the exact number. ; Patient: I ordered 236 hard drives because 236 is the perfect number that I needed to not only cover my bedroom so I could always be happy. ; Patient: And if the system went down, my room was always going to be covered. ; Patient: But then within that 236, it also covered my house so that my family could be happy. ; Patient: And my four neighbors were around us so we could all be happy. ; Patient: And that's the reason why I'm kind of angry at my one neighbor because I was including his house in on my grid so that he can also be happy all the time. ; Therapist: He would have been affected by your machine? ; Patient: Of course. ; Patient: He's the one that needs me. ; Patient: He helped me out. ; Patient: He let me borrow his tools. ; Patient: But evidently, he didn't let me borrow them this time. ; Patient: So I'm going to just pull him out. ; Patient: I'll have another neighbor take his place. ; Therapist: Were all those hard drives fairly expensive? ; Patient: I don't know. ; Patient: When I was up cleaning and running around the house trying to find more equipment, I found my mom's purse. ; Patient: And I was just like, oh my god, she has a credit card in there. ; Patient: Oh my god, I can use her credit card. ; Patient: So I was using her credit card because I was trying to make her happy. ; Patient: And so I don't know. ; Patient: I was at 236. ; Patient: They were probably $50 to $100 apiece, depending on where I could get them. ; Patient: And I just ordered them. ; Therapist: How did your mother respond to that? ; Patient: Well, my mom came to the hospital. ; Patient: I was just like, where are all these boxes coming from? ; Patient: I'm just like, just put them in my room with them. ; Patient: And she put them in my room. ; Patient: And then a week ago, she was just like, I see you use my credit card. ; Patient: She wasn't too happy with me. ; Therapist: Is that a strange relationship? ; Patient: No, that's just how my mom's relationship generally is. ; Therapist: You get along OK with it? ; Patient: We get along perfectly fine. ; Patient: That's how we talk to each other. ; Patient: We talk to each other literally because she's not in my room, so she's not happy. ; Patient: So any time she does come into my room, Beth is on the balance. ; Patient: So I get unhappy. ; Patient: And then I just tell her to stay out so that I can be happy and she can be happy in her own place. ; Therapist: And you mentioned that they changed your medications in the hospital. ; Patient: The government changed my medications. ; Therapist: The government? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: How are you feeling about taking your medications? ; Patient: Well, so the only reason I'm taking my medications now is because if I don't take them, then they're going to change them again. ; Patient: And then it's going to delay me in finishing my generator, my wave generator. ; Patient: And I need to finish my wave generator. ; Patient: So I'm taking them because I don't want the government to have more power over me, like they want to have power over everybody else. ; Patient: So I'm trying to avoid that. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So you really want to get back to working on that machine? ; Patient: Yes. ; Patient: I want to be back in my happy place. ; Therapist: Have you found yourself as motivated these last couple weeks as you were before you were hospitalized? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: I haven't been that motivated. ; Patient: I know I'm going to get it done. ; Patient: It's just I just don't know if I'm going to get it done today or tomorrow. ; Patient: But I know it's going to get done. ; Therapist: You still want to get that done. ; Therapist: It's important to you? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: It's really important to me because I ; Patient: can't be controlled by the government anymore. ; Therapist: All right, Jason. ; Therapist: I'd like you to continue seeing a counselor here. ; Therapist: Have you found the counseling to be helpful? ; Patient: The counseling has been OK. ; Therapist: It's been OK? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: I appreciate that they haven't been taking notes because I don't want that information to be leaked out. ; Patient: But it's been OK. ; Therapist: It's been OK? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: We'll continue with counseling. ; Therapist: And I hope that can help you a bit. ; Therapist: And I appreciate you spending this time with me and explaining what happened. ; Patient: Thank you.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name jason; sex male ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Suspicion on government 2. Decreased sleep ; History: Present history patient believes that the government has been trying to know his thoughts and actions through frequencies and waves entering his house via television. To protect himself and his family from it, he tried building a machine, a wave neutraliser. He had placed an online order of 236 hard drives to cover his room. They were expensive and he got the money from his mothers credit card. He was about to finish this work and required a tool that he brought from his neighbours garage. He was also covering his neighbours house on the grid thinking it would protect him too. As soon as he came back home, police reached his place and admitted him in the hospital. He had not been sleeping at all as he felt it was a waste of time and was more focussed on building the machine. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behavior patient was cordial and rapport could be established; thought content- preoccupation with suspicion on government and building th machine to protect him from them. ; Psychotherapy Type: Nil ; Psychotherapy Technique : Nil ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patients suspicion on government was discussed as he was trying to build a machine to cover his room and save himself from the government. He was later on brought to the hospital by the police and was admitted was a week. He believed that he medications were changed by the government. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: F22. 0 delusional disorder ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: Hi there, Ms. ; Therapist: Stone. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Hi, I'm BJ Daniels. ; Therapist: Sorry, let me wash my hands. ; Patient: Just call me Dorothy. ; Therapist: Oh, thank you. ; Therapist: That's the next thing I was going to ask you. ; Therapist: So Dorothy, the nurse mentioned to me that you wanted to talk about your care. ; Therapist: But what's going on? ; Patient: Five days ago, I was admitted to emergency, and they treated me by putting this tube down my throat. ; Patient: And I tried to tell them and gesture to them that I don't want this tube down my throat. ; Patient: And I just hope that never happens again. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: No, I totally understand that. ; Therapist: I mean, that is quite a scary thing to go through. ; Therapist: And I think we do need to talk about this more, and I'm glad that you've asked to talk to me about this. ; Therapist: So I had a little bit of a look through your chart, so I think I understand why they did it. ; Therapist: But did anybody explain it to you? ; Patient: Well, not really, because I was gasping for air in the state I was. ; Patient: But I'll tell you what, I'm really worried that this won't happen to me again. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: I don't want that tube anymore. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: I'm okay to pass as I am. ; Therapist: Absolutely. ; Therapist: And you know what? ; Therapist: There's no right answer when it comes to deciding on things that are aggressive like the tube. ; Therapist: We really want to know what the patient values in terms of things that are that invasive. ; Therapist: And so absolutely we'll respect whatever it is that you want. ; Therapist: But I do need to find out a little bit more about you in terms of what is your understanding of what brought you into hospital? ; Patient: Well, I have congestive heart failure. ; Patient: And I guess there was water in my lungs and stopping me from breathing properly. ; Patient: So I was living in my, so the ambulance brought me in to the emergency. ; Patient: So that was how they were treating me. ; Therapist: So you pretty much showed up to emergency and very quickly they put that tube down. ; Patient: That's correct. ; Therapist: Did anybody ask you if you were okay with that? ; Patient: Well, I tried to gesture to them that I don't want the tube, but... ; Therapist: They didn't quite pick up on that. ; Patient: I guess not. ; Patient: And you know, I've had that three times already and I don't want to go through that again. ; Therapist: The tube you've had down three times? ; Patient: Yes, yes. ; Therapist: Oh wow, okay. ; Patient: Yes, I don't want it anymore. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And so you have congestive heart failure and it sounds like you've had a breathing problem. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: And do you know why they would have put the tube down? ; Therapist: Do you know what they were trying to do? ; Patient: I guess because I was short of air. ; Patient: I had a hard time breathing. ; Patient: So they tried to, I'm going to use the word save me. ; Therapist: So it sounds like you understand that. ; Therapist: I mean, usually we only put a tube in if that was the only thing we could do to save you. ; Therapist: Most of the time a congestive heart failure will give some medications. ; Therapist: Have you heard of Lasix or furosemide? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: It's a medication we'll often give if someone is in heart failure. ; Therapist: But if someone is really sick and then we don't think we have time to give it, that's the time we would think of a breathing tube. ; Therapist: I haven't had chance to look through the chart, but it would suggest to me you were pretty close to dying when you came in. ; Patient: I guess so. ; Patient: But I'm okay with dying. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: You know, like I said, I've lived a good life. ; Patient: And if the good Lord says that it's my time, I'm okay with that. ; Patient: And you wouldn't put a tube down my throat. ; Therapist: No. ; Therapist: Already what I'm hearing from you, I'm just going to say exactly what you said. ; Therapist: It sounds like you've lived a good life. ; Therapist: You've been through this a few times. ; Therapist: You know exactly what it involves. ; Therapist: And if I could paraphrase to you, quality of life is more important than quantity at this stage. ; Therapist: Is that correct? ; Patient: That is correct. ; Patient: But you know what, Doctor? ; Patient: How can I be assured that my wishes are respected so I don't get this tube down? ; Therapist: That's an excellent question. ; Therapist: So first I did want to answer your previous question. ; Therapist: Based on what we're talking about, absolutely I agree with you that it is your wish and we will respect that wish, that we're not going to put a breathing tube down again. ; Therapist: And then of course your second question, which is great as well, is how do we make sure this doesn't happen? ; Patient: Absolutely, yeah. ; Therapist: So what I'm going to do after our conversation, and I do have a few more questions to ask you, but after our conversation I write a note documenting what we talked about, that we talked about the breathing tube and your reasons for why you don't want it, which of course makes sense to me. ; Therapist: And then what I do is I document a short form called Goals of Care. ; Therapist: And I, just so it's a really easy way for everyone to look at the form and in two seconds they know exactly what you want. ; Therapist: We will give you a copy of that to take home. ; Therapist: But I find that's not usually enough. ; Therapist: What we also do, what I do, is I tend to, when you leave hospital, dictate a note to your family doctor. ; Therapist: And that note's actually available online for anyone who might see you in any emergency department in Alberta. ; Therapist: And in that note it will very clearly state you and I had this conversation and you really didn't want the breathing tube. ; Therapist: So I'll reassure you, we'll do everything we can to make sure people understand you don't want that tube, okay? ; Patient: Oh, thank you. ; Patient: I was so concerned about that. ; Patient: And yes. ; Patient: I think I will rest now because, like I say, that was a horrendous experience and you said it won't happen again. ; Therapist: I do want to ask you just a few other questions related to this. ; Patient: Go ahead. ; Therapist: And the first question might sound a little off-putting, but I sort of have to ask it. ; Therapist: Anytime someone is changing the kind of therapy they want, we do have to ask, how is your mood? ; Therapist: How are you feeling? ; Patient: I'm feeling fine. ; Patient: My mood is fine. ; Patient: I have no problems. ; Therapist: Okay, excellent. ; Therapist: And how are you feeling overall about life before you came into hospital? ; Therapist: Like when you're healthy, as healthy as you can be, say a few weeks ago. ; Patient: I think I am enjoying life. ; Patient: Yes, I am enjoying life to the best I can. ; Therapist: Okay, great. ; Therapist: And then other related questions. ; Therapist: We did talk about the tube that we wouldn't put it in, but again, we want to make sure we know everything that you might want or not want. ; Therapist: So if we had to give you medications to get your breathing better, is that something you'd be willing to have? ; Patient: Certainly. ; Patient: Yes, I'll look at medication, just not the intubation. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And then usually along the lines with the intubation, when people don't want the intubation, we often also want to know if a nurse were to walk into the room and find just by bad luck, you had passed away, or if someone just found you at home, you had passed away, would you ever want people pushing on your chest and giving you shocks, trying to bring you back to life? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No. ; Patient: Like I said, the good Lord knows when it's my time. ; Therapist: No, and that all makes sense to me with the no breathing tube. ; Patient: Yes, and I have no problems with that. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: There are some other things we can do that's not a breathing tube, but they're a little aggressive. ; Therapist: And one is, have you ever heard of BiPAP? ; Patient: I don't think so. ; Therapist: It's a mask that really pushes air into you. ; Therapist: It's a little uncomfortable, but nothing as bad as a breathing tube. ; Therapist: It may be hard to answer this question because you don't know what that is, but do you have any thoughts on that? ; Therapist: If you were really sick, if we were to try just a mask, and we would do it just as long as you were okay with it and comfortable at the time. ; Patient: Would it be for a long time? ; Therapist: Not usually. ; Therapist: Most times with BiPAP, it's only about two to six hours for most patients. ; Patient: Yeah, that would be okay with me. ; Therapist: Okay, and if we had to put large IVs and lines into your wrist and stuff and take you to the intensive care unit, again, we wouldn't do breathing tube, but this is just to watch you closely? ; Patient: Yeah, I would be okay with that. ; Patient: Yes, yes. ; Patient: It doesn't sound invasive to me. ; Therapist: Alright, so let me just summarize. ; Therapist: I mean, it sounds like before you came into hospital, you know, life was pretty good. ; Therapist: I mean, it sounds like you've had some rough times with the heart failure. ; Therapist: We're very clear we do not want to put the breathing tube down. ; Patient: Absolutely. ; Therapist: But we're okay with medicines, we're okay with a mask, we wouldn't restart your heart. ; Therapist: I think that's pretty much everything I think I needed to hear, but is there anything else that you wanted to cover or talk about that I've missed? ; Patient: No, I just needed to be reassured that it won't happen again. ; Patient: And yeah, I know that on my chart, it's there. ; Therapist: Yes, yes. ; Patient: And that's all I need to hear because I was concerned. ; Therapist: Okay, I do want to say that this is not set in stone in the sense that if you ever change your mind, we can have the conversation again. ; Therapist: But if we don't hear from you, this is what we'll go with. ; Therapist: No breathing tube, no restarting the heart. ; Therapist: I just want you to know that in case anything were to change. ; Patient: Okay, so if I change my mind, I can, I will talk to you. ; Therapist: Absolutely. ; Patient: I don't think I'll change my mind. ; Therapist: I don't think you will either, but it's just nice to, so that you're aware of that. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Honestly, I mean, there's some other questions I tend to ask people when I don't know them well, just kind of routine stuff. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And maybe we'll just quickly go through it. ; Patient: Go ahead. ; Therapist: Your medical history is the heart failure, anything else? ; Patient: That's it. ; Patient: I'm beginning with an S, but I can't remember what it is. ; Therapist: Okay, that's okay. ; Therapist: We can, usually we have it written down. ; Therapist: Your medications, I think I saw, you're on aspirin and digoxin, I think two others. ; Therapist: Do you happen to know or have them written down? ; Patient: You know what, I always carry this paper with me, because I can't remember the names. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Oh, so you are on the water pill, the furosemide. ; Patient: Oh, okay. ; Therapist: Yes. ; Therapist: And then those high some. ; Patient: Okay, great. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Any allergies? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And I won't ask about anything that runs in your family, given your age. ; Therapist: They told me you're 70, is that correct? ; Patient: That is correct, yes. ; Therapist: And I do have to ask the following questions, completely unrelated to what we're talking about. ; Patient: That's okay. ; Therapist: Do you smoke at all? ; Patient: No, I don't. ; Therapist: Do you drink any alcohol? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And this will sound crazy, but I have to ask, any street drugs, illegal drugs, anything like that? ; Patient: No, I never had the opportunity. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And I don't want to ask. ; Therapist: Any over-the-counter herbals in addition to these? ; Patient: No, I don't take any of those. ; Therapist: And where are you living right now? ; Patient: I'm living in a convalescent home for the last six months. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: I used to live in my own home, and six months ago I moved to a convalescent home. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And how do you feel about that, with that change six months ago? ; Patient: I would really prefer my own home. ; Patient: But just trouble with my breathing sometimes. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: So are you feeling better about being in that place now, their new home? ; Patient: It's okay. ; Patient: I really have to adjust. ; Patient: Like I say, if I had my druthers, I'd go back, but I guess I have to learn to adjust to this. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So I think I sort of have all the information I need to make sure that your wishes are respected. ; Therapist: Just one last time, anything else that you want to talk about today? ; Patient: Oh, you answered my question. ; Patient: I was so worried about this tube. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Well, it was very nice to meet you, Mr. Tillman. ; Patient: Thank you. ; Therapist: See you.
summary: Patient Particulars : Dorothy; 70yrs; female; living at a convalescent home for past 6 months; known case of congestive heart failure ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Admitted to emergency 5 days back; referred by a nurse to the therapist; reason for referral preoccupation with worries about getting intubated in future ; Therapist Information : Name pj daniels; settingopd ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Apprehension about getting intubated in future na ; History: The patient is a known case of congestive heart failure and was apparently maintaining well till 5 days back when she started having difficulty in breathing. She was rushed to the emergency where the doctors intubated her in order to save her life. The patient was made aware of the procedure following which she gestured to convey that she does not consent. Despite that she was intubated. She reports that it was a horrifying experience for her. Following discharge she has had constant thoughts that if a similar situation arises again, she would have to go through the same traumatic experience again. When she shared this with an acquaintance who happens to be a nurse in the same hospital, she referred the patient to the therapist. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Affect euthymic; speech rate, tone, volume and productivity are normal, thought content preoccupation about getting intubated, judgement intact ; Psychotherapy Type: Supportive psychotherapy ; Psychotherapy Technique : Psychoeducation, reassurance, reflective listening ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patiens right to refuse invasive treatment to save her life ; Reflections by the therapist: It was difficult to build a rapport with the patient. She kept on seeking reassurance that her decisions would be respected and taken care of. In the end the patient trusted the therapist and got convinced ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: How are you doing today? ; Patient: I guess I'm okay. ; Patient: How are you? ; Therapist: I'm well, thanks for asking. ; Therapist: So you say you're doing okay? ; Therapist: What's going on? ; Patient: Um, just definitely no better than last week when we talked. ; Patient: I mean, it's been, I had some major binges this week and I don't even honestly know why we're bothering to talk about it because I've been down this road before. ; Patient: I should just give up and buy some moo moos and you know, just resign myself to the fact that I'm going to get fat and I'm going to stay fat. ; Therapist: Tell me about some of the foods that you've been eating that have been kind of leading ; Patient: to this problem for you. ; Patient: Brownies. ; Patient: Mm-hmm. ; Patient: Brownies, brownies, brownies. ; Patient: And well, that's what got it started. ; Patient: You know, I was great the first half of the week and I was staying away from the sugar, away from the flour. ; Patient: My son just stayed home from school. ; Patient: You know, he hurt his head. ; Patient: He wanted to bake brownies. ; Patient: So I'm like, well, it's my son. ; Patient: Okay, let's bake brownies. ; Patient: So then we ate the whole pan and we baked two more pans and then it didn't just stay the brownies. ; Patient: So we went out and I had hamburgers, french fries, candy, you know, stopped in, voila, on the way back. ; Patient: Oh, it's disgusting. ; Patient: I don't want to tell you how much because it's disgusting and my clothes aren't fitting. ; Patient: It's just really, really sad. ; Therapist: You've had a rough week. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So let's talk about for a second, I'd like to, kind of your relationship to this problem. ; Therapist: How do you view this problem? ; Patient: It's disgusting. ; Patient: It's like, it's slavery. ; Patient: Food owns me. ; Therapist: So the food is in control of the situation. ; Patient: Sounds ridiculous when you say it like that, but that's what it is. ; Therapist: It's in control. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So I want to ask you a couple of questions about the importance and the confidence of changing. ; Therapist: Clearly, you have some desire to change or you wouldn't be here. ; Patient: Oh my God, I would love to, yeah. ; Therapist: So if you're looking at a scale of one to ten, one was, it's not important to change. ; Therapist: Ten was, it's extremely important to change. ; Therapist: This is just how important it is for you to curtail your eating. ; Patient: Ten. ; Therapist: Ten. ; Therapist: So very important to you. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: It's very important. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So what if I ask the same question except this time you're confident. ; Therapist: So one is you're not confident all you can change, but ten, you're very confident you could change. ; Patient: I could probably change for half a day. ; Patient: I've done it. ; Patient: Sometimes if I'm lucky, I'll get a week, but overall? ; Patient: Overall. ; Patient: It's impossible. ; Patient: Like, you want a number? ; Patient: It's zero. ; Therapist: So it's below the scale of one to ten. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: So you have no confidence at all. ; Patient: I've tried it. ; Patient: I know. ; Patient: I mean, it's like beating my head against a wall. ; Therapist: So on one hand, you'd like to stop the eating. ; Therapist: It's important to you. ; Therapist: But on the other hand, you don't believe you can do it. ; Patient: I can't do it. ; Therapist: You can't do it. ; Patient: I can't. ; Patient: It can't be done. ; Therapist: Have there been any other changes you have been able to make, say, in the last few years that have been positive? ; Patient: I stopped biting my nails. ; Therapist: So you've had some small successes in terms of making changes. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: What do you think makes this, well, I'll just refer to it as the food problem, so much more powerful, so much more difficult to tackle? ; Patient: I wish I knew. ; Patient: I mean, there's so many things. ; Patient: It's everywhere. ; Therapist: The food is everywhere? ; Patient: Food is everywhere. ; Therapist: And, I mean. ; Therapist: You mentioned before that brownies were the culprit for this last week. ; Patient: Brownies, Hershey bars, Hershey kisses, yeah, chocolate. ; Therapist: You enjoy chocolate. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: How about other foods that could be contributing to the problem that maybe you don't enjoy as much as chocolate? ; Patient: Oh, potato chips, french fries, Mexican food, what else? ; Patient: Cheese, definitely. ; Therapist: Any other types of candies? ; Therapist: Start naming them. ; Patient: Skittles, Cherry Starburst, basically any candy. ; Therapist: Pretty much any candy. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So, of the candies, so I want to focus just on the candies. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: And not the other foods just for now. ; Therapist: The thought of, like if I introduced the idea of stopping eating chocolate, how would you react to that? ; Patient: Not going to happen. ; Therapist: That's not going to happen. ; Therapist: All right. ; Patient: I would love for it to happen. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: But that's not going to happen. ; Patient: I can just tell you. ; Patient: I don't even want to pretend. ; Therapist: So you know that for certain. ; Therapist: How about the, let's go for example with the Skittles. ; Therapist: What if I introduced the idea of stopping the consumption of Skittles? ; Patient: Just the candy Skittles? ; Therapist: Just that one candy, yeah. ; Patient: Why, bother? ; Patient: That, like can I not eat Skittles? ; Patient: Is that what you're saying? ; Therapist: Well, you could, it's up to you whether you eat them or not. ; Therapist: But if I introduced that idea of stopping the consumption of Skittles, how would you react to that? ; Patient: I don't really understand why. ; Therapist: Well, it represents a change in the direction that you want to move. ; Patient: But if I stop eating Skittles, I'm still going to eat brownies. ; Patient: I'm still going to eat, you know. ; Therapist: But we know that's an area that you can't really make a change right now from what you're saying. ; Therapist: That's the idea of stopping chocolate is not going over well with you. ; Patient: No, it's not going to happen. ; Therapist: And that's fine. ; Therapist: But the idea of stopping Skittles. ; Patient: That's fine. ; Therapist: That doesn't seem as daunting. ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: Would you agree still on say the one to ten scale that it's important to stop Skittles? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: I mean, I think that's a change that you could not eat them. ; Patient: Well, it's kind of funny now that you're talking about it. ; Patient: I sort of want Skittles more. ; Patient: But, you know, like from now until next week when I come in here, I'd say like I'm 99% confident I could not eat Skittles and it would not be a major problem. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So this is a change that you think you could accomplish. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Even though you're not sure it will actually contribute to solving the larger problem, we know that that's something that, that's an area where you don't really see a change as likely. ; Patient: Like this continued chocolate. ; Patient: If I don't eat Skittles this week or even for the rest of my life, is it going to solve my problem? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: But will I do it if that's what you want me to do? ; Patient: Yeah, that's fine. ; Therapist: Well, I would hope it's something that, that you would want to do. ; Therapist: I mean, what I want is one thing. ; Therapist: What you want is really important here. ; Therapist: Is this something that, I mean, are Skittles part of the problem? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Small. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Therapist: Right? ; Therapist: No pun intended, right? ; Therapist: Even though they're small. ; Therapist: But it's a small part of the problem, but you would agree it's still part of the problem? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Sure. ; Therapist: Not a huge change, but it's one that we can work on. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: I mean, I want you to be able to, you know, genuinely buy into the goal. ; Therapist: I mean, if you don't think it's important, we can talk about other areas of change. ; Patient: No, I guess I see what you're saying. ; Patient: I mean, if I'm going to be completely honest with you, I, ; Patient: I think it's going to work. ; Patient: Well, that's what I'm paying you for, right? ; Patient: So, I don't think it's going to work. ; Patient: I'll just tell you that. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: You think you could stop eating Skittles, but you don't think it's going to solve the larger problem or lead to? ; Patient: Exactly. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: But that's what we have to work with right now, because the larger problem is not something, you know, I mean, the way you put it is it has control. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: Right? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So, if I introduced the idea of stopping brownies. ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: No. ; Therapist: No. ; Therapist: Sorry. ; Therapist: So, let's, let's go after the change that we can achieve in this case. ; Therapist: You know, it's not perfect, it's not ideal, but it's what you can do. ; Patient: Fair enough. ; Therapist: Sound, sound like a plan? ; Therapist: So, so for this week, I'll see you again in a week. ; Therapist: For this week, just, just continue eating Skittles. ; Patient: No Skittles. ; Patient: All right. ; Therapist: No Skittles. ; Therapist: And let's see, let's see how we do with that change. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Fair enough. ; Therapist: Does that seem to make sense? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So, we'll work with that and I'll see you again in a week. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: Thanks again. ; Therapist: Thank you.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name ann; sex female; marital status married ; Clinical Identifiers: Setting opd ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Follow up session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Excessive eating 2. Feeling out of control over eating behavior 3. Eating large amounts of food 4. Feeling guilty and upset after eating ; History: Present history patient has been consuming more amount of food than required. It has been happening from quite some time. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Speech productivity- increased; mood frustrated; affect restricted; thought content- reflected frustration due to her eating behavior; judgement personal judgement was impaired; insight grade 4. ; Psychotherapy Type: Behavioral therapy ; Psychotherapy Technique : Shaping, scaling questions ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Patient discussed about her static progress of eating behavior. She had been consuming a lot fried and sugary eatables and found it hard to control which led to her feeling guilty about it. Patient was frustrated which made her less receptive to the treatment technique. Task has been divided into small steps for now so she can achieve the expected goals till next week. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Nil ; Action Plan : Patient has been told to abstain from eating skittles till next session. ; Next session details: After 1 week.

dialogue: Therapist: Come in. ; Therapist: Mrs. Olsen. ; Patient: Hello Doctor. ; Therapist: Hello I'm Doctor O'Connor. ; Therapist: Would you like to take a seat? ; Patient: Yes thank you. ; Therapist: How are you today? ; Patient: Oh Doctor I've not been feeling very well at all. ; Patient: Feeling really tired and run down and I've been having this breathlessness you know and I've really been worried about it. ; Therapist: You came in to see one of my colleagues about that recently didn't you? ; Patient: I did yes. ; Therapist: And she sent you for a blood test. ; Patient: That's right Doctor. ; Therapist: We think you might be anaemic. ; Patient: Oh gosh yes. ; Therapist: So what I want to do today was firstly to give you your blood test results and then talk to you a little bit about the condition of anaemia and then talk about some potential treatments. ; Patient: Oh right Doctor yes. ; Therapist: Does that ; Therapist: sound ok with you? ; Patient: That sounds fine yes Doctor. ; Therapist: Great so shall we have a look at your blood test results? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Here it is. ; Therapist: So what we're testing for is the level of haemoglobin in your blood. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: And just to show you the normal range for women is between 11.5 and 16 grams per deciliter of haemoglobin. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: And this is your level of haemoglobin it's 8.7. ; Patient: Oh that's low isn't it? ; Therapist: It's a bit lower than we would like. ; Therapist: Oh dear yes. ; Therapist: So what we'll be looking to do is to get that back within the normal range. ; Therapist: Right ok. ; Therapist: Just to reassure you iron deficiency anaemia which I think you've got is fairly common up to around 15% of women can experience this type of anaemia. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: And it's very treatable as well. ; Therapist: Yes ; Patient: yeah yeah. ; Patient: Oh yes I mean this tiredness that's just getting me down Doctor. ; Therapist: It must be it must be because you've got quite a busy lifestyle haven't you? ; Patient: I have yes yeah and I just feel as though I can't cope much longer with it. ; Therapist: Ok. ; Therapist: Shall I tell you a bit more about anaemia? ; Therapist: Do you know anything about the condition? ; Patient: I don't know I mean I've heard of it but I don't know what it is. ; Therapist: Well it's a condition related to your blood. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: And within your blood there's several components one of which is plasma. ; Therapist: Within the plasma you have your red blood cells. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: And within that you have a protein called haemoglobin which carries the oxygen around your body to all the different organs. ; Therapist: Ok. ; Therapist: Now if that's not working efficiently you start to experience the kind of symptoms that you've been having like breathlessness, tiredness. ; Patient: Yeah definitely. ; Therapist: Yes. ; Therapist: One of the causes can be blood loss so I wondered about your periods how are they? ; Patient: Well they've been heavy these last few months really heavy yeah. ; Patient: I've put it down to my age you know they start getting irregular and heavy and but you might ; Therapist: be right there yes. ; Therapist: That may be a factor. ; Therapist: Yeah yeah. ; Therapist: So I want to talk to you about treatments now. ; Therapist: Yes. ; Therapist: There are a couple of things that I would suggest that you try. ; Therapist: The first thing we'd like you to do is to increase the amount of iron in your diet. ; Therapist: Can you tell me a bit about this sort of diet you have at the moment? ; Patient: Well I mean I'm really busy and I think they have a reasonable you know a well-balanced diet. ; Patient: We eat a lot of ready meals and then on a weekend we always have a good breakfast it was cooked bacon butters. ; Therapist: No so ; Patient: I think it's quite quite a good diet. ; Therapist: Right with your teenage children they keep you busy. ; Patient: Oh they do yes I mean you know it's like having a taxi service you what with that and and then at work you know so busy at work it's just just so tired. ; Patient: Mmm just keep feeling tired it must be hard for ; Therapist: you to do all those things. ; Therapist: Yes yeah it's difficult though it just feels like I can't cope anymore. ; Therapist: Yeah now you mentioned ready meals I can understand you relying on those for convenience but the problem is sometimes you don't get the proper balance of nutrients. ; Therapist: All right doctor. ; Therapist: So what I'd ask you to do is perhaps to adapt your diet slightly and include more iron rich foods in your diet. ; Therapist: Oh right okay. ; Therapist: Before I tell you about what some of those foods are can I ask if you're a vegetarian? ; Patient: No no. ; Therapist: You're not. ; Therapist: The reason I ask that is because one of the best sources of iron in your diet is lean red meat. ; Therapist: Oh yes yeah yeah like steak. ; Therapist: Yeah exactly. ; Patient: Also liver is a good source. ; Patient: Oh no no no no no no couldn't eat liver. ; Therapist: What about something like steak that you mentioned would you consider eating that a bit more regularly? ; Patient: Well yes I mean steak wouldn't take long to cook would it at all? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: You could give that a go. ; Therapist: Good good. ; Therapist: There's also leafy green vegetables things like kale and spinach are good sources of iron. ; Patient: Oh the kids wouldn't eat that. ; Patient: But I mean they like sweet corn so they can have the sweet corn couldn't they with the green vegetables. ; Patient: I could go for the leafy the green vegetables. ; Therapist: Do you think you could give that a try? ; Patient: Broccoli. ; Patient: So it's broccoli. ; Patient: Yes broccoli. ; Patient: Yeah I like broccoli. ; Therapist: Oh good good. ; Patient: I'll have a go with that. ; Therapist: There's other things too you might want to consider things like fortified cereals which have iron. ; Patient: Oh right what are those? ; Therapist: Well if you look on the ingredients panel of cereals you'll see some are enriched with iron so you could perhaps incorporate some of those. ; Patient: Oh yes yes I'll have a look at the supermarket. ; Patient: If I got some of those we could have that at weekend and that give me more time I wouldn't have to cook would I? ; Therapist: It could make your life a bit easier. ; Therapist: Yeah definitely. ; Therapist: That would be a help wouldn't it? ; Therapist: It would yes. ; Therapist: Wholemeal bread is a good source of iron as well. ; Patient: Oh yes you know they only like white bread only them they buy white bread but I could buy myself some brown bread cobs and have it for lunch. ; Therapist: Yes yeah. ; Therapist: Oh good. ; Therapist: So do you think you could give some of those things a try? ; Patient: Yes I would try doctor definitely. ; Therapist: Great great. ; Therapist: The other thing I'd like you to consider is taking a course of iron tablets. ; Therapist: Oh I'm not into tablets why? ; Therapist: Okay this can be a really effective treatment for iron deficiency anemia and what it does is it supplements the amount of iron you're getting in your diet. ; Patient: So would that be short term? ; Therapist: Yes yes often people respond very well to those you can have some side effects. ; Patient: Oh dear. ; Therapist: Sometimes they can upset your tummy if you have them on you know on an empty stomach so what you do is you take them after a meal. ; Patient: Oh right yeah I do remember to do that yes yeah. ; Therapist: I think those two things adapting your diet and taking a course of iron tablets I think you might respond very well to those treatments. ; Therapist: Yes yeah I'll have a go at that doctor. ; Therapist: How do you feel about the information I've given you so far? ; Patient: That's fine yes I'll definitely try if it makes me feel any better it's worth it. ; Therapist: Yes excellent yeah excellent. ; Therapist: I've given you quite a lot of information about anemia today I've got a leaflet here about anemia which I thought you might like to take home and read in your own time. ; Patient: Oh thank you yes yeah oh yes yeah I'll read this doctor it's it's sometimes difficult to remember what what you tell so yes having a look at this at home would be really helpful. ; Patient: That's right yes that's right so just ; Therapist: to check that I've explained things to you correctly do you think you could just recap on the the two treatments that you're going to try? ; Patient: Well you said that the anemia is due to a lack of iron and I can get this from having some red meat I mean steak lunchops would that be? ; Patient: Yeah trim the fat off. ; Patient: Yeah and green vegetables and wholemeal bread and if I have these iron tablets and you know hopefully I'll feel better. ; Therapist: Thank you yes excellent so what I'd like you to do is come back in a couple of weeks and then we can see how you're doing. ; Patient: I'll do that yes. ; Therapist: Have you got any questions? ; Therapist: Are there any other tests I'll have to have? ; Therapist: I think at this stage when you come back to see me again we'll do another blood test and check on your hemoglobin level then if you haven't if it hasn't gone back into the normal range it might be then that we'd look at doing some other investigations but I don't want to worry about that at this stage I think let's see how you do with the dietary change in the iron tablet so we can discuss that next time. ; Therapist: Right thank you. ; Therapist: Yes is there anything else? ; Therapist: No I think that's it thank you. ; Therapist: Okay well good to see you and I'll see you again in a few weeks. ; Therapist: Okay thank you. ; Therapist: Bye. ; Patient: Bye.
summary: Patient Particulars : Sex female; marital status married ; Clinical Identifiers: Setting opd; diagnosis iron deficiency anemia ; Referral Information : Referred by another doctor, a colleague of the psychologist ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Breathlessnessna; 2. Dizzinessna; 3. Tirednessna ; History: The patient started having breathless, dizziness and tiredness due to which she is not able to perform her duties at home and at work. She has been having heavy menstrual flow. With these she visited another doctor who ordered blood investigations where her hb came out to be low i. E 8. 7 ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Nil ; Psychotherapy Type: Type supportive; mode individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Psychoeducation ; Assessments: Hb 8. 7 ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Reason for the presenting complaints and how to correct iron deficiency ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Iron deficiency anemia ; Action Plan : To include foods rich in iron into diet ; Next session details: Next session is scheduled after a few weeks

dialogue: Patient: Come in. ; Therapist: Hi, Ms. ; Therapist: Jones. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: I'm Jane Crohn. ; Therapist: I'm a medical student with the University here. ; Patient: Nice to meet you. ; Therapist: I've been sent in by Dr. Smith as part of our training as a medical student to do an interview with you. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And then I'll take that information back to Dr. Smith and then she will come back in and see you then after that. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: How may I address you? ; Patient: Mrs. Jones is fine. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Patient: Thank you. ; Therapist: Is that okay with you today to talk? ; Patient: Yes, that would be fine. ; Therapist: Thank you. ; Therapist: I'm going to start out today by just talking a little bit with you about your chief complaint. ; Therapist: What brings you here today? ; Patient: Sure. ; Patient: My left elbow has actually been bugging me a lot. ; Patient: Every once in a while I've been getting a little bit of pain, extending my arm and going back to bending it. ; Patient: Really that's the primary reason I've come in. ; Patient: I've attempted to take a little bit of Tylenol to relieve the pain but it's not really seeming to help much. ; Therapist: Before we talk a little bit more about that, is there anything else that you want to talk with either me or Dr. Smith today? ; Patient: Not that I can think of, no. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Tell me more about this pain. ; Patient: It's just kind of a throbbing pain. ; Patient: It'll act up kind of randomly throughout the day. ; Patient: It's not specific to the morning or evening or even in the middle of the day or night. ; Patient: It just kind of randomly acts up. ; Patient: I would say excessively like when I'm doing work, like after the dishes. ; Patient: It'll start to act up. ; Patient: If I lift one of my children up, it'll start to act up. ; Patient: Any sort of exertion is kind of where I've noticed a lot of the pain coming from. ; Therapist: Tell me when did it start for you? ; Patient: I would say maybe a week and a half to two weeks ago. ; Therapist: You describe the pain as throbbing. ; Therapist: Is there anything else about the pain in terms of the quality of the pain that you want to describe for me? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: Just really throbbing. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Patient: It started about a week or two weeks ago. ; Therapist: Do you recall what you were doing at the time that it started? ; Patient: I've been helping my husband clean out the garage lately and we were lifting some boxes. ; Patient: I didn't notice it at the moment but later in the evening it started to act up. ; Therapist: I would like to hear a little bit about the severity of it on a pain scale of 1 to 10. ; Therapist: 10 being the worst pain you've ever had. ; Therapist: 1 or 0 being no pain. ; Therapist: How bad is this pain? ; Patient: I would measure it probably about a 6 or 7. ; Patient: It's become more of a nuisance than an actual physical pain. ; Therapist: And is it a 6 or 7 all the time? ; Patient: Whenever it starts to act up, yes. ; Therapist: And how often a day does that happen? ; Patient: I would say maybe 2 to 3 times per day. ; Therapist: Do you notice any pattern to that at all? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: And can you point exactly to where it is for me, the location of it exactly? ; Patient: It's kind of the area that just wraps around the actual elbow that is really bothering me. ; Therapist: And does that pain go up your arm or down your arm or anywhere else on your arm? ; Patient: No, it stays right in that area. ; Therapist: Is there anything else that goes on at the same time? ; Therapist: Any other symptoms that happen? ; Therapist: Anything else other than when the pain is happening there? ; Therapist: Anything else going on for you? ; Patient: Not that I've noticed, no. ; Therapist: Is there anything that makes it feel better? ; Patient: Nothing that completely gets rid of it. ; Patient: Tylenol will relieve it for a temporary period of time, but it hasn't gotten rid of it. ; Therapist: And how much Tylenol do you take? ; Patient: Whatever it says on the bottle, usually 1 to 2 tablets. ; Therapist: And is that regular strength or extra strength? ; Patient: Regular strength. ; Therapist: And you just take it across the counter, the normal directions on the bottle? ; Patient: Correct. ; Therapist: And does anything make it worse? ; Patient: Like I mentioned, any sort of exertion. ; Patient: Picking up a child, doing the dishes. ; Patient: Pretty much daily living activities. ; Therapist: So using it? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Have you seen anybody else for this complaint? ; Patient: No. ; Therapist: What else have you tried other than the Tylenol and anything else other than Tylenol? ; Patient: I've attempted to use a heating pad on it and I've also attempted ice. ; Patient: Neither were successful. ; Therapist: It sounds you've talked a little bit about how it's impacted you to be able to work in the garage, or do the dishes, or lift your child. ; Therapist: Is there other impact on your life? ; Patient: Like I mentioned, it's more of a nuisance. ; Patient: There will be times in the middle of the night that it will start to act up. ; Patient: If I get up to go to the bathroom, I'll notice pain in my elbow. ; Therapist: Does it wake you at night? ; Patient: It doesn't, but if I wake up in the middle of the night, it will trouble me and fall back asleep. ; Therapist: What do you think it is? ; Patient: I'm not quite sure. ; Patient: My best guess is maybe some sort of pulled muscle or something. ; Patient: But honestly, I don't know. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: What I'd like to do now is just kind of go through all the things that you've told me and summarized for you. ; Therapist: This is information that I want to take back, but I want to make sure that I have it all correct. ; Therapist: So if I've forgotten something or I've gotten something incorrect, please help me. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: You came to the clinic today for a complaint of left elbow pain. ; Therapist: And it's pain that you mostly noticed when you were bending it or using it in some capacity. ; Therapist: It's a throbbing pain that happens randomly, but it does happen two to three times during the day. ; Therapist: What you notice about it is if you exert or you extend or flex your elbow at all, that's when it seems to be at its worst. ; Therapist: It's gone on for about a week, maybe to two weeks when you think back on it. ; Therapist: And it started out when you were helping your husband clean the garage and you were lifting lots of boxes. ; Therapist: It's about a six to seven on a pain scale. ; Therapist: And you describe it over and over as being a nuisance, which tells me that it's getting kind of in the way of doing some things that you want to. ; Therapist: You report that it happens probably two to three times a day and that the pain wraps around the joint completely. ; Therapist: You've taken some Tylenol for it across the counter. ; Therapist: You've taken that several times a day, not without much relief. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: That it hasn't helped much. ; Therapist: You've tried a heating pad. ; Therapist: You've tried some ice. ; Therapist: That hasn't really helped either too much. ; Therapist: It sounds like, again, you kept referring to it as a nuisance, that it's just kind of getting in the way of your daily activities. ; Therapist: It doesn't necessarily keep you up at night, but you do notice it at night when you wake up that it's still going on for you. ; Therapist: So sleep doesn't seem to help much. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: And that what you mostly think this could be is a pulled muscle of some type. ; Therapist: Is there anything I've forgotten or that you wanted to tell me about this? ; Patient: Not that I can think of, no. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Thank you for telling me about your chief concern. ; Therapist: I'm going to take it back to Dr. Smith. ; Patient: Thank you very much.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name jone, sex; female, marital status married, education medical student with the university ; Clinical Identifiers: Clinic ; Referral Information : Sent by dr. Smith ; Therapist Information : Name ms jane crohn. ; Past Session Information: Intake session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptoms left elbow pain ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior nad; speech nad, mood  affect low, thought, judgement and insight intact ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Themes discussed in the session 1 problem patients complaint about left elbow pain that occurs during arm extension and bending which impacts her daily activities like doing dishes, lifting her children, and working in the garage. 2 history  patient tried tylenol regular strength, heating pads, and ice to alleviate the pain, but these measures have provided only temporary or no relief. Also, not seen any other healthcare provider for this issue prior to this visit. 3 advise dr. Smith will be contacted for further evaluation and potential treatment options. ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Elbow pain ; Action Plan : Dr. Smith for further evaluation

dialogue: Therapist: Hello Carl, how you doing today? ; Patient: I'm good, how are you? ; Therapist: I'm doing well, thanks for asking. ; Therapist: Last week you were talking in therapy. ; Patient: Yeah, I mean, and I thought a lot more about it this week after I mentioned it last week, but Jill, I was telling you about Jill, my coworker, and she was kind of bothering me the past couple of weeks, but really this past week was like the worst, right? ; Patient: So she's not doing her paperwork, and the thing is that she has to do these reports in order for me to do my reports. ; Patient: So if she doesn't have hers, I can't do mine, and then I can't get mine out in time for the next person to do theirs, and it's a mess, the whole thing's a mess. ; Patient: And it's annoying me. ; Therapist: So her work slow down, or not being efficient work, is affecting your work productivity. ; Patient: Yeah, yeah, it definitely is. ; Patient: And it's one of those things that like, you know, it gives me a bad evaluation. ; Patient: If I'm not handing my stuff in in time, then it reflects negatively on me, you know, and it's all kind of, she's the first level, you know, and then all the other levels are kind of dependent on her turning things in on time. ; Patient: So if she doesn't, then I don't, then the next person does, and so forth. ; Therapist: And it makes it seem like you're not doing your job. ; Patient: Right, yeah, and my boss doesn't like it, my boss's boss doesn't like it, and so forth, you know? ; Patient: And I try to explain to them, you know, she's the problem, but it doesn't always, I don't always have the time to go up and tell them, like, here's what's happening, or it just somehow doesn't come out. ; Therapist: You don't always get the opportunity to tell people that are important at your work about the situation. ; Patient: Yeah, and that's pretty annoying too, because, you know, it's one thing if people get mad at me, but then I'm able to tell them why I'm not doing my job like I'm supposed to. ; Patient: But it's another thing for them to get mad at me not realizing it's not my fault, you know? ; Therapist: You have an explanation for why the work's not getting done. ; Patient: Yeah, I do, I do, that's the thing. ; Patient: But I can't always get it out, you know, I can't always tell the person that has the complaint about it. ; Patient: And yeah, I mean, I've tried talking to my boss, and I've tried talking to other people too, you know, but it really hasn't gotten anywhere. ; Therapist: So you're feeling stuck with this whole thing. ; Patient: Yeah, yeah I am, and I mean, I talked to Jill a little bit about it too, you know, and I tried to ask, I tried kind of genuinely reminding her, you know, like, such and such needs to be turned in by Tuesday at 12 o'clock. ; Patient: I didn't want to be real abrasive, you know, but I tried to remind her. ; Therapist: It was a polite approach. ; Patient: Yeah, yeah, and it didn't really seem to work because it still happened, you know. ; Therapist: Your attempt to fix the problem hasn't really worked the way you want it. ; Patient: No, no it really hasn't, and that's just, I feel like I've tried everything that I could try, you know? ; Patient: And even like, I came home and I was talking to a friend about it, and I was trying to think of other solutions, right? ; Patient: You know, I was trying to think like, what else I could do, what else I could say, who else I could talk to, things like that, you know? ;
