Patient: And I mean, my friend, you know, he was listening and stuff, and had some good suggestions, but he didn't know what to do either, like, because he doesn't know the way the company works, you know? ; Patient: So like, I got nothing. ; Therapist: You're not getting the help you need for this. ; Patient: Yeah, not at all. ; Patient: I'm feeling pretty lost with it, and I wish it was just like a clear way to do things, like, this is what you should do now. ; Patient: And I don't see anything. ; Therapist: Some sort of clear plan. ; Patient: Yeah, yeah. ; Patient: But yeah, I don't see a way to go about it. ; Patient: I mean, I've, so I've, okay, so this is the way I laid it out in my mind. ; Patient: I tried talking to the people above me. ; Patient: Didn't work out the way I thought it would. ; Patient: I tried talking to the people below me, so to speak, just lower on the, before me in the process. ; Patient: That's what I mean. ; Patient: And that didn't work out, which is just Jill, and I talked to her, and that didn't work. ; Patient: So like, there's nowhere else I could turn. ; Therapist: The options are exhausted. ; Patient: Yeah, that's what it seems like to me. ; Therapist: And this is frustrating for you. ; Patient: Yeah, it is. ; Patient: And I've been trying to rack my brain, you know, like, what else could I do? ; Patient: You know? ; Patient: Like, maybe if I could, maybe if there was like a committee or something that I could go to, you know, I'd be like, well, this person's not doing what they're supposed to be doing. ; Patient: But there's not, there's no committee like that. ; Patient: Or even if there was like a person, you know, like a resolution person or whatever, but there's nobody like that. ; Therapist: There's no other avenue. ; Patient: That's what it seems like to me. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: And that's, I mean, that's, and you know, as I'm even trying to think, like, I don't know, should I write a letter to somebody maybe? ; Patient: But I don't even know who or what. ; Therapist: You thought about a letter, but who would you send it to? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Or like, just something else that I can do instead of going to this person, going to that person, that didn't work. ; Patient: Could I call somebody? ; Patient: Is there anybody else in the company that, you know, might handle stuff like that? ; Patient: But I mean, there's HR people, but that's, I can't really see where they could come in. ; Patient: I don't know how human resources could deal with something like that. ; Therapist: You don't feel them as a potential solution? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: Yeah, no, I don't. ; Patient: I wonder maybe if there's like a, but there's, I mean, I'm thinking now that there's gotta be something or somebody or somewhere that I could put in like, almost like a complaint or something, like something's out of my hands and I don't know what to do about it. ; Patient: Like, there's gotta be something. ; Patient: And now that I'm saying this, I'm thinking that there's gotta be. ; Therapist: Some other resource you haven't tried yet. ; Patient: Yeah, yeah. ; Patient: And I mean, now I'm trying to think back to my training, you know, initially. ; Patient: You know, maybe there's, you know what, I think now that I'm thinking a little bit harder about it, a little bit differently about it, I'm thinking that there's like a, man, I forget what they call it now, but maybe like a complaint. ; Patient: It's not the right word, but maybe a complaint box or like suggestions or something. ; Patient: And I think, if I remember correctly, those suggestions and those complaints get brought up at every staff meeting, which we have like every other week. ; Therapist: They're discussed at this regular meeting. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: And I'm thinking now, I mean, nobody really uses it, but I'm thinking like maybe that's an avenue that I can use, you know, like maybe that'll get brought up and maybe that's something that might actually work. ; Therapist: This could be another option for you. ; Patient: Yeah, yeah, it could be. ; Patient: And then if it does work, it'll get brought, rather if they do read it, it'll get brought up at the staff meeting where everybody's at. ; Patient: My boss, my boss's boss, Jill, everybody's there. ; Patient: And maybe that's a way for it to come to everybody's attention that deadlines being missed affect other people in ways that you don't really know about. ; Therapist: So everyone will hear your complaint and maybe react in a way that would help you. ; Patient: Maybe, yeah. ; Patient: I think that's, I mean, that's gotta be the way to do it. ; Patient: And maybe that's the best way. ; Patient: I really think, yeah, I mean, after saying all that and after going through that, I really think that that's probably the best way to do it. ; Patient: And if it doesn't, then I guess I can find another way, but I really think that's the best way to do it. ; Therapist: You feel as though you've found an option here. ; Patient: Yeah, yeah, I do. ; Patient: And even if that doesn't work, then it'll be brought up and maybe it'll allow me to talk to my boss further about it and maybe they'll understand really where I'm coming from. ; Patient: But this will at least be a start to something, you know, to make me a lot less stressed with deadlines and stuff, you know. ; Therapist: You are frustrated with all this. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: But maybe, maybe after I do that, you know, put in the complaint or suggestion, maybe I won't be as frustrated. ; Patient: I mean, I'm feeling a little bit less frustrated now, even thinking that there is another option, you know. ; Therapist: It feels better now as you're contemplating another potential avenue here. ; Patient: Yeah, yeah, it does. ; Therapist: Well, this might be a good place to wrap this session up. ; Therapist: That feels like the right move for you. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And we'll schedule, so I see you next week and we can pick up from there. ; Patient: Sounds good. ; Patient: All right, cool. ; Therapist: Thanks, Carl. ; Patient: Thank you.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name- carl; sex- male ; Clinical Identifiers: Outpatient ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Follow up ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): 1. Excessive conscientiousness 2. Unreasonable insistence on others to work 3. Preoccupation with deadline and schedule ; History: Patient finds it difficult to work with one of her colleagues. It bothers him to the point that he gets preoccupied with thoughts of not meeting the deadline which will make him look bad. He tried to work on it through several ways like talking to others about it, taking suggestions, complaining about the co-worker but nothing has worked so far. He is preoccupied with further steps he can take to solve this issue. ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: General behavior- rapport established; speech productivity- increased; affect- anxious; thought content- preoccupation with perfection; insight- grade 1 ; Psychotherapy Type: Mode- individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Paraphrasing, problem solving ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: It was discussed that patient was stressed about his colleagues work performance which, according to him, had an impact on him too. He expressed different things he has tried and the support he tried taking from others so far which has not been of much help. Some ways of dealing with it which has not been tried in the past were discussed and patient wanted to try them too. ; Reflections by the therapist: Rapport was established with the patient; he had a preoccupation with perfection in terms of meeting deadlines and schedules and insisted his co-worker to work according to him. Problem solving approach was tapped on which helped in maintaining patients trust as for the current stage he lack insight. ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: After 1 week

dialogue: Therapist: Hi Carly, how are you doing today? ; Patient: I'm good, how about you? ; Therapist: I'm doing well, thanks for asking. ; Therapist: I want to give you a test that assesses your thinking and memory. ; Therapist: Is that okay? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Alright. ; Therapist: So I'll be asking you several questions. ; Therapist: Please just answer it as best as you can. ; Therapist: What is today's date? ; Patient: May 26th. ; Therapist: What is today's year? ; Patient: 2015 ; Therapist: What is the month? ; Patient: May. ; Therapist: What is the day today? ; Patient: Tuesday. ; Therapist: Can you also tell me what season it is? ; Patient: Spring. ; Therapist: Can you tell me the name of the building that we're in? ; Patient: The Graduate Center. ; Therapist: What floor are we on? ; Patient: The first. ; Therapist: What city are we in? ; Patient: Newcastle. ; Therapist: What county are we in? ; Patient: Delaware. ; Therapist: And what state are we in? ; Patient: Delaware. ; Therapist: So I'm going to specifically test your memory. ; Therapist: I'm going to say three objects and I want you to repeat them back to me. ; Therapist: The objects are ball, flag, and tree. ; Therapist: Can you repeat those back to me? ; Patient: Ball, flag, tree. ; Therapist: I want you to begin with the number 100 and count backward by seven. ; Therapist: I'll let you know when to stop. ; Patient: 100 ; Patient: 93 ; Patient: 85 ; Patient: 77 ; Patient: 69 ; Therapist: That's good. ; Therapist: Thank you. ; Therapist: I'd like you to spell the word world backwards. ; Patient: D-R-L-R-O-W. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: Can you recall the three words that had you repeat back to me earlier? ; Patient: Ball, tree, flag. ; Therapist: Okay, thank you. ; Therapist: Can you tell me what this is? ; Patient: Watch. ; Therapist: Can you tell me what this is? ; Patient: Pen. ; Therapist: I'm going to read a phrase to you. ; Therapist: I'd like you to repeat it back to me. ; Therapist: The phrase is, no ifs, ands, or buts. ; Therapist: Can you repeat that back to me? ; Patient: No ifs, ands, or buts. ; Therapist: Are you right or left handed? ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: I'd like you to take this paper in your right hand, fold it in half, and put the paper on the floor. ; Therapist: Okay, thank you. ; Therapist: I'm going to hold a page up that has instructions on it. ; Therapist: I'd like you to do what the instructions say. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Thank you. ; Therapist: You'll find a clipboard next to your chair with a pen and a blank piece of paper. ; Therapist: Can you write a sentence for me? ; Therapist: Okay, thank you. ; Therapist: If you flip that paper over, you're going to see a drawing. ; Therapist: Can you see the drawing? ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Can you copy that drawing? ; Therapist: That's fine. ; Therapist: See that? ; Therapist: Okay, thank you. ; Therapist: That concludes this assessment. ; Therapist: I want to thank you for your help, Cori. ; Patient: Thank you.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name carly ; Clinical Identifiers: Clinic ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Clinic- 1st floor, the graduate centre building, newcastle, delaware ; Past Session Information: Session for assessment of thinking and memory ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Nil ; History: Nil ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: Behaviour patient was cooperative throughout the assessment ; Psychotherapy Type: Nil ; Psychotherapy Technique : Nil ; Assessments: Mini mental state examination mmse ; Issues discussed in Current Session: Nil ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Nil ; Action Plan : Nil ; Next session details: Nil

dialogue: Therapist: How are you doing today? ; Patient: I'm okay. ; Therapist: What's been going on? ; Patient: Well, last time I started to tell you a little bit about one of my friends, my best friend ; Patient: actually, she had this issue. ; Patient: So what happened was she went to a bathroom at our local library and she found a video camera when she was going to the bathroom. ; Therapist: In the bathroom? ; Patient: Yeah, she actually, yeah. ; Patient: And she turned it into the police and I guess because she carried it or she had found it, her handprints were on it and they weren't able to detect who actually did it. ; Patient: They weren't able to catch the person. ; Therapist: Oh, they didn't catch the person? ; Patient: No. ; Patient: So since then I've been on really just high alert. ; Patient: I'm worried that that could happen to me, to my kids. ; Patient: I'm just really worried because they didn't catch the guy that him or someone like him could be out there. ; Therapist: So he's still out in the community. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: So how is it affecting your daily life? ; Therapist: Can you tell me kind of what you've been feeling? ; Patient: A lot of anxiety, just not knowing maybe what if someone were to videotape me like that. ; Patient: I've been very aware, shall I say, of cameras. ; Therapist: Okay, so anxious and aware. ; Patient: Right, like I know you have one in your office and people on their cell phone cameras. ; Therapist: Others? ; Patient: Just all the possibilities that I could be recorded. ; Patient: I've just been very aware of them, which makes me not want to go anywhere. ; Patient: So I've been having arguments with my husband a lot because he wants to go out to restaurants and I don't want to go because there could be cameras in the bathrooms. ; Patient: And how I dress also, as you can see, I'm kind of dressed more conservatively because I remember hearing once about cameras that people use on shoes that could be used in a creepy way. ; Patient: And so I can't, you know, it's now almost summertime, I can't dress in skirts or be comfortable because I'm dressing like that. ; Therapist: Right, so you covered a lot of ground there. ; Therapist: So you have the feeling of being worried, nervous, that it's going to happen to you. ; Therapist: But you've also had to kind of change your routine or you have to change your routine to feel safer. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: Has that helped? ; Therapist: Has changing the way you dress or changing where you go and when you go, has that helped reduce the anxiety? ; Patient: Not really. ; Therapist: No? ; Patient: I would say it's really, that's why I wanted to come in. ; Patient: It's really starting to affect my life. ; Therapist: You mentioned specifically your husband. ; Therapist: Like what's been going on there? ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: He just wants to go places with our kids, like go out to eat and I don't really want to go anywhere because, you know, cameras are everywhere nowadays. ; Therapist: They are? ; Patient: And I just kind of worry like public bathrooms, could they be there? ; Patient: Could someone be, you know, sometimes baby monitors are hooked to phones and people can hack into that. ; Patient: Laptop cameras. ; Patient: So even in my own house, I've just been really nervous. ; Patient: So I feel like I'm not really getting relief from that anxiety. ; Therapist: Have you taken any precautions because of this persistent worry? ; Patient: I mean, I've read... ; Therapist: Other than what you already mentioned. ; Therapist: With the camera specifically, I mean. ; Patient: I've, you know, when I go into bathrooms, I've been looking for cameras to make sure they weren't there before. ; Patient: You know, me and my children have used the bathroom. ; Patient: I have tried, I've read online that you can turn, how to turn off the cameras on your phone and that you can close your laptop and that way the camera will face down. ; Patient: So, and the same thing on a smart TV, so it doesn't recognize your face. ; Patient: I've tried to turn things off that don't need to be on as far as people being able to access my own information. ; Therapist: And that seems reasonable. ; Therapist: So you've taken reasonable precautions to try to avoid being video recorded against ; Therapist: your will. ; Patient: Exactly. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: But still you have this feeling of worry, anxiety and your schedule is being interfered with. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: So you'd like to cope more effectively with your feelings, reduce this anxiety. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: So, when you enter into a public bathroom, and we talked about automatic thoughts before. ; Therapist: Yes. ; Patient: Those thoughts just kind of pop into our head and they connect to feelings that can be unpleasant. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: Like anxiety and worry. ; Therapist: So, when you walk into a public restroom, what's the first thing that goes through your mind? ; Patient: That there might be a video camera that I don't see, that's maybe like with my friend it was big enough, but I might not catch it and that someone's going to use that in a vulnerable way. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So, when you walk in, you're wondering if there's a camera there. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: And when that automatic thought occurs, what follows that in terms of a feeling or a behavior? ; Patient: Usually, I'll try and find the camera, but it's usually anxiety, fear, my heart rate starts going up, I start getting really anxious. ; Patient: And then, you know, I try and either rush to use the bathroom if I really have to go, or a lot of times if I don't, I'll just leave. ; Patient: Sometimes I try and use the bathroom at home so I don't have to go out. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So, your behavior is looking for the camera or sometimes just leaving without using the restroom. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: And your feeling is that anxiety worry that we've been talking about. ; Patient: Yes. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So, really if we think about, we talked before about core beliefs, intermediate beliefs, and I'm wondering if the intermediate belief isn't I'm vulnerable or this, you know, more specifically maybe, and that's more of a core belief, more specifically I'm vulnerable in this area, like with this guy on the loose that, you know, committed that crime. ; Therapist: And then, you know, that's combining with situations that you encounter and that's where you're getting those automatic thoughts. ; Therapist: Does that sort of make sense? ; Patient: Exactly. ; Therapist: Okay. ; Therapist: So, you remember what, in terms of cognitive therapy, you like to apply what we call the adaptive response or self-talk. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: So, it's that thought that you interject at that moment you realize you're having an automatic thought that's going to lead to, in this case, anxiety and worry and behaviors that, well, looking for the camera isn't maybe an unuseful behavior, but leaving, you know, that could certainly be an unuseful behavior. ; Therapist: So, in terms of that self-talk, let's work to develop a self-talk response. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So, there's something you could tell yourself to that initial, you know, I wonder if there's a camera in this bathroom. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: What do you think you could tell yourself that would get in between that thought and the feelings you're having? ; Patient: I could say if when I walk in the bathroom. ; Therapist: Yeah. ; Patient: Maybe I could say, you know, while there could be a chance that there's a camera in this bathroom, the chance of it happening is not very likely. ; Patient: And, you know, I'm going to take steps to keep myself safe so that I won't be in a vulnerable position, such as looking for the cameras. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: That's good. ; Therapist: So, you have a low probability of it happening, and you're taking useful behaviors to minimize your risk even further. ; Therapist: Right. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: So, that's a good automatic thought. ; Therapist: I think, or a good adaptive response for the automatic thought, rather. ; Therapist: Why don't you try that one out, right, the next time you have that automatic thought? ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: Try out that. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And, you know, that's logical. ; Therapist: I mean, it's unlikely to happen. ; Therapist: Of course, there's a chance, right? ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: And we acknowledge that in the self-talk. ; Therapist: There's a chance that it could happen, but there's precautions you can take that's a low chance. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: Sometimes, as well, so keep that automatic thought kind of, you know, we'll review it at the end. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Right, before you leave today. ; Therapist: We'll write these down. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: But that's one adaptive response, rather, that I want to write down for you. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: I also want to talk about, like, the worst case scenario, because right now you have the anxiety and the worry about an event that, while it's unlikely it could happen, it could happen. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: And I'm wondering how you think you would react if the worst did happen, if you used the restroom and you found out from law enforcement or by finding a camera that an offender had been, you know, watching you, right, on a recording. ; Therapist: I think you would react to that. ; Patient: I mean, I think I would be really upset. ; Patient: I think I would feel vulnerable probably for a while and be hesitant. ; Patient: But, I mean, I think ultimately I would be okay. ; Patient: My friend, this happened a while ago, she's starting to get over it and get back to her usual routine, although she's still hesitant. ; Patient: So I think I would be okay eventually, although I'd be really upset that it happened. ; Therapist: And it would make sense to feel upset, right? ; Therapist: That would be upsetting for anybody. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: But, as you noted, that would probably be relatively temporary. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: Distressed, right? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: While acute, and certainly, you know, you wouldn't be happy about it and shouldn't be happy about it. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: It would probably go away. ; Therapist: You'd probably learn to adapt. ; Therapist: How long have you been in this state of anxiety and worry? ; Patient: Probably it happened like two months ago. ; Therapist: Two months. ; Therapist: And how many days in the average week are you affected by these feelings? ; Patient: Usually every day. ; Therapist: Every day. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So if we can compare it, right, we have the chances of being recorded, right, illegally. ; Therapist: That's a low probability event. ; Therapist: It could happen, probably not likely. ; Therapist: The anxiety and the worry that you're having, that's a high probability event because you're suffering from it every day. ; Patient: Yeah, that's true. ; Patient: I never thought about it that way. ; Therapist: So there's a point at which maybe you reach and you say, I'd rather take the risk, I'd rather deal with the potential consequence of an unlikely event of being recorded and face that if it happens than be in the state of anxiety and worry. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: Because right now I'm suffering every day. ; Therapist: Right, now you're suffering, right. ; Patient: Right. ; Therapist: So if you could adaptively respond effectively, you're still going to have that risk of being recorded, but you know you could survive that event if it happened. ; Patient: Right, yeah, I think I could. ; Therapist: And you're taking reasonable cautions and all the things we talked about. ; Therapist: So as you think about this in a more general sense, is there an adaptive response you could apply to that on-the-act thought of I need to be worried about this or whatever that thought looks like. ; Therapist: Sometimes the thought's an image, right, so maybe an image of being recorded. ; Therapist: But whatever that kind of general series of automatic thoughts are that are getting you anxious and worried before you even get out of the house, what adaptive response could you apply there? ; Patient: Maybe, you know, like I said, I'm worried about all the cameras. ; Patient: Maybe I could say, you know, I understand there's some cameras that, you know, are used for good purposes like security. ; Therapist: Probably most are. ; Patient: Right. ; Patient: And the chances of being recorded illegally are not likely. ; Patient: And I'm taking precautions to, you know, go to the right places, the good areas. ; Patient: So it's not likely to happen overall. ; Patient: And me going outside the house is worth the risk, you know, the minimal risk that it would happen. ; Patient: And if it did happen, I could survive. ; Therapist: That's good. ; Therapist: That’s a good adaptive response. ; Therapist: And that's kind of a few adaptive responses. ; Therapist: But that's good. ; Therapist: And you can apply them and we'll kind of break them down. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Like I said before you leave today, we'll break those down. ; Therapist: So you can hammer them down as you go out. ; Therapist: And I think it's important because, you know, automatic thoughts tend to spring on us quickly. ; Therapist: It's important to rehearse these adaptive responses so we're ready to go. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: And kind of, you know, we're being, we're preparing ourselves to apply that adaptive response. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And in order to be prepared, you have to know what it is. ; Therapist: So it's good to have it written down and kind of more or less commit to memory. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Does that kind of make sense? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So before you leave today, I'll take care of that. ; Therapist: And I want you to use those adaptive responses for this week. ; Therapist: I'll see you next week. ; Therapist: And record what the outcome was every time you're able to apply that response. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And that includes what you felt and what you actually did. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Right. ; Therapist: And of course as you mentioned any, you know, physiological reactions like your heart racing or anything like that. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: So that's, really that's a behavior. ; Therapist: But note both physiological behaviors and other behaviors. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: You know, once you're consciously controlling and then any feelings. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And we'll go through them, we'll go through each time you use it, one by one behavior there are. ; Therapist: And kind of see if we need to adjust the adaptive response and see how well it's working. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Does that sound like the plan? ; Patient: Yeah, I think that would be really helpful. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: So we'll go from there and I appreciate you coming in today. ; Patient: Thank you very much. ; Therapist: Thanks, guys. ; Therapist: Bye.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name hazel; sex female; marital status married ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Follow-up session ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting symptom anxiety chief complaint 1 not able to use public washrooms due to the fear of camera 2 daily activities are impacting 3feels unsafe thinking about the possibility of being recorded without consent. ; History: Nil ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior; anxious; speech less affected, mood  affect fearful, thought ruminations, perception anticipatory anxiety; judgement and insight judgment is poor ; Psychotherapy Type: Cbt; mode individual ; Psychotherapy Technique : Thought challenging and cognitive restructuring. ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: There are few issues discussed in the session 1fear patient feels anxious regarding her safety, particularly regarding the possibility of being recorded without consent both public and private spaces. 2problems anxiety is significantly affecting her daily life which includes going out in public, use public restrooms, or any social activities such as dining out with family. This leads to certain actions such as checking for cameras in restrooms and disabling unnecessary features on electronic devices. 3 learning adaptive responses therapist tries to show how to change her autonomic thoughts to adaptive responses related to anxiety which helps her to challenge irrational beliefs and reduce the intensity of anxiety provoking reactions. 4anxiety management therapist showed how to assess the difference between actual risk versus the perceived risk of the situation. He also tried to make her understand that her anxiety can be reduced if she acknowledges and accepts low probability of these events occurring and its negative outcome which she cant control. Through exposure therapy, therapist tried to desensitize her fear and planning to do it next session as well. 5 action plan the therapist advised to keep track of her experiences and reactions while switching to adaptive responses. This monitoring will help in evaluation of progress and modifications in the therapeutic process. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Anxiety ; Action Plan : Therapist asked to note both a physiological behaviors and other behaviors and keep a track of her experiences and reactions when applying adaptive responses. This monitoring allows will help to see progress and adjustments to the therapeutic approach as needed. ; Next session details: Next week

dialogue: Therapist: Hi, how are you doing today? ; Patient: I'm okay. ; Patient: How are you, Dr. Grande? ; Therapist: Not bad. ; Therapist: Thanks for asking. ; Therapist: What's been going on? ; Patient: There's not really a lot of change on the drug front. ; Patient: You know, the Adderall, I'm really struggling. ; Therapist: Still struggling with the Adderall? ; Patient: I'm not sure what to do because I know that, I mean, I'm having such a hard time with it, but when I don't have it, I'm just not functioning. ; Patient: I'm not able to get as much accomplished. ; Therapist: Alright, so, go ahead. ; Patient: Well, it's like it's always there too. ; Therapist: It's always available to you. ; Patient: It's always available, yeah, or so much of the time. ; Therapist: Alright, so you're having some mixed feelings about it though, I'm sensing. ; Patient: Yeah, yeah, like I know I want to stop, I think. ; Therapist: You think you want to stop? ; Patient: Yeah, no, I do. ; Therapist: You do? ; Patient: Oh my God, see, I feel crazy, but I know it would be good if I didn't have it in my life. ; Therapist: But at the same time, it is in your life. ; Patient: And I don't know how to get out of that. ; Patient: I mean, the one thing, if I didn't live with my roommate, that would be one thing. ; Patient: I wouldn't be in the apartment all the time. ; Therapist: So, you find you have easier access to the Adderall when you're in the house or apartment with your roommate? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So, if you physically weren't there, like with your roommate in that apartment? ; Patient: Yeah, like if I was, oh my God, living at home with my parents again, or even living with somebody else, I guess. ; Patient: Oh my God, to move! ; Patient: What a hassle, but that's, I mean, that's the problem. ; Patient: It's just there. ; Patient: It's accessible. ; Therapist: So, you're kind of, it sounds like you're recognizing that maybe you don't have the willpower to stop taking the drug when it's right there in front of you. ; Patient: Maybe you're right. ; Patient: That's good. ; Patient: Because before I didn't really want to stop. ; Patient: And sometimes I want to stop. ; Patient: My mind will go back and forth. ; Patient: But for the most part, I would like to be without it. ; Patient: I really don't want to deal with this anymore. ; Therapist: So, mostly, so there's still some feelings where you want to use it, but mostly you would like to stop. ; Patient: Well, it makes it so easy to get stuff done. ; Patient: I mean, I just take a couple and boom, boom, boom. ; Patient: I mean. ; Therapist: So, there's some advantages for you. ; Patient: Yeah, definitely. ; Patient: Definitely. ; Patient: And I'm so used to it, too. ; Patient: It's just comfortable. ; Therapist: It's comfortable and it allows you to be productive. ; Therapist: Are there any downsides to it? ; Patient: Well, yeah. ; Patient: When I don't have it, the crash, it's like a really bad crash. ; Patient: I'm not productive. ; Patient: You know, it's, and it's gotten worse than it used to be. ; Therapist: So, it's painful. ; Patient: Like, I need it. ; Patient: It's painful. ; Patient: Definitely. ; Patient: Definitely. ; Patient: It feels like a trap. ; Patient: And I want out. ; Therapist: And one of the ideas you were having was, it sounded like potentially, was moving out. ; Therapist: Moving out of the apartment. ; Therapist: Because then you wouldn't have access to the, you wouldn't have access to the Adderall anymore. ; Therapist: Or it would be harder to get. ; Patient: Oh my God. ; Patient: Like, sometimes it's really weird. ; Patient: Sometimes it feels like that's a good idea and then sometimes I'm like, no, no. ; Patient: I don't want to be, you know, kind of cut off from it. ; Patient: But, I think I'm ready. ; Therapist: You think you're ready for that? ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: And that moving out, you really see is what you would need to do. ; Therapist: Because stopping while living there is too difficult. ; Patient: Oh my God. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah, I think you're right. ; Therapist: I remember before you've tried to stop while living there a few times, right? ; Therapist: Or the last few months. ; Therapist: And with your roommate having it, with your roommate being the one that gives it to you, it just appears the temptation is so great for you. ; Patient: Yeah, she really doesn't get it. ; Patient: She doesn't understand, like, what a problem this is for me. ; Patient: She's definitely not supporting me or anything like that. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: God, maybe it would be better. ; Therapist: Well, are there any disadvantages to living with your parents? ; Patient: Living with my parents at my age, it just feels like a little bit humiliating, a lot humiliating. ; Therapist: Okay, so humiliation would be one? ; Patient: Yeah, and just this feeling of failure, embarrassment. ; Patient: And then my mom just is in my business, you know. ; Therapist: So there's some clear disadvantages to moving into parents. ; Therapist: Any advantages other than the obvious, it would sever you from the adderall? ; Patient: My mom would do my laundry, fully stocked fridge. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Patient: Yeah, my dad will fill my gas tank up. ; Therapist: Are these things that happened before when you used to live there? ; Patient: Yeah, yeah, not so bad. ; Therapist: So there's some disadvantages to this plan, but there's some advantages and there's a key advantage of being cut off from the adderall. ; Patient: Yeah, and it wouldn't necessarily have to be the rest of my life either. ; Therapist: Hmm. ; Patient: Just for now, just to get me out of that apartment with the drug, right? ; Therapist: That would separate you from the drug and you could potentially move out later on. ; Patient: Oh my God, do I want to? ; Patient: I mean, that's just it. ; Patient: It sounds really good until I really think about it. ; Therapist: So when you really think about it, what comes to mind? ; Patient: Oh, like I start to shake, like that feeling of, you know, when you really want something, you really want something and you can't get to it. ; Patient: And it's just that desperation that, and like right now, I know that I'm living there, it could be my choice. ; Patient: I could take it or I could not take it, you know, but at least when I want it, it's there. ; Patient: If I move out, I'm like making that decision for myself. ; Therapist: That's right, you would be. ; Patient: I don't know. ; Therapist: Is this tough? ; Therapist: Well, before it seemed like you were really more on the side of making this change than not. ; Therapist: But clearly there's still some things you want to consider. ; Patient: No, you know, you're right though. ; Patient: I want out. ; Patient: And it's not really a choice when I'm there. ; Patient: Like I say I have the choice, yes or no, but the choice is always yes. ; Therapist: You always end up using the Adderall. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So, let me make sure I understand the situation overall. ; Therapist: You live with your roommate, she has Adderall, when she makes it available to you, you use it. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: You've tried to stop that behavior, but that's just not working for you. ; Patient: Yeah, yeah, that's so clear. ; Patient: And I don't want to be using it. ; Therapist: You don't want to be using it, but yet you are, especially because the proximity. ; Therapist: Because you're right there and she has it and it's just tough for you to stop that behavior. ; Therapist: There's another possible decision, which is moving back home, which has some disadvantages and advantages. ; Patient: Yeah, that's true. ; Patient: God, it would be nice having that fully stocked fridge. ; Therapist: So, there's an upside to it that would be beyond just not using the drug, which in itself would be a big victory for you. ; Patient: Yeah, and my mom would be there to talk to, yeah. ; Therapist: So, let's do this. ; Therapist: It seems like that's the direction you're moving, right? ; Patient: Okay, yeah. ; Therapist: No pun intended with the word moving, but you're thinking that might be a better way to go. ; Patient: Yeah. ; Therapist: So, for the next session, let's plan out, and this wouldn't necessarily be doing anything, let's plan out the steps that you'd have to put in place to move back home. ; Therapist: Talking to your parents, whatever financial arrangement you have with your roommate, getting all your stuff out, the logistics of moving, let's just go through the steps. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And try to get a firm plan together. ; Therapist: And of course you can always reevaluate and change your mind. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: Right, but all we're doing at this point is just planning and seeing how it would look. ; Patient: This is kind of exciting. ; Therapist: Is it exciting? ; Patient: Yeah, it definitely is. ; Patient: I can do that. ; Therapist: Good. ; Therapist: So, I will see you next week. ; Patient: Okay. ; Therapist: And we'll pick up right where we left off, and we'll start with the planning, and we'll see what happens with that. ; Patient: Cool. ; Patient: All right. ; Therapist: All right. ; Therapist: Thanks, Anne. ; Patient: Sure.
summary: Patient Particulars : Name jill; sex male; education graduation ; Clinical Identifiers: Nil ; Referral Information : Nil ; Therapist Information : Nil ; Past Session Information: Follow-up ; Presenting Complaints (Symptoms): Presenting complaint anxiety and fear chief complaints 1self criticism 2 fear 3 perfectionism 4 comparison ; History: Nil ; Crisis Markers: Nil ; Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance  behavior anxious; speech normal, mood  affect anxious and sad; thought negative, perception normal, cognitive functions distorted, judgement poor ; Psychotherapy Type: Cbt; mode individual. ; Psychotherapy Technique : Reflective listening, thought challenging and cognitive restructuring. . ; Assessments: Nil ; Issues discussed in Current Session: 1 problems patient has a strong desire to achieve more and has a tendency of perfection in their academic performance which leads to heightened anxiety and fear of failure. 2 thinking pattern patient has a belief that receiving the award validates his hard work which lead him to seek external validation, such as winning the awards which contributes to their anxiety and pressure to perform. 3 self-image he has a feeling of competition and inadequacy and feels threatened by the presence of someone they perceive as a competitor. This tendency leady to self-critical thoughts perfectionism which leads to anxiety. 4 challenging automatic thoughts the therapist encourages the client to challenge their automatic thoughts and cognitive distortions by examining the evidence and considering alternative perspectives. The goal is to promote more realistic and balanced thinking patterns. 5 self-compassion and perspective the client struggles to extend the same level of compassion and understanding to themselves that they would offer to others in similar situations. They need to develop a more compassionate and balanced perspective on their achievements and self-worth. 6 action plan therapist challenged his automatic thoughts and suggests using writing exercises, such as thought records, to identify and challenge their negative thought patterns. Also introduced self-compassion for a balanced perspective in life. ; Reflections by the therapist: Nil ; Clinical Diagnosis by Reviewer: Anxiety ; Action Plan : Writing exercises, such as thought records, to identify and challenge the negative thought patterns. ; Next session details: Scheduled
